headline: White House Moves to End Feud at Information Agency
abstract: The White House has asked the director of the United States Information Agency, Bruce Gelb, to step down and accept the post of Ambassador to Belgium, Administration officials said today.   The move, the officials said, is intended to defuse a bureaucratic feud between Mr. Gelb and the director of the Voice of America, Richard W. Carlson.

headline: Gorbachev Puts Blame for Clash On Lithuanians
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev blamed leaders of the separatist Lithuanian Parliament and their supporters today for bringing on the Soviet military attack that killed 14 people in Vilnius on Sunday morning.    He did not disavow the attack or say that it was unjustified, but said he had found out about it only after it happened, when the local military commander sent in troops to protect a pro-Soviet "National Salvation Committee" that later claimed control of the Baltic republic in place of the elected legislature.

headline: Unocal Settles Suit on Pricing
abstract: The Unocal Corporation has agreed to a $78 million settlement with the State of California and City of Long Beach in a price-fixing lawsuit that goes back 16 years and involves five other oil companies.   The settlement, reached on Wednesday, will drop Unocal from the lawsuit. The suit charged the six oil companies with depressing the price of oil pumped from the tidal lands around Long Beach. The settlement must still be signed by Gov. Pete Wilson and endorsed by state and Federal courts.   In addition to price fixing, the suit contended that Unocal, Chevron, Exxon, Mobil, Shell and Texaco had conspired to monopolize the production and distribution of crude oil on the West Coast. The suit was brought by the City of Long Beach in 1975.

headline: Ticketmaster Deal To Get Ticketron
abstract: The Ticketmaster Corporation said it would acquire Ticketron, its rival computerized ticketing agency. The Los Angeles-based Ticketmaster did not disclose terms of the deal for Ticketron, which is owned by the Carlyle Group, a Washington investment group, and is based in Landover, Md. Both companies are private.    When it was formed eight years ago, Ticketmaster was the upstart that challenged the long-established Ticketron. Now Ticketmaster has become a larger cmpany, dominating sports and pop concert bookings and leaving Ticketron with few strengths except the legitimate theater business. The companies' business overlaps in many cities.

headline: Consumer Debt Plunged 4% in January
abstract: Consumer credit fell at a 4 percent annual rate in January, the Government reported today. It was the steepest plunge in four years as recession and war curbed personal spending.   The Federal Reserve said consumer installment debt dropped a seasonally adjusted $2.44 billion, the biggest percentage decline since it fell 5 percent in February 1987.

headline: Star-Ledger Raises Price
abstract: The Newark Star-Ledger increased the price of its daily paper Monday to 25 cents, from 15 cents. The increase is the first for the state's largest newspaper since 1980, when the price was raised to 15 cents, from 10 cents. The newspaper attributed the increase to sharply rising costs, compounded by reduced advertising revenues. The price of The Sunday Star-Ledger rose to 50 cents, from 35 cents, on Oct. 28.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.75-9   8.75-9   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   6.44   6.54   8.25        3-MO. headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bank of America, San Francisco, named Raymond C. Cherko and Ralph C. Schauss senior vice presidents. * Bombay Co., Fort Worth, a specialty retailer of home furnishings, said Carson R. Thompson would relinquish the title of chief executive but remain chairman. Robert E. M. Nourse, who has been president and chief operating officer, will become chief executive.

headline: Wages of War: A Dearth Of Capital
abstract: The war is won. Now the world will get to pay for it. One cost may be higher interest rates.   An emerging worldwide shortage of capital may help to explain the fact short-term rates have plunged while long-term ones have not, despite the Fed's repeated easing of credit.

headline: Dow Drops 5.70, to 2,730.69, But Smaller Stocks Surge
abstract: Propelled by momentum in technology issues, smaller stocks continued to score big gains yesterday, while the blue chips fell. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day at 2,730.69, down 5.70 points.    For the week, the Dow rose 71.28 points, for a gain of 2.7 percent.

headline: Scudder Fills Top Posts
abstract: Scudder, Stevens & Clark Inc., an investment management firm based in New York, has appointed a new chairman, Daniel Pierce, and a new president, Edmond D. Villani. They succeed George S. Johnston, who held those posts and who died of cancer last week. Scudder runs mutual funds and has $45 billion in assets under supervision.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: MONDAY: Mid-February auto sales. * European Community finance ministers meet in Brussels.  TUESDAY: Durable goods orders for January. * Balance of payments for the fourth quarter. * Conference Board's consumer confidence index for February.  WEDNESDAY: Fourth-quarter gross national product. * Comecon summit in Budapest, through Thursday, to formally disband the organization. * Pilots vote on new contract with American Airlines.  THURSDAY: Personal income and spending for January. * Deadline for Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores to file bankruptcy reorganization plans.  FRIDAY: Leading economic indicators and construction spending for January.

headline: War Summary
abstract: KEEPING THE MILITARY PRESSURE ON As hopes for a negotiated settlement rose and fell, artillery and warplanes of the American-led coalition blasted targets in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Allied planes flew 2,800 missions, ranging over Baghdad and Basra and striking Iraqi front lines and emplacements of the Republican Guards. As President Bush said a Soviet peace proposal had fallen short, the Pentagon reported that ground forces were "ready now" for an offensive. A single Iraqi Scud missile, the 67th fired to date, hit Israel but caused no casualties. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: No casualites were reported, leaving at 16 the number of American ground troops the United States said have been killed in action. Aircraft: An A-10 Thunderbolt attack plane was lost over Kuwait, raising allied losses to 31, and the pilot was reported missing. It was the 22d American plane lost in combat in the Persian Gulf. Naval Vessels: The American guided missile cruise Princeton, which was hit on Monday by an Iraqi mine, was withdrawn from action because of heavy damage. The helicopter carrier Tripoli, which had a 16-by-20-foot hole blasted in her hull by another mine on Monday, patched the damatge and remained on duty. IRAQI FORCES Troops: There we no new reports of Iraqi prisoners. More than 1,200 Iraqi soldiers are reported in captivity. Aricraft: Central Command reported five Iraqi planes destroyed on the ground. The air-to-air loss tallyfor Iraq remains at 42. No additional aircraft tried to flee to Iran. Other Weapons: The allies said they destroyed 5 Scud surface-to-surface missiles, 6 tanks, 5 artillery pieces, 3 armored personnel carriers, 1 multiple rocket launcher, 15 trucks and 2 ammunition bunkers.

headline: NatWest Warning To Troubled Units
abstract: National Westminster Bank P.L.C. said it had given its troubled securities firm one to two years to improve its performance before its future is reappraised and had given its money-losing American banking operation a bit longer. NatWest's chairman, Lord Alexander, suggested the units might be sold off if their performances did not improve in line with other operations.   NatWest also said its net profits nearly doubled, to $:370 million, or $710 million, last year from $:198 million in 1989. The latest figure included a gain from the sale of a Yorkshire subsidiary.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Vice President; Quayle Aims At Protests, A la Agnew
abstract: Until now, the White House has made a point of treating the antiwar demonstrations across Pennsylvania Avenue and across the country with benign neglect. But, in visits to three military bases today, Vice President Dan Quayle took a page from Spiro Agnew's approach during the Vietnam War and offered some tart criticism of the demonstrators and coverage of them.   Vice President Quayle did not have any catchy epithets, such as his predecessor's harangues against the press as "pusilanimous pussyfooters" and Vietnam War protesters as "effete corps of impudent snobs who characterize themselves as intellectuals."

headline: Ziploc Bags Makes Its Point With a Peripatetic Finger
abstract: DELLA FEMINA McNAMEE, the agency that created Joe Isuzu, the quintessential lying car salesman of American Isuzu Motors commercials, is hoping its latest oddball spokesman can duplicate that success.   Those hopes are pinned on Fingerman, who points out the features of Ziploc's new "gripper zipper" plastic storage bag in commercials that began last night.

headline: McDonnell Hints At Jet Project Move
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had run out of room to expand its Douglas Aircraft Company operations here and might have to produce its next-generation passenger jet outside California. The company said it might move the $3 billion MD-12X jet project to a state that offered more incentives. "The probability is that we will go elsewhere," said Donald Snyder, general manager of the MD-12X program.    A company spokesman, Don Hanson, said McDonnell was not considering shutting down its Douglas unit in Long Beach. "What we're talking about is a new facility" for the MD-12X, he said. McDonnell Douglas' board will decide by August where to manufacture the MD-12X, The Los Angeles Times reported.

headline: Baltics and Ukraine to Get U.S. Medical Aid
abstract: President Bush today authorized the shipment of emergency medical supplies directly to the three Baltic republics and the Ukraine in what Administration officials called an attempt to register American concerns about Moscow's policy toward its restive republics.   Administration officials said the shipments, which were announced a few hours before President Mikhail S. Gorbachev made a televised appeal for unity in his country tonight, were part of a broader effort to court opposition leaders in the Baltic republics and elsewhere. The United States told the Soviet Government in advance that it planned to make the shipments and received no objections, officials said.

headline: Dow's a Good Indicator, Except for False Starts
abstract: Almost alone among economic indicators, the stock market has been sending strong signals that the recession is nearly over. While other measures like housing starts continue to offer a dreary run of bad news, the Dow Jones industrial average has risen 21.5 percent since it bottomed on Oct. 11, despite yesterday's decline of 27.48 points, to 2,874.75.   The market's out-front role is not unprecedented. In several postwar recessions, stocks turned up before any of the other leading indicators the Commerce Department follows. And even when stock prices have trailed some other indicators, as happened in 1982, the market's strong performance provided evidence that the economy was going to strengthen long before most economists saw it coming.

headline: Mortgage Rates Mixed
abstract: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.59 percent this week, up from 9.50 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the highest since rates averaged 9.61 on Jan. 25. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.44 percent, down from 7.45 percent last week, the lowest since Freddie Mac began tracking adjustable mortages in 1984.

headline: Jordanians Feeling Vulnerable as Deadline Nears
abstract: Palestinian and Islamic fundamentalist demonstrators burned American flags and lofted portraits of Saddam Hussein here today as the deadline for possible war in the Persian Gulf drew closer.   The prospect of conflict that could embroil this land of three million evoked sentiments among Jordanians ranging from defiance to a bleak acknowledgement that war would confront their leaders with virtually insoluble military and political problems.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: BRACING FOR WAR    At Lloyd's of London, insuring tankers bound for the Persian Gulf is costly, but rates might easily triple in a war.  [ Page D1. ]   Traders, dealers and fund managers in markets from equities to foreign exchange said they hoped they were ready for war.  [ D7. ]   Technology-minded citizens -- from antiwar groups to arms makers -- are turning to personal computers for gulf news.  [ D7. ]   The company that spread El Al's security system to airlines worldwide is getting more business than it can handle.  [ D7. ]   Financial exchanges plan to remain open if war comes, but if the Big Board closes, others will follow.  [ D8. ] COMPANIES    Citicorp, Manufacturers Hanover and Chemical announced poor earnings, while Wells Fargo's profits fell slightly.  [ D1. ]   Eastern may stop flying within days and be liquidated because it is short of cash and cannot find more.  [ D1. ]   HarperCollins appointed Doubleday's editor in chief as associate publisher and editor in chief of its adult trade division.  [ D6. ]   Cubic Defense Systems and its former chief pleaded guilty to conspiracy in Pentagon purchasing fraud.  [ D4. ]   UAL said it expected to post the largest quarterly operating loss in its history.  [ D4. ]   TV network executives are describing midseason prime-time programming strategies that are built around not-at-all-great expectations.  [ C9. ] THE ECONOMY    Sales of cars and trucks made in the U.S. were mired at recessionary levels in early January.  [ D1. ]   The Fed said it would allow Bankers Trust and two Canadian banks to trade corporate stocks.  [ D2. ]   Retail sales fell 0.4 percent in December, Commerce reported, pushed by low auto sales and a lean Christmas.  [ D6. ]   The E.P.A. began a campaign to convince large businesses that they can reduce pollution, and increase profits, by buying better lights.  [ D6. ] BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY    Regional phone companies have served as gatekeepers for telephone networks, but the F.C.C. is trying to allow outsiders in.  [ D5. ] INTERNATIONAL    GATT's chief indicated that he might soon reconvene the talks because he sees signs of flexibility on farm trade.  [ D2. ] MARKETS    The oil market stared war in the face, and barely moved. Crude fell 71 cents, to $30.07.  [ D1. ]   Stock trading slowed sharply as investors waited for Mideast news. The Dow gained 6.68, to 2,490.59.  [ D8. ]   The looming reality of war enveloped the credit markets, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped.  [ D14. ]   Precious metals prices moved in a narrow range before settling lower.  [ D15. ]  The dollar was little changed.  [ D15. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS     The stock market normally takes a beating if war comes as a surprise. If shooting starts now, however, it would hardly be a surprise. Floyd Norris: Market Place.  [ D1. ]   Which banks should be counted as the walking dead? Regulators do not, and cannot, tell. Peter Passell: Economic Scene.  [ D2. ]   Many advertisers call for emergency meetings with agencies to formulate war strategies. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D6. ]

headline: Women Challenge Church Council Assembly
abstract: Some of the most striking moments of the World Council of Churches' seventh assembly here have been about women, underlining their increasing influence and inspiring a sort of backlash.    The Rev. Lois M. Wilson of the United Church of Canada, one of the council's seven departing presidents, electrified this gathering of some 4,000 people the other day by saying that women attending the conference, having received threats from men who are clerics, had cried in the restroom. Shesaid, "These are the politics of the World Council of Churches and they stink to high heaven, and I do not think it was what Jesus had in mind."

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article on the Company News page of Business Day yesterday about Amax Inc. misstated the closing price of the company's stock on Thursday. It was $25.25 a share, down 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: The Spy Who Went Into Retailing
abstract: Marian Zacharski has a finely tuned sense of irony, and he ought to. A decade ago, he was sentenced by an American court to life in prison, a Polish agent who paid a high penalty for stealing military secrets. Today, six years after his release in a spy exchange, he is a leading businessman in Poland, director of this country's most profitable retailer.   "Each day, all that is becoming more distant," Mr. Zacharski said of his years as a foot soldier in the cold war in the guise of a sales representative for a Polish machine-tools company. "History has moved forward. I owe a lot to America. If I've become a seasoned businessman, it was because of the years I spent in America. It was my university of life."

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Parker Pen dropped Lowe International in favor of Eurocom for its $11.5 million account. Della Femina McNamee will handle the $3 million U.S. portion of the account. * Sport Graphics Inc., which makes leisure products in Cranston, R.I., to Griffin Bacal Inc., New York, with a budget of $2 million to $3 million. * Thomas Nelson Publishers Inc., Nashville, to CDHM Advertising, Stamford, Conn., with a budget of more than $1 million. * New York Mets, to TBWA Advertising, New York, with a undisclosed budget. The previous agency was Della Femina McNamee, New York. * Perrier Group of America, Greenwich, Conn., a division of Source Perrier S.A. of France, to Chapman Direct Advertising, New York, a unit of Young & Rubicam, for undisclosed billings. The previous agency was Hal Riney & Partners.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The U.S. and Israel; Barrage of Iraqi Missiles on Israel Complicates U.S. Strategy in Gulf
abstract: The Iraqi missile attack on Israel could seriously complicate Washington's strategy in the Persian Gulf war. Much depends on whether Israel retaliates and if it does whether any of Washington's Arab allies bolt the anti-Iraq coalition.   President Bush said tonight that he was "outraged" at the attack, and American officials appealed to the Israelis to limit any reaction so as not to play into the hands of the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein. Ambassadors Summoned     Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, working at the White House alongside President Bush, immediately called the Ambassadors of Israel, Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Syria. Mr. Baker was understood to be trying to encourage the Israelis not to engage in any large-scale retaliation that might be used by Iraq to transform the gulf war into an Arab-Israeli conflict.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Economic and Social Council COMMITTEE ON NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS - 10A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Rating Cut for ITT Financial Unit
abstract: The credit rating of about $4.9 billion in long-term debt issued by the ITT Financial Corporation was lowered yesterday by Moody's Investors Service, which cited weakening asset quality as a principal factor.    Moody's indicated that the rating, under review since early December, was changed because of concerns about the commercial real estate and unsecured consumer loan portfolios. The rating agency said, "Further deterioration in this area could strain earnings and capital formation."

headline: Brazil Cutting Tariffs
abstract: The Government lowered hundreds of import tariffs today as part of an economic reform begun last June. Under the new rates, effective Friday, the tariff on imported cars will fall from 85 percent to 60 percent, then to 35 percent in 1994. Tariffs on electronic goods will fall from 55 percent to 30 percent in 1994. Tariffs on capital goods, machinery, farm equipment, locomotives and petrochemical products will also be cut and continue to drop until 1994, when they will range from zero to 40 percent.

headline: Manila to Sell Utility Stake
abstract: The Philippine Government, which is planning to sell several state companies, will partly privatize the country's biggest electricity company this year.   The company, the Manila Electric Company, will sell 25.5 million shares in June to raise money for expansion, the Government's Asset Privatization Trust said last week.    The utility, which distributes electricity to metropolitan Manila and parts of the main island of Luzon, was widely criticized last year because of frequent blackouts.   It is among hundreds of assets and properties that creditors are putting pressure on the Government to sell to the private sector. Philippine Airlines said last month that it would sell up to 60 percent of its equity to local and foreign investors by August.

headline: Domino's Pizza Weighs Switch
abstract: Domino's Pizza, has put its $50 million national account under review.   The company, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., has been having a rough time lately. Increased marketing pressure from Pizza Hut has put holes in its sales. Domino's has also had to face Pizza Hut's mocking and sometimes brutal advertising campaign. Some ads, which have been discontinued, showed Domino's employees munching on a pie they had ordered from Pizza Hut.    The current agency is Group 243, a unit of the Ross Roy Group, both of Detroit, which was created to service Domino's. Calls to the agency yesterday were not returned.   A spokeswoman at Domino's declined to comment, other than to confirm that the account was up for review.

headline: Wang and MIPS In Marketing Pact
abstract: MIPS Computer Systems Inc., based in Sunnyvale, Calif., and Wang Laboratories of Lowell, Mass., said they had signed a worldwide agreement under which Wang will market computer systems from MIPS based on reduced instruction set computing, or RISC. Wang will sell, service and support MIPS Riscomputer systems under the Wang Dynamix label.    The announcement is another in a series of gains for MIPS, which is working to establish its RISC technology as the leading alternative to Sun Microsystems Inc.'s Sparc processors.

headline: Penn Central Buys Insurance Group
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation completed the purchase of the American Financial Corporation's non-standard auto insurance group for about $335 million. The price is subject to change after a review of the group's pretax earnings for 1991-94, Penn Central said. The price could fall by up to $20 million or rise by up to $40 million.   Both companies are controlled by the financier Carl H. Lindner, who is the biggest shareholder in American Financial and chief executive of Penn Central. The insurers involved are the Atlanta Casualty Company, the Windsor Insurance Company and the Stonewall Insurance Company and their subsidiaries.

headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: The Overview; U.S. WEIGHS TIMING OF ATTACK AGAINST IRAQ AS DEADLINE PASSES AND DIPLOMACY FAILS
abstract: The deadline for Saddam Hussein to withdraw his forces from Kuwait passed at midnight Tuesday with the Iraqi Army still in place and the Bush Administration poised at the "point of decision" to unleash an American attack.    After the failure of last-minute peace initiatives, the White House appeared to hold little hope for further progress, although there was a sense that the Iraqi President might have another day or two, or perhaps a little longer, to acquiesce.

headline: Albania's Hard-Liners and Democracy Backers Battle for Control
abstract: Supporters of democracy vied with orthodox Communists across Albania today in a struggle for the upper hand in determining the future of the small Balkan country.   Scattered shooting, apparently by snipers, was reported today in Tirana, the capital, where army tanks and armored cars guarded key buildings of the Government and the ruling Communist Party.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: The Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York yesterday priced $138 million in bonds to refund other debt sold when interest rates were higher.   Goldman, Sachs & Company, lead manager for the underwriting group, said the offering went well and initial indications were that the bonds were well received by retail and institutional investors.   The maximum yield offered is 6.90 percent for an issue due in 2008, while yields on the short-term serial bonds range from 5.30 percent in 1992 to 6.10 percent in 1996, to 6.65 percent in 2001 and 6.80 percent in 2003.    The refunding bonds are rated A by Moody's Investors Service, A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, and AA by Fitch Investors Service Inc. Traders outside the underwriting group said the sale of these bonds could give a good indication of how well the credit markets would respond if the corporation should have to borrow again on the city's behalf.

headline: Airlines' $1 Billion Loss
abstract: The world's airlines lost more than $1 billion last month, mostly because of the Persian Gulf war, according to the International Air Transport Association. The 200-member airline group had reported a $1 billion shortfall for January. European airlines accounted for nearly two-thirds of the loss and nearly 60 percent of all flight cancellations. Some 21,400 flights, 6 percent of scheduled traffic, were canceled worldwide in February. Traffic on Middle East carriers was down by half compared with February 1990, as the airlines canceled 38 percent of their flights to the region.

headline: U.S. Hints at Chemical Arms Bunker in Libya
abstract: The United States suspects that Libya is digging a bunker near its Rabta chemical weapons plant to shield chemicals and bomb components from aerial attack, but so far lacks solid proof to back up its beliefs, American officials said today.    The officials also confirmed that the Rabta complex, some 25 miles outside Tripoli, the Libyan capital, has begun "large-scale production" of poison gas weapons for the first time since the plant was completed in 1989.

headline: Ethics as a Business Plus
abstract: To the Editor:   In Ronald P. Myers's letter ("The Prevalence of Expedient Ethics," March 10) the author states that as a strategic planning consultant he finds corporate executives giving less attention to ethics.   I don't know Mr. Myers's views on strategic planning, but I find that the published writings of many planners place stress on achieving higher "shareholder value" as the prime objective of business. This view has contributed a great deal toward ignoring ethical standards. Emphasis on shareholder value ignores the interests of the other stakeholders -- customers, employees, society and the industry.   My own view, with about 45 years in business before entering the academic world, is that most corporate executives have increased their attention to ethics, and to stakeholders other than their shareholders. They know that ignoring the law can put you in jail, and that poor ethics loses business in the long run. Good ethics is good business. WILLIAM COPULSKY  New York, March 12 The author is an associate professor of marketing at Baruch College.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Chesapeake Corp., Richmond, a manufacturer of paper products, named Thomas Blackburn group vice president for pulp and wood products. * Gap Inc., San Francisco, a chain of casual clothing stores, named David M. Demattei and Warren R. Hashagen senior vice presidents. * General Dynamics Corp., St. Louis, named Terry A. Straeter corporate vice president and general manager of its electronics division. He succeeds Melville R. Barlow, who is retiring. * Hearst Corp., New York, named Richard P. Malloch general manager of its books and business publishing group. * Hughes Aircraft Co., Los Angeles, a subsidiary of General Motors, named W. Allen Reed vice president and treasurer. He succeeds William A. MacGillivray, who is retiring. * SPP Hambro & Co., New York, the United States corporate finance affiliate of Hambros Bank Ltd., London, named Allan B. Ruchman president and head of mergers and acquisitions. * Tyco Toys Inc., Mount Laurel, N.J., named John P. Bohach vice president for advertising and communications. * Wang Laboratories, Lowell, Mass., named Richard L. Cote vice president and corporate controller. * Warner Brothers, Burbank, Calif., a subsidiary of Time Warner Inc., named John Heinritz vice president of international marketing and licensing for its worldwide merchandising division.

headline: Sales Fell, Income Rose For Macy in 2d Quarter
abstract: R. H. Macy & Company said yesterday that sales in its second quarter, which included the Christmas season, fell 9.4 percent from the level a year earlier.    But the company, New York's largest-volume retailer, said income before interest, taxes and depreciation rose 21 percent, to $254 million, from $210 million in the 1989 second quarter. It said it achieved the higher earnings despite lower sales by "adhering to our previously outlined plan of controlled inventories, prudent expense reductions and effective cash management."

headline: Oil and Gas Exploration Will Increase
abstract: The energy industry expects to increase worldwide spending to find and produce oil and natural gas by nearly 14 percent this year, but a majority of the money will go to projects outside the United States and its coastal waters, according to an annual survey by Salomon Brothers.    That trend would extend the industry's growing commitment to finding and developing energy prospects outside the United States at a time when this country is importing more than half of the 16 million barrels it consumes each day.

headline: Voice of the Pentagon Delivers Press Curbs With a Deftness Honed on TV
abstract: During his 10 years as a reporter-cameraman for KTWO-TV in Casper, Wyo., Louis A. (Pete) Williams once sneaked onto a restricted MX missile site to film a stand-up. Now, as Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs, he stands at the lectern and earnestly defends restrictions on journalists.   "We thought we couldn't do this program without showing what one of these silo locations with a Minuteman looked like," he said of his MX story. "We didn't actually crawl under the fence or anything like that, but we got close to it."

headline: L. L. Bean Plans Shipping Charge
abstract: L. L. Bean Inc. is ending its 79-year tradition of shipping merchandise free. The mail-order outdoors outfitter says it cannot afford to absorb increased delivery costs. Starting this summer, the company will add a flat $3.50 charge to each order, regardless of how much a customer buys, a spokeswoman, Catherine Hartnett, said.   L. L. Bean expects rate increases by United Parcel Service and the United States Postal Service to add about $13 million to its $37 million-a-year postage and delivery costs, she said. The company has also become more selective with its mailings, dropping 16 million from its list of 116 million.

headline: BUSH MAY CALL OFF FEBRUARY MEETING WITH SOVIET CHIEF
abstract: In the clearest sign of newly emerging problems in Soviet-American relations, President Bush is on the verge of postponing a summit meeting scheduled for Moscow in February because of differences over arms control and uncertainty in the Persian Gulf, Administration officials said tonight.    "We have been going over the prospects for the summit thoroughly in the last few days and there is now a strong possibility that there may not be a meeting in Moscow next month," said an official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

headline: Sales Are Strong For Macintosh
abstract: Apple Computer Inc.'s chairman, John Sculley, said the new Macintosh Classic should sell more machines in its first year than any other computer introduced by Apple.   The Classic, with an entry price of $1,000, was introduced in October, and Apple has been unable to keep up with demand. But Apple executives said the company should catch up by the end of March. Mr. Sculley did not disclose any sales numbers, but his description suggested that Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., might sell nearly a million Classics this fiscal year.

headline: Profits Rise 68.6% At Amoco
abstract: The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that its net income surged 68.6 percent in the last three months of 1990. It was the first report in what analysts expect will be a series of large gains in fourth-quarter profits within the oil industry.   Higher oil prices, which reflected growing fears of war in the Persian Gulf, enabled Amoco to post huge gains in its foreign and domestic oil-production subsidiaries. The gains more than offset the squeeze on profit margins caused by the higher crude costs in the company's refining, marketing, chemicals and transportation operations.  Following Expectations     "This is clearly in line with the trends that are expected for the industry" for fourth-quarter earnings, said Michael L. Mayer, an energy analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company in San Francisco.

headline: Aldus to Fight Software Theft
abstract: The Aldus Corporation, a maker of software, today introduced a two-part plan to combat theft of its personal computer programs.   The initiative, which is aimed at dealers, stresses education and "gentle persuasion" to convert software pirates -- those who illegally copy software -- into legitimate software users who purchase what they use. If that does not work, Aldus said, it will take legal action against those suspected of using its programs illegally.

headline: Severe Problems Seen at Savings Bailout Agency
abstract: The Government's senior auditor reported today that the agency in charge of the savings and loan bailout was plagued by severe problems with keeping track of its bloated portfolio of real estate and securities, hiring private contractors to manage the assets, and ultimately in selling them.   In a report to Congress on the Resolution Trust Corporation, Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, also said that the average time to dispose of savings institutions seized by the Government had doubled, to more than a year, since the summer of 1989, when the rescue began.

headline: Car Makers Revise Budgets In the Face of Slowing Sales
abstract: SOME leading auto makers are cutting advertising budgets substantially or deferring spending until later this year because of fears that recession and war will further depress sales, some automobile and advertising executives said yesterday.    Although auto executives would not disclose advertising expenditures, some said both the Chrysler Corporation and the General Motors Corporation had held back large amounts of ad dollars, perhaps as much as $100 million each, primarily from budgets earmarked for network television and magazines.

headline: Oakland Paper Seeks Pay Cuts
abstract: Executives of The Tribune in Oakland have asked 600 employees to take 11 percent pay cuts so it can meet this month's payroll, union officials said Friday. The Tribune's managing editor, Eric Newton, said the company and union officials had agreed not to discuss the proposal publicly.   Union officials said the cuts would begin no later than Jan. 23 and affect about 600 employees, including management as well as union and nonunion workers. Workers who make less than $25,000 a year, including clerks and editorial assistants, would be exempt.   An 11 percent pay cut would amount to a loss of $77.11 a week for top-scale employees who make $701 weekly and $55 for those who earn starting wages of $500. The union's contract expired a week ago and negotiations on a new pact are under way.

headline: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
abstract: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.    The pool reporters obtain information while under military escort, and their accounts are subject to scrutiny by military censors before being distributed. Some of the information appearing today on American military operations was obtained under such circumstances.

headline: Lebanon Defense Chief Survives Car Bombing
abstract: Defense Minister Michel al-Murr, who is in charge of plans for disbanding Lebanon's armed groups, escaped an attempt on his life today when a car bomb hit his motorcade, killing 10 people and wounding 25, the police said.   The official, whose bullet-proof car was overturned by the explosion, suffered bruises and cuts but was able to attend part of a Cabinet meeting at which a formal decision was made to disarm and dissolve all militias.

headline: On Main Street, The Bulls Are Stampeding
abstract: The public is back in the market, and the speculative stocks are soaring. The money managers, suddenly bullish, are searching for laggards, afraid to stay on the sidelines. All told, it is certainly enough to make a contrarian investor nervous.   It is individual investors who are pushing up prices now. "A lot of buyers came into the market," exulted Larry Armstrong, executive vice president of Fidelity Investment's discount brokerage operations, after peace hopes brought a buying panic on Monday, with volume soaring and more than two buy orders for every sell. Even on Jan. 17, when prices leaped after the air war began, that ratio was just three to two.

headline: Is Saddam Hussein a Phoenix?
abstract: The biggest unanswered question after the allies' stunningly decisive triumph in the Persian Gulf war is, Will they have to fight Saddam Hussein again? News analysis, page 16.

headline: Increased Activity In Collagen Stock
abstract: The Collagen Corporation said there was no business reason for the recent share-price volatility and increased trading in its common stock. The company, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., speculated that the activity might be related to a coming television program that focuses on the use of injectable collagen, one of its products, in surgical and cosmetic facial treatments.    Collagen shares dropped $1 today, to $19, in over-the-counter trading, on a volume of 199,000 shares.

headline: Prudential-Bache Chief Quits After Big Losses
abstract: George L. Ball, who led Prudential-Bache Securities in an expensive but failed effort to break into the top levels of Wall Street investment banks, resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of the struggling brokerage firm.    Mr. Ball, whose aggressive tactics in paying huge sums to recruit brokers and bankers helped drive up compensation on Wall Street in the 1980's, stepped down after nearly nine years as head of the firm. During that time, the firm, whose bedrock business is selling to individual investors, lost about $308 million, a serious blow to its parent, the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

headline: Crowds in European Cities Protest a War in Gulf Area
abstract: Mobilized by leftist, environmental, pacifist and trade union groups, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched through the streets of major West European cities today to demand that force not be used against Iraq in Kuwait.    As part of an international day of action coordinated with antiwar groups in the United States and Japan, protests against the military buildup in the gulf were organized in Britain and France, which have sent troops to Saudi Arabia, as well as in Germany, Italy, Switzerland, Sweden and Norway.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Allies and Adversaries; Anti-Iraq Nations Firmly Reject Offer, Calling It 'Insincere' and an 'Obstacle'
abstract: Iraq's conditional offer on Kuwait was firmly rejected today by Saudi Arabia and other Arab gulf countries, as well as by Egypt and Syria, which are at war with Iraq.    While Arab nations supporting Iraq welcomed the offer, the bitterness in the anti-Iraqi nations' response was evident in the tone and content of the statement today by the Foreign Minister of Egypt, Esmat Abdel-Meguid. He spoke in the name of the eight Arab foreign ministers in the anti-Iraq coalition who are meeting here, rejecting categorically the Iraqi offer.

headline: King Broadcasting's TV Asset Sale
abstract: The King Broadcasting Company agreed today to sell its six television stations and 13 cable systems to the Providence Journal Company and its joint-venture partner, Kelso & Company.    No price was disclosed for the television and cable operations, which represent about 85 percent of King Broadcasting.

headline: Iceland Proposes Reopening Its Ties With Baltic Republics
abstract: Iceland has become the first country to propose reopening diplomatic relations with the three Baltic republics struggling toward independence amid a Soviet military crackdown.   Iceland's Foreign Minister, Jon Baldvin Hannibalsson, made the offer Thursday in a message to his counterpart in Lithuania, which declared its independence from Moscow last spring. A smiliar offer is expected to be made to Latvia and Estonia.    Moscow, which annexed the Baltic states in 1940, is trying to suppress the independence movement in Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia.

headline: Furor in Japan Over U.S. Funding Program
abstract: At the height of frictions with the United States last year, Japan created an ambitious new $375 million Government-financed endowment to support scholarly, political and cultural exchanges between the two countries.   But now as the new venture is about to begin, an unusual controversy has arisen, with warnings by American foundation executives and scholars that the fund might backfire by being seen as a costly attempt to improve Japan's public relations reputation in the United States. To Japanese and Americans alike, the controversy reflects the tense state of relations these days, aggravated by endless trade disputes and American resentments over Japanese investments and what many officials see as Tokyo's half-hearted response to the war against Iraq.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington; 2d Iraqi Attack on Israel Raises Concern in U.S.
abstract: Reports of a second Iraqi missile attack on downtown Tel Aviv early today renewed concerns in Washington that Israel may strike back at Iraq and thus be drawn into the Persian Gulf conflict.    President Bush was awakened at Camp David and briefed by his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, early today on what preliminary reports indicated were three launches of Scud missiles from western Iraq and two hits in Tel Aviv, officials said. Washington immediately contacted the Israeli Government, but details of that communication were not known.

headline: A.T.& T. Is Paid In Phone Suit
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has settled a lawsuit involving allegations that International Telecharge Inc. had surreptitiously switched long-distance service at pay phones.    In the lawsuit filed in Federal court in Trenton, A.T.& T. contended that International Telecharge had switched long-distance services at pay phones without the knowledge or approval of the owners, said Ray Child, an A.T.& T. spokesman.   The out-of-court settlement included corrective measures to address unauthorized switching, as well as an undisclosed payment to A.T.& T., Mr. Child said.    National Telephone Services Inc., which was also named as a defendant, was not involved in the settlement, Mr. Child said.

headline: TORY GROUP BACKS BLACK CANDIDATE
abstract: Hoping to put an end to an ugly political debate charged by allegations of racism, British Conservatives in western England have agreed to unite behind a black barrister as their candidate for the House of Commons.   At a conference in Cheltenham, a fashionable spa city of 81,000 in the Cotswolds, members of the local Conservative Party on Sunday overwhelmingly rejected an attempt by party dissidents to overthrow the candidacy of John Taylor, a 38-year-old adviser to the Home Office on racial issues.

headline: Iraq Shows 2 More It Calls U.S. Airmen
abstract: Iraq showed what it said were two more captured American airmen on Baghdad television today and sought to link its handling of American captives to Israeli treatment of Palestinian detainees in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.    [ Videotape of the captured airmen, broadcast in the United States, identified them as Maj. Jeffrey Scott Tice and Capt. Harry Michael Roberts, both of the Air Force. Two airmen by those names were listed by the Pentagon on Sunday as missing in action. ]

headline: U.S. Clears Japanese Stake In Atomic-Arms Toolmaker
abstract: The White House has approved a Japanese company's purchase of 40 percent of the only American company that makes precision machine tools that satisfy the requirements of the Defense and Energy Departments for making atomic weaponry.   The deal between the Fanuc Company of Japan, which makes robots and machine tools -- machines that make other machines -- and Moore Special Tool Inc. of Bridgeport, Conn., was hotly debated within the Bush Administration.

headline: 2 Military Air Crashes
abstract: A plane carrying Senegalese soldiers crashed near the Saudi-Kuwaiti border, killing 98 people. Officials said smoke from burning Kuwaiti oil wells could have been a factor.    In an unrelated incident, 27 crew members were missing after the collision of two U.S. Navy patrol planes on a training mission off San Diego.    Articles, pages A9 and A20.

headline: South Africa and Namibia Halt Talks Over Strategic Atlantic Port
abstract: High-level delegations from South Africa and Namibia met in Cape Town today to search for some consensus on the future of Walvis Bay, a strategic deep-water port on the Atlantic Ocean that South Africa kept when it granted independence to Namibia a year ago.    The negotiations mired down in deadlock within a few hours, and the two sides broke off the meeting to consult with their governments. But the fact that they met at all underscored a mutual interest in finding a solution to a problem that has posed an intractable obstacle to normal relations.

headline: Smugglers Overrun Germany's Border With East
abstract: The Pannonia Express from Sofia, via Budapest, rumbled in pretty much on time, and disgorged a group of men in dark clothes with bulging tote bags. Minutes later, they haggled in sign language near Dresden's cavernous terminal with a group of Vietnamese over prices for shabby sweaters that spilled from their bags.   The traders, Hungarian gypsies and Vietnamese migrant workers stranded in what used to be Communist East Germany, are part of an explosion of smuggling along united Germany's border with the East. For if Germany is bracing for a predicted wave of refugees from Eastern Europe, pushed to desert their homes by collapsing economies in countries like Romania, Poland and the Soviet Union, the vanguard consists of a legion of con men and contraband specialists who are taxing Germany's ability to police its newly acquired eastern borders.  Market Was Disbanded     "Smuggling is surging," said Harry Baumann, a senior customs officer in Saxony, along the mountainous border with Czechoslovakia. "All highly taxed goods, like liquor, cigarettes, but also textiles, like sweaters."

headline: Colombian Kidnappings Are Gagging the Press
abstract: One recent evening, a remote-control bomb exploded on a street here, killing seven policemen. The next morning, this city's largest-selling newspaper, El Colombiano, carried this front-page lead headline: "Drug Trafficking Study Proposes Decriminalization and Elimination of Extradition."    At an office here, a businessman looked up from the El Colombiano headline, sipped his morning cup of coffee and commented: "The change in press coverage of drug trafficking has been brutal. There has been a total opening to the idea that the problem must be fixed quickly."

headline: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
abstract: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in small groups and given access to various military sources.   These pool reporters obtain their information while under military escort, and their accounts are subject to scrutiny by military censors before they are distributed. Some of the information appearing today on American military operations was obtained under such circumstances.

headline: Fidelity Planning To Cut 226 Jobs
abstract: Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund operator, said it would lay off 226 workers because a slumping economy has weakened investor activity. The layoffs will reduce Fidelity's staff by 3.3 percent, to a total of 6,670. The cuts will affect 151 employees in Boston, where Fidelity is based; 30 in Dallas; 18 in New York City, 12 in Salt Lake City and smaller numbers at other locations.    The private company forecasts a modest increase in overall revenues for 1991 but said processing volumes and revenues in some areas have declined. Fidelity has been trying to cut its expenses without layoffs, but decided that staffing cuts were also necessary, said Edward C. Johnson 3d, the chairman.

headline: Vendex Unit Trims Its Dillard Stake
abstract: Vendamerica B.V., the American arm of Vendex International, a Dutch retail concern, is selling six million shares it holds of Dillard Department Stores' class A common stock. The stock is estimated to have a value of about $600 million. The block will be offered in a public issue.   The shares represent about two-thirds of the 25.2 percent holding of Dillard class A common that Vendex has owned for many years. The class B stock of Dillard, one of America's fastest-growing retailers, remains 95.7 percent owned by the Dillard founding family and elects two-thirds of the company's board.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Press; Press and U.S. Officials at Odds on News Curbs
abstract: Three days into the fighting, the United States Government continues to exercise tight control over news of the war, withholding information about the extent of the bombing and the destruction in Iraq and restricting interviews with troops and returning pilots.   At the same time, journalists, particularly on television, have periodically failed to distinguish fact from rumor, and the public has received false and misleading reports.

headline: Jury Duty Pay
abstract: People who were called to jury duty in 1990 must report what they were paid for their service on line 22 of Form 1040. Because this money is reported to the I.R.S., people who fail to report it could receive a deficiency notice from the I.R.S. In cases were employers continued to pay jurors their regular salaries but required them to turn over their jury pay, they can then claim an offsetting deduction on line 30. (Source: Julian Block, tax lawyer)

headline: Insurgents Claiming Victory in Somalia
abstract: Rebels in Somalia said on Saturday night that they had won control of the capital, Mogadishu, and had forced President Mohammed Siad Barre to flee his palace.    The rebels' assertions, monitored over radio about 600 miles to the southwest in Nairobi, were largely confirmed today by a team of French doctors who were treating the wounded in the Somali capital.

headline: Dow Falls 13.36 in Slow Trading; Slide Moves to 5th Day
abstract: Stocks lost further ground yesterday for the fifth straight session, extending the erosion in the Dow Jones industrial average so far this year by nearly 125 points, or 4.7 percent.    With traders worried by the slump in other world markets, particularly London and Tokyo, the Dow closed at 2,509.41, off 13.36.

headline: More Jet Sales Seen to Eastern Europe
abstract: The Boeing Company said airlines based in Eastern Europe would buy an average of 12 to 13 new jets a year over 15 years to keep up with a sharp rise in passenger traffic and to replace their aging fleets. It said Western aircraft makers stood a good chance of getting a share of the market, which has been dominated by the Soviet Union.    Much of the demand will be for single-aisle aircraft, but the airlines will also buy some wide-bodied planes for longer routes, John Hayhurst, Boeing's vice president for marketing, said. He said airlines in Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland, Romania and Yugoslavia were likely to see a growth in traffic to 40 billion passenger miles by 2005, up sharply from 15 billion last year.

headline: Big Stake Holder's Chief To Be Fuqua President
abstract: Charles R. Scott, who has spent his career buying and developing midsize companies, was named president and chief executive of Fuqua Industries yesterday in a move to shore up his concern's investment in the company.    He succeeds Lawrence P. Klamon, 53, a longtime Fuqua executive, who will continue as chairman. Mr. Scott, 62, will move to Atlanta, Fuqua's headquarters, from La Jolla, Calif., to take over day-to-day operations.

headline: Report Cites Bailout Waste
abstract: Poor management by savings and loan regulators resulted in nearly $1 million in excess costs to collect payments on loans inherited from failed savings and loans, said a Congressional report released today.    The report, prepared by the General Accounting Office, said the Resolution Trust Corporation, which was created to oversee the savings industry bailout, could have reduced costs by $964,969 from January to July 1990 for servicing 1,800 loans it inherited from the failed Freedom Savings and Loan Association in Tampa, Fla.

headline: Managing; Executives, Take Your Risks
abstract: Anthony Luiso, the International Multifoods Corporation's chief executive, was due for a $100,000 raise last year. He not only turned it down, but also told the board to hold back $100,000 of his bonus. In their place, he took $200,000 in stock options, exercisable in 10 years at $32.625 each, the price on the day the deal was signed.    "Executives should have enough at risk so that they spend a couple of sleepless nights over their decisions," Mr. Luiso said.

headline: Wider Access to U.S. Securities Price Data Urged
abstract: A top Federal regulator said today that price data in the market for United States Government securities, the world's biggest market by far, should be made widely available rather than held within a select group of officially sanctioned bond dealers.   Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said disseminating quotations outside the main group of a few dozen dealers would spur competition and allow nonspecialists to obtain the best available deal.

headline: MAINLAND THREAT WORRYING TAIWAN
abstract: No one here seems to expect a military invasion from China soon, but some officials believe the threat of an attack from the mainland may again be increasing.   The Taiwan Government did put its military forces on alert last month, to make sure that China did not take advantage of the Persian Gulf crisis by launching an attack. And the alert, as well as the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the Soviet crackdown in the Baltics, seems to have reminded many of Taiwan's 20 million people of the risks. Fresh in many memories are the two serious efforts made by the Communists, in 1949 and 1958, to seize this island.

headline: ACCORD IS REACHED BY U.S. AND BRITAIN ON AIRLINE SERVICE
abstract: The United States and Britain reached an agreement yesterday that will have a broad impact on trans- Atlantic airlines and their passengers. One immediate result is that Pan American World Airways, on the brink of shutting down, will continue to fly.    By allowing United Airlines and American Airlines to buy routes to Heathrow Airport in London, the pact also provides much-needed money to Trans World Airlines, which, while not in as dire shape as Pan Am, has had huge losses lately.

headline: Poison Gas Attack: A Longstanding Fear That Continues to Nag the Troops
abstract: The renewed threat on Monday by Iraq's President Saddam Hussein to use chemical, biological and nuclear weapons against allied forces has sent a new chill through the front-line troops here.    "The soldiers have a real anticipation of getting gassed," Staff Sgt. Robert Langston, a 28-year-old medic from Ruidoso, N.M., told a pool reporter visiting the 82d Airborne Division at a northern encampment here.

headline: New Delhi Ousts Government of a Big State
abstract: In a move that critics say was as much an assault on the Indian Constitution as on a leader of the political opposition, Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar has dismissed the elected government of a big southern state, Tamil Nadu.   The ouster of the Tamil Nadu administration, led by Chief Minister Muthivel Karunanidhi, an ally of Mr. Shekhar's predecessor as Prime Minister, V. P. Singh, came in a midnight presidential proclamation Wednesday. Riots, demonstrations and at least one suicide by self-immolation have followed.

headline: Patents; Tears Tested to Measure Alcohol Level
abstract: Scientists in Toronto have patented a device that can measure the presence of alcohol within 15 seconds by analyzing vapor from the tears in an eye.    The researchers said the device made it easier to obtain measurements more accurate than those from breath tests and more quickly than those from blood or urine analysis. The device was invented by Gwynne Giles and Yedy Israel, scientists at the Addiction Research Foundation, an agency of the Ontario provincial government.

headline: Heinz Net Up 10% in Period
abstract: The H. J. Heinz Company said today that its profit increased 10 percent in the third quarter as sales rose 14.3 percent and the value of the dollar fell against foreign currencies.   The food maker said net income for the three-month period that ended on Jan. 30 totaled $128.9 million, or 49 cents a share, compared with $117.2 million, or 44 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago. Revenue came to $1.6 billion, compared with $1.4 billion a year earlier.

headline: Wall Street; Pick the Market, Weigh the Assets, Watch the Premium
abstract: Results from 1990 teach a sober lesson about the risk of investing in closed-end country funds. Picking the right stock market is not enough. You have to pick the right fund.    These funds have proven popular as an easy way to invest in exotic or hard-to-trade markets. But of eight major funds traded in New York last year, the value of the stock in seven plunged far more than than total net asset value. In two cases, Austria and India, the asset value rose but the stock fell.   T

headline: All About/Medical Supplies; Removing the Warehouse from Cost-Conscious Hospitals
abstract: In the palmy years before the nationwide squeeze on health-care costs, St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital in Houston kept a hoard of expensive medical supplies in its 20,000-square-foot warehouse. Like all hospitals, St. Luke's cannot afford to run short of vital items -- least of all in the operating rooms. At St. Luke's, Dr. Denton A. Cooley's teams perform open heart surgery on 3,000 patients each year, using prodigious quantities of supplies.    But to achieve economies as the pressure to control costs intensified, St. Luke's shut its warehouse and sold the inventory to Baxter International, a major hospital supplier. Baxter is becoming a full-time partner with this 950-bed hospital in managing, ordering and delivering Baxter's wares as well as the products of 400 other companies. Baxter's daily "just-in-time" deliveries to the hospital loading dock were only the first step. In an innovative system that hospitals call stockless inventory, Baxter fills orders in exact, sometimes small, quantities and delivers directly to departments, including the operating rooms and nursing floors, inside St. Luke's.   At least 50 hospitals buy stockless services from Baxter and a handful of smaller distributors. Converts to the concept are multiplying. About 250 more hospitals will go stockless in at least some departments in the next two years, said Pat Dolan, a partner in Chicago with Arthur Andersen & Company. Dolan recently studied stockless systems for the Health Industry Distributors Association.  Industry Leaders Competitors in a $15 Billion Market   The nation's 6,700 hospitals spent $15 billion last year on products like disposable gloves and gowns, sutures and therapeutic solutions. Baxter International, Johnson & Johnson and Abbott Laboratories dominate the market. Baxter is the largest manufacturer of hospital supplies, with 29 percent of the market, said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a securities analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. J. & J.'s share is 11 percent, and Abbott Laboratories has about 10 percent.   Baxter is also the leading distributor, with 28 percent of that market. The company says it makes 70 percent of the products it sells. But Baxter is also a middleman for many of its manufacturing rivals; it is Johnson & Johnson's largest customer for hospital supplies. J. & J.'s hospital products unit makes one-third of its sales directly to hospitals but, unlike Baxter, does not distribute supplies for other companies. Other major suppliers include Owens & Minor Inc. in Glen Allen, Va., with $1.2 billion in 1990 sales; the A. Stuart Company in Greensburg, Pa., with $600 million, and the General Medical Corporation in Richmond, with $340 million, said Mr. Abramowitz.  Multiple Benefits 'Just-in-Time' Means Less Handling    Hospital supply expenses only begin with the $15 billion in purchases. "For every dollar spent to buy a product, hospitals spend another dollar moving that product through the system," said David Cassak, hospitals editor with In Vivo Business and Medicine Report, a trade magazine.    Stockless systems lower hospitals' holding and handling costs. "We think we've saved $1.5 million a year since 1988" from just-in-time deliveries alone, said Randy Jackson, a St. Luke's vice president, with another $500,000 likely once the stockless system is fully implemented. Annual savings already have included $350,000 from reducing staff and $162,500 from eliminating inventory. The hospital has converted storeroomsto patient care and other money-generating uses.    Vernon R. Loucks Jr., Baxter's chairman, said the company is introducing the stockless service, which it calls Valuelink, at 17 large hospitals. "We walk very carefully and slowly, because we can't afford a glitch," he said. "The first morning that an operating room doesn't open, we've got a problem."    The distributors profit from stockless services because they impose extra charges, raise prices more readily and often become a hospital's sole source of medical supplies. They typically add 3 percent to 5 percent service fees. "Our price might be slightly higher than what the hospital used to pay us, but their total cost is reduced," said Glenn Dozier, the chief financial officer with Owens & Minor, whose major stockless client is the huge medical center of the University of California at Los Angeles.   By helping hospitals reduce costs through computerized ordering, just-in-time deliveries and stockless services, suppliers have been able to raise their prices by at least 5 percent per year. They have withstood pressure from Government and private insurers and the buying clout of groups like Volunteer Hospitals, which has 600 member hospitals and 190 affiliates. Mr. Abramowitz said the hospital supply market is growing by about 8 percent a year; Baxter's sales growth in 1991 will be about 11 percent. "Stockless is Baxter's most exciting growth opportunity," he said.    Mr. Loucks said stockless services benefit both sides. "We generally take about 30 percent of whatever is saved," he said. "The hospital is picking up 70 percent."   A medical supply company does not have to be Baxter's size to exploit these opportunities. Even before Baxter jumped in, smaller suppliers like the privately held Koley's Medical Supply Inc. in Omaha were providing stockless service to a handful of customers beginning in the mid-1980's. Michael P. Gittings, Koley's president, said 18 hospitals, mostly small and all within 200 miles of Omaha, buy the service. He said Koley's sales rose to $38 million this year, compared with $6 million in 1984, before it introduced the service. Being near at hand and relatively small helped Koley's make the service work. "The hospitals have a very strong trust relationship with us," Mr. Gittings said.  Concern Over Conflicts Most Hospitals Remain Skeptical    The overwhelming majority of the nation's hospitals still shun stockless services. Some administrators fear that suppliers would write themselves larger orders than the hospitals needed. Administrators say group buying organizations already give them deep discounts. "Some hospitals would not want non-employees working in sensitive areas like ordering supplies," said Dwight Winstead, president of the VHA Supply Company, the buying unit of Voluntary Hospitals of America. Administrators of hospitals that belong to the VHA are wary of becoming hens opening the door to an eager fox, he said. "They feel there could be a conflict between supplying and servicing stockless and a corporate strategy to move products," he explained.    Some suppliers say hospitals must be on guard to realize the potential savings. "Hospitals that don't have the internal systems and controls to manage it will be in trouble," said Frank J. Ryan, president of Johnson & Johnson Hospital Services, a unit of J.& J.   Hospitals also need to see whether the savings from going stockless are greater than the extra charges. "You have to find the happy medium where the price of the product doesn't exceed the need for the service," said Jerome L. Stracke, an assistant vice president at the Evanston Hospital in Illinois.   One hospital may have found a way to realize many of the benefits from new delivery systems without the risks. The independent St. Paul-Ramsey Medical Center in St. Paul, Minn., requires Baxter and two other suppliers to bid against each other. All three provide just-in-time deliveries to the loading dock, but the hospital takes charge of internal distribution. Michael I. Kerr, St. Paul-Ramsey's support services director, said this system keeps prices and inventory costs low, with the hospital staying in control of its supplies. Last year, as the cost of medical supplies rose nationally by 4 percent to 6 percent, his hospital's costs increased only 3 percent.   'PARTNERS' IN INVENTORY CONTROL    Steve Seide, a general manager in Houston with Baxter International, and Dave Render, his operations manager, meet every day with nurses and executives in two local hospitals. "We talk about everything from a request to stock the new Diet Dr. Pepper to a complaint that a pest control truck is taking too long at the loading dock," Mr. Render said.    Mr. Seide and Mr. Render run a service that Baxter calls Valuelink at St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital and Hermann Hospital. Under this stockless system, Baxter fills precise orders for supplies and delivers them just as they are needed, directly to the departments that place the orders.    "We have become their warehouse, their central supply -- we're it," Mr. Seide said. As the hospitals phase in the stockless system, he said, "all they will have left is two to three days of supplies. Then it's all up to us."    Among other economies, stockless service has enabled Hermann Hospital to eliminate a 68,000-square-foot warehouse and St. Luke's to get rid of a 20,000-square-foot warehouse. Baxter keeps enough supplies for both institutions in an automated warehouse with only 44,000 square feet.    Baxter has used the stockless system to become a virtual partner with St. Luke's and Hermann in managing their supply flow. "We formed teams in the hospital units, with leaders and steering committees to deal with problems," Mr. Render said.   Mr. Seide said Baxter can tailor its services according to the wishes of a hospital's staff. "Seventy percent of it is good communications," he said. Based on a suggestion from the operating rooms, Baxter became part of the telephone voice mail system at St. Luke's. Anyone in an operating room can dial the letters RSVP to reach the company.    A suggestion by an operating room nurse at St. Luke's has helped Baxter prevent surgical mix-ups. Mr. Seide said she had noticed that Baxter's blue labels on pentalyte liquid, used to moisten and clean surgical incisions, closely resembled the blue labels on sterile water. Baxter, which says it was already planning to remedy the problem, promptly started putting black labels on pentalyte.   Mr. Seide and Mr. Render have good reasons for boasting of their progress at Hermann and St. Luke's. They are hoping to attract other Houston hospitals to their service. Analysts say that the more hospitals join, the greater the economies for Baxter.

headline: PROTESTANT GROUP ADMITS KILLING 4
abstract: A Protestant paramilitary group took responsibility today for shooting and killing four Roman Catholic men and seriously wounding a fifth at a village pub in Northern Ireland.   The police said two men were being questioned about the Sunday night attack in Cappagh, 50 miles west of Belfast. They identified the dead as John Quinn, 23 years old; Dwayne O'Donnell, 17; Thomas Armstrong, 52, and Malcolm Nugent, 21. Malachy Rafferty, 2l, was wounded and was reported in serious condition at a hospital. Statement Issued     The paramilitary group, the Ulster Volunteer Force, asserted responsibility for the attack in a statement carried by the Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency.

headline: 2 American Sailors Accused Of a Pro-Iraq Plot on Carrier
abstract: Two American sailors were ordered today to face a court-martial on charges of trying to sabotage a carrier in the Persian Gulf in support of Iraq, the United States Navy said.   A report from the Subic Bay Naval Station said Airman Apprentice Abdul H. Shaheed, 22 years old, of Saint George, S.C., and Seaman Apprentice James L. Moss, 21, of Marrero, La., were charged with "urging disloyalty, mutiny, or refusal of duty" on the carrier Ranger at sea in January.

headline: That Good-for-Nothing Car Is Good for a Laugh
abstract: As eastern Germany spirals toward economic collapse, people who live here have found a way to escape from the onrushing specter of unemployment and social upheaval.   They visit the local movie theater and see "Go Trabi Go," the first film comedy about German unification. It makes them laugh not precisely at themselves, but at the absurdities of the system under which they lived until last year.

headline: Nike Approach To Women
abstract: Nike has employed an all- star roster of male athletes, including Bo Jackson and Michael Jordan, to lure men to its lines of athletic footwear. But what about women, who accounted for roughly 42 percent of all athletic shoes purchased in 1990?   "We feel our advertising has to be different for women," said Lisa DeNeffe, a Nike spokeswoman. "Women look up to other women, but they don't really have specific role models as much as men do. So we took a different approach."

headline: In Ads, Simple Is Replacing Slick
abstract: There can be little doubt about the subject of a new advertising campaign splashed across the pages of Gourmet magazine and other publications aimed at the affluent. Beneath seemingly candid photographs of fashionable diners is a large banner that declares, "Remy Martin est l'eau de vie."   Jeff Weiss, the co-creative director of Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss, the advertising agency that declared Remy Martin cognac was the "water of life," said the campaign was typical of the direct, even obvious advertising that his youthful New York agency is doing these days.

headline: Three Eastern European Leaders Confer, Gingerly
abstract: The leaders of Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland met this week at the ruins of a historic castle to pledge mutual cooperation, and then to insist that they meant no offense.   Such are the delicate politics of Eastern Europe these days, where nations are eager to break with the Communist past and the Warsaw Pact, but wary of offending an increasingly unstable Soviet Union.

headline: Chip Estimate Cut By NEC Officials
abstract: The NEC Corporation, one of Japan's top makers of computers and semiconductors, lowered its estimate for production of its most sophisticated computer chips because of weak demand. NEC officials said the company had expected production of four-megabit dynamic random access memory chips to reach about four million a month by this summer. But they said output was now expected to hover around three million a month.    Company executives explained that an economic slowdown in the United States and Europe had chilled the demand for computers and other advanced electronic products using four-megabit chips, the most sophisticated now available on the market.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Continental Corp., New York, an insurance holding company, promoted Wayne H. Fisher to executive vice president and Kenneth B. Zeigler to senior vice president. Samuel T. Byron Jr. was named chairman and president of its Marine Office of America Corp. subsidiary and Thomas J. Prendergast president of Continental International Group.  * Financial Institutions Retirement Fund, White Plains, promoted Robert D. Alin to senior vice president of legal affairs and Peter T. Baxter to vice president of thrift plan services. * HQ Office Supplies Warehouse Inc., Long Beach, Calif., appointed Chet E. Howard president and chief executive, replacing George J. Handgis, who returns to the position of president and chief executive of HQ International Inc. * Prairietek Corp., Longmont, Colo., manufacturers of hard-disk drives, named Michael Cannon vice president of Southeast Asia operations. * Scor U.S. Corp., New York, a subsidiary of Societe Commerciale de Reassurance, Paris, appointed Craig Johnson vice president and manager of its alternative risk unit and Daniel Brooks president of its Unity Fire and General Insurance Co. and General Security Assurance Corp. of New York subsidiaries. * Southern Phenix Textiles Inc., Phenix City, Ala., manufacturers of polyester industrial fabrics and a subsidiary of Johnston Industries, New York, appointed Richard J. Gibney vice president of its stitchbond and automotive fabrics divisions. * Sunrise Bancorp, Fort Mitchell, Ky., named Robert Patrella president and chief executive, succeeding James Davis, who resigned.

headline: Bankruptcy by Eagle-Picher Halts Asbestos Settlement
abstract: Eagle-Picher Industries, which faces up to 70,000 asbestos-related claims, filed a petition for bankruptcy protection yesterday. The move comes three weeks after the company fended off an effort by lawyers representing asbestos victims to force it into bankruptcy proceedings.   The request for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code was filed in Cincinnati, where Eagle-Picher is based. It automatically halted all court actions involving the company, including an effort by a judge in Brooklyn to work out a nationwide settlement for present and future asbestos claims. Federal District Judge Jack B. Weinstein had hoped to use the proposed class-action settlement as the basis for resolving tens of thousands of claims against other companies.

headline: So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual: Aerospace; No Rush Soon To Reorder Arms
abstract: A short war with Iraq would not have any direct mpact on aerospace companies and other military contractors, analysts and industry executives said. The war is being fought with existing inventories of weapons systems and other hardware, and contractors generally do not expect immediate new orders to replace arms expended or lost in the conflict.   Missile manufacturers, like the Raytheon Corporation and the Hughes Aircraft Company, could eventually receive replacement orders if the military decides to rebuild its supplies of tactical weapons.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Express Co., New York, promoted Susan Collens Heide to vice president of credit research in the company's corporate investment division. * Chemical Bank, New York, promoted Patricia Meier and William E. Newell Jr. to managing directors. * Datapoint Corp. San Antonio, which develops, manufactures and markets computer and communications products, appointed Joe W. Tucker vice president of its United States operations. * Genus Inc., Mountain View, Calif., a manufacturer of tungsten chemical vapor deposition systems, named Dr. David Cheng vice president of its systems engineering unit. * Metropolitan Financial Corp., Minneapolis, a financial services holding company, appointed Steven B. Dewald senior vice president and corporate controller and chief accounting officer. * Oshkosh B'Gosh Inc., Oshkosh, Wis., a clothing manufacturer, promoted Oliver E. Wood Jr., to corporate vice president of international sales and marketing. * Polygram Holding Inc., New York, a unit of Polygram N.V., London, named Helen Murphy vice president and treasurer. * USG Corp., Chicago, which manufactures gypsum wallboard, named J. Bradford James vice president and chief financial officer. * Varian Associates Inc., Palo Alto, Calif., a producer of electron tubes and devices, named Richard A. Aurelio president. * Vical Inc., San Diego, a biopharmaceutical company, appointed Dannie King president and chief operating officer, replacing Wick Goodspeed, who resigned.

headline: Market Place; Short-Term Lift For Arms Stocks
abstract: THESE are days of trial for American military contractors. Many of the weapons systems they have built over the last two decades have been deployed in the war with Iraq. And after years of being derided as a hotbed of fraud and waste, the industry has gotten a big psychological lift from seeing many of its advanced products work as advertised in the heat of combat.   The financial implications and the lasting effects of the war on the stock prices of arms makers are much less clear.

headline: Child World Receives Offer Competing With Earlier Bid
abstract: A second investor group announced a bid for Child World Inc. yesterday, in competition with an earlier agreement with WC Acquisition, a group led by two former Toys "R" Us executives. But Child World's largest shareholder reacted coolly to the second bid and said he continued to favor the earlier deal.   The new offer, by Baytree Investors Inc., is just as mysterious as that of WC Acquisition in that neither bid carries a total price tag, or at least one that has been made public.

headline: In Crowded Japan, a Bonus For Babies Angers Women
abstract: With its crowded roads, overstuffed commuter trains and cramped housing, Japan would hardly seem to be in need of more people. So when the Government recently started telling the Japanese to bear more children, many people, especially women, became incensed.    The focus of their irritation was a soon-to-be-offered "reward" of 5,000 yen, or $38, a month for each child of pre-school age, and twice as much for a third child, the centerpiece of a spreading campaign to combat a birth rate that has plummeted to its lowest level in history.  'Trying to Be Equal'     The baby bonuses were inspired by officials concerned that at the current rate, Japan's population will decline after the turn of the century, causing labor shortages, sluggish economic growth and higher tax burdens to support social services for the elderly.

headline: More on the Gulf
