abstract: Iraqi Leader Warns Of Plan for Holy War    President Saddam Hussein told a conference of Islamic leaders that he was preparing for a holy war against the American-led military alliance in the Persian Gulf that could be averted only if greater priority was given to solving the Palestinian issue.     Mr. Hussein spoke of war preparations, of cleansing the Arab lands of what he called corruption and of liberating Palestinians. He made no reference to the impending arrival of the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, seeking an 11th-hour commitment from Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Page 9. Bush Asking Israel To Stay Out of Conflict    President Bush sent a high-level mission to inform Israel that the United States would try to protect it from Iraqi attack should war erupt and to urge Israel to stay out of the conflict.     Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger left for Israel, accompanied by Pentagon and State Department officials. Mr. Bush previously urged Israel not to undertake any pre-emptive action against Iraq, a request that Israeli officials have said they will honor. Page 8.

headline: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
abstract: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.    The pool reporters obtain information while under military escort, and their accounts are subject to scrutiny by military censors before being distributed. Some of the information appearing today on American military operations was obtained under such circumstances.

headline: Roll-Call in House on Measure Authorizing the Use of Force
abstract: Following is the 250-to-183 roll call today by which the House gave President Bush the authority to wage war in the Persian Gulf. A yes vote is a vote to authorize the use of U.S. armed forces pursuant to U.N. Security Council Resolution 678. Voting yes were 86 Democrats and 164 Republicans. Voting no were 179 Democrats and 3 Republicans. Also voting no was 1 Independent. X denotes those not voting.Present denotes those who voted they were "present" at the time of the vote but did not vote "yes" or "no" on the issue.

headline: Chandris Picks Korey, Kay
abstract: Korey, Kay & Partners has been awarded the account for Chandris Celebrity Cruises, worth an estimated $10 million in billings.    The agency won in a review that included Bozell and the incumbent, Grey Entertainment and Media, which will retain the Chandris Fantasy Cruises account.    Albert C. Wallack, the senior vice president for marketing and passenger service for Chandris, based in New York, said Korey, Kay was picked because of its "outstanding creative style." Mr. Wallack said he was particularly impressed by the humorous campaign Korey, Kay created for Virgin Atlantic Airways.    Although Mr. Wallack would not say what strategy would be used in the campaign, he said the print and radio ads would not position the line as a "floating" resort, as some cruise ads do. "The advertising in this category is so similar," he said. "It's difficult for consumers to tell the difference between the competitors."

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The General; Briefing by Powell: A Data-Filled Showcase
abstract: In a nationally broadcast report on the Persian Gulf war today at the Pentagon, Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, showcased himself in a new role, that of an articulate and persuasive spokesman for Bush Administration policy.    "The comments I heard are that he had the press eating out of his hand," said a Government official who is regularly briefed by General Powell. "Whether that's good or bad, I don't know."

headline: Credit Cards Back $750 Million Issue
abstract: Chase Manhattan Credit Card Trust 1991-1, established by the Chase Manhattan Corporation, is offering $750 million in asset-backed securities through Chase Securities. The debt issue is backed by Visa and Mastercard credit card receivables.    The securities, which pay interest monthly, have an average life of 3.53 years and an expected final maturity of March 15, 1995, with a legal final maturity date of Nov. 15, 1997.   Underwriters said interest and principal payments were supported by a letter of credit provided by the Union Bank of Switzerland. That backing gave the issues a rating of Aaa by Moody's Investors Service and AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: SUNDAY: Financial ministers from leading industrialized nations begin a two-day meeting in New York. MONDAY: Martin Luther King holiday. Markets open; many government offices closed.  TUESDAY: Postal Service Board of Governors meets to consider postal rates. * Fed Chairman Greenspan testifies before House Budget Committee.  WEDNESDAY: Treasury deficit statement for December. * Fed Open Market Committee's beige book regional economic report. THURSDAY: Mid-January auto sales. * Jobless claims for the week ended Jan. 12.  FRIDAY: G.N.P. for the fourth quarter.

headline: Tech Notes; A Faster Way to Make Computers
abstract: A new class of transistor is being developed as a effort of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the International Business Machines Corporation. The new device turns on or off on the power of just a single electron. Conventional transistors require currents many times more massive before they will turn on or off to create the binary messages of computing. The new device is constructed like a four-layer sandwich of gallium arsenide, aluminum arsenide and gallium arsenide, topped off with a metallic layer that serves as a conductor. The gallium layers contain impurities, or "dope," that provide a source of electrons. At present, the transistor works only at temperatures approaching absolute zero, but the researchers say that problem can be solved. Although still years from commercialization, the new device could be used to fabricate computers far faster than any in use today.

headline: Credibility, Too, Is a Victim Of the Repression in Vilnius
abstract: Yelena Trifanova turned on her television Sunday evening to hear the latest news about events in Lithuania and, she said, she felt as if she had stepped back in time, to the years before Mikhail S. Gorbachev became the Soviet leader and began encouraging honest and truthful reporting.    The announcer described the army's killing of pro-independence demonstrators in the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius, as a defensive action, and the story he told was completely different from what she had heard earlier in radio reports by the B.B.C., Radio Liberty and the Voice of America.

headline: Channel in Bankruptcy
abstract: Channel Home Centers Inc. filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code today and announced it would sell or close 34 of its 86 home improvement stores. Joseph Nusim, president and chief executive officer, said the company would concentrate on New Jersey and Pennsylvania by closing stores in Baltimore, Washington, and New England. The company reached agreement with the General Electric Capital Corporation for up to $145 million in financing that effectively puts G.E. first in line for repayment.

headline: New-Home Sales Lowest Since 1982
abstract: New-home sales plunged in January to their lowest level in eight and a half years, the Government said today, but analysts, saying buyers had become more active in recent weeks, forecast a modest improvement this year.   "January was a month of high anxiety," with spending curtailed because of concern over the Persian Gulf war and the recession, said Richard Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association.

headline: Limited's Net Climbs 12.5%
abstract: Limited Inc. said today its fourth-quarter profits rose by 12.5 percent from a year earlier as sales increased 10.2 percent.   The specialty apparel retailer said it earned $172.2 million, or 48 cents a share, in the three months ended Feb. 2. That compared with $153.1 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: Brazil May Abandon Nuclear Sub Program
abstract: Brazil may abandon its program to build a nuclear-powered submarine if the United States opposes it, Foreign Minister Jose Francisco Rezek said in an interview published today.    Political analysts said it was the first clear indication from the Government that the project could be scrapped if the United States put strong pressure on Brazil.

headline: 4 Soviet Republics Defy Gorbachev on Currency
abstract: Four Soviet republics, including Russia, challenged President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today by giving their residents more time to exchange high-denomination ruble notes before they become worthless.   The central State Bank declared the extensions illegal, but for the second day, thousands massed at banks. In Leningrad, two people died of heart attacks and 19 were injured waiting to exchange money, a police spokesman said. Details of what caused the injuries were not clear.

headline: Treasury Securities a Big Hit With Americans Last Year
abstract: Individual American investors bought a record $120.5 billion worth of Treasury securities last year, according to data from the Federal Reserve Board. The purchases by individuals came to nearly 45 percent of the more than $272 billion in securities issued in 1990 to finance the budget deficit.   "That is an eye-opening number," said William M. Brachfeld, executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America. "But in the aggregate, individuals are more intelligent making investment decisions than the professionals who manage money. And there were lots of good reasons to be in high-quality securities last year."

headline: More on the Gulf
abstract: OIL DOWN Oil fell 71 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange, to $30.07 a barrel, as traders awaited last-minute developments in the Persian Gulf. Business Day, page D1.    YAWNS OR PANIC? Stock market history suggests that a Middle East war, because it is so widely expected, could initially provoke little reaction. But if the war goes badly, complacency could be replaced by panic. Market Place, page D1.    SHIPPING INSURANCE UP At Lloyd's of London, Christopher Rome is giving rates on insurance for tankers operating in the Persian Gulf -- and the rates are rising. Page D1.

headline: Apple Cutting Computer Price
abstract: Continuing its recent strategy of moving to increase market share by cutting profit margins, Apple Computer Inc. announced significant price reductions today on its mid-range and high-end Macintosh personal computers.    The price cuts on the SE/30, IIci and IIfx modes range from 10 percent to 31 percent and are effective immediately. The SE/ 30 is now $3,369 to $3,869, depending on hard disk drive and memory; the IIci is now $5,269 to $5,969, and the IIfx is now $7,369 to $8,669.

headline: Israel, Rebuffing U.S. Plea, Says It Will Answer Attack
abstract: Defense Minister Moshe Arens made clear today that Israel would not meet an American request to stay out of a Persian Gulf war if it is attacked.    After two hours of talks with a high-ranking American delegation, Mr. Arens drove to an air base in the northern Galilee region and said: "If we are attacked, we will respond. If attacked we will respond. I believe what I've said is quite sufficient."

headline: Treaty Dispute With Soviets Causes Delay in Troop Talks
abstract: Negotiators at arms talks here agreed today to postpone further formal meetings toward a new round of talks until March 21 as a consequence of a dispute over a Soviet interpretation of the conventional arms treaty signed last November.    The delay was suggested by NATO countries and unanimously approved in a plenary session of the 22 countries involved in the arms talks. The decision in effect halts the negotiations here, which were called for in the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe that was signed in Paris in November. The talks, which opened last week, are intended to reduce the number of troops in Europe and establish an aerial inspection system.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Pan Am Bankruptcy    Pan Am filed for bankruptcy protection, the third of the nine largest U.S. carriers to do so in the last 22 months.  [ Page A1. ]   Pan Am ticket holders will not be affected, Pan Am executives and travel agents said.  [ D6. ]   The Transportation Department tentatively approved the sales by Pan Am and T.W.A. of lucrative international routes.  [ D6. ] The Economy    Overstuffed mailboxes are about to get a breather. Direct marketers are being advised to wait until after Jan. 15.  [ D1. ]   Wall Street is preparing for war. New rules are being put in place in case Mideast hostilities break out.  [ D2. ]   Taxpayers who believe income tax laws do not apply cannot be convicted of criminal violations, the Supreme Court ruled.  [ D2. ]   Price data in the market for Government securities should be made widely available, a top Federal regulator said.  [ D3. ]   Officials recommended that Neil Bush be barred from working at any institution that received Federal insurance until he showed that he understood conflicts of interest.  [ D8. ]   Consumer debt grew by a slim $1.72 billion in November, the Government said, in another reflection of consumer caution.  [ D3. ]   The Senate Ethics Committee voted to excuse Cranston, who is ill, from public questioning on his ties to Keating.  [ A14. ] Companies    Cheney's decision to cancel the A-12 comes as McDonnell Douglas and General Dynamics face other troubles.  [ D1. ]  The cancellation has set off a Pentagon scramble for a replacement.  [ A12. ]   Kodak and Sanofi of Paris will create a company that will reportedly have $3 billion in drug sales.  [ D1. ]   Ford's strength has declined to the point that directors face a tough decision on the dividend.  [ D1. ]  Donald Petersen's decision to step aside two years ago was reportedly not his alone.  [ D4. ]   Japan gave United Airlines only limited permission to fly a new route from Chicago to Tokyo.  [ D6. ]   Sabena said it would record big losses for 1990, after British Airways and KLM pulled out of a joint venture.  [ D6. ]   Microsoft will turn up the heat on Lotus today when it introduces a version of its Excel spreadsheet program.  [ D7. ]   G.M.'s Saturn division will absorb up to $5.8 million in fees it originally charged to dealers, company officials said.  [ D4. ]   MCA agreed to sell its interest in the Yosemite tourist operations to a private nonprofit foundation.  [ A18. ] Business Technology    A radically different approach to air pollution -- converting harmful combustion waste products into something useful -- is being tested at New England's only cement plant.  [ D7. ]  Markets    In a surprise move, the Fed sent a signal that suggested it had again lowered a key short-term interest rate.  [ D1. ]   Stocks lost further ground for the fifth straight session. The Dow closed at 2,509.41, off 13.36.  [ D8. ]   Oil prices fell slightly in a nervous session.  [ D15. ]  The dollar rose broadly.  [ D15. ] Today's Columns    The stock market has gotten off to its second-worst start in history. Floyd Norris: Market Place.  [ D1. ]   Looking for a painless primer on the Soviet economic crisis and how it might be solved? Peter Passell: Economic Scene.  [ D2. ]   The owners of a California winery are quoting bad reviews as well as good in their ads. Advertising.  [ D5. ]

headline: Savings Bailout Delay Seen Without New Funds
abstract: Senior regulators said today that the Government's bailout of the savings and loan industry would stall if Congress and the Administration failed to reach agreement by next week on new financing for the effort.   "If we don't get the funds by the first week of March, then the delay starts," said Peter H. Monroe, president of the oversight board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Cabinet-level panel supervising the bailout effort. He predicted that a delay in closing or selling savings and loan institutions in Government hands would cost an additional $8 million to $9 million a day to pay for their continued operations and maintenance of assets.

headline: Publisher Takes On a Declining Paperback Market
abstract: At a time when fewer mass-market paperbacks are being sold, Little, Brown & Company is preparing to start publishing them.   When some industry executives learned about Little, Brown's intentions almost six months ago, they likened it to a suicide mission. But the company, a unit of Time Warner Inc., considers a mass-market paperback operation neccessary to compete for the big-money books increasingly being sold as part of a hardcover-paperback package.

headline: Businessland Reports Loss
abstract: Businessland Inc., the troubled personal computer retailer, on Tuesday reported declining sales and continued losses for its second quarter.    For the quarter that ended on Dec. 31, Businessland reported a loss of $4.6 million, compared with a loss of $2.1 million in the comparable period a year earlier. Sales dropped 11 percent, to $334.4 million, from $375 million in the quarter a year earlier. The current quarter includes a tax benefit of $4.3 million and a one-time charge of $800,000.    Businessland's shares jumped 75 cents today, to $2, on the New York Stock Exchange.   "We further reduced our inventories during the quarter and continued our previously announced staff reduction program," David A. Norman, Businessland's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. "We have reduced our worldwide staff 25 percent and will benefit from the resultant reduced expense levels beginning in the third quarter."

headline: A Net Loss Is Posted by Time Warner
abstract: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had record earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization in the fourth quarter, but that it had a net loss of $34 million because of interest expenses and accounting treatments for Time Inc.'s acquisition of Warner Communications Inc. at the beginning of 1990.    The media conglomerate said that income before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization in the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1990 was $634 million on revenue of $3.3 billion.

headline: Monk Magazine Takes Founders on a Rewarding Journey
abstract: Jim Crotty and Michael Lane travel the country in a mobile home, writing about themselves and America on a solar-powered Macintosh.    They are the modern troubadors who publish Monk, a whimsical travel magazine. Four times a year, Mr. Lane and Mr. Crotty tell with playful respect the stories of New Mexican shamans, Nebraskan bingo addicts and people they meet in trailer parks.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Iran; For U.S. and Iran, a Chance for Ties
abstract: Iraq's military defeat and the prospect of creating new security arrangements for the Persian Gulf provide an opportunity for the United States and Iran to repair their long-tattered relationship -- if the two sides choose to do so.   The two countries have emerged from the gulf war with three common goals: the military containment of Iraq, preservation of Iraq's territorial integrity and the creation of a postwar security structure in which Teheran plays an important political role.

headline: U.N. Security Council Drafts Plan To Scrap Most Deadly Iraqi Arms
abstract: The five permanent Security Council members are close to agreement on a plan to end the gulf war that is the most complex and ambitious effort the United Nations has ever made to settle a war and punish an aggressor.    The new draft resolution, hammered out in talks here early this morning involving the representatives of the five nations -- Britain, China, France, the Soviet Union and the United States -- orders the destruction of Iraq's most dangerous weapons, bans all military sales to its armed forces indefinitely and earmarks a percentage of all its future oil income to pay for damage caused by the annexation of Kuwait.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Arabs; Arabs in Many Nations Protest Bombing
abstract: Flags were at half-staff and tempers in full cry in many Arab nations today, as people took to the streets to grieve for Iraq's civilian dead and to damn the United States for what they called a deliberate massacre of women and children.   Protests swept across several countries, including Yemen, the Sudan, Libya and Tunisia, which along with Jordan declared a period of national mourning.

headline: Amid Talk of Peace, The Fighting Goes On
abstract: While peace was being discussed in Moscow, each side pressed attacks on the other.   The allies said they had pummeled Iraqi positions with the biggest artillery barrage of the war, and United States warplanes bombed Baghdad just as the Iraqi radio began broadcasting President Saddam Hussein's speech vowing to continue fighting.   Iraq fired three Scud missiles into Saudi Arabia in a rare but ineffective daylight launching.   A ranking United States commander said the American-led coalition had destroyed 2,100 of Iraq's 4,200 main battle tanks, up from 1,400 a week ago. The new figure means the allies have reached the level of destruction specified by several senior generals and politicians as the minimum needed before a ground offensive.   Article, page A10.

headline: Managua Defends Army Chief in Missile Uproar
abstract: Defying pressure from its political allies and the United States, the Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has defended Nicaragua's military commander against criticism in the recent transfer of Soviet-made antiaircraft missiles from Nicaraguan Army stockpiles to Salvadoran guerrillas.   The secret shipment, admitted by the Nicaraguan Army last week, placed Mrs. Chamorro's Government in violation of regional accords barring support for the subversion of neighboring countries.

headline: Your Money; One Simple Way To Help on Taxes
abstract: This may be the simplest advice an accountant ever gave. Yet for some people it could save no end of aggravation and even money. It concerns all those envelopes that arrive from mid-January through early February marked important tax document: Open them straightaway.    "Take two minutes now to check the figures and see if they look right," said Nicholas A. Nesi, a partner in BDO Seidman in New York. "If there is an error, contact the issuer immediately and get a corrected 1099 or W-2 issued."

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Israel; P.L.O. and Israel See Positive Signs in Bush's Mideast Speech
abstract: A Palestinian said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization was reconsidering a decision not to talk with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.   On his way to the Middle East on Thursday, Mr. Baker said, "If Palestinians want to meet, I would of course be pleased to meet with them." Today, the leading P.L.O. representative in the occupied territories, Faisal al-Husseini, said the P.L.O. was reconsidering its position of spurning Mr. Baker.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: An article on the Forum page last Sunday about effects of the Persian Gulf war on other nations referred incompletely to the area where people from third world nations were working before the war. In addition to Kuwait, they were in Iraq. The article also misstated the number of Filipino workers in those countries; it was 90,000, not 500,000.

headline: Bank Insurance in S.E.C. Study
abstract: A Securities and Exchange Commission study indicates that the Federal Government supplies banking deposit insurance far below what it is worth.    The study, released on Thursday by the S.E.C.'s Office of Economic Analysis, was requested by the commission's chairman, Richard C. Breeden, who was a key figure in the savings and loan bailout strategy two years ago when he was a White House aide.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: The Executive Life column on Feb. 3 about a sale at Guernsey's Auction House misidentified the current owner of a wine bottle once owned by Thomas Jefferson. It is Lloyd's of London; after the bottle was broken, the insurer took it over from the New York wine merchant William Sokolin.

headline: Agent Sees Bo's Injury as 'a Lucky Break'
abstract: BO JACKSON the athlete may be on the bench, but Bo Jackson the product spokesman may be busier than ever, said Richard Woods, a lawyer in Mobile, Ala., who is Mr. Jackson's agent.    "In some ways this is a lucky break," Mr. Woods said yesterday. "This will give him a lot of time to work on new and ongoing projects."

headline: Spanish Town Is Largely Unmoved by B-52's
abstract: The dark, bristling tails of 15 giant B-52's look strangely out of place against a backdrop of olive groves, green wheat fields and scattered cows. And except when the long-range bombers roar down the runway, the entire area is wrapped in silence.    But the isolation of the Moron air base, 250 miles southwest of Madrid and 15 miles from the nearest town, is apparently one reason why it was chosen by the United States and Spain as a staging post for B-52 bombing missions against Iraq.

headline: U.S. EXPERTS SPLIT OVER THE SECURITY OF EUROPE A-ARMS
abstract: In a top-secret dispute, Federal experts are divided over whether the thousands of nuclear arms the nation deploys in Europe are as safe as they should be from sabotage and theft.    The rift comes at a time of political tensions created by the Persian Gulf war, with American nuclear forces in Europe on high-level alert against terrorist attack.

headline: Tokyo Is Cautious On Mideast Aid
abstract: Japan adopted a cautious approach today to suggestions that it undertake a major aid program for the Middle East, as officials showed some embarrassment that fighting had ended with Parliament still debating an earlier pledge to aid the war effort.    In the last week or so, senior associates of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu have begun suggesting that Japan should lead the way to help create a new "Marshall Plan" for the Middle East, in part to mitigate its reputation for aloofness, which was reinforced because of its slowness in aiding the war effort.

headline: I.R.S. Seeks $5 Billion From Drexel
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service filed a claim for more than $5 billion today against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. for back taxes, interest and penalties.    Tax experts in Washington said there had been bigger claims filed by the I.R.S. against corporations but that the claim against Drexel ranked among the largest.

headline: Development's President Quits
abstract: Thomas Hutchinson, who took over as president of the General Development Corporation six months ago, has quit, the embattled construction company said today.   Mr. Hutchinson joined General shortly after the firm was charged with fraudulent home sales and filed for bankruptcy protection.   "There's just not a whole lot of major day-to-day challenges left in the operation," Mr. Hutchinson said. His resignation took effect on Monday, but he will remain as a consultant and director at least through January.   General Development's top executives quit in March after the company was accused of systematically bilking more than 10,000 home buyers at its nine planned Florida communities.   The company pleaded guilty to one fraud conspiracy count to end the criminal case against the corporation; four former executives face a trial in October.   J. Larry Rutherford, recruited by Mr. Hutchinson as executive vice president of operations in September becomes president, chief operating officer and acting chief executive. He is a former president of the Gulfstream Land and Development Corporation.

headline: The 22% Rise in Postal Costs Upsets Magazine Publishers
abstract: Already suffering from a pervasive advertising recession, magazine publishers are now facing the more formidable problem of a 22 percent increase in second-class mail, which will go into effect Sunday.    "Coupled with the 18 percent increase that we had in 1988, our costs have gone up 40 percent in a three-year period," said D. Claeys Bahrenburg, the president and chief executive of Hearst Magazines, which publishes Good Housekeeping and Cosmopolitan. "We are basically appalled by it."

headline: Your Own Account; The Awkward Full Nest Syndrome
abstract: A Washington professional in his mid-50's is facing this prospect: His oldest son, out of work and unable to pay his mortgage, feels he has no choice but to bring his wife and two children to live in his parent's home while he looks for a job.  The professional, who refuses to let his name be used, reported mixed feelings at best. "As much as I love my children and grandchildren, I'm at a different point in life now," he said. "My wife and I thought we'd be staying out late to have supper together. Now there's the same urgency to get home after work to take care of the chores. These things may seem petty, but they become hot buttons."

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Combat; Raids Said to Badly Delay Baghdad Messages to Front
abstract: The allies in the Persian Gulf believe that they have so severely disrupted Iraqi communications that it takes 24 hours for President Saddam Hussein to get a message to the front by reasonably secure means, American intelligence officers said today.    "They have backup networks we haven't been able to destroy," one officer said, "but they're pretty primitive. So they have two choices: Either they take the chance that we'll monitor their traffic, or they use safer but very slow methods to get the word from Baghdad to their people in the field. Once the land battle starts, that won't be nearly good enough."

headline: New Cable TV Service Names Its Chairman
abstract: John J. Sie has been named chairman and chief executive of Encore, a new national pay cable television service.    Mr. Sie, who is 54 years old, is resigning as senior vice president at Tele-Communciations Inc., the nation's largest cable television operator, to join Encore, which will be jointly owned by Mr. Sie's company, JJS Communications Inc. and Liberty Media.

headline: Britain Says Computer Theft Wasn't Work of Iraqi Agents
abstract: The Defense Ministry said today that a laptop computer containing military secrets was stolen from a Royal Air Force staff officer's car by ordinary thieves and not by Iraqi agents.   "We know it was a normal theft and not the work of Iraqi agents," a Defense Ministry spokesman said on condition of anonymity. "We're doing everything -- normal and abnormal -- to get it back."    The computer and a briefcase containing military documents "related to the gulf" was stolen from the car belonging to Air Chief Marshal Sir Patrick Hine's staff officer, Wing Comdr. David Farquhar. Air Chief Marshal Hine is commander in chief of British forces in the Persian Gulf. Commander Farquhar has since been transferred.

headline: February Sales Down As Wariness Persists
abstract: Most of the nation's largest store chains remained on a slow track in February, despite the end of fighting in the Persian Gulf late in the month. With consumers apparently showing little early interest in new spring clothing, many merchants yesterday reported declines or no gains in stores open at least a year.   Sears, J. C. Penney, Woolworth, Dayton Hudson, May Department Stores and the Limited were among those reporting year-to-year declines in sales at stores open at least a year, or same-store sales. In fact, of 20 of the nation's largest retailers reporting their sales for last month, 11 had decreases or minimal gains.

headline: U.S. SAYS HUSSEIN IS NEAR A VICTORY OVER SHIITE REBELS
abstract: Administration officials said today that President Saddam Hussein may be close to crushing the Shiite Muslim rebellion against his authority in southern Iraq. The officials, monitoring intelligence reports from the region, also predicted that he would then prevail over the Kurdish uprising that still threatens Baghdad's control over northern Iraq.   The Iraqi leader strengthened his position as the Bush Administration debated whether to become more deeply involved in protecting the rebels by carrying out its threat to prevent any flights by Iraqi helicopter gunships, which officials said had been important in crushing the last rebel strongholds. Helicopter Attacks Continue     Iraqi security forces continue to fly helicopter assaults on the rebels, Administration officials said, despite an attempt last week by United States military commanders in the Persian Gulf to stop the attacks by warning Iraq that such flights would be considered a threat to allied forces.

headline: Earthquake Kills 109 in Pakistan
abstract: A severe earthquake jolted the country before dawn today, sending panic-stricken residents fleeing into the streets. Officials quoted by the official press agency said that at least 109 people in Pakistan had been killed and 350 injured.   The quake, centered hundreds of miles away in Afghanistan, measured 6.8 on the Richter scale. The minute-long tremor struck at 4 A.M., when most people were in bed.

headline: Katharine Graham's Son To Head Washington Post
abstract: The Washington Post Company announced yesterday that on May 9 Donald E. Graham would replace his mother, Katharine Graham, as chief executive. Mrs. Graham will continue as chairman.   Mr. Graham, who is 45 years old, will also become president of the company and will remain as publisher of The Washington Post, a position he has held since 1979.

headline: Business Groups Fight Laws In California on Wage Scales
abstract: Several communities in the San Francisco Bay area have enacted what labor lawyers say are the nation's first local laws that specify the wages to be paid to employees of private businesses.    Alarmed business groups, fearing that such laws will become a nationwide trend, are seeking to have them struck down in court. That action has set the stage for a highly emotional battle between the business groups and labor unions, which support the laws and stand to benefit from them.

headline: Car Output Off in Week
abstract: United States auto makers are scheduled to make 99,810 cars this week, compared with 108,706 a week ago and 135,907 in the comparable week in 1990, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. Light-truck production for the week was scheduled at 64,028, compared with last week's 61,345 and last year's 89,170, the trade journal reported.

headline: Bringing Haiti's Shattered Economy Back From the Brink
abstract: When Jacques Auguste returned here in 1960 armed with an engineering degree and visions of founding his own building materials company, he quickly discovered how little of what he had learned at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute prepared him for the rigors of doing business in his native Haiti.    Not long after opening a small cinder-block factory in 1961, Mr. Auguste found his workers besieged by the Tontons Macoute, the militia of the recently enthroned dictator, Francois Duvalier.

headline: Iraq Aide Vows Action on CBS Crew
abstract: The fate of four missing CBS News journalists was raised at today's meeting between the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Foreign Minister, who promised to take action on the matter, a Soviet official said.   A CBS News correspondent, Bob Simon, and his three-man crew disappeared four weeks ago near the Kuwaiti border with Saudi Arabia. The first definitive report that they were alive came on Friday, with the network saying it had confirmed they were being held in Baghdad.   Missing with Mr. Simon are Peter Bluff, the network's London bureau chief; Roberto Alvarez, a freelance cameraman, and Juan Caldera, a freelance sound technician.   A Soviet Presidential spokesman, Vitaly Ignatenko, said Gorbachev discussed the detained CBS journalists during his three-and-a-half- hour meeting with Mr. Aziz.    Mr. Ignatenko said, "For the first time we heard from Aziz that he is familiar with the issue, that he is knowledgeable."    He added, "We received assurances that this issue would be dealt with."

headline: U S West Fined $10 Million For Violating Phone Accord
abstract: In the largest antitrust fine ever levied by the Justice Department, one of the companies created by the breakup of A.T.&T. has agreed to pay $10 million for several violations, one of which was termed unfair competition against A.T.&T.    The company, U S West Inc., said yesterday that the activities had violated the agreement that broke up the Bell System. That 1982 accord, known as the Modified Final Judgment, basically bans the "Baby Bells" from designing or making telephone equipment, offering long-distance service, or creating information services like stock-market quotes.

headline: Fixed Mortgages Rise
abstract: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.29 percent this week, up slightly from 9.25 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the first increase since mid-January. The 9.25 percent rate last week was the lowest since rates averaged 9.07 percent in the week that ended on March 27, 1987. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.57 percent, down from 7.59 percent last week and the lowest since a 7.56 percent rate for the week that ended on May 18, 1988.

headline: Patents; Electric Jolt Removes Itch From a Bite
abstract: An inventor in Minneapolis received patent approval this week for a battery-powered device that uses a minute electrical jolt to take the itch out of bug bites.    Designed to help campers, hikers and others who spend time outdoors, the handheld device consists of a 9-volt battery connected to electrode tips arranged in a dime-sized circle. It was invented by Marlin R. Pierson, a personal computer programmer at a Minnesota bank, who said it could soothe itches from mosquitoes and most other insects in 30 seconds.

headline: V..A. Lowering Loan Rates
abstract: The Veterans Affairs Department said today that it was lowering its maximum interest rate for federally backed V.A. home mortgages by half a percentage point, to 9 percent, effective Tuesday.   "This is the second time in less than three months that the V.A. has led the way in stimulating the housing market by lowering interest rates," said the V.A. Secretary, Edward J. Derwinski.   The department lowered the rate from 10 percent to 9.5 percent on Nov. 19. The V.A. had raised the rate half a percentage point, to 10 percent, in February 1990.   The latest action puts the rate below 9.5 percent for the first time since April 1987, the department said.   The department also lowered by half a percentage point the maximum rate for graduated payment mortgages to 9.25 percent, home improvement loans to 10.5 percent, manufactured-home loans to 11.5 percent, manufactured-homes lots-only loans to 11 percent and manufactured home-and-lot loans to 11 percent.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Henszey & Albert, a New York agency, announced three new accounts: Parlux, a fragrance company, with a budget of $3 million; Marika, a women's apparel company, with a budget of $1 million, and Atomic Entertainment, an independent production company, with a budget of $1 million. * Insurance Information Institute, an association of property and casualty insurers, to Brouillard Communications, New York, a division of J. Walter Thompson Co. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: U.S. IS TAKING OVER A GROUP OF BANKS TO HEAD OFF A RUN
abstract: Acting to avert a run on one of the nation's largest banking companies, the Federal Government today seized the Bank of New England and two affiliated banks and said it would protect all depositors until the banks could be sold.    The rescue is likely to cost taxpayers at least $2.3 billion, making it one of the costliest bailouts in history.

headline: Loss Is Expected At Boise Cascade
abstract: The Boise Cascade Corporation told securities analysts it expects a loss of about $16 million in the first quarter of 1991, largely because of a weak paper market. Net income for the first quarter of 1990 was $33.6 million, while income in the fourth quarter came to $4.8 million.   The company said the decline stemmed from lower paper prices, the weak economy, excess industry capacity and slow construction activity, which reduced demand for wood products. The company said it had reduced budgets and was cutting capital expenditures by about $500 million in 1991. Boise Cascade shares slipped 37.5 cents, to $26.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: A Fare War With a Difference
abstract: When American Airlines announced this week what it called the largest fare promotion in its history, it looked like the start of an old-fashioned fare war: one carrier slashing ticket prices, absorbing losses for a while in a gamble to increase its market share.    But industry analysts say they detect a difference in the strategy adopted by the airline that is widely viewed as the industry's most savvy marketer: The changes could actually improve American's financial picture immediately, even in the difficult times now facing the industry.

headline: Ex-Leader of Bulgaria Faces More Charges, Official Says
abstract: Todor Zhivkov, the ousted Communist leader already on trial for embezzlement of public funds, faces a second trial on charges of persecuting Bulgaria's Turkish minority, the chief military prosecutor has said.   The official, Lilko Yotsov, said an indictment against Mr. Zhivkov and five top Communists would be submitted in the near future, but he gave no date. He did not specify the exact charges, newspapers reported Friday.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Jordan; Jordanian Ends Neutrality, Assailing Allied War Effort
abstract: Evoking Islamic faith and Arab honor, King Hussein of Jordan abandoned his professed neutrality in the Persian Gulf war tonight to align himself with Iraq.   The allied war effort, he declared, is "against all Arabs and all Muslims and not against Iraq alone" and is intended to assert "foreign hegemony" in the Middle East.

headline: Wall Street; Supermarkets That Win Favor, Even With 'Junk'
abstract: Given the incessant grousing by reluctant "junk bond" holders -- from insurance companies to Uncle Sam -- it is notable to hear of investors who won't part with their junk for love or money. The owners of the Kroger Company's junior subordinated notes, for example.   In November, Kroger offered to exchange up to $350 million of the notes, which will start paying 15.5 percent interest in 1993, for a new issue of 13.5 percent notes that would pay cash interest here and now. The bondholders' answer: Forget it.

headline: CRISIS CONTINUING IN INDIA'S POLITICS
abstract: Chandra Shekhar, India's caretaker Prime Minister since his resignation on Wednesday, accused Rajiv Gandhi and his Congress Party today of bringing the country "to the brink of disaster."   In a television speech to the nation tonight, Mr. Shekhar said the irresponsible behavior of people he had trusted had created a constitutional crisis. He did not name former Prime Minister Gandhi or his party, but there was no doubt about their identity.

headline: Land War's Vanguard
abstract: Two days before the ground assault on Iraqi forces began in earnest, a vanguard of more than 3,000 marines secretly moved more than 10 miles into Kuwait, officers say.     Article, page 16.

headline: A Digest for Hungary
abstract: The Reader's Digest Association said last week that it would begin publishing a Hungarian-language edition of Reader's Digest in October. The magazine will be published by a wholly owned subsidiary in Budapest.

headline: Bond Prices Are Trimmed a Bit
abstract: Credit market participants sat through another slow session yesterday, and prices of Treasury securities again were mixed, as bond prices fell while prices of short-term bills and notes inched a bit higher.    Traders and analysts attributed the mild selloff of long-term securities to profit taking in advance of important economic data expected to be released today. The coming long holiday weekend may have provided another impetus to lighten positions, they added.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE>; Heads of Six New Units Named by Nestle USA
abstract: Nestle USA Inc., the umbrella company created this year to manage the American operations of Nestle S.A., has been reorganized to combine 15 food and beverage companies into six units. In doing so, the company also made several executive changes.   Timm Crull, 59, the president and chief executive of the new Los Angeles-based company since Jan. 1, remains at the top. His position seems solidified with the announcement yesterday that Jim Biggar, 62, the chairman of Nestle USA, will retire on July 1. No immediate successor has been named.

headline: What the Best-Dressed Astronaut Will Now Wear
abstract: While many products, from automobiles to appliances, have been redesigned to reduce weight, when it comes to space suits for astronauts, the nation's space program has left the weight issue behind.    During NASA's Apollo space program in the 1960's and 70's, weight was a major concern because of the gravity involved in lunar missions. But in flying shuttle missions, gravity is no longer an issue. In a weightless environment, heavier, less expensive materials can be used in space suits, said the Hamilton Standards division of the United Technologies Corporation, the nation's leading maker of the suits.

headline: Appointment At Times
abstract: The New York Times has appointed Susan Greendale Russo group director of planning, operations and The New York Times Magazine, Erich G. Linker Jr., senior vice president for advertising, said yesterday.   Mrs. Russo, 38 years old, who joined The Times in 1979 as a marketing research project manager, has been director of strategic and financial planning for the advertising department since April 1989. As a group director, she will also be responsible for the business activities of The New York Times Magazine and the newspaper's advertising preproduction operations.    As group director of The New York Times Magazine, she replaces Barbara J. Litrell, who last month was named vice president and associate publisher of McCall's magazine, which is also published by The New York Times Company.

headline: New Data Base Ended By Lotus and Equifax
abstract: The Lotus Development Corporation and Equifax Inc. said today that they had canceled plans to sell a data base of names, addresses and marketing information on 120 million United States consumers.   Stored on compact disks for use on personal computers, the product, which was to be called Marketplace: Households, had been scheduled for shipment in March.

headline: San Francisco Agency for The New Yorker
abstract: THE New Yorker magazine awarded its $1 million advertising account yesterday to Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein of San Francisco, but the significance of the assignment goes far beyond its billings.   More than anything else, the 66-year-old magazine, which is owned by Advance Publications Inc., is considered a plum assignment because of the prestige and audience it brings. The magazine asked only five advertising agencies to participate in its review, but Steve Florio, the president and chief executive of the New Yorker Magazine Inc., estimated that he had fielded an additional 35 serious inquiries.

headline: Campeau Suit Settlement
abstract: The Campeau Corporation has agreed to settle a class-action suit that contended American shareholders had been misled by the Canadian retailing giant.   The settlement calls for stockholders to get $650,000 from Campeau, whose United States retailing subsidiaries are in bankruptcy court reorganization. The stockholders had been seeking $13 million.

headline: Technology; Using Computer Engineering To Mimic the Movement of the Bow
abstract: In a darkened studio at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Laboratory, Michael Hawley composes music with a Sun Microsystems computer work station that controls 64 music synthesizers and a modified Bosendorfer concert grand piano. The system permits Mr. Hawley, a 29-year-old software designer, to create and play complex scores on the piano, accompanied by a synthetic orchestra.    The computerized array Mr. Hawley controls is a tool for a skilled musician. But it is also a prototype of what Mr. Hawley refers to as an "orchestra in a box": a powerful music system that will extend to a far broader audience the ability to play synthesized instruments. And it is but one of about two dozen projects at the Media Lab to find new ways to play, record and compose music.  Although simple music synthesizers have been widely available for years, they have not been able to match the fullness and flexibility of traditional instruments. What is changing in the face of more powerful computer-based technologies is the ability to capture musical information far more subtle than the sound of a tone.

headline: Computer Hands the Pen a New Setback
abstract: The computer age is taking another nibble out of the domain of the old-fashioned ballpoint pen. The United Parcel Service, the nation's largest package delivery service, is equipping its drivers with a new handheld computer that has an electronic stylus. Instead of signing a piece of paper with a pen, recipients will be asked to acknowledge getting their packages by using the pen-shaped nylon stylus to inscribe their signature directly on a sensitive membrane embedded in the computer.   The membrane creates an electronic image of each signature. That image accompanies information about the delivery that is recorded by the driver using the computer's keyboard or bar code scanner. At the end of the day, the driver puts the computer into a storage rack that draws the information from the small computer for transmission to U.P.S.'s data center in Paramus, N.J.

headline: Dow Jumps 114.60 Points; Tokyo Gains
abstract: After a moment of silent prayer for the troops in the Persian Gulf and a short clang of the opening bell on the New York and the American Stock Exchanges, trading got off to a flying start yesterday.   The waves of buying carried the Dow Jones industrial average up 114.60 points, or more than 4.5 percent, to end the day at 2,623.51. The Dow's point gain was second only to a jump of 186.84 just after the market crash in October 1987.

headline: Baghdad Schoolchildren Are Made Ready for War
abstract: At the Dijla School in the heart of Baghdad, the children are getting ready to go to war.    As part of their weekly outdoor military drill, they chant, rant and play-act their loyalty to their "father-leader," President Saddam Hussein, and hurl insults at President Bush. Dressed in their Pioneer scout uniforms, they shiver and goose-step in the cold drizzle that coats the mud-filled courtyard as the flag is raised and their song to their President is sung.

headline: Aquino's Successor? For Now, 'Just Call Me Mr.'
abstract: Here in Southern Leyte, in a town hit hard by a recent typhoon, is a good place to watch Fidel V. Ramos go about his unorthodox campaign to succeed President Corazon C. Aquino, who says she will not run again in 1992. Mr. Ramos, the Defense Secretary, is running for President by trying to do his job.   Thus Mr. Ramos, a methodical and sometimes humorless man, tried to resist all talk of the presidency. Providing a long discourse on the declining Communist insurgency here, the crucial bridge between Mindanao and Luzon, he pretended not to hear efforts to interrupt him with political questions.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: France; French Seem Willing to Work With U.S. in the Middle East
abstract: Having traditionally competed with the United States for influence in the Middle East, France has unexpectedly signaled its desire to work closely with the Bush Administration in trying to settle the Palestinian and Arab-Israeli problems in the wake of the Persian Gulf war.    That message, already conveyed during recent visits to Washington by a succession of senior French politicians, is expected to be ratified when President Francois Mitterrand meets President Bush for several hours of private talks on the French Caribbean island of Martinique on Thursday.

headline: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
abstract: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in small groups and given access to various military sources.   These pool reporters obtain their information while under military escort, and their accounts are subject to scrutiny by military censors before they are distributed. Much of the information in articles today on American military operations was obtained under such circumstances.

headline: Layoffs Set for 3,450 At Digital Equipment
abstract: Resorting to dismissals for the first in its history, the Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it would lay off about 3,450 employees by June 30.   The total is slightly higher than foreshadowed last month when Digital reported on its efforts to meet its previously announced goal of cutting its payroll by 6,000 workers through a voluntary severance program.

headline: People
abstract: * Mary Lou Quinlan has been named a senior vice president-management supervisor and Todd Brenard has been named a vice president at DDB Needham, New York. * Beverly Beaudoin, Jeanne Chinard and Anne MacDonald have been named executive vice presidents at Ayer Inc., New York. * Betty Fitterman has been named executive vice president-creative director at Lintas New York. * James Bourdganis has been promoted to vice president-internal operations manager at Campbell-Mithun-Esty Advertising. * Geoff Currier has joined Wells, Rich, Greene Inc. as senior vice president in its creative department. * Jack Dickman has been named vice president-national sales manager at USA Today. * Lorraine Thelian has been named director of the Washington office of Ketchum Public Relations.

headline: Board Shifts Called Manipulative
abstract: The decisions last week by the Chrysler Corporation and Sears, Roebuck & Company to shrink their corporate boards highlight a new phase in the struggle between increasingly powerful shareholders and the corporate managers threatened by their presence.    Both Sears and Chrysler are believed to have acted in order to keep out unwanted directors, raising basic questions about whether a board's composition can and should be manipulated to protect incumbent managers.

headline: Red Cross Workers Pull Out Of Embattled Somalia Capital
abstract: As fighting in Mogadishu, the Somali capital, between Government forces and clan-based rebels has intensified, Red Cross workers were forced to flee the country early this morning, the Geneva headquarters of the International Committee of the Red Cross said.    At the same time, a plane carrying 70 relatives of President Mohammed Siad Barre landed today in Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates, according to diplomats there.

headline: NCR Amends Bylaws To Expand Board Size
abstract: The NCR Corporation has amended its corporate bylaws to allow the company to increase the size of its board to 20 members and to appoint one of the new members acting chairman. The move appears intended to foil an attempt by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to remove Charles E. Exley Jr., NCR's chairman and chief executive, from the board.   Mr. Exley is one of four NCR directors standing for re-election at NCR's annual meeting, scheduled for March 28. The company's board now has 13 members.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; ISRAELIS REPORT LIMITED DAMAGE
abstract: At least seven Iraqi missiles carrying conventional warheads fell on Israel early this morning in an area running from Tel Aviv to Haifa.    The army said that seven people had been slightly injured "from a number of different hits in different parts of the country."

headline: Square D Lawsuit
abstract: A Federal judge on Wednesday denied Groupe Schneider S.A.'s request to move to Illinois a suit intended to block its attempted takeover of the Square D Company. Square D, a electrical equipment manufacturer, filed the antitrust lawsuit in Federal District Court in New York. Paris-based Schneider has made a hostile bid of $78 a share, or almost $1.9 billion, for Square D. A hearing that had been scheduled for today in New York State was canceled after a judge denied Square D's request that it be closed to the public, Schneider officials said.

headline: More on the Gulf
abstract: IRAQI PLEA TO ARABS Saddam Hussein sought to rally Arab supporters and Iraqis, saying Iraq had used only a fraction of its weaponry so far. Page A10.    IRAQ'S PLANES SURVIVE American officials believe that Iraq's air force has largely escaped destruction, but its usefulness may be limited. Page A7.    SILICON VS. STEEL If the Pentagon's claims of success bear up, a hero of the conflict will be the computer chip, vital to the weapons used. Page A8.   EXPORT CONTROLS The United States plans restrictions on exports to the third world of chemical and biological material and missile technologies. Business Day, page D1.    IMPACT IN AMERICA In churches and synagogues, Americans shared fear, confusion and prayers; war's deep effect was visible in towns in Texas and Vermont. Page A11.

headline: Big Loan Is Proposed For F.D.I.C.
abstract: L. William Seidman, the nation's senior banking regulator, said today that he had recommended that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation borrow $10 billion to avert the possible insolvency of the program that protects bank deposits and that the interest on the loan be paid by raising the annual contributions of banks by 18 percent.    Mr. Seidman, chairman of the F.D.I.C., said that by borrowing the money rather than relying solely on bank contributions, the agency would be able to raise substantially more money. Neither he nor the Administration has said whether the money should be lent by the Government or the banks.

headline: United Deal to Buy Eastern Operations
abstract: United Airlines said it planned to pay $60 million for the airport space and takeoff rights of Eastern Airlines in Chicago and Los Angeles. United would get three gates each at Los Angeles International Airport and at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport. The airline would also get takeoff and landing rights at O'Hare, probably about 20. United, based in Elk Grove Village, Ill., has 729 O'Hare slots.    A spokeswoman for Eastern, based in Miami, said talks with United began before the carrier closed down last Friday. The agreement, reached with Eastern's bankruptcy trustees, must be approved by a Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, local airport officials and Federal antitrust officials, she added.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; ISRAEL IS WARNED ON COMPLACENCY
abstract: As the 31st Iraqi missile hurtled toward a quiet neighborhood in the Tel Aviv area early this morning, the most persistent civil defense warnings being broadcast to Israel's people were admonitions against complacency.    If President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is hoping that repeated Scud missile attacks will so anger and exasperate Israelis that the Government has no choice but to respond, then it would appear that he has seriously misjudged the Israeli people.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The people of Albania, blinking in the first political daylight they have been exposed to in almost five decades, will vote on Sunday in multiparty elections organized by the governing Communist Party.    The outcome is unclear. No polls have been taken. But the Communists, led by President Ramiz Alia, are under pressure from a popular democratic movement launched by Tirana University students in December.

headline: Tokyo Journal; Who's Not Fit to Be Governor? Just Look at This
abstract: By the sedate standards of Japanese politics, the race for Governor of Tokyo is not a typical election.    Among the 16 candidates are a popular rock singer running on the slogan "Don't Make Tokyo a Dangerous Place Like New York"; a politician's wife who wants to evict the Emperor of Japan from the Imperial Palace and put up a new Parliament building on the palace grounds, and a man styling himself Japan's Ralph Nader who poses in the blue uniform and motorcycle helmet of a San Francisco policeman and wants to abolish automobile inspections.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: General Assembly SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON U.N. CHARTER -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Ohio Edison Offer
abstract: The Ohio Edison Company is offering $150 million in first mortgage bonds due 1998 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. Originally the size of the offering was to have been for $125 million, but good investor demand afforded the opportunity to sell more. Underwriters said the bonds were given an 8.75 percent coupon and priced at 100, to yield about 107 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

headline: Barclays Plans To Cut Jobs
abstract: Barclays Bank P.L.C. said today that it intended to sharply reduce its work force, perhaps by 15 percent to 20 percent over approximately five years.   Barclays hopes 13,000 or more jobs can be eliminated through retirements and resignations, said a spokeswoman.   In an interview in today's issue of The Financial Times, the bank's chairman, Sir John Quinton, said the cuts in the work force of 87,000 were necessary because of the recession. The bank said details of the job cuts would be announced when financial results were disclosed on Feb. 28.   Barclays has about 8,000 employees in the United States.    The Barclays spokeswoman, who insisted on anonymity, said: "The 15 to 20 percent is very much a forecast still. We don't have an actual program of cuts up to that level to be implemented. It is a forecast we will be working with over the next five years or so."

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THE ECONOMY    Seidman contradicted forecasts that the bank insurance fund he manages would be insolvent within two years. He played down suggestions that a taxpayer bailout will be required.  [ Page A1. ]   Several proposed accounting changes aimed at making banks' financial condition appear less bleak were described by Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency.  [ D1. ]   Magazine publishers face a big problem in the 22 percent increase in second-class mail about to go into effect.  [ D1. ]   Sales of new homes plunged in December, as sales for the year fell to their lowest level since 1982, Commerce said.  [ D2. ]   Prices farmers get for raw products increased 0.7 percent from December to January, the Agriculture Department said.  [ D2. ]   Drastically simpler export controls were called for by a National Academy of Science panel.  [ A16. ] COMPANIES    USX will separate the company's vast energy business from its steel operations by distributing a new class of stock.  [ D1. ]   The bankruptcy judge handling Eastern scheduled an auction of airport gates and takeoff and landing slots.  [ D1. ]   Tonka agreed to be acquired by Hasbro for about $516 million. Tonka, saddled with debt, had a dismal Christmas.  [ D1. ]   Lotus reported the first quarterly loss in its nine-year history, dropping $31.6 million.  [ D3. ]   Xerox said strong copier sales lifted earnings 11 percent, overcoming a decline in earnings from financial services.  [ D3. ]   UAL reported a loss of $123.5 million and a record quarterly operating loss of $296.6 million.  [ D6. ]   Eli Lilly and Johnson & Johnson reported strong growth in earnings and sales for the quarter.  [ D6. ]   MCI said its profits fell to $127 million, down from $143 million in operating profits a year earlier.  [ D6. ]   Sears said it intended to market Visa cards as well as Discover cards if it wins a suit against Visa.  [ D3. ]   "Jumbo," farewell. Detergent makers are test-marketing new "superconcentrated" products.  [ A1. ]   Pan Am was sued by an Iraqi for its policy of barring Iraqi passengers from all its flights.  [ A15. ]   Rhode Island's governor has made public a list of depositors with more than $100,000 in closed banks and credit unions.  [ A15. ] INTERNATIONAL    Germany's central bank raised two leading interest rates in a surprise move likely to slow global economic growth.  [ D1. ]   U.S.-British talks on a civil aviation treaty ended angrily after neither side would budge over five final British demands.  [ D2. ]   Brazil's Economy Minister indefinitely froze all wages and prices in an effort to stop inflation.  [ A3. ] MARKETS    Stocks advanced for the third day as money managers jumped on the bandwagon. The Dow climbed 23.27, to 2,736.39.  [ D6. ]   The Fed added huge reserves to the banking system. Prices of Treasury securities inched higher.  [ D5. ]    The price of crude oil rose 57 cents, to $21.54.  [ D12. ]  The dollar weakened against most currencies.  [ D12. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS    The U.S. seems to have two monetary policies: one conducted by the Fed, the other by banks. This is one of the obstacles to ending the credit crunch. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene.  [ D2. ]   The Bloom Agency was acquired by Groupe FCA, a French agency whose clients include Nestle. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D4. ]   Investors have been bidding up stocks of retail companies, even as consumers stay home. Market Place.  [ D6. ]

headline: Paris Journal; Gluttons for Tranquilizers, the French Ask 'Why?'
abstract: Sparkling with impeccable, sleek fittings, the pharmacies of Paris are hybrids of a cheerful laboratory and a stylish boutique, places that exude promises of beauty and everlasting health. Their clientele often looks equally polished and self-assured.   But ask a pharmacist what weapons from his powerful arsenal he sells most and his answer more than likely will be tranquilizers and sleeping pills.

headline: 12 Keating Charges Are Dismissed
abstract: A judge today dismissed 12 of the 46 fraud counts pending against Charles H. Keating Jr. and three of his former associates at the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, citing technical problems with amended charges filed by the prosecution.    Judge Lance Ito of the California Superior Court in Los Angeles agreed with arguments by lawyers for Mr. Keating and his co-defendants that six of the amended counts improperly altered the nature of the charges and that another six contained contradictory allegations.   Centers on Sale of Bonds     Mr. Keating and his former colleagues are charged with misleading thousands of investors in the sale of bonds by Lincoln's parent company, the American Continental Corporation, through Lincoln branches in Southern California. Lincoln subsequently failed, forcing American Continental into bankruptcy proceedings and making the bonds worthless.

headline: Yield on 30-Year U.S. Bond Falls Below 8%
abstract: The yield on the benchmark long-term Treasury bond fell below 8 percent yesterday and held steadfastly there for the first time in more than a year as strong retail demand caused a rebound in prices.    Dealers said the demand was not unexpected, given the enthusiastic reception accorded this week's auctions of $34.5 billion of Treasury notes and bonds.

headline: D.M.B.&B. Buying Agency To Expand in Health Care
abstract: MEDICUS INTERCOM INTERNATIONAL, the health-care agency subsidiary of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, plans to announce today that it has acquired the Sutton Healthcare Group.    The two units will be combined into one agency, to be called Medicus Intercom USA. Based on 1989 figures from Medical Advertising News, a marketing journal in West Trenton, N.J., the new agency would have almost $190 million in annual billings. That would rank it first among the 74 health-care agencies monitored by the journal.

headline: 4 Slain in Northern Ireland
abstract: Gunmen burst into a bar and shot four people to death tonight in the village of Cappagh, about 50 miles west of Belfast, the police said. The bar is frequented by Catholics and the gunmen are believed to be members of a Protestant paramilitary group, the news agency Press Association reported.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Air Commander; General Who Planned Air Assault, With Lessons of Vietnam: Charles Albert Horner
abstract: The lush green jungles of Vietnam were far from the Saudi desert and from the tactical demands weighing on Lieut. Gen. Charles A. Horner, commander of the American Air Force in the Persian Gulf, as his jets streaked over Iraq yesterday, pounding missile sites, command centers, radar stations and other targets.     But, friends and colleagues of the front-line officer say, the American experience in Vietnam, where General Horner flew 111 combat missions as a highly decorated F-105 fighter pilot, heavily influenced the general's perceptions of modern warfare, just as it has shaped the strategies pursued by the United States in the Gulf war.

headline: Economic Scene; Perestroika With Tears
abstract: COULD Mikhail Gorbachev become another Augusto Pinochet, the Chilean tyrant who rebuilt the Chilean economy with blood and iron?    Like General Pinochet, President Gorbachev rose to power on the insecurities of a ruling class that had made hash of the economy and feared retribution from a long-suffering proletariat. Like General Pinochet, President Gorbachev has divided the interests that might have been expected to check his ascent. And like General Pinochet, President Gorbachev seems not to have the slightest doubt that the right end justifies any means.

headline: NATO Sending Jets to the Turks In Gulf Face-Off
abstract: NATO announced today that it would send three squadrons of German, Italian and Belgian jet fighters to Turkey to strengthen its border with Iraq in case a war breaks out. The move was strenuously endorsed by the United States.   The action was significant for Germany, because what was West Germany has never before deployed military forces outside its borders, and had not sent any forces to the Persian Gulf because of constitutional restrictions against its military forces being sent outside the NATO area.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Khafji Clash: Whose Loss?; U.S., Saudis and Iraq Can Claim Benefits
abstract: It all depends on which lens you look through. The battle of Khafji, which produced the first protracted ground fighting of the Persian Gulf war, was an insignificant Iraqi incursion easily thrown back, or a demonstration of Arab prowess in battle, or evidence that the initiative now lies with Baghdad, or a warning that grim combat and heavy casualties lie ahead for American ground troops here.    In purely military terms, Khafji was a rout; it may well have been an error for the Iraqis to emerge from their bunkers. But that is by no means the only way to view matters.

headline: The Ground War and the American Economy; Further Drop Seen In the Price of Oil
abstract: The ground war against Iraq is likely to result in lower oil prices, at least in the short term, experts said yesterday. Most of these experts said a short ground war was more likely to bring lower prices than a longer conflict.    The new phase of the war reduced still further what the market had seen as a minuscule chance of Iraq's interfering with Saudi Arabia's oil production, the experts said.

headline: War's Hazards for Environment Are Assessed
abstract: The war in the Persian Gulf could have serious environmental consequences for the region, although most scientific opinion is that even an extensive burning of Kuwait's oilfields would not affect the global climate.   Iraq is generally assumed to have mined the 360 active oil wells in Kuwait as well as refineries and storage tanks, and Iraqi leaders have threatened to destroy them.

headline: Winnebago Plans To Recall Workers
abstract: Winnebago Industries, the recreation-vehicle maker, said it was increasing production and recalling more than 120 workers because of large orders from rental agencies.   Earlier this month, the company returned its three plants to five-day workweeks for the first time since mid-October. The latest recall will increase Winnebago's work force to just under 2,000 and will leave some 300 employees laid off, said Shiela Davis, a company spokeswoman.

headline: Small Company in Effort To Clone an Apple Computer
abstract: Working in a small office here two miles from the headquarters of Apple Computer Inc., a start-up company is close to completing the technology for what it says will make possible the first legal clones of the Apple Macintosh computer.   The company, Nutek Computers Inc., will face many legal and marketing obstacles in selling its technology. It was also impossible to verify the company's claims that machines that could be made with the technology would be able to run the same software operational programs that Macintosh does and work with Macintosh printers, pointing devices and other peripheral products.

headline: Aetna's Profit Declines by 6%
abstract: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company today reported a drop of nearly 6 percent in fourth-quarter earnings and said write-downs and reserves to cover losses from its huge real estate portfolio totaled $550 million for the year.   The insurance company reported fourth-quarter net income of $141.9 million, or $1.29 a share, compared with $150.6 million, or $1.35 a share, for the corresponding period of 1989.   Revenues for the fourth quarter were $4.59 billion, including $3.1 billion in premiums. That was 12 percent below the comparable quarter in 1989, when total revenues were $5.23 billion, including $3.6 billion in premiums.     For all of 1990, net income dropped 9.2 percent, to $614.1 million, or $5.52 a share, compared with $676.4 million, or $6.02 a share, in 1989. Revenues for the year came to $19.02 billion, down about 3.7 percent from $19.74 billion in 1989.   Aetna's stock gained $1.625 a share today, to $46.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; People
abstract: * Peter Scarperi has been promoted to chief financial officer of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide. * Bill Brunelle has been promoted to account executive at the Washington office of DDB Needham Worldwide. * Denise Leo has joined Chapman Direct Advertising, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam Inc., as senior vice president, account director. * Stan L. Friedman has been named vice president, marketing for Edward R. Pressman Film Corp.

headline: The Kurds: A Stateless People With a 70-Year-Long Grudge
abstract: Ever since Iraq was created in 1921, its Kurdish population has been engaged in an almost constant rebellion for some degree of autonomy against the Government in Baghdad.    In recent weeks, the Kurds have made extraordinary military gains against the Government of President Saddam Hussein, seizing most of the territory that makes up Iraqi Kurdistan, including the crucial oil center of Kirkuk.

headline: Time Warner's Cable Plans
abstract: Time Warner Inc. is expected to announce today that it plans to install an advanced fiber-optic transmission network in parts of its cable television system in Queens.    The move is expected to double the number of channels that its Queens cable subscribers will ultimately be able to receive to 150 from 75.

headline: Arafat Calls on Pope To Try to Halt Conflict
abstract: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organizaiton, asked Pope John Paul II today to intervene to stop the Persian Gulf war, the Palestinian press agency, WAFA, announced.   Mr. Arafat sent a message to the pontiff, asking him to use his "religious, moral and spiritual authority" to persuade President Bush to stop the conflict, WAFA reported.   The Pope has deplored the war, calling it a "terrible trial" and a "grave defeat" for humanity. Mr. Arafat and the P.L.O. have been allied with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and have denounced the war as Western aggression.   The Pope sent a letter to Mr. Hussein on Jan. 15, the United Nations deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, calling on him to "make a generous gesture that will avoid war." He also wrote to Mr. Bush.

headline: Insurance Reform Urged
abstract: Reforms are needed to stabilize the health insurance market that serves small businesses, Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said. In a speech Tuesday, he dismissed calls for national health insurance, but added, "It is vital that the small group market be stabilized so that the small businesses can get insurance at an affordable cost." Businesses with fewer than 25 employees represent 89 percent of all United States companies and employ about one-third of the country's workers.

headline: Twisted Hulk of Warehouse Tells a Grim Story of Death
abstract: Miniature American flags tucked into duffel bags and placed on the street stood guard today in front of the twisted metal girders and shards of metal -- the ghostly remains of a military barracks destroyed in a single flash on Monday by an Iraqi Scud missile.   The United States Command said today that the missile, which hit a transformed warehouse housing American soldiers at 8:23 P.M. on Monday, killed 28 soldiers and wounded at least 100. The warehouse stands near a supermarket in Al Khobar, a town considered to be part of Dhahran.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Emery Worldwide, Palo Alto, Calif., a subsidiary of Consolidated Freightways Inc., named Thomas Reilly vice president finance. * Federal Home Loan Bank of New York named Keith Bigwood to the newly created position of vice president for financial services. * Grace Energy Corp., Dallas, a subsidiary of W. R. Grace & Co., named Barry L. Morris a corporate vice president for investor relations. * Hills Department Stores Inc., Canton, Mass., named John G. Reen chief financial officer and senior vice president. * Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston, named C. Michael Shaw executive vice president for school publishing. * Mastercard International Inc., New York, named Paul J. Novak Jr. vice president for its Businesscard product group. * Nielsen Media Research, a subsidiary of Dun & Bradstreet Corp., named William G. Jacobi president and chief operating officer. * Otis Elevator Co., Farmington, Conn., a subsidiary of United Technologies Corp., named Robert A. Pentland vice president of new equipment operations for its North American operations. * Rite Aid Corp., Shiremanstown, Pa., named Timothy J. Noonan and Alex Schamroth executive vice presidents.

headline: U.S. Security Prices Stage Rally
abstract: The stunning successes scored by the United States and allied aircraft on the first day of the attack on Iraqt generated a powerful rally in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of some Treasury securities rose by as much as 2 3/8 points and interest rates fell sharply.    The markets' reaction, and huge rise in prices, took place before Iraq lobbed a number of missles into Israel.

headline: Bush Meets Estonia's Leader And Renews a Plea for Talks
abstract: President Bush met today with President Arnold Ruutel of Estonia and said good-faith negotiations were the only way to resolve the standoff between Moscow and the independence-minded Baltic republics.   Mr. Bush reiterated his unequivocal support for Estonia's right to self-determination and expressed outrage over Moscow's use of force in Vilnius and Riga in January, a White House statement said.

headline: Tel Aviv Stock Move
abstract: The Bank of Israel said on Tuesday that it would permit foreign companies to issue stocks and bonds on the Tel Aviv stock exchange. But the amount of money a foreign concern could take out of the country would be limited to 20 percent of any new issue.
