Previously the central bank had turned down applications by foreign firms to issue shares on the stock market. The change of policy "will make the Israeli stock market more international," said Gideon Schurr, speaking for the Bank of Israel."Now we need local investments, not Israeli investments abroad."

headline: U.S. Challenge To Billboards
abstract: In the latest challenge to outdoor advertisers, the Bush Administration is asking Congress to ban new billboards on national highways and main roads in rural areas.   The plan, which is proposed in the new $105.4 billion, five- year surface transportation bill, would also cede regulatory control over many billboards in urban areas to state and local governments. It seeks to restructure the Highway Beautification Act of 1965, which has been criticized as ineffective by organizations opposed to the spread of billboards.    "We're trying to enhance the environment through which the motorist drives," said Barbara Orski, director of the office of right-of-way at the Federal Highway Administration. "One way to do that is to not allow a proliferation of billboards."   Ms. Orski said that the Federal Government should continue to monitor billboards in rural areas, but that state and local governments, armed with detailed zoning laws, would be better equipped to control billboards in cities.    The billboard industry has been criticized in New York and several other cities recently for placing cigarette and alcohol ads in minority neighborhoods.

headline: Macy Profit Tied to Bond Repurchases
abstract: R. H. Macy & Company has repurchased more than $300 million of its bonds, the company disclosed yesterday.   The bond repurchases, at prices averaging about 42 percent of book value, enabled Macy to report an extraordinary gain and a net profit in its most recent quarter, ended on Feb. 2.

headline: Japan Chided for Threat
abstract: In a letter released today, Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan called Japan's threat to arrest United States rice industry representatives at a recent Tokyo food fair "a serious affront" to American farmers. "There are over two million farmers in America," Mr. Madigan said in a letter to Motoji Kondo, Japan's Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries. "Should they band together against buying Japanese products? Or are we united in our goal of accomplishing liberalized trade?" The letter was sent in response to Japan's threat this month to arrest the rice industry representatives for displaying bags of American rice at a food fair near Tokyo.

headline: IN OTHER SECTIONS
abstract: RESERVISTS' ROLE: American military leaders have concluded that they cannot rely on reservists to form a large element of the divisions rapidly deployed in war zones. Page A20.   THE STRAINS ON ISRAEL: The effort to achieve a Middle East peace is complicated by the uncertain ability of the Israeli economy to absorb the huge influx of Soviet Jews. Economic Scene, page D2.   STORMIN' (THE VIDEO): He riveted them in Riyadh, wowed them in Washington. Now, coming to video stores, it's Norman Schwarzkopf in "The Briefing." Business Day, page D5.

headline: The Rout Bush Wants A Disorderly, Humiliating Iraqi Surrender Will End Hussein's Power, Officials Believe
abstract: The Bush Administration is making it difficult for Iraq to end the war because it believes that only unconditional surrender can insure America's aims of eliminating Iraq as a military threat and permanently discrediting President Saddam Hussein.    Achieving these objectives, Administration officials said today, is essential both to speed the withdrawal of most of the 537,000 American troops in the gulf, and to make sure that they will not have to come back to fight again some day. These are the top priorities of the White House as it oversees what it hopes will be the conclusion of its war effort.

headline: Shutdowns Set By Car Makers
abstract: The nation's Big Three auto makers plan to shut 24 car and truck assembly plants this week, temporarily idling more than 62,000 workers because of a shortage of dealer orders, the companies said last week.   The General Motors Corporation said that it would stop production at 11 of its United States and Canadian factories and that output at two plants would be cut in half. In all, 39,000 workers will be idled.   The Ford Motor Company said 16,200 employees would be on temporary layoff as it shuts 10 North American car and truck assembly plants.    The Chrysler Corporation said three plants would be closed, idling 7,150.

headline: Your Own Account; Cashing In on Frequent Flier Miles
abstract: The competition in the airline industry is creating terrific opportunities for people who want to travel now. Even if you don't want to lay out any cash, you can take advantage of the chaos in the industry by using frequent filer miles you may have accumulated. There are now fewer restrictions on how you use them than at any time in recent years, experts say.  "Right now everybody is so desperate for business that you can stay anywhere and fly anywhere you want," said Joe Brancatelli, executive editor of Frequent Flyer magazine in New York.

headline: Northwest Fares
abstract: Northwest Airlines cut fares to Britain in half today and reduced fares to other European destinations by up to 40 percent. Trans World Airlines said it would match the fares. Northwest said discounts to London and Glasgow must be purchased before midnight Feb. 28. Tickets for other European cities it serves are available through March 15.

headline: Foreign Banks Filling the Loan Gap
abstract: Because so many of their American competitors have been reluctant to lend, foreign bankers have been expanding their portfolios of business loans in the United States.    "Foreign banks are providing a shock absorber for the U.S. banking system, " said Herbert L. Baer, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Newsweek magazine will publish an extra issue in May devoted entirely to the topic of children and their development. The issue, entitled "Watching Kids Grow," will be on newsstands for three months, beginning May 28. In addition, 10,000 complimentary copies will be distributed to the offices of pediatricians.

headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Congress in Step; After the Vote, Margins Are Ignored, But Potential Divisions Are Serious
abstract: A Congress that had seemed loath to deal with the Persian Gulf finally went ahead when its leaders despaired of getting President Bush to promise to ask formally for their support before attacking Iraq, some members of Congress and highly placed aides said today.    And a President who had previously told the leaders that he wanted action only if they could assure him the result would be overwhelming then went ahead and asked, and lobbied hard but won only a bare five-vote victory in the Senate.

headline: Muslims in Paris Keep Their Counsel
abstract: A girl who looked about 10 years old asked timidly for a tape "to learn how to pray." A young man wearing an embroidered fez searched for a bilingual edition of the Koran, while an older man in a well-cut, European-style overcoat came to buy a prayer rug.    "Whenever there is a crisis, more people turn to religion," the Moroccan owner of a bookshop in an Arab neighborhood of Paris explained. "That's what has happened since the war. More people look to God, more people go to the mosque."

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Soviet Union; MOSCOW WELCOMES BAGHDAD'S OFFER
abstract: The Soviet Government, pursuing its own diplomatic peace initiative in Iraq, greeted Baghdad's conditional offer today to withdraw from Kuwait initially with "satisfaction and hope."    Officials in Moscow continued to insist that they were fully behind the United Nations resolutions that sanctioned the use of force to evict Iraqi invaders from Kuwait.

headline: War Summary
abstract: IRAQI ARMY IN FULL RETREAT    On the third day of the ground war offensive, Iraqi's battered forces streamed northward in what President Saddam Hussein called a withdrawal. But President Bush, calling the Iraqi leader's speech "an outrage," said the Iraqi forces had been defeated and were retreating. "He is trying to claim defeat in the midst of a rout," President Bush said. Allied forces were attacking the Iraqis in two main thrusts: a force of 100,000 troops pushed northward deep into Iraq in an attempt to block their retreat, while a second drive was pushing farther into Kuwait to take the capital. A tank battle between Iraqis and United States marines raged at the international airport on the outskirts of Kuwait City, but other Iraqi units were reported fleeing the city. Kuwaiti resistance leaders said the fleeing Iraqis took thousands of Kuwaiti hostages with them. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES    Troops: The number of American soldiers killed in a Scud missile attack on a makeshift barracks in Saudi Arabia Monday rose to 28, with 100 wounded. Other American casualties in the ground offensive remained at four dead and 21 wounded. From Jan. 17 to Feb. 23, the start of the ground war, 23 Americans were reported killed in action, 34 wounded and 9 missing. Fifty Americans were listed as non-combat deaths in the operation and 105 other Americans were listed as non-combat deaths before the war.    One British soldier and 8 Arab soldiers were reported yesterday to have been killed. Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to the United States said that to date 18 of his country's soldiers had been killed in action with 40 wounded. IRAQI FORCES    Troops: Central Command reported that allied forces had destroyed 21 Iraqi divisions or rendered them ineffective for combat. An Iraqi infantry division ranges from 10,000 to 12,000 men; at the beginning of the war, Iraq had about 545,000 soldiers in Iraq and southern Kuwait. About 12,000 Iraqi P.O.W.'s were taken prisoner, bringing the total to over 30,000.    Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to the United States estimated the Iraqis had sustained between 85,000 to 100,000 casualties.    Armored and Weaponry: Coalition forces have reported destroying more than 400 Iraqi tanks since Sunday, up from the 270 reported Monday.

headline: Fox Network In Cable Deal
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable company, with 8.8 million basic subscribers, has agreed to carry the television stations of the Fox Broadcasting Company's network.    The deal, announced on Monday by Fox's chairman, Barry Diller, at a convention of the National Cable Television Association here, will extend the reach of the Fox network, which is four and a half years old and has 134 affiliate stations reaching 91 percent of America's TV households. Fox Broadcasting is a subsidiary of the News Corporation Ltd.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Bombers SAUDIS RECAPTURE GHOST TOWN; ALLIES BOMB NEW IRAQI COLUMN; NEW BASES FOR U.S.
abstract: To increase the number of B-52 bombing raids against Iraqi ground forces, the United States has been secretly basing some of the bombers in Spain and has obtained permission to use a British airfield as well, Western officials said today.    The use of the base in Spain, which was disclosed by Administration officials, has been considered politically delicate because the Spanish Government, under public pressure, has been trying in recent years to reduce the presence of American forces. In addition, Spain pays close attention to Arab sentiment, particularly in the Muslim countries of North Africa, American analysts said.

headline: Europe's Statement Urging a Total Pullout
abstract: Following is the text of a statement on the Persian Gulf crisis issued today at the end of a meeting of Foreign Ministers of the 12-nation European Community. It was put out in the name of Jacques Poos, Foreign Minister of Luxembourg, which currently holds the rotating presidency of the community.     In accordance with the positions adopted by the community and its member states since the beginning of the crisis, ministers reiterate their firm commitment in favor of the full and unconditional implementation of the relevant resolutions of the U.N. Security Council. Should this happen, the Twelve consider that Iraq should receive the assurance not to be subject to a military intervention. They consequently recall that the entire responsibility for war or peace rests with the Iraqi Government alone, as is spelled out in Resolution 678 of the U.N. Security Council.

headline: BUSINESS DIARY/February 24-March 1
abstract: AFTER THE WAR In 1930, when pearl-diving was the largest industry in Kuwait, Japan's development of cultured pearls wrecked Kuwait's economy. Now one of the world's wealthiest nations, Kuwait has seen its livelihood ruined again, its power and desalting plants destroyed, its oil wells feeding fires that blacken the skies. But few such devastated nations have ever had such gleaming prospects. With an estimated $100 billion in investments abroad, and most of its oil still securely in the ground, Kuwait has the cash and the credit for rebuilding. The Kuwaitis say the allies who fought the hardest will benefit the most; American companies have won about 70 percent of the 200 contracts signed so far. Kuwait has asked the Bechtel Group to manage the reconstruction of its oil industry, potentially a $10 billion task. Caterpillar Inc. is selling diesel engines to provide emergency power; Motorola Inc., portable telephones, and the Raytheon Company, air traffic control gear. Kuwait plans to not only rebuild but also modernize, promoting private enterprise and taking the nation another step beyond reliance on diving for pearls or drilling for oil. Kuwait would just as soon have an economy efficient enough to manage without the hundreds of thousands of Palestinian and Jordanian guest workers, whose political leanings are suspect. The War Payment Plan  Even as American companies gain contracts, the United States is likely to continue paying some costs of its Persian Gulf mission. With rebuilding expenses of $50 billion to $100 billion -- in the same range as the post-World War II Marshall Plan -- Kuwaiti borrowing could squeeze credit around the world. Many analysts suggest that payments from allies will more than cover American military expense. But Hermann F. Eilts, a former Ambassador to Egypt and Saudi Arabia who now directs the Boston University Center for International Relations, said that some nations might have second thoughts. Germany is burdened by reunification costs, he noted, and Japanese legislators are likely to renege on the Government's promises to the United States. "When the shooting is over, they find reasons to limit their payments," he said. "That means you and I are going to pay." Return of the Oil Jitters  The war ended, but the oil jitters resumed. A barrel of crude, down sharply since the allied assault began Jan. 17, eased back up by $1.47 a barrel to $19.38 last week. Some oil traders voiced fears that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would soon agree to cut back production. And Kuwait is unlikely to resume shipping oil for several months. Iraq, who knows when? But several energy analysts said that the world has already shown it can survive a winter without Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil; the longer run worries them much more. Christopher Flavin, an energy specialist at the Worldwatch Institute, said that with worldwide consumption growing and Soviet production falling, the real squeeze could come in the mid-1990's. G.N.P. Hints at Rebound  A revised estimate of the nation's output for the fourth quarter last year provided some evidence that the economy is poised for a rebound in the coming months. The Commerce Department said the the gross national product fell at an annual rate of 2 percent, compared to an initial estimate of 2.1 percent. But inventories were revised down, meaning that manufacturers would have to increase production to meet any stronger demand after the the victory in the Persian Gulf. Economists Turn Upbeat  Economists had a mind last week to emphasize the favorable aspects of statistics that still tell of a recession. Consumer confidence remained at depressing levels last month, according to the Conference Board's survey, but analysts noted that it rose for the first time since September. Purchasing managers, responding to another survey, also remained downcast, but again, not as dismal as the month before. The government's index of leading indicators fell four-tenths of 1 percent for January, the sixth straight decline, but economists tended to say that the end of the war, an expanding money supply and a rising stock market in February virtually guarantee that the next report will be more favorable. "You are forming a bottom," said Rosanne M. Cahn, an economist at First Boston. "There is no question about that." She said that growth is likely to resume in mid-year. COMPANIES   Revlon on the Block?  Strip away the makeup, the multibillion-dollar estimates of his worth, and underneath, Ronald O. Perelman is a man facing a possible cash squeeze. Revlon Inc., his giant cosmetics company, is holding sales talks with Procter & Gamble, L'Oreal and Unilever, at prices estimated in the billions. Analysts say that Revlon cannot continue to pay off its heavy debts without selling assets. Selling The Daily News  The survival of the Tribune Company's Daily News now depends on finding a buyer. Talks to settle a strike collapsed last week and The News is trying to negotiate a sale to Robert Maxwell, the British publisher. The Wallenbergs Reach Out  The Wallenbergs of Sweden offered $2.27 billion last week for the portion of Saab-Scania A.B. that they do not already own. The family, which already controls Swedish companies with a market value of between $31 billion and $36 billion, is apparently preparing for Sweden's entry into the European Community and the easing of restrictions on foreign investment. Choosing an Indy Pace Car The Chrysler Corporation's manner of demonstrating patriotic fervor entails as many swerves and scrapes as a 60-mile-an-hour drive though rush-hour traffic. On Monday, Chrysler scrapped plans for its Japanese two-seater, the Dodge Stealth, to be the pace car in the Indianapolis 500. To take its place, the company is rushing out a prototype of the sinuous Dodge Viper. "The Viper is a symbol of the can-do attitude and the technical innovation of the American auto industry," a Chrysler executive proclaimed. It also demonstrates the prowess of the Italian auto industry, where Lamborghini, a Chrysler subsidiary, aided in the Viper's development. Or maybe it really is an apt American symbol.  One prototype developed a cracked engine block, and Chrysler only trusts the pace car to manage a single ceremonial lap. If another car is needed during the race, Chrysler will send in the Japanese Stealth. A Looser Accounting Rein?  The four agencies that oversee the nation's banks and savings and loans recommended looser accounting standards on Friday to ease a credit crunch. Critics questioned whether the Government should weaken the rules when so many banks are in trouble. THE ECONOMY   Banks and Insurance  It's not exactly a bailout for banks. Maybe more of a siphoning operation, keeping the banking system afloat with the help of as much as $25 billion in Federal loans. Last Thursday, L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, proposed a $64.4 billion, five-year plan to keep the insurance deposit fund solvent. Annual bank insurance premiums, now 19.5 cents per $100, would increase by at least 3.5 cents, or more depending on how much the fund borrows. Some features of his plan require Congressional approval, while others need only the backing of the F.D.I.C. The insurance fund, at $8.4 billion, stands at its lowest ratio to deposits since it was created during the Depression. Verdict on the Keating Five  The Senate Ethics Committee said their doings reflected "poor judgement" at the least, but most of the Keating Five are claiming that they have been cleared. In a statement last Wednesday, the committee accused Senator Alan Cranston of misconduct in taking contributions from Charles H. Keating Jr., an executive of a failing savings and loan. Actions by Senators Dennis DeConcini and Donald W. Riegle Jr. appeared improper, the committee said, and Senators John Glenn and John McCain had failings of judgement. "I am, of course, relieved that I have been exonerated," said Senator McCain. It remains to be seen whether voters, who have been outraged over the costs of rescuing Mr. Keating's institution and hundreds of others, are equally relieved. A Lag in the Mag Trade  There's Crochet Celebrations and Girls of Outlaw Biker. Kansas City Live! and Kamikaze! and Missouri Wine Country Journal. A choice of Metal Party, Metal Explosion, Metal Revolution, Future Metal or Heavy Metal Mania Pinups. Space Monsters and Monster Truck Spectacular, too. All among 536 entries in Samir Husni's Guide to New Magazines for 1990. Dr. Husni recorded a decline in new titles last year, from 599 in 1989, for the first time since he started the guide six years ago. Sex again accounts for the most new titles, with 62, followed by life style and service, then sports.

headline: Anthropology in Government, Too
abstract: To the Editor:   "Coping With Cultural Polyglots" (Managing, Feb. 24) addressed the growing use of anthropologists by businesses. Government, also, should not neglect the potential applications of anthropology. In a city torn apart by incidents rooted in cultural misunderstanding, cultural awareness sounds like a good idea for all of us. Anthropology can be used as a tool to build it.    Awareness of one's own culture as well as the cultures of those one works with can aid government workers and social service providers. Cultural awareness can help mental health workers interpret the behavior of clients and choose treatment, and help managers in the public and private sectors improve the relations and performance of their workers. Every day more Asians, Hispanics, Caribbeans, Africans and others enter the workforce. Managers need knowledge of the cultural contexts of these people.    Ethnocentrism can lead to intolerance and violence. This city cannot afford either. Government should heed the example of the private sector and find ways to use cultural diversity and reduce cultural conflict. JULIO RODRIGUEZ  New York, March 8    The author is president of Culturelinc, consultants and researchers.

headline: Airlines Cancel Mideast Flights
abstract: Almost every major airline canceled most flights to the Middle East after the United States and its allies attacked Iraq on Wednesday evening.    Many carriers, including Pan American World Airways and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, had already curbed flights to the Middle East before the fighting broke out. Those actions followed huge increases in airline insurance rates by Lloyds of London.   In addition, the major carriers' flights between Europe and the Far East are avoiding the Persian Gulf region, flying south or north of the area. Those routes add about an hour to the flights and require some planes to stop for refueling.   "I don't believe any carrier wants to be in that part of the world with so many sorties being flown," said Steven E. Heydt, senior vice president of marketing at Liberty Travel, one of the largest travel agencies in the New York Area.

headline: Czech Book Industry Paralyzed by Freedom
abstract: Czechoslovakia's book industry has come into hard times since a famous author became President and lifted the burdens of censorship from the publishing industry.    The onetime dissident playwright, President Vaclav Havel, not only freed writers and publishers from censorship but he also removed the shackles of state control from the nation's centrally planned economy as it was under the Communist governments. Together, those benefits are virtually paralyzing publishing.

headline: Trading Ban Approved
abstract: Federal regulators have approved a proposal by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to ban dual trading in active contract months starting May 20. The plan is aimed at forestalling a more restrictive proposal by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. In dual trading, brokers fill customer orders while trading for their own accounts. Critics say that contributes to fraud.

headline: British Rates Cut Again
abstract: Britain shaved interest rates today for the second time in two weeks in an effort to help the economy out of a recession. The Bank of England said it was cutting its money market lending rate by half a percentage point, to 13 percent, a signal to commercial banks to cut their base lending rates. The Conservative Government of Prime Minister John Major also cut rates by half a point on Feb. 13. The National Westminster Bank P.L.C., Britain's biggest bank, led others today in cutting base lending rates to 13 percent. The Halifax Building Society, the largest mortgage institution, cut its mortgage rate to 13.75 from 14.5 percent.

headline: Business Scene; War Won't Open Too Many Jobs
abstract: FOR all its divisiveness, the Vietnam War broke down job barriers in ways the Persian Gulf war is never likely to match.    As the armed forces swelled in size in the late 1960's, men and women who had not sought work before were drawn into the labor force. The first big civilian job gains of the civil rights movement came then for blacks, and the rapid entry of women into jobs also began in this period.

headline: Payment Made For Hotel Site
abstract: The Trump Organization said yesterday that it and its partners in Trump Wilshire Associates had received $48 million from the Los Angeles Unified School District for most of the site of the Ambassador Hotel. The school district is condemning most of the site.    The Ambassador, a renowned hotel and the location where Robert F. Kennedy was assassinated in 1968, is part of a 24-acre site on Wilshire Boulevard where Trump Wilshire Associates had planned to build a billion-dollar complex of offices, retail malls and apartments. The announcement of the project came last January, several months before news of Donald J. Trump's severe financial strains was made public.

headline: Peru's Neighbors Halt Food Imports
abstract: Seeking to contain a cholera outbreak in Peru, health authorities across Latin America halted food imports today and tightened controls on people arriving from that country.    Since the outbreak was publicly identified as cholera 10 days ago, 86 Peruvians have died and 12,669 people have fallen ill, the health authorities reported in Lima today.

headline: U S. Ruling A Setback For T.W.A.
abstract: In a move that could plunge another airline into financial crisis, the Transportation Department gave tentative approval yesterday for the sale of only three of Trans World Airlines' London routes to American Airlines. It turned down the sale of three others.   Carl C. Icahn, T.W.A.'s chairman, promptly denounced the decision, which the Transportation Department said was intended to promote competition in service to London. American Airlines said it was puzzled by the ruling, but declined to comment on what effect it might have on the $515 million price tag American had agreed to pay for routes from six cities in the United States to London.

headline: Advertising Star Opens New Show
abstract: From the inception of mass marketing in the late 19th century, scholars and practitioners have debated whether advertising is an art or a science. Had the experts visited the headquarters of McCabe & Company last Thursday, in a space so bare that heating ducts doubled as desks, they would have learned that advertising is really a romance.    Ed McCabe, the legendary copywriter who put Perdue on the map with "It takes a tough man to make a tender chicken," prowled the office of his eponymous ad agency. He was swimming inside a baggy steel-gray double-breasted suit and letting loose an occasional yell about the dead batteries in his portable telephone. His new partners were clearly smitten.

headline: Fed Warned on Loans
abstract: The Federal Reserve should not buy commercial loans from United States banks to ease tight credit, Robert P. Forrestal, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, said last week. If the central bank made such a move, banks would have more money to lend. That could stimulate the economy. "I don't think that is a good idea," Mr. Forrestal said after a speech here on Friday. "That gets into the allocation of credit, and that should not be the Fed's preserve."

abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   9.00   9-9.50   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.47   5.57   8.12        3-MO. TREAS. headline: Drug Maker Halts Orders
abstract: A drug manufacturer has suspended shipments of all its products after discovering employees had falsified some applications to the Food and Drug Administration.   Pharmaceutical Basics Inc. sells generic drugs to some 300 drug wholesalers across the country as well as to the Pentagon. It is one of about 35 companies in the country that manufacture generic drugs, cheaper versions of name-brand items whose patents have expired.   Generic drug companies must apply to the F.D.A. to manufacture the cheaper drugs and prove they are equivalent in quality to the name-brand product.   Company officials discovered employees had falsely reported to the F.D.A. the amount of testing done on some drugs, a company spokesman, Daryl Johnson, said on Tuesday. He said that products currently on the market do not pose a hazard and that company investigators had found no evidence that employees had contended that a drug was effective when it was not.   But Pharmaceutical Basics will not ship any more of its products until they are all found to meet F.D.A. standards, Mr. Johnson said.   The falsified applications were not uncovered when the company was investigated by the F.D.A. last year during a wide inquiry into the generic drug industry. Company officials made the discovery and voluntarily reported the problem to the F.D.A., Mr. Johnson said. He did not disclose which drugs might be involved.

headline: Baxter's Net Climbs 28.1%
abstract: Hospital supplier Baxter International Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter net income rose 28.1 percent.    Baxter reported net income of $178 million, or 62 cents a share, for the three months ending Dec. 31, compared with $139 million, or 47 cents a share, a year earlier.    Vernon R. Loucks, company chairman, said improved efficiency, higher prices on some products and strong sales growth in every segment contributed to a 33 percent gain in fourth-quarter operating income to $274 million from $206 million.   "Our operating income showed strong improvement for the third consecutive quarter, which is allowing us to make the appropriate investments in research and development and new business opportunities," Mr. Loucks said in a statement from Baxter's headquarters in Deerfield.   Fourth-quarter sales totaled $2.2 billion, up 10 percent, from slightly less than $2 billion in the fourth quarter of 1989.

headline: New Uncertainties Said to Invigorate NATO
abstract: Just as the demise of the Warsaw Pact appeared ready to deal a symbolic blow to NATO's role as defender of Europe, the Persian Gulf war and the erosion of Soviet reforms have joined to pump new vigor into the aging Western military alliance, Bush Administration officials say.    The Soviet crisis, capped by an army crackdown in the Baltic republics, dashed hopes that Europe could finally safely dismiss Moscow's military threat, the officials said. Meanwhile, Iraq's seizure of Kuwait's oil industryawakened Europeans to the fact that the Soviets were not the sole danger to their collective security.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   9.50   9.5-10   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.50   6.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   7.12   2.00   8.31        3-MO. TREAS. headline: RIVALS IN MIDEAST WARN OF DANGERS
abstract: From opposing perspectives across the Arab political spectrum, Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization said today that the deadlock in diplomacy between the United States and Iraq had heightened grave dangers in a region increasingly nervous about the possibility of a Persian Gulf war.   The impasse between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq in their talks in Geneva on Wednesday had been expected by many of the Arabs who oppose Baghdad's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and support the American-led military buildup to confront it.

headline: Sale Plan By Unocal
abstract: The Unocal Corporation said today that it was considering selling its gasoline retailing and distribution operations in the Southeast and that it had hired the First Boston Corporation to evaluate the prospects.   It also said it would sell its 150 Auto/Truckstops.   Operations in the Southeast include 50 company-owned gas stations, contracts with 200 marketers to provide gasoline to 4,200 gasoline stations, 25 product-storage terminals and a lubrication-oil plant.

headline: Bank Funds and C.D.'s Fall
abstract: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts turned sharply down in the week ended yesterday, a result of the cut in the Fed discount rate on Friday to 6 percent, from 6 1/2 percent, and the cut in many big banks' prime rate to 9 percent, from 9 1/2 percent.    Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, a financial rate publication, said yesterday that consumers should brace for further erosion in deposit yields, which historically follow changes in the major lending rates.

headline: Low-Fat McDonald's Burger Is Planned to Answer Critics
abstract: In its latest move to counter sluggish sales and answer a growing chorus of criticism of its food, McDonald's plans to introduce a hamburger that is lower in fat. The new hamburger, which the company might announce as early as today, would be the first such product to be available nationwide at any fast-food chain.   The low-fat burger, which in test marketing has been called the McLean Deluxe, uses a new process that substitutes water for some of the fat.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF Next Phase: Testing a Fragile Alliance; For U.S. and Soviets, Far Different Needs
abstract: Iraq's proposal on Kuwait today appears to open a new phase in the Persian Gulf crisis, in which the cohesion of the anti-Baghdad coalition is likely to be severely tested, particularly the core United States- Soviet alliance.    While President Bush dismissed the Iraqi move as a "cruel hoax" and encouraged the overthrow of President Saddam Hussein, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, said that after Baghdad's latest overture, "everything looks rather encouraging."

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Vatican; War Stirs New Demands in Italy For Vatican Recognition of Israel
abstract: The Persian Gulf war and Iraq's missile attacks on Israel have prompted new demands for the Vatican to establish full diplomatic relations with Israel.    Since Iraqi missiles first struck Israeli cities, Jewish groups in Italy have issued statements and organized a demonstration with unexpected backing from Italian newspapers and politicians who had not before been openly pro-Israel.

headline: Oil Imports and Inventories Reported Down
abstract: Imports of crude oil and oil products were down sharply last month, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday, and inventories were also off sharply.    The report echoes a finding by the Energy Department on Monday that crude and product stocks in January were at their lowest levels in several years, with "the potential for creating tight product markets and rising prices in the coming months if major unforeseen problems should develop."

headline: Restive Soviet Republic Yields to the Kremlin
abstract: Acting to defuse one of the Soviet Union's most explosive ethnic conflicts, Soviet Moldavia has agreed to comply with a Kremlin order to reconsider its law making Romanian the republic's official language.   The republic's Parliament acted on Sunday in response to a decree issued on Dec. 22 by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the official press agency Tass reported.

headline: Tech Notes; The Disappearing Bar Code
abstract: Bar codes have become ubiquitous on consumer products because they allow quick pricing information and product identification by machine scanning. But they can be unsightly on packages that emphasize glamor, such as cosmetics, and can add clutter to advertising messages. So the Battelle Memorial Institute, a contract research firm in Columbus, Ohio, has developed a line of bar code inks that are transparent to visible light, but visible to the infrared radiation used by the scanning devices.    Because they are invisible to the human eye, the new inks can be placed anywhere on a package without interfering with the package design. More information can be added and the codes could be printed on all sides of a package, so that the information could be read regardless of the orientation of the container, speeding customers through the supermarket check-out lines. More information could also help stores keep better track of their inventories and help shippers keep track of their shipments.    "Several bar codes on a product could provide an enormous amount of information during the inventory, manufacturing and shipping processes," said B. Thomas Smith, a Battelle vice president.

headline: Nycor Complains About Zenith Sale
abstract: The Zenith Electronics Corporation's largest shareholder, Nycor Inc., asked the New York Stock Exchange to investigate last month's sale of about 5 percent of Zenith stock to a Korean company. The request was disclosed in a filing on Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.   Nycor, of Basking Ridge, N.J., has been battling to get seats on Zenith's board. It complained in a letter to the stock exchange that the sale of a 4.97 percent stake in Zenith to the Gold Star Company of South Korea came just two months before the annual shareholders meeting. The vote for the board will be held at the meeting on April 23. It may be harder for Nycor to win three seats with the sale of the shares to Goldstar.

headline: Major Sees Gorbachev and Is Reassured on Baltics
abstract: Offering a strong vote of confidence in President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Prime Minister John Major of Britain said today that his dismay over Soviet policy toward the Baltic republics had been eased by the Soviet leader's assurance that "the prospect of independence" was being extended to the rebellious republics.   The British leader referred to the secession process set forth in the Soviet Constitution, which has already been rejected by the Baltic governments as inapplicable. They argue that they are reclaiming independence lost in 1940 by Kremlin annexation.

headline: Skinner Backs Sales by Pan Am
abstract: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner conditionally approved the sale of several trans-Atlantic routes held by Pan American World Airways to United Airlines.   The $290 million deal cannot go through unless United is permitted to replace Pan Am at London's Heathrow Airport, a change the British Government has been reluctant to approve. All of Pan Am's routes between Britain and the United States would be sold to United except those between Manchester and Detroit and between London and Miami.

headline: Nike's Net Is Up by 12%
abstract: Nike Inc., the nation's largest marketer of athletic shoes, reported today that its third-quarter earnings jumped 12 percent, but the performance disappointed Wall Street and Nike's stock price tumbled.   The company earned $70.7 million, or 93 cents a share, in the quarter ended Feb. 28, up from $63.1 million, or 83 cents a share, a year earlier. Nike said revenues shot up nearly 39 percent in the third quarter to $802.2 million from $577.9 million a year earlier.

headline: Gorbachev, Easing Baltic Stand, Appoints Panels for Discussions
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev eased his hard-line pressure on the independence drives in the Baltic region today, appointing delegations to begin a "discussion of issues" with the three embattled republics.   The Soviet leader's shift to a more conciliatory approach follows worldwide criticism of his handling of the Baltic crisis, in which a score of civilians have died in recent weeks at the hands of Soviet soldiers.

headline: Secret Bank Link to Launderer Seen
abstract: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan, whose investigators are tracking a string of multimillion-dollar transactions around the world, said yesterday that he had concluded that a foreign bank convicted of money laundering secretly controls the biggest bank in Washington.   His investigators, along with a state grand jury in New York City, are trying to determine whether Clark M. Clifford, the former Presidential adviser who is chairman of First American Bankshares Inc., knew of the connections between the bank and the Bank of Credit and Commerce International of Luxembourg. B.C.C.I. has admitted that it had laundered millions of dollars for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the deposed ruler of Panama.   Shares Pledged as Collateral     Mr. Morgenthau's comments yesterday were his first public discussion of an investigation his office has been conducting for several months.

headline: Captors Link Fate of 2 Americans To Release of Arabs Held in Israel
abstract: A group that says it is holding two American professors hostage said in a statement here today that they would not be freed until Palestinian prisoners held in Israel were released.   "The case of the hostages will not be resolved until prisoners in Zionist jails are liberated," the statement by the group, Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine, said. It said mediation efforts that did not address the problem of Arab prisoners in Israel would not succeed. The statement rejected what it called American threats to resort to force to free the hostages.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; Iraqi Army's Status Raises Concerns
abstract: As negotiations continued today over an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, Israeli officials grew more alarmed.   They were dismayed over two possible prospects: that the Iraqi military would remain intact, and that the Soviet Union would resume its old role as defender of the Arab world at the expense of Israel.

headline: Iraqi Uranium Eludes U.N.
abstract: The agency charged with halting the spread of nuclear weapons has been unable to find out what happened to the uranium at Iraqi nuclear sites destroyed by the allies at the start of the Persian Gulf war.    The director o the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna, Hans Martin Blix, has written to the Iraqi authorities asking for information about the 50 pounds of highly enriched uranium fuel in the Tuwaitha nuclear research station near Baghdad, but has received no reply, officials say. Experts say Iraq might have removed the material before the war.

headline: Yugoslavia and Croatia: Arrest Order Reignites a Fire
abstract: The Yugoslav national Government today ordered the Defense Minister of the independence-minded republic of Croatia to be arrested and handed over to the custody of a federal military court in connection with allegations that he organized armed units planning to attack an national army base and carry out terrorist activities.   The arrest order appears to renew a battle of wills between Yugoslavia's Communist-led national army and Croatia's government, a struggle that last week appeared to be subsiding.  Brink of Violence     It also comes on the eve of a second round of talks between the leaders of Yugoslavia's six highly autonomous republics over its future as a single country.

headline: Want Ads Off in Canada
abstract: Canada's help-wanted index for February tumbled 5.1 percent, extending a slide that started 22 months ago. Unemployment in Canada is at 9.7 percent and is expected to rise to 10 percent when February figures are released on Friday. The help-wanted index, which monitors advertisements for jobs in 20 Canadian cities, is an early indicator of the demand for labor, the Government agency Statistics Canada said.

headline: K N Energy Selling Its Coal Operations
abstract: K N Energy Inc., a natural-gas supplier, said it would leave the coal business and absorb a loss when it sells two coal units to a Montana company for about $20 million. K N Energy, based in Lakewood, Colo., said it expected to sign an agreement this week with Entech Inc., a unit of the Montana Power Company, subject to conditions. The sale is to be closed by April 1.   K N Energy said its coal assets amounted to about 6 percent of its $559 million in total assets. The company will continue its primary focus of developing and distributing natural gas in the Rocky Mountain and Midwestern states, investing proceeds from the sale in the natural-gas business, said Charles W. Battey, the chairman and chief executive.

headline: Open Positions on Short Sales Decrease by 5% on Nasdaq
abstract: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a decrease of about 5 percent in the number of shares sold short, and not yet covered, for actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system during the monthlong period that ended on Jan. 15.    A total of 278 million shares were in a short position for the period, the association said, compared with 292.6 million shares for the period that ended in mid-December. The total represents dealings in 2,209 stocks; in December, the activity was spread among 2,258 issues.

headline: Open Positions on Short Sales Up 0.4% on Nasdaq
abstract: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported an increase of four-tenths of a percent in the number of shares sold short, and not yet covered, for actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the monthlong period ended Feb. 15.   A total of 279.2 million shares were in a short position for the period, the association said, compared with 278 million shares in the period ended mid-January. The figure represents dealings in 2,272 stocks; in January, the short selling was spread among 2,209 issues.

headline: Building an Economy, Bhutan's Way
abstract: Apple strudel and eclairs are not something a visitor would expect to find in this landlocked, underpopulated, almost totally agrarian mountain kingdom.   In Bhutan, however, the pastry produced at Ugyen Dorji's newly privatized bakery is a symbol of the bold economic initiatives undertaken by the Government of King Jigme Singye Wangchuck, head of the sole remaining Buddhist kingdom in the Himalayas.

headline: Iraqi Message: 'Duty' Fulfilled
abstract: Following is a transcript of a statement read on Baghdad radio tonight, as translated by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, an agency of the United States Government:   In the name of God, the merciful, the compassionate: Our armed forces have performed their holy war duty of refusing to comply with the logic of evil, imposition and aggression. They have been engaged in an epic, valiant battle that will be recorded by history in letters of light.

headline: Hussein Orders 'No Mercy' for Foe But Hints Iraq May Face 'Abyss'
abstract: In an emotional address laced with Koranic verse and invocations of Islam, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today urged his soldiers facing the advance of allied forces into Kuwait to "fight them and show no mercy."   "Fight them because with their defeat you will be at the last entrance of the victory of victories," he declared in a radio address that was monitored here about four hours after the assault began.

headline: Excerpts From U.N. Report on Need for Humanitarian Assistance in Iraq
abstract: Following are excerpts from a United Nations report on humanitarian needs in Iraq:     Nothing that we had seen or read had quite prepared us for the particular form of devastation which has now befallen the country. The recent conflict has wrought near-apocalyptic results upon the infrastructure of what had been, until January 1991, a rather highly urbanized and mechanized society. Now, most means of modern life support have been destroyed or rendered tenuous. Iraq has, for some time to come, been relegated to a pre-industrial age, but with all the disabilities of post-industrial dependency on an intensive use of energy and technology.

headline: ALLIES TO STEP UP ATTACKS ON IRAQIS IN COMING WEEKS
abstract: Declaring that a ground war with Iraq is now inevitable, the British commander in the Persian Gulf said Thursday that the allies planned to greatly intensify their fierce air assault on President Saddam Hussein's forces in the coming weeks.   In Paris, President Francois Mitterrand told television journalists that an allied ground offensive "promises to take place in the coming days, a little more perhaps, in any case, sometime this month."

headline: Uneasily, South Africa Exiles Return
abstract: Joel Diamond came home smiling from more than 27 hard years of foreign exile, steering a luggage-laden cart through the airport terminal with his left hand while he thrust his right fist skyward in the salute of the African National Congress.   "It is very good to be back," Mr. Diamond announced. "The struggle continues."

headline: Pier 1 Will Curtail Expansion Plans
abstract: Pier 1 Imports Inc. said it would slow its expansion program and lay off 29 of its headquarters staff because of the sluggish retailing climate. Pier 1, the nation's fastest-growing home furnishings retailer, has grown to 570 stores from 265 since 1985, and had hoped to have 1,000 stores by 2000. It opened 85 stores in 1989 and 74 last year.    Company officials said that the recession and the Persian Gulf war had had slowed sales and that as a result, only 25 new stores would be built this year. "It's down considerably from what we would have earlier anticipated for this year," said Robert G. Herndon, Pier 1's chief financial officer.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Torture; Freed Kuwaitis Tell of Iraqi Abuse Including Some Cases of Torture
abstract: On the third floor of a gutted mansion, a Kuwaiti Army major slowly pushed open a door with his foot to what was once a laundry room. It had been converted by the Iraqis, he said, into a torture chamber.    In one corner were metal box springs, raised off the floor by chairs. Next to the springs was a crude brown box with bare electrical wires protruding from black cords.

headline: Ex-P.O.W.'s Offer Accounts Of Terror and Torture in Iraq
abstract: In their first extensive public comments since being released two weeks ago, Americans taken prisoner in the Persian Gulf war today recounted tales of terror, torture and, occasionally, compassion at the hands of their Iraqi military captors.   Almost all the former prisoners who spoke today recalled feeling confident that the United States would extract them from prison, either by force or by a quick victory in the war, if they could merely survive their ordeals. And they expressed delight at the patriotic greeting they received on their release.

headline: Movie Maker Is Slain Filming Latvia Assault
abstract: Andris Slapins, a film maker who specialized in anthropological subjects, was fatally shot by pro-Soviet troops on Sunday evening while filming their attack on the Latvian Interior Ministry in Riga, friends said yesterday.    The 42-year-old Mr. Slapins, an ardent advocate of Latvian independence who made movies about Siberian Eskimos and other northern cultures, was among at least four civilians slain in the assault.    Mr. Slapins (pronounced SLAP-inch) made three films that were screened at the first exhibition organized jointly by Soviet and American museum curators, "Crossroads of Continents: Cultures of Siberia and Alaska." The show opened at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington in 1988-89, was at the American Museum of Natural History in New York in 1989-90 and is now in Los Angeles.    Mr. Slapins was "the finest northern anthropological film maker," a dedicated, inspiring artist, William W. Fitzhugh, director of the Smithsonian's Arctic Studies Center, said yesterday.

headline: EUROPEANS WARN SOVIET ABOUT AID
abstract: Reacting with a mixture of shock and disappointment, governments in the European Economic Community today condemned Moscow's violent overnight crackdown in Lithuania and warned that $1 billion in economic aid promised to the Soviet Union might be suspended.    Foreign ministers in the community called an emergency meeting in Brussels on Monday to debate the situations in Lithuania and in the Persian Gulf. "We cannot allow our preoccupation with the gulf crisis to blind us to the dangers in the Baltic states," Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said.

headline: Avon Stake Is Reduced By Chartwell
abstract: Chartwell Associates L.P. took a big step away from the Avon Lady's door yesterday.    The dissident shareholder group sold 10 million shares of its 12.6-million-share position in Avon Products Inc. yesterday to Salomon Brothers Inc. for $39.50 a share, or $395 million. Avon's shares closed at $40.25, off $1.50, with the 10 million shares making it the Big Board's most active issue.

headline: MORE ON THE GULF
abstract: Will Hussein Be Ousted?  While not saying it publicly, Administration officials are making it clear that the United States now considers the downfall of President Saddam Hussein attainable as an outcome of the war. Page A15. Implications for Economy

headline: Arab Bus Kills Israeli and Driver is Slain
abstract: A bus driven by an Arab collided with a car and killed an Israeli woman today, and the bus driver was then shot dead by an Israeli near the Gaza Strip.   Palestinians and Israelis gave entirely different versions of the episode, agreeing only that the bus driver, Mohammed Samir al-Katamani, a 30-year-old Palestinian from Gaza, was returning from Ashkelon in a bus without passengers at about 7 A.M. after taking families of Palestinian prisoners to visit them in jail.

headline: Patents; Future Look At Cruise Control
abstract: A Researcher at the General Motors Corporation has patented a futuristic automobile cruise-control system that automatically adjusts the car's speed to keep a safe distance from vehicles in front.    Invented by Ichiro Masaki, an engineer at G.M.'s Technical Center, the system is based on machine-vision technology developed for robotic manufacturing systems. Although the invention is not expected to be used soon in cars, the patent provides an intriguing glimpse into the future and the way that cars might come close to driving themselves.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Syria; 'Absolute Truths' Collide in Arabs' War of Words
abstract: The foreign newspapers on sale here have a flimsy lightness to them these days because government censors have torn out news of the Persian Gulf war. A recent copy of The International Herald Tribune, thus, went from page 2 to page 7, with nothing in between.   The censorship reflects an official urge in Syria and most other parts of the Middle East to control the flow of information about the war. The phenomenon that has shriveled press freedoms throughout the region, which is caught nervously between old calculations and a precarious, uncharted future.

headline: U S Sprint Pares Telemarketing Jobs
abstract: The U S Sprint Communications Company laid off 280 telemarketing employees, the nation's No. 3 long-distance telephone company said. The employees, who were laid off on Wednesday, were part of Sprint's consumer services group, which had 4,000 workers when it was formed in August to increase sales to residential and small-business customers.   Sprint eliminated about 1,300 jobs after it lost $42 million in the second quarter of last year. Sprint trails the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the MCI Communications Corporation among long-distance carriers.

headline: U.S. COMMANDERS REPORTED TO CALL FOR A 3--WEEK DELAY BEFORE A GROUND OFFENSIVE
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned today that the Persian Gulf war was threatening to go beyond the mandate set by the United Nations, and said he was sending a personal envoy to Baghdad to appeal to President Saddam Hussein to end the war.    Mr. Gorbachev, in his first public declaration on the the war since it began Jan. 17, said it was assuming "an ever more alarming and dramatic scope." He affirmed Moscow's adherence to the United Nations resolutions that condemned the invasion of Kuwait and authorized the war against Iraq.

headline: Washington State Health Care Issue
abstract: The Washington Health Care Facilities Authority yesterday tentatively priced $80.1 million in revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.46 percent for an issue due in 2018.   Underwriters led by John Nuveen & Company said the tax-exempt issue, which will provide funds for the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, was priced to yield from 5.5 percent in 1994, 5.85 percent in 1996, 6.75 percent in 2002 to 7 percent in 2005. For a term bond in 2011, the yield is 7.395 percent.    The financing includes a letter of credit from the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, which prompted a rating of AAA from Moody's Investors Service.

headline: The War's Inevitable Fifth Horseman
abstract: As the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse rampage east of the Suez, yet another scenario for a short, bargain-priced war is vanishing in the sands. The ghastly implications of this"creeping Vietnamization" are clear. But human sacrifices will not be the only costs.    In modern wars, a Fifth Horseman always trails behind the more familiar quartet to claim the toll on mountains of debt run up by the armies as they fire the cash equivalent of Mercedes-Benzes back and forth at each other. In 1991, this horseman's long, black shadow already stretches far across America.

headline: Little Change in Treasury Prices
abstract: Lethargy continued to rule in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities were little changed in light trading. But some market participants said certain investors were getting edgy.   Despite yesterday's weak retail sales report for January and a big downward revision in December's retailing figures, "some institutional accounts are concerned about the rise in the stock market and are starting to reassess their view on the economy," said John P. Costas, director of taxable fixed income at the First Boston Corporation.

headline: Oil Companies' Ad Strategy
abstract: The end of fighting in the Persian Gulf has caused many of the nation's oil companies to rethink their advertising plans, particularly as the heavy driving seasons of spring and summer approach.   But until those plans are set, most oil companies said they would continue to pursue the advertising strategies they began when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.

headline: U.S. EXPLAINS VIEW ON ENVOY TO IRAQ
abstract: The Bush Administration moved today to counter the impression that it callously left April C. Glaspie, the American Ambassador to Iraq, as a scapegoat for failing to prevent President Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait.    The public explanation given by the State Department today was that it had known for seven months that an Iraqi transcript of a meeting between Ambassador Glaspie and President Hussein was inaccurate in parts, but did not correct the record because officials did not want to divert attention from organizing the anti-Iraqi coalition.

headline: Fannie Mae Issues Total $1.5 Billion
abstract: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced a total of $1.5 billion in five-year and 10-year debentures through various securities dealers.   A $900 million issue of debentures due Feb. 12, 1996, was given a coupon of 7.70 percent and priced at 99.9375 to yield 7.715 percent, or about 33 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.   The remaining $600 million in debentures due Feb. 12, 2001, were given an 8.5 percent coupon and priced at 99.875 percent to yield 8.519 percent, or about 73 basis points more than Treasuries.    Underwriters said both securities are callable after two years, with the initial call price of 104.250 for the 10-year debenture. This premium will decrease by 0.304 percent at each interest payment date until the debentures reach 100 at maturity.

headline: World Bank Sets Sale of Bond Issue
abstract: The World Bank plans to price for sale today its fourth global bond issue totaling $1.5 billion through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company and J.P. Morgan Securities Ltd.    In the global sale, the issue will be offered simultaneously in the Eurobond market, the United States and Japanese markets.

headline: Mutual Funds; Still Fighting Shy of Stocks
abstract: The Lipper Growth Fund Index, which charts stock funds much the way Standard & Poor's 500 charts stocks, increased nearly three-fold, from 163.5 to 461.6, in the last decade. You might think, then, that money would be pouring into stock funds. Not so. The portion of mutual fund assets stashed in stock funds has remained virtually unchanged since recovering from the recession lows of 1981-82, according to a recent study by Lipper Analytical Services Inc., in Summit, N.J.   What happened? While the stock market sizzled, the bond market did almost as well.  An investor owning Government funds earned an annual return of 11.3 percent in the decade, while the average growth fund returned 11.5 percent. For taking the extra risk, growth fund investors got no reward.    Historically, bonds return an average of 6 percent to 7 percent while stocks return 10 percent. So when returns realign themselves, analysts say, investors will follow suit.

headline: Business and Health; Limiting Awards In Malpractice
abstract: SUPPORT is growing for new Federal legislation that would make it harder for plaintiffs to win multimillion-dollar awards in medical malpractice suits. A number of senators and House members are working on bills to change the system, which the American Medical Association says adds $21 billion a year to health-care spending. The association attributes $5.6 billion to malpractice insurance premiums and about $15 billion to defensive tactics that doctors take, like prescribing redundant diagnostic tests.   Employers and insurers, who pay for much of the nation's medical care, support the proposals to limit the awards. And President Bush told a medical group last year: "We've got to restore common sense and fairness to America's medical malpractice system." The Administration has drafted its own bill, which White House officials said would probably go to Congress next week.

headline: Albany Bank Takes Offer by Trustco
abstract: The Home and City Savings Bank, based in Albany, accepted a takeover offer of $25.12 a share in cash and securities from the Trustco Bank Corporation in Schenectady, N.Y. The $72.3 million Trustco offer must be approved by stockholders of both banks. The merged company, which would retain the Trustco name, would have $1.7 billion in assets and 43 branches.   Home and City Savings is also being sought by Rose Associates of Albany, which is offering to buy two-thirds of the bank's stock for $20 cash and $6 in subordinated debt a share. Home and City officials said the Rose Associates' offer was too late.

headline: Time Warner Constructing 2-Way Cable TV System
abstract: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that by the end of the year, 10,000 of its cable television subscribers in Queens would be able to receive 150 channels and communicate through their television sets to obtain services like electronic banking.    The Queens cable system, which will use an advanced fiber-optic transmission network, will be the most sophisticated system to enable viewers to interact with their television sets.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * Bernard Chaus Inc. said it had signed an interim line of credit for up to $45 million with its current lending banks. * Browning-Ferris Industries has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $300 million in debt securities.

headline: In Baghdad, Criticism Followed by Silence
abstract: Just hours before American and allied ground forces roared into Kuwait and Iraq, the last official word from Baghdad was a stinging attack on Pres Bush's ultimatum by a member of Saddam Hussein's inner circle. The official, Izzat Ibrahim, who is Mr. Hussein's second in command, was quoted as saying that the only way to stop the war was for Washington to accept the last-ditch Soviet-Iraqi peace plan.   And just after dawn today, with word from Saudi Arabia that American troops had raced six miles into enemy territory, the only official sounds emanating from Iraq were radio broadcasts of the Koran and other religious programming.    Article, Page 19.

headline: A Special Co-op Conversion; Hotel in Manhattan Saves Tax Benefits
abstract: A problem faced by many residential cooperatives with commercial space is how to comply with a Federal tax regulation known as the 80/ 20 rule while getting the maximum return on that space.  Manhattan's Ritz Tower Hotel at Park Avenue and 57th Street solved that problem with the creation of two condominium entities, one owning the commercial space and the other the cooperative apartments above.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                  Feb. 1   Jan. 25   Feb. 2        1991   1991   1990        Gasoline production, daily   6.6   6.7   7.1        Distillate production, daily   2.8   2.8   2.9        Gasoline stocks   224.7   220.9   231.4        Distillate stocks   110.7   115.4   121.0        Crude imports, daily   6.6   5.7   6.9        Product imports, daily   1.6   1.8   3.3        Crude stocks   328.0   324.4   350.7        Crude production, daily   7.4   7.4   7.5        Refinery utilization (%)   82.7   82.3   89.3       (Source: American Petroleum Institute)

headline: Air Traffic Drops 26.8%
abstract: International airline passenger traffic dropped by 26.8 percent last month on United States airlines amid a recession and the fear of terrorism, the Air Transport Association says.   Passenger traffic on routes inside the United States fell 5.5 percent, producing a total decrease of more than 10 percent, the steepest drop in nearly 25 years, the airline trade association said on Monday. The declines are measured against traffic in the corresponding month a year earlier.

headline: World Markets; Dollar's Gains Upset the Exchanges
abstract: Oh, how the dollar has hurt Americans with investments abroad this year.  And with so little warning.    The gains they realized in Europe, as markets rallied after the Persian Gulf victory, were cut in half or even more by the end of the first quarter, according to the Financial Times index of world markets. But until seven weeks ago they hadn't a worry about losing money when converting profits into dollars.

headline: Mattel's Net Rises 51.5%
abstract: Mattel Inc., the nation's largest toy maker, said today that its fourth-quarter earnings increased 51.5 percent, to $14.7 million, or 29 cents a share, from $9.7 million, or 19 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 19.2 percent, to $428.3 million, from $359.4 million.    Mattel said quarterly earnings were reduced because it set aside $21 million after taxes to cover bad debts.    For the year, Mattel, based in El Segundo, Calif., reported record earnings and revenues. Profits totaled $91.2 million, or $1.80 a share, up 32.8 percent from $68.7 million, or $1.38 share, in 1989, after taking an extraordinary charge of $11 million.    Sales for the year rose 18.5 percent, to $1.47 billion, from $1.24 billion.    Mattel rose 12.5 cents today, to $22.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Pepsi Cancels Big Giveaway
abstract: Pepsico Inc. decided last night that much as it wanted to promote Diet Pepsi it was not worth the risk of snarling the nation's telephone network in the process.    As part of its Diet Pepsi commercials during the telecast of the Super Bowl this Sunday, Pepsi had planned to give $1 million to each of three randomly chosen callers to a toll- free telephone number that would be shown during the commercials. But last night the company scrapped the idea.    As recently as yesterday afternoon, a Pepsi spokeswoman had insisted that the promotion would be done. "We don't know what to expect, and that's part of the curiosity," said Leigh Curtin, the spokeswoman. "We're very optimistic."   But the company announced last night that it had canceled the promotion after discussing it with the Federal Communications Commission. "We did not want to do anything that would have even the slightest chance of disrupting our nation's ability to communicate," said David Novak, executive vice president for marketing and sales.   Telephone industry experts had estimated that as many as 50 million calls could flood the nation's telephone network during the promotion.

headline: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Fall
abstract: Yields on bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the week ended yesterday, but only half as sharply as the preceding week.    According to The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest rate publication, drops in yields are expected to continue into next month, when another cut in the prime rate is possible. Analysts at the magazine advise depositors to check quoted rates before opening accounts as yields will continue to drop.

headline: Deficit at U.S. Credit Union
abstract: The financial crisis that has plagued many of the nation's savings institutions has hit home. The credit union used by Government employees and former officials who regulate the nation's savings and loans has been insolvent since 1989, its president said today.   "It is an embarrassment," said James Deemer, president of the credit union and comptroller of the Office of Thrift Supervision, which supervises the nation's 2,300 savings associations. "We had hoped nobody would find out about it."

headline: Israeli Soldiers in Gaza Wound 55 Palestinians
abstract: Israeli troops today wounded as many as 55 Palestinians, including a 5-year-old girl, in the Gaza Strip's worst violence since the Persian Gulf war began in mid-January, Arab reports said.   The unrest came three days before a visit by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. An East Jerusalem Arabic newspaper, Al-Fajr, reported that the Palestine Liberation Organization had approved a meeting of local Palestinian leaders and Mr. Baker.    Palestinians in the Gaza Strip, the West Bank and East Jerusalem marked 39 months of revolt against Israeli occupation with a general strike.    The United Nations Relief and Works Agency said that Israeli troops shot and wounded 45 Palestinians in Rafah, in the Gaza Strip. And Arab hospital officials said 10 others, including the 5-year-old, were wounded in other towns. The Israeli Army said that only 20 Rafah residents and an officer and soldier had been hurt.

headline: Big Change Is Expected For Sears
abstract: Sweeping changes at Sears, Roebuck & Company, including the possible sale or closing of the Sears catalogue, will be on the table next month when the company's board meets, retail executives and others watching the company say.    Other possible moves include shifting top management and cutting $700 million to $800 million in operating costs, these people say.

headline: Forbes Will End Publication of Egg Magazine in March
abstract: Egg, the magazine started by Malcolm Forbes just before his death last year, announced yesterday that it would cease publication with its March issue.    "It was a victim of the overall environment, and it was just not possible to see how the growth that we had to have was going to happen," said Timothy C. Forbes, president of Egg, a division of Forbes Inc.    The oversized magazine, which covered the downtown scene, was aimed at a young, urban, hip audience in New York and Los Angeles. Its first issue was published in March, just about the time that magazine advertising and newsstand sales began their precipitous decline. Among those cutting back were national advertisers like liquor and tobacco and local advertisers like restaurants and clubs, all of which were the backbone of Egg's advertising.  Decline in Pages     The March 1990 issue, for instance, had 150 pages; the March 1991 issue will have 82 pages, Mr. Forbes said. Last month Fame magazine closed for the same reasons.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; With Caution, Geer, DuBois Manages a Shift at the Top
abstract: A GROWING number of mid- sized agencies built in Madison Avenue's heyday in the 1960's and early 1970's now face the difficult challenge of finding new top executives to replace retiring founders.   Geer, DuBois is one example. The New York agency, whose clients include Sony and Brown & Williamson Tobacco, has begun to tackle the tricky problem of installing new management without alienating clients with close ties to those who had been in charge.

headline: Zenith Fights Nycor Takeover
abstract: The Zenith Electronics Corporation is urging its stockholders to reject an attempt by a shareholder, Nycor Inc., to take control of Zenith's board. In a letter dated last Wednesday and signed on behalf of the directors by Zenith's chairman and president, Jerry K. Pearlman, shareholders are asked not to sign any proxy statement sent to them by Nycor, an investment company based in Basking Ridge, N.J.   Nycor, which holds an 8.2 percent Zenith stake, announced last month that it would solicit shareholder proxies for its own slate of directors at Zenith's annual meeting April 24. All 10 Zenith directors are up for re-election. Nycor is a holding company that currently owns no operating businesses. It is controlled by the Salvatore Giordano family, which also controls the Fedders Corporation, the air-conditioner maker.

headline: IN OTHER SECTIONS
abstract: STAYED HOME, AND ANGRY: A Georgia National Guard unit that spent the gulf war training in California feels it was shunted aside and branded a failure. Page A14.    HOLIDAYS IN A NEW LIGHT: After the war, the traditional themes of Easter and Passover are taking on rich new meanings for Americans. The Living Section, page C1.    WHAT THE BEAR SAID: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf is much sought after for interviews, and his time with David Frost has produced some new tidbits. Word and Image, page C18.

headline: New-Home Sales Show Biggest Gain in 5 Years
abstract: Sales of new homes surged 16.2 percent in February, the biggest advance in nearly five years, the Commerce Department reported today. Analysts attributed the upswing to lower mortgage rates and the end of the war in the Persian Gulf.   The department said the February gain, the first since November, was paced by a huge advance in sales in the Midwest, although all regions enjoyed increases from an extremely depressed January level.

headline: Rebel Kurds Claim Control of Iraq Area
abstract: Kurdish rebels battling troops loyal to Saddam Hussein today claimed control of wide areas of the Kurdish region in the rugged northern part of Iraq, as opposition forces in several parts of the country reported new military gains.    Radio reports in Turkey and Iran said there was heavy fighting in Kurdish districts along their borders with Iraq, and a Kurdish radio station monitored by the British Broadcasting Corporation tonight appealed for discipline among people living in areas it said were now in rebel hands.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * Federal Home Loan Banks will announce tomorrow the interest rates for a total of $1.2 billion in six-month and one-year bonds. * First Chicago Corp. is offering $100 million in 11 1/4 percent noncallable subordinated notes due 2001 at 99.55 to yield 11.326 percent through Salomon Brothers. The issue is rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A- by S.&P. * Wells Fargo & Co., San Francisco, is offering $100 million in 8 1/4 percent noncallable notes due 1993 at 100 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P.

headline: Consumer Confidence Shows Big Rebound
abstract: In the first in-depth survey of consumer sentiment in March, the Conference Board reported yesterday that its index of consumer confidence rose to 81 from 59.4 in February -- a record gain for a single month -- reflecting both relief that the Persian Gulf war had ended and optimism that the economy would improve by late summer.    But the Conference Board, a business organization, warned that the euphoria over the war's end had apparently played such a big role in the upturn that it made the index a temporarily unreliable indicator of whether the recession might be ending. With the war effect gone, confidence could slide in April, said Fabian Linden, the survey's director.

headline: 35 Prisoners Freed and Flown to Hospital Ship in Gulf
abstract: Thirty-five allied prisoners of war, 15 of them American, were flown from Baghdad to a hospital ship in the Persian Gulf today. Some had suffered injuries when their aircraft went down, officials said, and some had been maltreated by their captors.    Col. Richard Williams, who examined them on the trip, said tonight that the freed Americans were "in fair shape," generally speaking. But he said that a few were malnourished and that some, including three with perforated eardrums, had been "slapped around a bit" by the Iraqis.

headline: A.T.& T.'s Earnings Are Flat
abstract: A.T.& T. announced yesterday that its earnings were nearly flat in the fourth quarter. The loss of tax credits, higher interest expenses and reduced gains from cash investments and asset sales offset a strong increase in operating profits.   Two of the seven regional Bell companies created by the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984 also reported fourth-quarter results yesterday. U S West posted a tiny gain in profits, while Nynex reported that profits from operations fell slightly. Nynex also announced a one-time after-tax loss of $211 million, mostly to cover losses and reorganization costs in subsidiaries selling equipment and software to businesses.

headline: A Busy Time For Airline Security Firm
abstract: Arik Arad has not slept in 48 hours. He runs United States operations for the company that has spread the security system of El Al, the Israeli airline, to airlines throughout the world. With war threatening in the Middle East, the company, International Consultants on Targeted Security, is getting more business than he can handle.   "Everyone is reinforcing security substantially," Mr. Arad said. "Airlines that I have never talked to and have never considered security are now knocking on our doors. They are now under tremendous pressure."

headline: Israel Says It Must Strike at Iraqis But Indicates Willingness to Wait
abstract: Israeli officials insisted today that the second Iraqi missile strike in two days had left them no choice but to retaliate, but they indicated that they were willing to wait in deference to American requests and because of new missile defenses provided and manned by the United States, which are already in place.    The second attack provoked a new round of tough talk here.
