But behind the promise to strike back hard when the time is right lay the clear suggestion that Israel would do nothing for now in deference to the United States' concern that an Israeli response could shatter the anti-Iraq military coalition in the Persian Gulf war.

headline: War Coverage and Commercial Limits
abstract: EVEN though war coverage will limit advertising on television, especially in the early days, many agency executives say the situation for advertisers will probably return to normal rapidly.   "There is a sense of shock and concern," said John Ferrell, the executive vice president and chief creative director of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in New York. "But business has to go on. After a couple of weeks everything should settle down."

headline: USF&G Planning To Trim 900 Jobs
abstract: The USF& G Corporation, the troubled insurance and financial services company, said it would eliminate 900 jobs. The layoffs will involve 360 employees in the Baltimore headquarters and 540 people in branches and subsidiaries, the company said.   The cuts, which will be in all levels of the company, will save USF&G about $42 million and will involve costs of about $7 million, the company said. It said more cuts were expected. At the end of 1989, USF&G had 12,600 employees nationwide. Its stock rose 12.5 cents today, to $7.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Regulators Are Glum On Outlook
abstract: The nation's senior banking regulators said today that more large failures like the Bank of New England would occur if the economy did not turn around by the middle of the year.   Painting a glum portrait of the banking industry, both L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and Robert L. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency, told Congress that there was strong evidence that the economy's problems, particularly in New England, had only begun.

headline: Careers; Students Find Job Search Much Harder
abstract: CORPORATE recruiting on most campuses is way down, according to Richard J. Lewis, dean of both the college of business and graduate school of business administration at Michigan State University.    The best students can probably still find jobs, he said in a recent interview, but many students may have to work harder to start their careers.

headline: Judge Leaves the Way Open for Further Bidding on FNN
abstract: A bankruptcy judge left the door open yesterday for a bidding war for the troubled Financial News Network Inc.    Federal Judge Francis G. Conrad in Manhattan upheld certain provisions of NBC's contract to acquire FNN for $105 million, but he did not rule out a new bid from Dow Jones & Company and the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company or another party.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Soviet Union; Awaiting Reply From Iraq, Soviets Debate Peace Plan
abstract: Another day came and went today with no signals from Baghdad on whether it would agree to the Soviet initiative on Kuwait, as the debate in Moscow continued on the merits and motives of the Soviet plan, Iraq's options and Washington's response.    The Kremlin continued to say it expected a quick response from Baghdad on the confidential proposals that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev handed to Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq on Monday.

headline: Continental Adds 32 Flights, 12 From Newark to Florida
abstract: Continental Airlines announced yesterday that it was adding 32 flights around the country, including 12 from Newark International Airport to Florida, to fill in some of the gaps left by the recent shutdown of Eastern Airlines.    When it halted operations on Jan. 18, Eastern was serving numerous East Coast cities, and it had hundreds of flights out of its main hub in Atlanta. It had 28 out of New York, leaving from La Guardia and Newark.

headline: No Profit in a Ground War
abstract: To the Editor:   "War Plays Bring Their Own Dangers" (Jan. 27) described Sunrise Medical Inc. as "a Persian Gulf pure play" and quoted Anthony J. Russo of Noonan/Russo, a public relations firm we use, as saying our company "would benefit from any war situation because it's in the wheelchair and crutches business." We never authorized any such remarks by Mr. Russo and would like to disassociate ourselves from their implications.   The story leaves a misleading impression about our company's business and the likely performance of our stock in the event of a ground war. We should not have been included in an article on "war play" stocks, and no one should buy our stock on that expectation.  Our products are not even used in the theater of war and any impact of expanded hostilities on our business is impossible to predict and will most likely be negligible. We believe the recent rise in our stock price reflects our positive general performance trends, which have included no impact from any war-related business.   Further, we reject totally the idea that our company is planning to capitalize on the casualties of war. Our primary motivation has always been to build products that improve people's lives. RICHARD H. CHANDLER  Torrance, Calif., Jan. 28   The author is chairman and president of Sunrise Medical Inc.

headline: Republicbank In Settlement With F.D.I.C.
abstract: A Federal bankruptcy judge today approved a settlement of legal claims and counterclaims that will amount to nearly complete repayment for holders of senior debt of the First Republicbank Corporation in Dallas.   First Republicbank, once the largest bank-holding company in Texas, has been in bankruptcy since the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation seized its 40 banks and sold them in July 1988 to the NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: An article on Jan. 6 about bar codes misstated the use of a new form of the code, which depends on infrared scanners. The new coding would be used in addition to present coding, which depends on visible-light scanners, but would not replace it.

headline: Right-Wing Party Joining Israeli Coalition
abstract: The Israeli Government signed an agreement today allowing the country's most extreme right-wing political party, which advocates expelling all Palestinians from the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, to join the ruling coalition.   The accord with the party, Moledet, was signed just before the Sabbath, and as attention in Israel and throughout the world is focused on the gulf war. The timing was apparently intended to deaden leftist and centrist opposition to the accord and to mute protest from foreign governments.   Moledet, which means homeland in Hebrew, won seats in Parliament for the first time in 1988. The party's central platform during the election was the notion of "transfer," as the expulsion of Arabs is known among some in Israel. The party believes that Palestinians living in the West Bank and Gaza should be removed to Jordan.   The agreement reached today gives Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir a coalition of 66 seats in Parliament, five more than needed for a majority.

headline: U.S. Airlines Ordered To Lend More Planes
abstract: The Pentagon has called on commercial air cargo companies to supply additional long-range aircraft to the military operation in the Persian Gulf, increasing the military's ability to deliver ammunition, spare parts and weapons to the forces there.   Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney declared "an airlift emergency" on Wednesday night, taking the formal step needed to commandeer the airplanes, mostly from companies like United Parcel Service and Federal Express, the Military Airlift Command announced today.   The activation of additional aircraft suggested that the Pentagon is prepared to continue military operations for a prolonged period.   Officials said the move could provide as many as 17 more cargo planes, on top of the 23 cargo planes already provided under an earlier activation of the civilian air fleet.

headline: Three Big Steel Companies Post Disappointing Results
abstract: Two of the nation's leading steel producers reported fourth-quarter losses yesterday, saying their earnings were hurt by special charges, sharply reduced steel prices and lower demand, and a third reported plummeting profits.    At the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel producer after the USX Corporation, the loss included a previously announced $550 million charge for layoffs and the shutdown of plants under a proposed joint venture with British Steel P.L.C.

headline: Parliament in Poland Approves Cabinet for New Prime Minister
abstract: The Parliament today approved the Cabinet of Prime Minister Jan Krzysztof Bielecki, who has pledged to speed the pace of economic change and placate those segments of the population hit hardest by the program.   The Cabinet Mr. Bielecki picked to carry out this delicate balancing act mixes holdovers in key positions with young technocrats from the Liberal Congress, a small party that favors the most rapid possible privatization of Poland's businesses and industries.    Today's vote was 272 to 4, with 62 abstentions.

headline: Japan's Car Export Limit
abstract: Japan said today that it would limit car exports to the United States to 2.3 million annually, prompting an outcry from some quarters of the United States auto industry, which has been losing ground steadily to Japanese auto makers.   The United Automobile Workers union and the Chrysler Corporation called for the Japanese Ministry for International Trade and Industry to include cars built in the United States by Japanese companies in the export ceiling.

headline: More Phones On Airplanes
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission has awarded permanent licenses to four more companies to provide nationwide telephone service from airplanes.   The only company currently in the market is Airfone Inc., a subsidiary of the GTE Corporation, which has been operating under an experimental license. Under the F.C.C. decision, Clairtel Communications Group L.P., the Mobile Telecommunications Technologies Corporation, the American Skycell Corporation and the In-Flight Phone Corporation will be able to compete with Airfone.   The F.C.C. awarded the licenses on Dec. 21. The new licensees must also seek the commission's approval for the equipment they use as well as approval by the Federal Aviation Administration.   The license for In-Flight Phone Corporation is a personal victory for John Goeken, who founded the MCI Communications Corporation in 1963 and Airfone in 1984. Mr. Goeken sold his stake in each company before it became a success.

headline: Wall Street Is Preparing Contingency Plans for a Gulf War
abstract: Wall Street is preparing for war. From the largest securities and futures exchanges to brokerage firms and mutual funds, new rules are being put in place and old systems are being checked as some of the nation's most important institutions ready themselves for an outbreak of hostilities in the Middle East.    The moves include expanding emergency powers of exchange officials, changing some trading rules and beefing up security, all intended to protect the nation's financial system from any huge surge in volume as the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait approaches.

headline: As U.S. Car Makers Cut Back, Toyota Is Expanding Briskly
abstract: At a time when the American automobile industry is laying off thousands of workers, shuttering factories and bracing for a recession, Kunihiko Minami, the chief of operations at the Toyota Motor Corporation's sprawling Takaoka plant here, says he has his own problems: he cannot find enough auto workers.    Even as the General Motors Corpo ration plans to close up to nine plants in the United States that employ tens of thousands of workers, Toyota is expanding at a breakneck pace and looking desperately for people to hire.

headline: Third World Seeks Advanced Arms
abstract: The deadly pounding that the West's military forces gave the Iraqis this year has whetted the appetite of third-world nations for advanced weapons, military analysts say. One result,, they say, could be a rapid advance in accuracy and technological sophistication of the developing world's military arsenals.   Having watched as "smart" bombs and cruise missiles dispatched an armed force that Iraq spent $50 billion to amass, third-world nations are already scouting for similar weapons, Bush Administration officials and private experts said in interviews.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: U.N. Resolutions; Iraq's Shift in Position: Not Enough for the U.S.
abstract: Since Feb. 16, Iraq has shifted from a repudiation of all Security Council resolutions calling for its withdrawal from Kuwait to acceptance of Resolution 660, demanding its unconditional withdrawal.    But the Iraqis have consistently demanded that all other United Nations resolutions, including those dealing with sanctions and other penalties, be voided as a condition of its withdrawal. The United States views this condition as a major sticking point for an accord.

headline: Consumer Spending Shows A 0.6% Climb in February
abstract: Consumer spending, depressed for months, rose by six-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Commerce Department said today.   The rise in consumer spending was the biggest since an eight-tenths of 1 percent increase in September, but economists were unimpressed. They said the gain was primarily a reaction to the severe six-tenths of 1 percent spending drop in January.

headline: Japan on Guard After Threats by Old Terror Group
abstract: Fearful that Japanese might be singled out in acts of terrorism, the police and security authorities here are stepping up their precautions against the Japanese Red Army, which has reportedly promised retaliation for Tokyo's support of the war against Iraq.   Japanese military officials say that in response to threats, they recently reinforced police protection against American military bases in Okinawa and other places. The police are also increasing their monitoring of airports and ports to identify possible JapaneseRed Army travelers.

headline: 2 Companies Offer a Mill To Workers
abstract: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation and The New York Times Company offered yesterday to give a paper mill they own jointly in northern Ontario to its employees, provided the provincial power company agrees by April 30 to buy an associated hydroelectric power plant.   If there is no deal by the deadline, operations of the money-losing mill will be slashed, and about 1,200 of the 1,450 people employed by the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, as the venture is known, will be laid off, said Darwin E. Smith, chairman and chief executive of Kimberly-Clark. The Dallas-based paper and consumer products company owns 50.5 percent of the venture.

headline: AT THE FRONTIER, NO SIGN OF EXODUS
abstract: The Lithuanians who walked across the Soviet-Polish border today at the crossing in this remote village were talking of jobs, not political flight.   "First of all, you can't escape," said a 40-year-old construction foreman from Kapsukas, Lithuania, who gave his name as Zidalis. "Second, we don't want to escape. This is our country. We want to live there. People will stay, even after what happened in Vilnius."

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: France; French Policy Upsets Friend and Foe, at Home and Abroad
abstract: France has yet to experience the pain of losing any planes, pilots or soldiers in combat in the Persian Gulf, but the week-old war has already made itself felt here through political in-fighting, rising social tensions and a crisis in French relations with longtime Arab allies.    As a result, while closely following events in the gulf -- where France has stationed 10,000 troops, 54 aircraft and a dozen warships -- the Government has been just as busy dealing with the domestic and foreign repercussions of its participation in the war.

headline: Soviet Economists Say Shift To Free Market Is Inevitable
abstract: More than a dozen Soviet economists and officials who attended a recent conference here say the Soviet Union's transition to a market economy remains irreversible, even if recent developments have slowed the process.    At the annual World Economic Forum here earlier this month, these people said that the conversion to a market economy had gathered too much momentum to be stopped and that the old centrally planned system had been too dismantled and discredited to be rebuilt, despite President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's recent shift to the right and the resurgence of old-guard Communist forces.

headline: First Brands Stock
abstract: The First Brands Corporation announced that half of the company's shares outstanding would be offered publicly by two major shareholders. The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the First Boston Corporation will offer 10.5 million to 12 million shares of common stock of First Brands. On the New York Stock Exchange, First Brands stock fell 50 cents a share today, to $23.25. That gives the stock being sold a current value of about $240 million.

headline: South Africa Seeks U.N. Help on Return of Exiles
abstract: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said tonight that South Africa would let the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees help with the return of political exiles who fled the country in protest against apartheid.    The decision, announced in a statement from Mr. Botha's office in Cape Town, signaled a change in the attitude of the Government, which had balked at giving the United Nations a role on grounds that it would interfere with the sovereignty of South Africa.

headline: Wal-Mart's Net Up 13%; 2 Others Fall
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's fastest-growing retailer, yesterday reported record profits and sales for the fourth quarter and the year ended Jan. 31. But two other leading chains, the J. C. Penney Company and the May Department Stores Company, said their fourth-quarter nets fell below those of the previous year.   But despite Wal-Mart's higher earnings and the other companies' disappointing fourth-quarter earnings, investors showed a mixed reaction. Wal-Mart's shares closed lower yesterday, while Penney and May's stocks advanced.

headline: Haiti's Press Holds Its Critical Tongue
abstract: After facing down guns and decrees in helping rid their country of a series of dictators, Haiti's independent press is struggling to redefine its role under the country's first democratically elected Government.    With the landslide election last December of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a 37-year-old liberal priest, Haiti's news organizations are torn between cheering a politician who has captured the national imagination and exercising its right to criticize, for fear of encouraging violent opponents of the President-elect or offending his volatile supporters. Father Aristide is to take office on Feb. 7.

headline: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
abstract: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and tomorrow's auction of one-year bills.    By late Friday the outstanding three-month bills were bid at 5.92 percent, and the six-month bills at 5.89 percent. The one-year bill was at 5.86 percent.    Government agency borrowings include $650 million in short-term floating rate notes due on Aug. 8, issued by the Student Loan Marketing Association. The notes will be priced at a spread to the bond-equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill.   The following fixed-income issues are scheduled this week: TAXABLE TUESDAY West Penn Power Co., $100 million in first-mortgage bonds due in 2021, Aa-3/AA-. Competitive. ONE DAY DURING THE WEEK Long Island Lighting Co., $250 million in general and refunding bonds due in 1997, Baa-3/BBB-. Lehman Bros. Security Pacific Home Equity Loan Trust 1991-A, about $1.305 billion in pass-through certificates. First Boston Corp. Source: MCM Corporate Watch Ratings: Moody's/Standard & Poor's. TAX-EXEMPT TUESDAY State of Washington, $200 million in general obligation bonds. Competitive. TENTATIVE OFFERINGS THIS WEEK Hawaii, $150 million in general obligation bonds. Merrill Lynch & Co. Illinois Municipal Electric Agency, $124.3 million in power-supply systems revenue bonds. Morgan Stanley & Co.  Los Angeles County, $289.4 million in certificates of participation for a correctional center project. First Boston Corp.  Michigan, $500 million in general obligation notes. Prudential-Bache Capital Funding.  New York City, $950 million in general obligation bonds. Lehman Brothers.  Orlando Utilities Commission, $213 million in utility and electric revenue bonds. Goldman, Sachs & Co.  Upper Occoquan Sewerage Authority, Virginia, $78 million in regional sewer system revenue bonds. Wheat, First Securities Inc.

headline: Merger Talks Are Suspended
abstract: The military contractors Thomson-CSF and British Aerospace P.L.C. today halted three years of talks about merging their tactical missile businesses.   Alain Gomez, chairman of Thomson-CSF, a French company, told reporters that missile makers were in a quandary over what weapons governments would select in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war and the crumbling of the Soviet bloc.

headline: ALLIES INTENSIFY BOMBING OF IRAQI TROOPS; ISRAEL HOLDS FIRE, GETS AMERICAN DEFENSES
abstract: After three days of concentrated aerial attacks on Iraq and parts of Kuwait, the United States said today that it had air control over many areas of Iraq and was now able to intensify bombardments of the Republican Guards, the elite Iraqi ground forces.    In a news conference, top Pentagon officials said the Iraqi air defenses south of Baghdad and in western Iraq had been "weakened significantly" and that many of Iraq's airplanes had retreated to bases in the north.

headline: Home Loan Bank's Debt Securities
abstract: The Office of Finance of the Federal Home Loan Bank is offering $2.996 billion in debt securities in five separate issues.   The offering consists of a $525 million three-month issue maturing June 25, a $825 million six-month issue maturing Sept. 25, a $585 million one-year issue maturing March 25, 1992, a $455 million three-year issue, and a $606 million four-year issue.   The issues are for settlement March 25.

headline: Mutual Funds; Picking Winners at Gabelli Growth
abstract: When Elizabeth R. Bramwell wrote the prospectus for her fund in early 1987, the Gabelli Growth Fund, she decided to give herself free rein so she could navigate easily among markets. Many of her colleagues are bound by more restrictive bylaws that might keep them in one sector of the market or prevent them from moving too much of their assets into cash. She didn't want to be bound by such restrictions.   Ms. Bramwell, whose fund now has assets of $203 million, was never one to follow a straight and narrow path. A chemist by training, she edited textbooks before graduating from Columbia University's M.B.A. program with Mario Gabelli, the money manager, in 1967. She started working with him in 1985 after stints as a research analyst and a full-time mother.

headline: Japan Trade Surplus Off
abstract: Japan's trade surplus with the United States shrank by 15.4 percent last year as it shipped fewer cars and bought more American airplanes, the Finance Ministry said today.    Worldwide, higher oil prices and a growth in imports brought Japan's trade surplus down by 18.5 percent, to $52.4 billion, the ministry said. It was the fourth straight annual decline in the global figure, the ministry said in its annual report.

headline: India's Violence Damaging Tourist Industry
abstract: Political uncertainity and thousands of deaths in sectarian and caste violence last year have led to widespread tourist cancellations and jeopardized plans by the Indian Government, which has billed 1991 as "Visit India Year," to generate funds from tourism.   The designation of India as an unsafe destination by Western countries, including the United States and Japan, has also led to a drop in visitors.

headline: Briton Holds Firm on Air Landing Rights
abstract: In a grim sign for the struggling Trans World Airlines and Pan American World Airways, Britain's Transport Secretary, Malcolm Rifkind, gave no sign in an interview today that his Government would soften its stand in the deadlocked aviation negotiations with the United States.    Pan Am, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, and T.W.A., whose shaky financial health is deteriorating rapidly, are desperate for the British to allow them to sell their landing and takeoff rights at Heathrow Airport near London to United Airlines and American Airlines, respectively. But the aviation treaty between the United States and Britain gives the rights to Pan Am and T.W.A. and must be revised for American and United to get them.  Living With 'Status Quo'     While possibly just posturing, Mr. Rifkind made it sound in the interview as if the British position had hardened. "I have to emphasize we can live with the status quo," he said. "It is our American colleagues who are anxious to see a change."

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: General Assembly SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON U.N. CHARTER -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. OUTER SPACE SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL SUBCOMMITTEE -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON PALESTINIAN RIGHTS -- 10 A.M. Economic and Social Council DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM -- GOVERNING COUNCIL -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Ann Taylor Stock
abstract: Ann Taylor Holdings, which owns all of the stock outstanding in Ann Taylor Inc., the fashion apparel chain, said it was considering a public offering of its common stock. Ann Taylor was taken private by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners and Joseph E. Brooks and other members of management in a leveraged buyout in 1989. The terms of the stock offering have not yet been determined, but a registration statement and prospectus are expected to be filed on April 1.

headline: Mutual Funds; Why Stocks Make Sense Now
abstract: Should you sink money into stocks this year? No way, most mutual fund investors would probably say. And with good reason: Many were badly burned in 1990, when the average stock fund lost more than 7 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks mutual funds.    But sidestepping stocks would be a big mistake, experts say. Although most believe the market hasn't hit bottom -- many expect the Dow Jones industrial average to fall to about 2,100 by mid-year and some expect an even steeper drop -- the consensus among analysts is that there will be a recovery this year. And the biggest profits always are made in the early part of a bull market, when many investors are not invested in stocks.

headline: Banking Regulators Seek Barring of President's Son
abstract: Enforcement officials at the Office of Thrift Supervision recommended today that Neil M. Bush, the President's son, be barred from working at any bank or other institution that received Federal insurance until he showed that he understood conflicts of interest.    Last month, an administrative law judge assailed Mr. Bush for what he called "conflicts of interest" and "unsafe and unsound practices" when he was a director of the Silverado Banking Savings and Loan Association in Denver. The institution's failure in 1988 has been attributed in part to unpaid loans secured by Mr. Bush to two associates. Denies Wrongdoing     Mr. Bush has denied wrongdoing and has said he would appeal the ruling.    The judge, Daniel J. Davidson, recommended the mildest disciplinary action that could be imposed. He recommended that Mr. Bush be ordered to make full disclosures about his other business ventures in future dealings with Federally insured institutions, and to uphold his responsibilities to depositors and shareholders. This is what is called a "cease and desist" order.

headline: Brooklyn Union Gas Offers Help in Crisis
abstract: With the start of the Persian Gulf war, one New York City advertiser has begun a campaign to offer help to military families, a move that also promotes its corporate image.    The Brooklyn Union Gas Company has created a radio commercial for its new "care line," which provides assistance for the families of members of the armed forces who have billing questions or who are having financial difficulty.   The spots begin with a conversation in which a woman tells her husband that his friend will not be joining him, because his reserve unit has been activated. The spot goes on to stress the company's concern for military families and assures them that Brooklyn Union Gas will be there to help.   "We were thinking of doing something in case the war broke out," said Steve Hunter, president and creative director at Moss Advertising in New York, the agency that did the spots. "It really isn't an image campaign; it fits into our regular advertising. But I won't deny that it will probably help us. While so many advertisers are pulling, we're putting in an offer to help."

headline: Trade Gap Narrowed in November
abstract: The nation's trade deficit fell 12 percent in November, to $9.7 billion, the Commerce Department reported today, as the weakening economy dampened demand for oil and other imports.   Even though oil prices were still rising during the month, the nation's petroleum bill fell by 13 percent, the largest drop in at least three years, as volume fell by 14 percent. Industry, motorists and other users cut back their purchases as the higher prices ate into their buying power.

headline: Weather in the Gulf
abstract: Clouds and showers will be abundant across Lebanon, Syria and northwestern Iraq as strong Mediterranean disturbance moves across the region. Snow heavy at times in the Kurdistan mountains of Iraq. Sun will be mixed with high clouds in central Saudi Arabia. Temperatures: Baghdad, high 62, low 40; Riyadh, high 73; low 48; Dhahran, high 72, low 53.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; Some Palestinians Are Permitted to Return to Jobs
abstract: The Israeli Army allowed some West Bank and Gaza Palestinians to return to their jobs in Israel today for the first time in three weeks.   But although there were provisions to allow 6,000 Arab workers to return, the authorities imposed so many restrictions on their travel that only about 1,400 were able to work. About 120,000 Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza normally work inside Israel.  'Test-Case Basis'     "This is going to be a gradual process and clearly on a test-case basis," Brig. Gen. Raanan Gissin, an army spokesman, said this afternoon.

headline: ISRAELIS STRIKING P.L.O. IN LEBANON
abstract: For the first time since the Persian Gulf war began, Israeli commandos ventured beyond their self-proclaimed security zone in southern Lebanon today to raid Palestinian guerrilla bases. The Government here warned that such strikes would continue unless the Lebanese Army ejected "terrorist organizations" from the region.   Moving before dawn, the Israeli units attacked a training base of the Palestine Liberation Organization and artillery batteries in Iqlim al Toffah, a hilly district a few miles north of the Lebanese zone that Israel patrols with the help of local militia units it has trained and equipped.

headline: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
abstract: With the start of war, the American-led military command in Saudi Arabia put into effect a system worked out beforehand under which journalists from many newspapers, news agencies, television and radio stations are assembled in groups and given access to various military sources.   These pool reporters obtain their information while under military escort and their accounts are subject to scrutiny by military censors before they are distributed. Much of the information in the accompanying article was obtained from such reports.

headline: Mutual Funds; The Embattled Energy Funds
abstract: Fielding telephone calls from angry investors has become part of Ned Shadek's routine since he took over the Putnam Energy-Resources Trust in late December. What gives? That's what investors want to know. Oil prices soared as high as $40 a barrel late last year. Oil companies are reporting excellent earnings. But the fund's performance -- like its peers' -- is down.   Last year, the 12 natural resource funds with more than $25 million in assets, mainly in energy, metals, forests products and similar stocks, lost an average of 7.8 percent, compared with a 6.3 percent drop in all stock funds, according to Lipper Analytical Services Inc., which tracks mutual funds. Over the longer haul, five years, the 12 outperformed the all-stock-fund average by 10.5 percent to 9.1 percent.

headline: Business and Health; Accountability In Health Care
abstract: EMPLOYERS, insurers, medical societies and hospitals are pressing to create tests and guidelines that they hope will bring more order and economic accountability to a health-care system that has traditionally been based on the judgments of doctors who may often disagree.   In a major development last week, 11 large companies and their insurers decided to test a system in which employees and their doctors are asked about specific results of medical treatments.    Employees treated for lower back pain, for example, would be asked whether they could climb stairs, bend over to tie their shoes and do other things reflecting their health status.    The test will seek to determine whether the system is "a useful and valid way of demonstrating accountability," said Bill Goss, the health-care programs manager at the General Electric Company. Large employers spend hundreds of millions of dollars each year on employee health care. "But we are not really sure whether we are getting value from it," said Mr. Goss, who is chairman of the group conducting the test.    The companies and insurers taking part include American Telephone and Telegraph, with the Travelers; Ameritech, with Illinois Blue Cross and Blue Shield; Digital Equipment, with Fallon Community Health Plan, Harvard Community Health Plan and Matthew Thornton Health Plan, three New England health maintenance organizations; General Electric's aerospace unit, with U.S. Healthcare, and General Motors, with Blue Cross of Missouri and St. Louis and Kaiser Permanente in Cleveland.   Other participants are Hercules, with the Intermountain group in Salt Lake City; Honeywell, with  Doctors and patients will use questionnaires developed by medical authorities for Dr. Paul Ellwood, president of Interstudy, a nonprofit research group based in Excelsior, Minn. The sponsor is the American Managed Care Association, whose members include 150 large companies that use health maintenance organizations and networks of doctors and hospitals.    During 12 months, the 11 companies will all ask employees about the same two or three medical conditions. Lower back pain, angina (heart attack) and asthma are the most likely subjects, said John Doyle, the project's coordinator at Interstudy.    Dr. Ellwood said Interstudy questionnaires were already being used in a similar project at half a dozen group medical practices across the country, including the Cleveland Clinic in Ohio. The American Group Practices Association is the sponsor.    In yet another project, General Motors, Ford Motor, Chrysler and the United Automobile Workers union agreed this month to work on quality-ofcare measures with nine health maintenance organizations in southeastern Michigan. The H.M.O.'s will be required to meet certain standards and their members will be asked whether the H.M.O.'s provided satisfactory care.    The American Medical Association and several medical specialty professional groups are taking a different tack. They are developing guidelines for medical procedures and treatments that are based on a consensus of views of experienced doctors and from medical journals.    The A.M.A. says the guidelines will be parameters, leaving ample room for variations in particular cases. "The specialty societies' fear is that if they don't develop guidelines, the Government will do it for them," said Dr. David M. Eddy, a professor of health policy and management at Duke University.    Indeed, Congress has already ordered Federal studies of both guidelines and medical results that the Government calls patient outcome research. "At least we ought to know where we are getting the biggest bang for the buck without causing harm to patients," said Ira Raskin, an economist who is acting director of the Center for Medical Effectiveness at the Federal Public Health Service.    Hospitals are also developing practice guidelines and "statements of expected performance," said Dennis O'Leary, president of the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Health Care Organizations, which accredits hospitals.    "We used to assume that clinical judgment alone was an adequate source of truth," Dr. Eddy said. "Now we have to go out there and measure the consequences of different medical activities."    "The problem is: How do you measure the whole spectrum of health care?" said Margaret E. O'Kane, executive director of the National Committee for Quality Assurance, a nonprofit group that accredits health maintenance organizations. "There are whole areas where you just don't know the answers. We're all grappling for measurements."

headline: Iran and Iraq Agree on a Half-Mile Border Zone
abstract: The highest-level delegation from Iraq to visit Iran since before the two countries fought their brutal eight-year war in the 1980's arrived today in Teheran. The two countries announced that they would pull back the remaining forces on their mutual border to create a buffer zone about half a mile wide.    The visit was the latest indication of the normalization of relations between Teheran and Baghdad, and raised further the possibility of a realignment of Iran with Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis. Over the last three months, Iran has issued stinging criticism of the American-led military buildup to confront Iraq over its takeover of Kuwait. But the Iranians have also been consistent in demanding Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait.

headline: DUE IN U.S., WALESA STRESSES AID NEED
abstract: President Lech Walesa insists that he is not coming to America with his "paws" out, but warns that Poland's economic reforms will fail if the West does not provide substantial additional assistance.    Mr. Walesa, who is to arrive on Tuesday for a six-day visit and a meeting with President Bush, said in an interview with several journalists here that without both debt relief and new investment, the economies of Eastern Europe would collapse and leave millions of refugees "at the gates of the United States."

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * Cracker Barrel Old Country Store Inc. is selling $30 million in 9.53 percent debentures due 2003 at a price of 100 through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. Common Stock  * Alta Health Strategies Inc. is making an initial public offering of 1.5 million common shares at $9.50 a share through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. * California Energy Co., San Francisco, has privately placed $21 million in common and preferred stock with United States, British and Norwegian investors. * Manpower Inc., Milwaukee, a newly formed corporation, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for about 72.5 million common shares. Ratings  * Ameritrust Corp.'s senior long-term debt has been lowered to Baa-3, from Baa-2, by Moody's Investors Service. The bank holding company is based in Cleveland.

headline: World Bank Loan to Iran
abstract: The World Bank, with United States approval, has given Iran its first loan since 1978, the year before Iranians took hostages at the United States Embassy in Teheran, a bank official said today.    A $250 million loan for earthquake reconstruction was approved by the bank's board of executive directors on Thursday but was not immediately announced. It is repayable in 20 years.

headline: BONN WILL RETURN PROPERTY IN EAST
abstract: Heinz Stern was 26 when his father was dragged off to the Buchenwald concentration camp and forced to sign a contract surrendering a family-owned flour mill to a German owner. The mill's new owner, in turn, lost it after World War II, as Soviet occupation officials nationalized key industries in east Germany.   Mr. Stern, who was then living in Kansas City, managed to get his father out of Germany thanks to an affidavit signed by one Senator Harry Truman. Now, half a century later, Mr. Stern may get the mill back, too.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THE ECONOMY    Rhode Island's Governor ordered the immediate closing of 45 state-chartered banks and credit unions.  [ Page A1. ]   The list grows ever longer of distressed airlines reduced to selling precious assets or courting merger partners.  [ A1. ]   Bank of America cut its prime rate to 9.5 percent, from 10 percent. It was the first of the nation's 10 largest banks to act.  [ D1. ]   The Interior Secretary threatened to cancel a contract for a Japanese company to provide services in Yosemite.  [ A12. ] COMPANIES    Landmark Land has reportedly agreed to sell the bulk of its golf courses, resorts and real estate for about $739 million.  [ D1. ] TROUBLED TIMES ON WALL ST.     The securities industry finally started making the tough choices to transform itself into a smaller, healthier industry.  [ D1. ]   "Inflection points," "enhanced indexing," "prepackaged bankruptcies" -- these are the coming buzzwords.  [ D1. ]   Interest rates will fall, perhaps by a percentage point or more, in the first half, most credit market analysts anticipate.  [ D7. ]   Big Board successes were led by innovative corporations whose basic businesses prospered.  [ D9. ]   On the Amex, the big winners were companies whose stocks were unaffected by the Middle East and by the recession.  [ D11. ]   Small stocks once again lagged behind the performance of the large-capitalization issues.  [ D12. ]   American corporations sought a record amount of cash from the public markets in 1990, but the volume did little to improve Wall Street's finances.  [ D14. ] BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY   Inventions in voice synthesis are making it easier for the blind to read and the deaf to communicate.  [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS    As bear markets go, this one so far has been much more alarming to brokers than to investors. But that could change. Floyd Norris: Market Place.  [ D1. ]   Deregulation of vacant New York apartments could leave renters and landlords better off, an urban planner argues. Peter Passell: Economic Scene.  [ D2. ]   It has been a tough year for the Mingo Group, but it has managed to do well. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D15. ]

headline: Soldiers in Haiti Are Seized In a Lethal Weekend Clash
abstract: Six soldiers were arrested and dozens of others were disciplined after a weekend clash in which four people were killed, the Government said today.   Traditionally, soldiers in Haiti have seldom been punished for criminal activity or human rights violations.

headline: TURKEY GIVES U.S. LIMITED BASE USE
abstract: Turkey agreed this weekend to let the United States use air bases here in a war against neighboring Iraq, but said operations would be confined to "humanitarian and limited logistical support."   The decision, reached at a long Cabinet meeting Saturday night, means that American pilots would not be allowed to stage air strikes against Iraq directly from Turkish territory.

headline: Abboud Out as Chief At Houston's First City
abstract: A. Robert Abboud, the Chicago banker who arrived in Texas three years ago to lead a $1.5 billion bailout of a Houston bank, was ousted today as chairman and chief executive of the First City Bancorporation of Texas in the face of mounting losses and problem loans.   The bailout, which consisted of $970 million in funds from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and $500 million in private capital, began to stumble about a year ago after some foreign loans turned sour and three major borrowers, Circle K, Federated Department Stores and Drexel Burnham Lambert entered bankrutpcy proceedings. Although First City suffered from further deterioration in commercial real estate values in Texas, the bulk of its troubles were out of state.  A Second Setback     The shake-up at First City represents the second time that Mr. Abboud, an aggressive manager, has been asked to leave the helm of a large bank and ends his personal quest to resurrect First City, once Houston's biggest bank. It also dashes his hopes that his successful stewardship of First City would vindicate his bumpy banking career. Mr. Abboud was dismissed in 1980 as chairman and chief executive of the First Chicago Corporation after board members criticized him for losing ground to a rival, Continental Illinois.

headline: THE YEAR IN FINANCE: 1990/From Wall St. to Warsaw, Economic Storms Are Growing; Alan Greenspan/Fed Chairman Feels Chill of Recession
abstract: In his nearly three and a half years as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan has gone through the repertory of experiences that can befall a central bank chief -- inflation, a stock market crash and now recession. Trying to shake it off is likely to occupy most of Mr. Greenspan's time in the final months of his term, which ends in August.    The 64-year-old chairman has even avoided using the term "recession" in public to refer to the economic downturn. But the stepped-up efforts of the Federal Reserve Board last month to reduce interest rates made clear that the Fed is trying to reverse the economic decline.

headline: Construction Spending Down 0.6%
abstract: Construction spending fell by six-tenths of a percent in November to its lowest level in two years, the Commerce Department said today. The decline wiped out October's rise, the first in building activity in six months.    Many economists foresee little improvement before the summer as the economy continues to weaken.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; PENTAGON IS CONFIDENT ON WAR BUT SAYS IRAQIS REMAIN POTENT; SEES NO IMMINENT LAND ATTACK
abstract: In a confident report on the Persian Gulf war, the nation's top military officials said today that allied forces were now intensifying a campaign to isolate and destroy Iraq's front-line force in and near Kuwait in hopes of forcing an Iraqi withdrawal.   On a day in which the Administration made a concerted effort to gain control of the public debate over the war and provide evidence to back assertions that the fighting is going well, Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said the effort to smash Iraqi communications and air defenses in the last week had been largely successful. He conceded that it was difficult to tell whether the bombing had harmed Iraqi forces in Kuwait.  Blunt Talk and Humor     Mixing blunt talk, occasional military bravado and flashes of humor at an hourlong news conference with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, General Powell said that if Iraq did not withdraw, a ground attack would not begin until President Saddam Hussein's army had been damaged badly enough to keep allied casualties to a minimum.

headline: Intel Loses Trademark Decision
abstract: A Federal judge ruled today that the Intel Corporation is not entitled to trademark protection on the name of the 386 microprocessor, the company's most important product and one of the most valuable franchises in the computer industry.    The ruling, by Federal District Judge William A. Ingram, who held that "386" is a generic term, will make it easier for competitors to market chips compatible with the 386.

headline: Boeing Expansion
abstract: The Boeing Company proposed a $1.5 billion expansion of its Everett, Wash., production plant that would add nearly 10,000 new jobs in the next four years. The expansion would accommodate construction of Boeing's newest plane, the 777 jetliner, and expanded construction of its 747's and 767's.

headline: Dow Drops by 8.17 to Close at 2,955.20
abstract: In spite of signs that the Fed eased monetary policy to bring interest rates down, stocks dropped sharply in the final two hours of trading yesterday to end in minus territory. Professional program selling was heavy.    The elusive 3,000 in the Dow Jones industrial average remained somewhere in the future, but Wall Street seemed certain it was not too far away.

headline: Futures Bill Advances
abstract: A House panel approved legislation yesterday that would impose a variety of changes on futures market trading and strengthen the regulatory powers of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. But the Agriculture Committee rejected a last-minute request from Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady to include in the bill the Administration's plan to shift regulation of stock index futures from the commission to the Securities and Exchange Commission. The bill would restrict brokers from simultaneously trading for themselves and their customers in high-volume markets. It would also tighten record-keeping of trades and increase market surveillance.

headline: U.S. Imposes Travel Curbs
abstract: The State Department has begun to ban travel by Americans to Iraq and Kuwait as a "precautionary measure," saying United States passports will no longer be valid for either country.   State Department travel advisories issued on Wednesday night say that "all U.S. citizens are strongly urged to avoid all travel" to Kuwait and Iraq and "are advised to depart as soon as possible" from both countries "unless a special validation has been obtained."

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Kremlin; Excerpts From Statement by Gorbachev on the Gulf
abstract: Following are excerpts from a statement yesterday by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union on the war in the Persian Gulf, as provided by the English-language service of Tass, the official Soviet press agency:

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Iraq; Iraqi Loyalists Pound Shiite Mosques, Rebels Say
abstract: Troops loyal to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq shelled Shiite Muslim rebels in mosques in the holy city of Karbala, and Iraqi soldiers defected by the tens of thousands elsewhere, opposition leaders said today.   They said that the Shiite fighters and civilians trapped in the crossfire were being slaughtered, and that 500 had been killed or wounded since Friday.

headline: Article 252091 -- No Title
abstract: To allay investor concerns that rising consumer defaults on credit-card loans could cause losses for holders of securities backed by those loans, J. P. Morgan Securities and the MBNA America Bank announced a new variety of credit-card security yesterday.    The new $500 million issue is backed by $60 million held in a special cash collateral account, rather than by a letter of credit from a bank. The cash account will be available to investors if needed to avoid a default on the securities.

headline: Europe Tries Bank Reform
abstract: The European Community has started a drive to cut the cost and increase the speed of the millions of money transfers that banks process daily in its 12 member nations, the community's executive body said today.    "There is widespread recognition of the need for rapid improvement in our systems of payment," Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community commissioner in charge of financial services, said in a statement.

headline: Gorbachev Denies Any Shift Away From Liberalization
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declared today that the confrontations in the Baltic states did not mark any change in his policies, and he rejected accusations that he had abandoned his reformist course.    Mr. Gorbachev made the defense of his embattled leadership at a hastily called news conference, but he declined to answer any questions after reading a prepared statement except for one pre-arranged written question about the war in the gulf.

headline: IN OTHER SECTIONS
abstract: DOES OPEC HAVE A FUTURE?  The gulf war may do long-lasting damage to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, by stimulating oil production while depressing global demand. Business Day, page D1.    EMPLOYEE ASSISTANCE A growing number of companies are organizing support groups and providing counseling and assistance to workers with relatives in the Persian Gulf. Business Day, page D1.    TENSE CLASSROOMS Children of Government policy makers and those of Middle Eastern diplomats share classes near Washington, producing tension. Page A16.   PRESIDENTIAL MATERIAL?  When the President meets with his war council, it brings together several of the leading 1996 Republican Presidential prospects. Page B7.

headline: SOVIET ARMY RAIDS LITHUANIA OFFICES
abstract: Soviet Army troops using tanks and live ammunition today stormed the Lithuanian press center and a building occupied by the Lithuanian civilian militia, sharply escalating Moscow's campaign against this rebellious republic.    The dramatic midday show of force reportedly left seven people hurt, including an unarmed civilian guard shot in the face by an enraged army colonel who sprayed the press building with machine gun fire after being doused by a firehose.

headline: Trump Talks With Banks
abstract: Donald J. Trump and his advisers are negotiating with bankers to try to rework the financial package that saved the developer from bankruptcy last year, people close to the Trump Organization said yesterday. The talks were first reported yesterday in The Philadelphia Inquirer.    The talks with the lead banks that arranged the financial rescue plan for Mr. Trump are in the preliminary stages, these people said.

headline: Top Story on Moscow TV: Vote 'Da' on Referendum
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's determination to win an important referendum on the nation's future was signaled on the main television news program tonight, with a Government-controlled tide of reports that accused foreigners of plotting against the vote and domestic critics of fomenting civil disorder.    Much of the evening news program, Vremya, was devoted to propaganda as the Gorbachev Government headed toward the referendum March 17 on the issue of protecting the national union from dismemberment by sovereignty-minded republics.

headline: People
abstract: * Felicia Ferber, Catherine Basile, Linda Greene, Paul Mavis and Nick Provenzana have been promoted to vice president at Geer, DuBois Advertising, New York. * Larry Dobrow has resigned as manager of corporate communications at Bozell, New York.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Lebanon; Israelis Continue Raids in Southern Lebanon
abstract: For the second day in a row, the Israeli Air Force struck guerrilla targets in southern Lebanon today, and the Lebanese Army moved into the area for the first time in 13 years to extend the authority of the central Government.   The police said Israeli helicopter gunships fired air-to-surface missiles at two villages east of Sidon, Serba and Homin, in the district of Iqlim al Toffah. Israeli aircraft struck in that area on Tuesday, killing 12 people and wounding 30. There was no immediate word on casualties in the attack today.

headline: BUSINESS DIARY/February 10-15
abstract: THE ECONOMY   Washington and London, at Odds in the Air  All's fair in love, war and international airline negotiations. Disputes over airline rights can divide even friends as close as Britain and the United States. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner rejected British Airways' proposed fare cuts to the United States last Tuesday. Britain had blocked the sale by Pan Am and Trans World Airlines, both desperate for cash, of several London routes to Heathrow airport that United and American Airlines want to buy. Sir Colin Marshall, chief executive of British Airways, flew into New York himself last week to display solicitude for the ailing airlines. The dispute is "not about knocking Pan Am or T.W.A. out of business altogether," he said. He also urged timid Americans to resume traveling abroad; those who don't risk losing business, he said. What British Airways actually seeks are broader operating rights in the United States, said American analysts. Problem is, that sort of deal might normally take a year to work out; T.W.A. and Pan Am need agreements within a few months.  Oddball Salary Inequities  When Babe Ruth was asked, about 60 years ago, why he deserved $80,000 when President Hoover only made $75,000, Ruth's legendary response was, "I had a better year than he did." A week ago, Roger Clemens signed a four-year contract giving him a record average of $5.4 million a year; President Bush draws $200,000. Clemens won 21 games, holding opponents to an average of less than two runs a game. George Bush showed quick reflexes in the Persian Gulf but bobbled the tax issue. So Clemens did have the better year. But 27 times better? Enough so that the cost of a single Clemens victory more than covers Bush's salary for an entire season? And the President certainly outplayed, say, Jeff Parrett, the Atlanta Braves pitcher, who recently settled for $855,000 after winning five, losing 10. Memo to team owners wanting to economize: draft George, the former Yale baseball captain, when his Washington contract is up. Alcohol-Fed Inflation Economists have found another fuel to blame for increasing wholesale inflation. A record 5.9 percent jump in alcohol prices raised the core inflation rate in January by five-tenths of 1 percent. Higher alcohol taxes do not figure into producer prices, but many manufacturers took the chance to raise their own prices. Some economists said that, even after accounting for liquor costs, the rising core rate would keep the Federal Reserve from easing further. "The Fed will rest on its oars for at least a couple more weeks," said Irwin L. Kellner of Manufacturers Hanover Trust. The broader inflation rate, including food and energy, fell one-tenth of 1 percent, as oil prices declined. Golden Arch of Catfish?  McDonald's believes it has found a recipe for Southern success: The Crispy Catfish Sandwich, a 2.3-ounce patty with lettuce and tangy sauce on a bun. McDonald's plans to sell it at 214 outlets in Alabama, Arkansas, Mississippi, Kentucky and Tennessee. Restaurants that specialize in catfish are hardly trembling. Don Buckner, general manager of Hall's on the River in Winchester, Ky., described McDonald's seafood sandwiches as "block pieces of fish" -- suitable for someone who would otherwise have a quarter-pounder. His $9.95 all-you-can-eat catfish dinner includes vegetables and hush puppies, he added. No hush puppies at McDonald's, said a spokeswoman, convinced that Southern customers will accept french fries. Competition for Cellular Lines All that static on the cellular phone lines is coming from aggrieved duopolists. The Federal Communications Commission decided on Wednesday to allow a new form of mobile service in six cities, including New York. Radio dispatch companies for taxis and delivery services will be able to squeeze thousands of other customers into their narrow slices of the radio spectrum. Cellular services that have flourished under rules allowing only two in each city could find competition heating up. Analysts doubt the new service, to be offered initially by Fleet Call Inc. of Bloomfield, N.J., will match cellular's flexibility and features. But the cellular industry called the decision unfair and threatened a fight. Production Declines Ease The slump in industrial output continued for a fourth month in January, but the decline was a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent after much steeper drops in the two previous months. Some economists said the report hints that the worst of the recession is past. But industries used only 79.9 percent of their capacity, the least in four years. In Brief A seven-tenths of 1 percent decline in already lean business inventories in December gave economists hope that any increase in demand would result in higher production. Citibank, long aloof and superior, has decided to join the automated teller machine masses. Its machines will become part of the Cirrus network, sharing access with machines from 7,200 other banks and financial institutions.  COMPANIES   George Ball Steps Down When the big boys on Wall Street are suffering, a guy who tried to play with them but failed is truly in trouble. George L. Ball resigned as chairman and chief executive of Prudential-Bach Securities last Wednesday, felled by his loss of $308 million in less than nine years as the firm's chairman and chief executive. Mr. Ball tried to transform a humdrum brokerage firm into a glamorous, global investment bank, throwing around millions to hire star financiers. When the Prudential Insurance Company of America lost patience with his prodigal ways, he responded with what he called a "light cruiser" strategy, fighting only those competitive battles that he believed the firm could win. The losses continued, however, and Mr. Ball finally gave up his command. Carter Hawley Hale Goes Under  The real markdowns at Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. last week were on "junk bonds" and common stock; the largest department store chain on the West Coast, parent of the Broadway, Weinstocks and Emporium names, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The Carter Hawley Hale story was another 1980's tale of efficient wealth transfer from bondholders, long-term investors and employees -- whose 45 percent stake in the company is now nearly worthless -- to lawyers, investment bankers and the usual short-term profiteers. In its efforts to fight off a takeover attempt led by the Limited Inc. chain in 1987, Carter Hawley Hale had taken on hundreds of millions of dollars in debt. Little was left, therefore, to improve the stores. Competition and a slack American economy did the rest. Auto Makers in Decline The Ford Motor Company has cut back, streamlined production and improved efficiency enough to almost rival the Japanese. But its fourth-quarter loss of $519 million confounded its mission to keep profits flowing even when a recession strikes. The General Motors Corporation lost $1.62 billion, giving the industry its second-worst quarter ever. Analysts were understanding, saying that auto companies can face no worse combination than a recession and higher energy prices. As James P. Womack, an auto industry authority at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said, "You can't take a 25 percent hit on volume and make much money in any business." In Brief A Federal bankruptcy judge approved the sale of 67 Eastern Airlines takeoff and landing slots and five gates at Washington National Airport to Northwest Airlines for $35.5 million. The Justice Department blocked a bid by United Airlines for antitrust reasons. U S West Inc. agreed to pay $10 million, the largest antitrust fine ever, for violating the agreement that broke up the Bell System. INTERNATIONAL   Germany's High-Cost East One weekend last fall, a carnival on East Berlin's Alexanderplatz was so dreary that visitors had to ask to make sure it was taking place. On the Kurfurstendamm in West Berlin, meanwhile, every evening brought out raucous crowds lingering well past midnight. German officials said last Tuesday that giving eastern Germany much to celebrate will prove far more costly than they had thought. With a turnaround nowhere in sight, the Government approved $3 billion in emergency aid for cities and states. Economists say that rebuilding the eastern regions will cost the Government nearly $100 billion this year, more than $1 trillion over the decade. Traditional Eastern European export markets have evaporated, factories are closing and residents are leaving for the West. Germany's bind might well pinch relations with the United States. The cost of aiding the easterners makes Germans more reluctant to lower interest rates in support of the dollar or finance the war in the Middle East. Trouble With the Trade Deficit The trade deficit is heading in the right direction for the wrong reasons. The gap shrank to $6.3 billion in December, better than most economists had expected. Imports fell 7.9 percent, as the recession curbed America's appetite for foreign goods. But exports slipped also, by 2.1 percent, auguring ill for one of the economy's few healthy areas. "We can't count on that sector as much in the months ahead," said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. As foreign economies slow, not even a weaker dollar is sufficient to stoke overseas demand.

headline: Another Yugoslav State Breaks Ties
abstract: More of the fraying legal ties binding Yugoslavia's six quarrelsome republics snapped today when the Parliament of Croatia adopted measures giving the republic's Government veto power over federal laws that it deems dangerous to its sovereignty and national interests.   The Parliament of the second-largest republic also adopted resolutions late tonight that back a plan to dissolve Yugoslavia and warn that the republic would withdraw its representatives from federal agencies if the federal presidency did not rescind an order demanding the disbanding of paramilitary units in Croatia.

headline: The Vote That Congress Can't Forget
abstract: For more than two decades, the Congressional vote that lawmakers most often cite as the one they would like to take back is their 1964 vote for the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, the resolution that was used as authority for the war in Vietnam. Only two Senators and no Representatives voted no.   Twenty-seven of those lawmakers are still in Congress. And as they prepared for Saturday's vote on what was even more clearly the equivalent of a declaration of war, the resolution to authorize the use of military force in the Persian Gulf, the memories of that earlier vote weighed heavily on the minds of the seven senators and 20 representatives who served then and still serve now.

headline: Tourists Stay Home, Blighting the Caribbean
abstract: As a glance down any of the nearly empty beaches here attests, these are difficult times for the islands of the Caribbean.   The region's all-important tourism industry has been left reeling by a dramatic decrease in travel by Americans from causes as diverse as the Persian Gulf war, a global recession and a relatively mild winter in the northeastern United States.

headline: Weather in the Gulf
abstract: A cold front will push showers into Syria, Israel and northwest Iraq. Increasing winds over northern Saudi Arabia will cause some blowing dust and sand. Clouds will spread east later today. Winds will become southeast at 7 to 15 knots over the Persian Gulf. Temperatures: Baghdad, high 64, low 38; Riyadh, high 75, low 47; Dhahran, high 72, low 57.

headline: Gorbachev Denounces Radicals, Meaning Yeltsin
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev accused Soviet radicals today of seeking to achieve power by force and said the country could slide into civil war if their campaign was not stopped.   Mr. Gorbachev, in combative mood during a trip to the republic of Byelorussia, also called for a quick end to American military action in the Persian Gulf and said progress in superpower relations was still fragile.

headline: Royal Navy to Train Women To Fly Helicopters, Then Jets
abstract: Women are to be trained for the first time to fly Royal Navy aircraft, Britain's Minister of State for the Armed Forces announced today.   The women who will serve as pilots will initially fly helicopters, and will later pilot Sea Harrier jet fighters, Archie Hamilton said in a letter to the House of Commons.   "We intend to widen the employment of women as air crew to enable them to undertake aviation roles in the Royal Navy," Mr. Hamilton wrote.   The Royal Air Force has already started training women for duty as pilots.   A Defense Ministry spokesman estimated that the first women trained as pilots could be ready to fly in less than three years.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Air Midwest Inc., an airline based in Wichita, Kan., said it had accepted an offer of $8 a share made by Mesa Airlines Inc., Farmington., N.M. * Baroid Corp., Houston, a drilling services and equipment company, said it had agreed to acquire Diamond Boart Stratabit S.A. from Diamond Boart S.A. of Belgium and Sanvik A.B., Sanviken, Sweden, for $70 million in cash and five-year warrants to buy two million Baroid shares at $7.875 each. * CIT Group Holdings Inc., New York, a subsidiary of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Corp., announced that the Federal Reserve had approved its planned acquisition of Fidelcor Business Credit Corp., the commercial finance unit of First Fidelity Bancorp., Lawrenceville, N.J. * Delphax Systems, Randolph, Mass., a printing technology concern, said it had acquired the Imaging Systems division, in Hopkinton, Mass., of Avery Dennison, Pasadena, Calif. * Hamilton Standard, Windsor Locks, Conn., a unit of United Technologies Corp., plans to reduce its work force by 550 people. The reductions -- about 5 percent of its 13,000-member work force -- will be through layoffs, voluntary resignations and retirements. * RTZ Corp., London, said its Capper Pass & Son Ltd. tin smelter unit is to close in the next six months, with the loss of 489 jobs at the plant.

headline: Dividend Linked To Pet Inc. Spinoff
abstract: The Whitman Corporation declared a dividend of one share of Pet Inc. common stock for each share of Whitman common stock to accomplish a previously announced spinoff of the food operation. Payment of the dividend is conditional on receipt of a ruling from the Internal Revenue Service by March 28 that the distribution is tax-free to shareholders and the company. If a favorable ruling is received by March 28, the dividend will be paid on April 1.   Whitman said the dividend would establish Pet Inc. as an independent company. After the spinoff, Whitman will consist of three operating companies: Pepsi-Cola General Bottlers, the Midas International Automotive Company and Hussman refrigeration operations.

headline: Saatchi & Saatchi Posts $9.3 Million Pretax Loss
abstract: The Saatchi & Saatchi Company said yesterday that it had a pretax loss of $:5.2 million, or $9.3 million, for the fourth quarter of last year.    The loss was in contrast to a profit of $:19.1 million, or about $34.2 million, during the comparable period in 1989.

headline: Universal Computer Code Due
abstract: A group of leading computer companies today announced an ambitious effort to develop a lingua franca for the electronics age, a universal digital code that could be used by computers to represent letters and characters in all the world's languages.   A consortium has been formed to develop and promote the new code, known as Unicode. Its 12 members include many top computer companies that are often fierce rivals, like I.B.M., Apple Computer, Microsoft, Sun Microsystems and Xerox.

headline: Advertising 'Bad Boys' Grow Up in a Downturn
abstract: It was 2:20 P.M. at the headquarters of Kirshenbaum & Bond Advertising on the fringe of SoHo, and surprisingly enough, nobody was swinging from the chandeliers. Instead, 10 copywriters, art directors and executives were crowded into a tiny conference room, debating whether a market research study adequately tested consumer reactions to a new ad.   That conventional scene was significant because Kirshenbaum & Bond is not supposed to care about market research. The three-and-a-half-year-old agency built its reputation onhumorous advertising, the kind shot from the hip, not from a researcher's computer. A typical Kirshenbaum piece of work was an ad for an Italian restaurant riddled with mock bullet holes. Thriving in a Downturn     Madison Avenue know-it-alls predicted that sort of advertising would eventually destroy the agency, especially as the country sank into a recession that many thought would make clients more conservative.

headline: Commodore Net Soars on Europe Sales
abstract: Continuing its rebound, Commodore International Ltd. today reported more than a threefold gain in earnings for the quarter ended Dec. 31, primarily because of strong European sales of personal computers.    Also today, two longtime makers of large computer systems, the Unisys Corporation and the Control Data Corporation, reported losses.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Automobiles Peugeot, a unit of Peugeot S.A., Paris, said it would extend temporary production slowdowns into April, closing for three days at its Sochaux plant in France and one at its Mulhouse plant. * BellSouth Corp., Atlanta, will buy the Puerto Rico Telephone Authority in a preliminary deal valued at $2.5 billion, according to people close to the negotiations. But Fabio Garcia Matienzo, president of the Puerto Rico Telephone Authority, denied that there was any agreement and said talks were continuing.

headline: Castrol Tries to Quash Talk of Dropping Scali
abstract: Castrol Inc. attempted yesterday to quash speculation that it might terminate its relationship with Scali, McCabe, Sloves Inc.   While Castrol has put an account for Super Clean, its new automotive engine cleaner, under review, Edward J. Carhart, vice president of marketing at Castrol, said yesterday that Scali would continue to handle its main business, which includes GTX brand motor oil.

headline: February Durables Orders Down
abstract: Orders for long-lasting goods like cars and refrigerators weakened in February in an economy that was troubled by recession and war, the Commerce Department said today.    But a report released by the Conference Board in New York showed a strong rebound in consumer confidence this month.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Security; With No Signs of Terrorism, F.B.I. Still Adds Precautions
abstract: Federal law-enforcement officials say they have no hard evidence that the Persian Gulf war will lead to terrorist acts in the United States, but they say extra security precautions are justified.   On that premise, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun an aggressive program intended to heighten vigilance in the United States and to serve as a warning to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that plotting terror is futile.

headline: Statement of the Group of 7
abstract: Following is the statement issued yesterday by the finance ministers and central bank governors of the Group of Seven after their meeting in New York:    The finance ministers and central bank governors of Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States met on Jan. 20 and 21, 1991, in New York City for an exchange of views on current international economic and financial issues. The managing director of the I.M.F. participated in the multilateral surveillance discussions.   The ministers and governors reviewed their economic policies and prospects and reaffirmed their support for economic policy coordination at this critical time.   They noted that although growth in all their economies had slowed, expansion of the world economy continues, and the pace of activity could be expected to pick up later this year.   They noted that growth remains particularly strong in Germany and Japan.   Implementation of sound fiscal policies, combined with stability oriented monetary policies, should create conditions favorable to lower global interest rates and a stronger world economy. They also stressed the importance of a timely and successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round.   The ministers and governors also discussed the situation in global financial markets in light of uncertainties arising from the gulf war and developments in the Soviet Union. They agreed to strengthen cooperation and to monitor developments in exchange markets.   The ministers and governors are prepared to respond as appropriate to maintain stability in international financial markets.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Iraq; In Growing Disarray, Iraqis Fight Iraqis
abstract: Republican Guard soldiers, their green uniforms dirty and torn, crouched near a cement wall in a small mud-and-wattle village and warily viewed the rooftops above.    Rapid bursts of fire from AK-47 rifles ripped through the rain, the bullets splattering in the ankle-deep mud and pinging against the cement. Cries of confusion were heard up and down the street as soldiers tumbled to take cover.   "Shiites?" an Iraqi soldier asked of another, "or army?" The fact that the soldier had lost all certainty of who the enemy was -- deserters or Muslim fundamentalist rebels -- showed the depth of disarray that has seized Iraq since the allied rout of Baghdad's forces from Kuwait.

headline: Housing in Connecticut; Lower-Priced Condos for Stamford
abstract: A vacant block sits in a streetscape of bulky commercial buildings and modest wood frame houses in the Waterside section of Stamford, and beginning next month it will be transformed into a condominium community. The project initiates a chapter in the neighborhood's rejuvenation and in the city's efforts to provide affordable housing.   Seventy-five condominium town houses and apartments are planned on the site at Selleck Street and Southfield Avenue; they will be sold to people with annual earnings of $35,000 to $50,000 who have had difficulty finding a home they could afford in the city.

headline: Pan Am Sale Of Routes Called Near
abstract: The Transporation Department is expected to issue an order this week giving preliminary approval of the sale of Pan Am's London routes to United Airlines, an official familiar with the department's policy said yesterday.   The order would be a big step toward approval of the sale, which Pan American World Airways, eager for the $290 million it would bring, wants to complete as quickly as possible.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Up Slightly
abstract: Stocks in Tokyo were slightly higher today in light trading. Brokers said the market was treading water, uncertain about the prospects for United States economic recovery and interest-rate cuts.    The Nikkei index of 225 issues finished up 94.45 points, or less than 1 percent, to 25,976.02. At midday, the Nikkei was up 57.65 points, to 25,939.22, with 200 million shares traded. On Friday, the index lost 527.65 points, a 2 percent decline.

headline: Hussein's Vision for G.I.'s: 'Swim in Their Own Blood'
abstract: With diplomatic efforts deadlocked in Geneva, President Saddam Hussein told the top leaders of his ruling party that he would make United States military forces "swim in their own blood" if war breaks out in the Persian Gulf, state-run television reported tonight.    Mr. Hussein made the remarks as United States, European and other embassies associated with the military alliance confronting Iraq prepared to carry out a coordinated evacuation plan, probably by special air charter, at the end of the week.

headline: As Ireland Battles AIDS, the Church Is Called a Roadblock
abstract: This nation is playing out the tragic drama of AIDS, and tradition, Roman Catholic orthodoxy and ignorance are among the grim protagonists, advocates in the fight against the disease say.    Ireland does not appear to have as serious a problem as many other countries; it has proportionally far fewer cases than the United States and even fewer than other European countries, official statistics indicate. But advocates say the situation is troubling because conservative attitudes arising from Roman Catholicism both predispose this country to the spread of AIDS and hamper its prevention.

headline: Data Bank/March 31, 1991
abstract: Personal Spending   Feb.   Jan.   Dec.        Monthly percent change   0.6   --0.6   0.7        New Home Sales        Monthly percent change   16.2   --12.6   --4.2        Farm Prices    March   Feb.   Jan.
