Monthly percent change   0.2   0.0   1.4        Gross National Product   IV Q'90   III Q'90   II Q'90        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions   $4,153.4   $4,170.0   $4,155.1        Real G.N.P. Growth        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in percent   --1.6   1.4   0.4        Money Supply Growth   3 mos.   6 mos.   12 mos.        M-1, annual percent change   4.7   4.3   4.1        Money Supply Growth        M-2   2.8   2.7   3.2        Money Supply Growth                M-3   3.2   2.2   1.9

headline: Alimony Lives -- but Call It Maintenance
abstract: To the Editor:   The financial advice in " 'Tis the Season to Get Divorced" (Jan. 13) is excellent, but the accompanying article on alimony deserves a footnote.   The flat statement that "only a nonworking spouse in a 'lengthy marriage' is eligible for alimony" is misleading. While alimony or maintenance, as it is now called, is less common than before, it is by no means limited to older full-time housewives. Younger women who have interrupted their careers for child-bearing can make a persuasive case for maintenance while they refresh their working skills, and even women who have remained in the work force but sacrificed advancement for the sake of motherhood have a strong legal argument for at least several years of maintenance -- and often get it.   Whether or not divorced women will be awarded or can negotiate such support depends on the norms of local courts and the skills of their attorneys, but they should not be put off by the unwarranted pessimism of the financial planners in your article. LOIS BRENNER  New York, N.Y., Jan. 16

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Buffton Corp., Fort Worth, a maker of electronic and plastic products, sold its National Pipe Co. operations to LCP National Plastics Inc., and its National Conduit Co. to its former owner, Jaakko Uuranniemi. The sale of the companies brought Buffton $15.4 million. * Comshare Inc., Ann Arbor, Mich., an information company, will purchase the operating assets and business of Execucom Systems Corp., a subsidiary of MPSI Systems Inc., Tulsa, Okla., for about $12 million.

headline: Lebanon Nears Pivotal Point in Disarming Militias
abstract: The Lebanese Government moved today into a pivotal phase of its program to fully disband all private militias, as President Elias Hrawi met with Syria's Vice President to discuss support from the 40,000 Syrian troops in Lebanon in suppressing any opposition to the effort.    The Syrian Vice President, Abdel Halim Khaddam, second-ranking in the Government after President Hafez al-Assad, paid an unscheduled visit to Beirut, the first by a high-level Syrian official in 10 years. He drove directly to Mr. Hrawi's presidential villa in mainly Muslim West Beirut, which is policed jointly by Lebanese and Syrian soldiers. The two leaders were soon joined by the Lebanese Prime Minister, Omar Karami.

headline: Chase Will Sell Ohio Branches
abstract: The Chase Bank of Ohio, a unit of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, said today that it had agreed in principle to sell nine branch offices in the Cincinnati and Columbus areas to Fifth Third Bancorp.   The sale is part of Chase Manhattan's plan to streamline after heavy loan losses. Last summer, Chase announced a $300 million cost-reduction effort that cut about 5,000 workers. Chase, the nation's third- largest bank, reported a $334 million loss for 1990.    The Ohio transaction will affect five banks near Columbus and four near Cincinnati with total deposits of about $220 million. The sale, for which a price was not disclosed, is subject to regulatory approval and is to be completed by the end of September.   Chase Ohio was formed six years ago when Chase Manhattan bought six institutions that closed during Ohio's savings and loan crisis. Fifth Third Bancorp is based in Cincinnati and owns the Fifth Third and 10 other banks with 214 offices and assets of $8 billion.

headline: Allies Rush to Cut Off Hussein's Elite Forces
abstract: Having collapsed Iraq's defensive structure in Kuwait, the American and allied forces have moved to close off escape routes for Iraqi forces south of Basra.   From the beginning of the campaign, the allied strategy has been to capture Iraqi forces south of Basra, strip them of their weapons and deprive President Saddam Hussein of the core of his army. And today American military officials expressed confidence that they had boxed in the Iraqi troops.

headline: Researchers Act to Cut Auto Pollution Further
abstract: Tailpipe catalytic converters are one of the most successful technologies in the history of air pollution control, eliminating 96 to 98 percent of the carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons, and three-quarters of the nitrogen oxide emitted by car engines. But this is no longer good enough.    Air quality in California is still so poor, even with stringent anti-pollution laws, that almost any emission is too much. So officials there are pushing the auto makers to do better, and several other large states plan to follow suit. This has set off intensive research into improving the technology used in catalytic converters.

headline: Role of Taxes Debated in Adding to Income Gap
abstract: Federal tax policy contributed to the widening gap between the wealth of rich and poor Americans in the 1980's, a group of experts told the Senate Budget Committee today, but they disagreed on how great a role other economic factors played in the inequity.   There was near unanimity that, as the committee chairman, Jim Sasser of Tennessee, put it, the 80's were "the decade when the rich got richer and the poor got poorer."

headline: Deadly Impasse Said to Go On in Somali City
abstract: The Italian Ambassador, who is manning the only operating embassy in the embattled Somali capital, Mogadishu, said today that Government forces and rebels continued to fight with neither side holding an edge.    He said the city's Roman Catholic Cathedral, one of the main buildings in the city of low-rise whitewashed structures and green palms, was ransacked and set on fire today.

headline: Bank Holiday in Argentina As Currency Plunges 12.5%
abstract: Argentine banks and foreign exchange houses were ordered closed and President Carlos Saul Menem's economic advisers offered to resign today after the austral plunged 12.5 percent against the dollar.   President Menem is considering the resignations of the Economy Minister, Antonio Gonzalez; the central bank president, Javier Gonzalez Fraga, and others, a presidential spokesman, Humberto Toledo, said. A decision is expected on Tuesday.   Banks and foreign exchange houses operated normally today but will be closed on Tuesday and Wednesday, according to a report by Telam, the Government news agency. Dollars Are Sold     The central bank sold $45 million to halt the austral's devaluation as the exchange rate plunged. The currency closed at about 8,000 australs to the dollar after opening at about 7,000.   The austral, which was severely overvalued for most of 1990, has lost 38 percent of its value against the dollar since Dec. 19, when the exchange rate was 4,985 australs to the dollar.   Devaluation is a key economic barometer in this South American nation, which has been buffeted by inflation for two decades.   The Government fears merchants will increase prices in line with the dollar, causing increases in the cost of living.

headline: Maxwell Selling Pergamon, Cornerstone of His Empire
abstract: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher who bought The Daily News in New York two weeks ago, announced today that he was selling Pergamon Press, the specialty publishing house in Oxford where he began his business empire 40 years ago.    In a statement released here today, the Maxwell Communication Corporation said it had agreed to sell Pergamon, a strongly profitable publisher of scientific and academic journals and one of the financial pillars of Mr. Maxwell's realm, to Elsevier, the Dutch publishing group.

headline: Europe Offers Plan to Encourage Iraq's Withdrawal From Kuwait
abstract: In a move to encourage Iraq to pull its troops out of Kuwait, the 12-nation European Community promised Baghdad today that it would work to resolve all problems of the Middle East if the gulf crisis could be settled peacefully.    At an emergency meeting here, foreign ministers of the community nations said "Iraq should receive the assurance not to be subject to a military intervention" once it had carried out United Nations Security Council resolutions demanding its withdrawal from Kuwait.

headline: May Stores Prices $100 Million Issue
abstract: The May Department Stores Company, St. Louis, priced $100 million in debentures yesterday that are due in 2021 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.   The 30-year debentures were given a 10 1/4 percent coupon and priced at 99.53 to yield 10.30 percent, or about 193 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.   Underwriters said the debentures were noncallable for life and rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; Israeli Aide Cancels U.S. Trip
abstract: In what his rivals called a fit of political pique, Foreign Minister David Levy this morning canceled a trip to Washington that had been scheduled for today, saying he believed Defense Minister Moshe Arens had undercut him with his own visit to Washington, which just ended.   Mr. Arens returned today from meetings with President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in which the main topic of conversation seemed to be Israel's growing impatience with the pace of allied efforts to destroy Iraq's scud missile launchers.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Poll; Public Shows Support for Land War
abstract: The initial reaction of the American public to the start of the ground war against Iraq is strongly supportive, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll.    Seventy-five percent of 687 adults interviewed Sunday evening said "the United States did the right thing in starting the ground war against Iraq," while 19 percent said the United States should have "waited longer to see if the bombing from the air worked," and 6 percent expressed no opinion.

headline: In the Age of the 'Black Box' War
abstract: For the past several decades, the Pentagon and the military contracting industry have spent billions of dollars developing sophisticated electronics capabilities, betting that advanced technology would give the United States a decisive advantage in any war. In the skies over Iraq and Kuwait last week, their strategy was put to its first real test, and the preliminary results seem to be good news for the military and its weapons suppliers.   Although claims of military successes were difficult to verify, Pentagon officials said that Tomahawk cruise missiles equipped with complex guidance equipment rocketed into Iraq, identified pre-programmed targets and apparently scored a series of precise hits. Air Force F-4G Wild Weasel aircraft packed with "black box" technology like radar-sensing and jamming gear sped in to destroy radar installations at surface-to-air missile sites. F-15E strike-fighters, equipped with a new system called Lantirn that allows pilots to identify and track targets at night, kept the skies clear of those Iraqi combat aircraft that ventured forth. Officials described how a "smart" bomb dropped from a radar-evading F-117A Stealth fighter-bomber was guided literally through the front door of a missile warehouse. When threatened by an incoming Iraqi Scud missile, American forces in Saudi Arabia shot it out of the night sky with the new and stunningly sophisticated Patriot antimissile system.

headline: GENSCHER AT EYE OF POLICY DEBATE
abstract: In the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war, a far-reaching political debate has broken out here over how Germany should fulfill its global responsibilities in the years ahead.    Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher is at the center of the debate. Polls show that Mr. Genscher is still held in high esteem by the German public, but he has been the target of stinging criticism from many political leaders, including some who supported him in the past.

headline: U.S. Chain Is Said to Plan Tokyo Store
abstract: Japanese who love to emulate fashionable New Yorkers may get a chance to spend their yen just like Manhattan's shoppers: Bloomingdale's is coming to the Tokyo area, according to reports here today.    A Japanese Bloomingdale's is being planned for the Makuhari area in neighboring Chiba Prefecture, said a leading financial newspaper, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, whose report was confirmed today by a local official. The report added that the department store, the first in what could be a chain here, might open in 1994 or 1995.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * Avery Dennison Corp., Pasadena, Calif., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $100 million in debt securities. * Associates First Capital Corp., a subsidiary of Ford Motor Co., has filed with the S.E.C. for a shelf offering of up to $300 million in senior unsecured notes.

headline: Palestinians Gratified by Israeli Easing of Bar to Migrant Workers
abstract: Palestinians from the occupied territories were gratified by two actions taken by Israeli authorities today, a week after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d asked the Government to lighten the pressure on the West Bank and Gaza Strip.    But the army said the timing of the actions was coincidental.

headline: Economic Scene; What Happens To Oil Prices?
abstract: AN effort to assess the economic consequences of the crushing of Iraq and the expulsion of Saddam Hussein's forces from Kuwait must start with the effect on oil prices and supplies.    It was the Iraqi leader's aim, long before the invasion of Kuwait, to gain more oil resources, force up oil prices and achieve the wealth and arms he needed to dominate the Arab world. After being frustrated by Iran, he turned against Kuwait.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Diplomacy; Kuwaiti Leaders Tell Baker Democratization Is Coming
abstract: The rulers of Kuwait told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that they intended to democratize their country in the near future, but added that until the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, is ousted, there will never be peace or stability in the Persian Gulf.    Mr. Baker, the first Bush Cabinet official to visit Kuwait since Iraqi troops were driven out, was also told that Kuwaiti leaders would be prepared to make peace with Israel only if it implemented the United Nations Security Council resolutions that call on Israel to trade occupied Arab lands for Arab recognition.

headline: Yeltsin Assails Gorbachev Rule For 'Stagnation'
abstract: Flush with the victory of his followers against the Kremlin's strong show of force a day ago, Boris N. Yeltsin assailed the central authorities today for seeking to restore the "period of stagnation" that preceded perestroika.    Mr. Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, issued the attack in a 90-minute report to a special session of the republic's Parliament. The meeting resumed today after the Kremlin withdrew the cordon of military vehicles and troops that was placed around the city center on Thursday in an attempt to block a demonstration by Yeltsin followers who took to the streets anyway, rallying peacefully in a crowd of more than 100,000.

headline: Business and the Law; Bank Regulators Losing in Court
abstract: A SERIES of Federal court decisions has held that regulators were overzealous in seizing some failed banks and savings and loans and that the Government could be liable for hundreds of millions of dollars in damages to investors.    In different cases, judges found that regulators overstepped their authority by reneging on promises to buyers of troubled savings and loans, by pushing healthy banks into insolvency, or by illegally trying to squeeze millions of dollars from owners of failed financial institutions.    Only a score of such lawsuits have been brought against the Government -- a minuscule number compared with the thousands of failed banks and savings and loans seized by regulators each year -- and many rulings are being appealed. But the trend has been against the Government, and some think it points to a disturbing pattern of regulators trying to reduce the cost of Federal bailouts at the expense of the law.      The validity of that interpretation, however, is still a matter of debate.   Rosemary Stewart, a lawyer with Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue in Washington and former director of enforcement for the Office of Thrift Supervision, thinks the courts have recognized that regulators "are going too far."   "In a vengence mentality after the savings and loan crisis," she said, "the Government is trying to get everything it possibly can."    But Alfred J. T. Byrne, general counsel of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Resolution Trust Corporation, feels the court decisions "reflect either a misunderstanding or a misapplication of the new law, or both."    "We do not draw any conclusion that there is a tide flowing against the Government agencies," he said.    No one contests the power of regulators to seize assets of insolvent banks and savings and loans in order to protect depositors' money. But several cases turn on interpretations of the savings and loan industry bailout legislation enacted by Congress in August 1989.    Two cases test the retroactive application of that law. They involve the seizure by regulators in March 1989 of several healthy Texas banks after their parent banks, MBank in Dallas and the Texas American Bank in Fort Worth, became insolvent.   Regulators pushed more than a dozen healthy subsidiary banks of the two companies into insolvency by failing to fully repay loans that the subsidiary banks made to the parents. Two courts have said that the subsidiaries are owed full payment under then-prevailing banking laws, but the Government is appealing on the ground that the 1989 bailout law permited only partial repayment.    The F.D.I.C. has since lobbied successfully to have the 1989 bailout law permit unequal payments to creditors of failed banks.    In another group of cases, regulators' attempts to abrogate concessions given to entice investors to buy failing savings and loans have been challenged. Eight of these cases have gone against the Government, four have gone in its favor and, in two others, the court said it had no jurisdiction.    The Government has lost three other cases that involved attempts by regulators to collect money from owners of failed savings and loans by forcing them to put up new capital after institutions were declared insolvent.    The 1989 bailout law is also being questioned in a group of cases involving concessions given by regulators to buyers of troubled savings and loans before the law's enactment. Regulators contend that the new law permits them to disregard these concessions, which are generally forbearances allowing newly acquired savings and loans to operate with lower capital requirements or more liberal lending policies than permitted by law.    One of the best known in this group of cases involves Far West Federal Bank, a Portland, Ore., savings and loan that regulators sold to investors in 1987. In return for investing some $27 million of capital, the Government gave the new investors 10 years to meet capital requirements and approved a liberal lending policy.    But with the 1989 bailout law, regulators told Far West that it was out of compliance with the law and that its owners faced daily fines of up to $1 million. Far West quickly complied, but as a result began losing money; officers and depositors fled and its balance sheet shrank.   Far West's owners now say the Government can take the institution back -- they just want their $27 million returned, along with $100 million in damages. United States District Judge Owen M. Panner agreed, ruling that regulators violated Fifth Amendment guarantees against illegal seizure of property and that their action was "economic suicide" for Far West." Damages have yet to be set.     A final batch of rulings against the Government involves attempts by regulators to collect money by enforcing capital requirements after a savings and loan failed. One leading case involves a Texas company named Tetco, which in 1983 bought a Texas savings and loan in San Antonio called the Bexar Savings Association. To get deposit insurance, Tetco agreed to certain capital levels and to add more when necessary. Over time, Tetco sunk some $25 million into Bexar.    Bexar, however, suffered losses and was declared insolvent and seized by regulators in February 1989, wiping out Tetco's investment. The Government then sued Tetco for $558 million -- the amount needed for Bexar to meet its capital requirements if it were still alive. But United States District Judge Lucius D. Bunton in San Antonio dismissed the Government's claim, as did judges in two similar cases elsewhere.

headline: 14 Wounded in Israeli Raid On a P.L.O. Base in Lebanon
abstract: For the second time in five days, Israeli fighter bombers today attacked a Palestinian guerrilla base in Lebanon, witnesses said. Lebanese police officials said 14 people were wounded in the attack.   The air strike came hours after Lebanese Army soldiers clashed with Christian militia fighters allied with Israel in a village east of Sidon, the port city 25 miles south of here.

headline: Executive at Sun Co. Moves Into No. 2 Post
abstract: The Sun Company, the nation's largest independent refiner of oil products, named Robert H. Campbell as president and chief operating officer yesterday. The move puts him in the No. 2 spot and makes him heir apparent to the chairman and chief executive, Robert McClements Jr.    Mr. McClements, 62 years old, formerly also held the title of president. The company does not have a manadatory retirement policy, but its senior executives traditionally retire around 65, a spokesman said.

headline: Hilton Plans to Seek Atlantic City License
abstract: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said today that it planned to apply for a license to operate a hotel and casino in Atlantic City with an eye toward entering the market.    "An opportunity for our company in Atlantic City could occur," said Barron Hilton, the company's chairman, in a statement. "We want to be in a position to proceed."

headline: Israeli General Pleads Guilty in Bribery Case
abstract: Only days after the Israeli Air Force began readjusting from a high state of alert during the Persian Gulf war, its officers are riveted by a new problem: a guilty plea by one of its most senior officers in a multimillion-dollar fraud and bribery scandal involving United States military contractors.    A military court in Tel Aviv is now deciding whether to accept the plea-bargain arrangement worked out for Brig. Gen. Rami Dotan, who was one of the Air Force's most senior purchasing officers. General Dotan also pleaded guilty to charges that he tried to arrange to kill the man who first exposed the scandal. He did not succeed at that.     In December, he was charged with taking bribes and kickbacks totaling more than $10 million from unnamed American contractors from whom Israel bought aircraft parts and other materials. General Dotan headed the Defense Ministry's department of military acquisitions in New York in 1984 and 1985.

headline: Citicorp's $600 Million Stock Sale
abstract: Citicorp announced last night that it had sold $600 million in preferred stock to a broad group of investors and had thus completed one of the key portions of its plan to strengthen its finances.    The announcement came just two weeks after a member of the Saudi royal family, Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, invested $590 million in Citicorp with a purchase of preferred stock.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; The Limited Names 2 Division Presidents
abstract: The Limited Inc., the specialty retailing company, said yesterday that it had appointed new presidents at its Limited Stores and Victoria's Secret Stores divisions.   At Limited Stores, with 781 outlets, Howard Gross becomes president, succeeding Verna Gibson, who announced on Monday her decision to leave the business.

headline: Cutbacks Bring Loss At GlenFed
abstract: GlenFed Inc., parent of the nation's fourth-largest savings and loan association, said today that it would add to loan-loss reserves, sell some assets, freeze management salaries and suspend its dividend. The company also said it would eliminate 600 jobs in the next quarter through attrition, but layoffs were not ruled out.    GlenFed said the moves, which it called "necessary and prudent," would result in a $140.8 million loss for the quarter.

headline: Civilian Toll in Iraq Could Strain Alliance And Bring Pressure to Speed a Ground War
abstract: After weeks of trying to minimize American military casualties to preserve domestic backing for the Persian Gulf war, President Bush is confronting the prospect that civilian casualties in Iraq could threaten international support for the continuing bombing campaign.   Administration officials and Western diplomats said today that a rising civilian toll, along with anti-American demonstrations in the Middle East and diplomatic overtures by the Soviet Union and other countries, could bring pressure to bear on Mr. Bush to advance the start of a ground offensive.

headline: BankAmerica Earnings Climbed 6.3% in Fourth Quarter
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's second-largest banking company, reported a 6.3 percent earnings increase for the fourth quarter. In a statement, it also reiterated its interest in using its increasingly strong financial position to acquire the failed Bank of New England Corporation.   Earnings rose to $287 million, or $1.29 a share, compared with $270 million, or $1.21 a share, in the quarter a year ago. Revenues climbed to $3.2 billion from $2.9 billion.

headline: German Approval For Pactel Venture
abstract: The Pactel Corporation, a subsidiary of the Pacific Telesis Group, said the German Goverment had issued a letter of intent accepting the plan submitted by Mannesmann Mobilfunk to provide cellular service to the former East Germany. Pactel owns 26 percent of Mannesmann Mobilfunk.    Mannesmann Mobilfunk's German network will reach a total population of 77 million residents, with Pactel's share equivalent to 20 million potential customers. The acceptance comes three months after Mannesmann submitted a plan to extend the digital cellular network it is building in the former West Germany into eastern Germany.

headline: Allied-Lyons Reports Big Loss on Currency
abstract: Allied-Lyons P.L.C., the British food and liquor company, disclosed today that it had a foreign exchange loss of about $:150 million, or about $285 million, and that its finance director had resigned.   The company said in a statement that the loss was being investigated by its auditors, KPMG Peat Marwick McLintock, and by the National Westminster Bank.

headline: POWER STRUGGLE IN KUWAIT BLOCKS NEW GOVERNMENT
abstract: More than a month after Kuwait's liberation from Iraqi rule, efforts to form a new government here are paralyzed by a power struggle that pits the hereditary rulers, the Sabah family, against an opposition demanding more democracy.    The contention stems historically from the way oil wealth transformed this tiny emirate into a unique society.

headline: Rockwell Notes To Yield 8.489%
abstract: A $200 million note issue by the Rockwell International Corporation was priced yesterday through competitive bidding won by a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.    The 8 3/8 percent notes due 2001 were offered to the public at a price of 99.236 to yield 8.489 percent, or about 67 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.   Noncallable through maturity, the notes are rated Aa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: President's Retirement Bringing Shift at Nucor
abstract: The Nucor Corporation, a leader in an efficient new steel technology, announced a shuffling of its management yesterday under F. Kenneth Iverson, chairman and chief executive.    The new lineup puts John D. Correnti, 43 years old, in the posts of president and chief operating officer; Samuel Siegel, 61, becomes vice chairman and continues as chief financial officer, and Terry S. Lisenby becomes vice president and corporate controller.

headline: Profits Spurt at Lockheed
abstract: The Lockheed Corporation reported sharply higher earnings today for the fourth quarter, showing a profit of $99 million, or $1.57 a share. In the corresponding period a year ago, Lockheed lost $109 million.   The loss last year developed after Lockheed subtracted $300 million from pretax earnings because of a miscalculation it made in bidding for a contract to develop an antisubmarine aircraft for the Navy.   Revenues fell 1.9 percent in the latest quarter, to $2.97 billion from $3.03 billion.   Daniel M. Tellep, the chairman of Lockheed, a military contractor based in Calabasas, Calif., said he expected revenues this year "to remain stable."   The company's fortunes face a critical turning point when the Air Force chooses a contractor to build the next-generation advanced tactical figther jet by May 1. A team of contractors led by Lockheed is competing with a team led by the Northrop Corporation.   For the year, Lockheed's earnings were $335 million, or $5.30 a share, up sharply from $2 million, or 3 cents a share, in 1989, when the company incurred substantial losses on several development programs for the Government.

headline: Sporting Goods Sales
abstract: Factory sales of sporting goods are expected to grow by 6 percent in 1991, to $32.7 billion, from $30.8 billion a year earlier, a trade group said on Thursday. The Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association said the industry was better positioned than others to withstand the recession. Sports apparel sales at the wholesale level are expected to grow by 8 percent.

headline: The Nativity Is Now Legal For Russians
abstract: Today was the first officially celebrated Christmas since 1917 in this rough beast of a city slouching toward an uncertain future.    "I think things will slowly get better," said Vassily P. Aksyonov, the novelist who now lives in Washington, "if they can just avoid sliding back into authoritarianism."

headline: Bailout Money Is Threatened
abstract: Members of New England's Congressional delegation threatened today to block new spending for the savings and loan bailout until the Bush Administration comes forward with a plan to ease the credit crunch.    Massachusetts and other New England states were hit early and particularly hard by the recession, and the failure of Bank of New England and two associated banks this month has further shaken the region's already weak banking system.   The threat to link the credit issue to the bailout could further delay the new financing the Administration has said it will need by the end of February to continue seizing ailing savings and loans.    The Administrations wants $77 billion this year to dispose of 225 institutions.

headline: Northwest Air Raises Possibility of a Merger
abstract: In a letter to employees today, the co-chairman of Northwest Airlines, Alfred Checchi, broached the idea of merging with a stronger airline or selling the carrier's lucrative Pacific routes.   But Mr. Checchi said management strongly favored remaining independent and might need help from employees to thrive as an independent carrier.

headline: Avon to Raise Dividend Payments
abstract: The Avon lady may stay independent after all. In a surprise move that analysts say could help it win a coming proxy fight, Avon Products Inc. said yesterday that it would increase its annual dividend 40 percent, to $1.40, and pay a special dividend of $3 a share, or more than a year's profits.   Chartwell Associates, Avon's largest shareholder and management's most vociferous opponent, said it would continue with its plan to mount a proxy fight at Avon's annual meeting in May.

headline: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
abstract: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.    The pool reporters obtain information while under military escort, and their accounts are subject to scrutiny by military censors before being distributed. Some of the information appearing today on American military operations was obtained under such circumstances.

headline: Irate Americans Get Gas Masks
abstract: Bowing to pressure from angry Americans and their elected representatives back home, the United States Embassy said today that it would offer gas masks to American citizens in Saudi Arabia.   It said the masks, obtained from military stocks, would be handed out as long as the supply lasted. But American diplomats made it clear that they believe fears of a chemical attack on the Saudi capital were unfounded.   Diplomatic sources, insisting on anonymity, said some American residents had complained to senators and congressional representatives, who in turn demanded an explanation of the embassy policy of not providing gas masks.

headline: Bush Asserts Need for Foreign Oil
abstract: Saying he was committed to "the power of the marketplace," President Bush presented an energy policy today that he asserted would save energy, increase domestic production of fuels and improve the environment without new taxes or harsh Government edicts.   Because the policy includes only a very limited effort to improve gasoline mileage -- the factor in the energy balance most experts believe easiest to influence -- Mr. Bush appeared to set the stage today for a major battle with Congress.

headline: FOR YUGOSLAVIA, ANOTHER IMPASSE
abstract: Leaders of Yugoslavia's six quarrelsome republics failed in talks today to find a way to overcome major obstacles blocking agreement on the country's future political configuration.   In their talks, the leaders sidestepped the central issues dividing the richer, independence-minded republics of Slovenia and Croatia, and the largest republic, Serbia, which favors strengthening the loose Yugoslav federation, an aide to a national Government official said.

headline: 37 Are Reported Killed In Soviet Ethnic Clash
abstract: Rival ethnic groups with armored vehicles and automatic weapons have clashed in the Soviet republic of Georgia, killing at least 37 people and wounding 150, the Soviet Vice President, Gennadi I. Yanayev, said today.   Casualty figures were expected to rise because reports had not come in from remote villages in the Georgian republic's South Ossetia region, Mr. Yanayev said.

headline: Peru Unlikely To Get Help
abstract: Peru, which is pressed for cash, is unlikely to receive assistance from big countries soon to help it bridge an $800 million fiscal gap, despite the end of the Persian Gulf war, the nation's President, Alberto Fujimori, said last week.   He said Peru would carry on repayments on its $21 billion foreign debt, adding, "Until now, we have not failed to make our monthly payments, and we hope our creditors will acknowledge that."   His remarks appeared aimed at reassuring Peru's international creditors after Prime Minister Carlos Torres said the country could not make repayments on its foreign debt indefinitely without additional credit.   Peru and the International Monetary Fund reached agreement in December on basic economic goals. The central bank governor, Jorge Chavez, said shortly afterward that nine countries, led by the United States, were willing to help bridge the fiscal gap.   The assistance would enable Peru to bridge a 1991 balance of payments gap and clear $2.15 billion in arrears to the I.M.F., the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank.

headline: Index of Leading Indicators Falls for 6th Month in a Row
abstract: The Government index created to predict turns in the economy fell four-tenths of 1 percent in January, its sixth straight decline, the Commerce Department reported today.   Despite the persistent negative readings in the index of leading indicators, the longest such string since 1984, most analysts still say the economy is likely to climb out of recession this summer.

headline: Mongolian President in U.S. to Sign Trade Agreement
abstract: Mongolia, a fledgling democracy wedged between the Soviet Union and China and long isolated economically, will sign its first trade agreement with the United States on Wednesday as part of efforts to broaden exchanges, officials of both Governments said.   The signing, which could lead to lower tariffs and more joint ventures, is scheduled as a high point of a trip to the United States by the newly elected President, Punsalmaagiyn Ochirbat, the first Mongolian leader ever to visit here. He arrived in this country on Sunday night.

headline: 'Junk' Index Posts a Gain
abstract: The First Boston Corporation's index of high-yield "junk bonds" posted a 2.7 percent positive return in January, its best showing since July.    The index of 240 issues reflected a number of positive developments, including the General Cinema Corporation's $1.4 billion agreement to acquire Harcourt Brace Jovanovich and RJR Nabisco's announcement that because of investor interest it was increasing the size of its debt exchange, analysts at First Boston said. The good news for those companies had a ripple effect through the market, the analysts said.    RJR Nabisco, which has more outstanding high-yield securities than any other company, said it had increased the size of an exchange offer to up to 41 percent, or $1.17 billion, of oustanding subordinated debentures due in 2007. Previously, the maximum to be exchanged was $752.7 million, or about 26 percent.

headline: Economic Scene; The Argument Over the Banks
abstract: THE battle has begun over the Administration's proposals for the most drastic overhaul of the nation's banking system since the Depression. President Bush's aim is to restore confidence in the banking system and make America's banks world leaders again.    As the Treasury stresses, of the 30 biggest banks in the world, ranked by deposits, nine were American in 1969, with the top three the Bank of America, Chase and First National City, which became Citibank; in 1989, only one of the top 30 was American, with Citibank in 27th place. The Administration's aim is admirable, but there are risks.

headline: Banc One Won't Make Bid
abstract: The Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, said yesterday that it would not, as had been expected, bid for the banks of the failed Bank of New England Corporation. It cited the weak state of the New England economy as the reason for its decision.    "We had no sense of when the region would get better, or if it had already bottomed out," said William Boardman, a Banc One executive who has arranged dozens of acquisitions in the last decade. Over the next several years, "we think there are going to be other opportunities that are probably a better use of our resources," he added.    Bids for the Bank of New England's failed subsidiaries in Massachusetts, Maine and Connecticut are due on Friday, with the winner to be announced in mid-April. In addition to the BankAmerica Corporation, which has said it will bid for all the banks, analysts have said the Bank of Boston Corporation, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company are interested in some of the banks.

headline: Backers of Gulf War Turn Out For a Capital Demonstration
abstract: A crowd of 3,500 people marched around the White House today to show support for President Bush and the Persian Gulf war. The marchers waved flags, jeered at peace demonstrators and burned an Iraqi flag.   About 400 motorcycle riders led the parade down Pennsylvania Avenue, past a few dozen antiwar demonstrators in Lafayette Park who kept up a drumbeat for peace.    At a rally on the grassy Ellipse between the White House and the Washington Monument, the crowd heard from several congressmen and Adrian Cronauer, the onetime G.I. disk jockey portrayed in the movie, "Good Morning, Vietnam."

headline: House Passes Futures Bill
abstract: A bill to reform trading practices in the futures pits while giving Federal regulators more authority to discipline wrongdoers easily passed the House today 395 to 27.   It was the second time in two years that the House has passed such legislation. The last bill was derailed by a jurisdictional battle between the agencies that regulate the futures and securities markets.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: United Nations; A Diplomatic Flurry at U.N. Falls Short of Deal on Iraq
abstract: The Soviet Union and Iraq asked the United Nations Security Council to declare a truce in the Persian Gulf war tonight. Moscow said President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had given the order for his forces to withdraw unconditionally from Kuwait as the Council had demanded.   But the United States and Britain opposed a cease-fire in line with the position taken by the White House earlier this evening. The United States insisted that Mr. Hussein must first agree to abide by all resolutions relating to the gulf crisis that the Security Council has passed.

headline: Rostock Journal; Left Out in Cold, German Port Fights to Survive
abstract: It is only 350 miles across the choppy waters of the Baltic Sea to Klaipeda, in Lithuania, and for the big rail ferries that link the cities the trip is an overnight run. So it did not sit well with some people here when they found out the other day that the latest ships to leave were hauling tanks, armored vehicles, trucks and other equipment belonging to the 350,000 Soviet troops still huddled in what was East Germany.   Nobody is prepared to dispute that Rostock, once the main port of Communist East Germany, needs work, and the harbor management said the deal to load the materiel would give dockworkers four years of work.

headline: Industrial Output Falls 0.8% to Lowest Level in 2 1/2 Years
abstract: Industrial production declined eight-tenths of a percent in February to the lowest level in two and a half years, the Government said today. It was the fifth consecutive monthly decline, and analysts saw it as another sign that the recession was continuing unabated.   The February performance marked the longest string of declines in manufacturing output since a 10-month stretch between March and December 1982, during the most severe recession since the Depression in the 1930's.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Abraham & Straus, New York, a division of Federated Department Stores Inc., named Robert Reichenbach senior vice president/general merchandise manager of its home division. The company also named Dennis Zezas senior vice president of engineering and operations. * Airco, Murray Hill, N.J., a member of the BOC Group that manufactures industrial gases, promoted Madeline Moore to vice president of sales for its carbon dioxide division. * Coopers & Lybrand, the New York-based accounting firm, named Harris J. Amhowitz a deputy chairman. He will remain the firm's general counsel. * ICM Property Investors Inc., New York, named Constance B. Moore president and chief operating officer. She succeeds Arthur W. Viner, who will continue as chairman and chief executive. * McDonnell Douglas Missile Systems Co., St. Louis, a division of McDonnell Douglas Corp., named Dr. Rodney M. Linford and Dr. James B. Peterson vice presidents. * Max Factor & Co., Los Angeles, a subsidiary of the Revlon Group Inc., promoted Elaine Esposito to vice president of the merchandisers' division. * Rockwell International Corp., El Segundo, Calif., named Charles B. Harrison vice president of advanced technology in its defense electronics organization. * Saks Fifth Avenue, New York, named Brian E. Kendrick senior vice president and chief financial officer. * Wertheim Schroder & Co., New York, named Scott C. Marden a managing director in its New York office.

headline: Sears 'Optimistic' About Catalogue
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company, which recently denied that it had planned to sell or close its catalogue, is "very optimistic" about the operation, but conceded it could be eliminated. The catalogue, the nation's biggest, has been unprofitable since 1985.    Edward A. Brennan, the retailer's chairman and chief executive, said in an interview in The Wall Street Journal yesterday that he did not believe there was anything "fundamentally wrong" with the company's $4 billion catalogue business. But he acknowledged that the catalogue could be closed if efforts to turn it around were unsuccessful. He declined to say how much time the Chicago-based company was giving the catalogue.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is offering 3-year and 10-year debentures totaling $1.4 billion through various securities dealers.   A $700 million issue due in 1994 has a 7.55 percent coupon and is priced at 100, to yield about 15.5 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.    The remainder of the financing consists of $700 million in 10-year debentures due Jan. 10, 2001, which are callable on or after Jan. 10, 1994, at an initial price of 104.438. The issue has an 8.875 percent coupon and, like the three-year debenture, is priced at 100, to yield about 75 basis points more than Treasuries.    Fannie Mae, which provides money to the mortgage market by purchasing mortgage loans from lenders, said it would use the proceeds from this financing to redeem, in part, about $1.6 billion worth of securities due on Thursday.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Press; Government's Strict Orders Limit Reports
abstract: A strict information policy has been imposed by the Bush Administration on the war against Iraq, with few specific details being made e available to reporters and the public about the first day of the bombing against targets in Baghdad and Kuwait.   The Defense Department has been reluctant to divulge details, officials contend, both because it is too early to know some things with certainty and because they fear the Iraqi military may learn something from such reports.

headline: Schwarzkopf's Minefield
abstract: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, who seemed testy today when asked if the threat from Iraqi mines was exaggerated, himself crossed a minefield in the Vietnam War, to rescue a wounded private whose leg was blown off by a mine.    General Schwarzkopf's Vietnam experience, recounted in the current issue of The New Republic, occurred on May 28, 1970, while he was a lieutenant colonel commanding the First Battalion of the Sixth Infantry Brigade.

headline: Soviet Opposition Weighs Disobedience
abstract: Stunned and wary, the Soviet opposition movement was considering today whether it could conduct a civil disobedience campaign to protest the Government's tough new military plan for policing the nation.   The Kremlin's plan, which goes into effect on Friday, gives sweeping investigative powers to the K.G.B. and authorizes the use of the army to begin policing major cities and regions of the nation in the name of combatting economic crime.

headline: Strife in Georgia Republic Reveals Danger in New Soviet Separatism
abstract: A tragic and largely ignored civil war -- one far deadlier than the Baltic republics' struggle for independence -- is under way here in the rugged mountains of Georgia, where the Soviet nation's separatist agonies are being played out in the daily clash of gunfire.    Minority Ossetians are battling with the republic's majority Georgians in this once peaceful Ossetian capital. It is now as darkly divided as Belfast, with concrete street barriers and neighborhood enmities setting a mood of despair.

headline: Boeing Sees End To Unit's Losses
abstract: The Boeing Company's military division, which has lost money for several years, will become profitable late in 1991, a company vice president, Gary Bland, said. Boeing expects its overall earnings to rise to $4.50 or $5 a share this year, compared with $4.01 in 1990, Mr. Bland told industry analysts.    Boeing is the world leader in commercial aviation, producing about 60 percent of the jets used by airline companies. But its military division has lost money for several years as United States military spending has leveled off. Despite the expected year-end turnaround, the division could still lose as much as $150 million in 1991, he said.

headline: Retailers Are Facing Hard Choices
abstract: After the worst and most perplexing Christmas season in more than a decade, American retailers face an agonizing quandary: Should they be cautious and conservative, or aggressive, hoping to force their luck?   As industry leaders gather in New York today for the annual National Retail Federation meeting, caution seems to be the prevailing mood.

headline: CRISIS ATMOSPHERE IN IRAQ'S CAPITAL
abstract: As international diplomacy on the Persian Gulf crisis entered what appeared to be the end-game stage, Iraqis formed long lines at gasoline stations today, topping off their gas tanks and filling plastic containers with extra fuel supplies.    At the same time, Iraqi Health Ministry officials told hospitals to accept only urgent civilian patients and to make room for war casualties.

headline: Article 114091 -- No Title
abstract: The PNC Financial Corporation said last week that it had lost $168.3 million in the fourth quarter, mostly because of a $430.1 million provision for credit losses.    The loss was in contrast to a profit of $1.46 million in the fourth quarter of 1989 for PNC, the nation's 14th-largest bank holding company.    PNC was formed in 1983 with the consolidation of the Pittsburgh National Corporation and the Provident National Corporation of Philadelphia. The company has 599 branches in Pennsylvania, Kentucky, Indiana, Ohio, Delaware and New Jersey.    For the year, the company said its profit fell 81 percent, to $70.9 million, or 73 cents a share, compared with income of $377.4 million, or $3.98 a share, for 1989.   "Last year was a difficult and demanding year for PNC and the entire banking industry," said Thomas H. O'Brien, PNC's chairman, president and chief executive.    PNC set aside $760.5 million for credit losses in 1990, compared with $331.7 million in the prior year.

headline: USAir Sees Deficit
abstract: USAir Group Inc. said it expected to post a first-quarter operating loss even greater than the $168 million it lost in the final quarter of last year. The airline also predicted a deficit for the full year, but said it should be less than the $350 million operating loss in 1990. USAir made the projections in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The recession and the decline in air traffic since the outbreak of the Persian Gulf crisis are the main reasons for the projected losses, USAir said.

headline: Gorbachev Is Promoting Hard-Line Police Chief
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, maintaining his emphasis on tightening the Kremlin's control over the nation, rewarded the new hard-line Soviet police chief today with a promotion and authorized further investigative powers in the name of fighting corruption and crime.    At the same time, the decision by the democratically elected Moscow City Council to appoint a new city police chief was overrruled by the central Kremlin authorities in a clear blow to local self-rule.

headline: Haiti's New Leader Takes on the Army
abstract: Within hours of being sworn in on Thursday as President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide said that all but two of the army's eight generals would be given a "well-earned retirement."   Other governments have foundered or been toppled for undertaking much less ambitious changes in Haiti's military. But analysts say the popular new President decided that the time was right for a radical restructuring of a force regarded here as repressive and corrupt. It is not yet clear how the military will respond.

headline: Canada Is Expected to Join U.S.-Mexico Trade Talks
abstract: After months of high-level talks, the United States, Mexico and Canada have reached agreement to include Canada in negotiations toward a continentwide North American free-trade zone, diplomats and trade officials said today.    The agreement, which could be announced as early as this week, would make Canada a direct participant in talks that have been under discussion by the United States and Mexico since the middle of last year.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; This Time, Better Deal For Black Servicemen?
abstract: American troops say they think, and hope, that the war against Iraq has forever changed the way hundreds of thousands of black and white servicemen see one another.   "You know the saying, 'There's no atheists in a foxhole?' " said a Marine staff sergeant, Bruce Shaw. "If the ground war starts, there will be no blacks or whites out there, just marines."

headline: Nicaragua Devalues Money To Stem Economic Collapse
abstract: Trying to satisfy Nicaragua's international creditors without setting off another round of violent strikes by Sandinista labor unions, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro began a new economic stabilization program today based on a major devaluation of the currency.    "We have already exchanged war for peace," Mrs. Chamorro told the nation in a televised address on Sunday. "Now we are going to exchange economic disaster for the stability we all want."

headline: Securities Ban for Milken
abstract: Michael R. Milken, the "junk bond" financier who is serving a 10-year prison sentence for his part in Wall Street's biggest scandal, has been permanently barred from the securities industry.   The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that Mr. Milken, who is jailed at a Federal prison work camp in California, had settled an administrative action brought by the S.E.C. Under the agreement, which was signed last week, Mr. Milken will be barred "from association with any broker, dealer, investment adviser, investment company or municipal securities dealer."

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * BP America Inc., Cleveland, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of $2.5 billion in debt securities to be guaranteed by its parent company, British Petroleum P.L.C.

headline: Circus Circus Chief to Retire Within Year
abstract: A co-founder of Circus Circus Enterprises Inc., which parlayed a small casino into a major Las Vegas gaming operation, said yesterday that he planned to retire as chief executive within a year. He also announced a new management lineup for the company.    William G. Bennett, who is 66 years old, also said that he had sold a block of 900,000 shares of Circus Circus at $60.25 a share, or $54.2 million, through Salomon Brothers Inc. Mr. Bennett said in a statement that the transaction, which reduces his interest in the company to 15 percent, was consistent with his pattern of sales over the last few years. He said he was taking steps to "balance the mix of his personal assets."

headline: Japan Says It Sheltered U.S. Group in Kuwait
abstract: The Japanese Government disclosed today that it secretly gave refuge to 16 Americans and their families in the days after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and then helped them escape from Kuwait City.    The disclosure came from Japanese officials who acknowledged that they are trying to prove that Japan contributed more than just money to the war against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. The Government here has been stung by criticism, both from abroad and from the Japanese press, that it wallowed in political infighting about how to contribute to the anti-Iraq coalition while its allies put their citizens at risk.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    The nation's trade deficit grew to $7 billion in January, as a rebound in imports was substantially offset by stronger exports, the Commerce Department reported.  [ Page D1. ]  The U.S. and Canada said they would speed up some tariff-cutting.  [ D7. ]   The banking industry has raised more capital this year from stock offerings than it did in all of 1990.  [ D1. ]

headline: Poland Sets Debt Demand
abstract: Poland said today that it would make no payment on its interest arrears to foreign banks until they agreed to a significant reduction of its staggering debt.   A Finance Ministry statement said any payments emerging from such an agreement would be limited to what the country could pay out of future trade surpluses.

headline: SOVIET LOYALISTS IN CHARGE AFTER ATTACK IN LITHUANIA; 13 DEAD; CURFEW IS IMPOSED
abstract: The National Salvation Committee, a faceless group of Communist Party loyalists, imposed a series of repressive measures on Lithuania today after the Soviet Army, with tanks and machine guns, had seized power for the committee overnight.   The committee ruled today in force but not in spirit, after a night of violence that left 13 people dead and more than 100 wounded by bullets or tank treads, according to official reports.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Exiles; Saudis Gather Ousted Iraqi Groups
abstract: Saudi Arabia, with the apparent acquiescence of the United States, has been quietly assembling former Iraqi political and military officials to form a potential government-in-exile that can fill a power vacuum in Baghdad if Saddam Hussein is ousted, diplomatic sources and Iraqi exiles said today.    Saudi officials have scoured Egypt, the United States, Britain and Syria to pull together a loose, somewhat disparate group of about 30 Iraqi exiles whom the Saudis hope will form the basis of a new postwar government in Iraq that will be friendly to the rich gulf states, the diplomats and exiles said.

headline: Bethlehem Steel Seeks A Venture
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it was discussing a joint venture with British Steel P.L.C. to produce rail and structural steel.   Bethlehem, the nation's second-largest steel producer, said the proposed venture would involve the closing of the steelmaking portions of its plant near its headquarters in Bethlehem, Pa., and the elimination of 2,000 jobs over three years, as well as improvements to plants in Bethlehem and Steelton, Pa.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy   Federal regulators moved to ease tight credit by recommending a relaxation of the standards used by banks to put a value on their loans. They called for changes in the way banks evaluate commercial and real estate loans that are in trouble.  [ Page 1. ]

headline: Changsha Journal; China's Castaway Babies: Cruel Practice Lives On
abstract: The babies in the stuffy, toasty-warm rooms of the orphanage, where hundreds of abandoned infants are brought each year, say something about Chinese social values: most are girls, the rest are handicapped.    For years, the Communist Government has tried to stamp out a feudalistic attitude toward sex roles that has persisted for centuries among China's peasants. Even today many parents want baby boys and not baby girls, and nowhere is this bias more vivid than in the rows of healthy but forsaken baby girls at the No. 1 Community Welfare Center here, most of whom have been found on someone's doorstep or in the street.

headline: Economic Indicators Up by 0.1%
abstract: The Government's main economic forecasting index edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in December, the first increase in six months and a sign, many analysts said, that the economy may have begun to stabilize after falling into recession during the latter half of 1990.   The report follows similar recent data on gross national product, incomes, unemployment insurance claims and orders for durable goods, all of which were less negative than many had feared. It tended to support the widely held belief that the recession would be shorter and milder than the 11-month, 2.2 percent average decline posted by the other eight postwar contractions. White House Encouraged     The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the Administration was encouraged by today's compilation of the index of leading indicators. But private economists cautioned that even a fully arrested downturn does not imply prompt economic revival. Some also noted that most of the data available so far cover periods before fighting started in the Middle East in mid-January and that polling and other evidence over the past week suggests a further sharp reduction in consumer confidence.

headline: Anheuser-Busch Has a New Beer
abstract: The world's largest brewer, the Anheuser-Busch Companies, is introducing another brand of beer in its continuing effort to increase its market share. Anheuser-Busch plans to test-market its latest entry, Natural Pilsner, in Arizona, California and Nevada beginning on Monday. By April 15, the full-calorie brother of Natural Light will also be sold in Ohio, Tennessee and West Virginia.   Anheuser-Busch has been introducing new beers frequently to meet its goal of gaining 50 percent of the domestic beer market, up from 43.7 percent. The Miller Brewing Company of Milwaukee is No. 2 at 22.1 percent. Natural Pilsner has 144 calories per 12-ounce serving. Natural Light has 110.

headline: Lockheed Proxies
abstract: Harold Simmons has accepted the Lockheed Corporation's proposal to forgo newspaper advertising in their separate attempts to win shareholders' votes at the military contractor's annual meeting on April 2. Mr. Simmons, the billionaire Texan who owns 20 percent of Lockheed through his NL Industries, is again trying to get his own directors elected to the Lockheed board.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bankers Trust Co., New York, a subsidiary of Bankers Trust New York Corp., announced five appointments in its corporate finance group: Scott P. George to managing director, head of the Midwest corporate finance group and head of Bankers Trust-Midwest, Chicago; Jeffrey Stephens to managing director and head of the West corporate finance group, and Richard A. Windatt, J. Andrew Cowherd and Andrew J. McCarthy to senior officers in the New York corporate finance group. * Jordan Marsh, Boston, a subsidiary of Allied Stores Corp., announced four promotions: John Budd to senior vice president and general merchandise manager of home furnishings; Janet Emerson to senior vice president and general merchandise manager for accessories, shoes, intimate apparel and cosmetics; Gary Nixon to senior vice president and director of stores, and John Macht to senior vice president and director of marketing.

headline: Toyota Buys Stake In Unit of Merrill
abstract: The Toyota Motor Corporation bought a 40 percent stake in a subsidiary of Merrill Lynch & Company in Tokyo. Toyota officials said their company, Japan's biggest auto maker, had acquired the share in Merrill Lynch International Capital Management Company through a subsidiary, the Toyota Finance Corporation. The price was not disclosed.   Toyota made the purchase by buying new shares the Merrill Lynch subsidiary issued to increase its capital, officials said. Toyota is believed to be the first big manufacturer in Japan to establish a link with a leading overseas financial institution.

headline: G.M. Cuts Dividend Almost 50%
abstract: The General Motors Corporation, citing war and a weak economy, slashed its dividend nearly in half today and announced cost-cutting measures, including reductions in its salaried work force and its capital spending plans.    G.M., the nation's largest car maker, was the first of the Big Three to trim its quarterly payout, dropping it by 46 percent, to 40 cents a share from 75 cents, but analysts predict that Ford and Chrysler will soon follow suit.

headline: All About/Hats; The Baseball Cap Is Breathing Life Into Headwear Sales
abstract: Roy Langenberg says that people burst out laughing when he tells them he produces hats. "How do you make a living?" they ask. But Mr. Langenberg, the fourth generation in his family to head the Langenberg Hat Company of Washington, Mo., says that the headwear business is actually enjoying a comeback. No one in the industry expects formal felt hats to recapture the universal popularity they enjoyed before World War II. But most Americans own many more caps and leisure hats than they realize and seem eager to accumulate more.    The Headwear Institute of America, a New York-based group, estimates that sales have been growing at 5 percent to 10 percent for the past few years. More precise statistics are hard to come by because all the companies are small, most of them secretive and none publicly traded. Many manufacturers say that despite the recession, sales are still growing, driven by everything from changing fashions to the awareness that sunburn can contribute to skin cancer. Hat and cap makers hope that they will scarcely feel the recession because, for every customer who suddenly feels too poor to buy, others decide that they can economize by purchasing a hat instead of a complete outfit.

headline: Nynex Ties Commercial to Gulf War
abstract: As many marketers try to avoid the appearance of exploiting the Persian Gulf war, the Nynex Corporation is swimming against the tide. The telecommunications company is scheduled to start an advertising campaign today that was created specifically to run alongside war-related television news.   With a single, short commercial about telecommunications and the war, Nynex, which spends about $20 million annually on corporate image advertising, will become the first leading marketer to create television advertising after the outbreak of war that takes advantage of what advertisers call the "news environment."

headline: Finnish Parliament: Average Age Under 40
abstract: The new Finnish Parliament elected on Sunday is more than one-third female and has an average age of less than 40.    "I think we are going to have fun," said 23-year-old Minna Karhunen, the youngest member elected to the 200-member Parliament.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   9.50   9.50   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.50   6.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   2.00   5.00   8.25        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.52   6.53   7.57        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.51   6.51   7.44        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.01   7.91   8.03        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   8.31   8.20   8.08        TELEPHONE BONDS   9.55   9.50   9.21        MUNICIPAL BONDS*   7.45   7.43   7.29       *Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Advanced Micro Devices Inc., Sunnyvale, Calif., which makes computer circuits and equipment, will phase out operations at a wafer fabrication plant by the end of the year. * British Aerospace P.L.C., London, said the planned merger of its guided weapons systems business with that of Thomson CSF S.A., the French military contractor, had been cleared by the British authorities. * BP Exploration, a unit of British Petroleum Co., and Statoil A.S., the Norwegian state-owned oil concern, have agreed to explore for oil and gas offshore in China, Vietnam, West Africa and the Soviet Union. * Furr's Inc., Lubbock, Tex., a grocery-store chain, said its managers would buy 70 of the company's 126 stores. Seven others would be sold, and 14 would be closed. * Hanson P.L.C., London, the British conglomerate, had protesters at its annual meeting. The protesters, Navajo Indians from Arizona, objected to mining by Hanson's Peabody Coal Co. unit in the Black Mesa region there. * SHL Systemhouse Inc., Ottawa, a computer systems company, has purchased the Computerland trademarks in Canada from Computerland Corp., Oakland, Calif. The price was $40.5 million (Canadian). * Tandem Computers Inc., Cupertino, Calif., which makes computer systems, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 1.5 million common shares on the open market. * Varity Corp., Toronto, a maker of farming and industrial machinery, has extended until April 30 its program for shareholders with fewer than 100 common shares as of Nov. 16 to sell them back to the company.

headline: Whistle-Stop Campaign, the Albanian Way
abstract: A day in the life of an opposition candidate for the Albanian presidecy begins soon after dawn in a modest apartment. It continues with a campaign speech for state television and an eight-hour drive to two election rallies in eastern Albania and ends a little after midnight at the offices of his party newspaper in Tirana, the capital.    Dr. Sali Berisha, leader of the three-month-old Democratic Party, is heading the campaign to defeat the Communist Party, which has ruled this country since November 1944. Until late last year, he worked at the University of Tirana as one of Albania's leading cardiologists. He was also a member of the Communist Party.

headline: Jamaican Assails I.M.F.
abstract: Prime Minister Michael N. Manley of Jamaica today accused the International Monetary Fund and the Inter-American Development Bank of inflexibility in refusing to allow Jamaica more time to pay its debts. Mr. Manley, who is in Venezuela on a three-day visit, said that over the last two years Jamaica had paid back more money to the two international lending institutions than it had received in new loans.

headline: Talks Break Down in Angola Over the Issue of a Cease-Fire
abstract: Despite intense mediation efforts by Portugal, the United States and the Soviet Union, a crucial negotiating session intended to pave the way for peace in Angola ended in failure here today amid disagreements between the warring sides over a date for a cease-fire.    At the session, which began on Wednesday, Angola's Soviet-backed Government and the guerrillas backed by the United States, had been expected to initial three carefully prepared documents setting the stage for ending the 16-year-old civil war in the former Portuguese colony.

headline: Hussein Urges Unity Against 'The Invaders'
abstract: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in a broadcast early this morning said "a fateful dual battle has begun -- a clash between believers and infidels."    In a brief message broadcast by the Baghdad radio, he encouraged his people to fight, threatened Saudi Arabia and Israel, and gave no indication that he thought that the American air attack had done significant harm to his nation.    Reuters, monitoring the broadcast in Nicosia, Cyprus, quoted President Hussein as saying that "the mother of all battles" had started after the "Satan Bush committed his crime."  Poor Quality     The Iraqi President's message was broadcast about 7 A.M. Iraqi time and was recorded by Israeli television's radio monitor, Mickey Gurdis. The broadcast quality was poor, possibly because of American jamming that started on Wednesday, or because of war damage to the radio's transmission operations.

headline: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
abstract: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in small groups and given access to various military sources.   These pool reporters obtain their information while under military escort, and their accounts are subject to scrutiny by military censors before they are distributed. Much of the information appearing today on American military operations was obtained under such circumstances.

headline: Dependence and Sovereignty Pull at Panama's Equilibrium
abstract: More than 13 months after the United States invaded Panama and arrested Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, most of the problems that have plagued the nation for years remain. Panama is still searching for its own identity and seems linked more than ever to Washington.   The economy here has rebounded and political freedoms have expanded since General Noriega's ouster, arrest and extradition to Florida to face trial on drug trafficking charges. But cocaine continues to be smuggled through Panama on its way to the United States and other destinations.

headline: 5 Airlines, Citing War Fears, Suspending Flights to Israel
abstract: Airport officials said this weekend that the number of airlines announcing a temporary suspension of service to Israel in the gulf crisis had risen to five. The airlines are blaming skyrocketing insurance rates based on fears of a war.    At the same time, Sweden and Germany have advised their nationals to leave Israel well in advance of Jan. 15.   A spokeswoman for the Israel Airport Authority said the five airlines -- Scandinavian Airlines System; LOT, the Polish national airline; Cyprus Airways; South African Airways, and Pan American World Airways -- had all cited insurance that shot up from about $3,000 per flight to $65,000.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Families; Joy Is Darkened by Fear For Kin of Captured Pilots
abstract: The families of the captured American fliers shown on Iraqi and American television were joyful yesterday that the men were still alive but fearful that the pilots, shown in what appeared to be battered conditions, would be used as human shields against allied bombing in the Persian Gulf war.    At Camp Pendleton, Calif., the wives of two Marine fliers held by Iraq expressed a guarded relief and hopes for the future on learning that their husbands were alive.

headline: Bush to Free Salvador Aid
abstract: President Bush has determined that the continued flow of weapons to Salvadoran rebels and their poor human rights record are grounds for freeing $42.5 million in withheld military aid to the San Salvador Government, officials in the Administration and in Congress said today. Under last year's foreign aid law, half the $85 million in military aid for El Salvador was frozen in an effort to encourage the Government to reach a negotiated peace settlement with the rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front.

headline: Kurds Alone Viewed as Unlikely to Oust Hussein
abstract: The unrest in Iraqi Kurdistan is the most serious anti-Government revolt in that region in almost two decades, but it alone is unlikely to topple President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Middle East experts say.   Military and political analysts inside and outside the Bush Administration agree that the rebellion by the Kurds, non-Arabs who make up about 20 percent of Iraq's population, could be an important factor in weakening the Hussein Government. But no Kurdish revolt has ever brought down an Iraqi government since the nation gained independence from Britain in 1932, although an inability to quash rebellions contributed to the overthrow of a number of governments before the Baath Party came to power in 1968.

headline: A Cautionary Note on Africa
abstract: To the Editor:    As a black African I was more than delighted to see that an article about the future of the continent was given space ("Afterward, Make Africa a Priority," Feb. 3).    In the piece, Salim Lone, a Kenyan, argues that after the current American engagement in the Persian Gulf is over, the industrialized Western countries must help Africa cope with its economic problems by offering massive "debt relief and easier terms for receiving aid." Furthermore, Mr. Lone advises the West not to spend more of its expertise and resources on Eastern Europe where the collapse of Communism paved the way for private investment.   With all due respect, I strongly disagree on both accounts. First, while Africa was busy getting close to $230 billion in loans and credit in the past 30 years, which marked the rise of the new African states from the era of European colonialism, the Eastern European countries that were forced into the Warsaw Pact by the Red Army weren't getting any sort of significant assistance from the West. "In the 1980's," writes Jennifer Whitaker in her book "How Can Africa Survive," "Africans, who are about 12 percent of the developing world's population, were receiving about 22 percent of the total aid and the share per person was higher than anywhere else in the third world."   Now that there has been democratic change in Eastern European nations, it is in the interest of the West that massive assistance, both private and public, be given to them so they can develop a free market economy with a stable middle class.   Africans, like yesteryear's East Europeans, need to get rid of their corrupted dictators who more often than not run the state for the benefit of one man, his family and his tribe. The West should not fall for the eloquent speeches delivered by Africa's 40-plus dictators who all of a sudden celebrate the virtue of free-market capitalism and the failure of centrally planned economic systems. They hadn't read Karl Marx's "Das Kapital" when they were with the Soviets and their new conversion to the market is not based on an understanding of Adam Smith's "Wealth of Nations." They say whatever the donor countries with the most funds wish to hear.   Unless Africa experiences an Easternn European-style revolution, no amount of debt relief and aid will be enough to solve its economic misery. ABDUL RAHMAN ABDI Greenbelt, Md., Feb. 10

headline: Rules for Journalists: Necessity or Prior Restraint?
abstract: The Pentagon is establishing a system for covering a war in the Persian Gulf that would impose much stricter restrictions on journalists than they were subjected to during the Vietnam War.     Under the system, print and television combat coverage would be carried out exclusively through groups of reporters called pools that are assembled and escorted by the military. The reports would then be subject to a "security review" by the military before being disseminated in Riyadh, Dhahran and Washington, where they would become the basis for newspaper, news agency, magazine and television reports.

headline: Mandela and Buthelezi Set Date to Meet
abstract: After months of delay and argument, South Africa's two largest black movements announced today that their leaders will meet on Jan. 29 in an effort to defuse their bitter rivalry, which has caused thousands of deaths and damaged black unity in the struggle against apartheid.   The meeting will bring together Nelson Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, and Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, president of the Inkatha Freedom Party. An African National Congress official said he expected the meeting to take place in Durban, where contacts between the two groups were initiated at a lower level last year.

headline: British Air Is Again Seeking Approval of Reduced Fares
abstract: Encouraged by early consumer response to fares as low as $249 round trip from New York to London, British Airways made a new effort yesterday to persuade the United States Transportation Department to allow it to extend the sale of reduced fares for travel during the peak summer season.   Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said Tuesday that British Airways had to stop selling discounted fares for summer travel by midnight tomorrow. The airline wants to extend the offer date to March 15. But whichever date becomes final, customers who have bought their low-priced tickets by then can still fly between Britain and the United States from April 15 through Oct. 31.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Iraqi Loyalists Pound Shiite Mosques, Rebels Say; Opposition Meeting
