abstract: More than 300 delegates from 23 Iraqi opposition organizations assembled today and considered ways to remove President Hussein from power in Baghdad.    Buoyed by what they said was the dramatic success of an uprising in Iraq, speakers who gathered at a hotel in mainly Muslim West Beirut for a three-day meeting appeared euphoric as they predicted an early fall of the man they called "the dictator of Baghdad."

headline: Treasury Issues Up on Light Day
abstract: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose solidly in light trading yesterday, as some traders and investors bought in anticipation of stronger demand in coming days.    With the coming of a new year, securities dealers expect many investors and speculators will have more flexibility to buy. In the waning weeks of 1990, many accounts were inactive, as portfolio managers tried to "window dress" their year-end financial statements and to avoid risk-taking that could jeopardize profits earned earlier in the year.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: A $150 million issue of two-year notes being sold by Merrill Lynch & Company was priced yesterday.   The notes, which mature on March 1, 1993, have an 8 5/8 percent coupon and are priced at 100, to yield about 160 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.    The noncallable issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * Comdisco Inc., Rosemont, Ill., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of $400 million in senior debt securities. COMMON STOCK

headline: The Executive Life; An Ethos for the 90's: Work's Out, Play's In
abstract: Executive stress is in vogue for 1991, but only because the country has slipped into a recession. It actually should be out of fashion, for this year people are taking a more cynical view toward corporate ladder-climbing, vowing to work less and play more.   "People are returning to many of the values held in the 1960's; they are turning against the 1980's glitz," said Faith Popcorn f the New York marketing consulting firm, BrainReserve Inc. "In all the mergers and leveraged buyouts of the last years, executives really got screwed by their companies. They're deciding that they want to be recognized now as humans at their work."

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                  March 15   March 8   Mar 16        1991   1991   1990        Gasoline production, daily   6.5   6.6   6.4        Distillate production, daily   2.9   3.0   2.5        Gasoline stocks   216.5   220.1   241.2        Distillate stocks   99.3   101.5   105.9        Crude imports, daily   5.4   5.1   5.7        Product imports, daily   1.3   1.8   2.4        Crude stocks   335.2   330.2   351.0        Crude production, daily   7.5   7.5   7.3        Refinery utilization (%)   82.9   84.3   83.7       (Source: American Petroleum Institute)

headline: Wallenbergs Seeking Rest of Saab-Scania
abstract: Sweden's leading industrial family, the Wallenbergs, offered today to buy the portion of Saab-Scania A.B. that it does not already own for nearly $2.3 billion.   Peter Wallenberg, the family's leader, offered to pay almost 40 percent more for shares of Saab-Scania than their recent price on the Stockholm stock exchange. The Wallenberg family already controls about 58 percent of the plane, truck and automobile maker.

headline: World Markets; The Geography of Diversification
abstract: With the end of the war in the Persian Gulf, Wall Street surged and stock markets around the world soared with it, highlighting once again the leadership role the American market can have.    But this is less the rule than one might think. In fact, outside of the big moves -- precipitated by events like the invasion of Kuwait last August and the stock market crash of 1987 -- many foreign stock markets follow their own tune.

headline: 10 Traders Found Guilty In Chicago Futures Case
abstract: A Federal jury today convicted eight soybean traders at the Chicago Board of Trade of racketeering, giving the Government its first major victory in the investigation of trading fraud in Chicago.   All 10 defendants were convicted of at least one count of the lesser charges of mail or wire fraud.

headline: 2 Officers Killed in Santiago
abstract: Suspected guerrillas shot and killed two police officers in northern Santiago today, the police said. An anonymous caller told a local news agency that the attack had been carried out by the Lautaro Front, a small leftist guerrilla gang, to protest the Government's handling of the investigation of human rights abuses under the former military Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

headline: Future Buzzwords Rise From Ashes of the 80's
abstract: Forget "L.B.O.'s" and "M.&A.," those code words of the 80's takeover boom. These days, center stage belongs to those who talk of "inflection points," of "enhanced indexing," of "prepackaged bankruptcies" -- the investment buzzwords likely to dominate the intellectual landscape of Wall Street in the year ahead.    Demography, with its attention to turns, or inflection points, in population trends, is gaining wider attention in investment circles. The new census results should give investing based on demographics further impetus.

headline: Germans Lower Expectations On East's Economic Recovery
abstract: The economic revival promised to eastern Germans will take much more time, money and effort than originally expected, German officials acknowledged today.   The Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl today approved more than $3 billion in emergency financial aid for the region's nearly bankrupt states and cities and introduced broad but vague proposals intended to spur a recovery.

headline: Czech Conversion to a Free Market Brings the Expected Pain, and More
abstract: Vera Tejcakova is a 68-year-old pensioner with a taste for beer and a plucky attitude about the hardships certain to accompany Czechoslovakia's efforts to create a free-market economy.    "It's part of the deal," Mrs. Tejcakova said this week as Czechoslovakia began its program for speeding the transition to private enterprise. "It has to be. We have to hold out and support our Government."

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Air Products and Chemicals Inc., Allentown, Pa., appointed Andrew E. Cummins president of its Air Products Pacific Inc. unit in Tokyo. * Brown Brothers Harriman & Co., New York, a private banking firm, named Austin J. Belton a senior manager. Brian A. Berris was admitted as a general partner. * Harris Corp., Melbourne, Fla., a manufacturer of advanced electronic systems, named Phillip Mighdoll corporate vice president of quality and new produdcts. * Lands' End Inc., Chicago, a mail order clothing company, appointed William T. End executive vice president of marketing and corporate planning. * Pueblo Railroad Service Co., a subsidiary of CF&I Steel Corp, Pueblo, Colo., named Gerald M. Bloder vice president and general manager. * Reebok International Ltd., Stoughton, Mass., appointed Barry Culkin executive vice president and acting head of its Boston Whaler division, replacing William J. Ryan, who resigned. * Retirement System Investors Inc., New York, a subsidiary of Retirement System Group Inc., named James P. Coughlin president. * TBC Corp., Memphis, which distributes automotive replacement parts, named Louis DePasqua president and chief operating officer. * Televideo Systems Inc., San Jose, Calif., designers of video display terminals, appointed David Kim vice president of business development. * Trust Co. of New Jersey, Jersey City, appointed Jamille Krupa assistant vice president. Robert V. Spinello was named vice president and business development officer. * VTN Corp., Orange, Calif., an engineering and planning concern, named Dennis Brown vice president. * Warner Brothers Inc., Burbank, Calif., a unit of Time Warner Inc., New York, named Patricia Morin Brown vice president of television merchandising.

headline: People
abstract: * Mary Ann Sapos has been named president and chief executive of Hutchins/Young & Rubicam, Rochester. She replaces James N. Morey, who has been named chairman of the agency. The agency also appointed Charles E. Reller chief operating officer and Richard P. Barry general manager of the agency's Yellow Pages advertising division. * Lee D. Gleason has been appointed a creative director of the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago. * McCann-Erickson Worldwide promoted Rob Brown to senior vice president, Steve Cunetta to vice president and Ed Tajon to vice president. * Michael V. Garcia has been named executive vice president/group account director for the New York office of Campbell-Mithun-Esty. Gerald R. Kerr has been named executive vice president/general manager for the agency's Houston office.  * Marty Kohr has been appointed vice president/management supervisor at Frank C. Nahser Inc., an advertising agency in Chicago.  * Gary Billings has joined Lintas Worldwide as director of public relations. Stone Roberts has been named chief operating officer and director of account management of Lintas New York.

headline: War Summary
abstract: THE "AIR-LAND BATTLE" PUT ON HOLD    After listening to the advice of field commanders via the Pentagon's top civilian and military chiefs, President Bush held off the decision on a ground offensive "for a while," saying the air war had been "very, very effective" and should continue for now. He refused to respond to questions but said he was taking the time necessary to consider "when a next stage might begin." AND THE RAIDS GO ON    In the already fierce assault on Iraqi targets, U.S., British and French warplanes bombed bridges, roads and front-line units in their dug-in positions. The battered port city of Basra, Iraq's second largest, also came under heavy bombardment, having been designated a military objective. And Iraq called up 17-year-olds for the first time, a possible indication of serious troop losses. A REMINDER FROM ISRAEL   Defense Minister Moshe Arens paid a hasty visit to the White House to tell President Bush that Israel had suffered greatly from Iraqi rockets and that its patience was wearing thin. His call seemed to reinforce warnings that Israel might strike, although it remained unclear what its weapons could do beyond what the U.S.-led air assault on Iraq, now in its 27th day, is doing already. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES    Troops: Yesterday's Pentagon briefer put the cumulative total of U.S. combat losses at 60: 12 killed in action, 12 wounded, 28 missing and 8 P.O.W.'s.    Aircraft: The Pentagon said "there were zero U.S. aircraft lost," leaving the combat total at 18. IRAQI FORCES    Troops: More defections pushed the number of P.O.W.'s past 1,000 yesterday. No meaningful data on military casualties are available beyond an unconfirmed report in an Egyptian weekly that Iraq confidentially informed friendly Arab countries that 15,000 soldiers had died thus far. As for civilians killed, a senior Iraqi official said yesterday that "thousands" had been killed or wounded in air raids, far more than the 650 dead and 750 wounded officially reported earlier. And former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, fresh from a visit to Baghdad, said the head of the Iraqi Red Crescent estimated the death toll at between 6,000 and 7,000 civilians. The White House yesterday rejected these high figures and talk of peace feelers as a "propaganda and P.R. battle"    Aircraft: The U.S. military in Riyadh said Iraq had lost about 40 percent of its prewar total of about 600 military aircraft, and the Pentagon yesterday broke that down as 39 shot down, 142 grounded with their crews in Iran for the duration, and the rest caught on the ground.

headline: Ameritech May Offer Credit Card
abstract: The Ameritech Corporation, the regional Bell company that provides local phone service in five Midwestern states, said yesterday that it was considering the possibility of offering a credit card and was holding discussions with potential partners.    If the Chicago-based company's senior management approves the idea, Ameritech would become the first Bell regional to follow the lead of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which introduced a combination calling card and credit card nearly a year ago. Michael F. Brand, a spokesman for Ameritech, said no decision had been made.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Iraq; Big Street Protests Reported in Baghdad
abstract: Street protests were reported in Baghdad today and Iraq admitted for the first time that the country was in the grip of an uprising against President Saddam Hussein.   In Iran, the Teheran radio said "massive demonstrations" in several parts of Baghdad led to clashes in which a number of people on both sides were killed or wounded.

headline: Managing; Farewell to the Training Seminar?
abstract: John L. Hanson, vice president of human resources at the Parker Hannifin Corporation, recently gave copies of "Keeping the Best," Martin Yate's book on motivating employees, to about 40 of the industrial component manufacturer's managers. "The book says that the first step in satisfying customers is having satisfied employees, and I want to drive that point home," he said.    Ricardo C. Calvillo, president of the New York advertising agency Calet, Hirsch and Spector, gave a dozen of his top people copies of Peter M. Senge's "The Fifth Discipline: The Art and Practice of the Learning Organization" because he thought it offered well-reasoned views on operating in a tough business environment.

headline: WAR SUMMARY
abstract: A 'LUCRATIVE TARGET'    United States and Saudi air, land and naval units, in their heaviest combined operation yet, hammered at a massed force of armor, artillery and infantry units in southern Kuwait. The battleship Missouri joined Marine attack planes and Saudi howitzer and rocket batteries in a three-hour predawn bombardment to put out of action what the United States command called "a lucrative target." The heavy attacks on bridges and Government buildings in Baghdad and other Iraqi targets continued as well. President Bust accused President Saddam Hussein of Iraq of exploiting reports of civilian damage and casualties for propaganda by exploiting reports of civilian damage and casualties for propaganda by "cranking out myths and falsehoods." Yesterday's raids came as a Soviet envoy, Yevgeny M. Primakov, met Mr. Hussein in the Iraqi capital. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES    Troops: The United States Central Command in Riyadh and the Pentagon reported no new combat casualties, but a Saudi soldier was reported killed and six were wounded in a mine-clearing operation in Khafji, near the Kuwaiti border.    Aircraft: According to the Riyadh briefer, there have been no allied air-combat losses. IRAQI FORCES    Troops: The Pentagon said more Iraqis defected and the Saudis were now holding "over 1,000" prisoners of war, with 48 others stil in United States detention. It said the highest-ranking defector was a lieutenant colonel.    Aircraft: The Riyadh briefer said a helicopter exploded over northern Iraq when attacked by an American F-15. He said no other Iranian aircraft were spotted "flying or fleeing to Iran."

headline: U.S., Allies Join in Buying The Dollar
abstract: The Federal Reserve and the central banks of the United States' major economic allies bought dollars in the foreign exchange market yesterday in an apparent effort to support the weakening currency and to signal that economic cooperation among the allies was still in force.   But the exact motivation for the concerted dollar buying was not completely clear. Instead of a primary concern about the dollar, the intervention could have been aimed at weakening the German mark and easing the downward pressure also being exerted on European currencies in the European Monetary System following the increase in German interest rates last week.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Amer Group Ltd., Helsinki, Finland, named Erkki E. Railo chairman of its Wilson Sporting Goods Co. and MacGregor Golf Co. * Amoco Oil Co., Chicago, named Edwin J. Roland vice president for operations, planning and transportation. * Boston Whaler Inc., Rockland, Mass., a manufacturer of power boats that is a subsidiary of Reebok International Ltd., appointed Sharon Cohen vice president of marketing. * Cadbury Beverages International, Stamford, Conn., a subsidiary of Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., promoted John F. Brock to president. * Landes Organization, New York, appointed Matthew R. Kahn managing director of the Lexington Group, its financial services firm, and executive vice president of RKO Warner Video Inc., one of its retail affiliates. * Mattel Inc., the Hawthorne, Calif., toy maker, promoted Norman Vaughan to vice president for properties and administrative services. * USF&G Corp., Baltimore, named Edwin G. Pickett executive vice president and chief financial officer. The company also named Richard J. Potter senior vice president for strategic planning and Jack Hart senior vice president for human resources. James N. Stanard was named executive vice president of United States Fidelity and Guaranty Co., a subsidiary of USF&G. * Viacom Broadcasting, New York, a subsidiary of Viacom Inc., promoted Michael Kelso to executive vice president and chief operating officer.

headline: Lord, Dentsu Favored To Win Dole Account
abstract: The Los Angeles office of Lord, Dentsu & Partners is expected to be awarded the account for Castle & Cooke Inc.'s Dole Food Company. The billings are estimated to be more than $20 million.   Lord, Dentsu came out ahead in a review that included Backer Spielvogel Bates, the incumbent; Cohen/ Johnson; Ketchum Communications, and Team One.

headline: Philip Morris Says Maxwell Will Retire
abstract: The Philip Morris Companies confirmed yesterday that Hamish Maxwell, the chairman and chief executive for nearly seven years, plans to retire this year in accordance with board policy. Mr. Maxwell will be 65 years old in August.    A board meeting is scheduled for today, but a company spokeswoman declined to comment yesterday on a report in The Wall Street Journal that Philip Morris planned to announce Mr. Maxwell's retirement this week. The board could announce a successor or changes that would lead to the appointment of a successor.

headline: Israeli General Is Sentenced To 13 Years in Bribery Case
abstract: A former chief purchasing officer in the Israeli Air Force was sentenced today to 13 years in prison for receiving $10 million in bribes and kickbacks on purchases of American-made equipment.   Brig. Gen. Rami Dotan's rank was reduced to private and he will be dishonorably discharged, the military court said.

headline: Chinese Leaders Warn of Electronic Spying
abstract: China's leadership has begun a new effort to tighten secrecy after uncovering attempts by foreign countries to use electronic equipment to eavesdrop on high-level conversations, Chinese officials say.    China has long been obsessed with secrecy, to the point that the office phone numbers of national leaders are classified. Many Chinese officials, particularly those in the military, are supposed to avoid contact with foreigners, and access to photocopiers is limited to avoid duplication of sensitive documents.

headline: U.N. Advises Its Non-Essential Staff to Leave Israel
abstract: The United Nations advised all its non-essential employees today to leave Israel right away, adding to the throngs of foreigners crowding Ben-Gurion International Airport, fleeing before the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraqi withdraw from Kuwait.    Airport officials reported that all outgoing flights were sold out for the next several days as many foreign students, businessmen, journalists, diplomats and foreign workers left because of fear of war.

headline: Weekly Edition of Life Will Focus on the War
abstract: For the first time since 1972, Life magazine will appear on newstands in a weekly format.   The magazine, which will continue to publish as a monthly, is adding a weekly edition that will be devoted entirely to the war in the Persian Gulf. The first weekly issue, which will be the size of news magazines, will appear on newstands on Feb. 18. For logistical reasons, no subscriptions to the weekly will be offered, said Peter Costiglio, a spokesman for Time Inc. Magazines.   "We felt Life could cover the war in a way no one else could, in terms of its tradition of photojournalism and writing," said Mr. Costiglio, who added that the weekly would be produced until further notice.

headline: Market Place; Money Fund Investors' New Tack
abstract: Investors' headlong rush toward the safest type of money market funds seems to have slowed, perhaps reflecting lower interest rates and reduced fears about the fragility of America's financial system.   Since the beginning of 1991, investors have added money to ordinary money market funds at about the same pace as they have added cash to the super-safe funds that invest only in Federal Government securities.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Computer Associates International Inc., Garden City, L.I., the software concern, said it had offered to buy all shares of its common stock from shareholders of record of 99 or fewer shares at the closing price on the day each certificate is received. * CRSS Inc., Houston, an architecture and engineering company, said it had received a contract from the Philip Morris Cos. to provide engineering design services and equipment procurement for the previously announced $400 million expansion of the Philip Morris cigarette plant in Cabarrus, N.C. * JTN Acquisition Corp., a concern led by Perry Sutherland and Barry Rosenstein, said it had ended its offer to buy up to 6,177,825 shares of common stock of Justin Industries., Fort Worth, a manufacturer of bricks and other clay products, for $18 a share in cash and had sold more than a million shares. * LDDS Communications Inc., Jackson, Miss., a long-distance telephone service and magazine publishing concern, said it had agreed to acquire two long-distance telephone service resellers with combined revenues of about $110 million. * Malev, Budapest, an airline, said it had entered into a preliminary agreement to buy two 767-200 ER jets from the Boeing Co., Seattle. Terms were not disclosed . * National-Standard Co., Niles, Mich., said it would divest portions of its speciality wire business. The company also said it had reached a tentative agreement for the sale of its tire-mold business in Hunfeld, Germany. * Northwestern Steel and Wire Inc., Sterling, Ill., has won certification as a supplier to construction projects financed by the Japanese Government.  * Nycor Inc., Peapack, N.J., an investment company, announced it had nominated Sal Giordano Jr., William J. Brennan and Howard S. Modlin to the board of Zenith Electronics Corp., Glenview Ill., of which Nycor is the largest stockholder. * Tandycrafts Inc., Fort Worth, a leather goods and wood frame company, said it would offer to buy back shares from shareholders with 99 or fewer shares at $20 a share.

headline: Trying to Fill The Shortage Of Engineers
abstract: American contractors are expected to have a big role in rebuilding the hundreds of bridges, roads and buildings destroyed in the Persian Gulf war, further straining an industry suffering from a chronic shortage of engineers.    According to an estimate by the National Science Foundation, the shortage of engineers in the United States will reach 70,000 by the year 2010, even though engineers have been trying for decades to persuade more students to join their ranks.

headline: U.S. Proposes Change in Air Reservations
abstract: The Transportation Department proposed rules today that would seek to make airline computer reservation systems fairer to consumers, travel agents and small carriers.   The proposal was praised by a trade group for travel agents, which said it would encourage competition among the four major systems in the United States -- all owned by airlines -- that are the backbone of the industry's ticketing system. In the past, some airlines have been accused by travel agents and others of setting up the systems to steer customers onto their flights.

headline: Real Estate Group Buys G.M. Building
abstract: One of the country's largest private real estate investment groups quietly acquired the landmark General Motors Building in Manhattan last month, people at G.M. said yesterday. The headquarters building was sold for $500 million plus other unspecified considerations, they said.    The 50-story building was acquired by Corporate Property Investors, the real estate investment trust that refinanced the property for G.M. in the early 1980's and in exchange received the option to acquire the building, on Fifth Avenue at the southeastern corner of Central Park, which opened in 1968.

headline: Tensions Bedeviled Allies All the Way to Kuwait
abstract: Winning the Persian Gulf war required the allies to overcome national self-interests, political obstacles and a few battlefield pitfalls, senior allied officials say.    Throughout the war, the allies presented a facade of total unity. But interviews with dozens of American and coalition officials disclosed that commanders were constantly forced to address tensions among the 37 countries that sent air, ground and naval forces, virtually to the day allied forces rolled into Kuwait.

headline: MORE ON THE GULF
abstract: THE WAR   American military officials said the allied forces were closing off escape routes for Iraqi troops trying to leave Kuwait. A high priority is being put on capturing or destroying Iraq's Republican Guards.  [ Page A19. ]   The air war continued, with Americans providing air support for Arab ground units in an unusual collaboration intended to magnify the allied forces' fighting punch. Air Force officers are coordinating movement and communications among the myriad troops and languages.  [ Page A21. ]

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Exiles; The Refugees Envision A Transformed Kuwait
abstract: The sand-colored high-rise apartment complex is known to its neighbors as Kuwait City, and each afternoon knots of idle young men and women gather in the marble entryways to swap rumors about the progress of the war and to plot the future of the country they hope soon to reclaim.    The sprawling towers are now home to more than 5,000 Kuwaiti refugees, and for most there is little to be accomplished each day except to arrange and rearrange their extended families in the cramped apartments that have been donated by the Saudi Government. Five or 6 or even 10 family members sleeping in the same room is not unusual.

headline: Xerox's Earnings Rise 11% On Strong Sales for Copiers
abstract: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that stronger-than-expected copier sales lifted fourth-quarter earnings 11 percent, overcoming a sharp decline in earnings from financial services.   Xerox shares rose sharply, gaining $5.375 yesterday, or more than 12 percent, to $48.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Sterling Optical Appoints Chief and No. 2 Executive
abstract: The Sterling Optical Corporation named two top executives yesterday.    Robert K. Low, 53, was appointed chairman and chief executive. Mr. Low, a director of Sterling since 1959, replaces Richard Block, who had been chairman, president and chief executive. No reason was given for Mr. Block's replacement.   And George Casabona, the company's executive vice president, assumes the additional title of chief operating officer. Mr. Casabona, 42, will be in charge of Sterling's day-to-day operations.

headline: U.S. to Investigate Jordan on Embargo
abstract: The United States said today that it was investigating reports that Jordan ignored a United Nations embargo and shipped weapons to Iraq during the war.    "We are definitely looking into it," said the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret Tutwiler. "We just don't have any conclusions yet."   Military intelligence officers in Iraq said they found supplies of Jordanian weapons shipped to Iraq long after the United Nations ordered the arms embargo. Reporters in Kuwait City also saw boxes of ammunition marked "Jordan Armed Forces."

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Accuride Corp., a unit of Phelps Dodge Industries, Phoenix, has named Robert F. Hoffman president. He succeeds Gerald T. O'Neill, who is retiring. * Bridgeford Group, New York, a financial services firm for Japanese companies doing business in the United States and for United States concerns doing business in Japan, has named Alexander P. Lynch senior managing director. * First Bank, Troy, N.C., has named Jim Gunter president. He will replace John Wallace, who retires on Monday after 26 years as president. * McDonnell Douglas Corp., St. Louis, said Ronald L. Kerber, vice president-technology and strategic business development, had resigned to direct technology operations for Whirlpool Corp. * Northern Telecom Ltd., Toronto, has named Guy D. Gill vice president, investor relations. * Sematech, Austin, Tex., a consortium of technology companies, has named William L. George chief operating officer and executive vice president.

headline: Thai Link Lost, Cambodia Feels More Isolated
abstract: The ousted Prime Minister of Thailand, Chatichai Choonhavan, had been best known for his desire to turn Indochinese "battlefields into marketplaces." He had annoyed his Southeast Asian neighbors, and his Foreign Ministry, by opening a diplomatic channel to the Vietnamese-installed Government in Cambodia.   That is a channel the Thai military junta that took power in a coup on Feb. 23 has moved quickly to close.

headline: A Short War Will Test Recession Assumptions
abstract: A brief Persian Gulf war would test one of the great assumptions about the national recession: that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait precipitated the recession and an American military victory will make the economy rebound. But evidence is accumulating that the recession has taken on a life of its own and will probably endure.    The phenomenon that links the gulf crisis and the economy, in the minds of many economists, is public confidence, which deteriorated sharply after the invasion on Aug. 2. Those who measure public confidence -- the Conference Board and the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center -- at first said the gulf crisis had precipitated the deterioration, in part because of rising oil prices. Now they argue that other factors are unnerving Americans, inhibiting the spending that invigorates the economy.

headline: Stock Rally Resumes; Dow Jumps
abstract: After a one-day breather for investors to pull out some profits, stocks moved higher again yesterday in heavy trading.    Showing that the greatest strength was in the broader market, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose to a record high.

headline: 70,000 Germans Protest Ecomomy in East
abstract: More than 70,000 people gathered in eastern German cities tonight in demonstrations harkening back to the pro-democracy protests of late 1989. But this time, they demanded an end to economic deprivation and pledged to turn out every Monday until the region's troubled economy improves.    "Misery, our lives are misery," said one of the demonstrators, Claus Paetzold. "We stood here in the fall of 1989 to put down a dictator, and now we are in another kind of dictatorship."

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   9.50   9.50   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.50   6.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   6.50   9.00   8.18        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.21   6.22   7.76        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.27   6.28   7.72        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.88   7.89   8.44        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   8.19   8.20   8.54        TELEPHONE BONDS   9.45   9.45   9.59        MUNICIPAL BONDS*   7.41   7.42   7.47       *Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Earnings Dip At Gannett
abstract: The Gannett Company said today that sluggish advertising demand contributed to earnings declines of 8 percent for the fourth quarter and 5 percent for the year. It was the company's first decline in annual profits since going public in 1967.   The nation's biggest newspaper company said it earned $117.3 million, or 74 cents a share, in the final three months of 1990, compared with $127.4 million, or 79 cents a share, in the corresponding period in 1989. Revenues for the quarter fell 7 percent, to $904.6 million, from $968.6 million in 1989.    For the full year, Gannett earnings fell to $377 million, or $2.36 a share, compared with $397.5 million, or $2.47 a share, in 1989. Revenues for the year fell 2 percent, to $3.4 billion.    Gannett, which publishes USA Today among its 82 daily newspapers, said that the 1989 fourth quarter had 14 weeks compared with 13 weeks in 1990. It said the 1989 fiscal year had 53 weeks compared with 52 weeks in 1990.   In a statement, John J. Curley, chairman and chief executive, said 1990 was Gannett's "most challenging year as a public company." The company also owns 15 radio and 10 television stations.   The number of advertising pages at USA Today dropped in the fourth quarter to 976, from 1,113, and in the year to 3,501, from 3,850 in 1989. But because of rate increases and new products, the paper's advertising revenues for the year increased 1 percent, the company said.

headline: Seidman Issues F.D.I.C. Aid Plan
abstract: L. William Seidman, the nation's senior banking regulator, today proposed a $64.4 billion plan over five years that relies heavily on Government borrowing to shore up the ailing Federal program that protects deposits.    The plan to strengthen the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is a compromise attempt to avert the insolvency of the $8.4 billion fund without relying on taxpayer revenues or overly taxing an industry that has suffered from declining earnings over the last year. But it calls for significant increases in the amounts that banks will have to contribute to the fund to finance loans that might ultimately come from taxpayer funds.

headline: Moscow Journal; Literary Magazine's Struggle in a Time of Change
abstract: Novy Mir, the most distinctive of the Soviet literary magazines that defined the limits of officially publishable writing for most of 70 years, may not survive the economic chaos that recently led President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to threaten a return to censorship.    It was partly the freedom that Mr. Gorbachev gave writers and enterprising Soviet publishers to break the traditional straitjackets of official approval that broke the backs of the "thick journals," as magazines like Novy Mir (New World), Druzhba Narodov (Friendship of Peoples) and Moskva (Moscow) are called.

headline: Best Iraqi Troops Not Badly Hurt By Bombs, Pentagon Officials Say
abstract: After nearly three weeks of heavy bombing, the United States and allied military forces in the Persian Gulf have not substantially weakened the combat effectiveness of Iraq's elite ground forces in a well-entrenched "strategic reserve" in northern Kuwait and southern Iraq, Pentagon officials said today.   Despite projections by the Air Force that it could reduce the fighting capability of Iraqi forces by 50 percent in the opening weeks of the war, military officials said the strategic reserve force, about 10 divisions of formidable Republican Guard and Army tank units, is substantially intact with well-dispersed underground depots and supply lines despite the daily pounding from allied air forces. Among the Iraqi military forces, the 140,000 members of the force are the best trained and equipped and are considered the most loyal.  Supplies for Six Months     Tank and artillery losses are in the "low hundreds," the officials said, and up to six months' worth of supplies have been salted away in thousands of small depots that cannot be targeted by allied bombers.

headline: War Summary
abstract: SAUDI PILOT DOWNS 2 IRAQIS As the weather improved, allied bombers stepped up the pace of their attacks deep inside Iraq, concentrating on positions of the Republican Guards. A 30-year old Saudi pilot in an American-made F-15 shot down a pair of French-built Iraqi Mirage fighters over the Persian Gulf. A force of Marines, described as the largest amphibious group since the Korean War, practiced landings. DANGEROUS BRITISH MISSIONS The most dangerous missions of the war are being carried out by British pilots, most in their 20's, who fly into Iraq a few hundred feet above the ground to drop cluster bombs on well-protected Iraqi airfields. So far, 10 of the Tornado bomber airmen have been killed or are missing. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: Fourteen Americans and 12 allied airmen are listed as missing in action. Aircraft: A 15th American plane, an Air Force F-16, was lost, but its pilot was picked up by a Navy helicopter. The allied command has reported 21 warplanes lost, 17 of them in combat. IRAQI FORCES Troops: Iraq has reported 39 military deaths and nearly 100 civilian deaths. The allies say 29 more Iraqis were taken prisoner on the island of Qura off the Kuwaiti coast. Aircraft: The American command reported that the allies had shot down 19 enemy planes and destroyed 41 on the ground. A Pentagon spokesman said Wednesday's announcement of 19 planes shot down was an overcount by two. A Saudi pilot shot down two Iraqis yesterday so the count was placed at 19.

headline: G.M.-Poland Deal
abstract: The General Motors Corporation is close to signing a deal with Poland's biggest car maker, FSO, on production of its medium-sized Opel model in Warsaw, the Industry Minister, Andrzej Zawislak, said. But in Detroit, a G.M. spokesman would confirm only that talks were continuing. Mr. Zawislak said G.M. was ready for a capital investment in FSO, but he declined to give more details. News reports said an agreement could be signed this month.

headline: U.A.W. Local Vote Due on Mazda Pact
abstract: The United Automobile Workers union Local 3000 will vote on Monday on a tentative contract with Mazda Motor Manufacturing (U.S.A.) Inc. Meetings are set for Friday for the 2,900 members of the local, the only U.A.W.-represented work force at a Japanese-owned assembly plant in the United States. The plant is in Flat Rock, about 30 miles south of Detroit.   Details of the pact have not been released officially. But The Detroit News today quoted union workers that it did not identify as saying that the agreement included a pay rise of $2.50 an hour, increasing Mazda workers' wages to that at Big Three plants, to about $16 an hour; pension improvements; four personal days off a year beside the current holidays, and hiring some temporary workers as full-time employees.

headline: House Vote Bars More S.& L. Aid
abstract: A deeply divided House of Representatives today rejected four measures to provide new financing for the bailout of the savings and loan industry.   The decisions came after Republicans and Democrats failed to reach agreement on whether to attach conditions to the request by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency managing the bailout, for $30 billion in new money.

headline: Listening for A Scary Word: Depression
abstract: War and peace caught traders' attention last week, but the growing evidence of a deteriorating economy may yet have a bigger impact on securities prices.   "People have basically not concentrated on the domestic problems," said Stanley Shopkorn, a vice chairman and chief equity trader at Salomon Brothers. "They should." He is bearish, and thinks even a short and successful war would produce only a brief rally in stocks.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Black G.I.'s; Powell to Study Complaints By Harlem Unit in Gulf War
abstract: Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will investigate allegations by members of a Harlem National Guard unit that they were placed into a combat situation in the Persian Gulf without proper training and not treated with respect by regular army forces, Representative Charles B. Rangel says.   "When you're fat and 40 and they throw you into combat, it isn't fair," said Mr. Rangel, whose New York district includes the headqurters of the National Guard's 369th Transport Battalion, also known as the Harlem Hell Fighters.

headline: Salvador Editor Says Attack Won't Keep Paper Shuttered
abstract: The director of an independent newspaper whose presses were destroyed in a fire that officials described as arson said today that the paper would continue to publish.   "It is not by bombs or by attacks that they are going to quiet Diario Latino," the director, Francisco Valencia, said.    Mr. Valencia blamed the armed forces and El Salvador's rightist Government for the blaze on Saturday that destroyed presses, computers and office equipment at the 101-year-old publication.

headline: Sale of Aetna Stake
abstract: Banco Hispano Americano said it would pay 9.7 billion pesetas, or about $100 million, to the Aetna Life and Casualty Company for its 45 percent stake in the insurance company La Estrella. La Estrella's chairman, Miguel Geijo, said the priceamounted to 45 percent of the company's capital, reserves and potential capital gains plus a 23 percent premium. Aetna estimated it would realize a capital gain of about $32 million for its interest in La Estrella. The transaction is expected to be completed in May.

headline: Fine of French Rightist Increased After Appeal
abstract: An appeals court today upheld a judgment condemning a leader of the far right for referring to the Nazi gas chambers as a "detail of history," and increased his fine from about 18 cents to almost $167,000.   The politician, Jean-Marie Le Pen, had been sentenced in May to pay a symbolic fine of one franc on a defamation conviction. But the Versailles Appeals Court raised the fine to 100,000 francs, or about $18,500, to each of nine groups that had filed suit. Six of the groups represent World War II Jewish deportees.   Mr. Le Pen is to pay 10 francs to a 10th group.   The court, presided over by Judge Pierre Estoup, also ordered the publication of the decision in five national dailies and in five weeklies, and said Mr. Le Pen must pay court expenses.   A member of the European Parliament who heads France's National Front party, he caused a scandal during a radio interview in 1987 when he referred to the existence of Nazi gas chambers during World War II as a "detail of history." Mr. Le Pen, who attended neither the trial nor the appeals hearing, denies he is anti-Semitic or racist.

headline: Nationwide Buys Sales Operation
abstract: The Landmark Land Company said the Nationwide Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, had acquired for $6 million most of the sales operations of Landmark Financial Services, a joint venture between Landmark and the Davenport Group of Oklahoma City. Landmark Financial markets and sells annuities, life insurance, mutual funds and other financial products.    Landmark, based in Carmel, Calif., said the sale would help its Oak Tree Savings Bank subsidiary, a troubled Louisiana savings and loan, satisfy regulatory requirements. It also said the sale would allow Landmark Financial to retire all its debt while keeping some of its operations.

headline: Loss Posted At Tonka
abstract: The Tonka Corporation, the nation's third-largest toy company, on Monday reported a loss of $18.5 million in the final quarter of 1990.   Tonka, which has agreed to be acquired by Hasbro Inc., said the loss was in contrast to earnings of $1.3 million, or 13 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1989. The toy maker reported revenue of $247.2 million, up 1 percent from $244.7 million in the 1989 period.     For the full year, Tonka said it lost $43.9 million, in contrast to 1989 net earnings of $5.7 million, or 67 cents a share. Revenues for 1990 totaled $788.5 million, down 9.4 percent from $870.5 million in 1989.

headline: Hispanic Ads At Little Caesar
abstract: Little Caesar Enterprises Inc. will announce today that it has selected Font & Vaamonde Inc., a New York agency, to advertise its Little Caesars pizza to Hispanic consumers.   "We liked the fact that they devote 100 percent of their time to understanding the Hispanic market," said Denise Ilitch Lites, senior executive vice president for advertising at Little Caesar. "This is their specialty."   Little Caesar, based in Detroit, will continue to use Cliff Freeman & Partners as its main national agency. The company would not disclose how much it planned to spend on advertising aimed at the Hispanic market.

headline: Lone Star Steel Bankruptcy Plan
abstract: A bankruptcy judge approved the reorganization plan of the Lone Star Steel Company, its parent company, Lone Star Technologies Inc., said. The plan will become effective in early April, it said, ending the bankruptcy case the steel subsidiary began in June 1989.   When complete, Lone Star Technologies will own 80.5 percent of Lone Star Steel. The rest will belong to Amroc Investments, which is affiliated with the Robert M. Bass Group, and the Trust Company of the West, a Los Angeles investment management concern. Federal Bankruptcy Judge Harold C. Abramson approved the plan on Monday, a Lone Star spokeswoman said.

headline: Real Estate; A New Effort To Redevelop Harlem Site
abstract: ON March 8, New York City will invite builders to propose redevelopment plans for a long underutilized property on the 125th Street shopping corridor in Harlem.  What the city's Public Development Corporation envisions on the 67,000-square-foot site, between Lexington and Third Avenues, is a two-story building with up to 230,000 square feet of space. It would have ground-floor retail space, possibly including a supermarket, topped by offices. The estimated value of the project is $20 million

headline: Your Own Account; For Growth, Look to the Little Guys
abstract: Large companies are expected to continue to slim down in coming years, resulting in fewer job opportunities at the country's largest firms, according to recruiters and outplacement specialists. Job growth, they say, will come from the very smallest businesses, and these companies will be looking for experienced people who can wear many different hats.   "There's a tremendous shift from Fortune 1000 companies to small companies," said Dale H. Learn, chairman of the Greenwich Group Inc., an outplacement firm in Greenwich, Conn. "That's where all the employment is taking place." He said people ought to be directing job searches "to companies of 25 people or maybe even five people."

headline: AFTER THE WAR: The Casualties; Wounded G.I.'s Tell Of Barracks Horror When Scud Struck
abstract: Pfc. Anthony Drees was scrambling for his helmet when an Iraqi Scud missile devastated his barracks. The blast broke one of his legs and shattered the other.   "One more day, that damned war would have been over," said Private Drees, 23 years old, who is from Grand Forks, N.D. "God, I had a nice life, too."

headline: Sales of Mideast Books Surge on News of War
abstract: For several weeks, books about the Middle East have enjoyed unusually brisk sales, but yesterday -- one day after the start of the war in the Persian Gulf -- bookstores were besieged by customers wanting anything about the region they could get their hands on. Many stores also reported a run on maps.   "We had a big display of Middle East books in the front of our store, but now we're just about out of everything," said Bill Heath, floor manager of a Dallas branch of the Bookstop chain.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Reactions/Egypt; Officials Call For Iraqi's Ouster
abstract: Abandoning much of their previous caution, Egyptian officials said today that the Iraqi President had to be toppled from power for peace to prevail in the Middle East.    "It would be much better without him," a senior Government official said in an interview, although he added that President Hussein's future was for the Iraqi people to decide.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; People
abstract: * Joe Palmo has been promoted to senior vice president and creative director at Ketchum Advertising, Pittsburgh. * Sara Coulter, Susan Johnson and Meredith Pillon have been promoted to executive vice presidents at the Rowland Co., New York. Promoted to senior vice president were Andrea Berken and Linda Stanier. * David J. Barrett has been named deputy general manager of broadcasting at the Hearst Corp., New York. * Victoria Lasdon has been appointed advertising director of Self magazine, a Conde Nast publication.

headline: Panama Canal a Worry to Shippers
abstract: International maritime officials are expressing concern that the condition of the Panama Canal is slowly deteriorating and that Panama will be unable to manage the waterway properly when it takes full control in 1999.   The 1977 Carter-Torrijos Treaties envisioned a gradual transition in management of the canal from American to Panamanian hands with no loss in efficiency or security. But an increasing array of troubles is raising the question of whether a developing country with a population and economy smaller than many American cities can be expected to run one of the most complex engineering enterprises in the world.

headline: Aquino's New Chief of Staff Is Raising Hopes in Manila
abstract: The young and energetic Oscar Orbos, newly appointed executive secretary to President Corazon C. Aquino, is expected to work varying miracles on behalf of a faltering administration facing severe economic difficulties.    In his new job, which is sometimes called "the deputy presidency," he is Mrs. Aquino's John H. Sununu, in charge of coordinating the entire range of Government policy.

headline: A Computer Becomes a TV Studio
abstract: An innovative package of hardware and software that can transform a computer into a desktop television studio has stirred an unusual degree of excitement in both the computer and video worlds.   Made by Newtek Inc., a small company in Topeka, Kan., the package consists of an expansion board, which plugs into a Commodore Amiga computer, and eight floppy disks. It can create most of the stylish effects seen on a network news broadcast, like splitting or flipping images. It can generate letters and other characters to superimpose over pictures and produces animation that looks three dimensional.

headline: Group of 7 Opens Talks On Outlook
abstract: Against the backdrop of war, the top economic policy makers from the United States and its six main industrial allies gathered in New York yesterday for a two-day assessment of the world economy.   The date of the meeting was set weeks ago to give the finance ministers and chief central bankers from the Group of Seven countries a chance at the start of the year to review a variety of financial and monetary issues. But the ministers agreed that those matters would now be overshadowed by the war. 'Not an Emergency Meeting'     "This is not an emergency meeting," a Bush Administration official emphasized. But he added, "The events in the gulf are of course going to be a very important part of the discussions."   Michael H. Wilson, the Finance Minister of Canada, said, "Expectations for various economies, particularly with regard to the impact of the hostilities in the gulf -- that's the key."

headline: A.T.& T. Rate Cuts
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it had reduced its interstate and international long-distance rates by $83.4 million a year as of Tuesday. The reduction is $49.5 million more than A.T.& T. predicted in a filing on Dec. 18 with the Federal Communications Commission. The difference reflects an F.C.C. order deferring proposed increases in the fees A.T.& T. would be assessed this year for federally managed programs that subsidize local phone companies in areas that are expensive to serve or that have many low-income subscribers.

headline: Bush Greets Walesa With Debt Relief
abstract: Welcoming Lech Walesa to the White House for the first time since he was elected President of Poland, President Bush forgave an additional $800 million in Polish debt payments today.    With that decision the United States has now agreed to wipe clean 70 percent of Poland's $3.8 billion debt to Washington,

headline: Sales of U.S.-Made Vehicles Down 31.4% in Early January
abstract: Paralyzed by consumers' uncertainties about a weak economy and the prospect of war, sales of cars and trucks made in the United States were mired at recessionary levels in early January.    Sales of all types of vehicles for the Jan. 1 through Jan. 10 period fell 31.4 percent compared with early January of last year. Both periods contained eight selling days.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * Broward County, Florida, is offering $68.3 million in tax-exempt gas tax revenue bonds, with a maximum yield of about 6.69 percent for a bond due in 2010. Yields on serial bonds range from 4.50 percent in 1991 to 6.55 percent in 2004. The bonds are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's Corp. * CIT Group Holdings Inc., a unit of Manufacturers Hanover Corp., New York, is offering $250 million in 8 3/4 percent notes due in 1996, at a price of 100, through Kidder, Peabody & Co. The noncallable notes are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P. * Federal Farm Credit Banks is offering $160 million in 7.19 percent consolidated system bonds due in 1994 at a price of 100 through Morgan Stanley & Co. * MBIA Inc., Armonk, N.Y., is offering $100 million in 9 percent notes due in 2001 at 99.352 to yield 9.10 percent, through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Inc. The noncallable notes are rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA+ by S.& P. * Republic New York Corp. is offering $100 million in 8 7/8 percent notes due in 2001, at 99.25, to yield 8.99 percent, through Lehman Brothers. The noncallable issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by S.& P. * Tenneco Corp., Houston, is offering $200 million in 9 7/8 percent notes due in 2001 at 99.65, to yield 9.93 percent, through Morgan Stanley & Co. The noncallable notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by S.& P. * Texaco Capital, a unit of Texaco Inc., White Plains, is offering $200 million in 8 1/2 percent notes due in 2003 at 99.15, to yield 8.615 percent, through Morgan Stanley & Co. The noncallable notes are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P. COMMON STOCK * Uno Restaurant Corp., West Roxbury, Mass., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 1.2 million common shares through A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. * Zilog Inc., Campbell, Calif., has filed an initial public offering of two million common shares through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. RATINGS * Armstrong World Industries' senior debt rating has been lowered to A-2, from A-1 by Moody's. The company is based in Lancaster, Pa.

headline: Majority on F.C.C. Opposing Networks On TV Rerun Sales
abstract: In what appears to be a serious setback for television networks, a majority of the five-member Federal Communications Commission now favors continuing to limit the ability of the networks to sell lucrative television reruns.    The development comes after weeks of deadlock on the issue, which has been the subject of an intense lobbying war between Hollywood studios and the networks over the $3 billion market. The commission is to decide the issue on Thursday, but has thus far been divided. Two commissioners, the chairman, Alfred C. Sikes, and James H. Quello, have favored repealing most restrictions. Two others, Sherrie Marshall and Ervin Duggan, want to keep many of the rules in place.

headline: Despite Ad Slump, U.S. Magazines Move to Britain
abstract: Steven Goodman, a London media analyst, contends that the current British market for new magazines is "downright diabolical."   Not surprisingly, Lee Eisenberg, the founding editor in chief of the new British version of Esquire magazine, takes a more upbeat view.

headline: U.S. War Plan: Still the Ground to Conquer
abstract: Though there is hope in the Pentagon that Iraqi forces might collapse before the allied bombing campaign ends, the more likely scenario for the next stage of the Persian Gulf war involves the far more dangerous task of pushing President Saddam Hussein's army out of Kuwait with a ground campaign.    That is the consensus among military analysts in and outside the Pentagon after three days of one of the most intensive air campaigns in the history of warfare.    Pentagon officials said today that they considered the allied forces in the gulf ready to direct their fire at Iraq's Republican Guards, the mainstay of the Iraqi Army.

headline: Texas Instruments Cuts 320 Workers
abstract: Texas Instruments Inc. laid off 320 employees, including 200 from the its military division, a spokeswoman said. The company attributed the layoffs to the weak economy, the Persian Gulf war and cutbacks in the military industry.   In addition to the military layoffs, 100 semiconductor workers and 20 information systems employees were laid off. All but 15 of those laid off worked at company operations in North Texas, the company spokeswoman said. Since last summer, 1,700 of the company's employees in military work have been laid off.

headline: Lois/GKK's Tasty Approach to High Tech
abstract: THE ads picture what looks like a large pizza box, with the message that the product within will make executives' lives "a whole lot easier." Inside, it turns out, is a $100,000 computer, without anchovies.   Data General is using the unlikely comparison in a $5 million campaign to illustrate the compact size of its new Aviion computer system, which will be introduced today.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., appointed Kazuo Yoshikawa vice president for its unit in Japan. * ALTA Health Strategies Inc., Salt Lake City, an independent health-care management company, promoted James A. Kenworthy Jr. to executive vice president and chief administrative officer. * American Superconductor Corp., Watertown, Mass., which developes ceramic superconducting wires, named Dr. Alexis P. Malozemoff vice president of research and development. * Atlantic Mutual Cos., New York, a property and casualty insurance concern, appointed Randolph J. Smith senior vice president of personal lines. * Comprehensive Health Services Inc., Rockville, Md., a provider of preventive and occupational medicine, named James S. Mitchell executive vice president. * GMI Engineering and Management Institute, Flint, Mich., appointed Dr. James E. A. John president. * North American Philips Corp., New York, a subsidiary of Philips Industries, Eindhoven, the Netherlands, named Donald L. Hamilton vice president of employee relations. Patrick J. Greaney was named senior vice president. * Volvo North America Corp., New York, a unit of Volvo A.B., Goteborg, Sweden, promoted Albert R. Dowden, to president and chief executive; David C. Korpics, to senior vice president and chief financial officer; Robert B. Mercer, to senior vice president; Keld Alstrup, to vice president of human resources, and Rob Wyder, to vice president of corporate development.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Ambase Corp., New York, an insurance company, rescheduled its special shareholders meeting for Feb. 12 for a vote on the sale of its Home Insurance Co. unit to TVH Acquisition Corp. * Black & Decker Corp., Towson, Md., the tool and outdoor products company, completed the sale of its Mallory Controls North American business to Emerson Electric Co., St. Louis, for about $90 million. * Cell Technology Inc., Boulder, Colo., said it would acquire Pioneer Pharmaceuticals Inc., a unit of Dow Chemical Co.'s Essex Chemical Corp. subsidiary, for cash equal to Pioneer's audited net book value of about $5.5 million. * First Charlotte Corp., Charlotte, N.C., a banking firm, and J. C. Bradford & Co., a securities firm, agreed to merge. * Hecla Mining Co., Couer D'Alene, Idaho, and Coca Mines, Denver, signed a provisional merger agreement. Hecla will issue more than 3.5 million common shares in exchange for the more than 12.6 million Coca common shares outstanding. * Home and City Savings Bank, Albany, said that Rose Associates I L.P., Albany, which owns 9.9 percent of the bank's outstanding common shares, had terminated its agreement to acquire the bank. * Raytheon Co., Lexington, Mass., the electronics, aviation and appliances company, said its United Engineers and Constructors subsidiary would provide the engineering services for a $130 million replacement co-generation power plant at Venezuela's Cardon oil refinery. * SL Industries, Laurel, N.J., a maker of electrical and mechanical equipment, sold all the business and assets of its SL Abrasives Inc. unit to Cincinnati Milacron Inc., Cincinnati, a maker of machine tools, metal works and other machinery. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Technology; U.S. Tells of Prewar Technology Sales to Iraq Worth $500 Million
abstract: Facing growing scrutiny of trade policy toward Iraq in the years before the Persian Gulf war, the Commerce Department today made public a list of $500 million in advanced American manufactured goods that it said were sold with its blessing to Iraqi Government agencies and private concerns from 1985 until Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August.   The 771 export licenses, for products ranging from lasers to oscilloscopes to computers, include some sales to Iraqi offices that have since been publicly identified as research centers for ballistic missiles or nuclear and chemical weapons; the installations were destroyed last month in bombing raids, according to the Pentagon.

headline: NBC to Drop System Of Adjustable Ratings
abstract: Pier Mapes, the president of the NBC Television Network, said yesterday that the network would abandon an adjustable program-rating system it established last year, because the system had not been a success.    Mr. Mapes said the adjustable rating system cost the networks between $100 million and $200 million in lost ad revenues. Unhappy with the system, advertisers spent more heavily on cable television and the Fox network, he said.

headline: Bridgestone Cuts
abstract: Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. said it plans to lay off 500 salaried workers, half of them at the company's Akron headquarters, because of slumping tire sales. The company also said it plans to leave 300 vacant jobs unfilled. The layoffs will reduce Bridgestone-Firestone's salaried staff in Akron to 1,500, down 25 percent in the past 18 months. The cuts are scheduled to take effect by June 30. There are 11,000 Bridgestone-Firestone white-collar employees nationwide and some 20,000 hourly workers.

headline: Wilkinson Loses Ruling
abstract: A Federal judge in New York ordered a permanent injunction yesterday barring Wilkinson Sword Inc. in Atlanta from making claims that its Ultra Glide shaving system provided a shave "six times smoother" than the Gillette Company's products. Gillette sued the company in 1989.    Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood ordered Wilkinson to stop making claims of "shaving smoothness superiority," and to drop certain claims that Ultra Glide was preferred by customers.

headline: IN OTHER SECTIONS
abstract: A FALLEN SON: For two days, family, friends and strangers held funeral services in Minnesota for a young marine killed two weeks ago in the war's first ground combat. Page B18. SOMBER TOY FAIR: A somber and unsettled mood has settled over the 88th American International Toy Fair in New York this week because of the war, and there is controversy over toys that capitalize on the fighting. The Home Section, page C1.

headline: FEDERAL RESERVE CUTS LOAN RATES TO PROD ECONOMY
abstract: In the face of stark new evidence of the nation's economic weakness, the Federal Reserve moved today with unusual force to stimulate the economy by sharply reducing the interest rates it controls.   Large banks across the country responded immediately by reducing their prime rate, the benchmark rate for many mortgages and other commercial and consumer loans.

headline: China Charges 8 Dissidents In 1989 Tiananmen Protests
abstract: China started court proceedings today against eight dissidents, including a prominent historian, for their roles in the Tiananmen Square demonstrations in 1989.   Bao Zunxin, a scholar at the History Institute of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, was charged with "counterrevolutionary propaganda and incitement." He was arrested shortly after the crackdown on June 4, 1989.    Wang Haidong was charged with the same crime, and six other people were accused of arson, looting, larceny and blocking traffic: Li Shuntang, Liu Xiaojing, Yang Junzhong, Zhou Wanshui, Lu Xiaochun, Yu Yongjie.

headline: Wall Street; Disguising the Risks of Research
abstract: How profitable is your favorite biotechnology company? How much is it spending on research and development, the staff of life in any science-driven industry? What do you stand to lose if its hot new idea is a dud?   Simple questions, really. But, in the wonderland of Wall Street, those basic questions have become increasingly difficult to answer. These days, the research and development "expenditures" at many promising companies show up on the books as "income," and the potential cost of actually bringing a new product to market may not show up at all -- except on the books of an ostensibly separate public company. As for who suffers from a flop, that may depend entirely on which paper entity happened to be the official owner of that product's patent.

headline: Tokyo's Importing More, but Who's Benefiting?
abstract: After a five-year battle by the United States and European nations to open Japan's markets and correct its big trade imbalances, imports have risen swiftly and Japan's huge financial surpluses have plummeted. On the surface, the changes seem substantial.   But as is often the case with such broad economic shifts, the side effects, like the expected boon to foreign companies and improved living standards for Japanese consumers, have not materialized the way some economists on both sides of the Pacific had forecast. While some progress has occurred, companies like Toys "R" Us are still struggling to build a network of stores here.  Too Expensive     Other companies still find it just too expensive, like Citibank, when it sought to buy a bank or bank branches to develop a retail system. So the flow of foreign capital into Japan remains a trickle, while corporate Japan has continued to build up its share of foreign markets with big overseas investments.

headline: Patents; Preserving Wine After Bottle Is Opened
abstract: A Boston restaurateur and two other inventors obtained a patent this week on an aerosol canister for wine bottles that makes it possible to drink part of the bottle and preserve the rest for as long as wanted.   The canister was conceived by Chuck Ellis, director of marketing at Boston's Grill 23 and Bar. Mr. Ellis said he had not been able to preserve wine for more than three weeks. As a result, he said, it was virtually impossible to sell expensive wines by the glass because the remaining wine might not be consumed before its taste and bouquet degraded. Similarly, wine collectors cannot sample a vintage and return the bottle to their collection.   The new device allows a person to pour wine without removing the cork or letting air into the bottle. It consists of a canister filled with a special gas, designed to take the place of liquid leaving the bottle. The gas consists of argon, which does not mix with anything, and a mixture of carbon dioxide and water vapor that matches the natural percentages in wine.   Protruding from the center of the canister is a hollow tube with a screw-tip that penetrates the cork. By pulling a handle on the canister's side, Mr. Ellis said, the hollow tip opens up and wine can pour through it. At the same time, he said, the aerosol canister pushes the replacement gas into the bottle through a second tube. As a result, outside air has no way of getting into the container. Mr. Ellis said the device made it possible to preserve a wine indefinitely.   Mr. Ellis, Michael Osean, and Nori Hirako received patent 4,984,711.

headline: The Castoff Children: Who's to Give Them Love?
abstract: At Tuesday morning breakfast, Bogdan Stoian, a 16-year-old resident of the home for severely disabled children in this hamlet near Bucharest, grinned broadly as he peered up from his new wheelchair.    "He understands what people say but cannot speak," said Nina Bratu, a doctor at the home. "He is very happy now that he doesn't have to stay in a bed all day."

headline: Thousands of Albanians Flee Aboard Ships to Italy
abstract: For the third time in seven months, thousands of Albanians are fleeing their country, this time by sea as well as by land as the Communist Government sinks into what a resident of the capital called paralysis.    Since Monday, mass departures from the Adriatic ports of Vlora and Durres have been under way, virtually stripping the harbors of seaworthy vessels. A thousand or more ethnic Slavs made their way to the northern frontier, seeking entry to Yugoslavia, while other citizens in the south continue to flee to Greece.

headline: He Had Money, Women, an S.&L. Now Don Dixon Has Jail
abstract: With a price tag to taxpayers that may reach $500 billion, the savings and loan bailout is destined to become the most expensive financial debacle in the country's history. About 550 failed savings institutions have already been closed, their assets brought under the Government's control to be sold. Deregulation, allowing savings units to invest in everything from raw land to risky "junk bonds," is largely to blame for the failures, but entrepreneurs who rolled into the industry and played fast and loose with the money are also culprits. Federal prosecutors won convictions of 403 of them of fraud. Among the most notorious is Donald Ray Dixon, the head of Vernon Savings and Loan, who could soon get the stiffest sentence of any. His story, culled from court documents and interviews, is emblematic of the torrid living that ransacked the industry.

headline: F.C.C. Rivalries Leading to Impasse
abstract: As an advocate of deregulation, Alfred C. Sikes, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has a sweeping agenda for relaxing many longstanding regulations throughout the communications industries and encouraging new technology.    But last week's impasse on rerun rights for television networks casts substantial doubt on whether he can forge a majority from an increasingly fractious panel to accomplish his goals.

headline: Gulf Victory May Raise U.S. Influence in OPEC
abstract: By virtue of its military victory, the United States is likely to have more influence in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries than any industrial nation has ever exercised. But in the short term, the Administration may not try to exercise this influence.    American officials say they are just beginning to discuss how they might use their new franchise. The first opportunity would arise if crude oil prices plunged from the current level of nearly $20 a barrel. In that event, Washington might lean on a reluctant Saudi Arabia to cut production and push prices back up to a range of $18 to $22.

headline: Eastern to Sell Northwest Its Washington Operations
abstract: The carving up of Eastern Airlines continued yesterday, as Northwest Airlines agreed to buy the carrier's gates, landing and takeoff rights and other operations at Washington National Airport for $23.2 million.    The Northwest purchase follows by a day the announcement by Delta Air Lines that it had agreed to purchase 18 Eastern gates at Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta and an international route for $42.9 million.

headline: Saatchi Expected to Offer New Plan for Shareholders
abstract: BOWING to pressure from shareholders, Saatchi & Saatchi, the troubled London-based advertising giant, is expected to announce early next week a new plan to change the terms of its equity ownership. If no plan is approved, there is a possibility that Saatchi could eventually be liquidated.    St. James's Place Capital, a London-based subsidiary of J. Rothschild and the largest holder of Saatchi's Europreference shares, has hired the Hambros Bank to devise a new restructuring plan, said David Beck, a spokesman for St. James's. The plan is expected to be presented today to S. G. Warburg & Company, Saatchi's investment bank.

headline: Police Question Londoners On Attack at Major's Office
abstract: The police scoured snow-covered streets today near Whitehall, the seat of Britain's Government, interviewing passers-by and looking for clues to the terrorist team that fired mortar shells on Thursday at the residence and office of Prime Minister John Major.   Officials at Scotland Yard said they had received more than 100 calls on a special anti-terrorist hotline. But the police disclosed nothing about any new information they might have received about the daring daylight attack at 10 Downing Street, which was attributed to the Irish Republican Army.

headline: Plodding Economic Cleanup Efforts Cost Greece in Credit and Credibility
abstract: Elected last year with a mandate to put Greece's house in order, Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis still seems overwhelmed by the legacy of almost a decade of chaotic Socialist rule that turned this country into the poorest member of the 12-nation European Community.    But while the Government still blames former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou for Greece's steady slide toward third world status, impatience is mounting at what many people see as Mr. Mitsotakis's lack of courage in failing to reverse the Socialist policies swiftly.

headline: Market Place; Chairman's Role In Rexene Feuds
abstract: WILLIAM J. GILLIAM, a brash young deal maker in the 1980's, split from his three partners in a messy Wall Street-style divorce in 1988. At the time, Mr. Gilliam argued that he had been the brains behind the partners' best-known deal -- a buyout and, later, a public stock offering of the Rexene Corporation, a petrochemical company based in Dallas. Sure enough, he wound up in effective control of the company when two of his former partners, who had been on the Rexene board, resigned in early 1990.    Now, a year later, Mr. Gilliam is embroiled in another messy feud, raising the question of whether the chairman has become a liability to a company that owed much of its early success to him.

headline: New Chief For Philip Morris
abstract: In a bold departure from having tobacco men as its chairmen, the Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest consumer-products company and the maker of Marlboro cigarettes, named Michael A. Miles its chairman and chief executive yesterday, effective Sept. 1.   Now the chairman of Kraft General Foods Inc., the company's largest unit, Mr. Miles is a newcomer to Philip Morris, a neophyte in the tobacco business and a former smoker. Mr. Miles was the unanimous choice of Philip Morris's 21-member board, which held a one-hour regularly scheduled meeting yesterday.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Reaction; U.N. PANEL TO MEET ON MOSCOW'S PLAN
abstract: The Persian Gulf peace plan agreed to by the Soviet Union and Iraq produced mixed reactions tonight from the members of the United Nations Security Council, which must decide whether to approve it and bring hostilities to a halt.   The United States representative at the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, who has a veto on any Council decision, said he had no comment to make, keeping in line with President Bush's statement that he would confer with America's allies in the conflict before taking any position.

headline: Monrovia Journal; A Monument to War: The City of Dreadful Sights
abstract: One of the rarest sights in Monrovia these days is the once ubiquitous palm tree. The trees began disappearing last fall when, as starvation spread in this war-shattered capital, thousands were cut down and their edible hearts eagerly and desperately consumed.   The trees will take years to grow back, but they surely will. Monrovia's future is less hopeful. "There is no more Monrovia," said Abu Kromah, who fled the country last August at the height of fighting in Liberia's 14-month-old civil war.

headline: IRAQ'S PRESIDENT PROMISES REFORMS ONCE REVOLTS END
abstract: Facing bloody civil insurrection in the north and the south of his country, President Saddam Hussein appealed today for the support of the Iraqi people, promising to push ahead with democratic reforms as soon as he crushed the rebellion.    In his first broadcast to the nation since Feb. 26, when he withdrew his defeated army from Kuwait, Mr. Hussein sought to portray himself as firmly in control of his nation's future, despite the destruction wrought by United States and allied forces in the war and continuing reports of bloodshed and civil insurgency inside Iraq.

headline: In Focus Systems Sets Compaq Deal
abstract: In Focus Systems Inc. said it had licensed its technology for color liquid crystal computer displays to the Compaq Computer Corporation. In Focus, a company based in Tualatin, Ore., that went public last month, will receive royalties if Compaq uses the flat panel technology in its machines.    The Houston-based Compaq is a leader in the notebook computer market but needs to begin supplying color screens if it is to keep pace with Japanese competitors. In Focus buys liquid crystal panels from the Kyocera Corporation of Japan and combines three of them in a unique way to produce a color screen. The company says its screens are less expensive to manufacture than other color liquid crystal displays and require less power, making it possible to use them in a battery-operated computer.

headline: Your Own Account; Buying Your Own Franchise
abstract: Like many executives today, James J. Oden took a look at his life -- a job as director of corporate accounting for Philip Morris in New York, a wife and two kids in New Canaan, Conn. -- and found his work and commute wanting. And like an increasing number of them, he devised a plan to get out of the corporate world and into his own business.   Mr. Oden, 43, believed his company had too many people on the payroll, and figured a way his department could be reorganized -- without him. The company was happy to save money, and gave him a lump-sum payment, which he used last September to buy a franchise in Charlotte, N.C., with Tom's Foods, a Georgia-based distributor of snack foods for vending machines and convenience stores.  By early next year, he expects to be earning what he made in the corporate world, although he will not say what that is.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Diplomacy; U.S. AND BRITAIN FAULT SOVIET PLAN
abstract: The United States and Britain have told Moscow that they find its proposal for a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf unacceptable because it lacks a tight timetable for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait and does not compel Baghdad to accept all Security Council resolutions on the crisis, Western diplomats said today.    The two allies told Moscow separately that they wanted Baghdad to agree to a deadline of a few days for its unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait, the diplomats said. This could force Iraq to abandon tanks, artillery and other arms taken into Kuwait after the Aug. 2 invasion.
