Baghdad has yet to respond to Moscow's plan, the details of which have not been disclosed. 12 Resolutions     Diplomats say the United States wants Iraq to be required to leave the tanks and heavy armaments behind, while Britain takes the view that obliging it to do so as a condition of a cease-fire would exceed the terms of the Security Council mandate. Nonetheless, the Americans and British both insist that Iraq must accept the terms of all 12 Security Council resolutions on the gulf war, and not merely Resolution 660, which calls for Iraq's withdrawal to its prewar positions.

headline: Agreement On Sabena Is Canceled
abstract: Faced with a year-end deadline and a variety of unresolved issues, the three companies involved in an agreement that would have given British Airways and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines each a 20 percent stake in Sabena Belgian World Airlines, canceled the deal today.    Sabena S.A., parent of the money-losing Belgian carrier, is recapitalizing, and its financial difficulties were the main reason the deal fell apart. Sabena said today that it would buy back the shares already purchased by the other two airlines. But British Airways and KLM said they might make another attempt at forging links with Sabena.

headline: Iraq Closes Border With Jordan, Cutting Off Escape for Foreigners
abstract: Iraq was reported today to have barred war refugees from entering Jordan, blocking the major escape route for hundreds of thousands of foreigners trapped behind the lines and prey to deprivation and allied bombardment.   Because of deteriorating conditions in Baghdad, where water, food and fuel are said to be scarce, the Iraqi move could lead to a "large-scale human tragedy if people do not get out," a Western diplomat said.

headline: The Flaws in Iraqi Strategy
abstract: In planning its defense of Kuwait, Iraqi strategists appeared to think this war would be like their last. But the allies can do things Iran never could. Military analysis, page A15.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Press; Soldiers Fault Lack of News Since War Began
abstract: Journalists covering the war against Iraq are not the only ones complaining about censorship by the Defense Department. So are some of the troops.    American soldiers interviewed in remote camps in the Saudi desert said that the amount of news programming on Armed Forces Radio broadcast in Saudi Arabia had been sharply reduced since the war began Wednesday morning.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    Greenspan said the nation could face a long, deep recession if the war lasts past the middle of April. In an interview, the Fed chairman said he expected a rapid rebound if the war is relatively short.  [ Page A1. ]  Excerpts from the interview appear on page D6.    The Government's main economic forecasting index edged up 0.1 percent in December, the first increase in six months and a sign, analysts said, that the economy may have begun to stabilize.  [ D1. ]   The F.D.I.C. mishandled the two most costly collapses so far, a Congressional task force said in a report. The findings suggest parallels between flaws in the agency's management and expertise in banking oversight and those in the savings industry.  [ D1. ]   The Energy Dept. said it would cut the sale of high-sulfur crude from strategic reserves by nearly 50 percent.  [ D2. ]   The Federal budget deficit will hit $298 billion this year, the Congressional Budget Office predicted.  [ A19. ] Companies    Continental Airlines said it was adding 32 flights around the country, including 12 from Newark to Florida, to fill in some gaps left by the shutdown of Eastern.  [ D1. ]   Standard & Poor's downgraded its credit ratings on Sears' senior debt. Sears also strongly denied published reports that it might sell or close its catalogue business.  [ D2. ]   Occidental Petroleum said it took $2.05 billion in after-tax charges in the fourth quarter, causing a $2 billion loss.  [ D4. ]   Philip Morris said its earnings inched up only 2 percent in the fourth quarter.  [ D11. ]   Bethlehem Steel and Armco reported losses, saying their earnings were hurt by special charges, sharply reduced steel prices and lower demand. National Steel's profits plummeted.  [ D19. ]   M.I.T. and General Instrument said they would work together to develop an all-digital TV transmission technology.  [ D4. ]   A tiny Kentucky company has come to dominate a $290 million program to install water meters in New York City.  [ A1. ]   The contract between USX and 18,000 union members expires at midnight, and many say a strike is likely.  [ A17. ]   Exxon is considering an offer to settle Valdez-related lawsuits by making a payment of $1.2 billion.  [ A16. ]   Bush's nominee to be Labor Secretary said she would press for tougher enforcement of child-labor and worker-safety laws.  [ A18. ] International    Argentina's stock market soared 30 percent, in a stunning reversal after three days of sharp plunges by the country's currency and the appointment of a new Economy Minister.  [ D1. ] Markets    Stock prices advanced sharply, to their highest level in six months, on hopes for economic improvement. The Dow jumped 50.50, to 2,713.12.  [ D1. ]   Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in light trading, with short-term maturities basically unchanged.  [ D15. ]   The dollar ended the day mixed, after staging a moderate early advance amid signs of a shift to a ground war.  [ D16. ]   Oil prices fell after the top U.S. general in the Persian Gulf said the combat was going well. Crude lost 88 cents, to $20.97.  [ D16. ] Today's Columns    Harcourt found a buyer, but can General Cinema get the deal done, and at what price for bondholders? Talking Deals.  [ D2. ]   The stock market seems to have concluded that the recession will be short, and that the recovery will not be slow and cautious. Floyd Norris: Market Place.  [ D8. ]   Saatchi & Saatchi is expected to announce early next week a new recapitalization plan. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D19. ]

headline: Saudi-Iranian Relations Are Being Restored
abstract: Saudi Arabia and Iran will resume diplomatic relations within the next 48 hours, the Omani press agency reported today.   The agency, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran as saying, "The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and the Islamic Republic of Iran have reached understanding on solving all problems between them and restoring diplomatic ties within the next 48 hours."

headline: Japan Pressed to Buy More U.S. Awacs Jets
abstract: Heating up another front in the continuing trade disputes with Japan, 70 members of Congress complained last week that Tokyo has dragged its feet in assuming responsibility for the defense of its air space and sea lanes.    At issue is whether Japan needs the radar surveillance plane built by the Boeing Company -- the Airborne Early Warning and Control System, or Awacs -- and if it does, how many it needs.

headline: Head of Yugoslavia's Government Resigns in Dispute on Army Role
abstract: The leader of Yugoslavia's eight-member ruling council resigned today after his colleagues rejected his plan granting urgent powers to the army to intervene in the country's civil strife.   The leader, Borisav Jovic, who is also the Serbian representative, criticized his colleagues for tying the hands of the army in the midst of the turmoil that has grown since the republics of Croatia and Slovenia took the first legal steps toward separation.

headline: Treasury Bills and Farm Credit Offerings
abstract: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. By late in the day Friday the outstanding three-month bills were bid at 5.80 percent and six-month bills were at 5.81 percent.    Government agency issues expected this week include Wednesday's pricing of three issues totaling $2.76 billion in consolidated systemwide bonds by the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation. The maturities to be offered are for three months, six months and one year.

headline: Inland Steel to Cut Workers and Hours
abstract: Citing lower steel demand, the Inland Steel Company said it would lay off some workers and reduce workweeks for others at its only plant. The company employs 14,700 at the Indiana Harbor Works in East Chicago, Ind. -- 13,140 at its Inland Steel Flat Products Company and 1,560 at the Inland Bar and Structural Company.   The bar and structural company will shut its mills next week, affecting about 370 people, though operations are expected to resume next Saturday. The flat products company laid off 160 people and reduced workweeks for others this week after it closed a blast furnace. The unit will lay off another 100 employees on Sunday and expects more layoffs in coming weeks.

headline: A New Chief at Provident
abstract: John A. Miller, chairman and chief executive of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company, said this week that he would step down in June after 13 years as chief executive.    Mr. Miller will relinquish the chief executive's post on June 30 to L. J. Rowell Jr., Provident's president.

headline: Norway Plans Bank Aid
abstract: The Norwegian Government said on Thursday that it would propose an $833 million state guarantee fund to assure stability and confidence in the nation's troubled banks. The proposal, to be presented to Parliament this month, would establish a fund to offer capital to the private commercial bank reserve fund and the savings bank reserve fund. The banks have been hurt by an economic slump.

headline: War Summary
abstract: THE RELENTLESS AIR WAR Amid some of the heaviest bombing yet, Iraq said a captured airman - name and nationality undisclosed - died in the wreckage of a Government building in Baghdad where he "had been evacuated." Closer to the Saudi border, allied warplanes caught an Iraqi convoy venturing into the open desert and destroyed 24 tanks, armored vehicles and trucks. THE PLIGHT OF THE CIVILIANS Refugees reached Jordan with tales of deprivation, fright and sheer despair griping the people of Kuwait and Iraq. They spoke of scarce water and food, severed communications, bombed bridges, roads and housing, and a black market in which one can make a living selling cigarettes one at a time. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: Of the 28 airmen listed as missing before, 11 are now known to be held prisoner. These are 7 Americans, 2 Brittons, and 1 each from Italy and Kuwait. Another 7 Americans were among those still carried as missing. Aircraft: The United States command reported no losses yesterday. That left its cound of aircraft downed by the Iraqis at 18, including 11 American. Iraq claimed yesterday to have shot down 6 more "aerial targets." IRAQI FORCES Troops: No meaningful figures aircraft sequestered in Iran reached about 90. It is still not clear exactly why the planes' pilots sought refuge. The United States command in Riyadh said one more MIG-23 was shot down, raising to 52 its tally of aircraft destroyed, 27 of them in aerial combat and the rest on the ground.

headline: Gorbachev Draws Ex-Backers' Rage
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's crackdown on separatism in the Baltic states has kindled long-smouldering discontent into a blaze of censure by Soviet journalists, intellectuals, and reform-minded bureaucrats who once were his main supporters.   Statement after statement denouncing Mr. Gorbachev for ordering tanks and troops into Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, on Sunday is being published in the Soviet press by intellectuals who were hailing the Soviet leader five years ago as their liberator. Even some of his former advisers have signed.

headline: War Summary
abstract: AIR RAIDS AND ANOTHER LOSS As attacks on the lifelines of 545,000 front-line Iraqi troop went on unabated, an American B-52 bomber plunged into the Indian Ocean while returning to base on Diego Garcia. Three crewmen were rescued, and the search continued for three others missing in the crash, possibly caused by mechanical failure. MOVING THE BEANS AND THE BULLETS As the number of allied troops passed 500,000 with the arrival of reinforcements from Germany, desert highways took on the look of an American expressway at rush-hour; bumper-to-bumper. The largest quick-order military deployment in history in in its last stages. CREDIBILITY GAP REVISITED The atmosphere at military briefings has turned noticeably testy as correspondents disparage the information as short on facts and at times misleading. Some veterans complain that their briefers seem even less informative than those of "five o'clock follies" memory in Saigon. WAR LOSSES ALLIES FORCES Troops: Two airmen were killed in a crash in Kuwait and three were missing in the crash of the B-52. This would bring the daily tally of American losses to 14 killed in action, 26 airmen missing in action and 8 confirmed as prisoners of war. The U.S. Central Command in Riyadh did not provide an overall count. A Saudi spokesman said 18 Saudi soldiers were killed in the fighting at Khafji last week, 29 were wounded and 4 were missing. A Qatari spokesman said he had no casualties to report. Aircraft: In addition to the B-52 bomber lost on its way back to base, an AH-1 Cobra with two aboard and a UH-1 helicopter carrying four crashed over Saudi Arabia. But the U.S. Central Command's briefer in Riyadh did not add them to the daily cumulative count of aircraft losses because, he said, they were believed to be "non-combat-related." The command said combat losses as such stood at 15 American and 7 other coalition aircraft, for a total of 22. IRAQI FORCES Troops: The number of Iraqi prisoners grew to "some 800," according to the United States command. No reliable data on other or military or civilian losses were available. Aircraft: The Riyadh command's count of aircraft destroyed while parked or bunkered rose sharply to at least 99 and as many as 140, since some bunkers sheltered more than one. The number of aircraft shot down stood at 27, and 89 aircraft and crews remained sequestered in Iran.

headline: Journalism vs. Economics
abstract: To the Editor:   "Rethinking Newspapers" (Jan. 6) spurs some observations. We should be explicit about the tension between journalism and economics. Cutbacks are reducing the ability of newspapers to deliver a quality news product. The deeper and more protracted the cuts, the more readers will be lost. A management decision to maintain editorial quality will be particularly painful when newspapers have a negative cash flow.   Newspapers are hypercyclical: they lose sales more quickly than the average industry when the economy softens, and they rebound more rapidly in a period of recovery. When the recovery comes, the 15 percent margins will return. Then the test for newspapers will be whether they invest in essential innovation.   It is easy to forget the decades of family ownership when many daily newspapers kept 40 cents or 50 cents of each sales dollar before taxes. This attracted chain buyers who have since watched the extraordinary margins evaporate because of the debt used to buy the papers, the changing needs of audiences and advertisers and the success of new competitors. JOHN POLICH  New York, N.Y., Jan. 7    The author is a member of the department of communications and media management at Fordham University.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Transportation Displays Inc., New York, an outdoor advertising agency, has established a new division, TDI International, which will be based in London. Elliot H. Rittenband will be its managing director.

headline: About Real Estate; New Rental in Chinatown For Low-Income Elderly
abstract: A building with two developers, two sets of architects, three lenders and two addresses is rising on a city-owned site at Walker, Baxter and Centre Streets in Manhattan's Chinatown after eight years of planning.  Physically, it is a single structure; legally it is two. It is called Chung Pak, or everlasting pine, because in Chinese culture, the pine tree is a symbol of longevity.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Dollar Rent A Car Systems Inc., Los Angeles, a subsidiary of Chrysler Corp., named Gary L. Paxton president and chief executive. * Equitable Capital Management Corp., New York, an investment management subsidiary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, named John D. Miller, an executive vice president, to the new position of chief investment officer. James R. Wilson will replace Mr. Miller as head of the corporate finance department and will add the title of executive vice president.

headline: Article 449091 -- No Title
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation priced $100 million in subordinated debt yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.   The issue of 9 5/8 percent subordinated notes due 2001 was priced at 99.70 to yield 9.672 percent, or about 185 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.   The securities are noncallable and are rated A-3 by Moody's and A- by Standard & Poor's.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Baghdad; 'NIGHT OF HORROR' IN BAGHDAD RAIDS
abstract: Enormous explosions shook Baghdad overnight and again at mid-morning Monday as bombs and cruise missiles pounded the Iraqi capital, correspondents for Western news organizations there reported.    "Columns of black smoke were observed in the Western sector of the city," The Associated Press reported.

headline: Study Finds U.S. Behind In Key Fields
abstract: The United States, which had a commanding lead in high technology a decade ago, is now losing badly to foreign competitors in a number of fields considered crucial, a group of executives said today.   The Council on Competitiveness, a nonprofit organization of leaders in business, education and labor, reviewed America's position in technologies. Ninety-four technologies were reviewed.

headline: Foote, Cone & Belding Reports Gain of 21.1%
abstract: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., Chicago, reported yesterday that its net income for the fourth quarter rose 21.1 percent, to $9.7 million, or 94 cents a share, from 8.0 million, or 78 cents, in the comparable period of 1989. Revenues were up 3.8 percent, to $94.9 million from $91.4 million.

headline: Laidlaw's Shares Plummet by 20%
abstract: The stock of Laidlaw Inc. plunged nearly 20 percent on the Toronto and New York stock exchanges after the company said the recession and higher fuel costs could slash second-quarter earnings as much as 50 percent.    On the Toronto stock exchange, Laidlaw class B shares tumbled $3.25, to $14.875, with 6.48 million shares traded, accounting for about 20 percent of the volume in the market. On Wall Street, Laidlaw shares sank $3, to $12.75, on volume of almost 6.9 million shares. The waste management and school bus operator said fewer acquisitions and management changes in the solid waste division were slowing second-quarter growth.

headline: New Campaign on Buses Urges Help for Homeless
abstract: When the cold blows in, so do pro bono advertisements for the homeless. Transportation Displays Inc., New York, is starting a new national campaign that will appear on the sides of buses.   The ads, which were done in-house at the advertising display company, depict homeless men and women whose features have been painted over to accentuate their expressions and create an almost silk-screen image. The theme line reads, "Homelessness Happens." The ad gives a "900" number that people can call for information on volunteering at local Coalition for the Homeless agencies. Three thousand posters will appear on buses in 30 large cities, beginning Jan. 21.   "T.D.I. is committed to giving back to the community," said William M. Apfelbaum, president and chief executive at the company. "Advertising allows us to create widespread awareness about the homeless so we can really make a difference in cities across the nation."

headline: Profit Posted By Ann Taylor
abstract: Ann Taylor Stores, the New York-based fashion chain of 174 stores, said yesterday that it had earnings of more than $1 million in the year ended Jan. 31, in contrast to a net loss of $11.2 million the year before. Revenues rose 16.1 percent, to $411 million, and same-store sales were up 5.1 percent.

headline: Gorbachev Is Losing Battles at Home
abstract: It is a measure of the fate of Mikhail S. Gorbachev that tonight, as he was attempting difficult Persian Gulf peace negotiations, a throng of tens of thousands of protest-minded Soviet citizens marched past the Kremlin walls intent on spelling out his failures as a leader at home.     They never mentioned the gulf. Instead, they faulted Mr. Gorbachev's attempt at tighter Kremlin control of the nation through soldier-police patrols, increased censorship, and a renewed dose of economic Communism.

headline: The Man Behind Munich
abstract: Saleh Khalef founded the Black September terrorist movement, which engineered the massacre of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich and the assassination of the United States Ambassador to the Sudan in 1973.   In recent years, he served as Mr. Arafat's intelligence and security chief, said Vincent M. Cannistraro, a former senior counterterrorism official for the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: People
abstract: * James F. Borcherdt has been promoted to creative director at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, St. Louis. * Julie S. Newhall has been promoted to vice president of communications for the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, New York. Martin J. Cody was named vice president and general manager of its Chicago office. * Lori Zelikow Florio was named publisher of New Woman magazine.

headline: Welcome Progress on Pollution
abstract: To the Editor:   The article "Hutchinson No Longer Holds Its Nose," Feb. 3, was a constructive account of the Pollution Prevention Pays program of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company. The article belies what seems to be an implicit assumption of many news media -- that pollution is news but pollution control is not news. JERRY J. JASINOWSKI  Washington, Feb. 6

headline: Tokyo Stocks Decline
abstract: Stock prices in Tokyo were down slightly today at the end of the trading session. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 shares was down 234.73 points, or 0.89 percent, to 26,104.65.

headline: A Year in the Life of a Troubled Bank
abstract: Dec. 15, 1989: Bank of New England announced that its bad loans would rise to $1.6 billion for 1989, that it might rescind a 34-cents-a-share dividend and that it was considering a merger and sale of assets.    Dec. 22: Bank of New England canceled the dividend.    Dec. 26: Walter J. Connolly Jr. said he would relinquish his position as chief executive "when the board has selected a candidate" to replace him.    Jan. 17, 1990: Shares fell on fears that Federal regulators would delay or stop the rumored sale of the bank's subsidiary operations to the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group.    Jan. 19: Bank put its 1989 loss at $1.05 billion and its fourth-quarter loss at about $1.2 billion. Non-performing loans were estimated at $2.5 billion. A plan to sell $6 billion in assets was unveiled.    Jan. 26: Bank announced that it had begun to borrow from the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. The board requested the resignation of Mr. Connolly. H. Ridgley Bullock was named as interim chairman.    Jan. 29: Citicorp bought the bank's consumer credit card business for $828 million.    Jan 31: Bank completed sale of the United States portion of McCullagh Leasing to GE Capital for $360 million.    Feb. 8: The bank revised its agreement to sell its Banc New England Leasing unit and $500 million of the lease portfolio to Bank of Tokyo for $92.5 million.    Feb. 15: Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce bought about $1 billion of the portfolio of the bank's communications lending group.   Feb. 22: Bank reported $1.11 billion loss for 1989.    March 1: In an agreement with Federal regulators, the bank agreed to increase its capital and reduce its assets so that capital equals 3 percent of assets by the end of May and 5 percent by year-end.    March 9: Lawrence K. Fish named chairman and chief executive.    April 4: Bank said it would cut 5,600 jobs by the end of the year.    April 27: Bank reported a first-quarter loss of $46.6 million.    June 15: At the annual meeting, Mr. Fish told shareholders that deposits had stabilized.    July 23: Saying it was unable to reach an agreement on an acceptable price, the bank took Maine National Bank of fthe block.    Aug. 3: Bank reported a second-quarter loss of $33.3 million. Non-performing assets rose to $2.78 billion, from $2.67 billion.    Aug. 20: Share prices hit a low after Ted DiMauro, a Massachusetts Congressional candidate, announced erroneously that the bank would be siezed by Federal regulators.    Sept. 4: Citizens Financial Group of Providence, R.I., agreed to buy most of the bank's Rhode Island operation for $75 million.    Oct. 19: Bank reported a third-quarter loss of $123.2 million. Bad loans rose $65 million to $2.84 billion in the quarter.    Dec. 20: Bondholders proposed a debt-for-equity swap that would give bondholders 92 percent of the company's common stock in exchange for $705 million in debentures.      Jan 4 1991: The bank estimated its fourth-quarter loss at $450 million and said non-performing assets would rise $500 million to $3.3 billion. The news led depositors to withdraw about $1 billion.    Jan. 6: Bank of New England's three major units were declared insolvent and taken over by Federal regulators, who injected $750 million into two of the units.     Jan 7: The bank holding company filed for bankruptcy. Bank's subsidiaries were reopened under F.D.I.C. control.

headline: Saab Is Closing Plant After Venture's Loss
abstract: Saab Automobile said today that it was closing its 18-month-old model production plant after the joint venture with the General Motors Corporation suffered an $840 million loss in 1990.   Some of the 770 factory workers and 100 administrative personnel will be transferred to Saab's aircraft division. Others will be given the opportunity to move from Malmo, in southern Sweden, to the Trollhattan auto plant in western Sweden.

headline: Rethinking Newspapers
abstract: Times are tough for the newspaper industry. Advertising is in a slump some analysts are calling the worst in 20 years. Profits are down substantially at many papers. Vacancies are being left unfilled and budgets are being squeezed if not slashed. Almost everywhere -- especially in the Northeast, where papers have been hit hardest -- the mood is black.   Perhaps because the business has been so lucrative for so long, the painful decline in advertising caught many in the industry unprepared, prompting a wave of anxiety about the future.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Environment; Winds Slowing Gulf Oil Spill, Keeping It From Saudi Coast
abstract: Saudi and Western officials said today that strong southerly winds had delayed the progress of a huge Persian Gulf oil spill, keeping it away from the Saudi coast and the country's largest single source of fresh water.   As teams of oil-spill control specialists scrambled to place floating booms and skimmers in front of seawater intakes for desalting plants, oil refineries and power plants, a Saudi official announced that a planeload of booms sent by Japan is expected to arrive on Tuesday, with a second shipment due two days later.

headline: Stocks Down in Tokyo
abstract: Stock prices declined today n Japan, and traders said they took decline on Wall Street on Tuesday as a cue to adjust their positions after five days of advances. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks was down 309.10 points, or 1.16 percent, to 26,418.32, at the close of trading.

headline: Best Products Seeks Chapter 11 Protection
abstract: The Best Products Company, a retailer whose shoppers buy from catalogues at stores famed for their bold architecture, sought refuge yesterday under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.    The privately owned Best, which operates 195 catalogue showrooms around the country, said it had failed to reach an out-of-court agreement with its lenders. By filing for Chapter 11, the Richmond-based comany hopes it can keep operating while it works out its debts.

headline: I.B.M. Credit Sues Leasing Company
abstract: The I.B.M. Credit Corporation has sued a competitor, Comdisco Inc., accusing the computer-leasing company of misappropriating components that had been leased to customers. In a lawsuit filed in Delaware, I.B.M. Credit said Comdisco had persuaded its customers to allow them to remove parts from mainframes made by the International Business Machines Corporation and exchange them for parts from other vendors. Comdisco then would resell the parts, in several cases winning bids for contracts in competition with the big computer maker.    I.B.M. Credit is seeking an injunction forcing Comdisco, based in Rosemont, Ill., to halt the practice. It is also asking for unspecified damages and is trying to compel the leasing company to identify profits it has made from selling I.B.M. parts.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corp. is offering $105 million in 7.42 percent consolidated systemwide bonds due 1994 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Co. * First Security Corp., Salt Lake City, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $150 million in senior subordinated debt securities through First Boston Corp. * Kaufman & Broad Home Corp., Los Angles, said it had increased its line of credit to $265 million from $200 million. * Loews Corp., New York, says that on Feb. 1 it plans to redeem all outstanding 9 3/4 percent subordinated notes due 1993 at a price of 100. Of the $200 million of notes issued December 1985, about $193 million are currently outstanding. * Southern California Gas Co., Los Angeles-based subsidiary of Pacific Enterprises, has filed for $175 million in first mortgage bonds. * Union Pacific Corp., Bethlehem, Pa., has filed for up to $500 million in debt securities. Ratings  * Beverly Enterprise Inc.'s subordinated debt rating has been increased to B-, from CCC+, by Standard & Poor's. The nursing home chain is based in Fort Smith, Ark.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    The F.C.C. proposed rules for "900" numbers aimed at preventing fraud and deceit by telephone services that provide information and services through them.  [ Page A1. ]   Business sales slackened 1.2 percent in January, helping to increase inventories by 0.4 percent, the Government said.  [ D2. ]

headline: Retailer Seeks Bankruptcy
abstract: Enstar Specialty Retail, which operates more than 700 clothing stores in the South, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday.   The company is a subsidiary of the Enstar Group, whose chairman was convicted last year in connection with the investigation of the financier Michael R. Milken.    The filing under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code includes Enstar Specialty's Shoe City subsidiary, which operates 373 stores, and its Amret subsidiary, which operates 359 Bargain Town, Simply 6 and Max 10 discount clothing stores.   Enstar Specialty listed assets of $309 million and liabilities of $70 million in the filing in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Montgomery.    In November, Enstar Specialty Retail reported a $9 million operating loss for the third quarter and a $10.1 million operating loss for the first nine months of 1990.   In October, the company's chairman, Richard Grassgreen, resigned. He subsequently pleaded guilty to Federal securities and mail fraud charges stemming from the investigation of Mr. Milken, the former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert's "junk bond" department who helped finance Enstar Group in the 1980's.

headline: Raytheon Gets Lift From Profits and Patriot
abstract: The Raytheon Company, already basking in the success of its Patriot missiles, announced record sales and earnings today for the sixth straight year. Employees of the $9 billion military contractor will have little time to celebrate though, because the Government asked the company today to step up production of the anti-missile missile system to support the war in the Persian Gulf.   Col. Bruce Garnett, the Army's program manager for the Patriot in Huntsville, Ala., said that the military had a considerable number of the missiles but that "more is better than less in this kind of business." Colonel Garnett insisted that the request did not indicate a crisis in the number of missile systems available and declined to say how many Patriots were ready to be used.

headline: Market Place; Traders Defy Forecasts Again
abstract: MANY expected a war to bring panic. Instead, the reaction verged on euphoria.   Whether that reaction can last is likely to depend largely on the course of war news from Iraq. Yesterday, the markets treated Saddam Hussein as a proven loser, unable even to cause significant damage to Saudi oilfields.

headline: Unease About Rate Parity and the New Dollar
abstract: You can listen to what Wall Street says -- or you can watch what it does.   The talk on the Street these days is that investors are going to keep buying stocks because they are focusing on the prosperous post-recession paradise that will eventually arrive, courtesy of the Federal Reserve Board's stimulative efforts. Thus, the Dow has continued its climb, closing the pre-holiday week on Thursday at 2,913.86, about 55 points higher than the prior week's close.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    A brief, mild recession? That's the predominant view, but making economic predictions seems particularly hazardous these days. The conventional wisdom, subscribed to by the White House, is that the worst is over, and numbers abound to support that view. But pessimists point to the extremely high debt of American families, businesses and governments and a banking system more fragile than at any time since the 1930's.  [ Page 1. ]   Prices paid to American producers fell 0.6 percent in December, the first decline since April, the Labor Department reported. The decline, the biggest since 1986, pulled the advance for the year back to 5.6 percent, or 3.2 percent when the gyrating energy component is excluded.  [ 31. ]   Seidman said he hoped the Bank of New England would be sold in three to four months. On a visit to the scene of the action in Boston, he added that several more potential buyers had emerged.  [ 31. ]   No single statistic can foretell which banks will fail, but from the welter of financial reports banks issue, government and private analysts can glean strong hints about which are the shakiest. While most bank failures involve small institutions, analysts say some large banks are in serious trouble.  [ 31. ]   U.S. oil consumption fell in 1990, the first year-to-year drop in seven years, driven by war fears, recession and the weather, the American Petroleum Institute said. Domestic oil production fell to its lowest level since 1961.  [ 31. ]   The International Energy Agency adopted an emergency plan to bolster oil supplies by releasing two million barrels a day from government reserves if war begins in the Persian Gulf.  [ 31. ]   A judge dismissed 12 fraud counts against Keating and three Lincoln associates, citing technical problems with amended charges filed by the prosecution, but left 34 counts intact.  [ 33. ] Companies    The talk of the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas has been the increasingly likely war between Sony's and Philips' versions of the new generation of cassette recorder.  [ 31. ]   Pan Am got access to $50 million of the $150 million loan that was authorized by a bankruptcy judge. The money, from a bridge loan arranged by Bankers Trust and United Airlines, is aimed at keeping Pan Am flying until it can complete the sale of its London routes to United.  [ 32. ]   A judge shaved $36 million off Polaroid's award in its patent infringement suit against Kodak. The original award had been $909.4 million, considerably less than the $1.5 billion to $2 billion many analysts had expected.  [ 33. ]  Markets    Stocks edged ahead for their second straight gain, but activity continued to be extremely light. The Dow rose 2.73 points, to 2,501.49, but for the week it lost 64.60.  [ 34. ]   A rally late in the day helped long-term Treasury securities erase a good part of their earlier losses.  [ 34. ]   The dollar finished mixed in subdued trading, as investors awaited Mideast developments. Gold prices advanced.  [ 40. ]   Oil prices fell in slow action as traders drew their breath and waited for Persian Gulf news. Crude fell 42 cents, to $27.29. The week's gain was $2.39.  [ 40. ]  Today's Columns    Many loyal employees who hold company stock have seen their nest eggs cracked in bankruptcies. Your Money.  [ 32. ]   A minute electrical jolt takes the itch out of bug bites. The battery-powered device that delivers the jolt was developed by a Minneapolis inventor. Patents.  [ 32. ]

headline: Paley Estate Sells Shares
abstract: The estate of William S. Paley, the founder of CBS, said announced today that it had sold 250,000 shares of CBS common stock for $180 a share.   The sale on Dec. 5 was disclosed in a filing with the Securities ad Exchange Commission. Paley died Oct. 26.   The shares were sold in a block trade but not through a stock exchange. The filing did not disclose who bought the shares.   The estate still holds more than 1.3 million shares, or about 5.8 percent of CBS's common stock.   Previously, CBS had said it intended to buy 10.5 million shares of its common stock for $190 a share. The tender offer for those shares is set to expire Jan. 22.   CBS's shares fell $1.625 today, to $167.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Steinway Changing Amid Tradition
abstract: Steinway occupies a unique place in the world of music, a near-monopoly both on the concert stage and in the public image of quality. There is a sense that the 12,000 parts of a Steinway grand piano, held together with solid brass fittings and 26 types of glue, is a work of art.    But in Steinway's factory in Astoria, Queens, where workers use 100-year-old equipment and methods that date back even farther to turn out 2,500 instruments a year, managers are wrestling with a difficult transition to modern manufacturing.

headline: Technology; The Tough Business of Recycling Newsprint
abstract: As newspapers rethink their futures and search for ways to cut costs, increase readership and prevent further erosion of their advertising revenues, new government regulations confront them with one more dilemma: recycling their newsprint.    So far, eight states have imposed taxes or regulations to encourage newsprint recycling while others have pressed publishers into voluntary agreements to increase its usage. According the American Newspaper Publishers Association, newsprint producers are committed to investments totaling $1.5 billion to more than double the output of recycled newsprint to 5 million tons by 1993.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Coltec Industries, New York, an aerospace and automotive supplier, named Michael J. Burdulis president of its Central Moloney Transformer division. Klemens B. Schoenfelder was named president of industrial sealing products, a unit of the company's Garlock Mechanical Packing division. * Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., New York, appointed Peter Schementi vice president of management information systems. * A. B. Dick Co., Chicago, a maker of copying equipment and a unit of General Electric Co. P.L.C., London, appointed James L. Bast president and director of the company.  * Foster Wheeler Energy Corp., a unit of Foster Wheeler Corp., Clinton, N.J., named Mani Seshamani vice president of commercial operations. * GFT USA Corp., New York, a clothing distributor and subsidiary of GFT S.p.A., Turin, Italy, appointed Elayne M. Garofolo senior vice president of corporate communications and image development. * GTE Corp., Stamford, Conn., named Ernst A. Burri president of its Compania Dominicana de Telefonos unit in Irving, Tex. * Sheldahl Inc., Northfield, Minn., which produces electronic components, named James E. Donaghy president and chief executive, succeeding James S. Womack, who continues as chairman.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview SAUDIS RECAPTURE GHOST TOWN; ALLIES BOMB NEW IRAQI COLUMN; A 36-HOUR STRUGGLE
abstract: As Saudi troops backed by American marines drove Iraqi invaders from the deserted coastal town of Khafji near the Kuwaiti border today after a 36-hour struggle, allied bombers pounded a 10-mile Iraqi armored column apparently headed for Saudi Arabia.    Almost two days after the fighting near Khafji began, Iraqi artillery was still shelling the area, and door-to-door searches were under way in the shell-pocked town in an effort to root out isolated Iraqi snipers. There were strong signs that another, bigger Iraqi assault might be in the making.

headline: Chrysler Auto Loans Back $600.8 Million of Securities
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation yesterday priced $600.8 million in certificates backed by auto and light-truck loans through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.    Sales of such asset-backed securities have picked up recently, as issuers hurry to complete transactions before the end of the first quarter, many securities dealers say. Issuers generally try to package assets as securitiies and remove them from their balance sheets by the end of the quarter.

headline: In Kuwait, Ramadan Has a Bitter Taste
abstract: On the first day of Ramadan, the Muslim holy month of daylight fasting and prayer, Kuwaitis were busy Sunday standing in half-mile-long lines, waiting for bread, rice, sugar and oil.    The more fortunate among them with connections to Government officials got permission to leave the country and drive down to Saudi Arabia, where they could properly observe this most important of Muslim holidays. Some came back loaded with enough sweets, meat and fish to cook a decent meal.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Germany; Kohl Draws Rising Charges Of an Insufficient War Role
abstract: Less than two months after Helmut Kohl's overwhelming election as Chancellor of the newly united Germany, his Government is being besieged by criticism for its response to the Persian Gulf war.   Germany's uncertainty about how fully to take part in the anti-Iraq coalition has raised a storm of protest. Many commentators, as well as some foreign leaders, have raised questions about Germany's reliability as an ally.

headline: Security Pacific Changing Role
abstract: The Security Pacific Corporation announced yesterday that it intended to give up its primary dealership in Government securities and restructure its activities into a regional, non-primary dealer operation.    The bank, which had been rumored to be seeking a buyer for its primary dealership for some time, said the dismantling of its merchant bank, announced late last year, had eliminated the need for a full-service primary dealership.    The regional operation will involve the distribution of Treasury and Federal agency securities, money market instruments and other derivative products, Security Pacific said.    Designated by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, primary dealers of Government securities make markets in those issues. The Federal Reserve conducts its open market operations exclusively through the primary dealers.

headline: Managing; Welcoming Those With Disabilities
abstract: FOUR years ago, Honeywell Inc. formed the Council of Honeywell Employees With Disabilities. The committee spent much of 1989 cataloguing what sort of physical accommodations such employees need, and much of 1990 helping Honeywell management put them in place.    At the Schwabb Rehabilitation Center in Chicago, a blind woman, using a computer that prints in braille, has for five years served as liaison with the community. Down the hall, a woman whose arms are paralyzed manages patient follow-up, typing reports with an instrument she holds in her mouth.

headline: The Executive Life; 'It Was a Dark And Stormy Night . . .'
abstract: "That first evening in Kuala Lumpur, she met an Amsterdamian student at the Digger Club. After two bottles of George Hermitage, they stole into the lush tropical garden behind the club. The moonlight filtered through the palms. Amanda sighed."

headline: Thai Officers Say They'll Try To Set Vote Within 6 Months
abstract: The country's military commanders, who put an end to another Thai experiment with democracy on Saturday with a bloodless coup, said today that they would attempt to hold new elections under a modified constitution within six months.    At a news conference in the army's auditorium, Gen. Suchinda Kraprayoon, the army Chief of Staff, sought to portray the overthrow and detention of the elected Prime Minister, Chatichai Choonhavan, as an exercise in protecting democracy and the monarchy.

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports A Profit in 4th Quarter
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage, reported higher fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, but that compared with the fourth quarter of 1989, when the firm took a large restructuring charge.   The brokerage earned $30.3 million, or 23 cents a share, on revenues of $2.81 billion, compared with a $361.8 million loss, on revenues of $2.78 billion. During the quarter, the firm took a pretax charge of $470 million to reduce the size of its operations.   For the year, Merrill earned $191.9 million, or $1.59 a share, on revenues of $11.21 billion. This compares with a 1989 loss of $213.4 million, on revenues of $11.31 billion.

headline: War Summary
abstract: MORE CIVILIANS KILLED, IRAQ SAYS  Iraq asserted that allied planes killed 150 civilians in a marketplace in the city of Fallujah, west of Baghdad. A senior allied commander said a laser-guided bomb had strayed from its target and hit the crowded market. Two American fighter-bombers, attacking entrenched positions of Iraq's Republican Guard, were shot down by surface-to-air missiles. BUSH'S COMMENTS ON HUSSEIN President Bush's call for the Iraqi military to overthrow Saddam Hussein reflects the extent to which Mr. Hussein's downfall is a key consideration in the Administration's Persian Gulf strategy. Mr. Bush was prompted to issue the call after watching televised scenes of jubilation in Baghdad at the possibility of peace, concluding that the Iraqi people were ripe for such an appeal.  War Losses Allied Forces  Troops: Yesterday, one airman died in a non-combat mission and two were reported missing in Kuwait. No new totals were released yesterday by the U.S. Central Command, but the latest previous toll of American was 62, including 14 killed, 12 wounded, 28 missing and eight confirmed prisoners of war.  Aircraft: Two American A-10 aircraft were shot down yesterday, the U.S. Central command in Riyadh reported. At the same time, the command declared that an EF-111 lost several days ago was a noncombat-related loss, even though it was returning from a combat mission. In addition, the command said an F-16C crashed during an instrument approach in Saudi Arabia. Such "non-combat" losses are not included in the daily tally of combat losses, which yesterday's briefer placed at 29 coalition aircraft, 20 of them American.  Iraqi Forces Troops: The American briefer put the number of P.O.W.'s at around 1,300.  Aircraft: The briefer also reported that an Iraqi helicopter was shot down, bringing to 42 the number of enemy aircraft brought down in air-to-air combat -- 36 fixed-wing craft and six helicopters.  Feb 17, 1991

headline: Mayors Press Congress For Control Over Cable
abstract: More than 600 mayors and local officials asked Congress today for legislation that they said would increase competitiveness among operators of local cable television franchises.    "Our constituents have come to us with countless complaints concerning, among other things, poor signal quality, the failure of cable operators to respond to service requests within a reasonable time period and, of course, dramatic rate increases," the 616 local officials said in a letter sent to every member of the Congress.

headline: Bush, Noting a Hussein 'Stiff-Arm,' Finds Hopes for Peace Waning
abstract: Accusing President Saddam Hussein of giving him a "total stiff-arm," President Bush said today that he was losing hope for a peaceful settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis.   "Nothing I saw today, nothing, leads me to believe that this man is going to be reasonable," Mr. Bush said at a White House news conference after the meeting in Geneva between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq.

headline: In Defense of Lotus in Japan . . .
abstract: To the Editor:   The Forum article "Japan's Mythical Trade Surplus" (Dec. 9), an interview with Bill Totten, author of "Don't Blame Japan" and president and founder of Ashisuto, a company that sells software in Japan, contains the assertion that large American software companies "tend to be arrogant or tend not to make their products fit the needs of the Japanese." Based on other comments made by Mr. Totten, I assume the Lotus Development Corporation was one of the companies to which he was referring.   Let me set the record straight. After almost three years of painstaking development work to insure the product met specific requirements of Japanese users, Lotus introduced 1-2-3/J in 1986. Within a month, it was the best-selling software package in Japan. According to Nikkei Sangyo Shimbun, a daily business newspaper in Japan, 1-2-3/J has been the best-selling spreadsheet in Japan since its introduction. The product has won numerous awards, including being the first non-Japanese product to win the prestigious Nikkei Award for creative excellence.   Lotus has 120 employees in Japan, all but one of whom is Japanese, and it's likely Japan will be the company's second-largest market in 1991, trailing only the United States.   For someone who claims to have adopted the Japanese culture, Mr. Totten's inaccurate and specious comments are uncharacteristic of Japanese business etiquette. RICHARD ECKEL  Cambridge, Mass., Dec. 14    The writer is senior manager, corporate press relations, of the Lotus Development Corporation.

headline: Article 366091 -- No Title
abstract: In what appeared to be the largest payment ever involving a violation of Federal pension law, the United Steelworkers of America has won a $415 million settlement from the Continental Can Company.    The settlement stems from a ruling in a civil suit that Continental Can, which is based in Stamford, Conn., engaged in an elaborate, covert scheme to deny the steelworkers their pensions by laying off the workers just before they qualified for retirement benefits.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION -- 3 P.M.  Economic and Social Council POPULATION COMMISSION -- 10 A.M.  POPULATION COMMISSION, PREPARATORY COMMITTEE FOR 1994 INTERNATIONAL MEETING ON POPULATION -- 3 P.M.

headline: FOREIGN RESIDENTS FLEE SAUDI TOWN
abstract: Fearing that Iraqi missiles could begin hitting this town and its important airport two days from now, Dhahran's large Asian population has begun to flee.    Mobs of would-be passengers have been scrambling for tickets to any foreign destination, sometimes resorting to under-the-table financial inducements to secure seats aboard special evacuation flights organized by the Saudi and Pakistani national airlines.

headline: Mandela Asks Talks With All Parties
abstract: The African National Congress called today for a conference of all political parties in South Africa to ease the writing of a new constitution that would transfer political power to the nation's black majority.    As the Congress described the conference, it, would set out principles for framing a new Constitution, determine the composition of a drafting body, such as a constitutional assembly, and establish an interim government to replace white minority rule until a new Government was democratically elected.

headline: Leftists Run in Salvadoran Elections
abstract: Pedro Pablo Mendez rose before dawn today, put on a clean shirt and his straw hat and rode a truck into town to carry the banner for supporters of leftist guerrillas in the electorial race for Mayor of Victoria.    Mr. Mendez, whose backers walked two to three hours each on steep dirt roads to cast their votes, lives nearby on the Santa Marta communal farm, to which several thousand relatives and followers of the guerrillas have returned over the last three years after living as refugees in Honduras since the beginning of the 1980's.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Memorex Telex, to Long, Haymes & Carr Advertising, Winston-Salem, N.C., for its Network Systems Business group, with an undisclosed budget.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Eric Mower Acquires Blair
abstract: Eric Mower & Associates of Syracuse has acquired Blair Advertising, a Rochester-based agency, from the Omnicom Group, for undisclosed terms.  Blair, which has $22 million in billings, was part of BBDO before BBDO came under the Omnicom umbrella. The new agency will be known as Blair/ Eric Mower & Associates. Eric Mower will serve as chairman and chief executive, with John F. Kraushaar as vice chairman and chief operating officer.   "This is part of a long-term strategy in upstate New York, and we've been having discussions with Blair for the last several years," Mr. Mower said. "We've had an ongoing interest in being in that market because it makes for an excellent trading area in the future."  In the last year, Mower formed LKW/Eric Mower & Associates Inc., an agency in Buffalo. "With our three companies, we can now offer a fairly substantial level of service to a much larger level of clients," Mr. Mower said.

headline: PRETORIA'S INQUIRY IMPLICATES ONLY 1
abstract: A judicial inquiry into the death of 42 blacks in Sebokeng township last September ended today with the judge announcing that he could determine responsibility for only one of the deaths.   The jurist, Justice Eddie Stafford, ending an investigation that lasted nearly six weeks, said a 22-year-old soldier, Rifleman John Booysen, had fired without orders, killing one of the victims.

headline: 2D HOSTAGE KILLED BY COLOMBIAN RING
abstract: Officials said today that cocaine traffickers had killed the kidnapped sister of a former presidential aide who helped plan a large-scale anti-drug crackdown.   Medical examiners confirmed that the body of a woman found a week ago in the Colombian capital was that of Marina Montoya. She was 65 years old and was kidnapped on Sept. 19.

headline: Russian in Iraq, Soviets Tell U.S.
abstract: Soviet officials informed the Bush Administration today that Moscow's senior Middle East envoy, Yevgeny M. Primakov, would enter Iraq today by land from Iran, but a Pentagon official said tonight that he was not aware of any special precautions taken to protect the diplomat from allied bombing.    A State Department official said the Soviet Embassy in Washington had provided American officials with a general itinerary for Mr. Primikov, who arrived in Baghdad today for a meeting with President Saddam Hussein expected on Tuesday. The official said Mr. Primakov flew first to the Iranian capital, Teheran, and then proceeded to the Iraqi frontier, which he crossed by car.    The information was passed to the Pentagon. An Administration official said, "They gave us an itinerary, but by the time they did, he already was in the country." The official added, "The Soviets did not ask us for safe passage, they just informed us he was going to be there."

headline: Business and Health; Guarding Medical Confidentiality
abstract: Growing concern about the cost and quality of health care is prompting changes that are eroding confidentiality rules that have long protected both hospital patients and doctors. Hospital records are increasingly available to outside reviewers. Employers and insurers, who ultimately pay many medical bills, insist that their representatives often need to see information that used to be closely guarded.    Laws and the courts in most states still guarantee confidentiality unless the patient authorizes disclosure. But there are often large loopholes. California, for example, has a Confidentiality of Medical Information Act, which permits examination of patient records by an insurer, employer or health plan to determine responsiblity for paying for services.

headline: Walesa Election Plan Rejected by Parliament
abstract: Poland's Parliament today rejected a plea by President Lech Walesa for immediate elections and voted to delay the balloting until the fall.   In a sharp rebuff to the founder of the Solidarity union, the lower house voted 314 to 18 with 40 abstentions to delay action on a draft electoral law. It rejected Mr. Walesa's plea for the immediate dissolution of the house and for new elections on May 26.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: United Nations; U.N. Council Meets and Sees Peace Chances Fade
abstract: Half a year after first calling for Iraq and Kuwait to settle their differences peacefully, the United Nations Security Council watched the last chances for a negotiated settlement slip away today as it held what was likely to be its final meeting before the start of the land war in the Persian Gulf.    The Soviet Union, clearly anxious to salvage something from its recent peace efforts, pressed the Council to devise a new peace proposal that would somehow marry the six-point plan that the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariz Aziz, accepted in Moscow on Friday with the very different terms laid down by the United States and its allies.

headline: U.S. Battle Plan: Massive Air Strikes
abstract: An American-led air campaign against Iraq and Iraqi forces in Kuwait would involve around-the-clock bombing strikes against military and industrial targets that could last several weeks, according to military experts.    In describing how a massive aerial assault would operate at the opening of hostilities, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee said on Tuesday that if war occurred, the international coalition would attack in phases, beginning with unrelenting bombardment.

headline: Frequent-Flier Brokers Barred
abstract: A Federal judge has prohibited three companies from buying or brokering American Airlines' frequent- flier coupons, which are not supposed to be bought or sold by passengers.   United States District Judge David K. Winder issued an order to stop Platinum World Travel, Coupon Connection and Texas Budget Flights, doing business as Texas Traveler, from buying or selling AAdvantage coupons.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Reacting to War    The opening of hostilities pushed up oil prices by as much as $7 a barrel in cash trading. But some large U.S. oil companies quickly said they would not change retail gasoline prices.  [ Page D1. ]   In Tokyo today, the yen soared against the dollar and stock prices moved higher within hours of the first reports that air raids had begun.  [ D1. ]   If the Persian Gulf war turns out to be brief, it will test one of the great assumptions about the national economy: that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait precipitated the recession.  [ D1. ]   It is uncertain how the financial markets will react today, but traders indicated that a heavy selloff of stocks looked less likely than was originally feared.  [ D1. ]   The three broadcast networks found their images as news leaders damaged by early dominance of the coverage by CNN.  [ D10. ] The Economy    Industrial output posted a surprisingly big decline, according to a Government report.  [ D8. ]   Consumer prices rose 0.3 percent in December, the Labor Department said.  [ D8. ]   Total sales by businesses fell 1.2 percent in November, helping to push inventories up 0.3 percent, the Government said.  [ D8. ]   Insurance company executives in the U.S. predict their losses will be small now that war has erupted in the Persian Gulf.  [ D8. ] Companies    A.T.& T. has received a strong show of support for its takeover bid for NCR, reporting that it had received tenders for about 70 percent of the computer maker's common stock.  [ D1. ]   AMR reported a loss of $215.1 million in the fourth quarter, the worst quarterly loss in company history.  [ D2. ]   Ameritech announced a sharp drop in profits, and Wall Street analysts greeted the report as a poor omen for other results.  [ D5. ]   GlenFed said it would add to loan-loss reserves, sell some assets, freeze management salaries and suspend its dividend.  [ D10. ]   Digital Equipment reported that profits fell 28 percent, but analysts were pleased.  [ D5. ]   Primerica reported that it had earned $98.8 million, or 89 cents a share, in the fourth quarter.  [ D12. ]   Armco took a step toward becoming a bigger force in the stainless-steel market by agreeing to buy Cyclops.  [ D5. ]   The Daily News threatened to close down soon or seek a buyer unless it stemmed heavy financial losses.  [ B1. ]  Markets    U.S. stocks defied war fears and actually rose a little, just hours before shooting started. The Dow rose 18.32, to 2,508.91.  [ D12. ]   Comments by Greenspan were the main cause of a slight drop in the prices of Treasury securities.  [ D18. ]   Currency trading was expected to be volatile today, traders said, after reports that the Fed and the Bank of Japan were selling dollars in Asia in an effort to calm markets.  [ D19. ]   Gold prices climbed nearly $7 an ounce in trading on cash markets around the world after war erupted, slipping back to register gains of about $1.50 above its New York close at $403.  [ D19. ]  Today's Columns    Just hours before Pan Am filed for bankruptcy protection, management was still not certain it would have enough money to avoid liquidation. Talking Deals.  [ D2. ]   Some analysts regard Nestle as a haven for investors amid the current tension and economic slowdown, even though it has been hurt by the weak dollar and U.S. competition. Market Place.  [ D12. ]   Omnicom is negotiating to buy a minority stake in Abbott Mead Vickers. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D10. ]

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Campaign by Bozell Wins Esquire Contest
abstract: Bozell Advertising in New York has won Esquire magazine's competition for a public education campaign on behalf of the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence.  The ad, which will begin in the March issue of Esquire, depicts a coffin with flowers on the end of it under the line "He beat her 150 times. She only got flowers once."  The ad bested submissions from 32 agencies, and it may run in other publications throughout the year. Judges in the contest included Deborah Norville, the co-host of NBC's "Today" program; a Manhattan Assistant District Attorney, Linda Fairstein, and the Esquire publisher, Randy Jones.

headline: IN OTHER SECTIONS
abstract: INDICTED FOR IRAQI LOANS A Federal grand jury indicted three former officials of the Atlanta branch of an Italian bank and four Iraqis on fraud charges involving more than $4 billion in loans to Iraq. Business Day, page D1.   NEW FLIGHT SCHEDULES Some of the biggest airlines to the Middle East are moving to restore service to cities in the region whose flights were suspended during the war. Page D2.

headline: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Latvia; A GORBACHEV CALL LIFTS LATVIA HOPE
abstract: As violent harassment apparently inspired by Moscow continued, a phone call from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev raised hopes today that a brutal crackdown by Moscow here might be avoided.    The Soviet leader spoke with Anatolijs Gorbunovs, President of the republic, late Wednesday night and stressed his wish that Soviet military forces here not be a destabilizing factor, according to the republic's account of the conversation.

headline: Poland Reaches an Accord To Get Monetary Fund Aid
abstract: Poland said today that it had reached a tentative accord on a crucial three-year pact with the International Monetary Fund, and its Prime Minister asked members of the Solidarity trade union for their help in maintaining "social peace."    The Prime Minister, Jan Krzystof Bielecki, bluntly told Solidarity members gathered for their annual convention in the northern city of Gdansk that Poland's transition to capitalism stood no chance without Western aid, which depends on imposing fiscal austerity.

headline: Seeking a Place on Santa's List
abstract: Hide this newspaper, Mom and Dad, and blindfold the children. Here is what Santa Claus is bringing next Christmas, or at least that is what the toy industry hopes.    Formally, the 88th Annual American International Toy Fair, which opens this morning, is a 10-day exhibition of the hottest new toys by nearly 1,400 toy makers for more than 20,000 buyers from retailers like Toys "R" Us, Wal-Mart and Macy's.

headline: A Year Later, Signs That Deng Guides China
abstract: After a year of playing with his grandchildren during a quiet retirement, Deng Xiaoping appears to have returned to the political scene in recent weeks to direct basic elements of national policy and to give a boost to the leaders he favors.   Mr. Deng, who is 86 years old and frail, has appeared in public only once recently, while voting in municipal elections at the end of December. But he has contributed his calligraphy to many organizations recently, possibly as a way of reasserting his primacy, and he is believed to have issued crucial political instructions recently on important issues.

headline: Goodrich's Earnings Off By 48 Percent
abstract: The B. F. Goodrich Company, a producer of plastic resins, specialty chemicals and aerospace components, said yesterday that its net income fell nearly 48 percent in the fourth quarter, as sales from some specialty chemical products were hurt by higher costs for petrochemical-based raw materials.   Goodrich said that its net income dropped to $14.1 million, or 47 cents a share, from $27 million, or 98 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1989. Sales for the quarter were up slightly, to $575.8 million, from $573.7 million in the period a year earlier.

headline: Transcript of Baghdad's Cease-Fire Order
abstract: Following is the transcript of a statement by an Iraqi military spokesman announcing a cease-fire order to Iraqi troops. The statement was broadcast on Baghdad radio and translated from Arabic by The Associated Press.    The aggressors imagined that through the Iraqi command decision to withdraw from Kuwait they were able to put our armed forces in a position that is contrary to the military and manly values for which the men of the mother of battles are reputed in this great showdown.

headline: Another Bidder Woos Child World
abstract: A third bidder for Child World Inc., the troubled toy retailer, emerged yesterday, but it is likely to encounter the same hurdles confronting the second bidder: courting Child World's largest shareholder and the company's suppliers and banks. Both bidders are trying to unravel an earlier deal between Child World and WC Acquisition. The two companies signed a letter of intent last week.    The latest bid is by Isaac Perlmutter, owner of Toy Biz Inc., a New York-based licensee of Batman toys, said Lawrence Mittman, Mr. Perlmutter's lawyer. Mr. Perlmutter plans a $20 million cash infusion for Child World. He is also offering the CNC Holding Corporation, which owns 82 percent of Child World, payment terms to Child World's trade suppliers and banks as well as CNC's release from bank debt and other obligations. A spokesman for Child World had no immediate comment on the Perlmutter bid.

headline: Romania Seeks to Reduce Abortions
abstract: The scarcity and high cost of contraceptives here as well as a lack of easily available information about birth control have left abortion as the primary means of family planning, slowing the country's recovery from the harsh population building policies of its former Communist dictator, health officials here said.   In his eagerness to swell the population of Romania from its present level of 23 million, Nicolae Ceaucescu had made the possession of any birth-control device a crime while outlawing abortions. All aspects of that policy were reversed after his overthrow and execution. But in the absence of other means, there has been an increase in the number of abortions.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Combat BUSH DEMANDS IRAQ START PULLOUT TODAY DESPITE ITS ASSENT TO 3-WEEK SOVIET PLAN; OILFIELDS AND TRENCHES AFLAME IN KUWAIT AIR WAR IS PRESSED
abstract: Allied fighter-bombers pounded enemy troop emplacements in every corner of Kuwait today, flying a record number of missions over the emirate despite clouds of inky smoke from oil-well fires, apparently set by Iraq, that covered a quarter of the nation.    Firing volley after volley of shells and missiles, American and British howitzers and rocket launchers joined in the final preparation for a ground offensive, as did armadas of United States Army and Marine Corps helicopters.

headline: G.N.P. Rate Off a Revised 2%; Signs of a Mild Slump Seen
abstract: In a report that tended to support the idea that the recession would be relatively short and shallow, the Commerce Department today revised its estimate of economic activity in the final quarter of 1990, showing that the gross national product fell at an annual rate of 2 percent.   This was only slightly less than the initial estimate last month of a 2.1 percent decline for the October-December period, but economists said that shifts among the various G.N.P. components were mostly heartening.

headline: Talking Deals; Saving Pan Am From Liquidation
abstract: JUST hours before Pan Am filed for bankruptcy protection early on the morning of Jan. 8, the airline's management was still not certain it would have enough money to avoid liquidation. The final agreement that provided the carrier with a $150 million loan from Bankers Trust and United Airlines was not worked out and signed until 6:45 that morning.   Without the loan, Pan American World Airways would have been forced to liquidate, said two men who played major roles in putting together the unusual financing package, James O'Herron, a general partner at Lazard Freres, who acted as Pan Am's investment banker, and Joseph O'Donnell Jr., a managing director in the corporate finance department of Bankers Trust.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: The Overview; IRAQ DISAVOWS ANNEXATION, PLEDGING TO REPAY KUWAIT; REBELLION MAY BE SUBSIDING
abstract: As the most populous section of Iraq seethed with revolt, the Baghdad radio said today that the Government of President Saddam Hussein had voided the annexation of Kuwait, which was announced after Iraq's conquest of the tiny emirate last Aug. 2.    The state-owned radio reported that the Government had also agreed to return seized Kuwaiti assets, including gold, currency, airliners and the contents of the Kuwait art museum, one of the Middle East's best.

headline: Grand Met Seeks Big Board Listing
abstract: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British parent of the Pillsbury Company and the Burger King Corporation, said it was seeking a stock listing on the New York Stock Exchange. The company filed a preliminary registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for its shares to be listed as American depository receipts. Each A.D.R. will represent the equivalent of two ordinary Grand Met shares, which are listed on London's Stock Exchange, the company said.   About half of Grand Met's earnings are generated in the United States, but only 6 percent of the company's stock is currently owned by United States investors.

headline: New Executive At McCall's
abstract: Barbara J. Litrell has been appointed vice president and associate publisher of McCall's magazine, William T. Kerr, president of The New York Times Company Magazine Group, announced yesterday. She will report to Michael Golden, the publisher of McCall's.   Mrs. Litrell, who is 46 years old, joins McCall's from The New York Times, where she was the group advertising sales director responsible for The New York Times Magazine. For the last four years, she directed the business activities of the magazine.    In her position at McCall's, which was acquired by the Times Company in 1989, she will be part of the women's publishing division, one of two divisions in the Times Magazine Group.

headline: Saudi Prince to Become Citicorp's Top Stockholder
abstract: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, said yesterday that a member of the Saudi royal family, Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, had agreed to invest $590 million, in a deal that will help Citicorp strengthen its finances.    The investment will make Prince Waleed the largest single shareholder in Citicorp. The Prince, who quietly bought about 4.9 percent of Citicorp's common stock in the last months of 1990, could eventually own as much as 14.9 percent of the company with his new stake. But he will not be represented on Citicorp's board and has promised not to try to gain control over the company.

headline: Former S.& L. Owner Freed
abstract: A Federal judge today freed the former owner of the Vernon Savings Association, Don R. Dixon, until he is sentenced on a fraud conviction.   United States District Judge A. Joe Fish said Mr. Dixon, now hospitalized after suffering a heart attack, could go home between his release from the hospital and the sentencing on March 19.   Mr. Dixon, one of the most flamboyant figures in the prosecution of wrongdoing among savings and loan association owners, was convicted last month on 23 of 38 counts of fraud and misconduct relating to his ownership of Vernon. Vernon failed in 1987 at a cost to taxpayers of $1.7 billion.   Mr. Dixon faces a maximum sentence of 115 years in jail and a $5.7 million fine.   Judge Fish had ordered that Mr. Dixon be held in prison until sentencing because prosecutors contended that he might flee the country.   In granting the release, Judge Fish ordered Mr. Dixon's wife, Dana, to surrender her passport to the United States marshal until the sentencing hearing.   Mr. Dixon had a heart attack on Jan. 6 at the Mansfield Law Enforcement Center, where he was held after the Dec. 20 conviction. He was treated at the Mansfield Hospital and Harris Methodist Hospital in Fort Worth.

headline: Dow Rises by 4.21; I.B.M. Drops Further
abstract: One day after its worst session in more than five months, the stock market brushed itself off yesterday and posted a small gain in nervous trading.    The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.21 points to close at 2872.03. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was fairly heavy, at 196.8 million shares, and advances led declines by a small amount.

headline: Retail Sales Group Told Recession May Be Short
abstract: Two economists told the annual convention of the National Retail Federation in New York yesterday that the recession would be of relatively short duration and would be followed by a gradual improvement as the year progressed. But both speakers took pains to hedge their forecasts.    "I expect the economy to experience only a mild contraction so that consumer spending should not be severely impacted," Rosalind Wells, chief economist for the federation, the nation's largest retail trade association, told an audience of more than 600 at the New York Hilton Hotel.

headline: New Bendel's Has It All, But Will It Be Enough?
abstract: The Henri Bendel that opens tomorrow will be the first large new store on Fifth Avenue in many years. It is a distinction that carries as much uncertainty as it does promise in these days of slow retail sales, even for stores that cater to the affluent.   To make the women's fashion store stand out, its designers and managers seem to be using nearly every page of the 1991 book of retailing recipes. The touches go beyond fanciful displays and decor that includes the bright and the muted.

headline: Nexgen Microsystems Names Chief Executive
abstract: Nexgen Microsystems said yesterday that Atiq Raza, its executive vice president, had been named president and chief executive. Based in San Jose, Calif., Nexgen is a privately held start-up company that is developing a microprocessor based on RISC, or reduced instruction set computing.    Mr. Raza, who is 42, succeeds Thampy Thomas, the company's founder, who will continue with Nexgen as chairman. As executive vice president, Mr. Raza was in charge of engineering, manufacturing and product marketing; in his new position he adds external relations as well.

headline: TURMOIL IN SERBIA DEEPENS DIVISIONS
abstract: The political turmoil in the Yugoslav republic of Serbia, which continued today with the arrests of important anti-Communist opposition leaders, adds a new impetus to the forces pulling this multi-ethnic nation apart. The trouble comes after recent moves by Slovenia and Croatia toward seceding from the six-republic Yugoslav federation.   Political parties opposing Slobodan Milosevic, the former Communist who won Serbia's presidential election last year, said that at least 15 of their members were in jail in the aftermath of violent clashes on Saturday between police officers and demonstrators.

headline: Brazil Freezes All Wages and Prices
abstract: The Brazilian Government indefinitely froze all wages and prices today in an effort to stop inflation, now running at 20 percent a month.    "Prices starting tomorrow are halted," the Economy Minister, Zelia Cardoso de Mello, said.

headline: Citicorp's Delinquent Loans Expected to Rise Further
abstract: Citicorp's chief financial officer said yesterday that the company expected loan delinquencies to continue to rise this year, with increases likely to be particularly large in the first quarter.   The warning by the executive, Thomas E. Jones, echoed statements made by Citicorp's chairman, John S. Reed, in the annual report that the nation's largest banking company began mailing yesterday to its 55,000 shareholders.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Strategy; Outnumbered and Outgunned, Allied Forces Outfox Hussein
abstract: Outnumbered in combat troops, tanks and artillery, the United States and its allies relied on deception, mobility and overwhelming air superiority to defeat the Iraqi military.    As the commander of United States forces in the Persian Gulf, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, put it today, the allied war strategy boiled down to a plan for using ingenuity and technology to gain a decisive edge over a larger Iraqi ground force, which had surrounded itself with defensive fortifications.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Ground War Begins    If the Persian Gulf war ends in an allied victory by late March, with relatively few casualties, the American economy will almost certainly receive a lift. But many economists doubt that peace by springtime is sufficient in itself to end the recession. An early victory's biggest likely benefits are a rise in consumer confidence and a drop in oil prices.  [ Page D1. ]

headline: Du Pont to Stop Emissions of a Gas
abstract: The Du Pont Company said that within five years its factories would stop emitting a gas that eats away at the earth's protective ozone layer. Du Pont set the timetable to eliminate nitrous oxide, which is produced while making a raw material in nylon.   Du Pont said its announcement was in response to an article published on Feb. 22 in Science, the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, that said nitrous oxide can eat away at the ozone layer and thus act as an agent of global warming.
