Du Pont has been developing a process to recycle the gas instead of burning or releasing it into the atmosphere. The process should be ready within five years.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: COMMON STOCK * Cardinal Distribution Inc., Dublin, Ohio, is offering 1.4 million common shares at $33.50 a share through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Inc. * Haemonetics Corp., Braintree, Mass., has filed with the S.E.C. for an offering of six million common shares through First Boston Corp. and Alex. Brown & Sons. Of the total number of shares, 420,000 will be offered by the company and 5.58 million will be offered by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. * Homedco Group Inc., Fountain Valley, Calif., has filed a registration statement with the S.E.C. for an offering of 3.7 million common shares at an estimated price of $14 to $16 a share through Robertson, Stephens & Co. * Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Newark, is offering 4.5 million common shares at $26.75 a share through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. RATINGS * Corning Inc.'s senior debt has been raised to A+, from A, by S.&P. The maker of glass products is based in Corning, N.Y. * Delmarva Power and Light Co.'s senior debt has been lowered to A-2, from A-1, by Moody's. The utility company is based in Wilmington, Del. * Executive Life Insurance Co.'s housing bonds backed by investment contracts have been lowered to B, from BB, by S.&P. The insurer is a unit of First Executive Corp., which is based in Los Angeles. DEBT * ARCO, Los Angeles, is offering $300 million in 9 percent debentures due in 2021 through Salomon Brothers Inc. The debentures are priced at 99 to yield 9.098 percent to maturity and are noncallable.  * Continental Bank N.A., Chicago, is offering $100 million in subordinated notes due in 2001 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The issue is priced at par to yield 12.50 percent. It has been rated Baa-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBB by Standard & Poor's Corp. * Dow Chemical Co., Midland, Mich., has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of $150 million in subordinated exchangeable notes due in 2001. The notes are exchangeable for a portion of the Magma Power Co. common stock owned by Dow. * PHH Corp., Hunt Valley, Md., is offering $100 million of noncallable notes due in 1992 through First Boston Corp. The notes are priced at par to yield 6.95 percent and are rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P. * Phillips Petroleum Co., Bartlesville, Okla., has filed with the S.E.C. for a shelf offering of $550 million in debt securities. * Student Loan Marketing Association has increased the size of its offering of notes due in 1995 to $300 million, from $150 million. The notes were priced at par to float 60 basis points above the Treasury's three-month bill.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: MONDAY: Minimum wage increases to $4.25 an hour. * Report on construction spending for February. * Purchasing managers release index for March. * K Mart annual meeting. * Treasury Department reports results of three- and six-month bills auction. TUESDAY: February factory orders. * Lockheed annual meeting.

headline: Keating Gets Warning
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission formally warned Charles H. Keating Jr. today that it might charge him with violating securities laws in the sale of $250 million in "junk bonds" at the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, which was owned by Mr. Keating's family.

headline: Nike's 2 Stars Appear In a New Campaign
abstract: Spike Lee and Michael Jordan are back with Nike. This time, the two are starring in the company's $5 million "Stay in School" campaign.   One spot, which will begin nationally during the National Basketball Association's All-Star Game on Feb. 10, features Mr. Lee as his "Mars Blackmon" character, joking around with Mr. Jordan, the Chicago Bulls star. After a slightly intense discussion about the principles of gravity, they tell other kids in the classroom, "Don't be stupid; stay in school."

headline: Buffett's Gillette Stock
abstract: The Gillette Company, the big consumer products concern, said on Thursday that six insurance units of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. would convert $600 million of Gillette 8 3/4 percent series B preferred stock into Gillette common. Gillette said the preferred shares would be converted into 12 million common shares on April 1. Berkshire Hathaway is controlled by Warren Buffett, the billionaire heralded for his investment acumen.

headline: Kodak Sells Unit
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company said on Tuesday that it had sold its Ultralife 9-volt lithium battery business for an undisclosed sum to investors operating under the name Ultralife Batteries Inc. Ultralife said it intended to continue production in Newark of the batteries, which are used mostly in smoke alarms, garage door openers and toys, and to diversify into other lithium battery products. Kodak said it would continue to produce its Supralife and Photolife alkaline batteries, as well as other lithium batteries.

headline: The Executive Life; Safety for 1990 Is a Low - or No - Profile
abstract: Last spring, when Citicorp shareholders got the company's 1989 annual report, they found dozens of photographs of the bank's top executives, including three of John S. Reed, chairman. In this year's report, to be mailed to investors next month, there will be pictures of Citicorp customers around the world, but there may be few -- possibly even none -- of Mr. Reed or top management.    "This year's report is filled with pictures of people whose lives are touched by the bank," said Michael Schubert, creative director of Ruder Finn    Rotman, who is designing the 1990 report. "It's meant to show how the company's building a global enterprise."

headline: Patents; Structures Developed For Compact Use
abstract: Using a new approach to folding, a former art student who turned to mechanical engineering has invented a family of structures that can collapse into compact bundles in seconds.    The invention could make it easier to design pup tents that pop out more quickly, trunks and suitcases that fold up for easy storage and even the trusses of a space-station platform that must be packed tightly for launching into orbit.

headline: Troops Saluted By Ketchum
abstract: The rush to capitalize on the patriotic fervor unleashed by the American victory in the Persian Gulf war does not stop with advertisers. At least one advertising agency is getting in on the act as well.   Ketchum Advertising is planning to offer a "Welcome Back Pack," which will include free product samples and coupons, to all members of the military who served since August. The pack will be a cooperative effort between the New York agency and a number of its clients, though the agency would not specify the names of those companies yesterday.

headline: Pope Urges a Convert Drive, Even Where Muslims Ban It
abstract: Pope John Paul II, in a new encyclical, issued a clarion call to Catholics today to go out and spread Christianity, emphasizing the need to evangelize in all parts of the world, including those where Islamic laws forbid proselytizing.    He urged Islamic countries to lift those laws as well as others that forbid Muslims to convert to another faith. Without identifying the nations but evidently referring to Middle Eastern, African and Asian countries where missionaries are refused entry, the Pope exhorted, "Open the doors to Christ!"

headline: The Dollar's Rally Continues
abstract: Last   Prior   Year       Week   Week   Ago              Japanese Yen   137.85   136.74   152.65       per Dollar       German Mark   1.6068   1.5694   1.6985       per Dollar       Canadian Dollar   1.1561   1.1616   1.1958       per U.S. Dollar       British Pound   1.8210   1.8640   1.6190       U.S. Dollar per British Pound       Gold   $364.25   $369.50   $400.00       Republic National Bank       Currency: Friday NY Close

headline: GORBACHEV GIVEN A PARTIAL VICTORY IN VOTING ON UNITY
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appeared today to have won a bittersweet victory at best in his fight for national unity.   Voters supported his union referendum on a nationwide level even as some of his strongest critics won far more fervid endorsements of greater autonomy in such republics as Russia and the Ukraine.

headline: Your Own Account; Developing a Skills Portfolio 'To Go'
abstract: When Charles Handy's children left college a few years ago, he told them this: "I hope you won't look for a job in a corporation." Instead, he suggested they should develop skills, services and products that they could sell to corporations and to others in the marketplace. "Look for customers," he advised. "If you have a saleable skill, you can always work."  This was not casual advice. Mr. Handy, who lives in London and is the author of "The Age of Unreason" (Harvard Business School Press, 1990), believes that the structure of the work place is changing dramatically and that a lifetime career at a corporation will not be a viable alternative for many people in the future.

headline: U.S. Hardens Trade Stance With Japan
abstract: The Bush Administration has turned more truculent in its economic relations with Tokyo, reflecting both frustration over Japanese trading policies and unease over a wave of Japanese investments in the United States.    Three Cabinet departments -- Interior, Justice and Treasury -- have recently taken steps that strike at Japan. That the White House has not slapped the wrists of those responsible for these steps, which go against the previous positions of the Bush Administration, is widely seen in Washington as tacit approval of the more aggressive approach.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Art's-Way Manufacturing Co., Armstrong, Iowa, a maker of farm equipment, appointed Ronald W. Hottes president, succeeding Harold A. Westberg, who is retiring. * Amoco Oil Co., a subsidiary of Amoco Corp., named W. Douglas Ford executive vice president. * Bolt Beranek & Newman Inc., Cambridge, Mass., a communications and computer company, named Ralph A. Goldwasser senior vice president and treasurer. * Chase Manhattan Bank, a unit of Chase Manhattan Corp., appointed Dr. Richard C. Aspinwall chief economist. * Cisco Systems Inc., Menlo Park, Calif., named John T. Chambers senior vice president. * Claire's Stores Inc., Pembroke Pines, Fla., a jewelry and accessories retailer, appointed Bernard Newburg executive vice president of Decor Corp., its graphic arts subsidiary. * Medstat Systems Inc., Ann Arbor, Mich., a health-care information company, named Deborah M. Gage and Michael J. Karaman vice presidents. * Parfums Nina Ricci U.S.A. Inc., New York, a unit of Sanofi, appointed Claudia Wood senior vice president of marketing in its fragrance and cosmetics unit. * Alan Patricof Associates Inc., a venture capital firm, named Robert M. Chefitz a general partner. * Rite Aid Corp., Shiremanstown, Pa., a retail chain, promoted Timothy J. Noonan and Alex Schamroth to vice presidents and Philip D. Markovitz to senior vice president of corporate real estate. * Utilicorp United Inc., Kansas City, Mo., an electricity and gas company, named Robert K. Green president of its Missouri Public Service division.

headline: Canadian Pork Exports
abstract: A Commerce Department agency has ruled that subsidized exports of some Canadian pork products are not threatening any United States industry. The agency, the International Trade Commission, approved the ruling unanimously last week, reversing two previous rulings in the case.

headline: Immunex Drug's F.D.A. Approval
abstract: The Immunex Corporation said that Leukine, its genetically engineered drug that promotes the growth of infection-fighting white blood cells, had been granted orphan drug status by the Food and Drug Administration. Such status gives Immunex seven years to market Leukine exclusively for treating bone-marrow transplant patients with certain cancers.    Immunex, based in Seattle, said it had agreed to share its marketing exclusivity with Hoechst Roussel Pharmaceuticals Inc., which co-developed Leukine and markets it under the trademark Prokine. Leukine was approved by the F.D.A. earlier this month for treating Hodgkin's Disease, non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia, all of which are blood-borne cancers. Typical treatments for such diseases tend to lower white blood cells, leaving a patient vulnerable to infection.

headline: Your Own Account; Adding Up the Fees
abstract: Here are fees you can expect if you refinance. They will vary by state, but might total 3 percent to 6 percent of the amount financed, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association.    * Application fee. It goes to the bank for considering your loan.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: White House Memo; War Introduces a Tougher Bush to Nation
abstract: War never leaves a nation where it found it, the British statesman Edmund Burke once said. It also never leaves a President where it found him.    When Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, saw news accounts about Mr. Bush taking solitary walks around the South grounds, grappling with the weight of war, he appreciated the paradox.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Hotel; Is It the Luxury Hotel's Basement, Or an Iraqi Military Nerve Center?
abstract: The manager of the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad led journalists on a tour of the building's basement today in an effort to persuade them that American military officials were mistaken in saying the hotel houses a military communications center, according to reports from Baghdad.    Ghazi Ali Ismael, the hotel's general manager, called the charges by American military officials "a conspiracy," adding that the hotel "has never been used and is not being used by any military or the Iraqi Government, except for the Ministry of Information." Both Reuters and Associated Press correspondents who toured the basement reported that they saw nothing resembling a military command center.

headline: Industrial Colossus Typifies the Miseries of the Soviet Economy
abstract: In November, workers battling management over the fate of the colossal Uralmash machine tool works here raised the stakes by changing one word in the name of their unofficial bargaining group.    The Workers Committee became the Strike Committee. The implicit threat sent a tremor through the heart of this country's most sensitive industry.

headline: Market Place; Evaluating Rally Of Small Stocks
abstract: SMALL stocks are enjoying their best rally in almost a decade, as money pours into the group. While big stocks are rising, the small ones are soaring.   Over the last five weeks, the Nasdaq industrial index has gained 21.4 percent, the second-best performance in the 30-year history of the index. The Dow Jones industrial average, by constrast, is up a comparatively modest 10.3 percent over the same stretch.

headline: Campbell Soup Net Up 28.6%
abstract: The Campbell Soup Company today announced a 28.6 percent jump in quarterly earnings. It was the best quarter in the company's 121-year history.   For the three months that ended on Jan. 27, net earnings climbed to $135.3 million, or $1.07 a share, on revenues of $1.77 billion. For the corresponding quarter last year, earnings were $105.2 million, or 81 cents a share, on revenues of $1.72 billion.   David W. Johnson, Campbell's president and chief executive, attributed the strong performance to a focus on core businesses and the bottom line as well as cutbacks over the last year.   Campbell's stock price fell 87.5 cents today, to $68.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Saudi Arabia; After the War, the Saudis Prepare For a New Role Among the Arabs
abstract: The military victory over Iraq has considerably strengthened Saudi resolve to play a stronger role in Arab politics as an ally of the West and an opponent of militant governments in the Middle East, senior Saudi officials say.    "The experience of asking the Americans to come over here is viewed by all classes of Saudi society, including the most conservative religious groups, as a wise and courageous move," said a ranking Saudi official who spoke on the condition that his name not be used.

headline: Excerpts From Remarks To Parliament by de Klerk
abstract: Following are excerpts from an address by President F. W. de Klerk at the opening of Parliament in South Africa today, as provided by the South African Government:  In the short span of a single year, substantial progress was made. The Government is determined to build on the foundations laid purposefully, efficiently and with due speed.

headline: Senate Vote Revives Sanctions for a Role In Chemical Arms
abstract: The Senate passed legislation tonight requiring the President to impose sanctions on countries and companies developing or using chemical or biological weapons.    President Bush rejected an almost identical measure last year. But Congress had adjourned by the time he announced his decision and there was no chance to try to override a veto. Mr. Bush said then that he could not accept the bill because it did not give him the authority to waive all sanctions if he thought the national interest required him to.

headline: Du Pont Selling Half-Stake In Coal Concern to Germans
abstract: The Du Pont Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 50 percent interest in its Consolidation Coal Company subsidiary to Rheinbraun A.G., a coal mining company based in Germany.    Terms of the agreement were not disclosed, but analysts speculated that Du Pont might receive about $1.25 billion from the sale.

headline: Budget Gives Poor Humor To Bulgarians
abstract: According to the local folklore, the residents of this town are renowned for their self-effacing humor and their tightfistedness.    One typical story has it that Gabrovians are so cheap that it is not unusual for married couples to make do with a single wedding band, with the husband wearing it one day and the wife the next. Another tale of Gabrovian economy contends that townsfolk snip the tails off housecats to cut down a little on the heat loss each time they open the door to let their pets out in wintertime.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Kuwait; For a Jubilant Crowd in Kuwait City, It's Victory Signs, Tears and Kisses
abstract: Although the inky smoke from burning oilfields formed a pall overhead, the people of Kuwait City lined their streets in jubilation today waving Kuwaiti flags, flashing victory signs, crying and often kissing those they took to be members of the allied force that captured the city in the last 24 hours.    Along the three-lane main highway into the city, women in long black veils hugged each other and laughed while their husbands climbed atop the cement dividers to fire off their automatic weapons. The black, green, white and red Kuwaiti flag, which had vanished from public display during Iraq's occupation, suddenly appeared everywhere, draped on cars, buildings and even peoples clothing.

headline: Washington at Work; C.I.A. Sidelines Its Gulf Cassandra
abstract: As Iraqi forces massed along Kuwait's border on Aug. 1, a Central Intelligence Agency analyst named Charlie Allen walked into the offices of the National Security Council's Middle East staff.    "This is your final warning," he is reliably said to have told them. Iraq, he said, would invade Kuwait by day's end.

headline: Europe Has Its Share Of Airline Problems
abstract: Airlines in the United States are not the only ones reeling from the Persian Gulf war. Uncertainty and a fear of terrorism generated by the conflict have also severely depressed the business of European airlines, which like American carriers had already been hit hard when fuel prices soared last year after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.   Slowing economies in Europe, especially in Britain and Sweden, have also hurt the airline business. All told, major European airlines are reporting that the number of passengers has dropped 10 to 30 percent, and they have been cutting domestic and international service accordingly.

headline: 6 Americans, Including Woman, Among 10 Released by Baghdad
abstract: The first 10 allied prisoners released by Iraq since the end of the Persian Gulf war, six Americans among them, walked, drove and flew to freedom today, saying they felt good.    The group, pronounced in good shape by a Red Cross representative, included the soldier who was the only woman known to be a prisoner of the conflict, Specialist Melissa Rathbun-Nealy, 20 years old, from Grand Rapids, Mich., and Lieut. Jeffrey Norton Zaun, a Navy airman, 28 years old, of Cherry Hill, N.J., who appeared, bruised and battered, on Iraqi and American television at the beginning of the war.

headline: Dollar Is Down On Interest Moves
abstract: Last   Prior   Year       Week   Week   Ago              Japanese Yen   131.05   132.55   145.35       per Dollar       German Mark   1.4680   1.4905   1.6860       per Dollar       Canadian Dollar   1.1593   1.1633   1.1885       per U.S. Dollar       British Pound   1.9750   1.9565   1.6120       U.S. Dollar per British Pound       Gold   $365.50   $375.50   $418.50       Republic National Bank       Currency: Friday NY Close

headline: Insurance Giants No Longer Ask To Be All Things to All People
abstract: Some of the oldest and best-known American insurance companies have decided to abandon their all-things-to-all-people approach in favor of a narrower focus. The change could substantially affect rates for many kinds of insurance, the prices of insurance stocks and the economy in the Northeast, where the largest insurance companies are based.    Stung by losses or shrinking profits in many of their businesses, the insurers are sharply cutting back on or abandoning entire areas of insurance, selling unrelated businesses, closing offices and laying off workers.

headline: Toronto Journal; Official Gadfly Finds Canada United in Discontent
abstract: When Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Government decided last fall to invite Canadians to express their feelings about Canada and its problems, it chose as its Pied Piper a former newspaper editor and language commissioner with a distinctly un-Canadian propensity for stirring things up.    Four months later, the official, Keith Spicer, has more than lived up to his billing as a quirky fellow who says what many Canadian public figures may think but hesitate to say in this country, where public discourse generally remains within well-circumscribed proprieties.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: United Nations; U.N. Compromise Plan To Widen Relief to Iraq
abstract: The United Nations Security Council pledged tonight to exempt more food and humanitarian aid from its trade embargo against Iraq and speed authorization for delivering the supplies to needy people there.    The decision, announced by Austria, this month's Council president, represented a compromise between the United States and its gulf war allies and a group of members who wanted trade sanctions lifted altogether on goods needed to preserve public health in Iraq.

headline: NBC Faces a Struggle To Keep Its Hit Shows
abstract: At a time when NBC needs its established hit shows more than ever, the network is about to enter negotiations with the producers of its four highest-rated comedies. At stake: whether the shows will remain on NBC next season -- and at what cost.   NBC's contracts for "Cheers," "The Cosby Show," "A Different World" and "Golden Girls" all expire at the end of the current television season. With no new agreement, the shows would be available to NBC's rivals.

headline: A Prince Of a Deal For Citicorp
abstract: People used to denounce banks for charging usurious interest rates. Now Citicorp, desperate for capital, is paying such rates.   The $590 million capital infusion that Citicorp obtained last week from a Saudi prince came at a heavy cost. It may have proved that it can raise capital, but the 11 percent rate on preferred stock it issued for the money is equivalent to a pretax rate of 15 percent for a corporate investor. And Citicorp may go on paying that rate long after the current crisis of confidence has passed. Not before 1996 can the company force Prince al-Waleed bin Talal to convert the preferred to common, at $16 per share. Any profits on conversion will come on top of the assured 11 percent return.

headline: Dow Caps Big Week With a Gain of 57.42
abstract: Capping a week of heavy buying and several new highs, the stock market advanced sharply yesterday in the wake of Iraq's surprise offer to withdraw from Kuwait.    Registering its third new high for the year in just the last five days, the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 2 percent, to 2,934.65, ahead 57.42 points for the day. That rise put the gain for the week at 103.96, or 3.7 percent.

headline: S.& L. Trouble In San Diego
abstract: The Great American Bank, a financially troubled savings and loan association in San Diego, said today that it was at risk of being seized by the Government because it is violating its Federally approved plan of operation.    The institution said it expected to set aside money to cover loan and real estate losses in the quarter that ended on Dec. 31 that would exceed by $100 million the loss provisions projected in its capital plan. Falling out of compliance with the capital plan violates an order from the Office of Thrift Supervision and could result in the institition's seizure, Great American said.    Robert L. Kemper, Great American's chairman, said it was uncertain what actions the regulatory agency would take.    Last November the Government approved a sweeping recovery plan for Great American that included the sale of its branches in California to Wells Fargo Bank.    It is not clear what effect any action will have on the sale agreement with Wells Fargo.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Arctic Alaska Fisheries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Can Atex Keep Its Proprietary Place in the Newsroom?
abstract: Once the world's premier manufacturer of computerized editorial and advertising production systems for newspapers and magazines, Atex Inc. is finding itself under increasing pressure as more nimble competitors capitalize on new technology to pass the company by.    Some executives and analysts have even begun to ask if Atex, an Eastman Kodak Company subsidiary based in Billerica, Mass., can surmount its problems quickly enough to maintain a foothold in the growing computerized publishing field.

headline: A TURKISH GESTURE TO KURDS FALTERS
abstract: A Government plan to soften language restrictions long imposed on Turkey's Kurdish minority has stumbled in Parliament and may die there, a victim of nationalist fears and political maneuvering.    With some fanfare and with hopes of improving their shaky human-rights image abroad, Turkish leaders announced in late January that they would lift a ban that had made it a crime for Kurds to speak their language in public or to listen to their traditional songs.

headline: Saks Assets Back Euromarket Notes
abstract: A three-part, $500 million private placement of various floating-rate notes backed by 42 properties owned by the Saks Fifth Avenue retail chain was made in the Euromarket yesterday.    The placement, by a specially created company called Fifth Avenue Capital Trust, was done through underwriters led by Goldman Sachs International.   The financing was done to pay down bridge loans taken out in the acquisition of Saks by Investcorp, an international investor group, according to a Saks official.   One group of notes placed was a $200 million issue of extendible, adjustable notes paying the three-month London interbank offered rate, Libor, plus 75 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.    These notes can be extended by the issuer for two years beginning December 1995 upon payment of 2 percent of the principal amount.    Also placed was a $25 million note issue paying the three-month London interbank rate plus 45 basis points, and $275 million of variable-rate notes paying 75 basis points over the interbank rate, which can be convertible on any interest payment date into floating-rate notes.

headline: Mutual Funds; Placing Bets on Recovery
abstract: Judging from where they had put their assets at the end of last year, managers of the five types of stock funds were making very different bets on where the economy was headed.    Historically, when consumer confidence rises, funds weighted down with consumer "stables" -- companies that make drugs, cigarettes and other products with steady consumer demand -- lag. By contrast, those holding "cyclicals" -- companies that make cars, appliances and other items that consumers can postpone buying -- do well.

headline: Texas Insurer In Settlement
abstract: A former Texas insurance commissioner who was accused of conspiring to steal millions of dollars from an insurance company he ran has settled an $11 million civil lawsuit.   Joseph D. Hawkins was accused of racketeering and theft in connection with the 1986 collapse of the Continental Bankers Life Insurance Company of the South.   His lawyer, Mark A. Weitz, and Texas insurance regulators involved in the Federal lawsuit confirmed on Tuesday that a settlement had been reached but refused to disclose details.   Mr. Hawkins, who resigned as state insurance commissioner in 1977, headed a group that bought Continental Bankers, chartered in Tennessee, in 1980 and sold it two years later. State investigators contend that during his ownership and for years afterward, Mr. Hawkins participated in a conspiracy to defraud Continental Bankers' policyholders.   In the civil suit filed in 1988 by Texas and Tennessee, Mr. Hawkins was accused with eight others of racketeering, conspiracy and fraud in the purported looting of Continental Bankers.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; A Costly Radio Failure Hurts Westwood One
abstract: On WNEW-AM, the New York radio station operated by the Westwood One Companies, Frank Sinatra can often be heard singing that if you can make it in New York you can make it anywhere. Unfortunately, in Westwood One's case Mr. Sinatra is wrong.   In 1989, the company hired Scott Shannon, one of New York's most successful disk jockeys, and brought him to Los Angeles to program the FM station it had just acquired for $56 million and be its morning star. Westwood One paid Mr. Shannon $1.5 million a year.

headline: Eastern Airlines Is Shutting Down And Plans to Liquidate Its Assets
abstract: Eastern Airlines, a fixture in United States aviation since 1928 and the nation's eighth-largest airline, announced that it had stopped flying last night and would begin to sell off its planes and other assets.   The airline, which had been struggling for almost two years to rebuild under the protection of the bankruptcy court, is by far the largest casualty of the pressures brought by the deregulation of the industry 13 years ago.

headline: Do It Yourself, Or Go to a Pro?
abstract: Mildred Mailick, a professor at the Hunter College School of Social Work, and her husband Sidney, a professor at New York University, have had their tax returns professionally prepared for more than 30 years.   "It's all that we can do to gather the data," she said. "We don't have the confidence to know what to take off that wouldn't get us into trouble."

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * Alco Standard Corp., Wayne, Pa., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of $150 million in debt securities. * J.C. Penney Co., Dallas, has established a $750 million, three-year international revolving line of credit with a group of banks and arranged by Credit Suisse First Boston. The line of credit is extendible to five-years. RATINGS * Maine's general obligation bond rating of triple-A is under review for possible downgrading by S.&P.

headline: BRITAIN REVIEWING SYSTEM OF JUSTICE
abstract: The wrongful conviction of six men imprisoned more than 16 years ago for the Irish Repubican Army bombings of two pubs in Birmingham has produced the most intense criticism of the British criminal justice system in over a decade.    Some critics of the system say that only a written constitution and bill of rights can produce the kind of far-reaching change necessary to preclude similar miscarriages of justice in the future. In the current two-decade-old struggle with the I.R.A., they say, successive British Governments have limited the rights of defendants in terrorist cases and left the police with extensive powers that can easily be abused.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: P.O.W.'s; Powell and Cheney Are to Greet Ex-Prisoners of Iraq on Arrival in U.S.
abstract: The former American prisoners of war are expected to return to American soil Sunday and will be greeted by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and maybe even President Bush at Andrews Air Force Base, Administration officials said today.   As they made the announcement, the Baghdad radio said Iraqi troops had captured two American servicemen in the southern city of Basra, and Red Cross officials said later in the day that the two men had been turned over to its officials in Baghdad. The Pentagon has so far been unable to clear up confusion about the two, who were identified by an Iraqi Government spokesman on the Baghdad Radio as First Lieut. Gavin Rice and Pvt. Allen Jeoffrey Allen, both of the Army's VII Corps.

headline: Bombardier Plant May Face Layoffs
abstract: Bombardier Inc., the Montreal-based transportation equipment company, may lay off workers for up to 18 months a its plant here even if it wins a $350 million Federal contract.   Amtrak is scheduled to decide later this month whether to award Bombardier a contract to produce 140 double-decker cars for long-distance passenger service. Although the contract would eventually bring a boom to the Vermont plant, assembly would not begin until 1992 and there is not enough work now to maintain full employment, officials said.

headline: Lord Einstein Founder To Join Unit of Lintas
abstract: Kevin O'Neill, a founding partner of Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners, is joining Lintas New York as executive vice president and group creative director. He replaces Mike Shalette, who was executive vice president and executive creative director and is moving to Lintas Marketing Communications.    Earlier this month, Lord Einstein was merged with HDM New York. Lord Einstein was formed in 1988 by six executives who left Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein. In addition, Lintas Worldwide has consolidated its North, Central and South American zones into one, which will be known as the Americas.   The office will be headed by Spencer Plavoukos, who remains chief executive of Lintas New York.   William V. Weithas, chief executive of Lintas Worldwide, attributed the consolidation to growth from existing clients, new business and expansion of media and marketing services.    A spokeswoman said that the agency planned no staff reductions.

headline: Psychiatric Care Chain Gets Sale Bid
abstract: The financially troubled Charter Medical Corporation, the nation's largest psychiatric hospital company, received a $1.1 billion acquisition proposal today from a California-based rival, Community Psychiatric Centers.   Charter, based in Georgia, was taken private in a 1988 leveraged buyout that left it with $1.65 billion in debt that it is now negotiating to restructure. It immediately rejected Community's offer, and a spokesman, Andy Brimmer, said, "The only result or intention of this offer is to destabilize the company and its operations."

headline: Freeing the Banks From 1930's Chains
abstract: Now that the Administration has unveiled its long-awaited plan to free banks from their Depression-era handcuffs, the real work begins: implementing the plan. The complicating factor in this case is timing. The recommendations come hot on the heels of the collapse of the savings and loan industry, a collapse that some wrongly insist is a foreshadowing of what's in store for banking.    While I don't mean to minimize the serious problems facing commercial banks, I contend that the prophets of doom are way off the mark when they suggest banks are about to go the way of the savings and loans. Make no mistake, there will be casualties. Many well-known names might not survive as we know them today. But it won't be the industry Armageddon some are predicting.

headline: Beber Silverstein Loses Subway Sandwiches Job
abstract: Subway Sandwiches, the chain of 5,100 sandwich shops that is based in Milford, Conn., and Beber Silverstein & Partners, an advertising agency based in Miami, have agreed to terminate their association after less than a year.   Beber Silverstein had handled creative development for Subway Sandwiches, with a budget of approximately $1.5 million, said Cindy Eadie, executive director of the company's advertising finances.

headline: New Competition At Top Set Up by ITT
abstract: The ITT Corporation realigned its management yesterday with new roles for two executives, in effect setting up a competition a rung below Rand V. Araskog, chairman and chief executive.    Moving into a prominent role is D. Travis Engen, 46 years old, who was named an executive vice president. Taking on more responsibilities is Dale R. Comey, 49, who is already an executive vice president.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Marines; Beneath a Charcoal Sky, Marine Units Roll Toward a Rendezvous
abstract: The trucks, laden with anti-tank missiles and tank ammunition, crept ahead one by one, as if in slow motion.   At intervals of five minutes, they started across the stony desert here at the southwestern corner of Kuwait, heading for the First Marine Division units farther to the north. It was slow going because there were minefields on either side of the narrow tracks marked out with colored barrels by the combat engineers.

headline: Cardinal Tomasek of Prague, Primate Since 1977, Retires
abstract: The Archbishop of Prague, Frantisek Cardinal Tomasek, one of the region's toughest Roman Catholic leaders and a staunch anti-Communist, has retired at 91, the Papal Nuncio said today.   Msgr. Miloslav Vlk, 58, who had been forced to work as a street cleaner under the Communist Government, was appointed to succeed Cardinal Tomasek as Archbishop of Prague.   Cardinal Tomasek, the church's oldest active archbishop, was named primate of Czechoslovakia and head of the Prague archdiocese in 1977, a year after he reached the normal retirement age.

headline: Business Diary/December 6-11
abstract: THE ECONOMY Baker and Aziz Send the Markets Spinning  Minutes before 2 P.M. on Wednesday, Brian Tagler of Shearson Lehman Brothers was trading oil for $23.85 a barrel. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d had been meeting with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. The moment Mr. Tagler heard Mr. Baker say on television, "Regrettably . . . ," the trader was on the phone to the commodity pit. Buy orders had pushed the price to $31 -- the quickest rise he had ever seen. Economists are somewhat more stable in their sentiments, occasionally holding them for a whole week. Their consensus by the weekend was that if the United States fights and wins quickly and tidily, oil prices would fall and the economy would benefit. "I understand the mood swings, but people are exaggerating," said Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at Bear Stearns. "There is a worldwide glut of oil against a backdrop of weak demand." But if there is a protracted war, many economists say, the budget deficit would widen, and oil prices and interest rates would rise. "The uncertainty will have a debilitating effect," said Richard B. Berner, a Salomon Brothers economist. "People will hold back from making long-term commitments." Even a last-minute settlement will not be enough to overcome recession, economists say, since growth was slowing before Iraqi troops set foot in Kuwait. Again, Sweat Doesn't Pay  Will the returns on labor rebound and surpass the returns on wealth in the 1990's? From 1984 to 1988, the wealthiest gained in net worth, while everyone else stagnated, the Census Bureau reported last week. The less affluent depend mostly on their wages, which in the 1980's barely kept pace with inflation. Stocks and bonds, meanwhile, enjoyed strong returns. Lacy H. Hunt, chief United States economist for the Hongkong Bank Group, doubts that investments will continue soaring. But wages will rise as labor supplies tighten, he says. "The headlines of one decade go into the trash bin of the new decade," he said. For investors, "The decade hasn't started off very well, has it?" Wholesale Comfort  The wholesale inflation news for December was comforting at every stop in the production chain. For finished goods, prices fell six-tenths of 1 percent overall; they only rose three-tenths of a point excluding food and energy. Prices for intermediate and crude goods, earlier in the production process, also fell. Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley said the report leaves the Federal Reserve plenty of room to stoke the economy. "The fundamentals are as constructive for inflation as they have been at any point in the onset of the last few recessions," he said. The annual gain, 5.6 percent, was the highest since 1981, but a mild 3.5 percent core rate. An Uptown Jazz Market  Where sopranos now screech, saxaphones will squeal and coo. Lincoln Center has launched a jazz department with a $1 million annual budget. The marketing problem for Rob Gibson, the department's chief: How to create an uptown audience, week after week, for music usually heard in downtown clubs. His answers include children's concerts, master classes and small, informal theaters in the center. One possibility is a tribute to Sun Ra, the band leader whose fans can verify his claimed birth in outer space. But judging by what works best at Lincoln Center, Mr. Gibson might better raise his top ticket prices to $115, require black tie on opening nights and drag dozens of shield-bearing supernumeraries on stage. Banking Forecast: Rain  At times last week, L. William Seidman's spirits improved to merely gloomy. Otherwise, he was downright dismal. On Wednesday, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned the Senate Banking Committee that more major bank failures were likely if the recession persists past mid-year. On Friday, he landed in Boston, like a governor visiting a hurricane disaster zone, to say that the region needs more widely available bank credit to free itself from a recession. "I don't think there's probably a bad loan being made in New England at this time," he said. "Unfortunately, there aren't many others either." INTERNATIONAL   A Payoff for Turkey?  One possible winner in the Middle East crisis: Turkey, which right after Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait cut off Iraqi oil pipelines and made military bases available to counter Iraq. Turkey hopes the United States and its allies will offer more help in its continuing disputes with Greece. And Turkey can look forward to closer economic ties with Europe's wealthier nations, said Robert G. Neumann, director of Middle East programs at the Center for Strategic and International Studies and a former Ambassador to Saudi Arabia. Turkey needs aid to improve its infrastructure -- the phone lines are too feeble to carry faxes abroad, for example -- if it hopes to capitalize on its low labor costs. Although the European Community is considering several applications for admission, Mr. Neumann said, "Turkey may very well move up in the line." With luck, Turkey might prove that it can approach the prosperity of the West.   Oil Importers Prepare for War  The International Energy Agency, representing 21 oil-importing nations, agreed on Friday to release 2 million barrels a day from reserves in case of war in the Middle East. The United States, the largest oil importer, cut petroleum consumption 2.1 percent in 1990, the first drop in seven years. Domestic oil production fell to the lowest level since 1961. THE ECONOMY   Again, Sweat Doesn't Pay  Will the returns on labor rebound and surpass the returns on wealth in the 1990's? From 1984 to 1988, the wealthiest gained in net worth, while everyone else stagnated, the Census Bureau reported last week. The less affluent depend mostly on their wages, which in the 1980's barely kept pace with inflation. Stocks and bonds, meanwhile, enjoyed strong returns. Lacy H. Hunt, chief United States economist for the Hongkong Bank Group, doubts that investments will continue soaring. But wages will rise as labor supplies tighten, he says. For finished goods, prices fell six-tenths of 1 percent overall; they only rose three-tenths of a point excluding food and energy. Prices for intermediate and crude goods, earlier in the production process, also fell. Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley said the report leaves the Federal Reserve plenty of room to stoke the economy. "The fundamentals are as constructive for inflation as they have been at any point in the onset of the last few recessions," he said. The annual gain, 5.6 percent, was the highest since 1981, but a mild 3.5 percent core rate. An Uptown Jazz Market  Where sopranos now screech, saxaphones will squeal and coo. Lincoln Center has launched a jazz department with a $1 million annual budget. The marketing problem for Rob Gibson, the department's chief: How to create an uptown audience, week after week, for music usually heard in downtown clubs. His answers include children's concerts, master classes and small, informal theaters in the center. One possibility is a tribute to Sun Ra, the band leader whose fans can verify his claimed birth in outer space. But judging by what works best at Lincoln Center, Mr. Gibson might better raise his top ticket prices to $115, require black tie on opening nights and drag dozens of shield-bearing supernumeraries on stage.
