On Wednesday, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned the Senate Banking Committee that more major bank failures were likely if the recession persists past mid-year. On Friday, he landed in Boston, like a governor visiting a hurricane disaster zone, to say that the region needs more widely available bank credit to free itself from a recession. "I don't think there's probably a bad loan being made in New England at this time," he said. "Unfortunately, there aren't many others either."

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    The run on the Bank of New England was worrisome, but panic eased when the F.D.I.C. took over. The lesson is that a modern-day bank run is containable because of Federal deposit insurance. The situation is far different from Depression-era runs that wiped out the life savings of millions.  [ Page 1. ]  The press has played an important role in recent months in shaping public confidence in many banks and attitudes toward the banking industry.  [ 33. ]   A majority of forecasters insist that the recession will end by August, basing their optimism on the behavior of past recessions and big recent rises in stock prices. By their own admission, however, they are playing down troubling features of this recession that could prove them wrong.  [ 29. ]   A new law requires drug companies to give Medicaid the same deep discounts they give other big customers. But instead of reducing Medicaid drug prices, many companies are raising the prices that other big customers must pay. Health-care experts say these added costs may soon trickle down to consumers in the form of higher medical costs, and ultimately, insurance premiums.  [ 1. ]   The problems of domestic auto makers are being aggravated by a decline in the sales of some of its most profitable products: full-size pickup trucks and vans. Sales of light trucks, which include pickup trucks, vans and sports-utility vehicles, declined 7 percent in the fourth quarter, while car sales rose 1 percent.  [ 29. ]   Some small companies that thought they were recession-resistant a finding they are not. Not only are consumers holding back on new purchases, but goods and services bought are frequently paid for more slowly.  [ 29. ]   A California company is proposing what may be the ultimate wilderness experience for those who think they are roughing it when they peer at mountains and canyons through the windshield of a car: viewing a magnificent film about Zion National Park on a giant wrap-around movie screen, without ever having to set foot in the park.  [ 1. ]   The Atlanta metropolitan area is expected to lose jobs this year for the first time since 1974. The demise of Eastern Airlines may have struck the final blow to the optimism of the city, the engine that drives Georgia's economy.  [ 10. ]   Cattle ranchers say they face bigger challenges than the extreme weather of places like Wyoming, the constant hard work and even weak beef prices. What bothers some of them the most, they say, are growing attacks on their products from the medical community and environmentalists.  [ 32. ]  The Media Business    Young & Rubicam is trying to regain the edge it held in the creative revolution of the 1960's. To that end, the agency has hired an outsider to head its New York creative department, which suffers from an image of making lackluster ads.  [ 29. ]   NBC is in the middle of a high-stakes game of programming poker as it tries to extend the lives of aging hit comedies. Even winning the game will cost NBC a potful of money; the producers of "Cheers," for example, are reportedly seeking $4 million an episode. But losing could end NBC's ratings dominance and even send the network into third place. Bill Carter: Television.  [ 34. ]   The gulf war is cutting into the publicity that new books receive. Some authors have had book tours curtailed or canceled. Others are finding it increasingly difficult to get television interviews. As a result, sales of some books are likely to fall. And the publication of at least one travel book has been delayed.  [ 34. ]   The BBC World Service has expanded its Arabic-language broadcasts to the Middle East. The Arabic Service provides news to 10 million listeners, the BBC estimates.  [ 34. ]  International    Several Soviet economists say the Soviet Union's transition to a market economy remains irreversible, even if recent developments have slowed the process, because the old centrally planned system has been too dismantled and discredited to be rebuilt.  [ 29. ]

headline: Rating Lowered For Nynex Unit
abstract: The rating on about $2.3 billion in New England Telephone and Telegraph Company long-term debt has been lowered to Aa-2, from Aa-1, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday. New England Telephone is a unit of the Nynex Corporation.   Analysts at the rating agency said the telephone company's weakened operating performance and debt protection measurements were unlikely to return soon to their levels of the 1980's because of severe weakness in the New England economy and growing competitive pressures.   Moody's said it thought the New England economy would remain weak at least in the near term.

headline: GTE Completes Contel Takeover
abstract: The GTE Corporation completed the $6.6 billion takeover of the Contel Corporation in the largest merger ever in the telecommunications industry. The merged company, with a market value of $28 billion and 197,000 employees, will be the country's largest local telephone company and the second-largest mobile cellular communications operator.   GTE said Contel's shareholders would receive 1.27 shares of GTE common stock for each Contel share. GTE closed today at $33.50, up $1, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Top Japanese Executive To Step Down
abstract: Seiji Tsutsumi, founder and chairman of the Saison Group, said Saturday that he planned to step down from active management of the large Japanese conglomerate and hand over authority to a collective leadership.   Mr. Tsutsumi, 63 years old, has been slowly withdrawing from day-to-day management of Saison, which operates Japan's largest department store chain, Seibu. He had already given up some of his titles at affiliated companies. But the suddeness of the announcement that he would reorganize the group's leadership and become an adviser surprised many Japanese executives.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Richard Barrie Fragrances Inc., East Hampton, L.I., to I. Goldberg & Partners Inc., New York, for its Misha and Baryshnikov fragrances. Billings are $1 million. * Jus-rol, a frozen pastry line recently acquired by Pillsbury, a subsidiary of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., to Leo Burnett Ltd., London. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Germany; ANTI-WAR PROTEST IS STAGED IN BONN
abstract: Thousands of anti-war protesters from throughout Germany converged on Bonn today to show their opposition to war in the Persian Gulf.    Many protesters carried signs emphasizing that they were not holding the United States responsible for the war. In past days, some newspapers and political leaders have sought to portray Germany's peace movement as anti-American.

headline: FORUM; Does the Rally Signal Recession's End?
abstract: The question in the minds of many investors, as they watch what may be the beginning of a new bull market, is whether the current runup in stock prices signals an early end to the recession.   For many years, we have been studying the value of stock prices as an indicator of future business conditions, going back for data as far as 1948. In general, what we have learned is this: Stock market prices are an good indicator of future economic performance.

headline: ALLIES REPORT FAST ADVANCES IN IRAQ AND KUWAIT, WITH LITTLE RESISTANCE; THOUSANDS OF IRAQIS TAKEN PRISONER
abstract: Allied troops drove deep into Iraqi-occupied Kuwait on Sunday, reaching the outskirts of Kuwait City before nightfall, according to senior officers. To the west, powerful armored columns and a huge fleet of helicopters stormed into Iraq, heading northeast toward Basra in an effort to isolate Iraq's elite Republican Guards.   It was the biggest American-led assault since World War II, and it touched off one of the largest battles in decades, spread across a front 300 miles wide and involving more than a million combatants and support troops.

headline: A Pace Car Made (Quickly) in U.S.
abstract: After protests from union leaders, snide letters from angry race fans and a surge in patriotic fervor coinciding with the Persian Gulf war, the Chrysler Corporation shifted gears today. It is yanking a Japanese-made two-seat sports car as its pick to be the pace car of the Indianapolis 500.    Instead, Chrysler will pace the race with a new model, the Dodge Viper, a prototype of which it will hurriedly build for the Memorial Day race. The Viper, developed in part by Chrysler's Lamborghini subsidiary in Italy, is expected to cost between $30,000 and $40,000. As the pace car, it will replace the Dodge Stealth, made by the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation.

headline: Unity Brings Many Traumas to What Was East Germany
abstract: In this gritty industrial town in what used to be East Germany, people have for years lived among slag heaps and strip mines, breathed poisonous air, and tried to shield themselves from the oppression of a Communist police state.    Many hoped that last year's unification of Germany would improve their lives. But now, they say, they realize that the worst is yet to come.   Giant power plants that ring the town will soon start laying off thousands of workers. The local textile combine, no longer supported by Government subisidies, is likely to shut down. Free health clinics and day-care centers have been closed, and rents will soon be raised to at least five times their current levels.  Once-Proud Cities Falter     German unification has plunged people in the eastern part of the country into a state of trauma. The complaints heard in Cottbus, with some local variations, echo from the Baltic port of Rostock, where tens of thousands of workers marched recently to protest the planned closing of local shipyards, to the once-proud cities of Leipzig and Dresden, where local governments are near bankruptcy.

headline: Your Own Account; Should You Switch Policies?
abstract: With the insurance industry in turmoil, brokers may approach you, toting news reports of troubles in your company and urging you to change policies. Be careful. Brokers may be following their own agendas, and reports can be misleading.    One widely circulated report, for example, was done by Public Citizen, a Washington consumer group. It charged that five of the 20 largest insurance companies would be at risk in an economic downturn. It later withdrew two insurers from the list. "We miscalculated, much to our chagrin and embarrassment," said Robert Dreyfuss, a spokesman for Public Citizen.

headline: Dow Rally Wiped Out Late in Day
abstract: With Wall Street cautious on the eve of a crucial weekend in the Persian Gulf war, investors pulled back yesterday in heavy trading after a strong rally earlier.    In a steep one-hour selling wave starting at 2:11 P.M, the Dow Jones industrial average plunged nearly 60 points, or 2 percent, from its high for the day. After being ahead 44, the Dow ended the day off 2.47, at 2,889.36, putting the loss for the week at 45.29, or 1.5 percent.

headline: Mancuso Sues Paramount
abstract: Frank Mancuso, the former chairman of Paramount Pictures Inc., filed a $45 million lawsuit yesterday charging a breach of contract against Paramount Communications Inc., the company that owns Paramount Pictures.    The suit, filed in Superior Court in Santa Monica, Calif., contends that Paramount's chairman, Martin S. Davis, dismissed Mr. Mancuso this week without cause.

headline: MOSCOW IS SENDING TROOPS TO BALTICS TO ENFORCE DRAFT
abstract: The Soviet Defense Ministry said today that it would send elite paratroop units to the Baltic republics and other separatist regions to arrest draft resisters and military deserters, a move that could dramatically raise ethnic tensions and complicate American-Soviet relations at a crucial time.   Leaders of the three Baltic republics, where resistance to the draft has been an integral part of movements toward independence, said the local Soviet military commander notified them today that he had authorization from Moscow to call in several divisions, with 10,000 paratroopers each. As of late tonight, there was no sign that any had begun to move.

headline: Big Wave Of Trading At the Merc
abstract: By the time the trading ended on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday afternoon, officials at the world's most important energy market were glowing with pride, and sighing with relief.   "Very orderly, beyond our expectation," said Z. Lou Guttman, the New York Merc's chairman, describing the day's activity, in which contracts for future delivery of crude oil, gasoline and heating oil all fell sharply.

headline: India About to Embark on Its Census
abstract: In a few weeks, an army of 1.8 million people will fan out from the frozen Himalayas to the sultry shores of Great Nicobar Island to complete one of the world's most challenging jobs: a national census for India.   In a country that is likely to nudge out China as the world's most populous nation sometime in the next century, taking a census means visiting 600,000 villages, countless city slums and thousands of scattered small communities speaking hundreds of indigenous dialects. Census forms and an instruction booklet for census takers are printed in 16 major languages.

headline: Dayton Profits Off 6%
abstract: The retailing giant Dayton Hudson Corporation today reported a 6 percent decline in fourth-quarter profits. For the quarter that ended on Feb. 2, earnings totaled $235 million, or $3.21 a share, down from $250 million, or $3.50 a share, in the final quarter of the previous year. Revenues totaled $4.87 billion, up 8 percent from $4.49 billion. For the year, Dayton's profits were $412 million, or $5.44 a share, up from $410 million, or $5.37 a share. Revenues increased 8 percent, to $14.74 billion from $13.64 billion.

headline: Sallie Mae Offering Totals $650 Million
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $650 million in short-term floating-rate notes due Aug. 8, 1991, through various securities dealers.   Sallie Mae, a federally chartered corporation owned by stockholders, generally issues short-term floating-rate notes every month. It uses the money to buy student loans from banks and other issuers, thereby providing them with money to make more student loans.    The corporation priced the notes yesterday at 100, to yield a variable rate equal to 35 basis points more than the bond-equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill.    Interest on the issue, payable at maturity, will be adjusted the day after each weekly auction of Treasury bills.

headline: Colombia Drug Baron Surrenders Under Offer of Lenient Treatment
abstract: The No. 2 man in the Medellin cocaine cartel surrendered today in exchange for the Government's promise not to extradite him to the United States, where he is wanted on drug charges.   Jorge Luis Ochoa, 41 years old, turned himself in at Caldas, 10 miles south of Medellin, and was jailed in the Medellin suburb of Itagui, court officials said.

headline: Dry California Turns to the Pacific
abstract: With California in the grip of a five-year drought, cities and utility companies in this state are building the nation's first large-scale plants to desalt seawater.    In turning to desalting, cities like Santa Barbara and companies like Southern California Edison are using a technology already extensive in the Middle East and other parts of the world to produce fresh water. Until now the high construction costs and operating costs of such plants made little economic sense in the United States.

headline: Georgia-Pacific Sells French Assets
abstract: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation has completed the sale of its interest in its French operations to the International Paper Company of Purchase, N.Y., for $102 million. The sale had been announced previously.   The transaction includes Georgia-Pacific's interest in Papeteries Etienne, a linerboard and corrugating operation in Arles; Papeteries d'Espaly and Emballages Laurent, two packaging plants at LePuy and Chalon-sur-Saone; and Ets. Charles Grenier and Rhone Valley Packaging, two sheeting operations at Saint-Vallier and Reventin-Vaugris.

headline: Oil Prices Move Higher; Crude for March at $22.04
abstract: The price of oil edged up yesterday as traders continued to fret about the possibility of Israeli retaliation for a fatal Iraqi missile attack on Tuesday.   On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude for March delivery rose 16 cents a barrel yesterday, to $22.04. The spot price of oil in cash transactions had already risen in after-market trading on Tuesday following reports describing the extent of the damage from an Iraqi Scud missile that landed in Tel Aviv.

headline: For Top Utility Official, A Post on the Railroad
abstract: George W. Edwards Jr., who led the United Illuminating Company through its most difficult years as an owner of the troubled Seabrook nuclear plant in New Hampshire, will join the Kansas City Southern Railway Company next month.    Mr. Edwards, 51, will become the president and chief executive of the railroad. He will also be an executive vice prsident of its parent, Kansas City Southern Industries.

headline: Eastern's Rivals Stand to Benefit
abstract: The shutting of Eastern Airlines on Friday night is likely to benefit Delta Air Lines and Pan American World Airways in particular, because they have competed directly with Eastern's largest business, carrying passengers from the Northeast to Atlanta and Florida.   Other airlines will gain fewer passengers but will have the opportunity to expand operations in Florida, Georgia and New York by buying Eastern's gates and landing rights.

headline: Rhode Island Bank Inquiry
abstract: Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun urged on Thursday that an independent prosecutor be appointed to investigate Rhode Island's banking crisis.   "I feel it is dead wrong," he said, "to have multiple investigations."

headline: Cartography: The Limits of Truth
abstract: To the Editor:   This is in response to the letter by Louis Jay Herman ("The Cartographic Underclass," Dec. 12) in which he deals sarcastically with the notion that maps are unfair to third world countries. In the letter he also asks, "Just what is the underlying concept here?"   The underlying concept is an important one in the sociology of knowledge: that truth varies with time, place and vested interests, as well as with technological limits. Since it is hard to show the curved surface of the earth on a flat plane, there are likely to be some distortions. Cartographers have choices.   According to German historian Arno Peters, they have chosen not to focus on prettier shapes, but to underestimate the areas of third world countries. The new world map, produced with the support of the United Nations Development Program, deserves at least some consideration. Although changes in political thinking occur far more slowly than those in the physical sciences, new knowledge makes some people uncomfortable. If those people have power, the innovators had better beware! MARY COHEN Jamaica, N.Y., Dec. 24

headline: Norway's Other Peace Prize Given to Lithuania's Leader
abstract: President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania received a peace prize from the Norwegian public today, on the first anniversary of the Baltic republic's declaration of independence.   The $475,000 special prize was awarded after Norway gave the Nobel Peace Prize to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union last fall.

headline: Angola Accepts Plan to End Its 15-Year War
abstract: The Angolan Government announced today that it had accepted in principle a peace plan to end the 15-year-old civil war against Unita, the United States-backed guerrilla movement led by Jonas Savimbi.    The Angolan News Service said the Government had accepted, with only "slight amendments," a plan outlined by Portuguese, Soviet and American diplomats earlier this month in Portugal. Leaders of the rebel group have said previously they are in broad agreement with the plan for the former Portugese colony.

headline: Trade Talks Are Resumed
abstract: Ten weeks after collapsing over the question of farm subsidies, a crucial round of talks aimed at liberalizing world trade resumed here today, with no new deadline set for conclusion of the four-year-old negotiations.    Arthur Dunkel, the Director General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, told a meeting of the 108-nation Trade Negotiating Committee, which oversees the talks, that it was possible to proceed.     But GATT officials said neither the United States nor the 12-nation European Community would be ready to start discussing substantive questions before June.   Mr. Dunkel said he had not proposed a date for ending the talks because it could take "two or three months" for major nations to agree on one.   The so-called Uruguay Round of trade talks, which began in Uruguay in 1986, fell apart in Brussels last December. Farm exporting nations, led by the United States, clashed bitterly with the European Community on cutting farm subsidies.   The United States said then that it would not return to the talks until Europe changed its position on resisting large cuts in the subsidies. That happened last week, when the community unexpectedly accepted Washington's view on possible ways to resolve the problem.

headline: Gray Flannels or Not, John Major Is Riding the Crest of Popularity in Britain
abstract: Prime Minister John Major has had what the British call "a good war."    He became Prime Minister only three months ago, after his predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, had already set the British war machine in train.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Bozell Inc., will close its Atlanta office, where it handled the Valvoline account, with $15 million to $18 million in billings. The bulk of its regional businesses will be shifted to New York; Alexandria, Va., and Tampa, Fla. Overall billing at the Atlanta office is $30 million annually.

headline: Times Publisher To Be Honored
abstract: The Advertising Council has announced that Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the publisher of The New York Times, will receive its Public Service Award in November.    Ruth A. Wooden, the council's president, said, "In the long litany of Punch Sulzberger's services we are especially proud of what he has given of time and talent to the council." The award will be presented on Nov. 13 at the group's annual dinner.   The Ad Council coordinates the production and distribution of public interest campaigns. Its recent efforts have focused on ways to save gasoline and to prevent people from driving while intoxicated.

headline: Market Place; Nagging Question In Bond Insurance
abstract: WITH investors searching for certainty, bond insurance has become a big business. Last year, about $50 billion principal value of bonds were newly insured, up from $45 billion the previous year. In total, about $450 billion in principal and interest payments have been guaranteed.    But the nagging question about the industry is whether it is, in fact, strong enough to withstand the defaults that could be brought on if there is a depression. There has been a price war in the industry for several years, and that has made some people nervous.

headline: Editors Criticize Picture Limits
abstract: News photographers and photo services have been hampered in attempts to supply pictures of American military action in the Persian Gulf by the close control exerted by the United States military command, photo editors say.    While the ground action has intensified, Pentagon limits on photographers' access to events have often resulted in bland pictures, the editors say.

headline: Aid for Czech Business
abstract: President Bush named directors today for a Government-financed organization to help the growth of private businesses in Czechoslovakia. The directors of the Czech and Slovak-American Enterprise Fund are John R. Petty, former chairman and chief executive of the Marine Midland Bank; David O. Maxwell, former chairman and chief executive of the Federal National Mortgage Association; Julia M. Walsh, managing director of Tucker Anthony Inc.; former Representative Charles Vanik, Democrat of Ohio, and Milan Ondrus, retired vice president of the FMC Corporation.

headline: U.S. Breaks Off Talks With Europeans on Airbus
abstract: Escalating the long-simmering conflict over the Airbus aircraft, the Bush Administration today broke off negotiations with the European Community on aerospace subsidies and announced it was seeking an international judgment on the dispute.    The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said she was asking the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that regulates trade, to set up a three-judge panel to study Washington's complaint that the $237 million in subsidies that the German Government provided to Daimler-Benz A.G. for its work on Airbus airliners violated the GATT subsidies code.

headline: Elite Kenyan Women Avoid a Rite: Marriage
abstract: For generations, marriage in Africa has been a rite never questioned. Now, for more and more of the relatively small numbers of university-educated women like 27-year-old Kay Makuku, marriage is a custom to be avoided.    Miss Makuku, a post-graduate student in French at Nairobi University and a former schoolteacher, sees herself 10 years from now as a single parent, with a male companion but not a husband. It is a choice that many of her female friends over 30, from television producers to professors, have already made.   Other modern-thinking women in urban Africa are delaying marriage. Of the 16 women who graduated from the law faculty at the university here in 1980, more than half remain single.   "Many, many women are not committing themselves to men," said Rosemary Kaduru, a lawyer from the 1980 class. Shift in Attitudes     Such unorthodox attitudes toward marriage are a revolutionary departure for African women, far more dramatic for them than for their American and European counterparts, who were crystalizing similar thoughts two decades ago. And simply put, the disdain toward marriage can be summed up in two words: African men.   "At least our African grandfathers looked after their women," said Miss Makuku, relaxing in her apartment, equipped with a stereo and television. "But now the average man might contribute to the rent but use the rest for mistresses and beer. They drink a lot. I can't imagine anyone beating me up but I talk to some women my age or older and they don't see anything wrong with it."   So far, Africa has produced few standout, publicly known feminists, a word barely in the lexicon. In some countries, like Zimbabwe and Uganda, women appointed to senior positions in government have found themselves free to express the need for an improved status for women.   But those women tread a difficult path. Male chauvinism is ingrained and indeed, codified, in much of African culture. For example, Kenya is one of the few African countries to have a law, passed in 1981, that allows women to inherit and own property, said Mrs. Kaduru, one of the minority of women in her law class to marry. But, she said, so few women knew about the law that many persisted in their beliefs that they did not have property and inheritance rights. Husbands' Restrictions     In a region where statistics are often hard to come by, little hard data exists to document the rebellion against marriage by Africa's young, educated women, whose abilities to articulate their expectations far outweigh their small numbers. The Kenyan Government's Women's Bureau estimates that in 1984, 24 percent of 20- to 24-year-old women had never married; five years later the percentage had risen to 32 percent. Another indicator stands out. The number of university-educated women is increasing. At Nairobi University, a third of the students are women; in some faculties, like law, half the students are women.   And anecdotal evidence abounds among professional women who have been briefly married but find they cannot tolerate the restrictions put on them by their husbands.   "Men are ready to be modern outside their homes," said Martha Njoka, a 33-year-old criminal lawyer with a flourishing practice in Nairobi. "You will find a man so liberal in all his relations except at home. Many will profess the idea but will not treat you as an equal partner. Once you are a Mrs., the husband will treat you as though you are bound to him and the home."   Miss Njoka's live-in relationship with a doctor ended soon after they became married. He could not endure her going out on her own with friends or business associates or to a diplomatic reception, as she did recently. But he was free to go out with his friends, she said. 'I Will Keep My Career'     She does not plan to marry again.    Of course not all educated women in their 20's and 30's are rejecting marriage. Janet Kabeberi Macharia, a 29-year-old lecturer in law who specializes in the law of reproductive rights at the University of Nairobi, said she believed in family and marriage.   "But I have decided to go into it at my own pace, at my own time," said Mrs. Macharia, who married her husband, a 30-year-old business consultant, last year. "I will keep my career and try to be a mother and wife." She has postponed having children until "we get to know each other a bit more."   And, she said, her husband is unusual. Men Seen as Slow to Adapt     "We do go out a lot together," she said. "It pains a lot of people. 'Why should you be with her?' they say to him. The perception is that it is because I'm educated and sit on him."   Some educated African men acknowledge that they have been slow to adapt to the idea of more independence for African women.   "We have been brought up to be like our fathers," said a Nairobi lawyer, who asked not to be identified. "When I came out of university, it was hard for me to adjust to the idea of women having a life of their own, a job of their own."   Gitobu Imanyara, editor of the Nairobi Law Monthly, said most African men expect to keep a mistress or two and for their wife to stay at home when they go out. Men have believed that their obligations end with provision of money for food and school fees.   An Inferiority Complex?     "There is an inferiority complex among these men that an educated woman who can do what he can do is a threat," said Mr. Imanyara, who was interviewed before he was arrested on Friday by the Kenyan authorities. Mr. Imanyara's law magazine had published the manifesto of a new opposition party in defiance of the country's one-party state.   The question of relations between the sexes in Africa is something that Miss Makuku, an outgoing woman who plays tennis and squash, has thought about not only in relation to her life but in her studies. She is pursuing the subject in her postgraduate thesis about the portrayal of male characters in the literature of two female Senegalese writers.   Miss Makuku, whose experience has been broadened by two trips to Europe on scholarships to study French, has had several boyfriends.    To remain unmarried, Miss Makaku says, African women must have economic independence and a decent standard of living, a goal that the vast majority of them cannot achieve. But women's organizations, including the Kenyan Women's Lawyers Association, that are dedicated to helping women improve their status have developed in Kenya.    Miss Makaku manages to support herself on her limited income. Through the teacher's credit union, she borrowed for the luxuries of her life: a late-model television, tape deck, refrigerator, stove and a few pieces of simple but attractive furniture.   But Miss Makuku said it would be difficult to have children without the financial support of a man.    Most of her successful single friends had decided by the age of 35 to have children without getting married, she said. There were several avenues. The first was to have a child by a younger man, which many women find acceptable because a younger man is less likely to boss them around, Miss Makuku said. The second was to have a child by a married man.   "Some choose to become mistresses," said Miss Makuku. "It is a paradox because they have rejected African men" for marriage because of their mistresses.

headline: New Peace Plan at U.N.
abstract: Cuba and Yemen circulated a new peace plan today as the United Nations Security Council met behind closed doors in its first review of the Persian Gulf war.    The latest peace proposal calls for a halt to allied bombing and the appointment of a Security Council commission to examine ways of ending the fighting, diplomats said. The proposed commission would report back to the 15-member Council by Feb. 25, they said.

headline: People
abstract: * Barbara J. Fallon, Dominick Maiolo and Michael A. Rizzo have been named vice presidents at Leo Burnett Company, Chicago. * Jerry Acciaioli has been appointed vice president-corporate new business at Campbell-Mithun-Esty, Minneapolis.

headline: Pinelands Chairman Is Finding 'Adventure'
abstract: Lawrence P. Fraiberg, with a long broadcasting career behind him, is now the head of a new company called Pinelands Inc., owner of WWOR-TV, a independent television station broadcasting in the New York area.    "This is the first time I've been a C.E.O. of a publicly held company and it's really an adventure," the 69-year-old Mr. Fraiberg said yesterday. "This is what everyone needs this time in their life -- a whole new career."

headline: Tech Notes; Fine-Tuning the Search for Oil
abstract: Time was, a gusher erupted over the field when oil was struck. Not so anymore. Low pressure in older fields, especially in the United States, has made the gusher a thing of the past. Now, oil is much more likely to seep from small scattered reservoirs through tiny root-like cracks in porous rock. Find the cracks, find the oil. To do that, Atlas Wireline Services in Houston, a joint venture of Litton Industries Inc. and Dresser Industries Inc., has designed a circumferential borehead imaging device to produce sharp electronic images of the inside of the well hole at depths up to 30,000 feet and temperatures up to 350 degrees Farenheit.   The device can be attached to a cable and dropped to the bottom of the hole or, in holes that have horizontal turns, pushed along with sections of drilling pipe. As the device is slowly pulled to the surface, three rotating transducers emit a series of sharp, high-frequency acoustical shocks. The sounds bounce off the rocks, return to the transducers and then are sent to a computer and tape recorder at the surface of the well. Rocks of different porosity cause the sounds to return at different rates. These differences can be measured and converted into an image of the inside of the well that can show features as small as 1/ 100 of an inch, the size of the cracks that convey oil. Once isolated, the oil find can be tapped.

headline: Mingo Doing Well Despite a Tough Year
abstract: WHEN Frank Mingo died a little more than a year ago, many people in the advertising industry wondered whether the agency he founded, the Mingo Group, would survive.    It has been a tough year for the Mingo Group, one of the best-known minority-oriented agencies, but it has managed to do well. Instead of losing some blue-chip clients that had close ties to Mr. Mingo, like Miller Brewing and General Motors, the agency has held its leading accounts and picked up several small assignments, including work for the National Basketball Association and Joseph E. Seagram & Sons' Crown Royal whisky.

headline: Gorbachev Sees Threat to Soviet Status
abstract: Warning that the Soviet Union's reputation as a superpower was at stake, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev tonight appealed to the nation to doom the separatist republics to failure by strongly supporting him in his March 17 referendum on the necessity of preserving the country.    "All my convictions are based on preservation of the union," Mr. Gorbachev said in a 15-minute national television address that amounted to his strongest appeal yet for approval of the referendum.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: INTERNATIONAL    The Bush Administration is asking Congress to authorize the Export-Import Bank to underwrite sales of military goods for the first time since 1974. After a long and divisive internal debate, the White House came down on the side of military contractors, whose business has been lagging. The proposal comes as the Administration is trying to halt the proliferation of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons.  [ Page A1. ]   The U.S. Rice Council reluctantly canceled an exhibition of American rice after Japan's agriculture minister threatened the exhibitors with arrest. The latest twist in the two countries' continuing trade disputes had seemed, for most of last week, like nothing more than an amusing standoff.  [ D1. ]

headline: Community Newspapers Preparing for Chapter 11
abstract: Community Newspapers Inc. announced yesterday that it would seek to reorganize under bankruptcy protection. It also ended a four-month offer to repurchase some of its bonds after some bondholders refused to accept the proposal.   The company, which operates several newspapers in the Midwest and which was once part of Ralph Ingersoll 2d's chain of highly leveraged newpaper companies, said its newspaper subsidiaries would continue operating and meeting their obligations to suppliers, advertisers and customers. The subsidiaries will not seek bankruptcy protection.

headline: Hollywood Park Dispute
abstract: The battle for control of the company that operates the Hollywood Park race track here took a new twist today when Marjorie L. Everett, the chairman and chief executive, said she wanted to bring in Stephen A. Wynn, the casino executive, to replace her.    The board of the Hollywood Park Operating Company said it would vote on Thursday to name Mr. Wynn to the new posts. He is chairman and controlling shareholder of Golden Nugget Inc., which operates the Golden Nugget and Mirage hotels.    The move was intended to help Ms. Everett in her fight against a dissident shareholder, R. D. Hubbard.    Mr. Hubbard, who owns 9.9 percent of Hollywood Park, and Ms. Everett are scheduled to wage a proxy fight at the annual meeting on Feb. 18.

headline: Jobless Drop in Europe
abstract: The European Community's unemployment rate was 8.3 percent in 1990, down from 8.9 percent in 1989, the community's statistics agency, Eurostat, reported today. The 1990 jobless rate was down 23 percent from a high of 10.8 percent in the 1984-86 period. Spain's 1990 rate of 16.1 percent was the highest of the 12 European Community nations. Luxembourg and Germany had the lowest rates.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Troops; War Cries and Whistling in the Dark
abstract: Capt. Mike Sanders of the Army's Second Armored Division used the tip of his bayonet to draw sharp, forceful lines in the dirt floor of his tent, mapping out what he said would be a land war of extraordinary violence.   "Our mission is a destruction mission," he said. "We are to expend the ammunition and time it takes to destroy the enemy forces."

headline: Fall in Yields Is Slowing
abstract: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report declined for the week ended yesterday. It was the third consecutive week that they had dropped, but the rate of decline appeared to ease considerably.    Analysts at Donoghue's said the aggressive easing of short-term rates by the Federal Reserve had ended, with analysts again predicting the economy was headed for a soft landing if there are no unexpected setbacks in the Persian Gulf.  May Seek Higher Returns     Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist, noted that while many investors had moved their money into money market funds and Treasury securities, he expected cash flows into the funds to dissipate. As yields fall and the spread between the money market funds and other types of investments widen, he said, some investors may seek higher returns in certificates of deposit, bonds or stocks.

headline: Business Diary/February 17-22
abstract: THE ECONOMY Gasoline Prices on the Downswing, but for How Long? Gasoline and crude oil prices have fallen to their lowest levels since shortly before Iraq marched into Kuwait. An American Automobile Association survey released last week said that gasoline had declined to $1.135 a gallon, about the same price as before the war but for a 5-cent-a-gallon Federal tax increase. Oil, driven down by peace proposals, closed on Friday at $17.91 a barrel, less than half its October peak. But don't start celebrating just yet. Even some of those analysts who expect crude oil to stay low expect gasoline costs to rise. Iraqi and Kuwaiti refineries have been ruined in the war; the Iraqis were apparently torching Kuwaiti facilities at the end of the week. Even the Saudis have to import fuel to supply the military, and gasoline demand will rise more rapidly once the American economy revives. "There will be ample crude for refiners, but not adequate refining capacity for consumers," said Alfred O. Munk, a consultant and the former foreign affairs manager for the Amoco Corporation. "Crude," he pointed out, "is not what you consume." The Inflation Numbers Game A recession that was supposed to extinguish inflation has still left the pilot light burning. Consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January, eight-tenths without food and energy. Economists, who can no more take a figure at face value than Ella Fitzgerald can leave a melody unadorned, went to work explaining away the news. Look at higher liquor taxes, increased auto costs, rising apparel prices, other one-time events, they said. But a few saw underlying pressures, especially the 6 percent annual-rate increase in service costs, which account for about half of the inflation index. In dousing inflation, said William C. Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman Sachs, "a short, shallow recession isn't going to give you much benefit." Greenspan Confused? Let nobody out-worry Alan Greenspan about the Persian Gulf war and the credit crunch. In addressing two Congressional committees last week, he rehearsed his forecast of a mild recession, but then added more fine print than your typical car-rental agreement. Some of those clauses concerned the war, but most troubling, he said, was the Fed's inability to prompt banks to resume lending to their creditworthy customers. If Mr. Greenspan usually appears as a determined general unwilling to reveal his battle plans, last week he all but confessed to confusion. He seemed uncertain about whether to maintain or lower interest rates, adding that others at the Fed are divided. Some of his colleagues counsel patience, anticipating a rebound; others have a darker outlook than his. Here Comes Unicode The United Nations' near-unanimity on Kuwait was unusual, but the computer industry's agreement to use a common digital code is truly extraordinary. The usually fractious companies, including International Business Machines, Apple, Sun and Microsoft, hope for Unicode to become a global standard representing letters and characters in every language. Companies could then more readily write software to work in a variety of languages, and international computer communications would flow more smoothly. "It's a lot more meaningful than Esperanto, because we're dealing with computers, not people" said Esther Dyson, publisher of the newsletter Release 1.0. She added that the third world would benefit the most. "It's like affirmative action for smaller nations," she said.  Where a Bank Finds Cash Banks may be where they keep the money, but when Citicorp itself needs money, it looks to the Middle East. Prince al-Waleed bin Talal agreed last week to invest $590 million in Citicorp. He had accumulated 4.9 percent of the company's stock last year, so his latest purchase could give him 14.9 percent if he converts his new preferred stock to common. He said in 1988 that he "would love to be a corporate raider"; just a joke, his aides now explain. Exactly where all the money is coming from is unclear. Prince Waleed is indeed a nephew of Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, but he had to put up his house as collateral to get a loan from Citicorp just a decade ago. Where Citicorp will find even more badly needed capital might soon become clear. Other possible sources include the displaced royal rulers of Kuwait. "You go wherever there is a lot of spare cash," said James E. Akins, a consultant and former Ambassador to Saudi Arabia. Even though the Saudi rulers are temporarily pinched, he said, "There is a lot of spare cash in the Arabian peninsula." COMPANIES   Tisch Takes the Giants  Yes, it's tough to get season tickets for the New York Giants. But $60 million, or more? Fortunately for Preston Robert Tisch, 50 percent of the Super Bowl winner came with the deal. Mr. Tisch, president of the Loews Corporation, bought half of the team from Tim Mara and two other relatives, leaving the other half in the hands of Tim Mara's uncle, Wellington. Loews owns 22.9 percent of CBS, where Mr. Tisch is a director and his brother, Laurence, is chairman. Mr. Tisch has promised to keep his football investment entirely separate from the network. And it's just as well. If the Giants adopted the same financial machinations as CBS, they might start buying back thousands of season tickets to boost the price of the rest, spin off a quarterback or two and sell Lawrence Taylor to the Japanese.11 Jail for Milken, Hope for Drexel  Michael Milken, the financier who studied at Berkeley in the 1960's, is returning to that area on March 4, this time to prison. Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood, who sentenced him to 10 years on securities charges in November, recommended last week that he serve 36 to 40 months before he is eligible for parole. Cooperation with investigators, said to be asking him about failed savings and loans that bought "junk bonds," might get him out earlier. Even without Mr. Milken, Drexel Burnham Lambert might rise again. Drexel convinced its creditors and litigants last week to tentatively accept a fraction of what they claim -- in this case, $2 billion out of $20 billion. A Federal Judge said enough money should be left to allow Drexel to emerge from bankruptcy.  Outlook for Airlines  The Federal Aviation Administration predicted on Friday that the nation's airlines will recover their financial health once the recession and the gulf war end. The agency predicted stable or lower fuel prices, although some analysts disagree. James B. Busey, the F.A.A.'s administrator, rejected the airlines' calls for Government aid. Quincy Jones, Inc.  Bertlesmann and Time Warner may think of themselves as thriving media conglomerates, but the best example might be Quincy Jones. On Wednesday his "Back on the Block" album won six Grammy Awards, as many gold-plated horns as he could carry, bringing his total to 25. After last year's Milli Vanilli embarrassment, the award-givers can be assured that Mr. Jones himself originated, arranged, conducted and produced the album. He is best known as a record producer and arranger for musicians from Duke Ellington through Frank Sinatra to Michael Jackson. He has also written the scores for 37 movies and produced several television shows and films -- convincing Steven Spielberg to direct and Oprah Winfrey to act in "The Color Purple." He has his own record label, and a major stake in a New Orleans television station that he oversees. His television and movie company, Quincy Jones Productions, has received so many uninvited visitors that he had to take its address off its business cards. Amgen's New Drug  The Food and Drug Adminstration gave Amgen Inc. approval for a genetically engineered medicine to help cancer chemotherapy patients fight off infections. Analysts expect the drug to become one of the biotechnology industry's best sellers. INTERNATIONAL   Another Step Toward Capitalism  If socialism, as many in Russia like to say, is the long, hard path from capitalism to capitalism, the Soviets took another halting step in that direction last week. The Government announced that prices would increase at least 60 percent on every basic need except fuel, medicine and vodka. The Soviets are trying to use central commands instead of free markets to reduce shortages, prune subsidies and set prices to more closely reflect production costs. Herbert Levine of the University of Pennsylvania, a specialist in the Soviet economy, questioned how much difference new state prices would make. "In many of these markets, the official channels are no longer the major suppply channels," he said. In his view, barter, private markets, the shadow economy and even commodity exchanges are acclimatizing many Soviets to more capitalist ways. Slovenia's Secession  The Slovenian Parliament's declaration last week of autonomy from the rest of Yugoslavia only ratifies a status that Slovenia's economy has already achieved. Closer to Munich and Milan than to Belgrade, Slovenia has 8.5 percent of the nation's people but about 20 percent of its hard-currency earnings from exports. The Slovenes regard Serbia, the dominant Yugoslav republic, as a flabby cousin wedded to the Cyrillic alphabet and Soviet ways. The Serbs regard the Slovenes as Mercedes-driving snobs. Joseph Tragert, an economist at the Planecon consulting firm in Washington, says that Croatia's eagerness to follow Slovenia out the door might well ignite a civil war because Croatia has a large Serbian minority. "It's probably the end of Yugoslavia," Mr. Tragert said of the Slovenian stand. But like the restive Baltic nations, he added, Slovenia and Croatia are probably too small to thrive as independent states. They might choose a loose confederation instead.

headline: Philip Morris to Enlarge Plant
abstract: The Philip Morris Companies, the maker of Marlboro cigarettes and the world's largest packaged-goods company, expects to announce as early as today that it plans to spend $400 million to expand by nearly 50 percent the capacity of its cigarette factory in North Carolina.   The huge capital expenditure at the plant, already among the world's largest, is unusual in an industry with a declining market. Cigarette makers normally spend little on expansion and simply use profits to finance non-cigarette acquisitions.   The plant will have the latest automated equipment, including an experimental production line that spits out 10,000 cigarettes a minute.    The plant is in Cabarrus County, N.C., about 20 miles north of Charlotte. It already has a production capacity of 85 billion cigarettes a year, and the new investment would add 40 billion.   Philip Morris will pay for the capital spending with cash flow and existing lines of credit.    William I. Campbell, president and chief executive of Philip Morris U.S.A., said the majority of the added capacity was to meet surging demand abroad, especially in Japan, Korea and Hong Kong. The new production will also go, however, to the domestic market, where Philip Morris enjoys the leading market share of more than 40 percent.   In the United States, Philip Morris makes a pretax profit of more than 40 cents for each dollar's worth of cigarettes sold. In Japan, where trade liberalization talks have led to greater sale of foreign cigarettes, the company earns nearly as much.   Philip Morris plans to spend the $400 million to enlarge the plant by more than a third, to 2.46 million square feet. The expansion would add 660 jobs to the current 1,800 and $20 million to the $70 million payroll.

headline: Sale of Most Ambase Assets Approved by Shareholders
abstract: After some nail-biting delays and last-minute lobbying, shareholders and note holders of the Ambase Corporation have approved the sale of most of the company's assets to a Scandinavian investment group. The assets include the Home Group of insurance companies and the Wall Street firm of Gruntal & Company.   In balloting results announced yesterday, a thin 54 percent majority of Ambase shareholders endorsed the sale to a group led by Trygg-Hansa Holding, Sweden's No. 2 insurer, for about $839 million in cash and assumed debts. The assumption of other contingent liabilities and administrative costs brought the total package to $970 million, a company spokesman said.

headline: Albanians Still Stream Into Greece Though Athens Asks Them to Stop
abstract: Hundreds of Albanian political refugees continued to pour into Greece today, despite appeals from the Greek Government that they stop coming.   A Government spokesman, Byron Polydoras, said, "The flow of refugees is now somewhat under control, but the problem is by no means solved."

headline: A Tax Program May Be Expert, But the User?
abstract: Melvin L. Steiner, a San Carlos, Calif., accountant, likes to tell about a client who decided to save money by preparing his own tax return on a personal computer.   Not long after buying a tax program, the client was back in Mr. Steiner's office, seeking advice on how to use it and help in understanding some of the more arcane tax laws. Ultimately, Mr. Steiner said, it cost his client more than if he had just supplied his financial records.

headline: In Latvia, Even Many Russians Vote Independence
abstract: The Baltic republics were ebullient today after new plebiscite demonstrations of the popular will to be free of the Soviet Union, a will that included significant support from people of the Russian minority, who had been heavily lobbied by the Kremlin to stand by the union.    Here in the Latvian capital, people of Latvian stock make up less than a third of the population, yet the independence measure was supported by 60 percent of the city's voters as large numbers of yes votes were cast by people of Russian and other non-Latvian stock.

headline: Guilty Plea in Arms Deal
abstract: A former marketing executive for the Unisys Corporation admitted today that he had conspired to obtain secret Pentagon procurement information while his company was competing for a Defense Department contract.   The executive, Robert C. Elfering, who had been a marketing manager for the Unisys Defense Systems division in Eagan, Minn., pleaded guilty to conspiracy to defraud the Government.

headline: Hewlett's Sprightly New Mood
abstract: A series of anonymous advertisements ran in newspapers around the country last week. "57 MIPS, under $12K," said one. And at the bottom in parentheses it added, "If you guess Sun, you guess wrong."    The teaser ads, referring to new a computer able to execute 57 milllion instructions a second and costing about $12,000, were an unsual step for the Hewlett-Packard Company, known for solid engineering but an almost complete lack of marketing flair.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.75-9   8.75-9   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   6.00   6.01   7.75        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.76   5.76   7.80        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.79   5.79   7.81        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.93   7.93   8.67        30-YR. TREAS. headline: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; The Army Commander Is Sidelined for Surgery
abstract: Before what may well be the biggest battle of his career, Lieut. Gen. John J. Yeosock, commander of all Army operations in the war against Iraq, was evacuated from Saudi Arabia today for surgery in Germany.    Army officials refused to describe the general's ailment. There had been earlier reports that General Yeosock, 53 years old, was suffering from pneumonia, although those reports could not be confirmed.

headline: Rights Group Charges Abuses by the Kuwaitis
abstract: More than 2,000 people, mostly Palestinians, have been rounded up by the Kuwaiti military since the Iraqis were driven from this country, detained, tortured and in several cases summarily executed, according to a report from a human rights organization.    The preliminary report, on a 12-day study done by Middle East Watch, an affiliate of the New York-based Human Rights Watch, said there was growing evidence of human-rights violations, particularly among the large Palestinian population in the capital.

headline: Design for a Post-Cold War Company
abstract: Japan's leading microelectronics companies are opening state-of-the-art research and development laboratories in the United States and are trying to steal away America's best scientists. Is the American computer industry -- the last bastion of American technological superiority -- about to succumb to the Japanese threat? A number of analysts think so. But it is not the Japanese we should be afraid of. We are our own worst enemy.   American companies, held hostage by the illusion that breakthroughs are the key to technological superiority and industrial competitiveness, have failed to employ a winning formula. To be competitive, big new ideas must be turned into products and that requires an ability to follow through. This is where we, as an industrial nation, fail. And this is where the Japanese succeed.

headline: BankAmerica Shows Interest in Failed Units
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that it was interested in acquiring the three failed banks of the Bank of New England Corporation and "is in discussion" with the F.D.I.C., which took control of the banks on Sunday.    The opportunity to acquire the largest branch network in New England was attractive enough for BankAmerica, based in San Francisco, that it began talking with Federal regulators about an acquisition before the three banks were put under Government control.

headline: So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual: Steel; Looking for Help In Durable Goods
abstract: Steel industry executives said the war in the Middle East would not affect their business prospects in the near term.   "Very little of what we produce goes into war materials," said Robert Lefley, a spokesman with Inland Steel Industries. "The biggest impact will be what it does to the overall economy and consumer confidence, which will enable consumers to buy durable goods."

headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: The Saudis; Boom Town in Desert: Expansion Amid the Crisis
abstract: The first sign that something was not quite right here in Saudi Arabia's petrochemical heartland was the birds.    A cage containing two brightly colored parakeets suddenly appeared one day near the entry to the lobby of a hotel soon after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last August. Most guests thought the pleasant chirping was intended to offset the mood of panic and gloom that had gripped the city immediately after the invasion. But the hotel employees, borrowing an old coal-mining practice, placed the birds in the lobby hoping that in the event of a gas attack, the birds would die first, alerting the staff and guests.

headline: 7 Years After Killings, Grenada Awaits Ruling
abstract: When Velma Hylton arrived from her native Jamaica in 1984 to oversee the trial of a group of Marxist hard-liners for the killing of Maurice Bishop, revolutionary Grenada's popular young Prime Minister, her widely shared expectation was that the case would be quickly resolved.   Instead, as Mrs. Hylton's continuing residence here as director of public prosecution attests, the legal battle over the killings that led six days later to the United States' invasion of this island in 1983 has dragged on to become one of the longest, most complicated and costliest cases in Commonwealth history.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Wishner-Cody Corporate Communications Inc., New York, and Hill & Knowlton Inc., New York, have formed a cooperative working relationship. Under the agreement, Wishner-Cody will assist Hill & Knowlton with sports marketing, management consulting and publishing projects. In return, Hill & Knowlton will provide Wishner-Cody with access to its resources in the international public relations field.

headline: Strife Empties South African Village
abstract: This village in the rolling Marico hills near Botswana seems a picture postcard of bucolic tranquillity, with shade trees to ward off the sun, green pastures for livestock and comfortable concrete houses built with the remittances of migrant workers employed elsewhere in South Africa.   But Braklaagte lies at the center of a struggle between the homeland of Bophuthatswana, which claims sovereignty over the village, and the African National Congress, which has come forward to champion the claim of its residents that they belong to South Africa.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Colonial Cos., Columbia, S.C., and its principal unit, Colonial Life and Accident Insurance Co., named Stephen G. Hall chief executive. * Cygnet Systems Inc., San Jose, Calif., a manufacturer of jukeboxes, named Tyler Wilkins vice president of engineering.

headline: Aides Urge U.N. Chief to Offer Iraq Mideast Talks if It Quits Kuwait
abstract: Senior United Nations officials have urged Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, now on his way to Baghdad, to offer President Saddam Hussein a possible way out of the Persian Gulf crisis by asking him for a firm pledge to leave Kuwait immediately in return for an international conference to address the Palestinian question.    But no governments have yet supported such a proposal to test the Iraqi leader's repeated hints that he wants to exchange Kuwait for a Middle East peace conference. The Bush Administration, in particular, remains officially opposed to any such "linkage" between the two issues.

headline: Israel's Debt Up $260 Million
abstract: Israel's foreign debt rose by $260 million in 1990, to $24.1 billion, reversing a decline since 1987, the Bank of Israel said on Thursday.    The central bank said the turnaround came in the last quarter, when heavy private- sector demand for foreign credit increased the debt by $500 million.

headline: New York City Begins Campaign on Condoms
abstract: The New York City Department of Health is hoping that the image of a group of smiling teen-agers batting around an inflated condom like a balloon will persuade sexually active teens to be cautious.   The image is the centerpiece of an ad campaign that the department introduced this week on 100 billboards throughout the city. The campaign, which will also appear in subway cars and in magazines, urges sexually active youths to use condoms to guard against AIDS, sexually transmitted diseases and unwanted pregnancies.   The ads were designed and produced by the department, whose spokeswoman, Margaret L. Karanjai, said the message of the image was: "When you play, play responsibly. That's what it means. But we hope they'll wait as long as possible."    But the Rev. Gerald Murray of the Nativity of Our Blessed Lady Church, a Roman Catholic church in the Baychester section of the Bronx, quickly objected to the campaign.    "I find that kind of advertising in incredibly bad taste," Father Murray said. "It gives official sanction to promiscuity."    One ad carries the theme line "If you're going to do it, do it right. Use a condom." Another advises: "Condoms. Play with them, but don't play around with them."   Ms. Karanjai said of the campaign: "We are charged with protecting the health of New Yorkers, and we are very concerned about the health of our youth. Whether we like it or not, 80 percent of New York teens are sexually active by the time they reach 19 years of age."

headline: Under Brennan's Leadership
abstract: Aug. 8, 1990: Edward A. Brennan replaced Michael Bozic as chief executive of the Sears Merchandise Group. Sept. 14: Consolidated various management jobs at Sears Tower and Offered buyouts to 600 people. Sept. 24: Reduced catalogue unit by 213 people. Dec. 5: Froze 1991 salaries at current levels for 20,000 non-hourly employees. Jan. 3, 1991: Confirmed that 21,000 jobs at 863 retail stores would be eliminated by June. Jan. 10: Announced that 47 McKids stores would be closed by the end of the first quarter. Jan. 30: Addressed rumors about the catalogue business, saying, "Reports that we have decided to sell or close our catalogue business are false." Feb. 11: Announced that job cuts in his group would reach 33,000 by year-end.

headline: Fax Displacing Manhattan Bike Couriers
abstract: They whooshed through the streets of Manhattan, members of a mobile cottage industry born of the incompatibility of big-city gridlock and the need to get important papers from one office to another right away. They were bicycle messengers, fearless and feared as they raced through red lights, around vehicles and sometimes into pedestrians.   But now the messengers have largely disappeared, victims of a speedier service they cannot match -- the facsimile machine -- and a business requirement they cannot meet -- insurance.

headline: The Best of Breakthroughs
abstract: To the Editor:   "Emulating the Best of the Best" (Dec. 30), documents well the approaches American businesses are taking to their problems. Unfortunately, it also demonstrates how American businesses will continue in the future to lag behind global competitors if benchmarking remains the approach of choice.   Learning about the best of the best technology and systems is always desirable. But copying what the best are doing is a mistake of the first order. The Japanese in the 1950's and 1960's "learned" a great deal about the best of the best American automobile manufacturers. They obviously did not copy what Americans were doing. The Japanese designed their automobile manufacturing systems with "break through thinking" -- install a system that is as close as possible to an "ideal." Anyone who has visited both Japanese and American automobile manufacturers recognizes the vast differences: the Japanese factory needs much less space, has virtually no storage capacity, permits great flexibility, etc. They converted the knowledge into practice most effectively.   Companies trying to emulate the best of the best (whether a competitor or not) are just playing a game of catching up. Assuming they were able to install the "best of the best" tomorrow, what makes anyone think even noncompetitors will not be further ahead at that time? It is just insufficient to claim that "our system is as good as the Japanese (or whatever company)."   The principles of "break through thinking" make this quite clear. The uniqueness principle points out that each organization, setting, and time is different if for no other reason than the fact the people are always different. Imposing solutions from somewhere else automatically creates huge problems and difficulties in the adaptation process. The "solution after next" principle points out the necessity of using what answers you think you may have in, say, five years as the guide in developing today's solution. There is no such thing as "the best." The solution after next builds in the directions of continuing change at the same time that creative solutions are being developed for today. The systems principle provides a framework of elements and dimensions to assure thoroughness and completeness while assessing consequences of actions that are being proposed.    Benchmarking generates a false sense of catching up, but the quarry it chases gets further ahead. American businesses instead need to do leapfrogging. Break-through thinking shows them how to this in their planning, designing, improving and problem solving. GERALD NADLER  Los Angeles, Calif., Jan. 11  The author holds the I.B.M. chair in engineering management at the University of Southern California.
