headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday   None  Tuesday   Durable Goods . . . Feb. Wednesday   G.N.P. . . . 4th Qtr.  Thursday   Personal Income . . . Feb. Friday  Leading Indicators . . . Feb.  New-Home Sales . . . Feb.  New-Home Prices . . . Feb.  Farm Prices . . . March

headline: War Summary
abstract: THE MYSTERY FLIGHT TO IRAN The unexplained flight of Iraqi warplanes to Iran continued on a large scale. Pentagon officials said more than 80 aircraft landed at various airfields. Iran vowed to impound them for the duration of the war, but the officials questioned Teheran's intentions. HUSSEIN GRANTS INTERVIEW In an interview with Peter Arnett of the Cable News Network, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said that "if Iraq uses oil for self-defense," it was justified. The journalist also quoted Mr. Hussein as saying that Iran was offering sanctuary to the Iraqi planes in a gesture of Muslim solidarity. STOPPING THE OIL SPILL U.S. and Saudi officials said the flow of crude from offshore Kuwaiti sources was virtually halted by the weekend's precision bombing. But they said the slick left by some 11 million barrels of spilled oil still threatened ecological disaster. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: The Pentagon listed 21 American casualties as of yesterday, consisting of seven wounded and 14 missing or taken prisoner, a fate shared by 12 allied airmen. Aircraft: The loss of a Harrier jet of the Marine Corps brought the number of American aircraft shot down to 11 in 12 days of raids on Iraqi targets. Seven allied aircraft also were lost. IRAQI FORCES Troops: There was no current information on military casualties. Iraq informed the United Nations yesterday that at least 324 civilians died in air raids, 416 more were wounded and religious and cultural institutions were destroyed or damaged as well. Many of the casualties occurred Jan. 21, when bombs struck two towns south of Baghdad, Iraq said. Aircraft: In addition to the planes at Iranian airfields, the Pentagon counted 26 Iraqi aircraft shot out of the sky and 24 more confirmed to have been destroyed on the ground as of yesterday.

headline: Harboring of Iraqi Planes by Iran Calls Its Neutrality Into Question
abstract: The flight of more than 80 Iraqi planes to Iran has raised urgent questions in the Bush Administration about Iran's intentions and avowed neutrality in the Persian Gulf war.    The nature and scale of the flights strongly suggest advance Iranian approval. Iran has said it intends to keep the aircraft grounded until the war ends, but there is concern in the Administration about that commitment and puzzlement over Iran's motivations in offering a friendly hand to Iraq. The two countries fought a bitter war from 1980 to 1988 that began when Iraq invaded Iran.

headline: IN OTHER SECTIONS
abstract: CAMPUSES DIVIDED In New Orleans, students at Xavier University are angry about the war, in striking contrast to their neighbors at Tulane University.  Page A12.    THE BIBLIOGRAPHY A listing of books on the Persian Gulf war, on the area's history and on past military campaigns. Books of the Times, page C26.

headline: Market Place; String of Dow Losses: Sign of an Off Year?
abstract: With worries growing that no peaceful resolution is possible in the Mideast, the stock market has gotten off to its second-worst start in history.   Only in 1978, when a plunging dollar and fears of rampant inflation were scaring investors, has the Dow Jones industrial average started off on such a downbeat. That year, it fell 5.6 percent in the first five trading days.

headline: Real Estate; Older Project In New Jersey Rejuvenated
abstract: THE Plaza Complex, a late-1960's office development at the southern tip of New Brunswick's downtown, is among the earliest projects that led to the transformation of the commercial district from a huddle of aging storefronts and littered lots into a thriving business hub. Now the old complex is undergoing its own rejuvenation to remain competitive in today's soft office market.  The owner, the DKM Properties Corporation of Lawrenceville, N.J., is investing $1 million in improvements to the two-building, 212,000-square-foot plaza. It is set on 10 acres on George Street, the main shopping corridor in this city of 42,000, about 40 miles from Manhattan. The company, an active investor in downtown New Brunswick, is making the bulk of the renovations to the 23-year-old Plaza I building with 102,000 square feet in six stories.

headline: Excerpts From an Interview With the Fed's Chairman
abstract: Following are excerpts from an interview with Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board:   Q. Other than lowering interest rates, what weapons do you have in your arsenal to increase the money supply?    A. Well, obviously we have reserve requirements. . . . I did mention that we were looking at other areas of action to get at the credit crunch, but if we were to resolve the credit crunch, in part it would flow through into the money supply.    Q. What about more liberal accounting rules, say on real estate?    A. Well, I don't want to get into that until we've got some specific policies. There are lots of different things that we can do, but I've become convinced that the vast majority of them are infeasible. But some of them may not be. Some of them may be useful and what I'm getting at is it's the credit crunch that we're focusing on. The money supply is symptomatic of the credit crunch. So it's more important that we resolve the credit crunch than the messenger of the credit crunch.    Q. How severe has that crunch been?    A. It's been as severe as any supply-induced constraint ever, other than from policy actions.    Q. You said that there was some slight evidence that the credit crunch was beginning to ease?    A. There is evidence that the better-capitalized banks are increasing their market share relative to those banks which are less well capitalized.    Q. And what's the implication of that?    A. What you need to get the credit crunch unwound is to change the attitudes of those who are concerned about their capital position and have them return to extending loans to their credit-rated customers. If they begin to lose those customers to competitors, which in this case would be the more well-capitalized banks, some banks will then under those conditions begin to start to be more willing to lend to customers.    Q. When will you know?    A. What I've been getting at is that what we know at this stage is the beginning of that process has begun but we don't yet see any evidence of that lending from the less-well-capitalized banks.    Q. How sensitive is the problem to lower interest rates? Would another point on the Fed funds rate encourage those less capitalized banks and make them move?    A. Well, it's obvious that any incentives you can give -- which means in effect opening up profit margins to the banks -- will clearly induce those at the margin who have been disinclined but just barely disinclined to start to lend.    Q. In retrospect, should you have acted sooner to deal with the credit crunch?    A. No. Because if the credit crunch had lasted for six months, its implications on the economy would probably have been very marginal. It is the cumulative effect of the credit crunch that I find increasingly disturbing.    Q. And you didn't think that would happen?    A. Well, no, I didn't. Looking back, I'm not sure that there's very much different that I would have thought personally to do.    Q. The Fed in general and you in particular were getting credit politically for a long time when it looked as if we were going to have a soft landing. Now that it turns out that the landing is a little rockier, why shouldn't you also get the blame?    A. First of all, if you're asking me whether or not that I thought without the Middle East that whether we would have gotten the soft landing. In July, I would have said yes, 50-50, maybe, most probable that we would have gotten a soft landing. The data that we got in for the months of August and September in retrospect, at least as best I can judge it, increased those probabilities. In other words, we knew actually what happened.    Q. Do you mean it increased the probability that you would not have had a recession?    A. Correct.    Q. What is the implication of the fact that so much lending now is going on outside of banks -- in commercial paper, for example? Does it mean the Fed has less influence over macroeconomic policy?    A. No. It does mean, however, that the trend towards the loss of competitive franchises in the commercial banking system has been going on now for quite a number of years. It still exists. There are increasing alternate means, as a result of technology, which can bypass commercial banking to get financing. . . .    So long as we have a monopoly on a major form of asset in the system, claims against the Federal Reserve banks, it is a sufficiently large instrument that we can affect interest rates.    Q. Is there some business that the banks could get into that would really help pay the rent? Wall Street is having enough problems making money in its own lines of endeavor.    A. The time you want to expand powers is when businesses which they might go into are not operating all that well. Because the real dangers to banks is that if you give them powers at a time when the new business in which they go are flourishing, you actually create possibilities that they may overextend themselves. If they succeed in a cautious environment which is weak, they're going to be non-risk-takers. That's what you want as they phase their way into the business.    Q. If everything goes as you expect and hope, would you guess that the recovery would be a strong recovery?   A. I think that it would be moderate. It depends where it starts from. We don't have that much slack in the economy as of now. If the economy slips further, and that of course is not to be ruled out, then the nature of the recovery will be more vigorous. But you cannot have a vigorous recovery from a shallow decline.    Q. And the banks will have to get over their own crisis of confidence in order to have a recovery?    A. Yes, I would say that is a necessary condition.    Q. Would the banking system be better off with a real thorough round of consolidation in one way or another?    A. I would think that there are a number of institutions which probably would be better off if they merged, and there's no question in my mind that some significant, real cost in savings would occur under those conditions. That is talking about individual institutions. But as far as the system as a whole, the basic issue is that we've got a large number of community banks out there who do very well, and they serve their communities in an exceptionally effective manner. When we know that is when big banks try to come in and take their business away, they fail. So, unless you're going to argue that a lot of those community banking institutions are somehow not serving your community or are unprofitable or unsafe and unsound, none of which one can argue, you can't just merely make a generic statement that we should collapse the number of banks. It is true that we should in certain areas and certain individual institutions.

headline: Iraqi Hospitals in Dire Shape, Foreign Doctors Group Finds
abstract: An international team of doctors just returned from Iraq says the clinics and hospitals they visited were desperately short of electricity, medical supplies and water and have been forced to turn away some acutely ill patients.    Two doctors from the humanitarian organization Doctors Without Borders, Reginald Moreels of Belgium and Jacques de Milliano of the Netherlands, described their findings at a news conference here on Friday after a weeklong visit to Iraq.

headline: Layoffs at Aetna
abstract: Layoff notices have started going out to employees of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company as the insurer begins a shrinking of its domestic insurance divisions, a company spokesman, Jon Powell, said. Aetna announced in October that it would eliminate 2,600 positions.

headline: Trump Casino Hires a Rival
abstract: In a move to bolster the performance of his weakest casino here, Donald J. Trump hired the top executive of a rival casino, executives in the Trump Organization said today.   Roger Wagner, the president of the Claridge Casino Hotel, who has kept the Claridge from losing ground in a flat market, was hired to run the Trump Castle casino resort.    Anthony Calandra, the president of the Trump Castle, was moved to an unspecified job in the casino's marketing department, the executives said.   Mr. Wagner was brought in to make the Trump Castle more competitive with its neighbor, Harrah's Marina Hotel Casino, said Ed Tracy, chief of Trump's three Atlantic City casinos. Harrah's has been the industry leader.   Mr. Wagner began his career in 1965 as a desk clerk at the Dunes Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Nev., and worked his way up to an executive position before moving to New Jersey and becoming president of the Claridge in June 1985.    The Trump Castle had gross gambling revenues of $233.9 million in 1990, compared with $264.8 million the year before, according to the the New Jersey Casino Control Commission.

headline: A Club Med Vocation For a New Executive
abstract: Tod Seisser said he had little difficulty adjusting to his new position as senior vice president and associate creative director at Ammirati & Puris, the New York agency he joined this month.   It helped that one of the first responsibilities he inherited was the Club Med account, which involves a bit of tropical travel. Ammirati, which has billings of more than $245 million, also handles accounts for BMW, Schweppes and U.P.S., though Mr. Seisser would not specify his other clients.    Mr. Seisser is perhaps best known for his work at Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver on the Maidenform campaign, which featured the actors Corbin Bernsen and Omar Sharif discussing their feelings about lingerie.   He left the agency to become vice chairman at Keye/Donna/Pearlstein, New York, but he found himself unemployed when the agency closed last year. He did freelance work for nine months before joining Ammirati.    In his new job, Mr. Seisser has already traveled on business to Club Med resorts in St. Lucia, Martinique and Guadeloupe.    "It beats touring a garbage bag factory in Alabama, which I've done, too," Mr. Seisser said.

headline: 4 Belgians Reported Freed By Arabs and Sent to Libya
abstract: Four Belgians held captive for three years and two months by a radical Palestinian guerrilla faction were released today and sent to Libya, where they are to be handed over to their Government, security officials said.    "They have been freed and moved to a friendly Arab country that we trust," Walid Khalid, spokesman for the Fatah Revolutionary Council, said at a news conference at a Palestinian camp in Beirut. He said the four would be handed over to the Belgian Government in the next 48 hours.    Mr. Khalid said the Belgian authorities would pardon a member of the Fatah Council, Nasser Saeed, who is serving a life term in Belgium for an attack 10 years ago on Jewish children in Antwerp.    The Belgians are Emmanuel Hotekins, 45 years old, his wife, Godelieve Kets, 51, and their two children, Laurent, 20, and Valerie, 19.

headline: KUWAIT INVESTS IN HUNGARY CHAIN
abstract: Stripped of its land and its oil, but not of its wealth, Kuwait has embarked on a strategy of investment in Eastern Europe's new and struggling democracies, starting with a modest joint venture agreement signed with Hungary's state-owned gasoline station chain this week.   Kuwait's Oil Minister, Dr. Rashid Salim al-Amiri, said his trip to Budapest was intended as a signal of his country's commitment to the region, as well as a gesture of thanks for Hungary's support of Kuwait during the occupation by Iraq.

headline: The Youth of America Go Home
abstract: To the Editor:   I read Mary Rowland's article ("The Awkward Full Nest Syndrome," Feb. 24) with great interest. While researching material for a book I wrote on family businesses, I found a similar interesting phenomenon taking place these days among young people in connection with their attitude toward "coming home" to their family business just as they are now going back home to live because of the recession and economic conditions.   About five years ago, when a young man or woman graduated from college and was offered the opportunity of joining a successful family business, the chances were they would turn it down in favor of trying to make a financial killing in such areas as Wall Street, the legal profession or financial consulting. Many of them did very well for a couple of years, but with the changing times they now are finding themselves out of jobs or with greatly diminished incomes and have decided that perhaps a solid family business, in a glamour area or not, might offer long-term security -- and would have been the wiser choice right from the start. ARTHUR PINE  New York, Feb. 25

headline: Square D Jumps 39% on French Proposal
abstract: Shares of the Square D Company, the huge electrical equipment manufacturer that received a $1.79 billion takeover bid on Tuesday from Groupe Schneider of France, leaped nearly 39 percent today. But Square D's management indicated they would oppose Schneider's $78-a-share offer when the full board meets within 10 days.   Square D's shares closed at $72.25 each, up $20.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. At one point, the stock traded as high as $75 a share. With a volume of 3.7 million shares, Square D was the Big Board's third- most-active issue, and the 38.9 percent gain was by far the largest.

headline: Navistar to Cut 525 Staff Jobs
abstract: The Navistar International Corporation is eliminating 525 administrative, professional and management jobs as part of a cost-cutting program. The cuts include 263 jobs in the Chicago area, where the truck maker is based; 70 to 80 positions at Navistar's Springfield, Ohio, manufacturing plant, and additional reductions at the company's engineering center in Fort Wayne, Ind., a spokesman, Bill Greenhill, said. Navistar employs about 14,000 people nationwide.   The order "includes positions that have become vacant recently which will not be filled and some early retirements," Mr. Greenhill said.

headline: OPEC Output Shows Rise
abstract: OPEC's oil production rose 300,000 barrels a day to a total of 23.5 million barrels a day in December, a seven-month high, the International Energy Agency reported today.    The 13 member countries of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries also produced 1.9 million barrels a day of natural gas liquids, bringing their total output to 25.4 million barrels a day, the energy agency said in its latest Monthly Oil Market Report.   The 24-member agency, based in Paris, made a copy of its report available in London.   After Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, the international boycott of crude oil from the two nations took about four million barrels a day off the market. But stepped-up production by OPEC members soon made up for the shortfall.

headline: Turner to Offer Global Services
abstract: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. will offer two channels of international programming to 700,000 cable households in 16 countries, starting on Monday.    Turner Network Television Latin America will be offered in three languages -- English, Spanish and Portuguese -- to the Caribbean and Latin America, the company said on Thursday. Cable News Network International will be broadcast in English with the exception of a one-hour daily Spanish newscast.    Cable News Network International will replace the domestic CNN signal. It will be a 24-hour feed with extended international programming.   The new Turner Network Television 24-hour entertainment feed will primarily be a movie service, presenting films from Turner's MGM and pre- 1950 Warner Brothers film libraries.

headline: The Way One Daddy Did It
abstract: To the Editor:    Regarding "Teaching the Kids About Money," Jan. 6: My father never gave me an allowance. My earnings in a choir went straight to the bank. I never saw the cash presents of my confirmation (until I was 21-plus). I did see the vivid black pluses of the old New York Sun stock tables, but I could never convince my hard-working father to invest even in a blue chip industrial stock. Had I been able to, it would have changed my future I think. BENNY GOLUB Brooklyn, N.Y., Feb. 4

headline: Protests by the Serbs Widen in Belgrade
abstract: Anti-Communist protests widened today in the Yugoslav republic of Serbia, and the ruling Socialist Party responded with a huge deployment of police officers on the streets and its own loyalist demonstration of workers.   Slobodan Milosevic, Serbia's President, addressed Parliament today and gave no hint of concessions. He urged Serbs to take their grievances to Parliament, where his party holds an overwhelming majority.

headline: Payment Halt By Hills Stores
abstract: Hills Department Stores Inc., a discount-store chain that has been trying to restructure its debt, said yesterday that it had temporarily stopped paying its creditors for merchandise and would not make the interest payment due on Tuesday on its 11 percent convertible debentures. The junior subordinated debentures have a 30-day grace period on interest payments.   The company, the country's fifth-largest discount retailer, said it had failed to reach agreement on a refinancing package with its bank lenders.    "The banks asked us to find another lender or investor, which would provide additional working capital, before they would go along with an increase in our bank debt now totaling $110 million," said John C. Brouillard, the Hills president.    The merchandise payments being held up exceed $50 million, he said, "but we hope to clear that up sometime next week after some negotiations with a new potential lender."    Hills, based in Canton, Mass., operates more than 200 discount department stores, with sales last year of $2.1 billion and net income of $5.6 million, against $10.6 million the year before. The retailer has been experiencing setbacks from the high costs of an increased expansion program.   Hills's stock dropped 62.5 cents a share today, to $1.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: New Catalogue Position Filled at Bloomingdale's
abstract: Gordon R. Cooke, executive vice president for sales promotion at Bloomingdale's, has been promoted to the new post of chief executive of Bloomingdale's by Mail Ltd., the department-store chain's catalogue division, effective April 15.   The 15-store Bloomingdale's, a division of Federated Stores Inc., said yesterday that John Jay, senior vice president/creative director, would succeed Mr. Cooke as executive vice president for sales promotion, marketing and creative services. Mr. Jay, who is 41, has been at Bloomingdale's since 1979.

headline: Intel to Spend Up to a Billion This Year
abstract: In a bold move to stay ahead of its competitors, the Intel Corporation plans to spend as much as $1 billion on new plants and equipment this year. If it does, that would make it the leader in capital spending among semiconductor companies, American or Japanese.    Gordon Moore, Intel's chairman, told securities analysts at a meeting here today that Intel's capital spending would be $800 million to $1 billion this year, and he said that the company expected to maintain that level for several years. That amount would be up sharply from about $670 million last year and would double the less than $450 million spent the year before that.  'Definitely a First'     "This is definitely a first for a company to spend $1 billion," said Rajiv Chaudhri, semiconductor analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company. Japanese chip makers, he said, are being more conservative in capital spending because they already make too many dynamic random access memory, or D-RAM, chips, their main product. The leading Japanese semiconductor producers are expected to spend $600 million to $800 million this year, he said.

headline: Salvador Guerrillas Pledge Not to Disrupt Next Election
abstract: In a fundamental policy shift, Salvadoran guerrilla leaders have ordered their followers not to interfere with voting in their country's municipal and legislative elections, scheduled for March 10.    The announcement of the new policy, made here Thursday night by commanders of the Faribundo Marti National Liberation Front, marks the first time in the history of the decade-old guerrilla coalition that it has permitted Government-held elections to go forward without determined and often bloody interference.

headline: Carter Hawley Plan
abstract: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the West Coast department store chain that filed for protection from creditors in bankruptcy court earlier this month, received court approval for its full $250 million financing arrangment from Chemical Bank. The company said the financing would help to keep its stores full of merchandise.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Strategy; Iraq: Hidden Cards?
abstract: Is Saddam Hussein playing possum? If so, what does that portend for the course of the war in the Persian Gulf? A week after allied bombers opened the campaign to oust Iraq from Kuwait, those are the most pressing questions facing American strategists.    Iraqi air bases, control posts, troop units and supply lines have been heavily damaged, according to witnesses and allied assessments. Enemy radar operations are said to have dropped off. The allies say their losses have been tiny.

headline: Your Own Account; 'Tis the Season to Get Divorced
abstract: Many couples with troubled marriages, who managed to get through the holidays for the sake of the family, are probably deciding at about this point to throw in the towel and get a divorce.   "Christmas and Thanksgiving are family holidays and such tension builds up," said Stuart B. Walzer, a divorce lawyer with Walzer & Gabrielson in Los Angeles. "There is a surge of business in January and February when people say: 'I just can't live this way any longer.' "

headline: 1990 Called Wall St.'s Worst Year
abstract: Wall Street firms lost as much as $500 million in 1990, the worst annual earnings performance by the securities industry in history, according to a preliminary estimate by the industry's trade association.    The estimate, made by the Securities Industry Association in a report sent this month to the heads of securities firms, is the starkest evidence to date of the economic tumult that has gripped Wall Street.

headline: P.L.O. Pledges to Stop Rocket Raids on Israel
abstract: The Palestine Liberation Organization said today that it would stop rocket attacks against Israel from southern Lebanon and would use other means to assist Iraq in the Persian Gulf war.   A P.L.O. spokesman in Sidon, 25 miles south of here, said the missiles had proved to be counterproductive. "The adverse effects outweighed achievements," the spokesman said.    Lebanese radio stations said the P.L.O. move was intended to pave the way for the deployment of the Lebanese Army in southern Lebanon.    Earlier today, rival guerrillas fought for several hours with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades at the Ain Hilwe Palestinian district in the south. The clashes were between Al Fatah, the mainstream group of Yasir Arafat, and the Fatah Revolutionary Council, a breakaway group led by Abu Nidal, who is wanted worldwide for terrorist activity.

headline: For a Soviet Military Editor, Battling Changes, Even Hitler Serves The Cause
abstract: Since taking over as editor of an obscure Defense Ministry magazine two and a half years ago, Maj. Gen. Viktor I. Filatov has lived up to his own standard for what a monthly should do: pack enough scandal into each issue to keep tongues wagging all month long.    In November, his Voenno-Istoricheski Zhurnal (Military-Historical Journal) published an excerpt from Hitler's autobiography, Mein Kampf, earning the 55-year-old editor a gentle reprimand from Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov.

headline: First Firefight Hits Marine
abstract: Some of the first casualties of the ground war arrived at Navy Fleet Hospital Five late tonight by helicopter, bus and on foot.   Lance Cpl. Martin Wilcox, and another soldier were apparently the first wounded men to arrive at the hospital, unloaded by stretcher from a Blackhawk helicopter at 11:29 P.M.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Schering-Plough Healthcare Products to William Douglas McAdams Inc., New York, a health-care advertising agency, for respiratory and women's products. Billings are estimated at $2 million to $3 million. * Angus Inc., San Mateo, Calif., the largest franchisee of Jenny Craig Weight Loss Centers, to Ayer. Billings were not disclosed. The account was previously held by the San Francisco office of J. Walter Thompson.

headline: NCR Stock Plan Seeks to Thwart A.T.&T.
abstract: In its first tactical step to fend off a hostile takeover attempt by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the NCR Corporation moved yesterday to muster the loyalty of its employees. It announced it had created a $500 million employee stock ownership plan that could effectively control 8 percent of the company's stock.    The NCR board also approved a special $1 dividend payment to shareholders and increased its regularly quarterly payout to 37 cents a share, from 35 cents. It also set March 28 as the date for the special meeting called for by A.T.&T. to try to remove NCR's entire 13-member board. NCR will also hold its annual meeting on the same day.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * GTE, Stamford, Conn., named S. Donald McCullough vice president and general manager of its European lighting division. * Genovese Drug Stores Inc., Melville, L.I., named Thomas Esposito vice president and director of professional relations.

headline: Digital to Open Czech Subsidiary
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation said it would open a subsidiary in Czechoslovakia to market, sell and service the company's computers. The division, expected to open in June with about 30 employees, would be Digital's first wholly owned subsidiary in Eastern Europe. Digital owns a 51 percent stake in a joint venture in Hungary. Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., is investing about $5 million in the Czechoslovak unit, which will be based in Prague.    Digital, like other computer makers, has been struggling with a sluggish United States market, but its European business has grown, bolstered by the rise of open markets in former East bloc countries.

headline: S.E.C. Charges L.I. Brokerage
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that it had filed a complaint accusing Nicodemus E. Faitos and his firm, Faitos & Company, a Long Island brokerage, with stealing at least $1.8 million from its customers.   At the same time, Mr. Faitos and Faitos & Company agreed to repay the misappropriated funds and consented to the firm's assets being frozen. These conditions are subject to approval by the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, where the complaint was filed.

headline: Treasury Bond Prices Drop Sharply
abstract: Conflicting readings of inflation and consumer sentiment sent prices of long-term Treasury bonds tumbling yesterday. Fears of inflation, the bane of investors holding fixed-income securities, were raised when the Government released its Producer Price Index for February before the markets opened.    In late trading, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue maturing in February 2021, fell 31/32, or about $9.75 for each $1,000 of face value, to 95 15/32. This lifted the yield to 8.28 percent, compared with 8.19 percent the day before and 8.30 percent a week ago.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: MONDAY: United Parcel Service and its pilots union resume talks on a contract that expired July 31. * USX and the United Steelworkers resume contract talks.  TUESDAY: Consumer credit for November. * Resolution Funding Corporation bond auction. * S.E.C. chairman Breeden reports to the Senate on the condition of the securities industry.  WEDNESDAY: Microsoft announces an enhanced version of its Excel spreadsheet to work with its Windows operating system.  THURSDAY: Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas through Sunday. * Weekly jobless claims. * Wholesale trade for November. * Treasury auction of 52-week bills.  FRIDAY: Producer prices for December. * Housing completions for November.

headline: Sales Rise for Authors Who Perish and Publish
abstract: After 12 weeks on the paperback best-seller list, including six weeks as No. 1, V. C. Andrews's "Dawn" is a huge success. "It's nearing three million copies in print," said Jack Romanos, the president of Simon & Schuster's mass-market division. "And it is selling better than any of her other books."   In fact, Miss Andrews, who died in 1986, did not write "Dawn" -- or four other posthumous novels published under her name. Nor is she the only dead author whose books continue to earn money.

headline: Assessing the Damage to OPEC
abstract: OPEC, founded in 1960 in Baghdad, may now be withering there.   The Persian Gulf war may do long-lasting damage to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, experts in the international oil market say, because it has stimulated oil-producing countries to add capacity, to replace oil that came from the wells of Iraq and Kuwait. At the same time, the war has increased prices and depressed global demand.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Diplomacy; Bush and Gorbachev Converse Person to Person, Sort Of
abstract: While it may seem the stuff of high drama, the White House insists that the 72-minute telephone talk between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today was a "standard living-room operation," like any long-distance chat between old friends.   Vice President Dan Quayle and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d were present this morning when Mr. Bush held his talk with Mr. Gorbachev about the conditions under which each wanted Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; IRAN PROMISES IRAQI PLANES WON'T REJOIN THE FIGHTING; BUSH SAYS U.S. IS PREVAILING
abstract: On one of the heaviest days of the air war in the Persian Gulf, with allied pilots flying more than 2,600 missions, American officials said the number of Iraqi warplanes fleeing to Iran reached 90 today, up from 80-odd on Monday.    It is not clear why the pilots have sought refuge. In a letter to the United Nations, Iran insisted that in accordance with its neutral status it had impounded the planes for the duration of the war. But President Saddam Hussein of Iraq suggested in an interview with the Cable News Network that Iran might permit the aircraft to return to the war later.

headline: U.N. SURVEY CALLS IRAQ'S WAR DAMAGE NEAR-APOCALYPTIC
abstract: A United Nations survey of civilian damage caused by the allied bombardment of Iraq calls the results "near apocalyptic." The survey, which was made public today, recommends an immediate end to the embargo on imports of food and other essential supplies to prevent "imminent catastrophe."    The report, prepared by a United Nations team that visited the country between March 10 and March 17, says the bombing has relegated Iraq "to a pre-industrial age" and warns that the nation could face "epidemic and famine if massive life-supporting needs are not rapidly met."

headline: West Plans 50% Write-Off of Polish Debt
abstract: Polish and French officials said today that Western governments would announce on Friday the write-off of a large portion of Poland's $33 billion in official debt in a move aimed at helping Poland's transition to a market economy.   Western officials said around 50 percent of Poland's debt would be forgiven. That is less than the 80 percent write-off Poland had requested, but would still represent one of the largest write-offs that creditor nations have ever allowed a debtor country.

headline: Ann Taylor's Sales Up 20.2% in Month
abstract: Ann Taylor Inc., the New York-based fashion chain, said its February sales rose 20.2 percent, to $27.7 million, from $23.1 million the year before, while its same-store sales were up 5.1 percent. Same-store sales are those recorded in stores open at least a year. Ann Taylor operates 173 stores.    The figures do not include the sales of the Joan & David shoe departments, which lease space in the stores. Including the departments, February sales rose 12.5 percent, while same-store sales dropped 1 percent.

headline: GORBACHEV WARNS THE LITHUANIANS TO HALT DEFIANCE
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called on Lithuania today to halt its defiance of Soviet authority immediately, and warned that "people are demanding" the introduction of direct Kremlin rule of the breakaway republic.    The implicit threat, coming at a time when the army has sent paratroopers here to help round up young men evading Soviet military service, heightened the fears of some Lithuanians that Mr. Gorbachev would exploit the world's preoccupation with the Persian Gulf crisis to move forcibly against the separatist republic.

headline: An Auction Is Planned For Eastern
abstract: Unexpectedly keen competition to buy the airport gates and takeoff and landing slots of Eastern Airlines has led the bankruptcy judge handling Eastern's case to schedule an auction.   As a result, some of the sale agreements already struck by the trustee who is running the carrier could be off, if there are higher offers at the auction on Monday.

headline: Transamerica Gives President a New Title
abstract: The Transamerica Corporation said yesterday that its president, Frank C. Herringer, would assume the additional post of chief executive.    Mr. Herringer, who is 48 years old, will succeed James R. Harvey, 56, on April 25.    Mr. Harvey, who was named chief executive in 1981, will continue as Transamerica's chairman. He previously served as Transamerica's president from 1979 to 1986 and has been chairman since 1983.

headline: Oil Climbs Again on Belief that OPEC Will Cut Output
abstract: Oil prices rallied late yesterday to close modestly higher for a fifth straight session in response to speculation that OPEC would soon take steps to cut production of crude.   "Going into an OPEC meeting, the trend of the market is always higher," said Nauman Barakat, a vice president at Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. "There is considerable talk and perception that there is going to be a material reduction in the output of the cartel, and that would be able to stabilize the market."

headline: United Engines Gears Up For Fire Equipment Orders
abstract: With Kuwait's oilfields ablaze and fires at some wells likely to burn for years, welders, mechanics and managers at the United Engines Inc. plant in Oklahoma City are working on two shifts to quickly produce the special equipment needed to fight the fires.    Six welders and 11 mechanics are working to assemble by the end of April a new batch of the ungainly tools and equipment. United Engines, a supplier to oilfields and dozens of other industries, has built equipment designed by and sold exclusively to the Red Adair Company for nearly 40 years.

headline: Review of California's Debt May Result in Downgrading
abstract: The ever-thinning ranks of triple-A-rated states may soon lose another if the Standard & Poor's Corporation lowers the rating of California's general obligation debt.    Standard & Poor's announced yesterday that it had placed under review for possible downgrading some $11.6 billion in California general obligation bonds as a result of a rapidly developing deficit that is projected for the fiscal years 1991 and 1992.

headline: CBS Lost $156 Million in Fourth Quarter
abstract: CBS Inc. reported a net loss of $156 million yesterday for the fourth quarter of 1990 and announced that it would reduce its quarterly dividend to 25 cents from $1.10.   The network had announced in November that it would post a loss for the quarter, largely because of the losses on its contract with Major League Baseball.

headline: Return of the Small-Stock Conundrum
abstract: It's January, the month when stock market lore says that small stocks outperform. And sure enough, last week they did just that. While big stocks started the year off declining rapidly, small stocks went down more slowly.   So while the Dow Jones industrial average is off 67.57 points, or 2.6 percent, to 2,566.09 so far in 1991, the Russell 2,000 is down just 1.5 percent, to 130.21. Smaller declines are not, however, what buyers of such stocks are seeking.

headline: The Victor Visits to Get Jar of Spoils
abstract: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the allied forces that drove Iraq from Kuwait, scooped sand from a beach in the emirate today as a souvenir of his victory.   "I promised myself I would fill this with Kuwaiti sand," he told journalists as he poured sand into a glass container.

headline: American Express Product
abstract: The American Express Company, taking direct aim at Visa and Mastercard, said yesterday that it would market a new corporate "gold" card with some unusual features.    The features, aimed at chief executives of small businesses and senior officers at large companies, include a 24-hour "executive service desk" that can plan meetings, deliver messages and replace lost visas and passports.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.75-9   8.75-9   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   6.03   6.05   8.18        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.80   5.86   7.93        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.82   5.90   7.87        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.86   7.95   8.68        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   8.18   8.26   8.60        TELEPHONE BONDS   9.35   9.40   9.76        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   7.32   7.32   7.48       *Estimated daily average, source Salomon Brothers **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Politics; Another Gulf War?
abstract: The question the American soldiers ask as they board planes for home after seven months in the desert is the same one that worries the politicians that live in the region as they turn from preoccupation with military problems to the concerns of civil life.     Will we have to do it all over again? Will we have to find the money and the will, they ask anxiously, to assemble half a million troops to turn back another of Saddam Hussein's attempts to push his neighbors around?

headline: HDM Worldwide Revamps, Consolidating Into 3 Groups
abstract: HDM WORLDWIDE, which is owned by Young & Rubicam and Dentsu, the giant Japanese agency, has been realigned and consolidated into three agency groups.    The most striking change comes in the United States, where HDM's agencies in New York and Los Angeles, along with Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners, have been combined to create Lord, Dentsu & Partners. Lord Einstein, which is partly owned by Y.& R., was merged with HDM's New York office in early January. Lord, Dentsu has billings of about $220 million.

headline: Testing a Race Horse On Muscle Efficiency
abstract: A doctor in Philadelphia received a patent this week on a system for testing the muscle efficiency of race horses. His method employs nuclear magnetic resonance technology.   Such systems are widely used to create high-quality images of the body. The systems are based on analyzing radio signals emitted by the atoms in the body, after subjection to a powerful electromagnetic field and a burst of radio energy. The signals are assembled by computer to generate a detailed picture.

headline: New York State Revenue Bonds
abstract: The New York State Housing Finance Agency is offering $90.165 million in tax-exempt revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.898 percent for a bond due 2020 through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.   Yields for shorter-maturity bonds range from a 7.55 percent issue due in 2002 to a 7.849 percent issue due in 2011.    The issue is rated A by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: Economic Scene; Bailing Out Eastern Germany
abstract: GERMANY, where money talks and nobody walks, seems to have run out of economic miracles. Nine months after unification, the eastern provinces once known as the German Democratic Republic have tumbled into depression. With 30 percent of the labor force without full-time jobs and industrial production down by half, economic union threatens to become a black hole for taxpayers in western Germany.   In part the mess is simply a measure of the failure of the G.D.R's rulers, who would not give up their belief that Germans could even make socialism work. But in part, suggest four economists from the University of California at Berkeley, the post-unification collapse results from a self-defeating effort to squeeze western German living standards from the unproductive eastern German industrial machine.

headline: Pepsi in a Super Bowl Rush After Scrapping Its Contest
abstract: In the aftermath of one of the strangest marketing mishaps in recent history, Pepsico executives scrambled yesterday to re-edit television commercials for tomorrow's Super Bowl to remove references to a phone-in contest that has been canceled.   Telephone executives had expressed fears that the contest would have dangerously snarled the nation's telephone system. Pepsi canceled the contest late Thursday night after a meeting with officials of the Federal Communications Commission and representatives of telephone companies.

headline: Kidney Drug Setback For Genetics Institute
abstract: In a setback for Genetics Institute Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., the Food and Drug Administration has denied several of the company's petitions to market an anti-anemia drug to patients with chronic kidney failure.   The action is a partial victory for Amgen Inc., which enjoys an exclusive right to sell the genetically engineered drug, erythropoietin, to kidney patients under what is known as "orphan drug" status. But the move does not settle the broader legal battle over patent rights for erythropoietin between Amgen and Genetics Institute, which awaits a Federal court decision.

headline: A Region in Mourning
abstract: Eleven men and two women. Black and white. Laborers and college students. The 13 Army reservists were killed last Monday in one of the final missile attacks of the gulf war.   All came from towns in western Pennsylvania tied together by immigrant backgrounds, a love of high school sports and a faith in country.     Article, page A12.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Germany; Kohl Is Sending $165 Million In Humanitarian Aid to Israel
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced today that his Government would send $165 million to Israel as "immediate humanitarian aid" after Iraqi missile attacks, and that more money would be sent to support the anti-Iraq alliance in the Persian Gulf.    "The news of renewed rocket attacks by Iraq against the territory of Israel fills us Germans with deep outrage," Mr. Kohl said at a news conference. "It is a clear blow against Israel's integrity and right to exist, for which we Germans have a special responsibility."

headline: Manufacturers Urge Big U.S. Export Push
abstract: Arguing that exports are the bright spot in an otherwise bleak economy, the National Association of Manufacturers is urging the Bush Administration to play a much more aggressive role in promoting the sale of American products abroad.   The lobbying effort, outlined here today at the group's twice-a-year board meeting, is based largely on the premise that more exports, particularly of manufactured goods, can reverse the recession. Should the Bush Administration respond to the appeal and adopt the proposals, it would become deeply involved in promoting and even managing trade.

headline: Kodak Expects Weaker Earnings
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company said it expected to post weaker first-quarter earnings, citing the economic slowdown and a sharp drop-off in tourism that has hurt sales of film and cameras. In the first quarter of 1990, Kodak earned $199 million, or 61 cents a share, on sales of $4.11 billion.   Last month, company executives told analysts they expected weaker earnings in the first quarter, a Kodak spokesman, Paul Allen, said. Analysts had expected earnings in a range of 65 cents to 72 cents a share in the first quarter. Kodak's stock closed down $1.625 today, at $41.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Houston Schools Offer Tax Bonds
abstract: A $147 million issue of limited tax bonds for the Houston Independent School District was priced yesterday through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation, which were awarded the financing in competitive bidding.   The tax-exempt bonds were priced to yield from 5.60 percent in 1994 to 5.95 percent in 1996, 6.375 percent in 2001, 6.75 percent in 2006, and 6.85 percent in 2011. Underwriters noted that with the bonds guaranteed by the Texas Permanent School Fund, they were rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Turmoil, Then Hope in Argentina
abstract: Following the appointment of a new Economy Minister, Argentina's stock market soared 30 percent today, in a stunning reversal of investor sentiment after three days of sharp plunges by the nation's currency.   Economic officials saw the rising market as a sign that financial and business executives still believe that the country's economic recovery plan is on track, despite the financial and political turmoil earlier this week.

headline: PAN AM IS CURBING SERVICE IN MIDEAST
abstract: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it was suspending flights to Tel Aviv and to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, because of surging insurance rates, a result of the crisis in the Middle East.   In addition, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines canceled its flights to Amman, Jordan, and other carriers are evaluating whether to continue serving Middle Eastern destinations. Travel agents said bookings to the area had dropped sharply and suggested that could be an important factor in the airlines' decisions.

headline: Economic Watch; Why Only a Few Big Airlines Prosper in a Deregulated Sky
abstract: Continental, Pan Am, T.W.A., Midway: The list of distressed airlines reduced to selling precious assets, courting merger partners or throwing themselves on the mercy of bankruptcy courts grows ever longer.   The run-up in oil prices just as the economy was slouching toward recession has certainly compounded the industry's problems. But many economists, including some who were early champions of deregulation, now believe that the resulting cash squeeze merely hastened the inevitable trend toward consolidation.

headline: Text of Congressional Resolution on Use of Force in the Persian Gulf
abstract: Following is the text of the joint resolution approved by the Senate and the House of Representatives on Saturday, regarding the use of force in the Persian Gulf:     To authorize the use of United States Armed Forces pursuant to United Nations Security Council Resolution 678.

headline: Motorola Plan For Modem
abstract: Motorola Inc. says it will provide technical details today of its high-speed wireless modem, which uses microwaves to carry data between computers.   The company, based in Schaumburg, Ill., demonstrated the technology at a news conference on Oct. 23 but hid the device's components in boxes because the final design had not been completed.    Several companies, including the NCR Corporation, have already introduced wireless modems, which are intended to replace the mazes of wires that link computers in offices.   Motorola is spending heavily to develop high-technology products like wireless modems, as foreign and domestic competition erodes its dominance of the market for cellular telephones and the radio transmitter and receiver stations that make these phones work.

headline: Europe Clears Centocor Drug
abstract: Centocor Inc., a biotechnology company based in Malvern, Pa., said yesterday that its Centoxin drug for the treatment of septic shock had been recommended for approval in Europe. Septic shock, an often- fatal disease, affects about a million patients annually in the European Community and the United States.    The European Community's Committee for Proprietary Medicinal Products recommended approval of Centoxin for the treatment of gram negative bacterimia, a severe blood infection that frequently causes septic shock and death.

headline: For African Congress, Tough Path Lies Ahead
abstract: A year after it was legalized by President F. W. de Klerk, the African National Congress finds itself wavering between its past as a revolutionary liberation movement and its future as a more conventional political party.    In setting out its goals for 1991, the organization declared that it "approaches the future with only two aims in mind," defining these as "the total abolition of the system of apartheid, and not its reform or amendment, and its replacement by a genuine non-racial democracy."

headline: U.N. Group in Hong Kong Taken To Task on Advice to Boat People
abstract: Responding to complaints from the United Nations refugee agency, the Hong Kong Government has curtailed the activities of a legal assistance group that has been advising Vietnamese boat people held in detention camps here.   The action has prompted charges that the United Nations agency is more concerned with sending refugees back to Vietnam than in looking after their best interests, the organization's official mission.

headline: TROOPS MAY GET UNLICENSED DRUG
abstract: The Defense Department is planning to administer experimental drugs, which experts say include a botulism vaccine, to troops in the Persian Gulf.    The vaccine, which may protect against a deadly bacterial toxin that could be used by Iraq, has been previously tried only by laboratory workers who handle the toxin. This experience provides too little data for the Food and Drug Administration to declare the vaccine effective. Experts say the vaccine seems reasonably safe but definitive data on this point too are lacking.

headline: Excerpts of Interviews With Men Identified as Pilots Downed Over Iraq
abstract: Iraq broadcast interviews yesterday with seven uniformed men that it identified as allied pilots downed in the first days of the Persian Gulf war. Audio portions of interviews with six of the men were broadcast by the Cable News Network, which obtained a recording through its correspondent in Baghdad, Peter Arnett. Following is a partial transcript of the CNN transmission. First Prisoner   Q. Would you tell us your rank and name?   A. Lieut. Col. Cliff  [ inaudible; believed to be Lieut. Col. Clifford M. Acree ] .    Q. What's your age?    A. Thirty-nine.   Q. What's your unit?   A. V.M.O. 2.   Q. You are the commander of that unit?   A. Yes, I am.   Q. Your mission?   A. Observation and reconnaissance.   Q. How your aircraft has been shot down?   A. I was flying a mission in southern Kuwait and was shot down by a surface-to-air missile.   Q. Do you have a message?   A. I would like to tell my wife and family that I'm alive and well. Second Prisoner    Q. Would you tell us your rank and name?    A. My name is Lieut. Jeffrey Norton Zaun, United States Navy.   Q. Your age?   A. I am twenty-eight.   Q. Your unit?   A. I am from Attack Squadron 35 on the U.S.S. Saratoga, the Red Sea.   Q. Your type of aircraft?    A. I'm flying the A-6E Intruder attack aircraft.   Q. Your mission?   A. My mission was to attack the H3 airfield in southwestern Iraq.   Q. Alone?   A. I flew as part of a formation of four aircraft in order to commit this attack.   Q. What do you think, Lieutenant, about this aggression against Iraq?   A. I think our leaders and our people have wrongly attacked the peaceful people of Iraq.   Q. Do you have a message?   A. Yes, I would like to tell my mother and my father and my sister that I am well treated and that they should pray for peace. Third Prisoner    Q. Would you tell us about your rank, name and nationality?    A. O.K. My name is Maurice Cocciolone. And I'm a captain from Italian Air Force.    Q. What is your age?   A. I am 30 years old.   Q. Tell us about your unit.    A. My unit is the 155 squadron that is now in the base of Emirates ---- United Arab Emirates.   Q. What was your mission?   A. To attack the forces of missiles in the southern region of Iraq.   Q. How you have been shot down?   A. We don't know exactly. It was right away fired from the ground. We don't know exactly what was it. There was firing from the ground from Iraq.   Q. What is your opinion about the war and the aggression against Iraq?   A. Well, the war is based on a bad reason . . . to solve a question, political question. War . . . a bad thing in front of you. So I think the best solution of peace . . . would be to find a political peaceful means of bringing this situation to the end.   Q. You have a message to send.    A. O.K. I think the only message would, like to tell my political leaders that to solve question by war is always mad.  . . And also, I have something to tell my parents, to my family. Don't be worried, I am pretty fine here. They are well taking care of me. Thank you. Fourth Prisoner    Q. About your rank, name and nationality?   A. My name is Guy Hunter Jr. I'm a warrant officer. I am an American.   Q. Your age?   A. Forty-six.    Q. Your unit?   A. D.M.O. 2 in the Marine Corps.    Q. Your type of aircraft?    A. OV-10 Bronco.    Q. What was your mission?   A. Against Iraqi troops in southern Iraq.   Q. How have you been shot down?   A. I am not certain. We were flying, and all of a sudden, a left bang off the left wing, a large bang off the left wing, and the plane began to crash.   Q. What's your opinion of this aggression against Iraq?   A. I think this war is crazy and should never have happened. I condemn this aggression against peaceful Iraq.   Q. Do you have a message to send?    A. Yes, sir, I do. To my wife and children, I miss you very much. I'm in good hands and being treated well. To the children, please study hard in school. Fifth Prisoner    Q. What is your rank, name and nationality?   A. My name is Flight Lieut. Adrian John Nichols. I'm British.   Q. Your age?   A. Twenty-seven.    Q. Your unit?   A. Fifteenth Squadron.   Q. Type of aircraft?   A. Tornado.   Q. What was your mission?   A. To attack an Iraqi airfield.   Q. How were you shot down?   A. I was shot down by an Iraqi system. I do not know what it was.   Q. What do you think of this war against Iraq?   A. I think this war should be stopped. I do not agree on this war with Iraq.   Q. Do you have a message?   A. Mom and Dad if you are listening, everything is O.K. here. Please pray for me. We shall be home soon. Sixth Prisoner    Q. Tell us about your rank, name and nationality.   A. My name is Flight Lieut. Peters. I'm British.   Q. Your age?   A. Twenty-nine.

headline: Dow Climbs 23.27 Points; Nasdaq Up
abstract: Stocks advanced for the third day yesterday as money managers jumped on the bandwagon before it got out of sight. Trading continued extremely heavy.    Many cautiously expected the Fed to lower interest rates soon after today's employment figures come out, possibly lifting the market a little more.

headline: South Africa Integrates Some Schools
abstract: As a new school year began here today, black South African children were for the first time admitted to previously all-white classes in 33 public schools where parents had approved plans for limited integration.    The breakthrough occurred in selected schools in Transvaal province and is due to be followed up in the next few days when 172 previously all-white public schools in other parts of the country begin their terms by enrolling some black children.

headline: The Baring of Buchenwald, Unfiltered
abstract: A debate over the meaning of German history has erupted at the site of the former Nazi concentration camp here.   Few names conjure up such vivid visions of human cruelty as that of Buchenwald. Under Hitler, a quarter of a million prisoners from three dozen countries were sent here as slave laborers. About 65,000 died.

headline: Australia News Groups Facing Tough Times
abstract: Australian news organizations, normally among the world's most vigorous, are facing severe financial difficulties in this country's deep recession. A leading newspaper group and two of the three private television networks have been forced into receivership and are expected to be sold to pay off billions of dollars in debt.    As a result, Australia's two most influential media billionaires, Rupert Murdoch and Kerry Packer, are gaining strength, even though Mr. Murdoch has also run into some trouble. Earlier this month, Mr. Murdoch refinanced about $7.6 billion in debt for his holding company, the News Corporation. In addition, he has combined the morning and afternoon papers he controls in Sydney and Melbourne to save money. Still, the Murdoch papers have about 67 percent of all newspaper circulation in Australia.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Keep Pushing Staples, A Media Planner Urges
abstract: War is the best time to advertise staples, even if they are defined as videos and and steak sauce.  That is what one media adviser is telling his clients, which include the agencies W. B. Doner, OMON and Pedone & Partners, and advertisers like Lea & Perrins, the steak sauce makers.   "January and February are high-viewer months because of cold weather, and products like staple foods should stay on the war," said Kal Liebowitz, the president of KSL Media, a media planning and placement firm in New York.  He cited Sweet 'n Low, Dannon Yogurt, Coors Beer and RKO video as "staple" advertisers that will benefit from increased viewership because of coverage of the Persian Gulf conflict. Advertisers that have pulled their spots because they think advertising is inappropriate will return in droves, Mr. Liebowitz warns, causing rates to rise.  "As long as the war is long and drawn out, and as long as the U.S. continues to exhibit superiority, products that are not war-sensitive should stay on," Mr. Liebowitz said. "As long as ratings are high, it's going to get difficult for those who withdraw to rush back in."

headline: ISRAELIS ADVISED TO KILL ASSAILANTS
abstract: Israel's Police Minister advised members of the public today to kill any Palestinian seen brandishing a knife apparently with the intent of killing Jews.   "We should kill whomever comes with a drawn knife to kill Jews," Police Minister Roni Milo said, "whether a policeman or not."

headline: South African Black Pupils' Failure Rate Surges
abstract: Nearly two out of every three black students completing high school in South Africa failed their final examinations in 1990, according to the results released today.   The showing, in which just 81,746 of the 233,411 students who took final examinations earned a matriculation certificate, equivalent to a high school diploma, and only 17,397 did well enough to apply for college, is the worst in the recorded history of segregated black education, said officials at the Department of Education and Training in Pretoria.

headline: Earnings Fall At Travelers
abstract: After taking a beating in the real estate market, the Travelers Corporation today reported a 14.4 percent drop in net income in the fourth quarter and posted the first yearly loss in its 127-year history.   The giant insurance company had fourth-quarter net income of $127.6 million, or $1.23 a share, compared with $149 million, or $1.42 a share, for the corresponding period a year ago.   Fourth-quarter revenues were $2.8 billion, down 12.5 percent, from $3.2 billion for the same quarter last year. Premiums totaled $1.6 billion, down from $1.9 billion in the fourth quarter in 1989.   The year-end loss came to $178.4 million, compared with net income of $455.1 million, or $4.37 a share, for 1989.   Total revenues for 1990 were $11.3 billion, down 9.6 percent, from $12.5 billion for 1989. Premiums totaled $7.4 billion, down from $7.8 billion in 1989. The company had predicted in October that it would post a loss for the year.   Travelers's stock rose 75 cents today, to $21.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: A Siberian City Will Vote With Little Enthusiasm
abstract: A neat young man recently walked into the offices of the local Communist Party newspaper and took out an advertisement inviting people to join him in quitting civilization.   The invitation seemed striking among the heated polemics and dire scenarios elsewhere in the newspaper, Krasnoye Znamya, in preparation for the referendum to be held on Sunday. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev hopes that voters here and throughout the country will approve his view of how the Soviet Union and its republics, some of which want independence, should stay together as a nation.

abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.75-9   8.75-9   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   6.25   6.35   8.18        3-MO.
