headline: Excerpts From CNN Report
abstract: For many Americans and others around the globe, the reports by Bernard Shaw, Peter Arnett and John Holliman of the Cable News Network provided the first eyewitness reports of the bombing of Baghdad. Here is an excerpt from CNN's broadcast last night from the Al Rashid Hotel in Baghdad.    [ SPEAKER UNKNOWN ] : I'm anxious for daylight to come. Maybe we can get some visibility. From what we can see, the populated areas of Baghdad where all the people live, there doesn't seem to be any bombing activity at all. The bridges are still standing. The bridges over the Tigris River, they are still it, so we don't see any action at all within the city. Around us and a couple of Government centers, there seemed to have been some bombing earlier, but right now, in fact, in the last half hour, the bombing has moved out, seemingly beyond the perimeter of the city to presumably military targets, strategic targets further west, towards Kuwait.   ARNETT: That's correct. And out of the immediate vicinity of Baghdad here. And I just looked out on the street a moment ago and saw a very small automobile driving down there. Peter, look at this. This is a bright flash of light that seems to be a -- it seemed to come across from north to south, and even came up here by us in the hotel. And there it goes -- almost like a shooting star.    HOLLIMAN: I think that shooting star is probably an F-15 John.    ARNETT: Yeah.   HOLLIMAN: So that's what they look like at night when they're working. All right. It's good to know. . . .    ARNETT: Yes, John, that was a heck of a strike. The plane could have been as close as 500 meters in the sky above its target. This certainly has been met with a lot of antiaircraft fire, but it is long gone at this point, John.    HOLLIMAN: Yeah. These planes are moving so rapidly, and with the one bright light on them. I guess that's the engines themselves that we're seeing going by. This is something that I've never covered before, ladies and gentlemen.

headline: Mongolia Gets U.S. Trade Aid
abstract: President Bush accorded Mongolia most-favored-nation trade status today and saluted the democratic and economic changes unfolding in the former Communist state.   Standing next to the Mongolian President, Punsalmaagiyn Ochirbat, Mr. Bush took note of the war in the Persian Gulf and said, "The actions of Iraq's dictator, the actions of one misguided man, cannot obscure mankind's bright destiny of democracy and freedom."    Mr. Ochirbat is the first Mongolian head of state to visit the United States. He said the meeting opened "broad vistas" for further ties.

headline: Grand Met Executive Gets New No. 2 Post
abstract: Ian A. Martin, the Scotsman who led Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.'s 1989 acquisition of the Pillsbury Company, has been promoted to a new No. 2 job at Grand Met. He thus becomes the heir apparent to Grand Met's feisty chairman and chief executive, Allen J. G. Sheppard, who is 58 years old.   At its annual meeting in London yesterday, Grand Met announced the appointment of Mr. Martin, 56, as deputy group chief executive. Next January, Mr. Martin will return to Grand Met's home base in London, from Minneapolis, where Pillsbury has its headquarters, and assume the position of chief operating officer and group managing director of Grand Met.

headline: Oil's Inconvenient Bonanza
abstract: In almost any industry, a batch of quarterly earnings reports heralding huge profit gains would bring on buoyant appraisals from gleeful executives. But not Big Oil. Despite vigorous profit gains in the fourth quarter announced last week by several oil giants, few industry executives were celebrating.   In releasing 1990 results, leaders of the nation's largest, international oil companies took pains to stress that their stunning profits from the last three months of 1990 were a solitary event, a bonanza from high oil prices that was unlikely to be repeated anytime soon.

headline: Pretoria Seeking Nonracial Local Government
abstract: In what could become the most significant move toward true racial integration in South Africa this year, the Government of President F. W. de Klerk is putting the finishing touches on a major program that would encourage white towns to merge administratively and financially with poorer black townships, with legal backing and financial incentives from Pretoria.    Mr. de Klerk, when he called on Feb. 1 for the elimination of the remaining laws upholding the apartheid system, said his Government had been giving attention to the reform of local government "for quite some time," but gave few concrete details.

headline: A Sharp Drop in Dollar Counters Expectations
abstract: The dollar fell sharply yesterday, confounding the expectations of many analysts who thought the United States currency would be a safe harbor in a time of war.   Traders said that the market would continue to be volatile and move with the headlines. Because of the uncertainties -- and the ability of the dollar to turn on a dime -- many are leery of trying to make money now on the currency's movements.

headline: U.S. Team Seeks to Reassure Israel
abstract: President Bush dispatched a high-level mission today to inform Israel that the United States would try to protect it from Iraqi attack should a war erupt in the Persian Gulf and to urge Israel to stay out of the conflict.   Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger left for Israel, accompanied by a team of Pentagon and State Department officials.

headline: Financial Aid Is Pledged
abstract: Japan responded today to the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf with a new pledge of financial aid to the United States and allied troops in the region and a reiteration of its determination to avoid direct combat itself.    Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, emerging from a round of hurried meetings with his Cabinet, said, however, that Japan might use some of its military aircraft to evacuate civilians or refugees from the region but that such a decision was still being debated.

headline: Bank Fraud Inquiries
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has dozens of cases pending against financial institutions, the S.E.C.'s chairman, Richard C. Breeden, told a House subcommittee today.    Answering questions from a subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee, Mr. Breeden declined to provide details but said his agency had "a number of cases in the pipeline." He added, "I would characterize it as dozens of cases."

headline: Gold and Silver Prices Jump As Commodity Funds Buy
abstract: The futures prices of gold and silver soared yesterday amid heightened fear of a war in the Persian Gulf. But dealers stressed that the price rises were more reflective of buying by commodity futures funds than of significant demand for the actual metal.    At the close of trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York, the largest gold and silver futures market, the nearest active delivery contract, for February, was settled at $396.20 an ounce, up $9 on the day. Dealers quoted a cash price for gold of $394.10, up $9.20 an ounce.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Palestinians; With Iraqis Gone, Kuwaitis Turn Wrath on Palestinians
abstract: Tanks rolled through Kuwait City's Palestinian neighborhoods today as edgy Kuwaiti Army soldiers blocked off entire areas to make house-to-house searches for weapons and people who collaborated with the Iraqis.    After four days of celebration of the end of the Iraqi occupation, the mood was tense today as Kuwaiti soldiers searched cars, frisking their occupants. Other soldiers fired in the air as they walked down the main avenues.

headline: NCR's Net Down 24.5%
abstract: The NCR Corporation, the computer maker fighting a hostile takeover bid by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 24.5 percent despite record revenue.   For the three months that ended on Dec. 31, NCR earned $111 million, or $1.71 a share, compared with $147 million, or $2.02 a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1989. Revenue rose 6.1 percent, to $1.90 billion, a record for any quarter, from $1.79 billion a year earlier.   NCR said its profits for the year were reduced by a share-repurchase program, under which it bought one million shares in the fourth quarter. Profit totaled $369 million, or $5.43 a share, compared with $412 million, or $5.38 a share, in 1989. Revenue rose 5.5 percent, to $6.29 billion, from $5.96 billion in 1989.   NCR's directors have unanimously rejected A.T.&T.'s $6.1 billion buyout offer, although Mr. Exley has said he will recommend the deal if A.T.&T. raises the $90-a-share offer to $125 a share. A.T.& T. has rejected that and is making a tender offer to NCR shareholders that expires tomorrow.   NCR's shares dropped $1.625 yesterday, to $83.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Damage; Assessing Damage Can Be Fettered by the Weather and Pilot Hyperbole
abstract: Bomb-damage assessment, a difficult skill at the mercy of the weather and enemy guile, is proving a frustrating bottleneck in this high-technology war of instant communications and precision-guided arms.    Yesterday, after getting complaints from Congress and the White House, the Pentagon said its assessment work had fallen far behind schedule.

headline: Army Activates 2,667 More From the Guard and Reserve
abstract: The Army said today that it was ordering to active duty 2,667 National Guard and Army Reserve members from 15 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico.   Among the units being mobilized is the Second Battalion, 142d Field Artillery of the Arkansas National Guard, based at Fort Smith. The other units are being called up for noncombat services like public affairs, maintenance and law enforcement.   More than 125,000 members of the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps Reserves have been called to active duty for operations in the Persian Gulf since late August.

headline: Forget the Oscar: These 3 Get Gold Ladders
abstract: THERE may be people who will remember this week because of a few movie awards, but you can be sure none of them were lunching in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. Oscars may be fine for some folk, but what counts for this smiling New York crowd is a 24-karat gold ladder encased in Lucite. The ladder represents election into the American Advertising Federation's Advertising Hall of Fame, the highest tribute in the trade.   Yesterday two agency founders and a former advertising columnist were inducted into the Hall of Fame. They were Carl J. Ally, founder of Carl Ally Inc. and former chairman of Ally & Gargano, Inc.; Sam R. Bloom, founder of the Bloom Companies, and Philip H. Dougherty, advertising columnist for The New York Times for 22 years until his death in 1988.

headline: In Foreign Exchange, Stay Tuned to the Mark
abstract: The foreign exchange story to watch in 1991 is the strength of the German mark and how its European colleagues cope with it.   The dollar, which fell 13 percent against the mark last year, will be a sideshow to this drama, following the lead of the German currency. The dollar is expected to slide further early this year as interest rates in the United States fall and the economy slumps further into recession.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * The National Cable Television Association, an organization that represents local system operators, cable networks and equipment suppliers, to Bozell Inc., New York. Billings were not disclosed. * Group W Satellite Communications to Adler Boschetto Peebles & Partners, New York, for its Country Music Television, a 24-hour music video network, and Group W Sports Marketing Group. Billings were not disclosed. The agency already handles Group W's Nashville Network, Nashville Network Radio and Request, a pay-per-view network.

headline: IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA, HUNT FOR VILLAINS
abstract: Czechoslovakia has begun screening more than 1,000 top officials -- Parliament members, Government ministers and their aides -- to discover which ones were informers for the secret police under the former Communist leadership.   The move reflects the ugly burden of mutual suspicion bequeathed by the Communists. Officials say that about 100,000 Czechoslovaks were persuaded, coerced or paid to spy on fellow citizens up to the time when the Communists were forced from power late in 1989.

headline: Founder of Control Data Plans to Leave Its Board
abstract: William C. Norris, the maverick founder of the Control Data Corporation, is leaving the board of the computer company he founded in 1957. Mr. Norris, 79, retired as chairman and chief executive in 1986 and has not been involved in the company's management since then.    According to company proxy materials, Mr. Norris, who carries the honorary title of chairman emeritus, will not stand for re-election to Control Data's board when his term expires May 1. Instead, he will become a nonvoting director emeritus. Mr. Norris's five-year, $1.5 million consulting contract with Control Data ended in January.

headline: Thais Name New Assembly
abstract: The Thai military junta, which seized power in a coup last month, announced the formation today of a new National Assembly dominated by soldiers. The assembly will be charged with approving a new constitution, paving the way for elections and the return of civilian rule, Radio Thailand said. More than half of the new members are serving or retired officers in the armed forces, the announcement said. The new assembly also includes some former members of Parliament as well as businessmen and journalists, the radio said.

headline: 35 Die in South Africa Township Attack
abstract: Gunmen stepping from the shadows fired automatic weapons at mourners during a vigil for a slain African National Congress youth organizer early today, killing at least 35 people and wounding 40.    The killings represented the worst incident of violence in the black townships near Johannesburg in the last four and a half months, in which more than 1,000 people have died. It eclipsed an attack on Soweto train commuters in September in which 26 people were slain.

headline: CNN Sees Its Concept Paying Off
abstract: The enormous success enjoyed by the Cable News Network in the first weeks of the Persian Gulf war has been largely a triumph of a concept: providing news as it happens from all over the world virtually around the clock.   "It's as though we were in training all this time for just this story," said Ed Turner, the executive vice president of CNN.

headline: New Bulk-Call Plan Offered by A.T.& T.
abstract: After years of hostility toward entrepreneurs who buy blocks of long-distance telephone time for resale to small businesses and schools, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday announced a service designed for them.   A.T.& T.'s decision represents a fundamental shift in the way the company tries to maintain its share of the $53 billion long-distance business, said Dr. Robert Self, a long-distance industry consultant in New York.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THE ECONOMY    Local telephone companies may face formidable new competition within a few years from the cable television industry. In the last week, the F.C.C. approved applications by three cable companies to build experimental telephone networks that would allow people to use small wireless telephones.  [ Page D1. ]   The Commerce Department revised its G.N.P. estimate for the fourth quarter, showing a drop of 2 percent at an annual rate. The report supports the idea of a short recession.  [ D1. ]

headline: U.S. Maker of Ball Bearings Loses New 'Dumping' Case
abstract: The United States International Trade Commission, in an unusual decision, today threw out an unfair trade case brought by a leading maker of ball bearings against Hong Kong and 13 countries including Canada and Mexico -- removing what could have become another point of international trade friction.    The commission, an agency that adjudicates trade complaints for the Federal Government, voted by 3 to 1 that ball bearings from Hong Kong and the 13 countries did not significantly hurt the domestic industry.

headline: Chairman of Keye/Donna Quits to Join New Agency
abstract: The Keye/Donna/Pearlstein advertising agency, a former highflier that has been spiraling downward for some time, has quietly fractured.    The agency's chairman, Paul Keye, has left, taking six clients with him to a new agency formed here with Roger Livingston, who owns the Seattle-based Livingston & Company agency.

headline: Interest Rates on Treasuries Up
abstract: Credit market participants, apparently sensing that victory in the Persian Gulf will lead to a pickup in the economy and push up interest rates, sold Treasury notes and bonds yesterday. The drop in prices pushed rates higher.    The selloff, during which the price of some securities fell by nearly a point, took place on thin volume, dealers said.

headline: Big Price Rises for Farm Products Called Unlikely
abstract: For the most part, American consumers will probably not see drastic price increases, reduced supplies or inferior quality in California fruits and vegetables in spite of the drought and state and Federal water cutbacks to agriculture, farming experts and growers' representatives say.    If one farmer cuts back on a crop for lack of water deliveries, another with abundant ground water is likely to increase planting of that crop, said Mike Henry, a spokesman for the California Farm Bureau Federation in Sacramento. "The diversity of California agriculture has saved the consumer in the past four years and may save us again," he said of the long drought. But the prices of some crops may be much more volatile because of periodic shortages.

headline: Sales of Cars and Light Trucks Down by 20.2%
abstract: Sales of cars and light trucks made in the United States fell 20.2 percent in mid-January, as demand for vehicles remained sluggish.    Industry analysts cautioned that the market for vehicles could become volatile, as consumers are buffeted by sometimes contradictory economic signals and war-related developments.

headline: MGM-Pathe Delays Film
abstract: The MGM-Pathe Communications Company halted next month's planned release of "Delirious" because it is too cash-strapped to raise $7 million to promote the John Candy comedy, a newspaper reported today.   An article in The Hollywood Reporter, a trade paper, also said the studio's former owner, Kirk Kerkorian, may be seeking to buy it back cheaply. In November, Mr. Kerkorian sold what was then the MGM/UA Communications Company for $1.3 billion to the Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti.    Craig Parsons, a spokesman for the debt-burdened studio, did not return a call seeking comment.   The newspaper said a printer, fearing non-payment, refused to produce lobby posters for the movie. The publication also said MGM-Pathe's movie chief, Alan Ladd Jr., was at odds with other company managers who want to release "Delirious" without promoting it.

headline: From a Dove To a Hawk: 25-Year Trip
abstract: Twenty-five years ago, Stephen J. Solarz was managing one of the first anti-war Congressional campaigns in the country.   Last week, the Brooklyn Democrat was a principal architect of the resolution authorizing President Bush to go to war in the Persian Gulf.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Chicago Title and Trust Co., Chicago, a trust services and insurance company, has filed with the California Department of Insurance to acquire two title insurers, Ticor Title Insurance Co. of California and Ticor Title Insurance Co., as well as other assets, from Westwood Equity Corp. The agreement between Chicago Title and Westwood Equity calls for a cash deal of $70 million subject to certain potential reductions and a promissory note due in 1995 for an initial principal amount of $15 million plus interest. * Compucom Systems Inc., Dallas, a microcomputer dealer that is acquiring Computer Factory Inc., Elmsford, N.Y., a microcomputer dealer, for $39 million, said it had received commitments from a group led by Gateway Associates L.P. for the subordinated debt portion of its acquisition financing. * Hanson P.L.C., London, a consumer products company, has bought the Canadian assets of Garant Inc., a maker of lawn and garden tools, for $13.7 million.

headline: China Ousts Foreign Human-Rights Group
abstract: A seven-member delegation that came to China from foreign countries to express concern about political prisoners had its own run-in with the law today, as the police detained the seven and ordered them to leave the country within 24 hours.    The seven delegates, including members from the United States, Canada, Britain and the Netherlands, were released this evening after being detained for nearly five hours. A CBS News cameraman, who was on the scene and whose television camera and film were forcibly confiscated, was toldto return on Tuesday to inquire about recovering the camera.

headline: Iraq Won't Put Pilots on TV
abstract: Iraq said today that it had stopped screening television interviews with captured American and allied pilots "until further notice" but added that the practice, widely condemned in the West, would resume "at the appropriate time."   The Baghdad radio, quoting a spokesman for the Information Ministry, offered no explanation for the announcement, which came shortly after the officially controlled station rebroadcast interviews with three American airmen shown earlier this week on Baghdad television.

headline: U.S.-British Talks End With No Aviation Pact
abstract: The latest round of talks aimed at fashioning a new civil aviation treaty between the United States and Britain ended angrily today after neither side would budge over five final demands by the British.   The United States Government has been eager to obtain a treaty that would allow Trans World Airlines and Pan American World Airways to sell their rights to operate out of London's Heathrow Airport to American Airlines and United Airlines, respectively.

headline: Small Software Maker Is Taking Giant Steps
abstract: The next Microsoft? Many software industry experts think it will be the Santa Cruz Operation Inc.   The Microsoft Corporation, founded in 1975, has grown to more than $1 billion in revenues primarily on the dominance of MS-DOS, the operating-system software it supplies for personal computers.

headline: Spending Down 2%
abstract: Total expenditures for advertising in newspapers declined by 2 percent, to $8.77 billion, in the fourth quarter of last year, from $8.95 billion in the period in 1989, according to preliminary figures released yesterday by the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. For 1990, advertisers spent $32.28 billion in newspapers, a negligible decline from 1989, when advertisers spent $32.37 billion.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Shock Waves; 70 TERRORIST ACTS OUTSIDE U.S. LISTED
abstract: A State Department official said today that about 70 acts of terrorism had been committed against American and allied interests outside the United States since the Persian Gulf war began, including 11 in the last day.   "These incidents have resulted in property damage," said Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman. "So far the injuries have been relatively few."

TREAS. BILLS   6.01   5.96   7.72        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.01   5.95   7.70        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.76   7.78   8.46        30-YR. TREAS. headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JANUARY 1, 1991
abstract: Markets The toughest year since 1981 for investors in stocks ended with a slight gain for the day. The Dow industrials rose 4.45 points, to 2,633.66. The Dow's decline for the year was 4.3 percent.  [ Page 41. ]   Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose solidly in light trading. The long Treasury bond ended 1990 yielding 8.24 percent, down from 8.29 percent on Friday but up from 7.97 percent a year ago.  [ 50. ]   The dollar is expected to be a sideshow this year compared with the German mark, against which it fell 13 percent last year.  [ 51. ]   Soybeans staged a moderate comeback on the Chicago Board of Trade from contract lows reached Friday.  [ 51. ]  The Economy    Gasoline prices have remained relatively high as crude oil prices have fallen steadily, giving rise to renewed allegations by consumer groups of price gouging. Industry executives and analysts disagree on who is making the killing -- service stations, refiners, or someone in between.  [ 41. ]  Crude oil rose 87 cents, to $28.44 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.  [ 53. ]   Ways of preventing a banking disaster are being proposed by consultants outside the banking industry.  [ 42. ]   The prices farmers receive for raw products fell seven-tenths of 1 percent from November to December.  [ 42. ]   In 23 years in Detroit, Focus: Hope has grown into a citywide conglomerate that operates food banks feeding 80,000 hungry people a month and that employs about 180 inner city workers.  [ 1. ]  Technology    What technologies will be most important in the next decade? Science and technology reporters from The New York Times have consulted with experts and chosen 10 of them. Special Report.  [ 35. ]  Companies    USG will attempt an out-of-court restructuring to avert bankruptcy in the face of a deep downturn in its core Sheetrock business. Two other leading makers of wallboard are in bankruptcy.  [ 41. ]   In a likely blow to Northrop, the Pentagon will probably decide not to begin construction in 1991 of any new B-2 Stealth bombers, Government officials and industry analysts said.  [ 41. ]   Ex-workers on the U.S. nuclear submarine program charge that there have been serious safety lapses at its West Milton, N.Y., site and that they were disciplined for raising safety concerns. The program is run for the Government by General Electric.  [ 1. ]   An agreement at Sabena Belgian World Airlines fell apart. The deal was to have given British Airways and KLM each a 20 percent stake in the Belgian carrier.  [ 41. ]   An investment firm sold its 10 percent stake in First Executive at 14 cents a share, below the current quote of 37.5 cents.  [ 42. ]   Two cellular telephone companies announced agreements for their sale: Graphic Scanning will be sold to BellSouth and Celutel will be bought by the Continental Illinois Venture.  [ 44. ]   Data General has dropped a product development agreement with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone of Japan.  [ 44. ]  International    Toyota is expanding at such a breakneck pace that the chief of operations at its Takaoka plant in Japan cannot find enough auto workers. Many Japanese manufacturers are investing heavily, even in the face of a U.S. recession and slower growth at home.  [ 1. ]   Commerzbank has made its strategy work far better than banking experts thought it could when it decided last spring to create its own network of branch offices in eastern Germany.  [ 41. ]  Today's Column    Confidentiality rules are eroding as an indirect result of the growing concern with the cost and quality of health care. Milt Freudenheim: Business and Health.  [ 42. ]

headline: Times Books Publisher
abstract: Peter Osnos, associate publisher of Random House adult trade books, has been named to the additional position of publisher of Times Books. The announcement was made on Monday by Harold Evans, president and publisher of Random House adult trade books. Mr. Evans also recently appointed Peter Gethers as publisher of Villard Books; before that Mr. Gethers was editorial director of Villard. Both Times Books and Villard are independent imprints of Random House Inc.

headline: Doctors Press States to Curb Reviews of Procedures' Costs
abstract: The fierce battle between insurers trying to control medical costs and doctors angered by the intrusion is spilling into state legislatures around the country, and the doctors appear to be gaining.    Pressed hard by influential medical societies and hospital associations, 15 states and the District of Columbia have passed laws to regulate the medical review companies that are at the heart of efforts to limit health-care spending. State medical and hospital groups plan to press for legislation in at least 20 more states this year.

headline: Consumers in Revolt? Light a Fountain of Joy
abstract: Next to a good book, a poem or a penetrating film, there is little a Bengali intellectual enjoys more than a political argument. There is no dearth of those this winter, and that could add up to trouble for the leftist coalition that has ruled the city and the state of West Bengal for almost 14 years.    For the first time, consumer organizations and public-interest groups are getting into the fray in a significant way, building a coalition of intellectuals and middle-class professionals no longer willing to tolerate the haphazard way in which their crumbling city is being run.

headline: MORE ON THE GULF
abstract: He's No L.B.J.  Unlike Lyndon Johnson, George Bush does not sit in the White House choosing enemy targets. He is trying to be a cross between Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, aides say. Page A8. Much Noise Over Silence  The Administration's handling of news coverage of the war has become controversial even before the public has judged its progress. Page A8. Linkage Once Again  Iraq showed what it said were two more captured Americans and sought to link its captives to Israel's Palestinian detainees. Page A10.

headline: Business Diary/March 10-15
abstract: COMPANIES British Airways Whines About Its New Competition  British Airways P.L.C. wants sympathy. Even after winning permission last week to fly between the United States and the Continent and penetrate the American market in a host of other ways -- rights no other foreign airline has had -- the British carrier is sounding defeated and distraught. It seems British Airways will have to accept some competition from United, American and Virgin Atlantic at Heathrow Airport, London's most convenient. The day before creditors were to seize Pan Am's planes, Pan Am and T.W.A. won British approval to sell their Heathrow routes to United and American. "U.S. negotiators have succeeded in weakening British Airways," a spokesman for the airline intoned, as the company's chairman spoke of reduced profitability. Kevin Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, shed few tears. "They're yelping so much it's suspicious," he said. British Airways already plans to invade the Continent by buying a large piece of Sabena World Airlines and forming a new carrier in Germany. The British deal hardly gives America's feeble old international carriers the strength to rise from their wheelchairs. Pan American World Airways, the sickliest case, is earning only enough from its route sale to perhaps survive until someone buys its remaining assets. And Trans World Airlines said the Transportation Department's ban on the sale of three of its six London routes to American, in the interests of competition, imperils its financial health. Maxwell's Plum, or Prune?  "Maxwell's Plum," said a Daily News headline Wednesday morning. "Miracle Max!" and "Daily News Lives!" followed that afternoon. Now Robert Maxwell needs to live up to his headlines. The plum he agreed to buy after settling with the unions last Tuesday has shriveled to perhaps half its former circulation of a million-plus, and even less of its former advertising. His purchase of The News -- the Tribune Company is actually paying    him   $60 million or more to take on the newspaper's liabilities -- is based on agreements by the striking unions to accept sharp staffing cuts. Mr. Maxwell, a British publisher, promised to invest what the News called "mega-money" -- not to mention the mega-time he might need in his trans-Atlantic schedule to lure scores of advertisers, several hundred thousand readers and Jimmy Breslin back to his pages.  Exxon, and Taxpayers, Pay Up  For a company that earns as much as Exxon, $1.1 billion actually isn't real money. No sooner had the Exxon Corporation agreed to pay such a settlement to Alaska and the Federal Government in the Exxon Valdez oil spill than Lawrence G. Rawl, the company's chairman, said there would be virtually no effect on the company's earnings or image. The company also pleaded guilty to four misdemeanors. Exxon's ability to write off the whole settlement save a $100 million criminal penalty will cost taxpayers an estimated $300 million.  A Purge at Chrysler  Tough times provided the Chrysler Corporation with the perfect occasion to kick a union leader off its board. Cost-saving, Chrysler called it, adding that four of the other 18 members were leaving as well. In fact, it's the loss of labor's voice, responded Owen F. Bieber, president of the United Automobile Workers, a dissident on the board and the only departing member who is not in at least his late 60's. Labor representation, unusual on American boards, hardly seems to have hurt corporate competitiveness in countries like Germany. But by reversing itself on the issue, Chrysler has carried out Detroit's most celebrated boardroom purge since H. Ross Perot left General Motors. McDonald's New Burger  No, McDonald's will not draw in the bean sprouts and oat bran crowd with its new, reduced-fat burger. At best, analysts say, the health-conscious might stop sneering so loudly that they embarrass those for whom dieting means ordering the burger and fries without the shake. Diners who do try the "McLean" are likely to be disappointed, said Caroline Levy of Shearson Lehman. "This doesn't even taste like a burger, based on what I've heard," she said. Like the company's recent abandonment of styrofoam containers to placate environmentalists, Ms. Levy said, "It's good for McDonald's image, but I do not see it as good for the bottom line."  In Brief  American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, reduced its lowest fares -- reviving the 30-day advanced-purchase ticket -- to encourage travelers frightened off by the Persian Gulf war or the recession. But some other fares are rising. The Federal Trade Commission is investigating the competitive practices of the Microsoft Corporation, the dominant maker of personal computer software. Microsoft calls the probe minor and limited, its competitors call it broad-ranging, and the F.T.C. is keeping quiet. The House reluctantly poured another $30 billion into the savings and loan bailout last week. THE ECONOMY   Putting a Leash on '900' Calls  The Federal Communications Commission proposes that callers to "900" numbers get to hear the price tags before they pay. Under rules announced Thursday, the "900" services would have to describe their prices and offerings, then give callers a chance to hang up before they are billed. No longer would callers applying for construction jobs learn only later that the calls had cost them $18 each, as the Government alleges, nor would callers for nearly useless credit cards end up paying $49.95. Several industry representatives blasted the F.C.C.'s proposal as a threat to legitimate "900" services; many provide weather, sports scores and stock information for willing customers.  The F.C.C. is likely to issue its final rules by the end of the year. Harsh Message in Output  Factory output fell in February for the fifth straight month, indicating that the recession continued to deepen. An eight-tenths of 1 percent drop last month brought production to the lowest level since June 1988. Lawrence Kudlow, the chief economist at Bear Stearns, said that considering last month's dismal employment report as well, the recession now looks to be as long as average. "The short and mild argument has gone down with the February numbers," he said. But consumer confidence appeared to improve in early March after the war. Inflation Just Simmers Along Wholesale inflation continues to simmer despite a tepid economy. While producer prices overall fell six-tenths of 1 percent last month, the core rate, without volatile food and energy prices, rose four-tenths of 1 percent. Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover, said that like Goldilock's evaluation of the baby bear's porridge -- "not too hot, not too cold," he sees the inflation report as "not too inflationary, not too recessionary." Some economists say inflation remains too strong for the Federal Reserve to further ease credit. Modest Cutback From OPEC  With Iraq no longer around to bluster about the need for much higher prices, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries last week agreed to cut production by only 5 percent, or about a million barrels a day. The agreement demonstrates the influence of Saudi Arabia, which wants to keep prices moderate enough to guarantee long-term demand for its vast oil supplies. With neither Iraq nor Kuwait exporting, most OPEC members have quotas far higher than their previous levels. News of the OPEC agreement nudged oil prices up by only 69 cents last week to $20. The Great Bankruptcy Shield  France had the Theatre du Grand Guignol, presenting murder, rape, torture and suicide. The United States has the bankruptcy courts. The latest example of creative bankruptcy is an Equitable Life Assurance Society production, starring a partly empty 53-story Times Square office tower and grieving investors. The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company accuses Equitable of deceiving other investors and trying to stick them with tens of millions of dollars in losses by throwing the partnership that owns the tower into bankruptcy. This, after Manville used the bankruptcy courts to confront its asbestos claimants; Texaco, to rebuff a challenge from Pennzoil, and Frank Lorenzo, to fend off his striking airline unions. Equitable and Manufacturers reached a tentative settlement on Friday, but negotiations on the exact terms continued. INTERNATIONAL   A Bigger Slice of Soviet Pie  Soviet officials harass foreign businesses, protesting crowds swarm around the Kremlin walls, but Pizza Hut's first two Moscow restaurants claim profit margins higher than in the United States. Russians line up down the block for the chance to pass an hour or two in a Western setting. But the trials of doing business in the Soviet Union have slowed Pizza Hut's expansion plans. Andrew Rafalat, the Pizza Hut executive who opened the restaurants in September, said he first needs to secure domestic supplies of meat and mozzarella cheese, to save the expense of buying them for hard currency in Western Europe and trucking them all the way in. Soviet meat suppliers are still incredulous when he asks them to meet his specifications. "They say, 'We're giving you a scarce product. We're doing you a favor.' " Mr. Rafalat, visiting the Pepsico parent company's New York headquarters last week, said he hopes to open some stand-alone take-out windows in Moscow by the end of the year. But as David Williams, senior vice president of Pepsico Food Service International, said, "Nothing in the Soviet Union comes easily. Nothing is handed to you on a plate." Except for some American-style pizzas, he hopes. Forgiving Poland  Leading industrialized nations have decided that the proto-capitalist Poles should not suffer for the borrowing binge of their deposed Communist rulers. To aid Poland's progress toward a market economy, officials meeting in Paris agreed to forgive about half the $33 billion owed and ease repayment terms on the rest. While micro-entrepreneurs have lined several of Warsaw's broadest boulevards with their booths, the most ambitious economic reforms in Eastern Europe have also caused severe unemployment. The Trade Police in Japan  Inspectors and police milling around an American rice exhibit at a Tokyo food show last week became, in the view of American officials, a prime exhibit of Japanese protectionism run amok. Japanese officials insisted that the sealed bags and plastic containers of American rice, if not the "Have a Rice Day" bumper stickers, violated laws against rice imports. Americans insisted the display was solely educational.

headline: Independent a Year, Namibia Is Pragmatic at Home and Ideological Abroad
abstract: When Namibia gained its independence on March 21, 1990, after 75 years of South African rule, some departing skeptics jibed that goats would soon graze on grass poking through the cracked asphalt on Kaiser Street, Windhoek's main thoroughfare.    Others predicted that the South-West Africa People's Organization, the nationalist movement that became the governing political party, would impose its Marxist ideology on the world's youngest nation.

headline: P.&G. Is Selling Its Santa Fe Brand
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company agreed to sell its Santa Fe brand of men's fragrances and toiletries to Ducair Tsumura. P.&G. declined to disclose the sale price or other terms.   Ducair Tsumura, based in North Bergen, N.J., is a division of Tsumura International Inc., the United States subsidiary of Tokyo-based Tsumura & Company. The company markets children's toiletries, cosmetic gifts and fragrances.

headline: Perrier Agrees To Change Ads
abstract: Perrier Group of America, the Greenwich, Conn., subsidiary of the French company that bottles Perrier mineral water, has agreed to a Government order to change its advertising.   Perrier approved a consent order by the Federal Trade Commission to give an accurate description of how its water is bottled. The F.T.C. had objected to what it said were Perrier's claims that the water was all natural -- unprocessed and unfiltered.

headline: U.S. OFFERS TO FLY BAKER TO GENEVA TO TALK TO IRAQI
abstract: In the latest move on an increasingly muddled diplomatic exchange with Iraq, President Bush offered today to send Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to Switzerland next week to meet with Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz.   Mr. Bush said he was "not prepared to repeat his previous offer" to send Mr. Baker to Baghdad to meet directly with President Saddam Hussein. But he and his aides left the door open to such a meeting, although the White House had originally set today as a deadline for talks.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; Shamir's Move: Post-War Leverage?
abstract: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir says he was merely strengthening his party's tenuous hold on power when he pushed through the Cabinet appointment of the Parliament's farthest-right-wing member, despite opposition from even some very close political allies.    But some analysts and Shamir political opponents are now saying the appointment this week was just one more step in the Likud party's preparations to rebuff the expected pressure from abroad to solve the Palestinian problem, once the gulf war ends.

headline: Daily Riyadh-Dammam Express: It's No Toonerville Trolley
abstract: War having closed the Dhahran airport to all but military aircraft and having clogged the roads with tank transporters, the train has become the preferred means of civilian travel between eastern Saudi Arabia and Riyadh.    It is no Toonerville Trolley. Pulled by big diesel engines that look a lot like the ones that used to pull the Super Chief into Los Angeles, the eight-car, silver-and-blue expresses run twice a day in each direction between here and Dammam, a seaport next to Dhahran. It crosses the 250 miles of desert on a smooth-as-silk roadbed in just over four hours.

headline: Recycling Is a Way of Life for Russians: To Survive, They Must Scavenge
abstract: When her son needed a new shirt, Zoya Begovaya moved up the cuffs on an old shirt of her husband. When she couldn't find sponges in the store, she knotted together old stockings to scrub her dishes. And when the price of newspapers tripled at the beginning of the year, she and her neighbors decided to share a subscription.   She is not poor and she is not starving, but like most Soviet citizens Mrs. Begovaya is forced by shortage and cost to patch, preserve and swap to run her household. Nothing Is Beyond Use     "I tell my husband that I am a human bird, building my nest by scavenging," she said, a cracked laugh belying frustration in a country where squirreling things away for future use is not an eccentricity, but a way of life.

headline: Conservation Doubles Elephants in Uganda
abstract: Uganda's elephant population has more than doubled in a decade as a result of an intensified war against poachers.   The New Vision newspaper today quoted Eric Edroma, director of Uganda's national parks, as saying that the number of elephants had risen to about 3,000 this year, from 1,350 in 1980 .   He attributed the increase to better training of park rangers, which has made them more effective against poachers and a campaign to educate the public about wildlife conservation.   Mr. Edroma made his comments to representatives of the Ele-Drive Trust, a British conservation group, who were on an African trek called the Great Elephant Trail Expedition.   The team is gathering information on the threats to the African elephant. Elephant tusks, sold mostly to Asian markets, are widely used to make ornaments.   Mr. Edroma said a wanton slaughter of Uganda's elephants occurred during the rule of the dictator Idi Amin from 1969 to 1979. In 1989, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species listed the African elephant as endangered and banned the sale of ivory worldwide.

headline: Kollmorgen Seeking New Chief Executive
abstract: The Kollmorgen Corporation is looking for a new chief executive. John L. Youngblood, who led the company successfully through several difficulties last year, has announced that he plans to resign July 1.   Mr. Youngblood, 49 years old, became president and chief operating officer in 1989, with responsibility for cuttting costs and streamlining the company, based in Simsbury, Conn. Kollmorgen makes specialized motors and controls and electro-optical military and industrial instruments. It has been making submarine periscopes for the Navy since 1916.

headline: McCaw Proposal For Debentures
abstract: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. announced a move to save millions of dollars in interest charges by converting debentures into voting stock. The nation's largest cellular telephone company said each $1,000 in principal of the company's 12.95 percent senior subordinated debentures due on Aug. 15 could be exchanged for 35 shares of class A common stock. The company said it would also pay $12.23 in cash for each $1,000 worth of conversion.   McCaw officials expect about 45 percent of the $600 million in debentures to be converted, resulting in annual savings of about $35 million in interest, a spokesman, Robert Ratliffe, said. The company has 112.9 million shares of class A stock and 66.3 million class B shares outstanding. The class A stock fell $1.50 today, to $22.75, in over-the-counter trading.

headline: Suburban Rental Market; Stamford Apartments Near Completion
abstract: Trammell Crow Residential, the nation's largest builder of rental housing, is making its first entry into the Stamford, Conn., market with a 197-unit project that is to open for leasing this month and for occupancy in April.  The four-story project, called Town Glen, is being developed by the company's Northeast division, which is based in New Canaan, Conn. The apartments, at 66 Glenbrook Road and Hope Street, will have one- and two-bedroom apartments, a heated outdoor pool, a clubhouse and a racquetball court. Rents begin at $970 for a one-bedroom apartment and at $1,260 for two bedrooms.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; Air Force Makes the Killing Methodical
abstract: The air war against Iraq is being divided into "killing boxes."    On new Air Force maps of Kuwait and southern Iraq, each box represents an area several miles long and wide, and is identified by a series of letters and numbers.

headline: Kodak Posts Improved Earnings
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company, best known as a producer of photographic film, yesterday reported strong earnings for the fourth quarter and year, despite a $564 million after-tax charge to settle its patent-infringement case with the Polaroid Corporation. Most of the quarterly growth came from overseas operations.    "Despite a sluggish U.S. economy, 1990 was clearly a recovery year for Kodak," Kay R. Whitmore, the chairman, said in a statement. "Significant factors contributing to higher earnings were gains in manufacturing productivity and the favorable effects of foreign currency rate changes."

headline: Virgin Atlantic Airways Set For First National U.S. Drive
abstract: VIRGIN ATLANTIC AIRWAYS plans to step up its battle with airline goliaths like British Airways in its first national ad campaign in the United States. The campaign will begin Friday.    The tiny British airline, which began flights between the United States and London six years ago, hopes to capitalize on its recently increased access to American cities, a right it gained as a result of an agreement by the two countries over landing rights at Heathrow Airport in London.

headline: Financing Is Offered on S.& L. Assets
abstract: In an auction next month, Federal officials plan to offer purchasers financing for up to 85 percent of the price of dozens of apartment buildings in Texas that the Government acquired in the savings industry bailout.    So far, the Government has not been able to attract enough bidders on these and billions of dollars of other foreclosed properties.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Captives; Baghdad releases CBS News Crew
abstract: The Iraqi Government freed the CBS News correspondent Bob Simon and his three-man crew yesterday in Baghdad after holding them captive for 40 days.    "I thank God that the four of us are alive," Mr. Simon said in a broadcast by CBS from Baghdad after the four were freed at the Soviet Embassy. They later left by car for Amman, Jordan.

headline: High Court to Hear Case On Special Tax Judges
abstract: In a case that could affect the way appeals are handled in many complex tax disputes, the Supreme Court agreed today to hear a challenge to the Tax Court's growing use of specially appointed trial judges.   The 19 regular judges of the Tax Court, which hears appeals on Internal Revenue Service rulings, are nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate for 15-year terms. By contrast, the special trial judges are chosen by the court's chief judge to serve indefinite terms. Because of the huge volume of cases, 14 such judges are handling nearly half the court's caseload, including many complex tax shelter cases.

headline: Bush Vows to Tackle Middle East Issues
abstract: As the United States grappled with signs of discord within the Persian Gulf coalition, President Bush promised today that when the war is over, Washington will take the lead in efforts "to bring peace to the rest of the Middle East."   In a speech to the National Association of Religious Broadcasters, Mr. Bush also sought to reassure American allies that the United States is trying to minimize civilian casualties in the war and does "not seek the destruction of Iraq."

headline: In Tense, Fearful Lithuania, a Bride and Groom Exchange Hopeful Vows
abstract: Against the tide of crisis, Yuratia Shaevienie went ahead with her wedding and managed to be radiant today amid the wintry frost that glazed this embattled republic. She was a study in white against white, hope against hope.   "The tanks can come, but life will go on," said Romas Kazlouskas as he photographed his friend in the church on her wedding day while the city remained clutched by fear of further Soviet military violence. "They can send more tanks, but still we will keep on living. We have no choice but to be born, get married, and die."

headline: Gorbachev Appoints New Finance Minister
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appointed a conservative economist today to be the new Soviet Finance Minister.   A new Cabinet list released in Parliament and signed by Gorbachev named the economist, Vladimir Orlov, to replace Valentin Pavlov, who was appointed Prime Minister in January.   Mr. Orlov's appointment must be confirmed by Parliament.   Mr. Orlov, an advocate of very gradual transition to market economics, is deputy chairman of the Soviet Parliament's Economic Reform Commission.   The list also indicated that Defense Minister Dmitri Yazov and Vladimir Kryuchkov, head of the K.G.B., seen by radicals as stalwarts of communist orthodoxy, would be retained in their posts.   The cabinet is the first to be drawn up under new power structures allowing Gorbachev direct control over his ministers and giving him sweeping authority to direct policy.

headline: Paris Journal; Vietnam Echo Stuns France: Case of Treachery?
abstract: As Georges Boudarel remembers things, he was driven by idealism when, in the early 1950's, he joined Communist Vietminh rebels fighting French colonial rule in Indochina and finished up giving Marxist indoctrination classes to French prisoners of war.    His former captives, on the other hand, remember Mr. Boudarel as the treacherous young Frenchman known as Dai Dong who deserted to the enemy camp, who engaged in "moral and psychological torture" and who did nothing to prevent dozens of his countrymen from dying of starvation.

headline: Economic Calender
abstract: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Retail Sales...Jan. Thursday Business Inventories...Dec. Friday Producer Price Index...Jan. Merchandise Trade...Dec. Industrial Production...Jan. Capacity Utilization...Jan.

headline: Fabricland Gets Bid
abstract: House of Fabrics Inc. began a $43 million hostile tender offer yesterday for another fabric retailer, Fabricland Inc. of Portland, Ore.    The offer, announced in an advertisement on page D5 of The New York Times, offered $13.50 a share for all shares. The offer was conditioned on, among other things, House of Fabrics obtaining financing and being able to vote all shares purchased. That would require action by Fabricland's shareholders or board to exempt their company from Oregon's anti-takeover law.   House of Fabrics, based in Sherman Oaks, Calif., had previously made such an offer to Fabricland's board, which said on Tuesday that it had hired Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company to advise it. But W. Douglas Caudell, Fabricland's vice president for finance, said the company had not known of the tender offer until he was told of it by a reporter. He declined to comment on the offer. House of Fabric officials could not be reached for comment.    In over-the-counter trading yesterday, before the tender offer was disclosed, Fabricland shares fell 25 cents, to $12.25. House of Fabrics rose 12.5 cents, to $28.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Vermont Development Laws May Have Saved Its Banks
abstract: Vermont is the only New England state that has not had a bank failure in the current economic downturn, and its strict environmental laws -- not shrewd Yankee banking -- are widely credited with saving the state from the worst excesses of the Northeast's real estate boom.   "There are still problems here, but nowhere like those in New Hampshire, Maine and Massachusetts," said Thomas Menson, a former chief operating officer of the Bank of Vermont. Mr. Menson also spent the last five years as the top banking and financial adviser to Madeleine M. Kunin, who recently stepped down as Governor.

headline: Bond Market Is Unchanged
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities were essentially unchanged yesterday in extremely light dealings. With New York Treasury dealers closed for Good Friday, along with most European financial centers, transactions were few and price moves largely nominal. The corporate and tax-exempt bond markets were closed, as were the stock and commodity exchanges.    But several dealers who were at their desks said they were marking down the Treasury's benchmark long bonds in expectation of weaker bond prices on Monday because of Government reports issued early in the day that showed sharp gains in the index of leading economic indicators as well as sales of new homes.

headline: No Zapata Bankruptcy
abstract: The Zapata Corporation, an energy and fishing company founded nearly three decades ago by President Bush, avoided a bankruptcy filing today by successfully buying back a series of debt securities at a steep discount. Under an agreement Zapata reached with banks in August, the company had to retire 66.7 percent of these securities as part of a broader debt restructuring that would help insure its long-term survival. The deadline for the sale had been Friday, but Zapata board members voted to extend it to 4 P.M. Saturday, central standard time.

headline: Money Market Fund Yields Are Mixed for a 4th Week
abstract: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report, and reported yesterday, were mixed for the fourth consecutive week.    Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's say that last week's consumer price data for February set the market back somewhat, leaving no sense that the recession is over, but they say most of rate decline has passed.

headline: Data Bank/January 27, 1991
abstract: Gross National Product   IV Q'90   III Q'90   II Q'90        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions   $4,147.6   $4,170.0   $4,155.1        Real G.N.P. Growth       Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in percent   --2.1   1.4   0.4        G.N.P Deflator       Percent change   2.8   3.7   4.7        Japanese Consumer Price Index   Nov.   Oct.   Sept.
