headline: Welbilt Chief Executive Quits to Form a Venture
abstract: Richard L. Hirsch joined the Welbilt Corporation, his family's stove manufacturing business, in 1963 and left at the first of the year after many years as its head. Yesterday, he announced plans for a new venture, Concurrent Industries Group, which will invest in and provide management for companies with potential that need help.    Mr. Hirsch, 50, was president and chief executive of Welbilt, based in New Hyde Park, L.I., since 1971. In 1988, the company agreed to be acquired in a leveraged buyout by a management group led by Mr. Hirsch and by Kohlberg & Company, an investment firm headed by Jerome Kohlberg.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Air France, the state-owned airline, will receive two billion francs, or about $400 million, of new capital from the French Government in 1991 as part of the effort to help the company through the current downturn. * Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc., New York, the technology and management consultant, will acquire Spicer & Oppenheim Consultants, London, a financial services consultant, for undisclosed terms. * British Steel P.L.C., London, said it would cut a further 1,100 jobs at its Scottish Ravenscraig steel works and operate only one blast furnace at the plant. * Campeau Corp., Toronto, the real estate and retail company, will sell its Hippodrome Blue Bonnets properties in Quebec to the Societe d'Habitation et de Developpement de Montreal, a municipal agency, for $46 million (Canadian). * Champion International Corp., Stamford, Conn., a producer of building materials and paper products, reduced the quarterly dividend payment on its common stock to 5 cents a share from 27.5 cents.  * Ford Motor Co., Dearborn, Mich., said its president, Philip Benton, would undergo coronary bypass surgery in the next few days. Mr. Benton's duties will be temporarily assumed by Allan Gilmour, president of Ford's automotive group. * General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn., said its equally-owned CFM International joint venture with Snecma of France had received an order worth more than $500 million to provide CFM56-3 high bypass turbofan engines for Asiana Airlines of South Korea. * Volvo Cars of North America said it would raise the prices of its 1991 models by 1.8 percent on a sales-weighted basis.

headline: U.S. Concern: Captives' Fate In Gas Attack
abstract: American officials are preparing to hand out gas masks to captured Iraqi soldiers, and given the state of their Soviet gas masks this may be good news for Iraqi prisoners.    The Soviet masks, made of cheap rubber, have been found to have defective filters. They are also very difficult to talk through.

headline: Gulf Concession That Wasn't: U.S. Moves to Quell a Furor
abstract: The Bush Administration scrambled today to contain political damage from a Soviet-American communique that embarrassed Mr. Bush with some of his allies and brought simmering conflicts between the White House and State Department into the open.   The statement about the war in the Persian Gulf -- drafted at the last minute on Tuesday night and, officials said, released without the President's knowledge -- was interpreted by some American allies as an offer of a cease-fire to Iraq and a link between the Persian Gulf and the Palestinian dispute.

headline: Germany Says It Seeks to Curb Its Arms Exporters
abstract: The Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced today that it would seek new sanctions against illegal arms exporters, as a result of the growing scandal over German arms exports to Iraq.   Under the proposals, the minimum prison term for those convicted of violating a trade embargo imposed by the United Nations would be increased from six months to one year, with maximum sentences up to 10 years.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; ALLIED FORCES STORM IRAQ AND KUWAIT AFTER HUSSEIN IGNORES U.S. DEADLINE; BUSH SEES A SWIFT, DECISIVE VICTORY
abstract: A vast, multi-pronged land attack against Iraqi forces began two hours before dawn today after President Bush's deadline for the start of an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait slipped by with no sign in word or deed that President Saddam Hussein would comply.   "The liberation of Kuwait has now entered a final phase," President Bush announced in Washington.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Intermet Corp., Atlanta, a manufacturer of iron products, named John D. Ernst vice president, finance, and chief financial officer. E.A. Bodnar was named president of the company's domestic foundry group. * Macmillan/McGraw-Hill School Publishing Co., Lake Forest, Ill., a joint venture of Macmillan Inc. and McGraw-Hill Inc., named Catherine McAward president of its international division. * National Heritage Inc., Dallas, a manager of nursing homes, named James J. Murphy executive vice president and chief operating officer. * Pinelands Inc., Secaucus, N.J., the new company that owns WWOR-TV, named Barbara L. Landes vice president, chief financial officer and treasurer. * RJR Nabisco Inc., New York, named Bruce J. Wood president of its Planters Lifesavers Co. He replaces Dolph W. von Arx, who is retiring. The company also established a new RJR Nabisco Foods Group, headed by H. John Greeniaus, to which Planters Lifesavers and Nabisco Brands Inc. will report. * Time Life Inc., New York, a subsidiary of Time Warner Inc., named Paul Stewart vice chairman. * Walt Disney Imagineering, Glendale, Calif., a subsidiary of Walt Disney Co., named Dick Sargon vice president, project management, a new position.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Companies    South Korea dropped McDonnell Douglas from a $5 billion program to build fighter planes for its air force and will award the contract to General Dynamics. The switch came after months of disputes over costs. Analysts say the performance of General Dynamics's F-16 in the Persian Gulf also impressed Seoul.  [ D1. ]  General Dynamics stands to get $2 billion in added revenue through 1999; analysts say McDonnell may not suffer severe damage.  [ D4. ]

headline: More on the Gulf
abstract: PRIDE OF WORKERS -- The 24,000 employees building F-16's at a General Dynamics plant in Fort Worth are rooting for the jet fighters with pride, confidence and worry. Business Day, page 37.  GAMES STILL ON -- There are no plans to cancel, postpone or reschedule any sports events. But the National Football League said television rescheduling could determine if Sunday's Giants-49ers and the Bills- Raiders games are played. The league can postpone the games up to Sunday morning. Sports, page 49.  PRAYERS FOR PEACE -- In the middle of a vast cathedral in the middle of the night, a diverse few gather to pray for peace. About New York, page 33.  WAR AND GOD -- Amid war's anguish, millions turn to God, stirring questions on the nature of prayer. Beliefs, page 17.

headline: Gasoline Prices Decline
abstract: Lower winter demand and increased oil supplies have pushed gasoline prices lower by more than 5 cents a gallon at stations nationwide in the last two weeks, a survey has found. The average price for all grades of gasoline at full- and self-service stations, including taxes, was $1.2522 a gallon on Friday, down 5.13 cents from Jan. 25, according to the biweekly Lundberg Survey of more than 13,000 service stations.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Vatican; The Pope's Divisions Attract Strange Recruits Over Gulf
abstract: The obvious futility of the many appeals from Pope John Paul II for an end to the Persian Gulf war is raising questions about papal influence that for some here evoke Stalin's derisive remark of decades ago: How many divisions does the Pope have?   A year ago, that cynical observation seemed clearly misguided as Communism collapsed across Eastern Europe. In spiritual influence, the Pope had amply demonstrated his strength, receiving credit from many sources for having supplied moral firepower to the anti-Communist revolution.

headline: Wall Street; One More Way to Lose on Airlines
abstract: One thing you can say for the airline industry: It has certainly offered investors a lot of ways to lose money over the last year.   There's the old-fashioned route of buying stock in an airline like Pan American, the latest carrier to seek bankruptcy court protection. Another option: investing in the "junk bonds" issued by Trans World Airlines in the days before Carl Icahn, the company's chairman, started using the term "Chapter 11" in his public conversations.

headline: Rhode Island Suit Is Filed
abstract: A lawsuit was filed today contending that Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun violated state and Federal constitutional standards when he closed 45 Rhode Island banks and credit unions.   "In effect, the Governor is confiscating people's property witout due process," said Stephen J. Fortunato Jr., the lawyer who filed the class-action lawsuit on behalf of a depositor at the Rhode Island Central Credit Union. "There was no hearing, no notice."   The lawsuit seeks the release of $276 million in frozen assets at the credit union, one of 16 state banking institutions that remain closed.   Mr. Sundlun; the director of the Department of Business Regulation, Maurice A. Paradis, and the state'sgeneral treasurer, Anthony Solomon, were named as defendants in the United States District Court lawsuit.   Thomas Tarro, Mr. Fortunato's partner, said while the Governor could temporarily suspend payments of savings accounts, the bylaws of credit unions require that money placed in checking accounts, escrow accounts, trust accounts and cashiers' checks be made available on demand.   Mr. Sundlun closed the 45 banks and credit unions on New Year's Day because of the failure of their private insurer, the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation.   Most of the small institutions have obtained Federal deposit insurance and reopened. But 16 remain closed because they have been rejected for Federal insurance.

headline: Variety Inc. Fills Post
abstract: Peter Bart, editor of Weekly Variety, has been named to the new post of editorial director of Variety Inc., to coordinate editorial direction and management of both Daily and Weekly Variety and to maximize information resources at each.    Weekly Variety, founded in 1905, is an international newspaper covering the entertainment industry while Daily Variety, founded in 1933, provides the West Coast entertainment community with breaking industry news. Mr. Bart, who remains editor of Weekly Variety, will oversee the editorial direction of both newspapers in consultation with their respective publishers. Both are publications of Cahners Magazines, a division of Reed Publishing (USA) Inc.    Mr. Bart, a former reporter at The New York Times, The Chicago Sun-Times and The Wall Street Journal, entered the film production field in 1968 as vice president, production at Paramount Studios. While there, he was involved in producing "Rosemary's Baby," "Goodbye Columbus" and "The Godfather." In 1975, he became a partner in his own film production company and in 1978 he was president of the Lorimar Film Company.

headline: Strikes Sweep Eastern Germany, Reflecting Increasing Discontent
abstract: Strikes and work stoppages idled tens of thousands of workers throughout eastern Germany for the second consecutive day today, just days after Germany's Government agreed to raise taxes to bolster eastern Germany's sputtering economy.   The angry demonstrations underscore growing discontent in the formerly Communist East just four months after it merged with wealthy West Germany. "We're not second-class citizens," said one banner held aloft at a rally in Frankfurt, where a large microchip factory faces closure.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: FRANCE Theme of Reaction: Unshaken Unity; Mitterrand Calls Iraqi's Choice Fatal
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand said tonight that the ouster of President Saddam Hussein was not an allied objective but that Mr. Hussein had nonetheless chosen "a kind of political and military suicide" that could change the situation in Iraq and "weaken his moral, political and military authority."    In a televised interview with four French reporters, Mr. Mitterrand went out of his way to pay tribute to last-minute Soviet efforts to avert a ground war, but he said the allies could not accept several terms, including those of giving Iraq 21 days to leave Kuwait and ordering a cease-fire before a withdrawal. "It was too late," he said.

headline: Dime Savings Bank Raises Its President to Chairman
abstract: The Dime Savings Bank of New York yesterday elevated its president and chief executive, Richard D. Parsons, to be chairman and chief executive and hired a new president and chief operating officer, Lawrence J. Toal, a former Chase Manhattan banker.    The Dime said Mr. Parsons, 42, succeeded Harry W. Albright Jr., who retired and was named chairman emeritus. Mr. Albright has been chairman since 1981.

headline: Your Money; New Calculations For Keogh Plans
abstract: Although income tax rules for 1990 returns are little changed from last year, self-employed people face some tricky new calculations that must be done correctly to determine how much may be contributed to a Keogh tax-deferred retirement plan.   Keogh plans must have been set up by Dec. 31, but participants have until the date their returns are due -- with extensions, as late as October -- to put money in them.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Troops; Harlem's Guard Troops Complain of Treatment
abstract: Members of the Harlem Hell Fighters, one of the country's oldest and most renowned black National Guard units, say it has been broken up, stripped of much of its equipment and moved into front-line positions without proper preparation or training.   Many of the National Guardsmen from the 369th Transport Battalion, over 50 percent of whom served in Vietnam and most of whom are over 40, have found themselves appendaged to a regular Army combat battalion that they say does not respect their experience, age or professional status.

headline: U.S.-Taiwan Trade Talks
abstract: Taiwan sought United States support today for its bid to enter GATT, the international trade organization.   The request came as the two sides opened four days of talks on such issues as tariff cuts, protection for patents and copyrights, and United States demands for greater access to Taiwan's agricultural, insurance and banking markets.

headline: Philip Morris Sets $350 Million Issue
abstract: The Philip Morris Companies is offering $350 million in notes due on March 1, 1998, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.   The eight-year notes have an 8 7/8 percent coupon and are priced at 99.778 to yield 8.663 percent, or about 70 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.    Noncallable through maturity by the company, the securities are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Mexican Inflation at 30%
abstract: Mexican consumer prices rose by 30 percent in 1990, the central bank reported last week. The figure is higher than the previous year but still somewhat heartening in a country that once suffered triple-digit inflation. Officials have pledged to cut the 1990 figure in half this year as they press for a free-trade agreement with the United States and Canada.

headline: Home-Loan Issue By Fleet/Norstar
abstract: Fleet Finance Home Equity Trust 1991-1, a unit of Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc., Providence, R.I., is offering about $380 million in securities backed by home-equity loans through the First Boston Corporation.   About $348.1 million of 8.45 percent class A certificates were priced at 99.29 to yield 8.639 percent, or 133 basis points above the comparable two- and three-year Treasury notes. The securities, which have a 2.41-year average life, will mature in 2006.   About $34.4 million of 10.10 percent class B certificates were priced at 99.29 to yield 10.33 percent, or 262.5 basis points above four-year Treasury notes. The securities, which have an average life of 4.14 years, will also mature in 2006.

headline: More Signs Of a Slump Nationwide
abstract: Business activity was falling in most parts of the country in the weeks leading up to the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf, with little sign that the contraction was being blunted by lower interest rates, a Federal Reserve survey showed today.   The Fed's "beige book" report on current economic conditions called the situation in the gulf "a key determinant of both current and future economic activity," which the Fed said "appears to be declining in most districts."

headline: Wall Street; Trouble as Defaults Rise
abstract: When demand for credit-enhanced securities took off in the 80's, many banks gladly offered to act as a lender of last resort. And why not? In exchange for promising to cash out bondholders in a pinch, the banks collected fees ranging from one-half of 1 percent to 2 percent of the issues. And unlike interest income, which is earned slowly over the life of a loan, fee income lifts profits immediately.    The test will come now that so many borrowers are defaulting. Citibank alone has about $25 billion of standby letters of credit on its books, more than three times its equity and more than its highly leveraged transactions and commercial real-estate loans combined.   Even so, many experts believe the banks' exposure is modest, given their ability to seize collateral or seek reimbursement from the bond issuers to offset losses.

headline: World Markets; A Cooler German Auto Market?
abstract: Recession is biting sharply into most European auto makers' sales and earnings. But Germany's auto market is booming, with new-car registrations climbing 39 percent in January, primarily because of pent-up demand for cars in eastern Germany. Even Daimler Benz's new top-of-the-line Mercedes luxury cars -- the "S" class, priced at $60,000 and up -- have been an immediate hit with critics and customers.  So why was Daimler's stock -- and shares of the industry's other German flagships, Volkswagen A.G. and Bayerische Motorenwerke A.G., the maker of BMW's -- left behind in the first-quarter surge on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, Germany's primary equities market?

headline: Chief Executive Named For A. L. Laboratories
abstract: A. L. Laboratories Inc. has an ambitious growth plan, and it named a new president and chief executive yesterday to try to carry it out.    The company, a maker of generic and specialty pharmaceuticals, named Richard P. Storm, 53, to succeed I. Roy Cohen, 68, who is retiring after leading the company through steady earnings growth since its establishment in the United States in 1976. Mr. Cohen will continue as vice chairman, said E. W. Sissener, the chairman.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Kuwait; Palestinians in Kuwait Face Suspicion and Probable Exile
abstract: Saleh Ismail stood trembling in front of the Kuwaiti security officer who had him brought up from a basement.   The 48-year-old Mr. Ismail is one of an unknown number of Palestinians being arrested here daily as Kuwaitis turn in those they accuse of informing on members of the Kuwaiti underground and spying for the Iraqi troops who occupied their country.

headline: Punta del Este Journal; For Argentines, There's No Place Like Uruguay
abstract: Summers do not pass at this chic, bustling resort city on the southern coast of Uruguay without talk of beautiful women, tiny bathing suits, deep tans, visiting royalty and a night life that regularly ends at 4 or 5 in the morning.    But that is being rivaled this season by more mercantile chatter: the vast flow of capital into this country from neighboring Argentina and Brazil, escaping economic upheavals and Government intervention there. And the most obvious manifestation of this flight of capital is the number of homes worth $1 million and more that are being built.

headline: New President At Muppet Unit
abstract: The oldest son of the creator of the Muppets, Jim Henson, has been named president of the television and film production company his father founded in 1958.   Brian Henson, who is 27 years old, will head Jim Henson Productions Inc., which he jointly owns with his four siblings. Mr. Henson replaces David Lazer, who will remain a board member and active consultant, company officials said last week.   Jim Henson, who created a gallery of beloved creatures including Kermit the Frog and Big Bird, died May 15 of pneumonia at age 53.   Jim Henson established the company more than 30 years ago as Muppets Inc. to produce his film and television properties. It has since grown to include home video production, book publishing, music publishing and licensing divisions.   Brian Henson, whose own production credits include "The Great Muppet Caper," "Labyrinth" and "Little Shop of Horrors," said the company's latest project, a prime- time situation comedy called "Dinosaurs," will begin on ABC-TV in the spring.   The company is supported in its projects by its two puppet workshops, the Creature Shop in London and the Muppet Workshop in New York.

headline: Iraq Says Air Raids Have Killed 324 Civilians
abstract: The Baghdad Government said today that the American-led alliance had killed at least 324 civilians, wounded another 416 and damaged or destroyed religious, cultural and residential buildings during its aerial bombardment of Iraq.   The Iraqi charges were made in a letter from Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, which also said Baghdad holds Mr. Perez de Cuellar personally responsible "to history and to mankind" for the civilian death and destruction it said the raids are causing.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE, LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: New Banking Restrictions Are Proposed
abstract: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee proposed legislation today that would require banks to suspend dividend payments and bonuses for senior executives if they failed to satisfy regulatory requirements.    The measure by the Senator, Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, is the latest to address the crisis in the banking industry and the dwindling money in the program that insures depositors.

headline: Real Estate and Tax Abuses
abstract: To the Editor:   With regard to Ronald G. Weiner's Forum article ("Blame the Recession on Tax Reform," March 10), while I have no quarrel with the general thrust of the article, I think Mr. Weiner is looking through the wrong end of the telescope when he blames the end of a tax abuse for real estate problems.   The very cause of the problem was the fact that investors flocked to real estate ventures of all stripes because of the artificial arrangements. Undoing those has caused and will continue to cause for some time a considerable degree of pain for those lured into such investments.   But Mr. Weiner blames the cure for being the disease. The fact is that the real disease has caused speculative overbuilding at every level and the real estate markets are coming apart from the oversupply (coupled with reduced purchasing power from a recessionary economy).   By Mr. Weiner's logic, the Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and now the Resolution Trust Corporation should be held liable for the saving and loan and other banking industry problems! HARVEY L. SHULMAN  New York, March 13

headline: TALKS IN IRAN SEEK TO FREE HOSTAGES
abstract: Talks are under way in the Iranian capital in an effort to secure the release of Western hostages in Lebanon, say Shiite Muslims well informed about the activities of the Party of God, the umbrella group for clandestine factions holding the captives.   The Shiites said today that high-ranking Party of God officials had been summoned to Teheran by senior officials in the Government of President Hashemi Rafsanjani.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Diplomacy; SOVIETS SAY IRAQ ACCEPTS KUWAIT PULLOUT LINKED TO TRUCE AND AN END TO SANCTIONS; BUSH REJECTS CONDITIONS: WAR IS TO GO ON
abstract: Moscow announced early today after talks with Iraq's Foreign Minister that President Saddam Hussein had given a "positive" response to a new Soviet peace proposal and had agreed to withdraw from Kuwait.    A breathless spokesman for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev rushed into a press briefing at 2:40 A.M. Moscow time after the meeting with the Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, and declared, "The response is positive."

headline: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
abstract: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.    The pool reporters obtain information while under military escort, and their accounts are subject to scrutiny by military censors before being distributed. Some of the information appearing today on American military operations was obtained under such circumstances.

headline: Advice Every Investor Should Ignore
abstract: I Have been advising people about how to invest their money for 38 years. What I have learned is simple: You have to forget about forecasting the markets and the professionals who say they can.   But what do you do now, with a war going on, with a recession, with a $3 trillion Federal deficit and a crisis in the savings and loan and banking industries? What do you do when there's not much happening to make you feel confident? The answer is the same. Concentrate on your needs.

headline: Slain Leader's Widow Leads in Bangladesh Vote
abstract: Khaled Zia, the widow of an assassinated President, held a strong lead this morning with the results of two-thirds of the contests in a parliamentary election unofficially declared.    The elections Wednesday followed the fall of Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, who is under house arrest awaiting trial on corruption and other charges.

headline: Chip Maker Posts Profit
abstract: Buoyed by a restructuring credit from the sale of a plant, the National Semiconductor Corporation today reported a profit for its third quarter. But revenues fell, and the company realized no operating profit.   For the quarter that ended on Feb. 24, National reported earnings of $5 million, or 2 cents a share, compared with a loss of $10.2 million in the comparable period a year ago. Sales dropped 5 percent, to $386.8 million, from $404.3 million.    The results include a credit of $21.1 million, mostly reflecting the sale of a Puyallup, Wash., fabrication plant.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   9-9.50   9.50   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   5.50   11.00   8.18        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.99   6.20   7.80        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.98   6.20   7.75        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.72   7.86   8.45        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Occidental Asset Sale
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its stake in the company that makes Arm & Hammer baking soda, seven weeks after the chairman of Occidental, Dr. Armand Hammer, died at the age of 92.   Occidental's purchase of the 5.4 percent stake in the Church & Dwight Company of Princeton, N.J., was often cited by critics who complained that Dr. Hammer operated Occidental more as a kingdom than as a publicly held corporation.    For years, people mistakenly thought Dr. Hammer was connected with Arm & Hammer. In 1986 he worked out a deal that gave Occidental the stake in Church & Dwight and himself a seat on its board.   Ray R. Irani, Dr. Hammer's successor as head of Occidental, said Occidental was selling its shares back to Church & Dwight for $19 million, a gain of about $4 million.   At the time the shares were bought, Occidental established a joint venture with Church & Dwight to make and market potassium carbonate. Mr. Irani called that venture a success and said it would continue.   Since Dr. Hammer's death, the company has announced an extensive revamping, including selling $3 billion in assets to help trim 40 percent of its large debt load of $8.5 billion.    Among other things, Occidental wants to sell its 51 percent stake in the IBP Corporation, a big meat processor. Also for sale are a coal mining venture in China, a petrochemical venture in the Soviet Union, and cattle and Arabian horse operations -- all pet projects of Dr. Hammer.   Occidental has cut its annual dividend to $1 a share, from $2.50.  Dr. Hammer had vowed never to cut the dividend even though it far exceeded operating profit in his later years.    Occidental's stock rose 12.5 cents today, to $17.375 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Lehman to Advise Chartwell on Avon
abstract: Chartwell Associates, an investor group seeking to elect members to the board of Avon Products Inc., has hired the investment banker Lehman Brothers as its financial adviser.    In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Chartwell said it had agreed to pay Lehman Brothers, a unit of the American Express Company, up to $2 million if three or more of its candidates were elected to the board. Chartwell holds 22.17 percent of Avon's common stock.

headline: GERMANS ARE TOLD OF GULF-WAR ROLE
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl warned Germans today that they would not be able to avoid playing a role in the war against Iraq.    In a speech to Parliament, Mr. Kohl pledged that Germany would pay a fair share of war costs and would provide increased military aid to Israel.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.75-9   9.00   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   7.01   7.11   8.31        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.93   5.95   7.70        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.92   5.93   7.70        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.77   7.72   8.54        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   8.06   8.03   8.56        TELEPHONE BONDS   9.24   9.20   9.65        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   7.32   7.30   7.43       *Estimated daily average, source Salomon Brothers **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Arafat Sees No Damage To P.L.O. in War Stand
abstract: During the Persian Gulf crisis, Yasir Arafat appeared to be conspicuously on the side of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. Now that the war is over, Mr. Arafat does not acknowledge that he hurt his cause by appearing to back the losing side, even though his failure to stand by the Kuwaitis has cost the P.L.O. some $100 million in yearly contributions from the gulf.    To those who have said he should quit in disgrace, he vowed today that he would stay on as head of the Palestine Liberation Organization. To those who have urged him to soften his demands toward Israel, he insisted that there could be no peace without Israel's withdrawal from the West Bank and Gaza Strip and establishment of a Palestinian homeland there.

headline: Real Estate; A Big Shopping Mall in a Suburb of St. Louis Gets Bigger
abstract: ONE of the nation's largest shopping mall expansions is under way in Richmond Heights, an older suburb about 10 miles west of downtown St. Louis. The $215 million project will more than double the space in the Saint Louis Galleria, to 1.18 million square feet. The new stores are scheduled to open in August.  To get the land for the expansion, the developer bought 99 homes, 20 businesses and the 3 acres occupied by the Junior League, giving the project a total of 56 acres. The existing mall has 510,000 square feet of shopping space on 23 acres of land. A 265,000-square-foot Dillard's department store is the anchor; other stores occupy an additional 245,000 square feet.

headline: Marines Take Goat Hill But Camels Don't Care
abstract: Blunt-nosed armored personnel carriers, surrounded by squat jeeps equipped with anti-tank missiles and .50-caliber machine guns, accelerated down a rise and headed across the desert valley.   Over an arid tract of two square miles, some 150 vehicles raced forward, sending up clouds of dust, pitching and rolling like unwieldy ships on an open sea and filling the air with the noise of strained engines and treads.

headline: Southern Democrats Are Torn as Vote Nears
abstract: Until Thursday, Senator J. Bennett Johnston said, "I thought sanctions were the way to go." But the Louisiana Democrat emerged from a meeting at the White House supporting President Bush. "The die was cast," he said, and it is important for senators to "present a united front."   "I thought he wouldn't attack without the Congress being strongly behind him," he added. "But I do now."

headline: Bush Prods Gorbachev On Arms Pact Dispute
abstract: In an effort to break a deadlock that has been hampering efforts to schedule another Soviet-American summit meeting, President Bush has written to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev urging him to address Western concerns about a conventional arms treaty signed last year.   Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the letter was delivered today by Jack Matlock, the American Ambassador to Europe.

headline: NBC Decides to Allow L.A. Gear Commercial
abstract: NBC, which said Monday that it would not broadcast a 30-second spot for L.A. Gear's new Catapult sneaker, reversed its decision yesterday and agreed to carry the commercial.    Richard Cutting, an NBC spokesman, said Monday that the commercial's tagline, "Everything else is just hot air," was an unsubstantiated potshot at its competitors. Yesterday, he said the network had reviewed the ad and had decided that "the major thrust of the commercial was not competitive."    CBS is standing by its decision not to run the ad, a network spokesman said. ABC has been running the commerical.

headline: Papandreou Trial Date Is Set
abstract: The Greek Supreme Court announced today that March 11 would be the date for the trial of Andreas Papandreou, the Socialist former Prime Minister, and three of his former senior Cabinet ministers, on charges of involvement in a $200 million bank embezzlement scandal.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: General Assembly AMENDMENT CONFERENCE TO PARTIAL TEST-BAN TREATY -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: 2 in Congress Plan New Bill To Govern Cable TV Costs
abstract: In the latest attempt to re-regulate the cable televison industry, two members of Congress from Connecticut said today that they would introduce legislation to give state and local governments wide latitude to control prices charged by local cable systems.   The measure, proposed by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, a Democrat, and Representative Christopher Shays, a Republican, would allow local officials to govern rates on all forms of cable programming, including premium services like Home Box Office, if the local system did not face "effective competition."

headline: Soviet Vote Becomes Test of Loyalties
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declared today that a large "yes" vote in the referendum on national unity Sunday would safeguard the nation against war and restore normalcy to society, while his archrival Boris N. Yeltsin told Russians not to be frightened by such "propaganda."    The referendum is formally being held on the question, "Do you support the preservation of the union as a renewed federation of sovereign republics in which the rights of a person of any nationality are fully guaranteed?"

headline: Part of Boeing Pact Canceled
abstract: The Air Force said today that it had canceled parts of a $1 billion contract with the Boeing Company for development of a new air defense network for Saudi Arabia.   Jack Rankin, a spokesman for the Air Force's electronic systems division at Hanscom Air Force Base in Massachusetts, said the contract was "partially terminated" for default because Boeing did not meet the contract's delivery schedule. Boeing has also encountered unspecified cost overruns on the program.

headline: Ford Plans to Reduce Salaried Work Force
abstract: Faced with mounting losses, the Ford Motor Company announced plans today to cut its salaried work force through layoffs and early retirements, in an effort to save $3 billion by the end of the year.    Speaking by closed-circuit television to the company's 53,000 salaried employees in the United States, Ford's chairman and chief executive, Harold A. Poling, said, "It's becoming increasingly clear that some salaried layoffs are inevitable in the short term."

headline: The Executive Life; Japan's Funky Export: Wild and Crazy Nights
abstract: Forget power lunches at the Downtown Association on Wall Street or evening bridge games at the Harvard Club. Japanese executives find it's easier to unwind while doing business outside the office by swilling whisky and singing schmaltzy songs at what are known as "karaoke bars." The karaoke club, which loosely translated means "empty orchestra" is a home away from home for many Japanese executives both in and outside of Japan.   On a recent evening in Manhattan, a group of American executives led by an enthusiastic Japanese film executive from Tokyo met after work before heading for the Albatross Club, one of several karaoke bars in New York. Located on Second Avenue next door to a dingy Off-Track Betting parlor, the club is unmarked, save for a small brass nameplate on the door, and sits at the bottom of a flight of dimly lit stairs.

headline: Rig Count Off in Week
abstract: The number of working rotary oil and gas rigs dropped last week by 55, to a total of 996, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The count was higher than a year ago, when there were 931 working rigs. Ike Kerridge, a vice president at Baker Hughes, attributed last week's decline to a high number of drilling completions in West Texas and Bakersfield, Calif., as well as traditional seasonal declines.

headline: New Buyers Give Lift To Housing Market
abstract: For the first time in years, lower interest rates and a backlog of unsold low-priced homes are making it possible for many first-time buyers to enter the housing market. Their buying is adding to the small spurt in real estate activity that was detected first in the sluggish Northeast late in January and that has now spread across the country.    Business Day, page D1.

headline: Assisting Kuwait Work
abstract: The Commerce Department announced today that it had set up an office to assist and advise American companies seeking contracts being awarded in the Persian Gulf.    Department officials estimate Kuwait will spend $60 billion to $100 billion on reconstruction in the next five years. Kuwaiti authorities have already said American companies will be favored in the contracting.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Latin America; War's Ripples Lap at Latin America
abstract: One recent morning, a group of young men hurled paint bombs at the United States Consulate here, protesting American participation in the Persian Gulf war.    The same day, a separate group of young men gathered at the consulate to inquire about enlisting to fight for the United States in the Persian Gulf.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Infiltration; Saudis Are Reported to Execute 6 As Terrorists Infiltrate From Iraq
abstract: Terrorists have begun infiltrating Saudi Arabia with orders from Baghdad to carry out assassinations and sabotage, officials with access to sensitive information say.   In the last week or so, a half dozen terrorists are reported to have crossed into Saudi Arabia and to have been captured. The men were executed soon after their capture, the officials said, and before they were killed, interrogators are said to have found lists of terrorist targets in their possession.

headline: Tool Orders For Factories Rise 43.7%
abstract: The machine tool industry reported a surge in capital spending by American manufacturers in December.    New orders for American-made machine tools climbed 43.7 percent in December from November, to the highest point since September 1989, according to a monthly report by the industry's trade association.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: United Nations; Destruction of Iraqi Chemical Arms Urged in U.N.
abstract: Britain is pressing the Security Council to demand that President Saddam Hussein destroy all his chemical and biological weapon stocks under international inspection and publicly renounce terrorism before a formal cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war is put into place, diplomats said today.    The British argument is that the council is now in a position to impose such further conditions on President Hussein as part of an obligation under previous resolutions to restore "international peace and security in the area."

headline: Senators Fear Allies Will Renege on War Payments
abstract: Senators from both parties complained today that United States allies were slow to help pay for the gulf war and warned high-ranking Administration officials that if combat ended in the next few days, they might be even more reluctant.   "Will they feel that once the hostilities are over, the pressure on them will lessen?" said Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who chairs the Appropriations Committee.

headline: Blasts Rock Sites in Athens Linked to Allies in Gulf War
abstract: Three explosions rocked branches of American and British banks and the home of the French military attache early today, the police said.   There were no reports of injuries and only minor damage. A police spokesman said the first explosion was reported early today at a Citibank branch. Minutes later bombs went off at a branch of Barclays Bank and outside the home of the French attache.

headline: Communist Party Veterans Dropped by Laos Politburo
abstract: Kaysone Phomvihane, the undisputed leader of Laos's Communist Party since 1955, was re-elected today, but a veteran revolutionary of royal descent and four others were dropped from the party's Politburo.   Mr. Kaysone, 70 years old, was reappointed party chairman and head of the Politburo, according to a transcript of an official radio broadcast made available in Bangkok.

headline: First Executive Stake Is Sold for 14¦ a Share
abstract: Rosewood Financial Partners said yesterday that it had sold its entire stake in the First Executive Corporation, a Los Angeles insurance holding company with problems stemming from its sizable "junk bond" portfolio.   Rosewood, an investment affiliate of the Rosewood Corporation of Dallas, reported that its stake, just under 10 percent of First Executive's 85 million common shares outstanding, had been sold for 14 cents a share, below current market quotes of 37.5 cents and a fraction of the stock's 1990 highs of just over $17 a share.

headline: Bechtel Is Offering 3-Day Weekends
abstract: The Bechtel Group engineering concern is promising workers 26 three-day weekends a year to attract engineering talent to its San Francisco offices. The deal means workers will come to work nine days every two weeks instead of 10. All 4,000 Bechtel employees in the San Francisco area are eligible for the new schedule.   Company officials say the plan will go into effect next Monday. Bechtel's San Francisco employees voted overwhelmingly to adopt the new work schedule a few months ago. Their counterparts in Los Angeles and Houston already have similar programs. Under the new schedule, employees will work nine-hour days Monday through Thursday of every week. On the first Friday, about half the employees work eight hours, while the other half are off.

headline: Agencies and Clients Plan Strategies if War Occurs
abstract: MANY advertisers have called for emergency meetings with their agencies to formulate strategies in case there is a protracted war in the Middle East.   With the possibility that advertising could be curtailed during the conflict, executives say, the crisis would at least temporarily play havoc with the industry.   "There is a terrible uncertainty among advertisers about what to do," said DeWitt Helm, the president of the Association of National Advertisers. "It is very difficult to determine just what the most prudent course is."

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Diplomacy; Old Glory Returns to Kuwaiti Capital
abstract: To the thunder of machine-gun fire and the bang of a military drum, Washington's new Ambassador to Kuwait hoisted the American flag above the United States Embassy here today and declared the besieged building open for business.    The arrival of the envoy punctuated a day of frantic, flag-waving celebration among jubilant Kuwaitis, many of whom shouted "Bush! Bush! Bush!" as they formed a boisterous, blaring traffic jam along the sea-front highway outside the walled embassy compound.

headline: Beirut Sets Troops' Goals
abstract: Defense Minister Michel el-Murr said today that Lebanese Army troops deployed in the south would seek to prevent the launching of rockets against Israel and oust gunmen from the region.   Hundreds of fighters of the P.L.O. and of the Amal and the Party of God, two rival Shiite Muslim miltias, withdrew from Iqlim al Toffah as the regular soldiers moved in with tanks and armored personnel carriers.

headline: Chernobyl Cleanup Leads to Charges
abstract: Almost five years after the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, the Soviet prosecutor general conceded today that there had been gross failures in the Government's cleanup plan and said some officials would face criminal charges for failing to protect the public properly from fallout and continuing radiation contamination.    In a sweeping preliminary condemnation of the cleanup, the national Government, prodded by private and local government complaints, charged that some officials involved in the cleanup had failed to evacuate people as quickly and safely as they should have; ignored dangerous radiation readings; used slipshod methods to bury masses of contaminated wastes, and then built resettlement homes in contaminated regions.

headline: U.N. Relief Agency Declares Israelis Beat Two of Its Staff
abstract: The United Nations relief agency for Palestinians said today that Israeli soldiers in the occupied Gaza Strip had beaten two members of its staff in the second such attack in 10 days.   Sandro Tucci, spokesman for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, said a Chilean refugee affairs officer and his Palestinian assistant were sworn at on Sunday by an Israeli soldier in the Nur Shams refugee camp.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Troops; LONG WAIT BEGINS FOR GROUND FORCES
abstract: The long, agonizing wait has begun for hundreds of thousands of American ground troops who know that when the air war against Iraq is over, it will be their turn to fight.    Huddling in foxholes and sand-dusted barracks in the vast northern deserts of Saudi Arabia today, they said their part of war would almost certainly be longer, messier, bloodier.

headline: Europeans May Release Aid Frozen Over Baltics
abstract: Hoping to nudge Moscow toward a negotiated settlement to the crisis in the Baltic republics, European Community foreign ministers signaled today that they might soon approve a $560 million aid package that was frozen after the recent Soviet crackdown in Lithuania and Latvia.   A statement issued after a ministerial meeting in Luxembourg said the community's executive commission had been instructed to resume preparatory work on food credits and on a technical assistance accord. A final decision will be made when the ministers next meet March 4, it said.

headline: SOVIET EX-MINISTER GIVES NEW WARNING
abstract: Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who quit the Gorbachev Government in December with a sharp warning that a dictatorship was looming, re-emerged in public today vowing to defend the "new political thinking" as head of a new independent foreign-policy research institute.    Looking fit and rested, the former Foreign Minister made his first public appearance at the Soviet Foreign Policy Association shortly after it was formally founded by nearly 40 governmental and public agencies.

headline: California Agency Raises $88 Million
abstract: The Los Angeles County Redevelopment Agency yesterday priced $88.2 million in tax-allocation bonds through competitive bidding, which was won by a group of underwriters led by Bank of America.    Yields on the tax-exempt issue range from 6 percent in 1997 to 6.3 percent in 2001, 6.8 percent in 2006 and 6.85 percent in 2010.    Underwriters said the bond issue was insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation and was rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service and AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: Market Place; Stock Funds Staged a Rally in '90
abstract: Mutual fund investors were cautious in early January, but flocked back to stock funds after war broke out, fund managers said yesterday.   The statements came as industry figures showed that 1990 was in some ways the best year for the industry since 1987, with funds that primarily invest overseas enjoying a sharp increase in popularity.

headline: Jolting Yugoslavia, a Region Widens Its Autonomy
abstract: The national unity of Yugoslavia was shaken today when Slovenia, the most affluent and independence-minded republic, approved basic legislation allowing it to take over functions like banking and defense from the central Government in Belgrade.    The Slovenian Parliament also passed a resolution offering a blueprint for dividing Yugoslavia into at least two independent states. The proposal is to be sent to the parliaments of the five other Yugoslav republics along with a warning that Slovenia will unilaterally secede if they do not approve it.

headline: Haitians' Lament: Anemic Opposition
abstract: A month after Haitians voted in the country's first free presidential elections, voters will return to the polls on Sunday to choose legislative representatives and local government officials.    While electoral enthusiasm was high in last month's presidential race, in which the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide was the overwhelming victor, popular interest has flagged, generating concern for Haiti's efforts to establish its first system of multiparty democracy since independence in 1804.

headline: Dow Rises By 42.57, To 2,830.94
abstract: Stocks rallied briskly yesterday for the third day in a row as investors scrambled to pour more money into what many on Wall Street see as the start of a new bull market.    From the blue chips on the New York Stock Exchange to the smaller, lesser-known issues on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market, stocks moved sharply higher as banks, insurance companies and mutual funds entered the market.

headline: An Outflow At S.& L.'s
abstract: Savings and loan customers withdrew $14.7 billion in deposits in August and September as the industry continued its rapid shrinkage, the Government said this week.   Net withdrawals totaled $8.7 billion in September and $6 billion in August. Most of the money, $10.8 billion, was drained from the still-solvent part of the industry, which consisted of 2,388 institutions at the end of September. The rest, $3.9 billion, came from Government-controlled savings and loan associations, of which there were 206 at the end of September.

headline: Holders Approve Saatchi Revamping
abstract: Shareholders of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company approved the advertising giant's recapitalization plan today, and the company's banks agreed to increase the size and extend the maturity of its credit lines.   Under the plan, preferred shares will be converted to common shares, resulting in the former preferred shareholders owning 78.8 percent of the company. In addition, about $:60 million ($105 million) worth of new common shares will be sold. Most of these shares will be offered first to existing shareholders.

headline: Foreshadowing A Short Recession
abstract: The stock market's reputation as an economic seer looks like it is about to get another boost. The American recession, which seemed so fierce only a couple of months ago, now seems to have eased as the new year began.   It now appears likely that the last few months of 1990 were the worst of the downturn, and that the economy could start growing as soon as the second quarter of this year.

headline: Ho Chi Minh City; Poking Around in the Attic of Vietnam's History
abstract: In the archeology of discarded foreign influence here, Soviet artifacts now sit atop the multilayered trash heap of history. But the fascination with America, if it ever disappeared, is re-emerging.   Jean Nguyen Khac Doan is one of this still-sophisticated city's best gauges of fashion, selling and recycling the detritus of foreigners. A northern-born Roman Catholic who speaks excellent French, he moved to the south in 1951. He was a teacher, then served in the South Vietnamese Army as a political officer, learning a working English. Russian, he says, he never took the time to learn.

headline: Fuller Industries Picks Executive From Avon
abstract: Stuart A. Ochiltree's new challenge is to turn around Fuller Industries, a once-dynamic maker and direct seller of brushes and cleaning products that used to be known as the Fuller Brush Company. Mr. Ochiltree, former president and chief executive of the direct sales group of Avon Products Inc., has been named Fuller's president and chief executive.   Mr. Ochiltree, who is 49 years old, was reached yesterday at the Bally's Casino Resort in Las Vegas, Nev., where he was meeting 50 of Fuller's West Coast managers. "We are clearly in need of turning around this company," he said in a telephone interview. "This is the first year of being privately owned, and as a result there has been a lot of change. Our sales were $70 million at retail, slightly up from the year before, but our profits were only marginal."

headline: Chrysler Seeks Sales Curbs on Japan Autos
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation has asked the Bush Administration to put pressure on Japan to limit car and truck sales in the United States for the next 12 to 18 months, warning that a surge in sales by Japanese auto makers could put it out of business.   The President has not directly responded to the request, which came in a letter from Lee A. Iacocca, the Chrysler chairman, to President Bush. But the Treasury Department indicated that the Administration was not inclined to support protectionist measures like those suggested by Mr. Iacocca.   Excerpts of Mr. Iacocca's letter, which was dated March 6, appeared in The Detroit News and Free Press on Sunday, along with excerpts of the Treasury Department's background paper, which addressed issues raised in the letter. The background paper was obtained by The News and Free Press. A Chrysler spokesman declined to comment on the published excerpts, saying Mr. Iacocca's letter was "personal."    In the letter, the Chrysler chairman suggested that if Japanese auto makers could be persuaded to cut exports by 500,000 vehicles this year, they could be limited to their current share of the American market, about 31 percent. Otherwise, he said, Japan's auto makers may cut their prices to reduce growing inventories of unsold vehicles, causing their market share to grow to 40 percent.   "Unless the Japanese act now to immediately cut back their export shipments, they will begin to 'distress merchandise' this huge amount of overshipment and their share will rocket up again," Iacocca said in the letter.    "I can tell you, Mr. President, at a Japanese share of 40 percent in a depressed industry, Chrysler is gone and Ford could be mortally wounded from a competitive standpoint," Mr. Iacocca wrote. "Even G.M. is at risk unless and until we decide as a nation that a domestic auto industry is a strategic industry and should not be allowed to fall victim to Japan's industrial strategy of targeting key industries." Mr. Iacocca said his proposed limits on Japanese sales should remain in effect until American auto makers "regain their footing."    The outlook for Chrysler has looked increasingly bleak in recent months as the company's sales and profits have dwindled. The entire industry has been mired in a downturn for nearly two years, and as the smallest domestic auto maker, and one that was on the brink of financial collapse just a decade ago, Chrysler appears less able than the Ford Motor Company or the General Motors Corporation to weather the current climate, while paying the huge development costs required in producing a full line of models. Chrysler Stands Alone     None of the Big Three auto makers has prospered in direct competition with the Japanese, but only Mr. Iacocca favors United States intervention against the Japanese industry. Japan's voluntary limit on car exports has declined sharply since the early 1980's, to about 1.6 million from more than 2.6 million. But in recent years, as the Japanese have built factories in the United States, they have been selling more and more American-made vehicles and importing fewer vehicles from Japan.   The Treasury Department managed the Government-guaranteed loans that saved Chrysler from bankruptcy in 1980. Since the mid-80's, the Government has declined to request Japanese export restraints, although Japan has agreed to limit vehicle exports nonetheless.   Indeed, the Treasury Department's background paper noted that the Japanese auto industry has invested $6.4 billion in American plants and employs about 25,000 American workers. Moreover, the Big Three have significant investments in the Japanese auto companies, and they sell Japanese-made vehicles under their own nameplates.

headline: Toyota Profit Falls 1%
abstract: The Toyota Motor Corporation reported a 1 percent decline in net earnings on Friday despite increased sales for the six months that ended on Dec. 31. Japan's largest auto maker posted a profit of $1.16 billion, while its operating profit fell 15 percent, to $1.49 billion. Sales rose 16.6 percent, to $32.33 billion. The company cited higher labor costs and increased spending on research and development for the downturn in earnings.

headline: Price Data Set On U.S. Issues
abstract: The Public Securities Association, a trade group, said yesterday that an industrywide joint venture to disseminate price information on Government securities had named its system Govpx Inc.    Vendor testing on the system will begin Feb. 15, the association said, and the service will be available sometime in March on a 24-hour, global, real-time basis.    The information will reflect more than 75 percent of the interdealer brokers market for United States Treasury securities and will be available exclusively through Govpx Inc. Average daily trading volume in Treasury securities is $112 billion, the association said.    All 40 primary dealers and all 6 interdealer brokers are participating in the joint venture, which was formed last year to meet the goal of expanding access to Government securities price information through private sector initiatives.    For the most part, public access to United States Treasury prices has been limited to price information provided by Cantor Fitzgerald & Company Inc. through Telerate Systems Inc., a subsidiary of Dow Jones & Company.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; Allies Study New Steps to Avoid Civilians in Bombing
abstract: Shaken by the deaths of Iraqi civilians in the bombing of what the United States said it had identified as a purely military installation in Baghdad, senior American officers here said today that they had ordered intensive studies of methods to avoid the repetition of such an incident.    As they weighed the lessons of Wednesday's bombing, American officials announced a sharp increase in the rate of destruction of Iraq's main ground weapons in Kuwait, including tanks, artillery and other armored vehicles. They put the number of tanks demolished at 1,300 -- almost a third of the 4,280 tanks Baghdad is believed to have had in position when the war began, and up from a total of 750 claimed as killed five days ago.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Miscellany
abstract: * Rivera & Robinson Communications Inc., New York, has changed its named to Rivera & Rivera Communications Inc., to reflect full ownership of the company by Arnold E. Rivera, president and chief executive. Mr. Rivera had previously been one of three partners.

headline: Net at Central Newspapers
abstract: Central Newspapers Inc., which owns newspapers in Indiana and Arizona, said its earnings dropped in the fourth quarter and all of 1990 because of weak advertising and costs from employee cutbacks.   The newspaper chain, which was founded by Vice President Dan Quayle's grandfather, said on Monday that earnings for the last three months of 1990 dropped 33 percent to $8 million, or 31 cents a share, from $12.1 million, or 46 cents a share, for the comparable 1989 period. Revenues totaled $112.8 million, down 5.2 percent from $119.1 million.

headline: LTV Reports Net Loss
abstract: The LTV Corporation said today that it lost $19.5 million in the fourth quarter because of a decline in steel earnings and a charge for a research division the company is trying to sell. The company, which has been reorganizing under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code since July 1986, also reported a 1990 profit of $70.9 million, down 73.2 percent, from $264.9 million in 1989. LTV's loss in the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31 compared with a profit of $72.3 million, or 50 cents a share, in the same quarter of 1989. Revenues rose to $1.61 billion, against $1.58 billion a year earlier.

headline: Net Up at Chase and Morgan; First Chicago Posts Decline
abstract: Chase Manhattan and J. P. Morgan yesterday announced higher profits for the fourth quarter of last year, as Chase benefited from the sale of office buildings and Morgan reaped rewards from its strong financial condition.    Among other banking companies, problems with bad real estate loans resulted in a decline in the quarter at First Chicago and an estimated loss of at least $145 million at PNC Financial, the holding company for Pittsburgh National Bank.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Airlines Inc., Dallas, a unit of AMR Corp., has exercised four options on MD-11 aircraft, increasing its firm order for MD-11's from McDonnell-Douglas Corp. to 19. * FMR Corp., Boston, a holding company, is part of a group that has cut its stake in House of Fabrics Inc., Sherman Oaks, Calif., a fabric retailer, to 10.35 percent from 11.57 percent of the common shares outstanding. * Firstbank of Illinois Co., Springfield, Ill., will acquire Central Banc System Inc. and its two subsidiaries, Central Bank of Fairview Heights and Farmers and Merchants Bank of Carlinville, Ill., for $27.5 million, subject to certain adjustments. *Nokia A.B., Helsinki, Finland, has agreed to buy the privately owned British mobile telephone maker Technophone Ltd. for $:34 million in cash. * Safeco Corp., Seattle, an insurance, real estate and investment company, said it would close its Canadian property and casualty insurance operations. * Universal Health Services Inc., King of Prussia, Pa., an operator of hospitals, has sold its three hospitals in the United Kingdom to Compass Group P.L.C. for about $51.1 million plus future considerations.

headline: Imcera Cutting Stake in IMC
abstract: The Imcera Group said today that it was reducing its stake in the IMC Fertilizer Group by selling five million IMC shares back to the company for $41.25 a share, or almost $206.3 million.   IMC also paid almost $6.3 million for an option to buy back the remaining Imcera holdings of five million shares, Imcera said. Imcera's stake of 10 million shares represents 38 percent of IMC's common stock. The exercise price is $35 a share on or before Oct. 8.

headline: In This Corner, Another Italian Government
abstract: Italian politics is often described as Byzantine and difficult to fathom, but in fact there are a few basic rules that anyone can understand:   If political language has entered high-decibel range, it means that a Government crisis is under way. If not, it means that a Government crisis will be under way before long.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: The assets of the nation's 534 money market mutual funds increased by $3.7 billion, to $464.4 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 163 institutional funds fell by $806.3 million, to $129.21 billion. The assets of the 269 general-purpose funds were up by $1.5 billion, to $158.94 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds increased by $3.01 billion, to $176.25 billion, the institute said.

headline: Oil Prices Edge Upward As War Optimism Wanes
abstract: After collapsing last week, the price of oil rebounded slightly yesterday, with less optimism about the course of the war and a sense that the market had overshot its proper level.    Product prices also rose, but industry officials and other experts around the country said prices were falling at the gasoline pump in response to last week's oil price plunge. Pump prices appear to be declining more slowly than wholesale gasoline prices, with many companies being vague about how much margins are increasing at the retail level.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; NBC Faces Tough Decision On Its Costly, Aging Shows
abstract: NBC, the strongest, most profitable television network of the 1980's, finds itself in the middle of a high-stakes game of programming poker.   Even winning the game will cost NBC a potful of money; losing it may mean a precipitous slide to last place in television's prime-time race.

headline: SLOVENIA'S SCHISM IS A CAUTIOUS ONE
abstract: Slovenia's slow separation from the crumbling six-republic Yugoslav federation amounts in many ways to a bookkeepers' revolution.   Instead of the mass demonstrations, marches and passionate speeches that have accompanied the transformation from Communist rule and Soviet domination elsewhere in Eastern Europe, the process of disengagement here has been characterized by low-key argument reinforced with highly detailed economic rationales and analysis to prove that an amicable separation from the Yugoslav federal union would be in everyone's best interests.

headline: Bank of Boston's Chief of Corporate Lending
abstract: While consultants and academicians warn that bank lending to large corporations does not generate enough profits relative to the risks of loss, bankers see enough prospects to stay in the business and to hire talent from competitors.    The Bank of Boston, for example, announced earlier this week that it had recruited Newton Merrill, a senior executive vice president who has had 30 years' experience at the Bank of New York. Mr. Merrill will head the groups handling lending to large corporations, leasing and investment banking activities, including the financing of corporate mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Patents; An Industrial Pump To Move Solid Materials
abstract: A British scientist obtained an American patent this week on an industrial pump that he believes will simplify the job of moving anything from coal powder in an electric utility to beans and peas in a food processing plant.    The object of the pump is to move solid materials as simply as pipelines now transport liquids and gas. It was invented by Donald Firth of Dartmouth, England, who spent nearly 30 years as a scientist at the National Engineering Research Laboratory of Britain.

headline: All About/Making Recycling Pay; In Solid Waste, It's the Breakdown That Counts
abstract: The first thing everyone needs to know about recycling, said Charles F. Oyler, is the difference between trash and recyclable materials. Mr. Oyler is the recyling manager at the big materials recovery center in suburban Philadelphia. The center is operated by Browning-Ferris Inc.   A material recovery facility is a key element in the recycling chain. Materials that have been discarded are brought in to be separated, decontaminated and compressed into bales for shipment to mills that can make them into new products.

headline: Bank Plan's Gains Are All Long Term
abstract: The broad changes in the banking system proposed today by the Bush Administration would not solve the nation's current economic woes, but they could have important long-term benefits for the economy.    It will take Congress at least a year to deal with such comprehensive legislation and even longer for new laws to go into effect. If the recession is not over and the scarcity of credit is not more or less resolved by then, the economy will be so sick that it will need much stronger medicine than changes in the banking laws.

headline: Report on NATO Calls on U.S. To Cut Its Forces by Two-Thirds
abstract: A panel of 26 experts on Atlantic security, including important members of Congressional committees on the military and foreign affairs, urged the United States today to cut its forces in NATO by two-thirds in an effort to shift the burden of defending Europe to the Europeans.   In a report on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the experts said the demise of Communism in Eastern Europe effectively ended the need for a big American commitment of troops and equipment to protect the continent from the Soviet Union.

headline: Harcourt Accepts Bid From General Cinema
abstract: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, the publishing and insurance company that has been struggling under a heavy debt load, yesterday accepted a $1.4 billion takeover bid from General Cinema, the movie theater company that controls the Neiman Marcus retail chain.    The deal would give holders of Harcourt's stock, both common and preferred, $1.30 a share, 5 cents above yesterday's common stock closing price, and will also include tender offers to the company's debt holders. If approved by the holders of Harcourt's stock and debt, the deal is expected to be completed this spring.

headline: WINNIE MANDELA ACCUSED BY YOUTH
abstract: The stalled trial of Winnie Mandela on kidnapping and assault charges lurched ahead today when a prosecution witness came forward to testify that the wife of the African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela had repeatedly slapped, punched and whipped him and three companions who were abducted to her Soweto home in late 1988.   The trial had been postponed for three weeks when Kenneth Kgase, who is 31 years old, and his companion, Barend Thabiso Mono, 21, refused to testify against Mrs. Mandela, citing fear for their lives, after a third witness, Gabriel Pelo Mekgwe, 22, disappeared on the eve of his appearance in court.

headline: Dow Gains 27.72 Points, to 2,909.90
abstract: Prodded by signs that the economy is mending, stock prices recovered from an early slump and moved ahead briskly yesterday.    The Dow Jones industrial average bounced back from a 27-point slide to close at 2,909.90, up 27.72, or nearly 1 percent. Showing that the advance was widespread, the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose at almost the same rate, gaining 3.40 points, to 370.47, a record high. And the Nasdaq 100 index of the top 100 non-financial over-the-counter stocks also reached a record high of 504.78, up 4.55.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; U.S.-IRAQI CLASHES GROW FIERCE IN POSSIBLE PRELUDE TO ATTACK; SOVIETS AWAIT BAGHDAD'S REPLY
abstract: In a series of sharp encounters with Iraqi ground forces that may have presaged an early land assault, American troops destroyed large numbers of enemy tanks and howitzers today and took more than 450 prisoners of war, the American command reported.    Not since the battle of Khafji three weeks ago have United States ground forces been so directly and hotly engaged with the Iraqis. The Americans suffered losses of their own, but they were comparatively slight, with one soldier killed, seven wounded and armored vehicles badly shot up.

headline: Ames 2d Half Loss
abstract: Ames Department Stores Inc. said it would have an operating loss of $44.7 million for the second half of 1990, about $15 million less than earlier projections. In filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, Ames also predicted it would have operating income of $55.8 million for the current fiscal year, compared with an operating loss of $320.2 million in the just-completed year.

headline: Czechoslovakia Auctions Stores to Private Buyers
abstract: The auction gavel came down today in Prague city hall, and Ladislav Krombholc became one of Czechoslovakia's first private owners of a fruit and vegetable store.    The 34-year-old writer and translator said he was already employing eight sales people to sell produce at outdoor market stalls. Now, by being the last bidder to stay in the contest as the selling price hit $17,000, he became owner of his own store.

headline: Vehicle Sales Fell 5.1% in 1990
abstract: United States vehicle sales closed the year on a downbeat amid widespread expectations that the automotive industry's slump will probably continue well into 1991. Total sales in 1990 were the lowest since 1983.   Retail sales of American-made cars and trucks fell 1.4 percent in the Dec. 21-30 period, capping a year in which sales were off 5.1 percent from 1989. The overall drop in the final 10 days was caused by a 15.5 percent decline in light-truck sales; car sales for the period were up 8.1 percent, for a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 8.3 million, compared with 7.5 million last year.  Monthly Sales Also Down     Car and truck sales were off 2.1 percent for all of December, to 962,767, from 983,330 last year. Car sales were up 1.8 percent, to 657,164, but light-truck sales dropped 9.5 percent, to 305,603. The monthly figures include all retail sales, of both American-made and imported vehicles.

headline: Protests in Lithuania Continue, Turning Peaceful
abstract: Soviet Interior Ministry troops and Army personnel carriers appeared briefly today in the streets of the capital of Lithuania as large pro-independence demonstrations continued for the second day, but withdrew after crowds dispersed peacefully, witnesses said.   Crack Soviet Army paratroopers apparently made no move today to force draftees in Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to report for duty, as thousands have refused to do over the last year. But leaders of the Baltic republics warned them to take precautions before the Defense Ministry carried out its threat to use elite forces to crack down on them this weekend.

headline: CHENEY FORESEES NEW SOVIET UNREST
abstract: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told Congress today that he foresaw "continued economic decline" and "increased unrest" in the Soviet Union. As a result, he said in his exceedingly bleak assessment, the Administration may reconsider its request for reductions in military spending over the next six years.   "The possibility for major unrest may be such that we would not feel safe recommending to the Congress of the United States the kind of long-term six-year reductions" in military spending requested by President Bush in his latest budget, Mr. Cheney said. The budget was sent to Congress three days ago.

headline: THAI ARMY PLEDGES GOVERNMENT SOON
abstract: The Thai military, which seized power on Saturday without firing a shot, said today that it would announce a provisional government in the next five to seven days.   In an effort to calm foreign critics and overseas investors, the caretaker administration is likely to be headed by a respected, senior civilian, military officials said, although military commanders would continue to serve in a role described as advisers.

headline: Several Issues in This Week's U.S. Sale
abstract: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week includes the regular weekly auction today of three- and six-month bills and the auction on Wednesday of seven-year notes. The Government has also scheduled an auction of a one-year bill on Thursday.   Another Government arm expected to sell debt this week is the Resolution Funding Corporation, which will auction 30-year and 39 1/4-year bonds tomorrow. The corporation, which raises money through the sale of debt to finance the bailout of troubled savings and loans, said the 39 1/4-year bond issue is a reopening of an 8 7/8 percent bond due in February 2030 that had been previously sold.

headline: Beggars and Ethnic Strife's Refugees Make Soviets Turn to Private Charity
abstract: In the basement of what was once an elegant townhouse in Moscow, behind a door marked Andrei Sakharov Order of Charity and Social Welfare, women wrestle with boxes of donated clothes, printed forms, insistent visitors, incessant calls.   A few miles to the north, in an abandoned children's summer camp in the industrial city of Mytishchi, other women sit in a cluster on broken chairs in a lightless lounge, talking of terror and despair. A year ago these women and tens of thousands of other refugees fled ethnic violence in Azerbaijan, never doubting that somebody in the capital would know what to do next. So far, nobody does.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Moscow; Senior Soviet Officer Says U.S. Rushed Into War
abstract: A military adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union said today that the United States had acted prematurely in attacking Iraq.   Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, who now serves as an adviser to the Soviet President on defense issues, said in an article in the Communist Party newspaper, Pravda, that it was "deeply regrettable that all possibilities for a peaceful solution of the conflict had not been exhausted," and that as a result "war broke out in this dangerous region."

headline: Bolar Plans Guilty Plea On Generics
abstract: The Bolar Pharmaceutical Company said yesterday that it would plead guilty to charges of illegally distributing adulterated generic drugs and obstructing Government inquiries. The company also said it would pay $10 million in fines in connection with the 20 criminal charges brought Tuesday by the Justice Department.   Until Bolar withdrew most of its products last year, after Government allegations that the company had submitted bogus drug samples to the Food and Drug Administration, the company was the nation's largest publicly owned generic drug maker.    Bolar, based in Copiague, L.I., said it would also pay $250,000 toward the costs of the inquiry. Bolar admitted that its employees had falsified labels of generic drugs and destroyed computerized records subpoenaed by Congressional investigators and a Federal grand jury in Baltimore.

headline: What Business Can Teach the Schools
abstract: With their ability to compete undermined by poorly trained graduates from failing public schools, many companies have been forced to pick up the pieces. In fact, business has become America's second-largest educator. It now spends a record $40 billion a year on education, about three-quarters of this to teach workers basic skills they should have learned in school.   Exactly what needs to be done to fix our schools was spelled out in great detail by two Brookings Institution scholars, John E. Chubb and Terry Moe, in a study published last summer. After analyzing data involving 500 schools, and including 20,000 principals, teachers and students, the researchers concluded that government-sponsored reform efforts have failed because government itself is the problem. The only approach with a reasonable chance of improving education is based on a business model, involving deregulation of both the supply and demand of education through competitive markets and parental choice.

headline: NCR Seeks F.C.C. Action
abstract: The NCR Corporation filed a petition yesterday asking the Federal Communications Commission to investigate the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's takeover bid for NCR, saying the takeover would harm the public interest.
