NCR said the takeover would "jeopordize A.T.& T.'s ability to sustain adequate levels of investment in the infrastructure supporting its regulated telecommunications services." It was not clear whether the F.C.C. would take up the petition.

headline: Insurgents in India's Northeast Call for Peace Talks
abstract: A powerful insurgent group in the northeastern state of Assam says it is ready for negotiations and a peaceful settlement of its demands. But it continues to inspire fear here despite a three-month crackdown by Indian Army and paramilitary troops.   Top security officials say the army is likely to be slowly phased out of the operations and their work handed to paramilitary troops. That is apparently aimed at preparing the ground for talks and possible statewide elections in April.There are three other major insurgencies in India -- in the Punjab, Kashmir and Nagaland, which neighbors Assam -- and the central Government's moves here will be followed closely nationwide.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; People
abstract: * Arn R. Ashwood has been named vice president-creative director and Sarah C. Belle has been named vice president-management supervisor at Lockhart & Pettus Advertising and Public Relations Inc., New York. * Christopher Culver has been named executive vice president-New York sales manager for Transportation Displays Inc., an outdoor advertising concern.

headline: War Hero Status Possible for the Computer Chip
abstract: If the Pentagon's claims of success in the Persian Gulf war bear up, a hero of the conflict will be the ubiquitous computer chip, no larger than a fingernail and usually made of silicon, which processes reams of information in an instant for planes, bombs, sensors and cruise missiles.   "It's the triumph of silicon over steel," said John E. Pike, a senior analyst at the Federation of American Scientists, a private group in Washington.

headline: Economic Scene; Even Stalin Did It Better
abstract: TO long-suffering Soviet citizens, last week's confiscation of 50- and 100-ruble notes may seem further proof that perestroika is just another word for nothing left to lose. But to many Western economists it is an example of good intentions gone awry, of Mikhail Gorbachev's disheartening brand of administrative incompetence tinged with nostalgia for a puritanical socialist past that never was.   Cutting the currency in circulation by perhaps 20 to 30 percent "was not totally stupid," concedes Ed Hewett, a veteran perestroika watcher at the Brookings Institution. The mountain of rubles in private hands does threaten to bury any attempt to decontrol store prices in an avalanche of inflation. But the sacrifice of all those rubles will be in vain unless it is followed by a determined effort to halt further accumulation of cash -- an unlikely prospect, since much of the money is being handed out to prevent open rebellion against Moscow's rule.

headline: 4 Albanians Die as Police Seize Refugee Ship
abstract: Four Albanians were killed and 10 were wounded when the police moved in with guns to seize a ship commandeered by citizens seeking to flee from the port of Durres, residents in Tirana, the Albanian capital, said today.    The incident took place late Friday night. The harbor of Durres has since been cleared of would-be escapees and sealed off by an Army regiment.

headline: Technology; In Search of Short-Order Chips
abstract: Amateur photographers once sent their film for developing to huge plants that took days or weeks to return the finished photos. Then film processing machines were built that were small and inexpensive enough to be used by small shops that could deliver the film in an hour.   "It has revolutionized photography," said Krishna C. Saraswat, a professor of electrical engineering at Stanford University's Center for Integrated Systems.

headline: 3 Networks Retrench After War
abstract: Despite their satisfaction with the coverage of the Persian Gulf war, the three broadcast networks face serious economic consequences from the war's costs, and one or more news divisions may be compelled to cut budgets and staff.    The Cable News Network, however, says it plans to increase its budget and its international news coverage.

headline: Reports Say Spain's Army Plotted to Kill King
abstract: Right-wing army officers planned to assassinate King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, the Defense Minister and other Government and military leaders at an armed forces parade on June 1, 1985, El Pais has reported.   The influential Madrid daily newspaper serialized an investigation into several unsuccessful army coup plots it says sprang from an abortive coup in February 1981 that was averted by King Juan Carlos.

headline: Jaguar Is Planning To Cut Production
abstract: The Ford Motor Company's Jaguar subsidiary said it planned to stop production for two of every three weeks until the end of March to cope with declining sales. The decision means all 8,000 hourly production workers will be laid off during the halts at the luxury auto maker's three plants in Coventry and Birmingham, a company official said. The plants make a total of about 800 cars a week.   Jaguar's worldwide sales were off 9.8 percent, at 42,754 cars, in 1990, the company said. Jaguar is scheduled to begin negotiations with trade unions on Thursday in a bid to cut about 1,000 jobs.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: General Assembly SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON UNITED NATIONS CHARTER -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council STATISTICAL COMMISSION -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
abstract: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in groups and given access to military sources.    The pool reporters obtain information while under military escort, and their accounts are subject to scrutiny by military censors before being distributed. Some of the information appearing today on American military operations was obtained under such circumstances.

headline: All About/Silver; With the Price Right, the White Metal Heads for a Rebound
abstract: When the price of silver reached a momentary peak of $48.70 an ounce during the Hunt brothers' buying spree a decade ago, and averaged out in 1980 at a stratospheric $20-plus, manufacturers abandoned the precious metal in droves.   But since then, silver has fallen to about $4.20 an ounce, its lowest point since the late 1970's, and the metal is once more attractive, particularly in photography and electronics. Industry analysts estimate that global silver use by manufacturers climbed 2.3 percent last year to 480 million ounces, the most since 1976. They also estimate that 123 million ounces were used in the United States, the most in a decade.

headline: THE YEAR IN FINANCE: 1990/From Wall St. to Warsaw, Economic Storms Are Growing; Richard G. Darman/Getting the Blame For the Budget Pain
abstract: When Richard G. Darman became budget director, his goal was to engineer what he called "the Grand Compromise," a sweeping deal in which Republicans and Democrats agreed to politically painful measures to reduce the budget deficit.   This year, Mr. Darman pulled off the deal, but he ended up getting little credit and taking most of the blame.

headline: Haitian Victor's Backer Is Harsh Toward U.S.
abstract: Before winning the presidency last month in his country's first democratic election, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide often denounced Haiti's elite for "sitting at tables, eating steaks and pate and veal flown in from across the water" in a land where most people struggle to get by.    But from Father Aristide's earliest days in politics, one of the most fervent backers of the spartan Roman Catholic priest has been Antoine Izmery, a 47-year-old multimillionaire of Palestinian ancestry. As the country's largest food importer, Mr. Izmery leads a life of considerable comfort, serving lucratively as the grocer for those who can afford to pay.

headline: U.S. Logistical Effort Nears Peak in the Gulf
abstract: Every few minutes during long stretches of the day, another American cargo plane laden with weapons or equipment rumbles to a halt on the runway of a giant military base here in the Saudi desert.   Commercial jets, each filled with hundreds of American soldiers fresh from Europe or the United States, pull up alongside the cargo planes already parked on the sun-warmed tarmac.

headline: G.E. Sets Thorn Deal; Lamp Chief Is Chosen
abstract: The General Electric Company completed its deal yesterday to buy Thorn EMI P.L.C.'s $360 million European light bulb business and named David E. Momot to be president and chief executive of the newly created company, G.E.-Thorn Lamps Ltd.   Mr. Momot comes from a stint at the Genlyte Group, a maker of lighting fixtures, where he was president and chief executive, and which he joined in 1989. He is no stranger to G.E., having worked there for 30 years until 1989.

headline: Albanians Urge Official's Ouster
abstract: In a rare public protest, more than 1,000 Albanians demonstrated in the capital today, demanding the resignation of the Foreign Minister.   Students and workers joined pensioners and housewives on a grassy bank opposite Tirana's Foreign Ministry, chanting: "Resign, resign! We want an answer now!"

headline: Troubled Unisys Names Chief Operating Officer
abstract: The Unisys Corporation appointed Reto Braun president and chief operating officer yesterday. He had been elected to the board of the troubled computer company last month, causing analysts to speculate that the board was positioning Mr. Braun for a position of increased authority.   Mr. Braun's promotion follows the departure of two senior-level executives last month, Curtis A. Hessler, a vice chairman, and Cyril Yansouni, an executive vice president. Mr. Hessler's departure had been expected since he lost a race for the top Unisys job to James A. Unruh, the company's chairman and chief executive.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Gavin Anderson & Co., New York, a financial and corporate communications unit of Omnicom Group Inc., has acquired Valin Pollen P.L.C., a British financial investor relations firm. The company, to be known as Gavin Anderson, will be headed by Howard Lee.

headline: Wells Fargo Executive Joins Security Pacific
abstract: Ronald S. Parker, a top executive in charge of corporate lending at Wells Fargo & Company in San Francisco, left the company yesterday to join the rival Security Pacific Corporation in Los Angeles, officials at Security Pacific confirmed.    Bankers in California said Mr. Parker, 46, was unhappy with a decision by Wells Fargo's management to reduce its lending to large corporations and to close offices in New York, Chicago and Atlanta. Late last year, when Wells Fargo announced plans to close the offices, a company spokeswoman said the business they produced was not enough to justify the expense.

headline: MANDELA'S GROUP PLAGUED BY TRIAL
abstract: The trial of Winnie Mandela on charges of kidnapping and assault is turning from an embarrassment into a public-relations debacle for the African National Congress, even though the odds that Mrs. Mandela will not be convicted have never looked better.    On Thursday the trial of Mrs. Mandela, the wife of Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress leader, was postponed by Judge M. S. Stegmann until March 6, after one of the state's principal witness disappeared and the two others refused to testify against Mrs. Mandela, citing fear for their lives.

headline: Some in Congress Harden on Trade
abstract: Many members of Congress are preparing for another confrontation with the Bush Administration over trade legislation.   Resentments about the slow pace at which Japan and South Korea are opening their markets to American companies is feeding a drive for laws that would require Washington to retaliate against countries that keep markets shut.

headline: Cabinet in Kuwait Resigns, Emirate's Envoy to U.N. Says
abstract: Kuwait's Cabinet resigned today in a move intended to bring in new officials as the nation rebuilds from nearly seven months of Iraqi occupation, the emirate's United Nations ambassador said.   The Kuwaiti leadership has been under pressure from foreign and domestic critics who believe it has lacked a commitment to democratic reform and has mishandled the first weeks of postwar rebuilding.   Ambassador Mohammad Abulhasan said the Prime Minister, Crown Prince Saad Abdullah al-Sabah, submitted the resignations, which were immediately accepted by the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah.   Mr. Abulhasan said the new Cabinet should be named in about a week. "This is the first step in putting the house in order," he said.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.75-9   8.75-9   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.98   6.08   8.25        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.85   5.91   7.91        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.84   5.90   7.87        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.01   8.00   8.57        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   8.30   8.31   8.46        TELEPHONE BONDS   9.45   9.45   9.71        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   7.35   7.35   7.50       *Estimated daily average, source Salomon Brothers **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Hunt for Marcos's Billions Yields More Dead Ends Than Hard Cash
abstract: After a five-year hunt through the courts and banking systems of three continents, the Philippine Government has uncovered yachts and paintings and silver services and a few hundred million dollars, but not much more of the $5 billion or more Ferdinand E. Marcos is said to have stolen from his country.   As the six-year term of President Corazon C. Aquino nears its end next year, a touch of desperation has entered the search and her Government has begun talking of cutting its losses and making deals with Mr. Marcos's widow, Imelda.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: P.O.W.'s; Red Cross Is Frustrated on Prisoners in Iraq
abstract: The Red Cross complained today that Iraq had without justification prevented its representatives from meeting allied prisoners of war and from determining how desperate conditions had become in battered Iraqi cities.   Cornelio Sommaruga, president of the International Committee of the Red Cross, said his group had nine delegates in Baghdad but none in Kuwait.

headline: Riot Squads Separate Rivals At Albanian Opposition Rally
abstract: Riot police intervened today to separate supporters of the ruling Communists and the main opposition Democratic Party during an opposition rally by 10,000 people.   An unconfirmed report said two children were injured.   Albania's first opposition party is challenging the Communists in multiparty elections scheduled for March 31. It will be the first time the Communists face a challenge at the polls since they took power in 1944.   Squads of police toting shields and riot batons cut through crowds in the main square of Burrel, separating chanting Democratic Party supporters from Communists waving pictures of Albania's late strongman Enver Hoxha.   Hoxha, the founder of Communist Albania, kept the country under strict rule until his death in 1985.

headline: One Way for Business to Go Green
abstract: Last April, Du Pont's oil subsidiary, Conoco, announced it would build new double-hulled oil tankers designed to reduce oil spills. A few days later, the H. J. Heinz Company said it would no longer fish for tuna on dolphin sightings or use drift nets. And in November, McDonald's announced it would do away with its plastic foam "clamshell" hamburger box. These headline-making actions, and others like them, signal important changes in corporate environmental thinking. Yet, double-hulled tankers, dolphin-safe tuna and abandoned polystyrene packaging -- while praiseworthy -- do not make corporations environmentally responsible.   One way for multinationals like Du Pont, Heinz and McDonald's to become more environmentally responsible is for them to sign the Valdez Principles, named after the Exxon Valdez, the oil tanker that ran aground in Alaska causing a massive oil spill. This is a code of conduct aimed at improving the entire company's environmental performance. The principles not only require companies to respect the environment but also to market safe products and services and accept responsibility for any environmental damage they may cause. These principles require companies to disclose operations that might cause harm to the environment and to appoint at least one director to represent environmental interests. They also require an annual environmental audit.

headline: Market Place; Mortgage Banker A Popular Stock
abstract: AS a mortgage banker with less than sterling credit, Countrywide Credit Industries gave the appearance a year ago of being a likely victim of a credit crunch. Now Wall Street thinks it will be a beneficiary, and a new issue of common stock seems likely to be snatched up this week.    The most important business of Countrywide Credit, the nation's largest independent mortgage banker, is making mortgage loans on single-family homes, and then selling them to investors.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Up in Light Trading
abstract: Stocks climbed slowly today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in a day of light trading. Traders said they had little incentive to move because today was the last day of trading for March delivery and for the current fiscal year.   The Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 32.60 points, or less than 1 percent, to 26,645.79, on a volume of less than 300 million shares. At midday, the Nikkei was stronger, up by 154.16 points, to 26,767.35, on a volume of 260 million shares. It rose 163.84 points on Friday.   "The market is having a hard time moving," a trader with Lehman Brothers Japan Ltd. said after the early session ended. "It's very quiet."    The Nikkei rose in the morning session on arbitrage-related buying programs, while the broader market lagged behind, the brokers said.

headline: British Pilots' Risky Mission: Low-Level Raids on Airfields
abstract: They fly the most dangerous mission of the air war against Iraq, these daring young British pilots, most in their 20's, who must skim over Iraqi territory just a few dozen feet above the desert sands and try to bomb well-defended airfields.    So far, 10 of the Tornado bomber airmen have died or are missing; 6 of the planes have been shot down over enemy territory or crashed. That compares with 15 planes lost by the much larger American bomber fleet.

headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Jordan; Seeing War Near, King Hussein Vows to Protect Jordan's Land and Sky
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan, evidently abandoning all hope for Western or Arab diplomacy in the Persian Gulf crisis, sought tonight to ready his people for embroilment in war and said the Middle East stood on the verge of imminent catastrophe.    "We are now hearing the drums of war, which are threatening all of us with the most dangerous consequences," he said in a television address to his nation of three million people.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * Avco Financial Services Inc., a unit of Textron Inc., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $900 million in debt securities and warrants to buy debt securities. * Employee Benefit Plans Inc., Minneapolis, filed for $50 million in convertible subordinated debentures due in 2006 through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

headline: Greek Troops To Aid Police
abstract: Responding to a series of terrorist attacks in Greece related to the Persian Gulf war, the Government said today that it would use troops to help police counter the threat of more violence against Western offices and installations.   Commenting on the seven bomb attacks of the past four days, which have damaged Western targets but caused no casualties, the Public Order Minister, Yannis Vassiliades, said, "It seems that Greek terrorists have made an alliance with Saddam Hussein."    He added, "We must include men of the armed forces because the targets that must be protected number in the thousands."    The Government said the attacks are the work of the November 17 terrorist group. The organization, since its appearance in 1975, has been responsible for the assassination of 15 Greeks and Americans and a large number of bomb attacks; it has said it is now acting "in solidarity with the people of Iraq."

headline: Eager to Help Russians, Germans Cut Other Aid
abstract: The outpouring of German emergency aid for the Soviet Union has led some Germans to reduce their contributions to groups helping the third world, relief and charity workers say.   German politicians, along with celebrities and other prominent figures, have joined in the two-month-old drive to raise money for the Soviet Union. Major newspapers, magazines and television networks are also involved.

headline: Chief of La Salle Bank To Step Down in April
abstract: The La Salle National Corporation, a bank holding company in Chicago, has announced a management restructuring, with John Rau due to step down in April as president and chief executive of its flagship, the LaSalle National Bank.   Mr. Rau, who is 42, came to La Salle when it acquired Exchange National Bank of Chicago in 1989. Mr. Rau, who had run Exchange since 1983, became head of the combined operations. He will continue on La Salle's board and will join Northwestern University's Kellogg Graduate School of Management as a visiting scholar in its Banking Research Center.

headline: War Summary
abstract: BAGHDAD SPEAKS OF WITHDRAWAL Baghdad radio said Iraq's armed forces had been ordered to make an orderly withdrawal from Kuwait, and Iraqi tanks and trucks were reported heading north from Kuwait. But Washington dismissed the broadcast, saying that there had been no authoritative communication of its message, and that the war would go on. ALLIES FORGE AHEAD Bombers and attack helicopters roamed ahead of advancing allied armies in southern Iraq and Kuwait as Americans reported their first contact with the Iraqi Army's vaunted Republican Guard. Saudi and Kuwaiti units backed by United States Marines and airborne troops were reported preparing for an assault on Kuwait City, while a Marine amphibious force waited offshore. To the north, the 101st Airborne Division sat astride the Guards' supply lines as two other United States Army units, the First and Third Armored Divisions, were reported closing in on the Guards from the west. For the first time in the war, the allies reported the launching of Iraqi Silkworm anti-ship missiles at allied warships off Kuwait, but no damage was reported. Baghdad reported crushing allied ground attacks, with allied troops "rolling in their blood and shame." TERRORISM: 'THE ONLY IRAQI SUCCESS' Citing the destruction of Kuwait oil wells and reports that buildings were being blown up and citizens executed in Kuwait City, an allied Central Command spokesman said that "terrorism remains the only Iraqi success to date." The top Saudi general said he hopes to bring war crimes charges against those responsible. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: In the worst Scud attack of the war, at least 27 American soldiers were killed and 98 were wounded when an Iraqi missile demolished a barracks in Saudi Arabia. Before the Scud attack, American casualties since the allied ground offensive began were listed as 4 killed and 21 wounded. From Jan. 17 to Feb. 23, 23 Americans were reported killed, 34 wounded and 9 missing. Five allied Arab soldiers were reported killed and 20 wounded in ground action. Aircraft: Four American aircraft were lost, with three of the five pilots rescued, bringing to 27 the tally of American planes lost in combat. Other allies have lost 9. IRAQI FORCES Troops: Iraqi troops continued to surrender en-masse, with the total now reported to about 20,000. There have been no reports from either side on the number of Iraqi dead and wounded. Armor and Weaponry: An "extremely conservative" count by American commanders listed more than 270 Iraqi tanks destroyed in two days, including 35 of their top-of-the-line T-72's. Extensive destruction of artillery batteries was also reported by the allies.

headline: 'Junk Bond' Price Rise Continues
abstract: Prices of high-yield "junk bonds" continued to rise yesterday and finished February with their best-ever monthly return.    An index of 339 high-yield issues compiled by the First Boston Corporation posted a return of 8.6 percent in February, the highest monthly return since the firm began compiling monthly statistics in 1985. For the first two months, the index has posted a return of 11.6 percent.

headline: A Coke Bottle Uses Recycled Plastic
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company's North Carolina bottling operation began a limited market introduction here of the first soft drink bottles made with recycled plastic. The 2-liter bottles of Coca-Cola Classic are made with a blend of 25 percent recycled plastic and 75 percent "virgin" resin.   The new bottle, announced by Atlanta-based Coca-Cola last year, is the result of new technology that breaks down plastic polymer into its original components, then regenerates the purified resin for use in making new bottles. This is the first time the United States Food and Drug Administration has allowed recycled plastic to be used in food packaging.

headline: Unit of Williams In Centel Deal
abstract: The Williams Telecommunication Group, which has an 11,000-mile fiber-optic telephone network but has been in search of customers, agreed to acquire the business telephone unit of the Centel Corporation. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.   The Centel division, Centel Communications Systems, distributes, installs and maintains office phone systems and has about 16,000 customers. Williams Telecommunication is a division of the Williams Companies, a Tulsa-based pipeline operator.

headline: For a Gloomy Outlook, Hungarians Top All
abstract: Last year, as democracy was making its comeback in this country of 10.5 million, polls showed a deep gloom descending over Hungary. Now, a year later, the mood has sunk even lower, making Hungarians the most pessimistic country of those surveyed in an international poll conducted by the Gallup Organization.    A regional poll of Eastern Europe done by Gallup Hungary indicates that the Hungarians' economic worries are widely shared by citizens of other formerly Communist countries, also caught in the throes of transition to a market economy.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Pepsi-Cola Expanding Its 'Uh-Huh' Promotion
abstract: Pepsico Inc. announced plans yesterday to expand its "Uh-Huh" Diet Pepsi promotion with a nationwide talent contest that begins during this week's Grammy Awards broadcast.  The soft-drink maker, a long-time sponsor of the music awards, said it's looking for the best, funniest and most entertaining home-video rendition of its new jingle, "You've Got The Right One Baby, Uh-Huh!"  "We're excited about the overwhelming response consumers have expressed for our new Diet Pepsi commercials," said David Novak, Pepsi's executive vice president for marketing and sales. "We hope our contest will capture all the fun and spontaneity that home videos reveal, and give our consumers a chance to share the spotlight with Diet Pepsi."  Pepsi said it would select three grand-prize winners whose videos would be judged on originality, humor and appropriateness to the "Uh-Huh" theme. Prizes include an appearance on a Pepsi television commercial and $10,000.  The company said it would accept entries through April 30 and notify winners by the end of June. It said details of the contest would be released during its 60-second commercials scheduled for the broadcast of the Grammy Awards tomorrow.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; Battle Horrors: U.S. Troops Prepare
abstract: As preparations for a ground war continue, American military commanders are trying to prepare the inexperienced for grim battlefield realities.    Col. James Riley of the First Armored Division, habitually soft-spoken, showed unusual fierceness in a 50-minute monologue to his officers, according to a pool report. "My goal is for this to be a killer brigade," he said. "Killers survive."

headline: Two Financiers Head National Intergroup
abstract: Abbey J. Butler and Melvyn J. Estrin tightened their grip yesterday on National Intergroup Inc., the $5.5 billion successor to National Steel.   And they said they had decided against selling the company's Foxmeyer wholesale drug unit because its business was improving. Besides, they could not get their asking price.

headline: Mellon Bank Posts a Loss
abstract: The Mellon Bank Corporation today posted a fourth-quarter loss of $99 million and attributed it to an increase in the company's reserves against losses from bad real estate loans.   The quarterly loss compared with earnings of $6 million in the final quarter of 1989.

headline: Stocks Rise Sharply, With Dow Up 49.01
abstract: Stocks advanced sharply yesterday in heavy trading, as analysts started to predict again that the Dow Jones industrial average could be on its way to the magical 3,000 level that it has flirted with several times.    "Investment opportunities right now," said Peter DaPuzzo, senior executive vice president of Lehman Brothers, "are better on stocks than on bonds, real estate or precious metals, and the Dow will make a new assault on 3,000."

headline: More on the Gulf
abstract: NOW A CRITIC Gen. William C. Westmoreland, criticized in the Vietnam War, is the critic now. And George McGovern says he may run for President. Page A14.   TOWN PITCHES IN A Michigan town pitches in to help after vandalism and a fire at a restaurant owned by a Palestinian-American who opposes the war. Blissfield Journal, page A14.   CHILDREN'S FEARS Peter Jennings, the ABC News anchor, is trying to address the concerns children have about the war. Word and Image, page C28.    HOW HIGH THE COST?  As the Administration tries to stabilize the economy to ward off inflation or recession, the war's cost may overwhelm all its calculations. Economic Scene, page D2.

headline: Vienna Takes Aim at Myths About Mozart
abstract: On Dec. 5, 1791, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart died of poisoning while working on a Requiem Mass commissioned by a gray-cloaked stranger. Too poor to buy even a proper coffin, Mozart's wife, Constanza, buried the composer in an unmarked pauper's grave with four other bodies. Right?    "Look, the creation of these myths is a very complicated affair," said Gunter Brosche, director of the music collection at the Austrian National Library. "On one hand, we're of the opinion that modern Mozart research has cleared up these legends for the most part. But it's not like that in the minds of the public and in the media."

headline: Excerpts From Saddam Hussein's Comments on the Gulf War
abstract: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in an interview Monday with Peter Arnett, Cable News Network correspondent in Baghdad. The interview was broadcast by CNN Tuesday night. The excerpts were provided to Reuters by News Transcripts Inc.     What we say is that light comes through the dark, penetrates the dark. As much as -- whenever the American Administration expects that it is filling Baghdad or covering Baghdad with darkness, then the American Administration will face the light that exists, that fills the breasts of the Iraqi people, the light, which is based on deep conviction in God, the one and only. What is important to us is that the darkness which the American Administration wants to see penetrate to the brains, to the minds, to the hearts, to the conscience of the people, is a darkness that has no place in the people -- amongst the people of Iraq.                 . .

headline: Cairo Says Pullback Is Not Compliance
abstract: Although delighted by the announced Iraqi retreat from Kuwait, Egypt cautioned today that Baghdad still had more to do to comply with United Nations resolutions on the Persian Gulf, including one that nullifies the annexation of Kuwait last summer.   Egyptian military leaders, who command one of the largest Arab contingents in the gulf with nearly 40,000 troops, were clearly pleased with their role in helping to oust the Iraqis from Kuwait. Their troops, they said, had advanced faster than expected, they had suffered no casualties and, as a bonus, 4,000 Iraqi soldiers had surrendered today alone to Egyptian forces.

headline: All About/Golf Courses; Can Builders Rely on a Fairway View to Sell Homes?
abstract: Developers discovered during the 1980's that they could sell whole subdivisions built around golf courses as readily as the new residents could sink one-foot putts. But by now, they have built so many homes on the links that many projects have turned out no better than the slices into the woods.   There are 13,951 operating golf courses in the United States, with hundreds opening each year as more people take up the sport.  The National Golf Foundation, a developers' trade group based in Jupiter, Fla., reports that 289 new courses opened last year; 561 are under construction and 781 are planned.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Video Technology Industries Inc., Wheeling, Ill., to Berenter Greenhouse & Webster, New York, with a budget of $10 million. The account was previously handled by Ayer, New York and Zwiren Collins Karo Trusk, Chicago. * Blockbuster Video, Washington, to DDB Needham, Washington, with billings of $2 million to $3 million. * CVS, to Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, Boston, for its Peoples Drug Stores. The previous agency was Ehrlich-Manes Associates, Bethesda, Md. * Century 21 Real Estate, Irvine, Calif., to Campbell-Mithun-Esty, Detroit, for three of its Midwestern offices. Billings could not be learned.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * AON Corp., Chicago, an insurance holding company, said its retail brokerage subsidiary, Rollins Burdick Hunter Co., would acquire Huntington T. Block Insurance, Washington. Terms were not disclosed. * Computer Sciences Corp., El Segundo, Calif., a computer services company, said an affiliate had acquired Analytics Inc., Willow Grove, Pa., an information security and communications systems company. Terms were not disclosed. * Energy Service Co., Inc., Houston, an oil and gas drilling company, has completed the acquisition of the operations of Argosy Offshore Ltd., for $24.2 million, along with certain merchandise credits from Energy Service's supply division, not to exceed $5 million. * General Motors Corp., Detroit, said its Hungarian subsidiary plans to sell 4,000 Opel cars in Hungary this year and about 17,000 to 18,000 next year. * Hawker de Havilland Ltd., which is 70 percent owned by Hawker Siddeley Group P.L.C., London, a maker of electrical equipment, will cut 200 jobs at its airframe and aircraft engine parts plant at Port Melbourne, Australia. * Heilig-Meyers Co., Richmond, a home furnishings company, has acquired seven stores from Furniture Center Inc. for undisclosed terms. * Morrison Knudsen Corp., Boise, Idaho, a construction, engineering and environmental company, has received contracts to manage new construction projects for General Motors Corp. in Hungary, Glaxo Inc. in Triangle Park, N.C., and the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation in the Pacific Northwest. Terms of the contracts were not disclosed. * Nabisco Brands Ltd., a Canadian unit of RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp., will close its cannery in Simcoe, Ontario, on Feb. 22. The plant has 98 employees. * Telesphere Communications Inc., Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., a telecommunications and data management company, said it had signed agreements for investors to buy $22 million of its common shares and signed agreements with its lenders and vendors for $35 million of additional credit in the next 12 months. * Tetra Technologies Inc. has acquired TSI, an oilfield equipment, supplies and services provider, in a stock purchase exchange.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    The common stock dividend is being sliced. With profits shrinking as the recession digs in, the nation's auto, aerospace, appliance and other companies are left with little extra cash to pay to shareholders. Thus another of the corporate excesses of the 1980's is being reversed.  [ Page A1. ]   Leading retailers reported generally disappointing results for January, creating concern over profits in the final quarter and the year as a whole. Twelve of the 19 largest chains announcing their results had same-store declines or minimal gains.  [ D1. ]   Former F.D.I.C. regulators told a Congressional hearing that for more than a year their superiors had thwarted their efforts to recover large losses from the billionaire owner of a Phoenix savings and loan that failed.  [ D2. ]   "An invitation to regulatory civil war." That is what William Seidman calls the Administration's radical plan to change the way banks are run. As head of the F.D.I.C., Seidman stands to lose some of his extensive power under the new bank plan.  [ D2. ]   Consumer credit fell at an annual rate of 2.3 percent in December, the steepest decline in nearly four years, the Fed said.  [ D3. ]   New York City bonds are likely to be issued without insurance backing for the first time in years.  [ B3. ] Companies    Chrysler surprised Wall Street by posting a $31 million profit in the fourth quarter in the face of plunging car and truck sales. But its profit was too narrow to quiet growing concerns that the No. 3 auto maker may soon face severe financial difficulties.  [ D1. ]   Avon said it would increase its dividend 40 percent and pay a special dividend of $3 a share, or more than a year's profits. Analysts said the surprise move could help it win a coming proxy fight with Chartwell Associates.  [ D1. ]   MIPS Computer Systems has emerged as one of two leaders in the race to sell computers based on the RISC chip design.  [ D1. ]   Sony is reportedy talking to Orion Pictures about buying that financially troubled film and TV company. Sony is said to be acting through Castle Rock Entertainment, a small film production company one-third owned by Columbia Pictures.  [ D1. ]   Mesa Limited Partnership agreed to sell 11 percent of its natural gas reserves for $275 million in cash.  [ D3. ]   A team trying to arrange an employee stake in The Daily News met to lay out its strategy.  [ B4. ] Markets    Prices in the credit markets gave ground for the first time in days, as market participants apparently took profits after a successful auction of $11 billion in new 30-year Treasury bonds.  [ D1. ]   Stocks fell for the first time in almost a week, but trading remained exceptionally heavy. The Dow lost 20.30, to 2,810.64, as many investors switched into lower-priced stocks.  [ D6. ]   The dollar edged higher in domestic trading for the first time in more than a week after two central banks intervened to shore up the currency.  [ D13. ]   Oil prices fell after a rally driven by the price of heating oil faded on forecasts of warmer weather in Europe.  [ D13. ] Today's Columns    The battle has begun over the Administration's proposals for the most drastic overhaul of the nation's banking system since the Depression. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene.  [ D2. ]   Volvo awarded its $40 million account to Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer. The account review had been closely watched in the industry recently. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D5. ]   Just what is a securities exchange? More than 50 years after Congress adopted the Securities Exchange Act, putting the regulatory framework in place for the modern marketplace, a debate is raging on that question. Market Place.  [ D6. ]

headline: Raise Is Deferred By Bloomingdale's
abstract: Bloomingdale's and the United Storeworkers Union, Local 3, reached an agreement yesterday to defer an $18-a-week increase for store workers until June 1 instead of the negotiated date of March 1.    The department-store chain, which is a unit of Federated Department Stores, had asked for elimination of the scheduled increase for some 3,500 unionized workers because it was in voluntary bankruptcy as part of Federated Stores. But the union local had opposed it. In the settlement, the two parties also agreed to extend the five-year contract for an additional year until March 1, 1995, protecting all contract provisions on wages, benefits and health care.

headline: Article 869891 -- No Title
abstract: The Beneficial Corporation yesterday priced $300 million in senior notes due Feb. 15, 1998, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.   Underwriters offered the 9 1/8 percent notes at a price of 99.75 to yield 9.174 percent, or about 153 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.    Noncallable by the company through maturity, the notes are rated A-3 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Korea Auto Exports
abstract: South Korea's auto exports to the United States plunged in the first two months of the year from a year earlier, the Korea Automobile Manufacturers Association reported today. Association officials said exports to the United States, Korea's biggest export market, fell 21.2 percent, to 17,554 cars, accounting for 43.5 percent of this nation's total car exports. Korea's overall car exports were listed at 40,380 in the first two months of this year, up 2.7 percent from year earlier.

headline: Few Riches in Rags These Days
abstract: The rag trade is looking a bit frayed. Already battered by competition from low-cost imports, hundreds more American clothing makers were driven out of business last year by the weak economy and poor retail sales.    Nationwide, the industry lost 50,000 jobs in the last 12 months, according to the American Apparel Manufacturers Association. As Wall Street took note of the industry's troubles, the stocks of many well-known companies, including the Hartmarx Corporation, Gitano Group Inc., Farah Inc., Russ Togs Inc. and V. F. Corp., fell sharply in 1990.

headline: 10,000 at Jewish Rally Urge Hussein Ouster
abstract: Amid fluttering American and Israeli flags, thousands of demonstrators at a midtown Manhattan rally in support of Israel and the allied troops lustily cheered repeated calls for the ouster of the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein -- not only from Kuwait, but also from power in his own country.    "When this operation is over, there will be no more Iraqi tanks, Iraqi planes, Iraqi missiles, Iraqi chemical weapons, and there will be no more President Saddam Hussein," said Uriel Savir, the Israeli Consul General in New York. "The Middle East without Saddam Hussein is a Middle East that can work for peace."    Kuwait was mentioned almost as an afterthought by many at the rally, who appeared more concerned with destroying Mr. Hussein.    It was the New York Jewish community's response to the Iraqi missile attacks on Israel. The police estimated that 10,000 people jammed Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, near the United Nations headquarters, for the midday rally, which they said was the largest public gathering since the war began.    Senator Daniel P. Moynihan, who had voted against using force to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait, said the attacks on Israel meant the allies must now "go beyond" their original objective of ending the conquest of Kuwait.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; Iraq Issues a Call for Peace Hours Before Bush's Speech
abstract: Hours before President Bush announced a conditional suspension of offensive fighting today, Baghdad moved closer to capitulation, offering to relinquish all claim to Kuwait, release allied prisoners and accept responsibility for war reparations in return for an immediate cease-fire and the lifting of international sanctions.   Shortly after the Iraqi offer was made known on Wednesday, three explosions rocked central Baghdad, and a Reuters correspondent there said the blasts, possibly from cruise missiles, were so great that the Rashid Hotel, where Western reporters in the city are staying, "heaved and shuddered."

headline: Explosions by Base in Turkey
abstract: An explosion damaged a car outside the United States Consulate and another blast blew the door off a Turkish-American organization today in this southern city near an air base used to attack Iraq, the authorities said. No one was reported injured in the explosions, the first reported in Adana since the war against Iraq began. Adana is the main city near the strategic Incirlik base being used by American warplanes. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the explosions.

headline: Iraqis Reduced To a 'Rabble,' General Asserts
abstract: The guns fell silent across Iraq and Kuwait today, with only isolated exchanges of fire marring the cease-fire between the remnants of President Saddam Hussein's occupying armies and the coalition forces who thrashed them in a 100-hour ground war.    Six weeks after President Bush unleashed a relentless series of air attacks on Iraq and almost seven months after the Iraqi conquest of Kuwait, the American command said all of the 42 divisions that Mr. Hussein had assembled to defend Kuwait had been destroyed, captured or rendered unfit for battle. Only about "a division plus," or 15,000 to 20,000 soldiers, remained in fighting trim at war's end, a command spokesman estimated.

headline: Questions About New Glaxo Drugs
abstract: IN the last decade, Glaxo Holdings P.L.C. has been one of the strongest British stocks, largely as a result of Zantac, its anti-ulcer medicine that is the world's top-selling drug. In the year that ended June 30, Zantac accounted for 49 percent of Glaxo's sales of $:2.85 billion ($4.98 billion).    But a slip in Glaxo's price in recent weeks on the London Stock Exchange has raised the question of whether the long rise is over. While not expecting an immediate plunge, several analysts believe the stock, long an overperformer relative to the market, could turn into an underperformer in the months ahead. They have recently downgraded their earnings estimates for Glaxo.

headline: How to Protect Family Business
abstract: People who own a business and hope their sons or daughters will carry it on should visit their lawyers soon unless they have done so recently. The reason: the tax law and Deficit Reduction Act passed just before Halloween last year makes it necessary to draw up new plans for the eventual transfer of the business to the next generation with as small a tax bite as possible.    Actually, the history of the matter goes back farther than that, and it relates to an essential problem for the taxpayers: Gift and estate taxes run as high as 55 percent, but such a sizable tax bite could cripple many small businesses.

headline: In a Ghost Town, a Deadly Skirmish
abstract: What happened in Khafji, the scene of the first sustained land battle in the Persian Gulf war, was being debated today even as the deadly skirmishing continued.    The town is surrounded by low, wet sand areas known as sabkhas, impassable to heavy vehicles because of recent rains. Intermingled Saudi and American units had both been outside the deserted port city, to the south, when the action started late Tuesday.

headline: Microsoft In Inquiry By F.T.C.
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission is investigating the competitive practices of the Microsoft Corporation, the maker of software for personal computers.    The F.T.C. does not comment on investigations in progress, but some industry executives reached by the commission said the investigation addresses whether Microsoft had used its dominant position in operating-systems software to stifle competition in other areas, including applications software, like word processors, and peripheral products, primarily the mouse pointing device.

headline: British Air Giving Away 50,000 Tickets
abstract: Impatient to fill seats emptied by the war, British Airways announced a bold promotional campaign today aimed at coaxing people into the air again. The airline, Europe's largest, will give away about 50,000 tickets on international flights as part of a broad program of incentives and promotions.   Fear of terrorism "evaporates with a free ticket," Lord King, the chairman of British Airways P.L.C., said at a news conference announcing the program.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Miscellany
abstract: * Ketchum Public Relations, New York, has acquired an interest in London-based Group Public Relations P.L.C., a $3.5 million consulting firm. Terms were not available. * BDDP Worldwide has offered to buy outstanding stock of the British public relations firm Broad Street. BDDP currently holds a 38 percent share, which it acquired last year.

headline: Chrysler, Banks Set Credit Pact
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation agreed with a consortium of 38 banks today on a new $1.75 billion revolving credit through the end of 1993. The new credit agreement is smaller than the $2.64 billion credit agreement it replaces, but it constitutes an important financial safety net for the No. 3 auto maker, nevertheless.    Thomas Capo, Chrysler's assistant treasurer, said there was no current plan to borrow under the new credit line. "Depending on future business we may or may not draw on the line," he added.

headline: U.S. and Bahrain Near Pact On Permanent Military Base
abstract: The Pentagon is close to an agreement with Bahrain, an island nation in the Persian Gulf, to establish the forward headquarters of the United States Central Command there, Administration and Bahraini officials said today.   In another development in the aftermath of the gulf war, American officials said that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, favor reversing policy to allow some American ground forces to be permanently stationed in Saudi Arabia as part of any joint security arrangements in the region with Arab nations.

headline: Italian Network Bars Hussein Interview, Setting Off Dispute
abstract: The state television network has refused to broadcast an interview with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, touching off a heated dispute among Italian journalists and politicians over whether press freedoms have been unjustly curtailed to help promote Government policies.   One side accuses the network of suppressing important information, while the other says the public air waves should not be used as a propaganda platform for dictators.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Arabs; Neighboring Allies Outraged By Iraqi Violence in Kuwait
abstract: Saudi and Egyptian officials deplored Iraq's "scorched-earth" policy in Kuwait yesterday, while Kuwait accused Iraq of killing dozens of Kuwaitis and arresting thousands more indiscriminately.    Representatives of the countries said they feared that the killing and destruction inside Kuwait would escalate before President Saddam Hussein withdrew his forces.

headline: Medellin Journal; In Colombia's Tortured City, Elite Lives in Fear
abstract: Classroom attendance has thinned at the private English-language high school here. Society reporters from newspapers encounter closed doors across town. And tables stand empty at the Cuatro Estaciones, this striving city's imitation of the Four Seasons restaurant in New York.    "People don't want to throw parties, they don't want to go to cocktail parties," a businessman here said. "There has been an exodus to Bogota and Miami. You can't get a board of directors meeting. A lot of the companies are now run by fax."

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Companies   Eastern Airlines said it would stop flying and begin selling off its planes and other assets. The airline, a fixture in U.S. aviation since 1928 and the nation's eighth-largest carrier, is by far the largest casualty of the pressures brought by the deregulation of the industry 13 years ago.  [ Page 1. ]   At Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta, Eastern officials were notified that all international flights had been canceled.  [ 48. ]   The 24,000 employees building F-16's at a General Dynamics plant in Fort Worth are rooting for the jet fighters in the Mideast with a mixture of pride, confidence and worry.  [ 37. ]   Nissan said it planned to build a second U.S. plant that would make automobile engines, enabling the company to increase the domestic content of its American-assembled cars.  [ 37. ]   Some fashion magazines and retailers have canceled or re-evaluated their plans to attend European couture shows.  [ 38. ]   Federal banking regulators filed suit against Michael R. Milken and a number of former savings executives.  [ 39. ]   The Go Corporation named William V. Campbell president and chief executive. He is now president of Claris.  [ 39. ]   Heileman Brewing ousted its president and chief operating officer, Murray S. Cutbush, and named Thomas J. Rattigan.  [ 39. ]   Savvy Woman announced that it would cease publication after its February issue, the latest victim of the ad market.  [ 39. ]   Alcoa reported a $140.4 million loss for the fourth quarter, after $275 million in charges against earnings.  [ 39. ]   NCR is claiming in court documents that A.T.&T.'s hostile takeover offer violates Federal law.  [ 39. ]   Peabody Coal said it would cooperate in a broad Federal inquiry into scientific fraud in the nation's coal mines.  [ 14. ]   Infant-formula price-fixing investigations provide insights into the industry's lobbying tactics. Consumer's World.  [ 54. ] Markets    Oil prices fell 10 percent more, the day after the biggest one-day drop ever. Crude lost $2.19 a barrel, to $19.25, its first close under $20 since July. The drop for the week was $8.04.  [ 37. ]   One of the most hectic weeks in Wall Street history ended with a flurry that carried the Dow ahead 23.27, to 2,646.78. For the week, it added 145.29, the biggest weekly point gain ever.  [ 37. ]   Prices of long-term Treasury securities rose in a modest late rally.  [ 40. ]   The dollar closed mostly lower even with war raging, a crisis that would normally draw investors.  [ 45. ]   War news buffeted precious metals, but gold settled a bit higher. Grain and soybeans were lower.  [ 45. ] The Economy    The Bush Administration will ask Congress for an additional $80 billion to bail out 225 more savings and loans this year, or 10 percent of the industry, officials said.  [ 37. ]   The nation's accountants are beginning a push to convince the public they are the best source of financial planning advice. Consumer's World.  [ 54. ] International    The nation's trade deficit fell 12 percent in November, to $9.7 billion, the Commerce Department reported, as the weakening economy dampened demand for oil and other imports.  [ 37. ] Today's Columns    Those envelopes marked "important tax document": open them and check the figures. It could save no end of aggravation and even money. Your Money.  [ 38. ]   A system that bounces messages off tiny meteor trails that last only a few seconds has been patented. Patents.  [ 38. ]

headline: All About/Oil Services; A Lean, High-Tech Industry Poised for Postwar Growth
abstract: During the oil boom of the early 1980's, most companies spent more than $10, some more than $20, to find and produce a barrel of oil in the United States.  Since then, the service companies that provide equipment and crews to drill for oil, and for the natural gas often found with it, have improved the process vastly. They have introduced supercomputers to spot drilling sites and sophisticated equipment that can even drill sideways (box).    For the three years that ended in 1989, the average cost to produce one barrel of oil in the United States was just $4.82, according to John S. Herrold Inc., an oil research firm based in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; IRAQIS SPEAK OF A WITHDRAWAL BUT IMPOSE LIST OF CONDITIONS; BUSH DENOUNCES 'CRUEL HOAX'
abstract: Iraq said for the first time today that it was prepared to discuss compliance with a United Nations Security Council resolution calling for its withdrawal from Kuwait if numerous conditions of its own were met. But President Bush rejected the offer as a "cruel hoax" and urged Iraq's military leaders and civilian population to "take matters into their own hands" and force Saddam Hussein from power.   The statement from the ruling Revolutionary Command Council, normally headed by Mr. Hussein, was read over the Baghdad radio and was welcomed by the Soviet Union, which was simultaneously stepping up diplomatic efforts to end the war.

headline: Data Bank/March 10, 1991
abstract: New-Home Sales   Jan.   Dec.   Nov.        Monthly percent change   --12.3   --4.3   4.5        Factory Orders        Monthly percent change   --1.7   --0.5   --5.8        U.S. Productivity   IV Q'90   III Q'90   II Q'90        Percent change   0.3   0.6   0.3        Cash Wheat Price   March 8   March 1   Feb. 22        No. 1 K.C., per bushel   $2.96   $2.90   $2.78        Prime Rate       Most major banks, in percent   9.00   9.00   9.00        Employment    Feb. headline: An Issue of Consumer Privacy . . .
abstract: Last April, the Lotus Development Corporation announced plans to release the Lotus MarketPlace: Households, a revolutionary mailing list complete with the names, addresses, demographic and prior-purchasing behavior data for 120 million Americans. Equifax Inc., a consumer information company, supplied the data. But nine months later, Lotus and Equifax cancelled the project, citing consumer complaints and "the substantial, unexpected additional costs required to fully address consumer privacy issues."   MarketPlace is a stunning example of the risks that companies face when they try to take personal information -- anything from your name and address to the size of your mortgage -- and sell it.

headline: Industry's Top Mystery: Book Sales
abstract: WHO knows what's going on in publishing? Well, to be honest, nobody does.   There are some basic facts. More than 50,000 new titles are published every year, authors get paid for writing them, tons of books are being shipped around the country at any one moment, and sometimes a rather select group of people reads them. But beyond that: total mystery.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Partners & Shevack, New York, said it had resigned the creative assignment for Meineke Discount Mufflers because of an "inability to reach an acceptable compensation agreement." A Meineke spokesman declined to comment. * Oglivy & Mather Direct, a subsidiary of th Oglivy Group, has formed a new division, the Production Group, to meet all direct advertising production needs. The group, to be run by Norman T. Paley, senior vice president of production services at Oglivy & Mather Direct, will be based in New York.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Air War; Allied Aides Scaling Back Claims To Have Achieved Air Superiority
abstract: Allied officials are scaling back their earlier claims to have achieved air superiority over many areas of Iraq and to have disabled most of President Saddam Hussein's Scud missile-launching sites.    After a harrowing night and morning in which Iraq fired at least nine surface-to-surface missiles at the Saudi capital, Riyadh, and at the huge air base here, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney said Monday in Washington that Mr. Hussein still had "hundreds of them."  New Missile Alerts     Maj. Gen. Burton Moore, operations officer of the American command in the Persian Gulf, said the allies are "nowhere near" eliminating either the fixed or mobile platforms used to launch the Soviet-made projectiles, known as the modified Scud-B.

headline: Latvia's Leader Tries to Placate the Kremlin
abstract: Defended by a mere truck barricade and bonfire vigil, the Latvian government sought to protect its fledgling democracy today, presenting a conciliatory tone toward the Kremlin.   Crowds of anxious civilians kept watch by night and day in the winding streets of Riga's handsome old town, vowing to stand up to the fear of a Soviet military raid similar to the lethal one Sunday in Lithuania.

headline: Great American
abstract: The Great American Bank said it was out of compliance with a capital plan approved by regulators last November. It said fourth-quarter provisions for loan and real estate losses put its capital levels on Dec. 31 at as much as $155 million less than those required by the plan. The bank had reported a loss of $173 million in the period. Non-compliance with the plan could cause the Federal Office of Thrift Supervision to impose sanctions, Great American said.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Technology; Baghdad Is Heart of Iraq's Complex Military Communications Structure
abstract: The command and control system of the Iraqi military relies on a large national network of communications centers and is based on Soviet design, experts say.    United States officials say that one such communications center, or "node," is in a false basement of the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad and that a command center was located in the reinforced concrete structure destroyed by bombing on Wednesday in Baghdad, killing many civilians.

headline: 'We Own This Piece,' G.I. Proclaims
abstract: More than 2,000 American air assault troops plunged at least 50 miles into Iraq at first light today in what officials described as the largest helicopter-borne operation in military history.   The attack north of Iraq's troop concentrations by the 101st Airborne Division established what is essentially a giant, fortified gas station. The installation, known as Cobra base, will fuel helicopters for assaults in the strategic Euphrates River valley to sever the main highway between Baghdad and Basra.

headline: U.S. and Allies Open Air War on Iraq; Bomb Baghdad and Kuwaiti Targets; 'No Choice' But Force, Bush Declares
abstract: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Jan. 17 - The United States and allied forces Wednesday night opened the long-threatened war to drive President Saddam Hussein's army from Kuwait, striking Baghdad and other targets in Iraq and Kuwait with waves of bombers and cruise missiles launched from naval vessels.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: News Analysis; Hard Times, Better Allies
abstract: Cooperation between the Bush Administration and Israel in dealing with Iraq's missile attacks has strikingly improved United States-Israeli relations after two years of mounting tension, Israeli and American officials said today.    But these officials are keenly aware that the recent sensitivity the two countries are showing and American soldiers' participation, for the first time, in the defense of Israel, derive primarily from a coincidence of strategic interests and not from an outburst of mutual concern. If those interests change, so might some of the good feelings.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Off a Bit
abstract: Stocks on the Tokyo Stock Exchange were off slightly in early afternoon trading today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 45.9 points, or 0.17 percent, to 27,146.91.

headline: Eaton Unit Offers 10-Year, 10% Issue
abstract: Eaton Offshore Ltd., a unit of the Eaton Corporation, priced $100 million in 10-year notes yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.    The notes have a 10 percent coupon and were priced at 100, to yield about 114 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than Treasury securities with similar maturities.    Underwriters said the issue was noncallable and was rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Soldiers; Still Time for Tenderness: G.I. Makes Last Call Home
abstract: After buying $156 worth of candy bars, King Edward cigars and Pepsi for his platoon, Sgt. Ted L. Smith walked through the shallow puddles that filled the streets of a northern Saudi border town toward a clothing store.    He entered the store, which had a painted sign out front that read, in shaky English: "Atantion: Here is Atelphone Service."

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * America West Airlines, Inc., Tempe, Ariz., said its ridership increased 8.4 percent in the fourth quarter, but not enough to prevent a fourth-quarter loss. The carrier's chairman, Edward R. Beauvais, estimated a loss of $50 million. * Arvin Industries, Columbus, Ind., a maker of auto-exhaust and ride-control products, has completed the sale of its Arvinair division to a group of private investors, including Arvinair management and led by Oppenheimer & Co., New York, the investment firm. Terms were not disclosed. * Comerica Inc., Detroit, a bank holding company, and Plaza Commerce Bancorp, San Jose, Calif., a bank holding company, have completed their merger. Comerica acquired all outstanding shares of Plaza Commerce common stock by exchanging one share of Comerica common stock for each 3.5 shares of Plaza Commerce common stock. The total value of the transaction is $86.5 million. * Consolidated American Industries said it would pay a one-time dividend to holders of record on Feb. 1 of one common share of Gemstar Enterprises for each 12 common shares of Consolidated American held. * Sogeti S.A., Paris, a professional services holding company, said it would acquire a majority interest in MAC Group, Cambridge, Mass., a management consulting group, for undisclosed terms. * Toshiba Corp., Tokyo, the Japanese electronics company, said it has developed a robot so flexible it can arrange flowers into a bouquet. The robot is made of silicon gum and nylon and is moved by air or water pressure. * Ver-Val Enterprises, Fort Walton Beach, Fla., a maker of fabrication materials for the military industry, has offered to purchase the assets of the telephone line sharing switch technology operations of Rainier Technologies Corp., Kirkland, Wash. The proposed purchase price was not disclosed.

headline: TLC Beatrice Shows Profit
abstract: TLC Beatrice International, the international food company controlled by the New York financier Reginald F. Lewis, this week reported fourth-quarter net income of $4.5 million, compared with a loss of $15 million in the corresponding period of 1989. The company attributed the improvement to expansion into Eastern Europe, strong sales in Southern Europe and "favorable currency effects."    Revenues for the quarter were up 35.3 percent, to $376.4 million, from $278.1 million a year earlier. The company is a maker of ice cream and desserts, snacks, beverages and grocery products, primarily in Western Europe. The company also operates a wholesale and retail food distribution business in France.

headline: Dow Gains 15.84 Points, To 2,619.06
abstract: In a tense market where investors make big decisions on the strength of little headlines, nervous stock traders touched off heavy selling late yesterday after reports of two explosions in Saudi Arabia and air raid sirens in Israel.    The Dow Jones industrial average still managed to end the day 15.84 points higher, at 2,619.06, as traders soon began buying again after reports that Iraq had sent missiles over both countries but that none had gotten through.

headline: CNN Takes an Early Lead In Coverage of the Gulf War
abstract: The shooting in the Persian Gulf began tonight with the three broadcast networks committed to covering the war on a 24-hour basis, although their image as news leaders was damaged by the Cable News Network's early dominance of the coverage.    CBS and CNN refrained from interrupting their news reports with advertising, but ABC interrupted its coverage throughout the night. NBC began using commercials after President Bush addressed the nation. In both cases, the number of commercials was much lower than that on normal prime-time television.

headline: A Code Word, a Lunch And a Series of Briefings
abstract: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d gave the news to Prince Bandar bin Sultan, Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to the United States, early today in a private briefing. The Prince then called King Fahd and, using a prearranged code word, gave the hosts of the allied coalition final word of imminent war against Iraq.   President Bush's warnings and Mr. Baker's last-chance pleas of recent days made it apparent that the Administration would wage quick war if Iraq did not vacate Kuwait. But officials say the planning and precise timing of the military strike were carefully concealed, an enigma to most foreign and domestic leaders and even to Administration insiders until the final instant.

headline: A Real Estate Fortune Dissolves
abstract: Daniel Mauck Galbreath had a reputation as a conservative real estate developer. But even his cautious stewardship could not save his business or the family fortune.    As head of the eighth-largest real estate development company in the country, he guides a family-run business that has erected skyscrapers for Borden Inc., the Mobil Corporation and Merrill Lynch & Company. And Forbes magazine put his wealth at about $340 million only a year ago.

headline: Markets Closed
abstract: All financial and commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Washington's Birthday. Government offices, most banks and many businesses were also closed.

headline: Hussein Hiding Billions? Report Stirs Furor
abstract: News reports that Saddam Hussein had squirreled away billions of dollars in bank accounts around the world reverberated through business and diplomatic communities yesterday.   The Treasury Department was besieged with questions about how much of Mr. Hussein's assets were, in fact, hidden in such accounts, where they were and what would be done about them.

headline: Japanese Leader Cancels Trip
abstract: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan has canceled a trip to Southeast Asia next week, citing the need to stay in Tokyo and watch developments in the Persian Gulf crisis. Mr. Kaifu expressed disappointment today at the apparent failure of talks between the United States and Iraq to avert war.

headline: U.S. Companies to Join Bid To Minimize Gulf Oil Spill
abstract: American companies specializing in oil-spill cleanups are preparing to join an international effort to help Saudi Arabia minimize the effects of the giant spill in the Persian Gulf. But some of the concerns say they are reluctant to send men and equipment to a war zone. .    "There are three assessment teams over there now -- one American, one British, one French," said Benjamin Tisdale, president of Martech, a company based in Anchorage, Alaska, that specializes in cleaning up oil spills. "We understand there is going to be a meeting at noon, Saudi time, tomorrow to decide what to do. Right now everybody's going in different directions."

headline: Bank Lending Still Tight Despite Easing by the Fed
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board's latest readings on whether banks are lending show that despite aggressive easing by the central bank recently, they continued to tighten lending standards this winter.   As a result, the nation's money supply barely edged up in January.

headline: U.S. Sales Of Vehicles Drop 31.5%
abstract: Sales of American-made vehicles dropped 31.5 percent in late January, closing a month of drastic sales declines for auto makers buffeted by war and a weak economy.    The latest drop is a stark reminder that domestic and foreign auto makers confront the most serious slump in demand for cars and trucks in the United States since the last recession ended in 1982. Since August, consumer confidence has been stuck at its lowest level in a decade, according to recent surveys conducted by the University of Michigan.  'Prospects Are too Uncertain'    "Rather than telling us that car price discounts aren't big enough or that interest rates are too high, people are saying their economic prospects are too uncertain," said Richard T. Curtin, the director of the survey. "A lot of consumers have put off even looking for new cars and trucks."

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Pro Bono
abstract: * The United Hospital Fund, a not-for-profit organization that addresses health care issues, will introduce a print and radio campaign next month intended to recruit 2,500 volunteers for New York City's hospitals and nursing homes. The campaign and its slogan, "Give a little, get a lot," were designed by William Douglas McAdams Inc., New York, on a pro-bono basis. * The Stogel Companies, a small New York agency, is donating its time and resources to a campaign for Food For Survival Inc., a not-for-profit group that provides free and reduced-cost food to organizations that serve the poor and elderly. The campaign uses direct mail, among other methods, to solicit food and money for the New York-based charity.

headline: Mid-March Vehicle Sales Off 11.1%
abstract: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks fell by 11.1 percent in the middle of the month, as demand for new vehicles continued to sputter at recessionary levels.   Surveys show consumer confidence has strengthened since February, and dealers report more visitors to showrooms. But analysts say many people simply cannot afford to buy new cars, because they already have so much debt.

headline: Durables Orders Up In Month
abstract: Buoyed in part by new military orders related to the Persian Gulf buildup, orders to factories for long-lasting goods climbed 4.4 percent in December, the Commerce Department reported today.    The increase was somewhat more than expected, but analysts said they found little in the latest figures to support hopes of an economic rebound. Even the rise in military orders, they noted, was from a severely depressed level the month before and was not large enough to provide any more than a nudge to business activity in coming months.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Alltel Corp., Hudson, Ohio, a telecommunications company, will acquire the Missouri Telephone Co. for $85 million. * BSN Corp., Dallas, a sporting goods company, said its board had decided that a $55 million offer for two of its businesses was inadequate.

headline: U.S. Delays on Claim Against Contractors
abstract: The Pentagon said yesterday that it would delay its efforts to collect $1.35 billion from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the General Dynamics Corporation while the contractors challenged the Government's claim in court.   The Pentagon's action removed, at least temporarily, a financial cloud that has hung over the companies since last month, when Defense Secretary Dick Cheney canceled their contract to build a new Navy warplane, the A-12.

headline: Environmental Coalition Is Split
abstract: An unlikely coalition of state officials, industry representatives and environmentalists that had pledged to reduce the amount of solid waste going into landfills in the Northeast has become divided over rules intended to cut down the amount of packaging used in consumer products.    Eleven environmental and consumer organizations have stopped participating in the Source Reduction Council of the Coalition of Northeast Governors because of what they said was a lack of action on setting specific packaging-reduction goals.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * May Department Stores Co., St. Louis, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $800 million in debt securities. RATINGS * Ameritrust Corp.'s debt is under review for possible downgrading. The bank-holding company is based in Cleveland. * Corestates Financial Corp.'s debt rating is under review for possible downgrading by Moody's. The bank-holding company is based in Philadelphia. * Sweden's debt rating has been lowered to Aa-1, from Aaa, by Moody's. * Tribune Co.'s senior debt rating is under review for possible downgrading by Standard & Poor's because of the costs of the strike at The Daily News in New York and the potential impact of the tentative decision to close or sell the newspaper. Tribune Co. is based in Chicago.

headline: U.S. Ruling On Screens Favors Japan
abstract: The Commerce Department said today that Japan was selling the display screens used in popular laptop and notebook computers below fair market value, but in a preliminary ruling it found that the differences, or "dumping" margins, were relatively modest.   The decision in the closely followed case was considered a victory for the Japanese makers of "flat panels," which include most of the leading Japanese electronics companies, and for the big American computer companies that buy Japanese panels. It was seen as a defeat, though, for domestic producers.

headline: Displaced Iraqis Streaming Into Allied-Held Zone
abstract: Thousands of Iraqi civilians have streamed into small villages and isolated desert communities in Iraqi territory controlled by allied forces, United States Army officials said today.    The majority of the people are returning home after fleeing advancing allied ground forces. But many others are refugees from the civil unrest that has engulfed several towns and cities in southern Iraq, the officials said.

headline: Market Place; What Constitutes An 'Exchange'?
abstract: MORE than 50 years after Congress adopted the Securities Exchange Act, putting the regulatory framework in place for the modern marketplace, a debate is raging among industry professionals and Government officials: Just what is a securities exchange?   At the center of the controversy is a privately owned computerized system that allows institutional investors to buy and sell over-the-counter options on Government securities.

headline: Resales Of Homes Jump by 7.9%
abstract: Sales of existing homes shot up 7.9 percent in February, the first increase since November and the biggest in nearly five years, giving private economists hope that a housing rebound may be heralding the end of the recession.   The National Association of Realtors said today that the February rise put sales of existing single-family homes at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.13 million units.

headline: Hiring Those With Disabilities
abstract: To the Editor:   For over a year, we employed a deaf person for word-processing ("Welcoming Those With Disabilities," Feb. 3). This was a conscious decision. We sought out a deaf person because we too were looking to supplement what, at the time, was a work force with declining reading, writing and, consequently, typing skills. We all learned rudimentary sign language and provided her with a device ($429) so she could make and receive calls like anyone else.   Your article neglects to discuss the problems a small business faces in welcoming those with disabilities: increased cost, for one. For example, an interpreter needs to be hired to help interview deaf candidates and also to assist at staff meetings and similar group events. The least costly one charged us $60 an hour.   We tried to hire other deaf employees because ours was, overall, a positive experience, but we couldn't find a pool to select from. We also tried to hire people with other types of handicaps including those in wheelchairs. But although we had a person devoting considerable time to this activity, we couldn't find interested candidates.   In New York City, there is an additional problem you don't mention: transportation. All who are willing don't necessarily have an office or live along a route with buses equipped with wheelchair lifts. No one talks about these severe impediment. RITA SUE SIEGEL New York, N.Y., Feb. 5, 1991  The writer is chairman of Rita Sue Seigel Associates, a management advisory firm in New York City.

headline: Weather in the Gulf
