abstract: Clearing skies are expected in the Persian Gulf. Sunny and mild weather will prevail in Iraq and northern Saudi Arabia. After morning clouds, sun will increase in Syria and Lebanon. Clouds will linger from northern Egypt to southern Israel as onshore winds blow. Temperatures: Baghdad: high 57, low 34; Riyadh, high 70, low 43; Dhahran, high 69, low 49.

headline: Mutual Funds; Global Bond Funds' Gulf Strategy
abstract: Managers of global bond funds were among the top performers last year. But now they're at the center of wildly volatile international markets. Their worst nightmare, they say, is this: Iraq bombs the oil fields of Saudi Arabia, disrupting world oil supplies, sending up inflation and depressing bond prices. A major breakdown in the flow of oil is the wild card in all of their strategies, the worst-case scenario.    Despite such fears, fund managers in the $4.4 billion global bond market say they have done so much scrambling since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August that they are now sitting tight -- however temporarily -- to see how things unfold.

headline: Jailed S.& L. Owner Stricken
abstract: Don R. Dixon, the former savings and loan association owner who was convicted last month of fraud, has been hospitalized after a heart attack.   Mr. Dixon, 52 years old, was taken to the hospital early Sunday, his lawyer said. It was confirmed on Monday that Mr. Dixon had suffered a heart attack.   Mr. Dixon's lawyer, Deborah Goodall, said her client had previously suffered two heart attacks, most recently 12 years ago.   Mr. Dixon is scheduled to be sentenced on Feb. 19. The former owner of the Vernon Savings Association of Dallas, he has been held since Dec. 21, when he was convicted on 23 counts of misusing Vernon funds. Vernon Savings failed in 1987, and its bailout is expected to cost taxpayers more than $1.2 billion.

headline: Mutual Funds; Bargains in Single-Country Clones
abstract: In a classic psychological study, a salesman showed shoppers two pairs of shoes, identical except for the price. When the customers asked, the salesman stressed that only the price was different. Yet most shoppers bought the more expensive pair.   The same thing is happening now in single-country closed-end funds. Given the choice of nearly identical funds, investors are choosing the pricier ones, puzzling market experts. But it means bargains for those who steer clear of the expensive ones -- bargains that look enticing in today's hot market.

headline: Air Strike by Israelis Kills 12 Guerrillas In Lebanon's South
abstract: Israel unleashed its deadliest air attack of the year on Lebanon today, killing 12 Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas in a predawn raid near Sidon.   The police and the P.L.O. confirmed in separate statements that there were no survivors among the guerrillas at the base, who belonged to Yasir Arafat's mainstream Al Fatah branch of the organization.

headline: U.S. Securities Mixed in Light Day
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in thin trading yesterday in a session that would not have taken place but for the war in the Persian Gulf.   Before the fighting began in the gulf, participants in the Government securities market had planned to take the day off in observance of the Martin Luther King Jr. Birthday.

headline: Lisbon Journal; From the Pure of Tongue, Catcalls in Portuguese
abstract: When it comes to being a mother country, Portugal has not had an easy time dealing with Brazil, dwarfed as it is by a former colony with 90 times more territory, 15 times more inhabitants, 8 times more economic clout and a good deal more self-assurance.    Brazilians do not make things easier. They constantly poke fun at the Portuguese for their way of speaking Portuguese, they tease them for being dour and old-fashioned and they cannot resist telling jokes that suggest the Portuguese are, well, not as clever as the Brazilians.

headline: Schering-Plough Drops Suit
abstract: The Schering-Plough Corporation agreed today to drop its patent-infringement lawsuit against a New Brunswick research concern over the anticancer agent interferon.   The move came after the company, Interferon Sciences Inc., agreed to stop using Schering-Plough's recombinant interferon alpha-2b, which was the subject of the dispute.

headline: Soviet Army Marks Holiday by Protesting Democracy
abstract: A large but noticeably dispirited protest rally took place outside the Kremlin today as the Soviet military establishment resorted to a technique of democracy -- the right to free assembly -- the better to complain about democracy's alleged excesses.    "Enough demogoguery, you democrats! Stop interfering with Gorbachev," read one of the neatly printed red signs marking the throng of thousands of soldiers bused and trucked into town for the rally on Army Day.

headline: Patents; Developing Improved Vaccines
abstract: Researchers at a small pharmaceutical company in Montana have obtained a patent on new variations of a fatty acid molecule that the company said could be used to create stronger and safer vaccines.    Called Monophosphoryl Lipid A, or MPL, the molecule itself is derived from a toxin contained in many common bacteria. Developed by Ribi Immunochem Research Inc. of Hamilton, Mont., the molecule appears to stimulate a class of white blood cells in the immune system.

headline: Savings Bond Sales Up
abstract: Americans bought $953 million in United States savings bonds in January, the Treasury Department said today. January sales were up 15 percent from the same month in 1990, when they totaled $826 million. Last month's total was the highest for any January since 1944, when sales were $1.09 billion. Savings bond sales have increased steadily since July 1990, the Treasury said, and totaled $8.09 billion last year, 6 percent higher than in 1989. The bonds currently earn interest at a rate of 7.19 percent when held five years or longer.

headline: China to Raise Arms Spending Again
abstract: China's leaders announced a sharp increase in military spending today, despite a rising budget deficit and economic challenges that will mean slower growth in the economy this year.    The increase in military spending, the second in two years, apparently reflects the rising status of the People's Liberation Army since the army-led crackdown in 1989. The Chinese military is gaining influence at a time when a transition of generations in the nation's leadership is likely before long, and greater financial resources are expected to bolster that influence. Chagrined by Comparison     In addition, Western diplomats and Chinese with ties to the military leadership say that during the Persian Gulf war, the Government was deeply distressed by the remarkable display of Western weapons, which are far more advanced than Chinese military systems. The military leaders have apparently lobbied hard for more money to modernize weapons systems.

headline: Ready for 'The Envelope, Please'
abstract: Most days, Franklin R. Johnson bills $315 an hour, lunches at bistros like Jimmy's in Los Angeles and huddles with famous Hollywood clients seeking financial advice. But this week he was holed up in a windowless room in downtown Los Angeles stuffing envelopes.   Mr. Johnson, the 54-year-old Price Waterhouse partner who heads the accounting firm's entertainment division, is preparing for the annual Academy Awards presentation Monday night. His job is to count the ballots.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: U.N. REPORT Iraq Says Air Raids Have Killed 324 Civilians; Iraq Says U.S. Caused Spill
abstract: Iraq denied responsibility for the huge oil slick in the Persian Gulf today and said allied bombing had created it, hurling back at the Americans their accusation of "environmental terrorism."   "The alliance planes bombed oil installations in the province of Kuwait and targeted oil pipes which ignited a fire and led to the flow of quantities of oil" into the Gulf, Baghdad Radio said. "Technical teams are trying with all possible means to extinguish the fire and stop the flow of oil to minimize the effects of the American crime."

headline: Treasury Securities Rise in Price
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities rose in light trading yesterday, as at least some investors apparently decided that after recent sharp declines, notes and bonds were being offered at attractive levels.    On Tuesday an alarming inflation report, the second in less than a week, helped to push bond yields close to 8.40 percent, their highest level since mid-January.

headline: Credit Card Delinquency
abstract: The number of Americans behind in paying credit card bills rose sharply in the fourth quarter but the combined delinquency rate for seven other kinds of consumer loans was stable, a trade group said today.    The percentage of credit card holders 30 or more days late on their payments was a seasonally adjusted 2.86 at the end of the year compared with 2.56 at the end of September and 2.24 a year earlier, the American Bankers Association said.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * Corestates Financial Corp., Philadelphia, is offering $100 million of 9 5/8 percent subordinated notes due 2001 at a price of 99.335 to yield 9.73 percent through Lehman Brothers. Noncallable through maturity, the issue is rated A-2 by Moody's and A- by S.& P. * General Motors Acceptance Corp., Detroit, plans to redeem $300 million of outstanding 9.25 percent notes due Feb. 15, 1993, on March 15 at a price of 100, including accrued interest. * Merrill Lynch & Co. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $1.5 billion in medium-term notes with fixed or variable rates through its own underwriting facilities. * Metropolitan Government of Nashville and Davidson County, Tenn., through its Health and Educational Facilities Board, is offering $23.5 million of tax-exempt bonds for Vanderbilt University. The underwriter, Goldman, Sachs & Co., initially priced the issue to yield from 5 percent in 1992, 6.6 percent in 2006 and 6.75 percent for a bond due 2016. The issue is expected to be rated double-A by both Moody's and S.& P. Common Stock  * Amtel Corp., San Jose, Calif., filed for an initial public offering of 4 million common shares through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. * Gensia Pharmaceuticals Inc., San Diego, filed for 2 million common shares through Alex. Brown & Sons. * Immunogen Inc., Cambridge, Mass., filed for 2 million common shares through Paine Webber Inc. The shares will be sold in the U.S. and overseas. * Norwest Corp., a financial service company based in Minneapolis, filed for 7 million common shares to be sold in the U.S. and internationally.

headline: PRESSING HUSSEIN, U.S. SHOOTS DOWN AN IRAQI AIRCRAFT
abstract: Stepping up the pressure on President Saddam Hussein, an American F-15 shot down an Iraqi fighter-bomber over Iraq today. President Bush warned that allied forces would fire on any other aircraft that defy the ban on Iraqi military flights imposed by the forces that drove Baghdad's troops from Kuwait.   The attack, the first aerial combat since hostilities were suspended on Feb. 27, came as rebellions continued in Iraq. A senior Administration official said that insurrections in the north and south were stronger than Washington had anticipated, but that it was not clear whether the rebellions could lead to the ouster of the Iraqi President.  Help From Iran     Iran is aiding southern Shiite Muslim rebels, while Mr. Hussein has been forced to shift military units north to prevent Kurdish rebels from taking control of large cities and to protect his oilfields, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: DEBT * Arkla Inc., a gas company in Shreveport, La., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $500 milion in debt securities. * Durr-Fillauer Medical Inc., Montgomery, Ala., filed for $60 million in convertible subordinated debentures due in 2006 through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. * Meridian Automobile Grantor Trust 1991-A, a unit of Meridian Bancorp Inc., Reading, Pa., is offering $303 million in securities backed by auto and light-truck receivables through First Boston Corp. The 7.95 percent securities due in 1995 have an average lifespan of 1.5 years and are priced at 99 21/32 to yield 8.108 percent. The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's and is supported by a letter of credit provided by Credit Suisse. * Universal Corp., a holding company based in Richmond, is offering $100 million in 9.25 percent noncallable notes due 2001 at 100 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The issue is rated A-3 by Moody's and A- by S.& P. COMMON STOCK * AMSCO International Inc., Pittsburgh, a maker of sterilization and infection-control equipment, surgical tables and surgical illumination systems, filed for an initial public offering of 5.85 million common shares through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. * Dell Computer Corp., Austin, Tex., filed for 3.5 million common shares, 2.8 million to be sold in the United States, through Goldman, Sachs & Co. RATINGS * Barclays Bank P.L.C.'s senior debt rating has been lowered to AA+, from AAA, by S.& P., which also lowered the subordinated debt rating to AA, from AA+.

headline: More Gains Among Oil Companies
abstract: The ranks of large oil companies posting sharply higher profits for the fourth quarter grew today, with ARCO, Phillips Petroleum, Unocal, Amerada Hess and Pennzoil each reporting substantial gains largely because of higher crude prices.    The gains were especially pronounced because results at Phillips, Unocal and Pennzoil were compared against losses in the final quarter of 1989.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: MARKETS   The dollar has rebounded from a 17-month downturn that brought it to a historic low against the mark and near the record low against the yen. The American currency has risen 18 percent in seven weeks.  [ Page A1. ]  The dollar rose to over 1.7 marks after remarks by Germany's Finance Minister.  [ D16. ]   Small over-the-counter stocks continued to gain strength, but most issues leveled off. The Dow rose 2.72.  [ D10. ]

headline: New Campaigns
abstract: * Readers of Inc. magazine, Newsweek, U.S. News and World Report, and Working Woman may soon find themselves doing double takes, thanks to a new advertising campaign for Mita copiers and fax machines. In the print campaign, which begins in the March issue of Inc., the magazine color cover is duplicated in black and white on the next page. A banner at the bottom of the duplicate cover conveys the theme line: "Just a reminder: When you think duplication, think Mita copiers." Two 30-second Mita television spots, scheduled for broadcast in March, use clips from the films "The Wizard of Oz" and "High Noon." The $15 million campaign was prepared by Lord, Dentsu & Partners, New York. * A can of chow mein noodles that can leap off a shelf and a bottle of soy sauce that can jump from the floor onto a counter are the stars of a new television campaign for La Choy products, which begins today. The campaign, prepared by the San Francisco office of Ketchum Advertising, marks La Choy's first major television commercials since it used the theme line: "La Choy makes Chinese food swing American." * Mannington will introduce a multimillion-dollar national campaign on March 1 to promote its floor coverings. The campaign, which was prepared by Weightman Advertising, includes 15- and 30-second television spots that will be broadcast on network and cable television, as well as print ads that will run in more than 25 consumer publications.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Relief; Allies Asked to Guarantee Safe Transit on Medical Aid
abstract: Unicef and the World Health Organization are asking the allies in the Persian Gulf war to guarantee safe passage through eastern Iraq for a convoy carrying medicine from Iran to women and and children in Iraq and occupied Kuwait.    The request for the allies to refrain from bombing this convoy of trucks carrying $500,000 worth of medicine is a first attempt to hold them to the pledges they made at the World Summmit for Children last year to protect mothers and children caught in war zones and guarantee them adequate supplies of food and medicine.

headline: U.N. Rebukes Israel on Palestinian Deaths in Gaza
abstract: The United Nations Security Council formally rebuked Israel today over the recent killing of Palestinians by its security forces in the territories it has occupied since the 1967 war and reaffirmed that these territories include Israel's capital, Jerusalem.    The rebuke was issued in the form of a non-binding statement read by the Council's President, Bagbeni Adeito Nzengeya of Zaire. It marked the fourth time since the start of the gulf crisis in August that the United States has allowed the Security Council to adopt a position criticizing Israel.

headline: Stock Sale By Citicorp
abstract: Citicorp announced Wednesday night that it had sold $600 million in preferred stock to a broad group of investors and had thus completed a key portion of its plan to strengthen its finances.    The announcement came just two weeks after a member of the Saudi royal family, Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, purchased $590 million of preferred stock from Citicorp.

headline: UAL's Unions Prepared To Renew Buyout Effort
abstract: United Airlines' union workers are ready to renew their efforts to buy the company once the economy improves, the head of the pilots union said. "The union employees at United are fully prepared and economically capable of maintaining their role as major players in any acquisition efforts at our company," Frederick C. Dubinsky, chairman of the United chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association, said.   Mr. Dubinsky and the union organized last year's employee bid to buy United's parent, the UAL Corporation, for $4.4 billion. The attempt failed for lack of financing after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait sent financial markets reeling. Mr. Dubinksy told a meeting of O'Hare International Airport employees and business workers that "the possibility of employee ownership, at least at United, should not be regarded as permanently over."

headline: Life May Become a Weekly
abstract: Life magazine, which ceased publication as a weekly in 1972 and came back to life as a monthly in 1978, is now looking into the possibility of becoming a weekly again.   Direct-mail tests will be conducted nationwide to see if there is enough reader enthusiasm for a weekly Life. Katherine M. Bonniwell, the magazine's publisher, declined to say how large the mailings would be or what would be considered a high enough rate of response for the Time Warner publication to become a weekly.    "The reason we are doing the test is that we think the monthly is doing well with consumers," Ms. Bonniwell said.    A sample of the people who respond favorably to the direct-mail test will receive a prototype issue in March. The prototype will bethe same size as Time magazine, which is smaller than the current issue of Life.   Life's advertising pages were down 22 percent for the first 11 months of the year, according the Publishers Information Bureau. The monthly's circulation is 1.7 million, the same as last year.    Ms. Bonniwell said Time Warner Inc. would not decide whether to make Life a weekly before the summer. Life is also exploring other ways to capitalize on its name, including the possibility of videos, books and foreign-language editions.   A team of editors, writers and designers has been working since last summer on producing prototypes for a possible weekly Life. Details about the changes have been closely guarded, however, and the official word from Time Warner has simply been that the magazine is considering a number of options.

headline: Milken and S.&L. Executives Sued
abstract: Federal banking regulators yesterday filed a $6 billion suit yesterday against Michael R. Milken and a number of well-known former executives with savings and loans contending that they had participated in a fraudulent scheme that led to huge losses at the institutions from their "junk bond" investments.    The savings executives named in the suit include Charles H. Keating Jr. of Lincoln Savings and Loan, David L. Paul of Centrust and Thomas P. Spiegel of Columbia Savings. Primarily as a result of junk bond losses, each of their institutions was financially hobbled, and both Lincoln and Centrust have been seized by Federal regulators.

headline: Tungsram's Track Record in Research
abstract: To the Editor:   Regarding "Running on Fast-Forward in Budapest," Dec. 16, which described the joint venture between General Electric and Tungsram, a Hungarian firm specializing in electric lighting, it may be of interest that, between the two World Wars, Tungsram created, in addition to its manufacturing facilities, one of the strongest research laboratories in Europe.   The discoveries made and developed in this lab were patented by Tungsram and are the basis of its leading position in the industrial world. One of these discoveries by the distinguished physicist Imre Brody was the krypton incandescent lamp. (His great contributions did not save Mr. Brody and his family from being murdered by Nazis in 1944.)   After the war, Tungsram continued its high-quality basic and applied industrial research. Apparently there are organizations that not even Communism can destroy. PETER D. LAX  New York, N.Y., Dec. 22

headline: Patents; A Treatment To Reverse Osteoporosis
abstract: A gynecologist in Massachusetts obtained a patent this week on a treatment program using hormones that he said appeared to reverse the bone-weakening condition known as osteoporosis, which primarily affects elderly women.    More than 15 million American women are afflicted with osteoporosis, which makes them vulnerable to curvature of the spine and fractures.

headline: 'Baby Bells' Wait; Hope Judge Relents
abstract: It was probably inevitable that regional Bell telephone companies would come to loggerheads with Federal District Court Judge Harold H. Greene. But the official end of the honeymoon probably dates back to Jan. 13, 1986. Two years had passed since the judge had presided over the court-ordered breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and he had become increasingly suspicious that the new "Baby Bells" were ignoring ordinary telephone customers to rush into new lines of business.    "The disdain shown by some of the regional companies for their telephone obligations is as inexplicable as it is disconcerting," he wrote in a blistering opinion. "A.T.&T. was imbued with a service mentality. By contrast, the regional companies, or some of them . . . indicate that an ascent into the ranks of conglomerate America rates far higher on their list of priorities than the provision of the best and least costly local telephone service."

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Israel; Mideast Pact: Israelis' View
abstract: On four crucial points, almost everyone in the Israeli political establishment seems to agree:    Never has there been a more opportune time for Israel to make peace with its Arab neighbors.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Columbia Pictures Television, Burbank, Calif., has named Alan Daniels vice president, creative services. * KCAL-TV, Hollywood, a subsidiary of Walt Disney Studios, has named David J. Woodcock president and general manager.

headline: Eastern Air Admits to Conspiracy
abstract: Eastern Airlines, under a plea-bargaining agreement, has admitted that it conspired to prevent the Federal Aviation Administration from determining if its employees and managers were falsifying maintenance records and will pay $3.5 million in fines.    The agreement was made between Andrew J. Maloney, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, and Martin R. Shugrue Jr., the trustee for Eastern. The airline could have faced $26.5 million in fines if Mr. Maloney's office had insisted that it plead guilty to all 53 counts in an indictment.  'A Factual Basis'     In one of the most damaging parts of the agreement, Eastern admitted "that a factual basis for its guilty plea exists and will not disclaim its participation in the charges."

headline: Pump-Priming Pail Is Dry As U.S. Budget Comes Up
abstract: In the textbook world, a primary tool to fight recession is an expanding Federal budget deficit. Extra Government stimulus, the theory goes, will make up for diminished spending in the private sector and thereby soften the economic downturn.    Even before the outbreak of war, the reality did not match the ideal, and the conflict in the Persian Gulf is not expected to bring the two any closer. By contrast to the industrial mobilization for World War II, which pulled the nation out of the Great Depression, this conflict is backed by a well-stocked military inventory.

headline: Swiss Weigh Secrecy Shift
abstract: Switzerland is proposing to ease strict rules on banking secrecy to crack down on money laundering and iron out loopholes in existing legislation, the Justice Ministry said Friday.   Under the proposed package, financial sector workers will not be charged with infringing banking secrecy if they report suspicious financial transactions. At present workers are in a double bind. Failure to report illegal transactions can lead to charges of money laundering; reporting them can be an infringement of banking secrecy.   Switzerland outlawed money laundering in August. Before that, laundering was illegal only if profits were recycled into drug trafficking.   The Parliament is expected to debate the package in July.

headline: Taking a Break From Compaq
abstract: The Compaq Computer Corporation, which is based in Houston, said yesterday that Michael S. Swavely, its president for North America, was taking a six-month sabbatical.    Mr. Swavely's move, which is for personal reasons, has prompted a management reorganization under which Eckhard Pfeiffer, the company's president for Europe and international, has been named executive vice president and chief operating officer, with responsibility for the company's operations on a worldwide basis. Mr. Pfeiffer, who is 48 years old, will be relocating from Munich to Houston.    Rod Canion, Compaq's president and chief executive, said that the 37-year-old Mr. Swavely's decision had come as a surprise and that there had been no decision regarding what position he would have on his return. "We have no plan at this point for what Mike would come back to," he said. "In our business, six months is an eternity."    In the reorganization, Mr. Pfeiffer will take on some of Mr. Canion's day-to-day operating responsibilities, leaving him more time to devote to strategy. Ben Rosen of the venture capital firm Sevin Rosen continues as Compaq's chairman.

headline: Fur Industry Shrinking With No End in Sight
abstract: These are bitter times for those involved in trapping, dressing, making and selling furs. In a harshly symbolic blow to the industry, the Hudson's Bay Company of Canada announced recently that it was closing the last fur salons in its Bay department stores.    The company, which was synonymous with fur for centuries after it was founded in 1670 to pursue the trade under a royal charter, had been confronted by the relentless campaigning of animal rights advocates and plunging demand that began with the 1987 stock market crash.

headline: Cramer-Krasselt Office Is Moen's New Agency
abstract: Moen Inc., a maker of faucets and other plumbing products, has given its advertising account to the Chicago office of Cramer-Krasselt.   The account, which is worth between $4 million and $5 million, was previously held by Griswold Inc., a Cleveland agency. Cramer-Crasselt also handles advertising for Master locks, which like Moen is part of Masterbrand Industries. Masterbrand is a subsidiary of American Brands Inc. of Old Greenwich, Conn.   "Griswold served us very well," said Robert Moorman, Moen's manager for marketing services. "We just felt at this point in time that we were looking for a little more synergy within the Masterbrand companies. We're trying to get a new strategic viewpoint."

headline: Economic Scene; Pink Slips, Budget Blues
abstract: FORECASTERS who have been counting on the recession to melt away with the sunny news from the Persian Gulf got a rude surprise from the Labor Department on Friday. Unemployment reached 6.5 percent in February, the highest rate in four years and a sobering three-tenths of a percentage point higher than a month earlier.    The prospect of a slow recovery is likely to focus attention on a subject that almost everyone in Washington would like to ignore: unemployment benefits. For while there is wide agreement that the safety net for jobless workers has been weakened in the last decade, a fix would cost money.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   9.50   9.50   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.50   6.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   6.25   6.00   8.18        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.14   6.05   7.68        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.21   6.17   7.54        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.93   7.91   8.18        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   8.24   8.20   8.25        TELEPHONE BONDS   9.46   9.45   9.31        MUNICIPAL BONDS*   7.44   7.44   7.31       *Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Square D Rejects Schneider Offer
abstract: The Square D Company said today that its board had unanimously rejected an unsolicited takeover offer from Groupe Schneider S.A.    Square D had advised its shareholders last week not to tender their shares to Schneider, which is based in Paris. The French manufacturer of fuse boxes had begun a $78-a-share tender offer for Square D last Monday. The action taken today represents a formal rejection of the $1.98 billion offer, a Square D spokeswoman said.

headline: Flights to the Middle East Are Limited and Uncertain
abstract: Airline travel to the Middle East, especially to and from cities like Tel Aviv; Amman, Jordan, and Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, has become limited and uncertain as most of the world's leading carriers have canceled flights to the region.   "It's a day-to-day, touch-and-go" situation, said Kerstin Sabene, a spokeswoman for Lufthansa, the German airline, which has several flights to the Middle East.

headline: Japan Acts to Ease Rice Rift
abstract: Japanese officials will visit the United States this week to try to soothe American anger over the Japanese ban on rice imports.    Agriculture Ministry officials said today that the Japanese representatives would meet in Washington with American Government and agriculture industry representatives.

headline: Bush's Remark's After Congress Authorized War
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference today after the vote in Congress authorizing him to use military force in the Persian Gulf, as recorded by The Associated Press:               OPENING STATEMENT

headline: Evidence of Cash Problems Mounting at Carter Hawley
abstract: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the largest department store operator on the West Coast, said this evening that efforts to improve its financial future had fallen through, including a plan to sell its credit-card receivables.    While the company said it had other financing talks under way, the announcement appeared to indicate that another big department store chain had run into serious financial difficulty. On Monday, Hills Department Stores Inc., the nation's fifth-largest discount store chain, filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors.

headline: U.S. Insurers Expecting Small Loss in Gulf War
abstract: Insurance company executives in the United States predict their losses will be small now that war has erupted in the Persian Gulf.    The executives say that in recent years the business of insuring buildings and equipment in the Middle East has been largely left to European underwriters, a few local insurers and the individuals who together make up Lloyd's of London.

headline: Money Managers Fell Behind the Indexes in 1990
abstract: Private money managers performed even worse than the broad market indexes last year. The year ended with Standard & Poor's index of 500 major stocks falling 6.6 percent (before dividends) and the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 4.3 percent, the worst performance since 1981. Most money managers would have done better last year if they had bought Treasury bills.    CDA Investment Technologies Inc., which bases its calculations on money managers' filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said that of the 474 managers who filed reports, the average portfolio value fell 6.1 percent in 1990, including dividends but not counting management fees or expenses.

headline: Prices of Treasuries Drop Sharply
abstract: A big jump in the price of oil and other commodities -- a byproduct of a weekend of growing tensions over the Middle East -- hurt the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities fell sharply and interest rates rose.    The decline, the second in succession, left bond yields more than 20 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, above their level late Thursday.

headline: Walesa Urges 'Instant' Elections for Poland
abstract: President Lech Walesa urged Parliament today to dissolve itself and make way for immediate elections to complete Poland's transition to democracy.   He said the public was losing confidence in the present Assembly, dominated by ex-Communists and their former allies. New elections are not required until mid-1993.

headline: Currents, Not Man, Will Decide the Spill's Effects
abstract: With oil from Kuwaiti spigots within 100 miles of reaching Saudi Arabia's main desalting plant, experts say that human efforts are no match for the tide of oil and that the plant's fate depends mostly on currents.    Like an avalanche against a fence, the leading edge of the oil will brush aside containment booms and overwhelm boats that skim up oil if currents send large quantities their way. Trying to filter oil that evades the booms is not feasible because the plant gulps far too much water -- three billion gallons daily, twice as much water as New York City consumes. And the desalting process itself cannot separate oil from water.

headline: S.E.C. Inquiry Is Reported On Loans to Accountants
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether several partners at Arthur Young improperly borrowed money for personal real estate investments from a large Texas bank that they had pronounced financially sound, according to lawyers and government officials. The bank later failed, and became one of the nation's most costly bailouts.   The investigation is apparently one of several being conducted by the S.E.C. to determine whether the independence of bank auditors was breached because the partners borrowed money from a bank that their firm regularly audited. The S.E.C. is the final arbiter of all rules governing the way the nation's accountants handle the publicly traded companies that hire them.

headline: Chairman and Chief Quits at Fred Meyer
abstract: Frederick M. Stevens has resigned as chairman and chief executive of Fred Meyer Inc., the retail chain based in the Pacific Northwest.   Mr. Stevens, who is 54 years old, was not available yesterday for an interview, a company spokeswoman said. She said she could provide no details beyond a news release issued on Friday.

headline: Greek Military Airplane Lost In Storm With 66 on Board
abstract: A large-scale search by air and sea today failed to locate a Greek Air Force C-130 military transport plane a day after it went down in stormy weather in a rugged eastern mountainous region. Sixty-six members of the military were aboard.   Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis said the authorities were "investigating all possibilities, including that of terrorist sabotage." He alluded to the November 17 terrorist organization, which has already conducted several bombing attacks against American, British and French interests in protest over the Persian Gulf war. Greece is also making a small contribution to the multinational force blockading Iraq.   But most officials ruled out the possibility of terrorist sabotage and said indications so far pointed to an accident.

headline: New President At Travelers
abstract: Richard H. Booth, widely viewed as the heir apparent to Edward H. Budd, chairman and chief executive at the Travelers Corporation, was named president and chief operating officer today at the troubled insurance giant.   Mr. Booth, who is 43 years old, has been the company's vice chairman and chief insurance officer since 1989. Mr. Budd, 57, has held the post of president since 1985, along with his other titles of chairman and chief executive officer.   The position of chief operating officer has been vacant for several years.

headline: Germany's Top Banker Gives Europe a Warning
abstract: In a blunt warning, the head of Germany's central bank said today that German monetary union was a disaster that should serve as a "drastic illustration" of mistakes the European Community must avoid as it moves toward a single currency and a European central bank.   The rebuke by Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the Bundesbank, was his most forceful yet of French and British proposals for monetary union within the European Community. The Bundesbank says the move toward a single European currency and a common central bank is premature.

headline: London Journal; A 2d Tunnel Project: Less Glamour, More Water
abstract: What will be longer than the English Channel tunnel, deeper than the London Underground railroad and will insure that there are not a lot of thirsty, smelly Londoners in the 21st century?    The answer is the London Water Ring Main, a 50-mile tunnel being dug deep beneath metropolitan London. It is the biggest water project here since the Victorians built the sewers after the Great Stink of 1858.

headline: Pinochet Assails Chilean Rights Report
abstract: Gen. Augusto Pinochet issued a sweeping criticism today of a Government human rights report released earlier this month that catalogued the killing or disappearances of more than 2,000 people in Chile during his 17-year military government.    Addressing an assembly of his top military commanders, General Pinochet denounced the report as a one-sided assessment of events in Chile after the September 1973 coup, and said it was written by people unqualified to judge the actions of the Chilean Army.

headline: Dow Soars in Heavy Trading to Gain 41.59
abstract: Stocks rose strongly yesterday in hectic trading, with the Dow Jones industrials and other leading averages scoring new highs for the year. One of the nation's most influential Wall Street investment houses said the six-month bear market had ended.    "I think the bear market is over," Steven G. Einhorn, a partner and co-chairman of the investment policy committee of Goldman, Sachs & Company, said in an interview. Only a week ago, Mr. Einhorn had said, "The bear is still growling, but more softly."

headline: Palestinians and Israel Renew Lebanon Clash
abstract: Palestinian guerrillas and Israeli forces battled with howitzers and rockets in southern Lebanon today in the fourth day of what one television station called "the new front in the gulf war."   The police said there was no word of casualties in the fighting around the Palestinian-held hills and Israel's self-proclaimed security zone, an occupied strip running along the Israel-Lebanon border.

headline: In Distressed Poland, a Success Story
abstract: For most Polish enterprises, the nation's headlong plunge from Communism to capitalism has produced a story of woe: They have been slow to adapt to consumer desires, their production has plummeted and hundreds of companies are near bankruptcy.    Out of this traumatized landscape a few star performers have emerged, and one of them is Dresso, a state-owned sportswear manufacturer that can serve as a model for other Polish and Eastern European enterprises.

headline: Your Money; Company Loyalty: A Potential Risk
abstract: The humbling of once-proud companies like Pan American World Airways and the Bank of New England has cracked the nest eggs of many of their loyal executives and employees who hold company stock, and it suggests a warning for others across America.    Do not tie up a disproportionate amount of personal assets in the employer's stock, experts say.

headline: Weather in the Gulf
abstract: High clouds will thicken across northern Saudi Arabia, southern Iraq and Kuwait. A few showers will develop near the Red Sea. The Mediterranean Coast will be clear with offshore winds. Winds form the north will strengthen over the Persian Gulf with gusty winds in Iraq. Temperatures: Baghdad: high 55, low 36; Riyadh, high 68, low 45; Dhahran, high 66, low 47.

headline: Westchester Housing; Project in Dobbs Ferry for Firemen
abstract: With a plan that may become a model for other communities, the Westchester village of Dobbs Ferry will begin work this spring on an affordable housing project designed to attract badly needed volunteer firefighters to the area.   Called the Firemen's Cooperative, the development will consist of 32 town houses built on land owned by the Livingston Hose Recreation Company, one of Dobbs Ferry's three fire companies. Construction will begin in April.

headline: Airline Woes May Damage Pension Unit
abstract: The airline industry's crumbling finances, highlighted by Continental's announcement on Thursday of a $2.25 billion fourth-quarter loss, have become the top concern of the Federal pension insurance agency, the head of the agency said yesterday.    The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, which insures the private pension plans of 40 million Americans, faces more than $1 billion in potential losses if failing airlines like Continental and Pan American do not recover, said James B. Lockhart 3d, the organization's executive director.

headline: First Fidelity Buys Branches in Jersey
abstract: The First Fidelity Bankcorporation, the largest banking company in New Jersey, announced yesterday that it had acquired 48 branches and $2.5 billion of deposits from the City Federal Savings Bank, a failed bank that has been operating under Government control. The branches, in Union, Middlesex, Ocean, Morris, Essex and Somerset counties, have about 430,000 accounts and will open for business on Monday. First Fidelity, which paid $21 million for the deposits, bought nine City Federal branches with $468 million of deposits in September.    Eleven branches of City Federal with $344 million of deposits were sold to four smaller New Jersey banks, while no acceptable bids were received for seven branches.

headline: London Journal; Sipping in a Snowdrift: Numb Britons Carry On
abstract: For two days now, this city has been surrendered to winter, besieged by the kind of cold, snowy weather more common to Chicago than England.   Judges have closed their courts, soccer teams have abandoned their pitches and police officers patrolling snow-covered highways have resorted to the most British of emergency measures, carrying hot urns of tea to sustain stranded motorists.

headline: Goodyear to Cut 1,100 Jobs and Take $65 Million Charge
abstract: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, rocked by increasingly sluggish sales for tires, said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,100 salaried jobs over the next 12 to 18 months. The giant tire company also said it would take a $65 million pretax charge against first-quarter earnings for the cost of the work force reduction.    The Akron-based tire maker has eliminated thousands of salaried and hourly positions in the last two years, slashing its work force by about 9 percent in that period. The cuts announced yesterday represent about 1 percent of the work force and will bring the total number of workers down to 102,000.

headline: Shares of L.A. Gear Drop on News of Loss
abstract: Shares of L.A. Gear Inc. tumbled 21.5 percent today, the worst performance on the New York Stock Exchange, after the company said it expected to lose $4 million to $6 million in the fourth quarter.   The stock closed down $2.875, at $10.50, on volume of 1.6 million shares. It was the third-most-active stock on the Big Board.

headline: White House Sticks to Its Subdued Reaction to Baltic Crackdown
abstract: Moving cautiously in response to the Soviet military action in Lithuania, Bush Administration officials said today that the White House was reluctant to take stringent economic or political measures against Moscow.    Instead, officials said the Administration was weighing some mild punitive actions, like temporarily suspending technical exchanges.

headline: People
abstract: * Alison Lowy has been named a vice president at Waring & LaRosa Inc., New York. * Robin Koval has been named an executive vice president of Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson Inc., New York.

headline: Unrest in Iraq Reported to Spread From Basra to Three Other Cities
abstract: Official Iranian and Syrian reports and the accounts of travelers from Iraq today reinforced Western intelligence assessments that civil commotion and possible anti-Government unrest in Iraq had spread from the southern city of Basra to a string of other towns in southeastern Iraq.    Reuters quoted travelers arriving at the Iraq-Kuwait border as saying that Government forces in Basra were facing a Shiite Muslim uprising led by supporters of a Teheran-based cleric and longstanding adversary of President Saddam Hussein, Mohammed Bakr al-Hakim.

headline: Building of New Stores Expected to Slow
abstract: Construction of new stores and shopping malls will be considerably slowed over the next five years because of the difficulty in obtaining financing as banks become increasingly cautious, speakers told the annual convention of the National Retail Federation yesterday.   "Banks are practically out of the lending market as far as new malls are concerned," said Melvin Simon, the chairman of Melvin Simon & Associates, one of the nation's largest mall builders. "They want so much equity and so many other things for their loans that I see a real slowdown of new construction."

headline: Bundesbank Lifts 2 Key Interest Rates
abstract: Germany's central bank raised two leading interest rates today in a surprise move that is likely to slow global economic growth and further strain the country's relations with its main European trading partners.   While higher interest rates were expected soon, no action was foreseen today. Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the central bank, the Bundesbank, said earlier this week that international political conditions were not right for such a move.

headline: A Retraction By Pioneer
abstract: The Pioneer Electronic Corporation, a leading Japanese audio products maker, has retracted its report that Paramount Communications Inc. approached it with an offer to sell the Paramount motion picture division.    A Pioneer spokesman had said on Monday that the American company had contacted Pioneer last year with a preliminary offer and that Pioneer had declined it. In the United States, Nick Ashooh, vice president for corporate communications at Paramount, vigorously denied the account.   On Tuesday, Toru Yokomizo, a Pioneer spokesman, said Paramount had not sounded out Pioneer about buying its motion picture division. Asked about the Monday report, he said, "There were misunderstandings."   The Japanese economic newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported earlier that Paramount had asked several Japanese companies, including the Sumitomo Corporation and Pioneer, whether they would be interested in buying Paramount Pictures.   Paramount denied the Nihon Keizai report. Sumitomo and other companies said there had been no contact.

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: Assets of the nation's 546 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.93 billion, to $471.25 billion, in the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 191 institutional funds decreased by $793.3 million, to $132.32 billion. The assets of the 265 general-purpose funds were down by $1.05 billion, to $182.16 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds decreased by $149.3 million, to $156.77 billion, the institute said.

headline: Germany Stands Alone on Rates
abstract: The German central bank's surprising decision to increase interest rates last month has raised new questions about Germany's commitment to international cooperation in general and to Western Europe's goals of economic integration and monetary union in particular.    In the week after Jan. 31, when the central bank, the Bundesbank, raised two important rates by half a percentage point each, the dollar fell to new lows against the mark.

headline: A Fragrance for Elvis, And $5 Million for Ads
abstract: Just when you thought Elvis could not be exploited another inch, along comes a fragrance named after him. And where there's a fragrance, there's promotion.   I. Goldberg & Partners, New York, is beginning a $5 million campaign that includes national television spots and a print series that will run in many women's magazines. The spots juxtapose Elvis with all the American Presidents with the theme line "America has had 41 Presidents but only one king. Elvis, for all the King's men." "We are trying to appeal to a memory," said Irwin Goldberg, the agency's chief creative officer and president. "There is a resurgence in the 50's and 60's, and we thought it was appropriate to have a fragrance dedicated to him."

headline: Tax-Exempt Issue Priced by Orlando
abstract: A $235.8 million offering of tax-exempt water and electric subordinated revenue bonds issued by the Orlando, Fla., Utilities Commission wase tentatively priced yesterday to yield a maximum of 6.75 percent for a bond due in 2020.   The lead underwriter, Goldman, Sachs & Company, said the only other bond being offered, which is due in 2026, was priced to yield 6.65 percent.   Underwriters said the issue was rated AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, and that it was expected that Moody's Investors Service would rate the issue Aa.

headline: Treasury Securities Hold Steady
abstract: The Treasury securities market meandered in a narrow price range yesterday after a brief upward movement early in the session. Dealers said bond prices rose about a quarter-point after the opening on hopes of an end to the Persian Gulf war. But there was no follow-through buying and prices retreated to opening levels.    Late in the session, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue maturing in February 2021, were unchanged at 97 30/32, as was the yield of 8.06 percent, a bit below its three-week high of 8.07 percent. A week ago the long bond's yield was 7.97 percent. The long notes, the 7.75 percent issue due February 2001, were unchanged at 99, as was the yield of 7.89 percent.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Iraq; Iraqis Hail Cease-Fire With a Hail of Bullets
abstract: Iraqis had a day free of bombing today for the first time in six weeks and began to look ahead to postwar life in their devastated country.   They awoke after a night punctuated by the crackle of celebratory gunfire instead of wailing air raid sirens that had marked nearly every night since the allied air attacks began in January.

headline: Bidermann Industries Has a New President
abstract: Bidermann International S.A., a big clothing maker based in Paris, has named Alfred F. Fuoco president and chief executive of its United States subsidiary, the Bidermann Industries Corporation -- the largest apparel manufacturer in North America.    Mr. Fuoco, who is 47 years old, succeeds Guido Petruzzi, 59, who has left the company, a spokesman said yesterday.

headline: ALLIED UNITS SURGE THROUGH KUWAIT; TROOPS CONFRONT ELITE FORCE IN IRAQ; BUSH SPURNS HUSSEIN'S PULLOUT MOVE American and British Troops Gird for an Iraqi Last Stand
abstract: Iraqi troops were in headlong retreat across most of Kuwait this morning, the American command said, and allied forces entered Kuwait City, a smoking wreck, after its Iraqi occupiers fled the capital of the nation they conquered on Aug. 2.   The vanguard of allied armored columns in Iraq punched through to the Euphrates River, cutting a main line of retreat for the elite Republican Guards, officials reported. Powerful American and British armored forces farther south, near the Iraqi frontier with Kuwait, girded for a battle with Guard tank units if they chose to make a last stand.

headline: U.S. Wants Technology Trade Curb
abstract: The United States is circulating to its allies and to American businesses proposed restrictions on exporting chemical and biological material and missile technologies to third world countries.    The proposals reflect a fear that nuclear and chemical weapons and missiles could proliferate in the third world. Such fears have been heightened by the prospect that Iraq would use poison gas in the Persian Gulf war.

headline: South Africa Moves to Scrap Apartheid
abstract: President F. W. de Klerk moved today to smash the legal bedrock of apartheid by announcing that he would scrap the remaining laws on which South Africa's ideology of racial discrimination has long rested.    In a speech opening the 1991 session of Parliament, Mr. de Klerk said legislation would soon be introduced to repeal the Land Acts of 1913 and 1936, which reserved most of the country's land for the white minority, the Group Areas Act of 1966, and the Black Communities Act of 1984, which entrenched the separate status of black townships.    In appealing for the revocation of racial laws, now considered to be virtually certain, Mr. de Klerk went beyond what had been expected by also mentioning the Population Registration Act, which classifies all South Africans into four racial groups: blacks, whites, people of mixed race and Asians. Reversing an earlier Government position, he said that the law, entrenched in the nation's Constitution, would, like the others, be soon eliminated.  Transitional Steps Proposed     He said this could be done through the enactment of what he described as "temporary, transitional measures" needed to maintain the present Constitution until a new one can be negotiated and drafted.    "Should Parliament adopt the Government's proposals," Mr. de Klerk said, "the South African statute book will be devoid, within months, of the remnants of racially discriminatory legislation which have become known as the cornerstones of apartheid."  [ Excerpts from the speech, page 7. ]   In Washington, the State Department welcomed the proposals as "dramatic and far-reaching," but noted that all political prisoners had yet to be released, as required under United States laws governing the lifting of sanctions. Further Momentum     The speech by Mr. de Klerk today lent further momentum to a process that the President began at the opening of Parliament last year, when the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid organizations were legalized and Mr. de Klerk announced his Government's intention to release the congress's leader, Nelson Mandela. Mr. Mandela walked out of a prison farm nine days later.    "In the short span of a single year," Mr. de Klerk said today, "substantial progress was made. The Government is determined to build on the foundations laid purposefully, efficiently and with due speed.    "South Africa cannot allow or permit the dynamic process of reform to slow down," he told Parliament.    As he spoke, the African National Congress, conducted mass marches in Cape Town, Johannesburg, Pretoria and some other cities to put pressure on the Government in advance of looming but as yet undefined Constitutinal talks. The anti-apartheid group also sought to underscore the reality that blacks remain excluded from Parliament and from institutional political life.    In Cape Town, Walter Sisulu, a senior leader of the congress, addressed a crowd of perhaps 15,000 people who had gathered outside City Hall.  Insists on Right to Vote     "We still do not have the vote, and this is what our people want today," Mr. Sisulu said. He added that the scrapping of the apartheid laws must be followed by "measures to retrieve the damage they have done."    Mr. de Klerk reiterated his opposition to an elected constituent assembly to draft a new constitution and an interim government, something that the African National Congress has demanded.    "The idea that the present, legally constituted Government should relinquish its powers and simply hand over its responsibilities to some or other temporary regime cannot be considered in a sovereign, independent state," Mr. de Klerk said.    But he suggested that the Government might share some of its authority with the congress and with other groups outside the parliamentary process, once the transition to nonracial democracy was under way.    "Consideration may be given to certain transitional arrangements on the various legislative and executive levels to give the leaders of the negotiating parties a voice in the formulation of important policy decisions," Mr. de Klerk said.   Entrenched Inequality     While the elimination of the remaining racial laws will likely signal the demise of apartheid as a legal system, the disparities, inequality and hostility that have divided black and white South Africans under the apartheid system are unlikely to be erased as categorically.    Though public facilities like libraries and community swimming pools were legally integrated in October, many of these remain unused by blacks. Similar recent laws enabling some formerly white schools to accept black pupils when more than 72 per cent of the parents approved have so far to led the integration of 205 schools, a small number nationwide, with generally few black children admitted at each school.   Once the laws cited today are repealed, a black South African will legally be able to live in a white neighborhood and buy land previously set aside for whites. In practice, though, few blacks can afford it. The Government has not said that it will return land confiscated from dispossessed blacks, with little or no compensation, in the last four decades.    Some lingering resistance to change was evident in Parliament, where legislators of the right-wing Conservative Party, the official opposition, angrily walked out during Mr. de Klerk's hourlong speech. The Conservative Party leader, Andries P. Treurnicht, said later that Mr. de Klerk's plans to scrap the apartheid laws struck at the roots of white community life.    "It is surprising that South Africa now has the only leader in the Western world who is negotiating himself, his party and his people out of power," Mr. Treurnicht said.  White Liberals Gratified     However, Zach de Beer, the leader of the liberal Democratic Party, observed that President de Klerk had promised to repeal the Group Areas and Land Acts. But, Dr. de Beer said, "most of us did not expect that the Population Registration Act would go this year, and we're pleased."    The Government had said that the Population Registration Act would have to remain in force until a new constitution extending political rights to the black majority was adopted.    But President de Klerk said today that "following investigation, it would, in fact, appear possible to repeal this act, provided that this is accompanied by the adoption of temporary transitional measures toward the acceptance of a new constitution."    The total elimination of existing racial distinctions would throw into question the legitimacy of Parliament, which now has separate chambers for white, mixed-race and Asian legislators, though none for blacks. Mr. de Klerk was proposing, among other things, keeping Parliament, and by extension his Government, intact through temporary legal provisions in place of the Population Registration Act.    Gerrit N. Viljoen, the Minister for Constitutional Development, told foreign journalists that the racial classification of all new babies or immigrants would end the day the Population Registration Act was repealed. He suggested that the racial classification of other South Africans, while still on the registration books, would quickly fall into disuse.   The President is not expected to have difficulty enacting his proposed reforms because his National Party and the liberal Democratic Party control close to three-quarters of the seats in the white House of Assembly. The leaders of the Democratic Party have consistently sought discussions with the nation's black majority, and in recent years, Mr. de Klerk has convinced many in his own party that such dialogue is inevitable.  End of Emergency Rule     Since he committed himself and his Government to fundamental change, Mr. de Klerk has repealed the Separate Amenities Act, which let municipalities reserve public services for whites, has opened hospitals to all races, among other changes, and has ended a national state of rule by emergency decree, which restricted political activity.    Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said that the measures announced today were not aimed at eliminating the economic and other sanctions imposed by Western nations, including the United States.    "What is happening today is confirming President de Klerk's clear statement that the process toward the dismantling of apartheid and fundamental change in South Africa is irreversible," Mr. Botha said.  Tutu Now Doubts Sanctions     The Anglican Archbishop, Desmond M. Tutu, who attended the African National Congress march, told reporters there that President de Klerk's speech made it hard to dispute his seriousness about dismantling apartheid.    "We are getting very near to where it will be irreversible," said Archbishop Tutu, a prominent proponent of economic sanctions. "It is going to be very difficult for us to continue to ask for sanctions."   The Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act enacted by the United States Congress in 1986 provided that sanctions would end once the Pretoria Government released Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners, repealed rule by decree, legalized banned political parties and unfettered political activity, repealed the Group Areas and Population Registration Acts, and agreed to enter into good-faith negotiations with representatives of the black majority.    It further permits the President to suspend or modify sanctions once three of the last four conditions were achieved.    The President told Parliament that the constitutional reform he envisionedd had to be accompanied by economic growth to give blacks real equality. "Until the pressing problems of poverty and unemployment are alleviated," he said, "constitutional models will be of little avail to us."               --------------------          U.S. Praise and Pressure     WASHINGTON (AP) -- The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler today called President de Klerk's proposals "dramatic and far-reaching." But she said that South Africa has yet to release all political prisoners or people detained without trial.   Current American sanctions ban new investment in South Africa; the import of South African arms, iron, steel, gold coins and farm products, and also bar South African Airways flights. They also restrict banking activities.                --------------------          Europeans Encouraged     BRUSSELS, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The European Community's executive body said today that Mr. de Klerk's plans to repeal South Africa's major apartheid laws could lead to a softening of sanctions against the country.   "The enforcement of these initiatives will allow the community" to discuss softening the economic sanctions imposed in 1986, said the community's External Relations Commissioner, Frans Andriessen.

headline: Midlantic Lays Off 120 in New Jersey
abstract: Midlantic National Bank of Newark has laid off 120 employees to save about $2 million a year. The chairman of the Midlantic Corporation, Robert Van Buren, said the layoffs were the latest cost-cutting effort by the financial company, which reported a net loss of $195 million last year.   The cuts reduce to 4,300 the work force of Midlantic National, the flagship bank of the Edison-based Midlantic Corporation, a bank spokeswoman, Dorothy Hinchcliff, said.Most of the layoffs came from middle management and clerical positions that were not needed after the bank sold some operations. In recent months Midlantic National has sold credit card operations, leasing agreements and home equity loan portfolios to trim operations.

headline: Federal Regulators Tell New England Governors of Plans to Help Banks
abstract: Federal banking regulators told a meeting of New England governors, bankers and business executives today that new accounting rules to benefit banks would be announced within a week.   L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, also told those attending the New England Governors Conference here that he was considering helping banks by making direct investments of F.D.I.C. capital.

headline: Bad Loans Take Toll At Banks
abstract: Three large New York banking companies -- Citicorp, Manufacturers Hanover and Chemical -- announced poor quarterly results yesterday, reflecting losses on loans for real estate projects and some corporate takeovers. The losses overshadowed the benefits of falling interest rates and cuts in their work forces. Manufacturers Hanover also said it was cutting its dividend.    In California, Wells Fargo said its profits fell slightly from a year ago, because of the costs of acquiring failed savings associations, and an increase in troubled real estate loans. Security Pacific announced a large loss for the quarter, while First Interstate posted a profit.

headline: Britain Frees 32 Iraqis
abstract: Britain today freed 32 Iraqi men whom it had held as prisoners of war at a military camp near Salisbury, the Defense Ministry said today.   But the Home Office said Britain would not free 33 other Arabs -- 31 Iraqis and two Palestinians -- who had been served deportation notices as possible threats to domestic security and jailed since the war with Iraq began Jan. 17. Most of them are appealing deportation.

headline: A.T.&T. Inquiry Barred by F.C.C.
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission denied a request by the NCR Corporation that it investigate the $6.1 billion hostile takeover bid by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. It also denied a request that it bar A.T.&T.'s reliance on the credit and earning power of its regulated phone operations to finance the takeover.   The F.C.C. said, "Nothing in the record provided a basis for the commission to conclude that the acquisition posed a real threat to the viability of A.T.&T.'s provision" of long-distance telephone services. A.T.&T., the nation's largest long-distance company, began a $90-a-share hostile takeover bid for NCR after it was rebuffed last December by the computer company's board. A.T.&T. has since said it will raise the offer to $100 a share if it can replace all 12 NCR board members at a shareholders meeting next Thursday.

headline: Ruling on the Hell Fighters
abstract: A Pentagon investigation into allegations of mistreatment by members of a Harlem-based National Guard unit in Saudi Arabia has found no cause for action, a New York Congressman says.   The lawmaker, Representative Charles B. Rangel, said on Wednesday that the unit, the 369th Transport Battalion, "did the country proud" in the Persian Gulf war.

headline: Commercial Jet Sales Spur Sharp Gain in Boeing's Net
abstract: Aided by continued strong sales of its commercial jets, the Boeing Company reported a fourfold increase in earnings and a sharp rise in sales for the fourth quarter.   Despite the gains, though, Boeing shares fell $2.25 today, to $46.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said that while strong, the results fell at the low end of Wall Street estimates. There was also concern that the Persian Gulf war would weaken the world's airlines, resulting in lost sales or canceled orders for Boeing.

headline: Top Contender For Levine Post
abstract: Just two weeks after the unexpected departure of Robert Schmidt, the former chairman and chief executive of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, the New York agency is close to picking his replacement.    Harold Levine, the co- founder and acting chairman of the agency, said he had talked to a number of candidates for the post. He confirmed rumors that a leading contender is Andrew Langer, chief executive of the Lowe Group.    Mr. Langer would not comment on any discussions.    Some industry executives said Mr. Langer was a logical choice. As head of the Lowe Group, he has pumped life into an agency that had stagnated, helping it to win the $60 million Prudential Insurance Company of America account. The New York agency has billings of about $400 million.    In addition, he is a highly regarded creative executive, having helped to create, for example, the "Thank you, Paine Webber" campaign.    Mr. Levine said that the agency wanted to move quickly in finding a new chairman and that there would be a decision by the end of the month.    The agency is reportedly wasting no time in picking Mr. Schmidt's replacement, because it wants to make sure a leading client, Subaru, does not jump ship. Mr. Schmidt had close ties to Subaru.    Levine Huntley has every reason to worry. Madison Avenue is in a slump, and after Mr. Schmidt resigned, a handful of account-hungry agencies immediately approached Subaru about obtaining the account.

headline: Nutrasweet Cuts Up to 12% of Staff
abstract: The Nutrasweet Company announced layoffs of up to 204 employees in a move that reinforces its plans to stop developing new products for its fat subsitute, Simplesse. A spokesman, Richard L. Nelson, said the layoff of up to 12 percent of Nutrasweet's work force of 1,700 would affect employees at its headquarters in Deerfield, Ill., outside Chicago; the research and development operation in Mount Prospect, Ill., as well as the aspartame plants in University Park, Ill.; Augusta, Ga., and Harbor Beach, Mich.   Nutrasweet, a unit of the Monsanto Company, manufactures aspartame, a low-calorie sweetener marketed under the brand names Nutrasweet and Equal, and Simplesse, which the company uses in its Simple Pleasures line of frozen dairy desserts.

headline: Hussein Visited Troops at Front for New Year, Iraqi TV Says
abstract: Iraqi television tonight broadcast a videotape of what was described as President Saddam Hussein's visit on Monday night to his front-line forces in Kuwait, where he gave them a pep talk, stirred their campfire meals and pronounced them "ready to fight."    The New Year's Eve visit to the front was not announced in advance and the videotape was made public tonight without explanation about the delay. Mr. Hussein was videotaped outdoors meeting with troops bivouacked in the desert. He then delivered remarks indoors to a group of officers described as Iraqi commanders in Kuwait.

headline: Your Money; Personal Finance Perplexes Many
abstract: Many people, even those who are successful in their business or professional lives, have trouble handling personal finances, and last week Citibank co-sponsored a seminar focusing on women who want more control of their finances. Though the topic is certainly of interest to both men and women, a bank spokesman said the focus was put on women in response to numerous customer comments and requests.    "Part of it is childhood conditioning," said Ann B. Diamond, a chartered financial consultant, at the seminar, which was also sponsored by the New York City Commission on the Status of Women. Usually the father took care of money, she said, and few schools taught personal financial management, so many women grew up without thinking about budgeting, investing or setting financial goals. But for women who want to be self-sufficient, it is time to rectify that. Ms. Diamond outlined a simple, common-sense approach.

headline: Brazil Pays Part of Debt
abstract: Brazil paid $300 million today to foreign creditors in an effort to break an impasse over debt payments, the central bank said.   The payment represents 30 percent of the $1 billion in interest the country owes foreign banks on debt due in the first quarter of 1991, a central bank spokesman said.

headline: COLOMBIA ROILED BY GANG BATTLES
abstract: In recent months, Government anti-drug efforts have struck major blows to the Medellin cocaine trafficking ring. But far from helping this city to cope with its problems, the easing of the drug lords' hold has left a dangerous power vacuum in the poorer neighborhoods where more than half of Medellin's 2.5 million people live.    Three top drug bosses have surrendered under a Government promise of lenient treatment, and two cartel leaders died in a police shootout late in January.

headline: Quiet but Uneasy, South Koreans Vote
abstract: For the first time in 30 years, South Koreans will vote on Tuesday for local government officials. But in sharp contrast to the constant political tumult here since military rule ended three years ago, this election is remarkable for what is missing: strikes, huge rallies and tear gas.    Both the governing Democratic Liberal Party, which President Roh Tae Woo created a year ago in a deft merger with two of his biggest political opponents, and the remaining major opposition group, Kim Dae Jung's Party for Peace and Democracy, have spent the last two months trying to explain away a giant bribery case that has embarrassed them all.

headline: Gorbachev Urges Curb on Press Freedom
abstract: Faced with growing condemnation of his administration's weekend assault on unarmed demonstrators in Lithuania, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called today for suspension of a much-hailed law guaranteeing freedom of the press.   Mr. Gorbachev's proposal to the Supreme Soviet flouted the press law's guiding principle that "censorship of mass information is not allowed," and was an attempt to curb the very openness the Soviet leader once encouraged.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Exiles; Worries Dim Hopes as Kuwaiti Exiles Lose Touch With Resistance
abstract: Kuwaitis in exile marked their National Day yesterday with joy over what they see as their country's impending liberation. But there was deepening anxiety over atrocities that they say are taking place there.   At the same time, conflicting, unverifiable reports of human rights abuses and destruction within the Kuwaiti capital prompted confusion and concern. The sense of foreboding was heightened when several Kuwaiti exile groups said they had lost contact with Kuwaitis opposing the Iraqi occupation in Kuwait City.

headline: Another Report On Hussein Kin
abstract: A London newspaper quoted diplomatic figures today as saying that President Saddam Hussein's family has flown to Zambia and is staying in a house owned by President Kenneth Kaunda, who has received large amounts of aid from Iraq.   A spokeswoman for the Zambian Government denied the report.   It was the latest in a series of reports in German, Egyptian and Swiss newspapers, among others, about the whereabouts of the Iraqi President's family since Iraq invaded Kuwait.   The Daily Telegraph quoted unidentified diplomatic figures as saying that Mr. Hussein's wife, Sajida, and his family fled Baghdad shortly after the first allied air attack last week.   The paper said an Air Mauritania flight took them to Nouakchott, the capital of the Islamic state of Mauritania, a former French colony in the Sahara. Then they flew on an Air Zambia plane to Lusaka.   Reports about Mr. Hussein's family began to surface shortly after Iraq seized Kuwait. An Egyptian newspaper said they had sought refuge in Switzerland. A Swiss and a German newspaper also have reported that they were in Switzerland.

headline: After Review, Hardee's Stays With Ogilvy
abstract: OGILVY & MATHER has managed to hang onto the $80 million Hardee's account, winning a creative shootout yesterday against J. Walter Thompson, Chiat/Day/ Mojo and Ayer.    The news came as a surprise to some industry executives. In a creative review, the incumbent usually loses because the client is clearly dissatisfied. Some executives expected the account to go to Thompson, which had once worked for Burger King.

headline: European Nations Plan No Further Peace Efforts
abstract: Frustrated at seeing their diplomatic efforts rebuffed by Baghdad, European Community governments said today that they planned no new last-minute initiative aimed at persuading Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait.   Meeting in emergency session here, community foreign ministers ended 10 days of intense lobbying of Iraq after being briefed on the failed peace mission to Baghdad over the weekend by the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar.

headline: British Chief Assails Hussein, Saying He Is 'Without Pity'
abstract: Prime Minister John Major lashed out today against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, calling him "amoral" and "a man without pity" over Iraq's treatment of allied prisoners of war.    Until now, British leaders have stressed repeatedly that the allies are fighting to liberate Kuwait and not to impose a new government on Iraq or to dismember the country. But their tone has changed markedly since the Iraqis displayed seven battered allied airmen, including two British fliers, on television and announced plans to deploy them as human shields at strategic sites.

headline: France's Maverick Gulf Role
abstract: France, which once had close ties to Iraq, now appears to be trying to rebuild its credibility in the Arab world by taking the lead in European peace efforts. News analysis, page 4.

headline: North Korea Cancels Talks With South
abstract: North Korea called off the next round of high-level talks with South Korea today, blaming what it called military provocation by South Korea and the United States.    The Prime Ministers -- Young Hoon Kang of South Korea and Hyong Muk Yon on North Korea -- had been scheduled to meet in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, next week for their fourth round of talks about easing tensions on the peninsula.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington; New Bill Mandates Sanctions On Makers of Chemical Arms
abstract: The Senate passed legislation on Wednesday night that requires the President to impose sanctions on countries and companies developing or using chemical or biological weapons.    President Bush rejected an almost identical measure last year. But Congress had adjourned by the time he announced his decision and there was no chance to try to override a veto. Mr. Bush said then that he could not accept the bill because it did not give him the authority to waive all sanctions if he thought the national interest required him to.

headline: Compromise Is Seen
abstract: The White House today effectively dropped its insistence that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq meet with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d before Jan. 3. And it signaled Baghdad that if Iraq offered a compromise date before Jan. 12, Washington would most likely accept it.   President Bush initially offered to send Mr. Baker to Baghdad for talks anytime before Jan. 15.
