But, he later modified the proposal and said that Mr. Baker would not go any later than Jan. 3 because the Iraqis might use a later meeting as an excuse that they did not have the time both to see Mr. Baker and still withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15, the United Nations deadline for Iraq to pull out or face eviction by force. Pressure for Talks Grows     But with Congressional and allied pressure for discussions with Baghdad increasing, the White House moved today to extricate itself from this diplomatic bind, one largely of its own making. The President's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, indicated that Mr. Bush would still send Mr. Baker to Baghdad if the Iraqis, who have been insisting on a Jan. 12 meeting, proposed a new date between now and the 12th.

headline: Judge Who Gave Milken 10 Years Wants Him Eligible for Parole in 3
abstract: The judge who sentenced Michael R. Milken to 10 years in prison in November recommended yesterday that the former financier be eligible for parole after serving three years.   The decision, announced by Judge Kimba M. Wood at a hearing in Federal District Court in Manhattan, was the first official indication of the amount of prison time that Mr. Milken, whose pioneering use of "junk bonds" fueled many big corporate takeovers in the 1980's, would likely serve.

headline: Payments Are Missed By T.W.A.
abstract: Trans World Airlines said yesterday that it had defaulted on $75.5 million in payments on various notes. The airline said it wanted to conserve cash in the face of a severe drop in bookings that could last into the summer.   Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of the company, said the action was "imperative for the survival of T.W.A."

headline: U.S.-Canada Air Travel
abstract: Restrictions on air travel between the United States and Canada costs $9.5 billion a year in lost economic activity, according to a study released Tuesday. Liberalizing air travel rules could create up to 210,000 jobs, according to United States Airports for Better International Service, a coalition of 23 American cities, states and airport authorities. The group said limited seat capacity, restricted air routes and poorly situated air transport hubs caused slow growth in air travel between the countries.

headline: Ads for Tums Upset a Rival
abstract: The manufacturer of Mylanta anatacid is the latest corporation to accuse its competitor's comparitive advertising of being unfair and innacurate.   Johnson & Johnson Merck Consumer Pharmaceuticals, which makes Mylanta, filed a lawsuit Friday in Federal District Court in Manhattan against the SmithKline Beecham Corporation, the manufacturer of Tums antacid. The suit said that a Tums television campaign had falsely said that Tums, which contains calcium, was safer and more nutritious than Mylanta, which contains aluminum and magnesium compounds.   "We did consumer surveys to see what message people took from Tums advertising," said Bob Kniffin, a spokesman for the maker of Mylanta, a joint venture of Johnson & Johnson and Merck & Company. "We determined that a significant number of people would be reluctant to take an antacid containing aluminum or magnesium."   Donna Furdis, a spokeswoman for SmithKline, said the campaign provides a "truthful" representation of the two products and does not discuss their safety. "The ad was designed to insure that consumers are informed that Tums is an effective antacid and an excellent source of calcium carbonate," she said.    The lawsuit seeks corrective ads from SmithKline and a court order barring SmithKline from making such claims in future commercials.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Europe; France Says U.S. Bombers Can Now Use Airspace
abstract: France announced tonight that American B-52's based in Britain would be allowed to fly over its territory on bombing raids against Iraq and refuel at a French military base en route from Britain to the Persian Gulf war zone.    A spokesman, Louis Le Pensec, told the French television network La Cinq that the "temporary authorization" would include conditions specifying the type of bombs that can be used by the B-52's and the areas of enemy territory where the bombs can be dropped.

headline: Spread of Cholera Brings Frenzy and Improvisation to Model Lima Hospital
abstract: Hospitals and medical clinics around this capital and along Peru's coast have become the front lines in the battle against the first cholera epidemic in more than 100 years. The epidemic is sorely testing the country's meager medical resources.    Hundreds of patients a day are being carried in limp or unconscious. So far, 100 have died. But most patients have a good chance of surviving, physicians say, because cholera, for all its devastating effects, is a treatable disease if caught early enough.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Advanced Telecommunications Corp., Baton Rouge, La., named Norman Klugman president and chief operating officer. * Borden Inc., Columbus, Ohio, named James T. McCrory senior vice president for public affairs. * Fairchild Space and Defense Corp., Germantown, Md., a subsidiary of the Matra Group, named Larry M. Calvert corporate vice president. * Melville Corp., Harrison, N.Y., named Judy Vredenburgh president of its Chess King division, a retailer of apparel for young men. * Neutrogena Corp., Los Angeles, named Martha R. Pease senior vice president of marketing. * Nikko Securities Co. International, New York, a subsidiary of Nikko Securities Co. of Japan, named Stephen A. Maher executive vice president and general manager of its fixed-income division. * Pratt & Whitney Co., East Hartford, Conn., named John P. Balaguer president of its government engines and space propulsion business. He succeeds William C. Missimer, Jr. who will retire on April 1. Robert A. Wolfe was named executive vice president of the government engines and space propulsion business. He succeeds Mr. Balaguer. * Sony Corporation of America, Park Ridge, N.J., a subsidiary of Sony Corp. of Japan, named Paul Foschino vice president of the mobile electronics division, Sony Audio Component Systems Co. Sony also named Jay Sato vice president of its consumer video products company.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Postal Rise May Cancel A Direct-Marketing Edge
abstract: THE recent increase in postal rates appears likely to cut down on the "junk mail" that consumers receive.   Direct marketing executives say they expect their industry to be altered drastically by the higher third-class rates that took effect earlier this month. They say they will probably be sending far less direct-mail advertising to private homes.

headline: U.S. Trade Benefits From War
abstract: As a result of the war in the Persian Gulf and its aftermath, the United States is likely to borrow far less from abroad this year than last. Many forecasters expect the deficit in the current account -- the broadest gauge of the nation's imports and exports of goods and services -- to shrink sharply in 1991.   "We'll see a remarkable improvement," said David Rolley, an economist at DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic consulting firm.    According to a report released by the Department of Commerce yesterday, the United States' current account deficit amounted to $99.3 billion in 1990, down from $110 billion in 1989. The $99.3 billion figure is the smallest gap since 1984.

headline: Borrowing By F.D.I.C. Suggested
abstract: Congress's chief economist proposed today that to head off insolvency, the Federal bank insurance program borrow from the Treasury and pay taxpayers back later.   Robert D. Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, told lawmakers that without such a step, the fund that insures bank deposits could have a deficit by the end of this year. Even if the banks increase their contributions and the recession is mild and short-lived, he said, the fund will run a deficit of about $2.8 billion next year.

headline: Saudis Seek to Borrow Billions
abstract: Because of the gulf war, Saudi Arabia is seeking to borrow billions of dollars from international banks, a Western diplomat said. Page A15.

headline: Kremlin Unveils Plan to Double Prices
abstract: The Kremlin announced a plan tonight to raise retail prices two to three times on average across the country, while ending subsidies on most consumer goods and softening the shock with compensation for food-price increases.    The plan for steep price rises, which had been awaited for weeks by the wary Soviet public, is the Government's latest attempt to put some life back into the deeply troubled economy.

headline: U.N. Council Declines To Debate Cease-Fire
abstract: The United Nations Security Council today resisted an attempt to force a public debate on a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war.   Cuba and Yemen, the two Security Council members that have voted against several Council resolutions against Iraq, have tried for more than a week to open such a debate at the request of Libya, Algeria, Morocco, Mauritania, Tunisia and the Sudan.   The North African nations have been circulating a peace plan that would have the Council declare a cease-fire so that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq could cede to resolutions demanding the withdrawal of his troops from Kuwait and then allow Arab peacekeeping troops take their place. The allied coalition would also withdraw its forces under this plan.   The majority of the Council's 15 members decided in private talks today not to meet on the gulf in the immediate future, diplomats said, speaking on the condition of anonymity.   American diplomats who asked not to be named said they had firm instructions from Washington to see that no public debate takes place.

headline: Stocks Mixed After Wide Price Swings
abstract: The end of the war is expected to give the economy a lift, but stocks fluctuated wildly again yesterday, with prices closing mixed as investors moved out of highfliers and into less-favored stocks.    Trading jumped to a strong 223 million shares, from 211.4 million the day before, and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 6.93 points, to 2,882.18.

headline: Announcement by Bush
abstract: Following is a transcript of the statement made by President Bush at the White House on Saturday night to announce the start of the ground war against Iraq:   Yesterday, after conferring with my senior national security advisers and following extensive consultations with our coalition partners, Saddam Hussein was given one last chance, set forth in very explicit terms, to do what he should have done more than six months ago: withdraw from Kuwait without condition or further delay and comply fully with the resolutions passed by the United Nations Security Council.

headline: Airlines Deepen Discounts For Members of the Military
abstract: Most leading airlines are offering deep discounts of 70 percent off full coach fares for military personnel and their immediate families as a token of appreciation for winning the war in the Persian Gulf.    Delta Air Lines set the pattern for the industry when it announced on Friday its "Welcome home fares," which offer a 70 percent discount off full coach. The offer includes reservists and members of the National Guard, as well as the regular services. Other carriers that have matched the fare are Northwest, Continental and USAir.

headline: 'Fused at the Hip,' And to the President
abstract: In an Administration where secrecy and loyalty are prime virtues, Brent Scowcroft, President Bush's national security adviser, and Robert M. Gates, his deputy, are the most virtuous.   With war in the Persian Gulf, the two men have leaped to prominence, filling the role that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d filled in peacetime.   The new arrangement has fueled the long-smoldering rivalry between the White House staff and the State Department, where envious officials deride the Scowcroft-Gates team as the Siamese twins of the White House. Washington at Work, page A14.

headline: Ba Liep Journal; Family Braves a Cruel Sea and Just 2 Come Back
abstract: Dang Chi Cuong came home today to his father's house in this little village in the Mekong Delta, eight months after he left by boat with his wife and two children.   "We met disaster on the sea," Mr. Cuong said simply as his 9-year-old son clung mournful and bewildered to his leg. Thai pirates intercepted their boat of 77 people, he said. They raped the women, including Mr. Cuong's wife, Le Thi Han, then tried to kill all witnesses.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Companies    Exxon and Chevron said earnings had risen because of higher oil prices. Exxon reported a threefold increase, partly because 1989 results were depressed because of the Valdez accident.  [ Page D1. ]   A.T.& T. said its earnings were nearly flat in the quarter. U S West posted a tiny gain in profits, while Nynex's profits from operations fell slightly.  [ D1. ]   Harcourt Brace Jovanovich accepted a takeover bid from General Cinema in a $1.4 billion deal.  [ D1. ]   American Express said its net income dropped more than 46 percent in the fourth quarter, as well as 84 percent for all of 1990 because of a loss of nearly $1 billion at Shearson.  [ D1. ]   G. Heileman Brewing filed for bankruptcy protection, becoming the latest victim of the wide use of debt in the 1980's.  [ D1. ]   Met Life and RJR Nabisco announced a settlement that restores much of the lost value of RJR bonds.  [ D1. ]   Consumers Union warned against buying certain Chrysler cars and mini-vans equipped with electronic transmissions.  [ D2. ]   Bethlehem Steel is discussing with British Steel a venture to produce rail and structural steel.  [ D5. ]   Dow Jones said its profit dropped 41.2 percent for the fourth quarter and 66.3 percent for the year.  [ D16. ]   Northwest is not joining the airline industry rush to spend heavily on routes being sold by weak carriers.  [ D3. ]   Zenith Electronics said its directors had opposed Nycor's proxy challenge and supported Zenith's chief executive.  [ D5. ]   The Daily News and union leaders are locked in a new dispute that has stopped all negotiations, even as the clock ticks.  [ B1. ]   Newspapers may be sued for racial discrimination in ads, a court ruled in a suit filed against The New York Times.  [ B4. ] The Economy    As debate begins on how the war will be paid for, there are many uncertainties.  [ A12. ]   Sales of cars and light trucks made in the U.S. fell 20.2 percent in mid-January, as demand remained sluggish.  [ D2. ]   The Financial Accounting Foundation's executive vice president told trustees another deficit was likely.  [ D3. ]   Governor Cuomo said he expected New York's budget gap to balloon to $6 billion, or a fifth of the state budget.  [ A1. ] International    Britain's House of Lords upheld a ruling that local governments in Britain had no authority to enter into interest-rate swaps.  [ D2. ]   Bush is looking forward to more commerce with Mongolia, he said. Mongolia has a large oil potential.  [ A3. ] Markets    Stock prices advanced broadly in the heaviest trading in a week. The Dow jumped 24.01, to 2,643.07.  [ D6. ]   Treasury securities rose and yields fell, helped by the sense that the Fed would move soon to push down short-term rates.  [ D12. ]   Oil prices eased in sluggish trading that seemed to suggest the market had grown used to bombing and missile attacks.  [ D13. ]  The dollar rose after recovering from a morning slide.  [ D13. ] Today's Columns    As the Administration tries to stabilize the economy to ward off inflation or recession, the war's cost may overwhelm all its calculations. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene.  [ D2. ]   Strong sales of I.B.M.'s newest mainframes gave the computer maker a solid fourth-quarter report, and analysts say the trend will continue in 1991. Market Place.  [ D6. ]   Ad campaigns for California savings and loans tend to focus on conservative mortgage business. Advertising.  [ D16. ]

headline: Net Improves At Safeway
abstract: Safeway Inc., the supermarket chain, today reported improved results for the quarter and year that ended on Dec. 29. It attributed the gains to better buying practices, tighter inventory controls and higher sales in its specialty departments, like prepared foods, which have higher profit margins.    For the quarter, Safeway, based in Oakland, Calif., reported earnings of $27.7 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with a loss of $21.1 million a year earlier. Its sales rose 2.6 percent, to $4.63 billion, from $4.51 billion in the 1989 quarter. The 1989 results reflect a $46 million tax expense on a $460 million dividend from Canadian units.    For the year, Safeway reported earnings of $87.1 million, or 91 cents a share, up dramatically from $2.5 million.

headline: Quick Kuwaiti Recovery Is Seen, With the Cost Less Than Thought
abstract: Kuwait's economy, far and away the strongest among the oil-producing countries before the Iraqi invasion in August put it into a coma, is expected to revive and move back to boom times within two years, say many economic and financial experts on the region.    In scores of interviews here in the last week, Kuwaiti, American and Western financial specialists, including business executives and economic planners, estimated that the cost of reviving the emirate's economy, including the devastated oil industry, would be far less than earlier estimates.

headline: Huge Anti-Communist Rally Honors Day in Serb History
abstract: Tens of thousands of anti-Communist demonstrators gathered today to commemorate the 50th anniversary of a military coup that overthrew a pro-Nazi Serbian government, and to draw parallels to their challenge to the government of former Communists, which now controls their republic,    "We don't want such an authority in Serbia," Vuk Draskovic, the leader of the Serbian Movement for Renewal, told the crowd huddled beneath a sea of umbrellas. "The government that stained its hands with the blood of its own people has to go."

headline: Israel Declares Emergency; Staying Indoors Urged
abstract: Israel declared a state of emergency early this morning, minutes after word reached here of the American attack on Iraq. The authorities advised all Israelis to stay in their homes, open their chemical warfare kits and make their gas masks ready for immediate use.    Iraq has said that it would retaliate against Israel for any allied attack on Iraq.

headline: Mesa Sets $275 Million Gas Sale
abstract: Mesa Limited Partnership, the oil and gas company headed by T. Boone Pickens, agreed today to sell 11 percent of its natural gas reserves for $275 million in cash.   The properties will be acquired by the Seagull Energy Corporation and a second energy company that was not identified. They agreed to pay as much as $35 million more in 1994 if natural gas prices rise.

headline: Insuring 'War Risks' at Lloyd's
abstract: It is 11:50 A.M., and as war clouds gather over the Persian Gulf, a line of insurance brokers forms at the second-floor desk of Christopher W. Rome in the Lloyd's of London building on Lime Street.    The first broker to approach Mr. Rome, the head of one of Lloyd's 400 underwriting syndicates, is seeking $8 million in insurance for a small Saudi Arabian tanker bound for the Saudi gulf port of Jubail, where the vessel plans to load a cargo of fuel oil later this week. His customer wants coverage for the two days the ship will be within the likely war zone.

headline: IN OTHER SECTIONS
abstract: EXPERTS ON HAND: American commanders are relying heavily on civilian employees sent by military contractors to provide technical expertise for the world's most advanced weapons. Business Day, page D2.    MILITARY ORDERS UP: A jump in military orders related to the war helped to raise orders to United States factories for long-lasting goods by 4.4 percent in December. Page D1.    CONSUMERS PESSIMISTIC: Worried about the war and rising unemployment, consumers became increasingly pessimistic in January, the Conference Board said. Page D2.   ABC LEADS THE PACK: In the first full week of the war, all three network evening newscasts made ratings gains. ABC held the lead, followed by NBC and CBS, as the three networks expanded their newscasts to a full hour for at least part of the week. Word and Image, page C14.

headline: ECUADOR FIGHTING TO AVOID DRUG LINK
abstract: Sandwiched between Colombia, the world's largest cocaine refiner, and Peru, the world's largest coca leaf grower, tiny Ecuador is fighting to keep out of South America's drug trade.    For the moment, the tranquillity of this Pacific Coast country contrasts sharply with the violence of its big neighbors.

headline: Data General Unit In Japan to Be Sold
abstract: The Data General Corporation agreed to sell its Japanese subsidiary, Nippon Data General, for about $46 million to the Omron Corporation, a Japanese maker of automated bank tellers and other automation products. Data General expects to report a gain of about $13 million from the sale, with the actual cash proceeds at about $30 million.   As part of Omron, which had $2.6 billion in sales in its 1990 fiscal year, Nippon Data General will be Data General's exclusive distributor in Japan. Nippon Data General, which employs about 550 people, has been a subsidiary of Data General since 1979. It develops, markets and sells Data General computers in Japan.

headline: Market Place; Tokyo's Prospects Depend on Rates
abstract: THE swift conclusion of the Persian Gulf war has cleared up a big uncertainty hanging over the world economy. But in Japan, the removal of that question mark has merely permitted investors to focus on a host of other knotty uncertainties that are leaving the outlook here uncharacteristically muddy.    Suddenly, investors in the United States, who had been fretting over an ailing economy and the prospects of a prolonged war, seem much more certain about the future than do the Japanese, who import 70 percent of their oil from the Middle East and seemed to have the most to gain from war's end.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.75-9   8.75-9   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.88   5.98   8.25        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.77   5.80   7.94        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.78   5.82   7.88        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.88   7.86   8.70        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   8.19   8.18   8.61        TELEPHONE BONDS   9.35   9.35   9.76        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   7.31   7.32   7.48       *Estimated daily average, source Salomon Brothers **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: U.S. Airman Is Slain in Blast Walking to House in Greece
abstract: A powerful bomb blast killed an American Air Force sergeant in an Athens suburb tonight and the police said they believed it was the work of the November 17 guerrilla group, which has killed 15 Greeks and Americans since 1975.   Sgt. Ronald Stewart lost both his legs in the explosion and died while undergoing surgery at a private Athens hospital. Doctors said he bled to death.   The police said the bomb was detonated by remote control as Sergeant Stewart, 35, was walking near his house in the seaside suburb of Glyfada. He worked at the Hellenikon United States Air Force base and was due to go home in two weeks.

headline: Statement by Iraqi Revolutionary Council
abstract: Following is a transcript of a statement made in Baghdad yesterday by a spokesman for the ruling Revolutionary Command Council, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of CNN:    In the name of God, Bush tried in his statement today, in a way expressing his moral deterioration, to portray or hint that what the Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, agreed upon in Moscow is one thing and what President Saddam Hussein said in his speech yesterday is another. In his statement, Bush wanted to deceive nobody but himself, because Mr. Tariq Aziz, as authorized by President Saddam Hussein, to be committed to whatever is agreed upon with the Soviets with regard to their peace initiative.

headline: G.M. in Plans On Natural Gas
abstract: The General Motors Corporation and the Gas Research Institute said they would spend $39 million to develop trucks that run on cleaner-burning natural gas. The auto maker and the gas-company group said production could begin by the mid 1990's.   G.M. will spend $24.1 million and the institute will spend $15.2 million to engineer and develop the light- and medium- duty trucks, a G.M. spokeswoman, Kari Hulsey, said. Initially, a limited number of trucks would be produced for field research, she added.   The institute's members include Brooklyn Union Gas, Columbia Gas System, Consolidated Natural Gas, Pacific Gas and Electric, San Diego Gas and Electric and Southern California Gas.   G.M. has not made plans for producing the trucks once the engineering and development program is over. But Ms. Hulsey said any medium-duty trucks would be built at its Janesville, Wis., truck plant.    G.M.'s GMC truck division announced a project last July to produce at least 1,000 natural-gas powered pickup trucks this year for use in Texas and California. Those vehicles are being converted for natural- gas use by an outside company, Ms. Hulsey said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Barton Industries, Shawnee, Okla., a maker of valves, filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. * FMR Corp., Boston, a holding company, raised its stake in First Chicago Corp., Chicago, a bank holding company, to 9.98 percent after buying 676,700 additional shares for between $24.20 and $24.68 a share.

headline: U.S. Awards Grants to Aid Technology
abstract: The Commerce Department announced $9 million in matching grants to companies yesterday that are designed to foster innovative civilian technologies and restore American competitiveness.   The grants are part of a program that some in Congress and industry hope will grow into a larger effort by the Government to help United States technology become more competitive internationally.

headline: U.S. AND KREMLIN STILL DEADLOCKED ON ARMS TREATIES
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union, at the end of two days of high-level talks, said today that they remained deadlocked over two important arms control agreements that are delaying the next summit meeting, which Moscow has proposed for the end of May.   Although Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and senior Soviet officials said overall relations remained good, there were rumblings today suggesting that serious strains were developing.

headline: Treasury Issues Continue Upward
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities rose again yesterday and yields fell, as traders responded to a second day of seemingly positive developments in the Persian Gulf war by buying notes and bonds.    In addition to the generally favorable news from the gulf, credit market participants said the nearly pervasive sense that the Federal Reserve Board would move soon to push down short-term interest rates also helped to buttress prices.

headline: Manboxinzhai Journal; The 'Barefoot Doctors': Shod, but Still Footsore
abstract: Dr. Su Ke faces little risk of malpractice suits, but there are other hazards of working as a doctor in a remote Chinese village like this one.   "When we go out and try to inoculate babies, some of the peasants are very frightened and hide their kids," Dr. Su, a 46-year-old man with a graying crew cut, explained in a tone of sorrow. "Or they turn their dogs on us to bite us and drive us away."

headline: Serb-Croat Showdown in One Village Square
abstract: The main square of this small Croatian town with a large Serbian population, was, at least for today, the epicenter of Yugoslavia's tensions.   On one side, a young Croatian policeman guarded the Orthodox church normally attended by Serbs. A few yards away, three armored vehicles belonging to Yugoslavia's Federal army were parked in front of the Roman Catholic church, where most local Croats attend.

headline: RULING PARTY WINS KOREA LOCAL VOTE
abstract: President Roh Tae Woo's governing party won a resounding victory on Tuesday, claiming more than half the posts in South Korea's first local elections in three decades.   The election was the first in a series intended to return some measure of local autonomy to the nation's cities and towns after a long period of military rule in which virtually every decision had been made by officials in Seoul.

headline: Pentagon Eyes Syrian Airspace but Bush Is Wary
abstract: The Pentagon wants access to Syrian airspace to help wage the air war against Iraq, but the White House has declined to push Syria for permission, Administration officials said today.   Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, had urged President Bush to seek Syria's permission for American spy planes and other aircraft to fly over its territory to monitor bomb damage in Iraq and possibly carry out other combat missions, the officials said.

headline: Pension Sale Of 'Junk Bonds'
abstract: California's public employees' pension fund decided on Wednesday to sell its "junk bond" portfolio, which has a face value of about $530 million.   The State Treasurer, Kathleen Brown, urged the investment board of the Public Employees Retirement System, commonly referred to as Calpers, to liquidate the high-yield, high-risk bonds "in an orderly and prudent fashion" to protect pensions.

headline: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Drop
abstract: Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were down for the week ended yesterday, but the rate of decline appeared to be easing after three weeks.    According to The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest rate publication, many banks apparently are of the opinion that interest rates will continue low, and they have adjusted their savings rates accordingly.

headline: In Tiananmen Trials, Attitude Counts
abstract: The three-hour trial of Wang Dan, the student leader sentenced Saturday to four years in prison, unfolded as smoothly as the script allowed it, and while the players assumed Mr. Wang's guilt, all eyes were on his performance.   The two dozen or so Tiananmen Square trials held in recent weeks were closed to journalists and other foreigners, but bits and pieces gathered through people allowed to watch Mr. Wang's trial suggested that the process was more theatrical than judicial.

headline: A Tube Is Developed To Treat Glaucoma
abstract: A New York ophthalmologist and one of his patients have teamed up to invent what they describe as a more effective way to treat glaucoma, a leading cause of blindness.   Glaucoma occurs when fluid pressure builds up behind the eye and begins to damage the optic nerve. The problem occurs when the eye's natural drainage system becomes blocked, so that fluids cannot pass through the eye and drain into the bloodstream. If the pressure is not relieved, it can destroy the optic nerve.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: U.S. Statement; Transcript of White House Statement and News Conference on Soviet Plan
abstract: Following is a transcript of a briefing last night by the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, as recorded by The New York Times:  OPENING STATEMENT    President Gorbachev called President Bush at 6:47 P.M. this evening to discuss his conversation with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. President Gorbachev outlined all the major points of a Soviet initiative developed by himself and the Foreign Minister. President Bush thanked President Gorbachev for his intensive and useful efforts, but raised serious concerns about several points in the plan.    President Bush said the United States will consult with its coalition partners on the proposal. We are in the process of examining the Soviet initiative tonight. The United States and its coalition partners continue to prosecute the war. That is the sum and substance of the situation that we have at this point. QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS    Q. Marlin, did President Gorbachev give any indication that once President Bush gave him these concerns that he was going to take those back to Aziz, and did he leave any hope that there may be some give on the part of Iraqis on those points the President raised?   A. They didn't discuss follow-on procedures. President Bush did say that we would be examining these points tonight, and we will be considering then, how we intend to respond. I would not expect anything -- any response -- tonight, anything before tomorrow. But in terms of what happens then, that really is contingent upon how we view the various points in this plan and what action needs to be taken at that time. Excuse me, Helen? Plan's Drawbacks    Q. What are the concerns that -- what are the chief drawbacks as the Administration would see them?   A. Well, we don't want to go into the individual points. Of course, this plan was just announced by the Soviets a very short time ago.    The telephone conversation lasted approximately 33 minutes, and although they did get a chance to go through the major points, we obviously have a considerable analysis to do. But I would emphasize again that as they went through the various points, President Bush did state the concerns that he felt the coalition would have on this matter, both in terms of points that are in the plan that we have problems with, as well as issues that are not included, so there are a number of issues to resolve. Ground War Timetable    Q. But  [ inaudible ]  hold up the ground war, doesn't it?   A. The ground war is a matter that is still under consideration. The war itself continues. We will continue to seek compliance with the U.N. resolutions, and the President will make decisions concerning the ground war as appropriate. This process that was initiated by the Soviets is continuing at a rather intensive pace, but there is not change at this point in our schedule for prosecution of the war. Aziz-Bush Exchange    Q. During the meeting itself, was Aziz in communication with the President? Was there any two-way on that?   A. No, there was no one else on the phone call and no other communications. Ann? Pullout's Prospects    Q. Does President Bush see now here a chance, for the first time since Aug. 2, to reverse the invasion of Kuwait and actually come about this without launching a ground war?   A. Well, there have been innumerable chances since Aug. 2, in the sense that Saddam Hussein could have pulled out at any time. That still is the fastest and most efficient way to end this war.    In terms of this initiative, it's just too soon to characterize it. We need to take a look at it, but I would say again that we have had our hopes raised before. After serious examination there have been significant problems, and certainly the President has indicated there could well be some difficulties here, but we are taking a look at it. War During Talks    Q. How could he prosecute a ground war if indeed the talks are proceeding in Moscow?   A. Well, that's not an issue at the moment. We are proceeding the war -- the air war continues. There's been no decision on the ground war at this time. And we continue to pursue the matter in the Persian Gulf in the most effective and efficient military way possible. Michael?  Terms of Withdrawal    Q. The President has said all along that the 12 U.N. resolutions are what Saddam Hussein must live up to. In the points that the President raised that he doesn't like, the possibility sounds like that there may be a negotiation under way to drop one or more of those points. Can the President live with anything less than full acceptance of all 12 as long as Iraq pulls out of Kuwait?   A. There is no negotiation under way with regard to the United States. I would remind you again that this is a matter between the Soviet Union and Iraq -- that we are commenting on their proposal, and we are not directly involved in that sense. I would repeat once again, as well, that compliance -- full compliance with the 12 U.N. resolutions -- is the goal we seek, and those are the guideposts that we would use in judging any consideration of withdrawal.    Q. Are you willing to go beyond those 12, though -- to scale back any of those 12?   A. We have said repeatedly that we must have full compliance with the 12 U.N. resolutions. There's no change in that situation. Rita? Soviet Plan's Fate    Q. Marlin, aside from raising serious considerations here, you said that we've had our hopes raised before. In the process of reviewing this, do you at least see that there is some hope here that this peace proposal could work if some of these problems that the President sees are worked out?   A. I just don't want to give it any characterization until we've had a chance to give it the full analysis of the United States Government. Let's take one more question. Charles? Moscow's Role    Q. Marlin, how can you say there are no negotiations going on when Gorbachev tells you his points and you tell them which ones are objectionable, and basically ask him to go back to Tariq Aziz and say -- about these points? Are those not negotiations? Is he not negotiating on your behalf?   A. We haven't asked him to do anything. He's asked our views on these matters. We'll provide them as we have in the last few days, but I reiterate again that this is a matter between the Soviets and Iraq, and we are appreciative that -- of the communication that has told us of these discussions, but we are not a part of the negotiations. Thank you very much.

headline: Chief Operating Officer For Montgomery Ward
abstract: In a promotion that Montgomery Ward & Company called a step toward corporate growth, the Chicago-based retailer has announced the appointment of Daniel H. Levy as vice chairman and chief operating officer. He will be the first company executive in more than a decade to hold both titles.   Mr. Levy, who is 49, was previously Ward's president for the apparel and home furnishings group. He joined the company in 1987, a year before Bernard F. Brennan, its chairman, began a management buyout of the company from the Mobil Corporation. Since then, through a shrinking of the company, termination of its catalogue business and the adoption of a specialty-store approach, Montgomery Ward has generated steady increases in profits and expects to report record earnings soon for the 1990 fiscal year.

headline: Pilots at Northwest To Weigh Concessions
abstract: The pilots for Northwest Airlines have agreed to negotiate contract concessions because of the carrier's worsening financial condition.   The move by the 5,600-member union came on Tuesday, a day after union officials met with Northwest's chairman, Alfred A. Checchi, and chief executive, John Dasburg, for more than three hours.

headline: Leaders of A.F.L.-C.I.O. Back Health Plan
abstract: Leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. struck a compromise on health-care reform today, endorsing national health insurance as a long-term goal but agreeing to push for more modest changes for now.    Labor leaders gathered here for their annual winter meeting had disagreed over whether their union should back a Government-financed national health insurance plan like Canada's or less drastic revisions like an insurance pool for the uninsured.    At the urging of Lane Kirkland, president of the 14.2-million-member American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, the executive council adopted a compromise that keeps national health insurance as a union goal but pushes the less drastic changes for now because they are seen as having a better chance of passing. A United Front     The compromise, which also calls for uniform reimbursement rates for hospitals and doctors, should allow labor leaders to present a united front once Congress starts debating health- care reform, union officials said.   Mr. Kirkland said that the compromise gave the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "the latitude, the flexibility, to sit down with the leading players in the House and Senate" to work out legislation reforming health care.   "We are not committed to any rigid, single plan," he said. "We are in a negotiating posture."    But labor officials who worked on the compromise said that ideally an insurance pool would be set up to provide coverage for the 37 million Americans who have no health insurance. That pool would be financed by employers who do not provide benefits to their workers.   The system would be an expansion of Medicare and Medicaid. Changes would include lowering the Medicare eligibility age to 60, rather than 65. 'Play or Pay' System     Big companies that provide health plans for their workers could opt out of the system. It would be a "play or pay" system in which employers either provided coverage or paid into the pool.   Labor has stepped up its campaign to bring about national health-care revision. Last summer it began a $3 million television campaign urging changes and held hearings across the country.    Unions view health care as an urgent issue because rising costs have caused breakdowns in contract talks as employers tried to get workers to pick up part of the costs.

headline: New England Bank Review
abstract: L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today that he will try to assess how well the F.D.I.C. is running three failed New England banks when he visits Boston on Friday.   Mr. Seidman was also scheduled to meet with the governors of the six New England states.

headline: Leslie Nielsen Starring In Dollar Car Campaign
abstract: Leslie Nielsen, the actor who is perhaps best known for his slapstick performances in the films "Airplane" and "The Naked Gun," has taken on a new role: the star of new television ads for Dollar Rent A Car.   Dollar said yesterday that it had signed Mr. Nielsen for a campaign that will highlight an overhaul of its image, including a new logo and new uniforms for its employees. The campaign will begin on April 15.    In the 30-second spots, Mr. Nielsen, who recently appeared in a campaign for Coca-Cola, will play "an everyman" who reacts to different traveling situations, said Florence Quinn, a Dollar spokeswoman. "There will be humor, definitely humor," she said.

headline: Israel Lowers Shekel's Value
abstract: Israel lowered the median value of its currency today by 5.66 percent against a "basket" of foreign currencies dominated by the United States dollar. The action will require Israel's central bank to devalue the currency, the shekel, on Monday.   The Bank of Israel said the new median rate was 2.5522 shekels for each unit of the currency basket, up from 2.4077. The median rate is a stable rate around which the shekel's value can fluctuate by 5 percent in either direction.   The shekel's representative rate against the dollar was 2.0550 today.

headline: Big California Utility Deal Is Set Back
abstract: The proposed merger of two large California utilities was dealt another setback today when two officials of the California Public Utilities Commission recommended against the deal.    The two officials, Lynn Carew and Brian Cragg, who are administrative law judges, said in a long-awaited ruling that the proposed merger of Southern California Edison and San Diego Gas and Electric would adversely affect competition. They argued that the merged utility would dominate regional transmission lines and eliminate an alternative to Edison for many energy customers.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Lebanon; P.L.O. Missiles Attack North of Israel
abstract: Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas based in southern Lebanon unleashed the biggest barrage of short-range surface-to-surface missiles toward Israel in eight years, but Israel said the rockets fell short of their targets.   A P.L.O. spokesman in Sidon, a southern port, said that the rocketing was "in defense of Iraq and its people."

headline: Haiti Installs Democratic Chief, Its First
abstract: Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a 37-year-old Roman Catholic priest who rose from the obscurity of a small parish to help lead the battle against the Duvalier family dictatorship, was sworn in today as the country's first democratically elected President.   With thousands of the slum dwellers whose cause he has championed raucously chanting his name outside, Father Aristide wiped tears from his face with both hands and bowed his head as the ceremony began in the National Assembly building. Opening the inauguration, the president of the newly elected Senate, Eudrice Raymond, said the event represented "the overthrow of a system of repression and darkness."

headline: I.B.M. Contract At Tax Agency
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation has won a contract worth as much as $339.6 million to computerize the Internal Revenue Service's tax collection system.   The I.R.S. has said it expects to collect an additional $2.52 billion in unpaid taxes over seven years once the new system begins operating.    The initial contract, awarded on Dec. 28, is for $126.3 million. It provides for the I.R.S. to spend additional amounts, up to $213.3 million more, if the system proves satisfactory.   The contract calls for 11 mainframe computers, with an option for 10 more. The agreement also contains an option for the I.R.S. to buy 5,000 I.B.M. desktop computer systems and 10,000 laptop systems.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq's Army; The Formidable Republican Guard Blocks the Road to Victory
abstract: Iraq's best-trained and most heavily armed divisions, the Republican Guards, must be destroyed if the allies are to decisively win the war in the Persian Gulf, American military analysts say.   "The Republican Guard is the linchpin of the ground war," said Joshua Epstein, a military analyst at the Brookings Institution, expressing a view that is widely accepted in military circles. "If they can be defeated, you can say to those in the defensive arcs to the south, 'Look, the war is over.' "

headline: On Return, Arabs Find Jobs in Israel Are Taken
abstract: As Soviet Jews poured into Israel over the last year, the new immigrants took over nearly half of the best factory jobs and a vast portion of the other semi-skilled positions traditionally held by Palestinians.   And as the Israeli authorities begin releasing Palestinian workers from a monthlong curfew so they can return to work, many will find that Soviet Jews are also making small inroads into the menial jobs long dominated by Palestinians and shunned by Israelis.

headline: Through the Form 1040 Step by Step
abstract: A tax return is like a roadmap to a family's financial life, and the more complex personal finances are, the more complex the tax return will be. Many tax professionals advise their clients year-round on tax and financial planning, but taxpayers themselves still have plenty of work to do this time of year in getting all their records ready for a professional. Studying an expertly prepared return can help taxpayers with this, as well as help them understand tax strategies. Jack Porter, national director of tax practice for BDO Seidman, and Diane Clifton and Chuck DeLanoy, national tax fellows in the firm's Washington office, prepared this return for a two-income couple who were not liable for the alternative minimum tax.

headline: TOP BUSH ADVISERS CALLED IN TO MEET ON IRAQ STRATEGY
abstract: President Bush met with senior advisers tonight to discuss the military and political strategies for the final push leading to the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait, Administration officials said.   "We are going to start to talk about what we are going to do," a senior Administration official said before the meeting. "This is the first time the whole team will be back together since Dec. 18 to compare notes and review the whole range of strategic issues."

headline: Big 3 Set Up Pollution Study
abstract: The nation's Big Three auto makers said today that they had formed a joint research project to study the environmental effects of automobile emissions and manufacturing.   The effort is the third of its kind by the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, which are also involved in joint research in plastics and batteries.

headline: Heavy Fighting Erupts in Somali Capital
abstract: Fighting between Government and opposition forces intensified today in the Somali capital, Mogadishu, amid reports that the President, Mohammed Siad Barre, had taken refuge at the international airport.   The position of the President, an ally of the United States, appeared increasingly vulnerable, officials in Washington said. But they said that they had no confirmation that the President was at the airport preparing to flee the country, and that they had no clear idea who had the upper hand in the fighting.

headline: GORBACHEV BANS MOSCOW RALLIES
abstract: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev tonight sharpened his political rivalry with Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic, by ordering a ban on all public rallies and demonstrations in the capital for the next three weeks.    Insurgent anti-Gorbachev political groups had been planning to continue their sizable demonstrations of support for Mr. Yeltsin in Moscow during a special session of the Russian Parliament this week. In the session, the Communist opposition is expected to try to strip Mr. Yeltsin of his position.

headline: 6 Die in Swiss Avalanches
abstract: Avalanches in various regions of alpine Switzerland killed six skiers over the weekend, the police reported today, and two more bodies were found from a snowslide on Mount Blanc in Italy, bringing the confirmed death toll in that accident to nine. The deaths in Switzerland raised the toll in avalanches this season to 16, compared with 28 in all of last winter.

headline: IRAQ SETS OIL REFINERIES AFIRE AS ALLIES STEP UP AIR ATTACKS; MISSILE PIERCES TEL AVIV SHIELD
abstract: As the skies over Iraq cleared and allowed an intensification of the American-led air war, allied military officials said today that Iraq had set fire to two Kuwaiti oil refineries and to an oilfield near Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia.   By setting the oil installations ablaze, they said, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq carried out his threat to destroy oil sites in the Persian Gulf if Iraq's occupation of Kuwait was challenged.

headline: L.A. Gear Responds to Suit
abstract: Responding to a lawsuit filed on Wednesday by Nike Inc., L.A. Gear Inc. denied today that its new Catapult shoe infringed two Nike patents.    L.A. Gear said technology used in the Catapult did not infringe a cushioning system patent held by Nike. The company said the United States Patent Office had previously not objected to L.A. Gear's use of technology that might appear similar to Nike's.

headline: Rockland County Housing; 'Clearance' Sale Is Planned at 3 Projects
abstract: Three Rockland County builders are holding a "clearance" sale on existing housing here to make way for new units that they think will be more salable in today's soft market.    The sale, scheduled for March 16 and 17, involves 18 one- and two-bedroom condominium town houses and one-bedroom apartments, ranging in size from 940 to 2,400 square feet. There will be six units on sale in each of three developments.

headline: A.T.&T. Files Suit In NCR Stock Plan
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked a Federal District Court in Dayton, Ohio, to declare the NCR Corporation's newly created employee stock ownership plan invalid. A.T.& T. said in court papers that NCR directors had breached their fiduciary duties by creating an employee stock plan designed to deny NCR stockholders "the ability to decide for themselves whether or not to accept the A.T.& T. tender offer."    A.T.& T, which is trying to acquire the computer maker for $6.1 billion, said the stock plan diluted existing NCR stockholder voting power by 8 percent. NCR adopted the plan, which effectively puts 8 percent of its common the stock in employees' hands.

headline: More on the Gulf Crisis
abstract: VIETNAM AND KUWAIT Many Americans who lived through the Vietnam era are finding as they face a new war that answers are no longer so simple. Page A14.   EMIGRES' EMOTIONS Iraqi-Americans, many with relatives in their homeland, struggle with conflicting emotions. Page A14.    PRAYERS AND PROTESTS Americans expressed their anxiety about war with prayer vigils, panel discussions and protests. Page A15.    STUDENTS DIVIDED Students in Rye Neck, N.Y., who have been writing to soldiers, are dividedabout the prospect of war. Our Towns, page B1.   NETWORKS PREPARE United States television news networks prepare for war. Word and Image, page C16.    COMPANIES' PLANS Companies are poised to put into effect plans to safeguard or evacuate employees in the Middle East and deal with possible terrorism at home. Business Day, page D1.    OIL PRICE JUMPS The price of oil jumped $3.49 a barrel, to $30.78, its highest level since early December. Page D1.

headline: U.S. Reviewing FNN Deal
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it was investigating for possible antitrust violations the proposed purchase of the Financial News Network by its biggest competitor.    The commission said it had asked a Federal bankruptcy court to withhold final approval of the sale of FNN to the Consumer News and Business Channel until it had a chance to complete its review. It asked the two parties for information and asked the court for 20 days to review it.

headline: Setting Standards for Compost
abstract: To the Editor:   The Solid Waste Composting Council welcomes the identification of composting as an integral part of solid waste management ("The Packaging Industry's New Fancy -- Composting Garbage" Feb. 24). Only with composting can recycling rates of 25 percent to 50 percent be achieved.   The author suggests, however, a policy dispute between industry sectors and environmental groups that simply does not exist. No one favors the production of substandard compost. Indeed, the council was created to establish uniform standards for compost quality and, last November, launched a national standards-setting initiative.   The council is against composting undifferentiated waste and provides the forum for a serious, ongoing and technical debate on how to separate elements of the solid waste stream. While some of our members favor extensive curbside separation, others argue that the efficiency and quality control of centralized processing is superior. The discussion is about implementation, not ideology.   The author also suggests an alignment between the waste management industry and environmental groups, on the one hand, and the council and consumer products companies on the other. In fact, the council is a roundtable organization whose membership includes the Natural Resources Defense Council, Waste Management Inc. and the Tellus Institute (mentioned as critics in the article). CHARLES A. CANNON  Washington, March 4  The author is executive vice president of the Solid Waste Composting Council

headline: Open Positions on Nasdaq Short Sales Down 4.2%
abstract: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a decrease of 4.2 percent in the short interest in actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended on March 15.    A total of 267.9 million shares were held "short" and not yet covered in mid-March, it said, compared with 279.7 million shares in the period that ended in mid-February. The figure, a decrease of 11.8 million shares, represents short-selling in 2,266 stocks. In February, the short-selling was spread among 2,256 issues.

headline: Mutual Funds; Gold's Luster in Uncertain Times
abstract: Because gold prices have been slipping as inflation rises, experts are debating whether gold remains a good inflation hedge. But investors in precious-metals mutual funds -- which primarily buy gold-mining stocks -- are probably more interested in gold's role as an insurance policy.   The world has been rocked by extraordinary events since the Berlin wall came down in late 1989. During the shifts in Eastern Europe immediately preceeding the wall's demise, sales of precious-metal funds shot up as investors sought a safe harbor. The same thing happened when Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, and in December (the latest figures available), as the war deadline drew near.

headline: IN OTHER SECTIONS
abstract: OUTLOOK ON OIL: For oil-importing nations like the United States, the immediate postwar outlook is highly favorable, but the long-term picture is far more troubling, said experts at a conference on Middle East oil and security. Business Day, page D.    ARSENAL TOWN REBOUNDS: With the war, artillery has made a comeback, and so has Watervliet, N.Y., whose economy is dependent on a Government arsenal. Page B1.    TV AND THE WAR: A parade of human images -- celebrators, victims, captives -- replaced maps and numbers, adding drama to the war coverage. Word and Image, page C16.

headline: New Luxury Tax May Cost More Than It Can Bring In
abstract: The luxury tax that Congress adopted in its closed-door budget sessions last year may cost retailers and the Internal Revenue Service more to collect than the revenues it brings in, some tax experts and business leaders contend.   The excise tax on high-priced automobiles, aircraft, pleasure boats, jewelry and furs went into effect on Jan. 1 and is now expected by Congress to bring in slightly under $1.5 billion in the next five years.

headline: People
abstract: * Ammirati & Puris, New York, an affiliate of Robert Marston & Associates Inc., named Kirk Souder vice president-art supervisor and Tony Gomes vice president-copy supervisor. * Della Femina McNamee, Pittsburgh, named Joe Poprosky and Donald Kress vice presidents. * Earle Palmer Brown & Spiro, Philadelphia, a part of Earle Palmer Brown, named John C. Bythrow, Dale A. Kramer and Diane Lutz vice presidents. * Ned Costello has been named vice president-management supervisor at Kelley & Wallwork Advertising, Boston. * Joan Bergman has been named senior vice president-director of new business development at Deutsch Inc., New York. * Mark Herlyn has been named to the new position of associate publisher of the magazines Cruising World and Sailing World, publications of The New York Times Company Magazine Group. * Bill Madonna has been named Los Angeles advertising sales manager at USA Today. * Amy R. Churgin has been named advertising director of Elle Magazine.

headline: British Trade Gap Cut
abstract: Britain's current account trade deficit shrank sharply in February from January, thanks to a drop in oil imports. The Government's Central Statistical Office said today that the deficit narrowed to $:192 million ($340 million) from a revised $:783 million ($1.4 billion) the month before.

headline: Germans Cut Drug Prices
abstract: Pharmaceutical companies in western Germany agreed today to pay hefty subsidies so that drugs may be sold at discount prices in the former East Germany, a Cabinet minister said today.    The Labor Minister, Norbert Bluem, announced details of a deal requiring the drug industry to pay $1.5 billon through 1993 so that low-paid people in the once-Communist part of the country can buy medicines at a 55 percent discount.

headline: Huge Rally in Moscow Calls on Gorbachev to Resign
abstract: More than 100,000 people marched through this capital today demanding Mikhail S. Gorbachev's resignation and urging a "no" vote in the referendum on Soviet unity a week from now.    The rally and similar ones in several other Soviet cities contributed to making next Sunday's referendum a showdown between President Gorbachev with his coalition of Communists, centrists and conservatives, and the liberals, nationalists and reformers who have rallied behind Boris N. Yeltsin, the leader of the Russian Republic.

headline: Bank's Plan In Maryland
abstract: Maryland's largest banking company said today that it would announce before the opening of the stock market Tuesday how it intended to repay millions of dollars in debt.   MNC Financial Inc. is the parent of the Maryland National Bank, the largest bank in Maryland, and American Security Bank, the second-largest in Washington. It had a deadline of today for repaying $375 million to nine banks led by J.P. Morgan & Company. It also faces a Tuesday deadline to repay $271 million in variable rate notes.   John Heffern, an analyst at Alex, Brown and Sons in Baltimore, said he expected MNC to make a partial payment on the Morgan loans using the proceeds of a previous sale of assets and a complete payment Tuesday on the variable rate notes.   MNC will pay the Morgan group the balance with the proceeds from the planned spinoff of the Maryland National Bank unit, he said.

headline: Bank Freeze in Rhode Island Puts Pressure on Depositors
abstract: It was payday today at the Wickford Gourmet. But Joseph Dube could not write checks to his 25 employees because the Davisville Credit Union, where he has his account, has been closed indefinitely by Rhode Island's new Governor as part of a "bank emergency."    Mr. Dube was angry, frustrated and left feeling that he was in a "nothing situation."

headline: Trump Gives Taj Mahal Data
abstract: The Taj Mahal Casino Resort, owned by Donald J. Trump, will lose money in the next four years but will generate enough cash to meet interest payments on its huge debt, according to documents submitted to state gambling regulators on Wednesday.   The documents were presented to the State Casino Control Commission as part of the panel's hearings on the financial stability of the Taj Mahal, which opened last April.

headline: People
abstract: * Josh Baran has been named general manager of Edleman Public Relations Worldwide, Los Angeles. * Michele Bruno was appointed public relations director at Walsh & Associates in Malverne, L.I.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; For the Saudi Fallen, Martyrdom; To Their Families, Hefty Benefits
abstract: In the United States, those killed in the war against Iraq have been considered patriots who sacrificed for country. In this ancient desert land, they are instead revered martyrs for Islam.   This week, King Fahd of Saudi Arabia declared the first martyrs of the war, the 18 Saudi soldiers who died in the battle to retake the coastal town of Khafji, the first major ground battle of the war.

headline: Treasury Prices Narrowly Mixed
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed yesterday in lackluster trading. Dealers attributed the dull session largely to the lack of any significant economic data. Many investors moved toward the shorter maturities.   Partly as a result, the average discount rate at the weekly auction of 90-day Treasury bills rose to 6.09 percent, from 6.01 percent a week ago. The average rate on the companion six-month bills rose to 6.06 percent from 6.01 percent.

headline: Hewlett, Sun In Venture On Software
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company, the two leading vendors of computer work stations, today announced a joint effort to develop advanced software that will allow their computers, as well as machines made by other companies, to work together.   The goal is to create software that will allow computer users throughout an organization to share information over a network, even if they use computers made by different companies or software programs that were not designed to work together.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Economy    In Rhode Island, there was anger and frustration at the closing of 45 credit unions, banks and investment companies. The Governor said 7 would reopen on Monday.  [ Page A1. ]   More than 1,400 credit unions with $18.6 billion of deposits in more than half the states have their own insurance programs.  [ D4. ]   Federal regulators said many of the 45 closed Rhode Island institutions were were too weak to be eligible for Federal deposit insurance.  [ D4. ]   The nation's largest banks lowered their prime rate to 9 1/2 percent. It was their first drop in nearly a year.  [ D1. ]   The country is in a recession, the White House acknowledged for the first time. It was a judgment reached weeks, if not months, ago by most private economists.  [ D1. ]   For the vacant Fed seat, Bush's top economic advisers have reportedly recommended that the President nominate Lawrence B. Lindsey, a conservative economist on the White House staff.  [ D2. ]   The energy industry expects to increase worldwide spending to find and produce oil and natural gas by nearly 14 percent this year, a survey shows.  [ D3. ]   The 1988 sales by Federal regulators of failed savings and loans were flawed by an unfair competitive process, according to a new study ordered by Congress.  [ D4. ]   Purchasers' index of economic activity fell to 40.4 percent in December from 41.3 percent in November. It was the weakest showing since November 1982.  [ D8. ]   Construction spending fell by 0.6 percent in November to its lowest level in two years, the Commerce Department said.  [ D8. ]   Sales of vehicles made in the U.S. fell by 19.1 percent in mid-December, as demand sank to the lowest level since 1982.  [ D8. ] Companies    U.S. chip makers gained market share in 1990 at the expense of the Japanese, for the first time in more than a decade.  [ D1. ]   St. Martin's Press said it would not exhibit at the American Booksellers Association convention in New York in June because of the high cost.  [ D5. ]   A dissident Hollywood Park shareholder said he had won a proxy fight to oust the company's board, but the race track concern said his claim was premature.  [ D3. ] Markets    Oil prices fell nearly $2, dipping to $26.49 a barrel, on speculation that Washington and Baghdad will reach a last-minute diplomatic solution.  [ D3. ]   Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply and interest rates fell after a flurry of negative economic reports.  [ D6. ]   Stocks sagged broadly despite a jump in bond prices and a drop in oil prices. The Dow lost 23.02, to 2,610.64.  [ D8. ]   Grim economic news sent the dollar stumbling, but traders said war concerns lessened the drop.  [ D14. ]  Gold prices fell.  [ D14. ] Today's Columns    Big banks caught the most attention for slashing dividends last year, but they were not alone. Figures show that 143 companies decreased their dividends. while 266 omitted them entirely. Floyd Norris: Market Place.  [ D1. ]   The excesses of the takeover years may be coming back to haunt Wall Street and investors in a new way: Firms and stockholders that profited from buyouts that subsequently failed could be forced to give their money back. Talking Deals.  [ D1. ]   Turning packages into elaborate ads may be the best way for many marketers, especially those with limited budgets, to stand out in the clutter of advertising in supermarkets. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D5. ]

headline: Why Rich New York Is So Poor
abstract: In his latest budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York proposes sizable cuts in Medicaid, local aid and the state payroll, which fiscal conservatives have been urging for years. Yet even after these cuts are in place, New York will still be spending more per capita and relative to income than most other states. And the Governor's tax increases insure New York's standing as one of the highest taxed states in the nation. Mr. Cuomo has to do better.   The last eight years saw a historic resurgence of New York's economy. Real personal income rebounded from no growth to average annual increases of more than 3 percent. Per capita income in the state zoomed to 20 percent above the national average in 1989, up from 12 percent above in 1983. Despite the current recession, there are nearly one million more New Yorkers working today than eight years ago. The state's unemployment rate edged to 5.5 percent in December; when Mr. Cuomo delivered his first State of the State message, it was 9 percent.

headline: Yes, That's A Tunnel; Yes, That's Light
abstract: Happy days are almost here again. Consumers, at least if one is to believe what they tell pollsters, are now more confident about the future than at any time since early last year.   The rising tide of consumer confidence is probably good news for owners of stocks and of speculative bonds, but it may not be such great information for owners of Government bonds. For Republicans, basking in the glow of the Persian Gulf victory, it could remove the last apparent obstacle to a landslide victory next year.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt * The Province of Alberta is issuing $500 million (Canadian) of 10 5/8 percent Eurobonds due 1996, at a reoffered price of 99 5/8, through UBS Phillips & Drew Ltd. The bonds are rated Aa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by Standard & Poor's Corp. * Waste Management Inc., Oak Brook, Ill., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $600 million in unsecured debt securities to be issued from time to time. Ratings * The Town of North Hempstead, L.I., has had its general obligation bond rating lowered to A, from A-1, by Moody's. * Olympia & York Water Street Finance Corp.'s rating on secured notes due 1996 has been lowered to A, from AA, by S.& P. The company was set up by Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the Toronto-based real estate company, to finance a construction project in New York.

headline: Patents; Genetic Material By Nobel Laureate
abstract: Dr. Thomas R. Cech, a co-recipient of the Nobel Prize for Chemistry in 1989 for his work with genetics, has won patent approval for what he calls "ribozymes," an unusual form of genetic material that could someday be used to deactivate deadly viruses.    Ribozymes are snippets of R.N.A., the molecules that translate the genetic code of D.N.A. into particular proteins, that behave like enzymes and can be used to cut other strands of R.N.A. The allure of ribozymes, Dr. Cech said, is that they can be customized to remove a crucial sequence from the genetic code of a virus. "It can be targeted, like a Patriot missile with an onboard guidance system," he remarked.

headline: Shoe Imports Up by 4%
abstract: Shoe imports rose last year in the United States for the first time in three years, the International Trade Commission said today. Imports captured 83 percent of the United States market. Imports of non-rubber shoes -- the vast majority of footwear -- rose by 4 percent, to 900 million pairs, valued at $8.4 billion. Of the total, China shipped 267 million pairs, nearly 100 million more than Taiwan and South Korea, the commission said.

headline: ISRAELI TELLS BUSH OF MISSILE DAMAGE
abstract: Israel's Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, in a hastily arranged one-day visit to Washington, told President Bush today that Israel was suffering heavy "destruction" from Iraqi missile attacks and that its willingness to refrain from retaliating was wearing thin, Administration officials said.   While Israeli leaders have consistently said since the missile attacks began that they are reserving the right to retaliate, until now they have refrained from doing so at Washington's behest. It is not clear what the Israelis could do to Iraq that the much larger American-led coalition air forces have not done.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Postwar Politics; Kuwait Says Borders Disputed By Hussein Are Not Negotiable
abstract: Kuwait's foreign minister was quoted today as saying that his country would never negotiate border and oil-rights claims with Iraq, even if President Saddam Hussein were forced from power.   Such negotiations were called for in United Nations resolution 660, the same one that ordered Iraq to withdraw its troops from Kuwait. Baghdad has been saying for the last 12 days it will honor the resolution.

headline: Refinery Closing Outrages Mexican Workers
abstract: A week after this city's largest oil refinery was abruptly shut down to ease a critical pollution crisis, the reasons for that decision still linger in the air.    For blocks around the 430-acre complex in north-central Mexico City, the sharp smell of distilled petroleum still pervades the streets. The hissing of distant gasses recalls the fumes that billowed from the plant. Even casual passers-by still come away with watering eyes and burning lungs.

headline: Europe Backs Brewery Deal
abstract: The European Commission today cleared a proposed asset swap between Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and Courage, the brewing arm of Elders IXL Ltd., after the companies agreed to an adjustment in the deal.   Under the swap, Courage will buy all Grand Met's breweries, and in return the companies will form a equal venture to manage pubs linked to the companies.   The commission said that the sale and the new pub management venture did not infringe European Community competition rules but that an exclusive 10-year supply agreement between Courage and the venture did.   After consultations with the companies, the commission said Courage could have only a five-year exclusive agreement to supply beer to the venture, called I.E.L. It said that in the five years afterward, I.E.L. would have to buy fewer quantities of Courage beers. This, the commission said, would give the landlords of pubs tied to I.E.L. the chance to buy beers outside those brewed by Courage.   Elders and Courage agreed on the deal last year. In November, the British Government gave its approval, and the companies began talking with the European Community.   While all Courage pubs will be acquired by I.E.L., not all Grand Met ones will be taken over by the new company.   Britain and the commission have agreed to a formula that will leave I.E.L. with 6,950 pubs and Grand Met with about 1,700. Courage has also sold about 1,500 pubs.   The price of the breweries and details of the I.E.L.'s financing have yet to be decided.

headline: Where the First Amendment Can't Go
abstract: To the Editor:   Messrs. Berman and Rotenberg's Forum article poses interesting questions concerning First Amendment obligations (if any) of privately owned electronic information systems ("Free Speech in an Electronic Age," Jan. 6). However, their use of "free speech cases involving shopping centers" as an analogy is faulty.   In 1980, in Pruneyard v. Robins, the United States Supreme Court ruled that the First Amendment    does not    permit public access to a shopping center for noncommercial purposes against the wishes of the property owner. However, states were left free to interpret their state constitutions to require access over the property owner's objections. As a result, California became the first state to require such property owners to permit expressional activities on property used solely for commercial purposes.   The article implies that free access to shopping centers is a generally accepted notion, if not downright common. This implication grossly overinflates the acceptance of California's position.    The overwhelming majority of states to consider this issue have ruled in favor of property owners. Giving the pro-access side the benefit of all doubts, only three states (including California) have arguably accepted this position while the position has been expressly rejected by at least Arizona, Connecticut, Georgia, Michigan, New York, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin and (arguably) Washington. WILLIAM J. BERG Atlanta, Jan. 10,    The author is a lawyer who has handled similar cases in Georgia.

headline: Hard Edges Aside, Manhattan Still Lures the Ambitious
abstract: After months of persuasion, Sylvia Laniado, a recruiter for an advertising agency, convinced Bonnie Brainin, a talented copywriter from Connecticut, to set aside her fears about crime in Manhattan and take the train into the city for a job interview.   In the short walk to Ms. Laniado's office from Grand Central Terminal, Ms. Brainin's wallet was stolen from her purse. "She spent the first half hour of the interview on the phone with the police and the credit card companies reporting the theft," recalled Ms. Laniado. "Needless to say, it was not exactly the best way to start the interview."

headline: Fed Penalizes Italian Bank
abstract: Federal regulators penalized an Italian bank today that had made secret loans to Iraq through its Atlanta office.   Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, the state-owned bank, consented to a Federal Reserve order requiring it to increase its reserve on deposit at the Fed by $5.2 million for 18 months.   The American central bank pays no interest on reserves, and its action means that during the period, which expires on Sept. 16, 1992, the Italian bank cannot use $5.2 million it would lend or invest at a profit.   According to information gathered by the House Banking Committee and presented at an October hearing, the Atlanta office approved $2.9 billion in loans to Iraq. The loans had not been authorized by United States regulators or by Banca Nazionale's American headquarters in New York or the parent office in Rome. About $1.8 billion was disbursed.

headline: IRAQ ELITE ROUTED, U.S. SOLDIERS SAY
abstract: American troops described a ferocious armored battle between the United States and troops of Iraq's Republican Guards that resulted, they said in interviews tonight, in devastating losses for the Iraqis and a torrent of thousands of battle-weary Iraqi prisoners of war.    In battlefield interviews with troops from three of the four Army divisions involved in the assault on the guards, American soldiers said that the tank clash raged across dozens of miles of the southern Iraqi desert. Speaking before President Bush ordered military operations suspended, the soldiers said that the Iraqi guards were offering fierce resistance despite overwhelming odds.

headline: French Company Makes Bid Of $1.8 Billion for Square D
abstract: The Square D Company, a big electrical-equipment manufacturer that has been the object of much takeover speculation in recent months, said today that a French company had proposed acquiring it for roughly $1.8 billion.   Square D, based in Palatine, Ill., outside Chicago, made its announcement after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, where Square D shares rose $1.75, to $52, compared with the bid of $78 a share. The stock is expected to open sharply higher on Wednesday, but whether it actually rises to $78 will depend on investors' perception of the chances that the bidder, Groupe Schneider, another giant electrical-equipment manufacturer, will succeed.

headline: Bank of America Cuts Prime Rate to 8 3/4%
abstract: The Bank of America, the nation's second-largest bank after Citibank, said yesterday that it was cutting its prime lending rate to 8 3/4 percent from 9 percent.    The cut by the huge San Francisco-based bank, which takes effect today, comes less than three weeks after many banks lowered their rates from 9 1/2 percent, and less than two months after all of the nation's largest banks, almost in unison, cut their prime rates to 9 1/2 percent from 10 percent.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: The "All About" column last Sunday, on the medical supply business, misstated 1990 sales of two privately held companies. The A. Stuart Company said its sales were $750 million in the calendar year 1990. The General Medical Corporation also had sales of $750 million, which brought total health-related revenues of its parent company, R.A.B. Holdings Inc., to $2.2 billion

headline: Bouygues Ends Maxwell Suit
