abstract: The French construction company Bouygues S.A., the main shareholder in the French television station TF1, last week withdrew its suit against the British publisher Robert Maxwell over his sale of a stake in the television station.   Bouygues said the issue had been settled after Goldman, Sachs & Company sold the 10 percent stake in TF1 it had purchased from Mr. Maxwell to a group of Bouygues allies. The block of 2.6 million shares was sold for about $58 each.

headline: Bass Stake Is Cut
abstract: Members of the Bass family said they had reduced their holdings in the First Executive Corporation to 4.9 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said it had sold a total of 650,000 depositary preference shares and 60,000 convertible shares. First Executive, a Los Angeles insurance holding company, has been troubled by the falling value of its investments, a substantial portion of which are high-risk "junk bonds."

headline: Iraq: Domestic and Diplomatic Concern
abstract: President Bush's warning to Iraq on Wednesday to stop combat operations against insurgent forces reflects a strong and recurring desire in the Administration to bring Saddam Hussein's rule to an end, but to do so without crossing the line to direct intervention on the part of the 100,000 United States Army troops that continue to occupy southern Iraq.   As the cease-fire discussions drift and as the Army occupies 15 percent of Iraq, and flies over the rest of it daily, according to Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney, Administration officials say there is a strong current to use presidential rhetoric, threats and pressure to keep President Hussein guessing about American intentions. That uncertainty, officials say, will make him think twice about the means he uses to restore order in Iraq.

headline: Silver Prices Drop Sharply; Gasoline Up on Supply Data
abstract: Silver futures prices fell sharply yesterday, erasing Tuesday's gains, after the market failed to rise above recent highs. Other precious metals prices also fell.   Gasoline futures surged on a mixed day for the energy markets; grains and soybeans were mostly lower, and livestock and meat futures fell.

headline: Chrysler Dividend Is Halved
abstract: The board of the Chrysler Corporation cut the auto maker's regular quarterly dividend in half today, to 15 cents a share from 30 cents.   The action, taken at the board's regular monthly meeting in New York, was widely expected by financial analysts. It will save Chrysler roughly $33 million quarterly.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Press; Pentagon Moves to Widen Reporters' Access to Gulf Ground Units
abstract: The American command in the Persian Gulf said today that in response to a week of protests it was broadening opportunities for reporters to cover front-line combat units.    Capt. R. E. Wildermuth of the Navy, the top public information officer in the war zone, said five seven-member pools -- groups of reporters supervised by military escorts who share their information with colleagues in the rear -- would be converted to coverage of ground forces within a week. That would double the number of correspondents assigned to the ground units, which would play the central part in any offensive against President Saddam Hussein's forces in Kuwait.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Military; U.S. Says Early Air Attack Caught Iraq Off Guard
abstract: Iraq's air defense command was caught off guard at the outset of the Persian Gulf war by a combination of tactical surprise and nighttime stealth air attacks in which unmanned cruise missiles were used to protect allied pilots, military officials and analysts said today.    In setting priorities for the initial phase of the war, United States military commanders put the highest priority on eliminating Iraqi defenses against air attack, which could have threatened the allies' air superiority as they destroyed key military targets, including fixed Scud-B missile launchers.

headline: Furor Erupts Over Hong Kong Plan
abstract: Plans for a new airport here have led to a furor over who now speaks for this British colony's 5.7 million people -- Britain or China, which is scheduled to take control in 1997.   Hong Kong's British Governor is to visit Beijing on Monday and is expected to tell the Chinese authorities that the project will proceed, despite their angry objections.

headline: Township Squatters Build, Bit by Bit
abstract: Edith Silayi, her worn brown sweater snugly fastened with a safety pin, sat hammering a twisted strip of corrugated metal. Once it took usable shape, the metal would be added to the roof of her new dwelling.   "You start with one room so you can put up a bed," Mrs. Silayi explained in Xhosa. "When you get more material, you put up a kitchen, until you have a good space."

headline: Judge Rules On Northrop
abstract: A Federal court today dismissed part of a lawsuit that charged the Northrop Corporation with falsifying records on the Stealth bomber program, costing the Pentagon billions of dollars.   The suit was brought by four former Northrop employees.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Troops; U.S. Investigates Whether Marines Were Killed by American Jets
abstract: The Pentagon said today that it was investigating whether some of the marines who died during clashes with Iraqi troops this week were killed by fire from American jets, but officials warned that the investigation might prove inconclusive.   As the Pentagon officials spoke, press reports from Saudi Arabia today cited instances in which coalition forces fired dangerously close to their allies during the intense fighting of the last few days.

headline: Early-Month Vehicle Sales Down 23.6%
abstract: Sales of domestically made cars and light trucks dropped 23.6 percent earlier in the month as most buyers remained out of the market because of concerns over war and the weak economy.    Dealers and automotive analysts have been saying that most sales in the last month were to fleets and to customers forced to buy a new vehicle, as opposed to those trading in for a newer or more luxurious model.

headline: War Cuts Companies' Trips Abroad
abstract: Most globe-trotting executives will be staying home for a while. With war raging in the Persian Gulf, many large corporations have banned travel to the Middle East and greatly curtailed other international travel, officials of several dozen top companies said.    At many companies, permission for international trips deemed essential for business must come from senior-level executives. Domestic travel has apparently not been affected.

headline: Ex-LeBow Associates In Turnaround Venture
abstract: William Weksel, a former chairman of the Liggett Group and a business associate of the investor Bennett S. LeBow, has struck out on his own with another former LeBow executive, Robert H. Davies, to start a management turnaround company.    Mr. Weksel, who is 54, and Mr. Davies, 37, have established Weksel, Davies & Company in New York. They intend to seek out underperforming industrial companies with sales of $50 million to $400 million. The object will be to take a role in the managements of the companies, invest capital if it is needed, and "do all the elements that you have to do to make the company healthy again," Mr. Weksel said.

headline: The Prince a Corporate Raider? No, Just Joking
abstract: Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, the 35-year-old Saudi who is investing $590 million in Citicorp, once declared in an effusive moment that he would "love to be a corporate raider."   Prince Waleed was said to be unavailable in Saudi Arabia yesterday, but his advisers were assuring Citicorp that the remark in 1988 to a reporter for Forbes magazine was made in jest.

headline: Philip Morris Net Rose By 2% in Fourth Quarter
abstract: The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest consumer-products company and the maker of Marlboro cigarettes, said yesterday that its earnings inched up only 2 percent in the fourth quarter.    The rise is small, though, mainly because of special items in the 1989 period. Without those items, quarterly earnings would have risen 23.8 percent, Philip Morris said.

headline: Low Oil Prices Are Bad, Some U.S. Experts Say
abstract: American oil experts are closely watching a fractious OPEC as it meets in its first session since the Persian Gulf war, with many hoping for the same things that some OPEC members want: a new agreement that will hold down production, so prices will stabilize or rise.    Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and other members abandoned all production restraints during the war to stop prices from getting out of control. Now that the war is over, they are arguing over who should cut back and by how much.

headline: Markets Closed
abstract: All financial and commodity markets in the United States will be closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday. Government offices, most banks and many businesses will also be closed.

headline: Hotel Executive to Run New Burger King Unit
abstract: Completing a management alignment undertaken by its British owners, the Burger King Corporation has named a hotel executive, Barry L. Conrad, to direct the franchise side of the business.    Mr. Conrad, who will head Burger King's newly created USA Franchise division, will be responsible for the profitability, growth and development of the chain's more than 4,500 franchised restaurants in the United States, which represent 85 percent of Burger King's business.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; HUSSEIN IS DEFIANT AS RAIDS CONTINUE
abstract: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, defiant on the second day of devastating air strikes aimed at forcing his troops from Kuwait, played one of the most powerful cards in his hand by launching missile attacks against Israel.    In a speech broadcast on Baghdad radio and television earlier on Thursday, Mr. Hussein said that the "mother of all battles had begun." He predicted the defeat of President Bush, whom he called "the Satan in the White House," and of "treacherous" King Fahd of Saudi Arabia.

headline: Doing Business Screen to Screen
abstract: By most measures, the business of holding video conferences was a boom waiting to happen. Thanks to an unpredictable confluence of events, ranging from the Persian Gulf crisis, to corporate curtailment of foreign and domestic travel, to a sizable drop in the cost of meeting screen-to-screen, video conference rooms are filling up.    "It's incredible," says Holly Owens, director of the Sprint Meeting Channel, a unit of U S Sprint based in Atlanta. One big company, she said, has reserved meeting times in 900 video conference rooms on the Sprint network between now and July. The company expects to hold 140 meetings between managers in the United States and foreign cities. "We've never seen anything like that before," Ms. Owens said. "Video conferencing was popular before, but nothing like it has been since January 15," shortly before war erupted in the Persian Gulf.

headline: Many Kuwaiti Installations Are Reported in Good Shape
abstract: The damage done to Kuwait's basic installations by retreating Iraqi soldiers appears to be less severe than first thought, Government officials and Western diplomats said today.    In separate interviews, Kuwait's Finance and Planning Ministers said that many of the country's highways and bridges were in surprisingly good shape. They said that 12 days after Iraqi forces were evicted by allied troops, Kuwait was beginnning to show signs of revival.

headline: Food Shortages, Now Violence Make Soviet Investing Dicier
abstract: At the same time as war engulfs the Middle East, the Soviet Union continues to unravel both politically and economically. After five years, the democratic reforms and economic liberalization initiated by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev seem to be backfiring, threatening, among other things, the future of thousands of joint-venture plans between Western and Soviet enterprises, only a small fraction of which are in place.    Last month, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Schevardnadze resigned, expressing fears that the country was moving toward dictatorship. A week ago, Soviet troops moved tanks and machine guns into Lithuania, killing 15 demonstrators among the thousands demanding independence for the republic. The violence touched off protests throughout the country and around the world. Despite roadblocks, hundreds of thousands of ethnic Russians, Poles and Byelorussians walked to Vilnius later in the week to attend the funerals of the demonstrators and quietly protest Moscow's rule. To surpress criticism of his administration for its actions in Lithuania, President Gorbachev advocated suspending a law that guarantees a free press. The White House said the Soviet Army's actions threatened next month's summit meeting between the two heads of state.

headline: Czechs Begin Shift to a Free Market
abstract: Today, Czechoslovakia is taking a daring leap toward private enterprise, aimed at making it the second East European nation after Poland to scrap its rickety Communist economic structure.    Czechoslovakia's move borrows heavily from the radical overhaul that Poland began last Jan. 1, and after a year of careful preparation, policy makers in Prague hope that the country of the Velvet Revolution can now undergo a comfortable transition to a market economy.

headline: Changsha Journal; In China's Cities, the Busybodies Are Organized
abstract: When Wang Xingzhou's wife threatened to divorce him, he ran down the block to the street committee. Soon a team of elderly women filed into his tiny apartment and showered his wife with a dozen reasons why the couple should stay together.    Their foreheads wrinkled with concern, the women offered to buy winter coal for the wife whenever the husband had to be out of town. They pleaded that, for the sake of the three children, the couple not separate.

headline: Wheat, Corn and Soybeans Are All Hit Hard in a Selloff
abstract: Prices of grain and soybean futures closed sharply lower yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.   Leading the selloff were wheat futures, which were sold in anticipation of heavy weekend rains in the plains region that produces hard red winter wheat.

headline: Patents; Bouncing Messages Off Meteor Trails
abstract: Hoping to offer a lower-cost alternative to satellites for long- distance communication, a start-up company in New Jersey patented a system this week that bounces messages off tiny meteor trails that each last only a few seconds before disappearing.   Developed by Broadcom Inc. of Mahwah, the system cannot transmit television or telephone conversations. But the company said it could relay about 500 words of text every two seconds, using transmitters and receivers, each of which costs less than $1,500. As with a satellite, company officials say, the new system would allow communication with the most remote places on earth. But it would be far cheaper because satellites, which often cost several hundred million dollars to build and launch, are unneeded in these cases.   The underlying principles of the technology, known as "meteorburst," were well established by military researchers in the 1950's. But the technology never entered widespread use because of severe limitations. Inventors of the new system contend that they have overcome the obstacles and already have an experimental system in operation.   The technology uses the trails of charged particles, which continually appear and disappear as grain-sized meteorite specks bombard the earth's atmosphere and disintegrate. During their short lifetimes, they will reflect radio signals like a mirror. To bounce signals to a particular location, a sender has to find a trail that is positioned at the proper angle.   The systems essentially search for such trails, then fire off a brief message when they find one. The problem, however, is that the trails fade so quickly that the systems have thus far been unable to send more than a few words in a single burst.   The new system is designed to pack 100 times more data over each trail. For starters, it links as many as 10 low-powered transmitters, which each send identical messages in a combined signal. In addition, the system tightly focuses its radio beam on a particular trail, rather than broadcasting a wide beam that blankets the sky. According to the company, both moves create a more intense signal that can use each trail for a longer time and pack more data into each burst.   The company hopes to sell its equipment to corporations that want long-distance mobile communications systems for trucks, trains and people working in remote areas.   Charles J. Schmidt and Joseph Kadin, officials at Broadcom, and S. Eugene Poteat, a consultant, received patent 4,985,707.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Boston Five Bancorp Inc., Boston, named Peter J. Blampied chairman. He will continue to serve as president and chief executive. * Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta, named Lance E. Disley vice president and treasurer.

headline: Minority Auto Dealers Face More Than Just the Recession
abstract: The automobile industry is in its deepest slump in years, leaving many established dealers struggling just to keep their doors open. For Tim Turner, who is black, the odds for success are especially steep. Minority-owned car dealerships have been failing at double the rate for all dealers. Of those minority dealers still in business, proportionately fewer are turning profits compared with their white counterparts.   The difficulties faced by minority dealers pose problems for the Big Three domestic auto makers, which for years have been trying to increase the number of such dealerships. They want to appeal to black and other minority customers, who represent a small but growing market that is needed at a time when sales are lagging and Japanese rivals are eroding market share.

headline: Several Midlevel Shifts Are Announced by G.M.
abstract: The General Motors Corporation yesterday announced a series of medium-tier executive changes.   The moves, approved by the G.M. board, "will further strengthen G.M.'s marketing and manufacturing operations," Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman, said.

headline: Data Bank/February 24, 1991
abstract: Housing Starts   Jan.   Dec.   Nov.        Thousands of units, annual rate   850   975   1,127        Consumer Price Index                Monthly percent change   0.4   0.3   0.3        Consumer Price Index (excluding food, energy)                Monthly percent change   0.8   0.4   0.3        Municipal Bonds (Bond Buyer Index)   Feb. 22   Feb. 15   Feb. 8        Yield in percent   7.33   7.21   7.18       Auto Production   Feb. 15   Feb. 8   Feb. 1        In units, weekly total   85,677   109,567   118,738        Truck Production                In units, weekly total   46,682   35,636   55,461        Electric Power                Millions of kilowatt hours, weekly total   --0.7   0.2   0.4       Lumber Production   Dec.   Nov.   Oct.        Millions of board feet   2,667   3,412   4,015

headline: Bungamati Journal; A Town So Old, Communism Is Hope of Future
abstract: Over the hills and far away in Eastern Europe, democratic elections have ended a Communist era. Here, in a 16th-century red-brick town where corn hangs out to dry under the eaves in the golden winter sun and men wrapped in shawls warm themselves on the steps of the village temple, a lot of people say they believe that Communism is the hope of the future.   In Bungamati, said Asha Moru Shakya, a 68-year-old farmer, the Communists will get most of the votes when in a few months Nepal holds its first open-contest, democratic election in more than 30 years after a long period of "partyless" royal government.

headline: Technology; Using Biological 'Fire' To Turn Waste Into Fertilizer
abstract: With landfills closing and high-technology incinerators unpopular in many areas, some communities are turning to nature's way of getting rid of solid waste: composting.   Not all trash can be composted, but as much as 70 percent of typical municipal solid waste is a candidate for the process. Yard wastes alone, the leaves, brush and grass clippings that accumulate in suburban areas, account for 18 percent of all solid waste, according to the Environmental Protection Agency. In the spring and fall, when lawns are mowed for the first time or fallen leaves are collected, that percentage spikes far higher.

headline: Super Bowl 25: The Football Hoopla Yields to Hype
abstract: When the Super Bowl breaks for half time three weeks from today, Walt Disney World and Coca-Cola will take the field with a 12-minute show featuring New Kids on the Block, the teen-age pop group, and thousands of singing and dancing children. Throughout the game, television viewers will be bombarded with 28 minutes of network commercials, bringing ABC about $45 million in revenues. And when the game ends, the most valuable player will be given a Buick, part of a frenzy of product tie-ins involving everything from computers to beer.   Football hoopla aside, Super Bowl Sunday has another claim to fame: it is the biggest day of the year for many advertisers.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Tactics; U.S. Says Night Raiding Costs Iraq More Tanks
abstract: Senior United States military officials here and in Washington say that American planes are using a new night-fighting tactic to destroy as many as 200 top-line Iraqi battle tanks a day.    Using a technique that combines laser-guided bombs and enhanced night-vision sensors in a new way, American fighter-bombers have in the last week increased as much as fourfold the number of Iraqi T-62 and T-72 tanks destroyed or disabled each day, a senior officer said.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   9.50   9.5-10   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.50   6.50   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   7.25   7.12   8.31        3-MO. TREAS. headline: Apartheid Foes to Rally At Parliament Opening
abstract: The African National Congress and its allies have called on supporters to stay away from work and join large demonstrations on Friday to protest the opening of Parliament, from which South Africa's black majority remains excluded.    But plans for a march on Parliament by thousands of opponents of apartheid suffered a setback when Nelson Mandela, the Congress's deputy president, canceled a planned appearance and speech. Congress officials attributed the 72-year-old leader's withdrawal to a heavy schedule elsewhere and the resulting strains on his health. His place at the head of the march will be taken by his colleague Walter Sisulu.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; IRAQ ORDERS TROOPS TO LEAVE KUWAIT BUT U.S. PURSUES BATTLEFIELD GAINS; HEAVY AMERICAN TOLL IN SCUD ATTACK
abstract: The Baghdad radio announced tonight that Iraq had ordered its occupation army to withdraw from Kuwait, but the Bush Administration parried the move and said the war would continue.    With Iraqi forces taking severe losses, Baghdad broke into its regular broadcasting at 1:35 A.M. Iraqi time (5:30 Eastern time) Tuesday to say: "Orders have been issued to our armed forces to withdraw in an organized manner to the positions held prior to Aug. 1, 1990. This is regarded as practical compliance with Resolution 660."

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Syria; Iraqi Dissidents in Syria Reflecting Damascus's Complex Policy on War
abstract: Akram el-Hakim dreams of overthrowing President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in the name of Islam. Fakhri Kareem nurtures the same hope, though for him, it is Karl Marx, not divinity, that provides the inspiration.   The two men are part of Iraq's disparate exiled opposition, thrown together in an odd coalition formed here on Dec. 27 as a putative alternative to President Hussein in a postwar Iraq. As their presence in Damascus suggests, they reflect a part of Syria's complex aims as it confronts the challenges, the opportunities and the losses of the war in the Persian Gulf.

headline: New Setback in Jesuit Case in Salvador
abstract: In the face of new accusations in the United States Congress that the Salvadoran Defense Minister and high command are obstructing the investigation into the slaying of six Jesuit priests, the two principal prosecutors in the case have resigned and have accused the Attorney General's Office of interference.   The prosecutors, Edward Sidney Blanco Reyes and Alvaro Henry Campos Solorzano, said today that they resigned on Tuesday because the armed forces were preventing a broad investigation of the slayings and because the Attorney General's Office had stopped them from pursuing officers who committed perjury.

headline: Bid for NCR Is Extended
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today extended its offer for NCR Corporation stock. NCR said the $90-a-share cash tender offer was still inadequate.   A.T.& T. began the $6.1 billion hostile takeover bid in December, seeking to gain strength in the computer market by acquiring NCR, the nation's No. 5 computer company.    The new expiration date of A.T.& T.'s tender offer is April 30 at midnight. The company said it reserved the right to shorten the period.   A.T.& T., based in New York, said it had received tenders for about 66 percent of NCR's outstanding common shares. The company said it was advised by the depository for the shares, First Chicago Trust of New York, that more than 42.4 million shares had been tendered by midnight Friday. The company had reported on Jan. 16 that 70 percent of NCR's shares had been tendered, meaning that about 4 percent of the shares have since been withdrawn.   "This was an expected market reaction to the fact that A.T.& T. is not yet in a position to buy the shares because NCR's anti-takeover devices are still in place," A.T.& T. said.   But NCR said its shareholders were supporting its position that A.T.& T.'s offer is too low.

headline: Dominant Emotion: Anger at the U.S.
abstract: As Iraqis danced in the streets of Baghdad in response to President Saddam Hussein's speech ordering a withdrawal from Kuwait, Palestinians and Jordanians, who had been his ardent supporters, seemed stunned, bewildered and enraged today.   Those turbulent emotions were quickly fused into a general anger transferred to the Americans seen as the architects of his, and their, humiliation.   "You Americans, you are all liars," said a Jordanian officer who displayed increasing bewilderment, then hostility, as he listened to the speech with Western reporters at the Ruweishid border crossing into Iraq.   Many in Amman at first refused to believe the news, telephoning international news agencies to inquire whether it was not some kind of hoax. In their heart of hearts, many had known that the Iraqi leader could not prevail. What hurt was the speed of his collapse. Baghdad Radio's Message     When Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, President Hussein quickly linked his action to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, insisting that a pullout be linked to an Israeli withdrawal from occupied Arab lands.   "It looked like Gamal Abdel Nasser coming back," said Nabil Shaath, a senior adviser to Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization. "It looked like a knight with shining armor, the hero fighting the Americans."   For the six weeks of the war, a Western specialist said, Palestinians had chosen to believe the central message of the Baghdad radio's propaganda: allied airplanes might prowl the skies, but Iraq's ground forces, tested in the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war, had the skills to resist an allied offensive.   Then, two days after allied troops pressed forward into Kuwait, Iraq announced its withdrawal. 'Longer Fight' Expected     Reached by telephone in Cairo, Mr. Shaath said that eventually President Hussein's move "will be seen as a very prudent move." But, he acknowledged, "people expected a longer fight."

headline: Top Ogilvy Executive Resigns in Chicago
abstract: Bruce Beach has resigned as executive vice president and managing director of Ogilvy & Mather's Chicago office, a position he held for three years.   Graham Phillips, chairman and chief executive of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, said Mr. Beach had left "to pursue other interests" and did not resign because the Chicago office lost the $35 million Nutrasweet domestic advertising account in December.    "I've spent the last four weeks trying to persuade Bruce to stay," Mr. Phillips said. "This has absolutely nothing to do with the Nutrasweet business."   Tom Hall, currently president and executive creative director in the Chicago office, will head the office as president and chief executive.

headline: Wall Street; Industrial Pressures Hit the Metals Markets
abstract: Since at least mid-1989, the precious metals have tended to take their lumps in unison. But more recently, that has started to change, with gold meandering along a dull but steady course while platinum, palladium and silver sink like rocks.   This divergence suggests that industrial users, not investors, are becoming the key arbiters of price trends in the glittery metals markets. Platinum and palladium, used in automobile catalytic converters, are slumping because of anticipated declines in car production. Silver is expected to feel a recessionary pinch on several fronts, from flatware to photography.

headline: Dow Up 2.73 Points After a Slow Session
abstract: Stocks edged ahead yesterday for their second consecutive gain, but activity continued to be extremely light.    Practically all of the gain in the Dow Jones industrial average came from Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, the producer of Scotch tape, which rose 2, to 81 5/8. It said it had invested in Forstmann Little & Company, the leveraged buyout firm.

headline: Germans Criticize Handling of Report on Official's Role as Informer
abstract: The German Government's attempt to rehabilitate the former East German Prime Minister, Lothar de Maiziere, despite evidence that he was once a police informant has set off protests and led to the dismissal of two officials investigating the former government's secret police.   "Everyone from eastern Germany who applies for even a job in the post office has to swear that he never served the old East German regime," said Stefan Wolle, one of the two who were dismissed. "But de Maiziere was an important informant, and yet he is welcomed back into public life. People in the east are very upset about it."

headline: Pope Sees Walesa; Urges Aid
abstract: Warmly welcoming Lech Walesa to the Vatican as both the new President of Poland and a Roman Catholic pilgrim, Pope John Paul II appealed to wealthy nations today to help his fellow Poles through the financial hardships afflicting their young democracy.   Poland's foreign debt "should be treated in the spirit of international solidarity and in the light of the church's social doctrine," the Pope said, calling for "the understanding and cooperation of rich countries."

headline: Omnicom Seeks Stake in British Agency
abstract: THE OMNICOM GROUP, the giant agency network that includes BBDO and DDB Needham, is negotiating to buy a minority stake in Abbott Mead Vickers, a highly regarded London agency known for its innovative ads for clients like Volvo and J. Sainsbury, a leading British supermarket.    David Abbott, the chairman of Abbott Mead, said he could not discuss any possible deal. But in an announcement in London yesterday, the agency confirmed that there had talks that "might result in a closer relationship" with Omnicom.

headline: Chrysler Raising Some Rebates
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation increased rebates on some of its cars and mini-vans, as it continues to be haunted by slow sales. Among the changes announced, the company doubled the rebates to $1,000 on the Chrysler Imperial, New Yorker Fifth Avenue, Lebaron sedan, Plymouth Acclaim and Dodge Spirit. It also increased rebates on 1989 and 1990 models of its standard and extended-length Dodge and Plymouth minivans.   Chrysler is expected to report its fourth-quarter results next Thursday. Wall Street analysts have speculated that the auto maker will report a loss of about $50 million.

headline: Jewish Emigration Resuming This Week, Ethiopians Say
abstract: The Ethiopian Embassy here said today that the emigration of Ethiopian Jews to Israel would resume this week after a sudden pause that gave rise to concern in Israel and the United States.   The embassy said over 500 Ethiopian Jews had been given exit visas and would leave for Israel as soon as travel arrangements were made.   The pause, it said, was caused by "technical irregularities" in questionnaires required by Ethiopian and Israeli authorities to process the emigration. The Ethiopian statement accused Israel of cheating on the questionnaires by using the same forms over and over.

headline: Theme of Reaction: Unshaken Unity
abstract: Amid reports of early successes from the battlefront, Prime Minister John Major said tonight that "things seem to be going very well indeed" for allied troops in the long-awaited ground offensive for Kuwait.    But in brief remarks outside 10 Downing Street, Mr. Major said that while the war should be "relatively short," optimism must be tempered with caution. "This is a very early stage of the campaign," said Mr. Major, who had earlier spent 15 minutes on the telephone with President Bush.

headline: Bush's Letter to Congressional Leaders
abstract: Following is the text of President Bush's letter today to Bob Dole, Senate minority leader; Speaker Thomas S. Foley; George J. Mitchell, Senate majority leader, and Robert H. Michel, the Republican leader in the House:    The current situation in the Persian Gulf, brought about by Iraq's unprovoked invasion and subsequent brutal occupation of Kuwait, threatens vital U.S. interests. The situation also threatens the peace. It would, however, greatly enhance the chances for peace if Congress were now to go on record supporting the position adopted by the U.N. Security Council on 12 separate occasions. Such an action would underline that the United States stands with the international community and on the side of law and decency; it also would help dispel any belief that may exist in the minds of Iraq's leaders that the United States lacks the necessary unity to act decisively in response to Iraq's continued aggression against Kuwait.   Secretary of State Baker is meeting with Iraq's Foreign Minister on Jan. 9. It would have been most constructive if he could have presented the Iraqi Government a Resolution passed by both houses of Congress supporting the U.N. position and in particular Security Council Resolution 678. As you know, I have frequently stated my desire for such a Resolution. Nevertheless, there is still opportunity for Congress to act to strengthen the prospects for peace and safeguard this country's vital interests.   I therefore request that the House of Representatives and the Senate adopt a Resolution stating that Congress supports the use of all necessary means to implement U.N. Security Council Resolution 678. Such action would send the clearest possible message to Saddam Hussein that he must withdraw without condition or delay from Kuwait. Anything less would only encourage Iraqi intransigence; anything else would risk detracting from the international coalition arrayed against Iraq's aggression.   I am determined to do whatever is necessary to protect America's security. I ask Congress to join with me in this task. I can think of no better way than for Congress to express its support for the President at this critical time. This truly is the last best chance for peace.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; Allies Destroy Iraqis' Main Force; Kuwait Is Retaken After 7 Months
abstract: Hours before President Bush announced the conditional suspension of offensive military operations in the Persian Gulf, allied armored units trapped Iraq's vaunted Republican Guard and cut it to pieces in a ferocious tank battle that began Wednesday and raged until early this morning, American officials said.    At midday Wednesday, United States marines captured the Kuwait International Airport after a smaller but nonetheless intense two-day fight, and later marines, Kuwaiti and other Arab troops rode in triumph down the broad boulevards of Kuwait City, past scenes of devastation and desolation. That essentially completed the expulsion of President Saddam Hussein's forces from Kuwait, which they had overrun in a surprise assault last Aug. 2.

headline: Administration Presents Its Plan For Broad Overhaul of Banking
abstract: The Bush Administration today formally presented its plan for the most sweeping overhaul of the nation's banking system since the Great Depression.   The proposal, the broad outlines of which had been widely known here for weeks, offers the nation's commercial banking system a competitive landscape unrestrained by many of the barriers and regulations that were installed by the Government after the national banking crisis in the 1930's.

headline: Former Keating Associate Pleads Guilty to Bond Fraud
abstract: The former president of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association pleaded guilty today to two Federal securities fraud charges in connection with the criminal investigation of the defunct institution and its former owner, Charles H. Keating Jr.   The charges against Raymond C. Fidel related to the sale of high-yield "junk bonds" issued by Lincoln's parent company, the Phoenix-based American Continental Corporation, which Mr. Keating headed.

headline: France Will Pursue Peace Till 16th, Mitterrand Says
abstract: France will pursue its independent diplomatic efforts to find a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis until the morning of Jan. 16, when a United Nations mandate clears the way to use force to push Iraqi troops out of Kuwait, President Francois Mitterrand said tonight. But he warned that unless Iraqi troops withdrew by then, war "is practically certain" and that France would join it.    Mr. Mitterrand spoke at a news conference before talks concluded in Geneva between Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. A few moments later Mr. Baker announced that the talks had produced no change in the position of either side, but there was no further comment from Mr. Mitterrand or his spokesmen.

headline: As Collor Completes First Year, Brazilians Write Off Their Highest Hopes
abstract: One year ago, Brazilians watched with expectation as Fernando Collor de Mello donned the presidential sash here and vowed to bring Latin America's largest nation into the first world, following a road of low inflation and free-market economics.   As the anniversary of the inauguration passes on March 15, the 41-year-old President's first-year report card in the Brazilian press speaks of a year of disappointment.

headline: Control Data Sells A Chip Factory
abstract: The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation said it had purchased an advanced semiconductor manufacturing plant from the Control Data Corporation for $14.7 million.    T.J. Rodgers, chief executive of Cypress, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said his company was able to buy the "gold plated" factory at a bargain price and had hired 75 of the employees that work there. He said the factory, in Bloomington, Minn., cost $60 million to build and was used, among other things, to produce chips for the National Security Agency, the Government's code-breaking organization. Control Data had previously said it would leave the semiconductor business.

headline: O.K., Flabby Press Corps, 32 Pushups for Uncle Sam
abstract: Worried that too many reporters are too far out of shape to cover a war, Pentagon officials have imposed a physical fitness test on journalists who wish to be sent out with American troops if there is battle with Iraq.    The test, which some journalists say has frightened them more than Saddam Hussein ever did, requires the reporters to meet the standards the military sets for its own men and women for sit-ups, pushups and a mile-and-a-half run.

headline: Economic Scene; Cheap Oil, Expensive Cartel
abstract: SAUDI ARABIA, the muscle behind the international oil cartel, made no secret of its aims at the meeting of OPEC ministers in Geneva last week: keeping the price of a barrel high enough to replenish its war-depleted treasury -- but not high enough to weaken the magic kingdom's grip on the market.   America, the muscle behind Saudi Arabia, is of two minds about the price of oil. On the one hand, policy makers worry that low prices would discommode their friends from Abu Dhabi to Houston. On the other, they fret that high prices would slow recovery from the recession and anger voters who believe deep down that Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf was fighting to make the world safe for unleaded regular at $1.06 a gallon.

headline: Patents; A New Artificial Hip Is Said to Last Longer
abstract: Stephen M. Horowitz, an orthopedic surgeon at the University of Pennsylvania, won patent approval this week for an artificial hip that he said would outlast those now being used.    Almost half of artificial hips fail within 15 years because stresses loosen the cement that binds the artificial hip to bone. To address that problem, Dr. Horowitz invented a prosthesis that he said combined the best features of synthetic cement and natural bone growth.

headline: JERUSALEM ARABS SUE OVER A HOUSE
abstract: A Palestinian family has filed suit against a Jewish seminary in the Old City's Muslim quarter over rights to a house that stood empty for 22 years until Israelis moved in over the weekend.   The house was seized by the military in 1969, and the Palestinian owners have repeatedly requested its return. But last week, after a Jewish theological student was found in the basement with his throat cut, other seminary students moved in.

headline: Farm-Trade Talks Are Set To Resume
abstract: A crucial round of world trade talks that broke up in disarray last December came alive again today after the European Community countries accepted an American-backed approach for dealing with the issue of agricultural subsidies.    Officials at the Geneva headquarters of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said a meeting of the 108-nation Trade Negotiating Committee scheduled for next Tuesday should mark the formal resumption of the talks known as the Uruguay Round.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: The assets of the nation's 534 money market mutual funds increased by $926.8 million, to $460.7 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 163 institutional funds increased by $1.27 billion, to $130.02 billion. The 269 general-purpose funds were down by $283.1 million, to $157.44 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds decreased by $63.6 million, to $173.23 billion, the institute said.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: General Assembly SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON U.N. CHARTER -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Publishing Appointment
abstract: Mark McCormack, chairman and chief executive of International Management Group, based in New York, announced yesterday that Arthur Klebanoff would become vice president of IMG Publishing, in charge of the group's newly founded literary agency division.   Mr. Klebanoff, who is 43 years old, has run his own literary agency for the past seven years. A graduate of Yale College and Harvard Law School, Mr. Klebanoff was one of the founders in 1978 of Morton L. Janklow Associates Inc., the literary agency.   International Management Group, with 42 offices in 19 countries, represents such athletes as Martina Navratilova, Chris Evert, Jennifer Capriati, Ivan Lendl, Andre Agassi, Monica Sales, Joe Montana, Herschel Walker, Wayne Gretzky, Arnold Palmer and Nancy Lopez.   With IMG Publishing, based in New York, Mr. Klebanoff will represent, among other clients, Ms. Navratilova, Mr. McCormack (the author of the best selling "What They Don't Teach You at Harvard Business School"), John Madden, Richard M. Nixon, Itzhak Perlman and Roger Tory Peterson, the nature writer and painter.   Barry Frank, senior group vice president, said that while IMG Publishing is starting with an emphasis on non-fiction, "we intend to grow into all categories of publishing." The belief that publishing offers an opportunity for significant growth derived from a study conducted for International Management Group by Ray Cave, formerly the editorial director of Time Inc.

headline: The Fine Art of Coping With Taxes
abstract: Gregory Russell, a Manhattan artist who works in a youth program through the day so he can paint through the night, is attacking the conflict between finding time to paint and earning enough to pay the rent, by taking a close look at his taxes.   "If I save $500 in taxes, that's $500 I can keep," he said.

headline: Group of Seven Plans Meeting
abstract: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and finance ministers from six other leading countries are planning their first meeting of 1991 for later this month to talk about bringing the Soviet Union closer to the economy of the West, diplomats said today.    It would be the first Group of Seven meeting since September as well as the first for Britain's new Chancellor of the Exchequer, Norman Lamont. His predecessor, John Major, succeeded Margaret Thatcher as Prime Minister last month. The finance ministers of Japan, Germany, France, Italy and Canada are also expected to attend.   The meeting is expected to be held in New York. One diplomat said the ministers' deputies would meet soon to arrange the details.   Besides discussing the Soviet economy, the ministers are also expected to talk about interest rates, which they try to coordinate among the seven countries.

headline: Nicaraguan Aide Says Killer Of Ex-Contra Might Be Dead
abstract: The man who killed a former rebel leader last month might himself be dead, an Interior Ministry spokesman said today.   The spokesman, Frank Cesar, said that the police had briefly held eight people for questioning since the killing of the former rebel, Enrique Bermudez, on Feb. 16, but that no one had been formally charged in the case. All those interrogated have been released, he said.   He said the police were investigating the possibility that the killer was slain by others involved in the plot to assassinate Mr. Bermudez, who was the military leader of the contras, the United States-backed rebel force that battled Nicaragua's leftist Sandinista Government for most the 1980's.    Former contras have accused the Sandinistas of killing Mr. Bermudez. The Sandinistas, who were voted out of power last year, have denied any role in the killing.

headline: I.B.M. Plans Australian Hub
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation has announced plans to establish a major telecommunications networking hub in Australia for the Asia-Pacific region. The move would double I.B.M.'s Sydney-based networking capacity over the next two years.   Hilton McKeener, the company's branch manager in Australia, said the decision emphasized the computer company's confidence in Australia as a regional center for investment.

headline: Brazilian Troops Kill 3 Colombian Guerrillas
abstract: Brazilian troops killed three Colombian guerrillas on Tuesday in a fire fight in the Amazon jungle near the Colombian border, the Brazilian Army said today.    The clash followed an attack by Colombian guerrillas on a Brazilian garrison in the area a week ago. In that attack, the guerrillas reportedly killed three Brazilian soldiers and two Colombian gold miners, wounded 12 soldiers and stole all the garrison's arms.

headline: The Upheavals in the Media
abstract: Though the media are confronted with a host of near-term problems, in general, they will continue to constitute a formidable institution in our lives. Over the course of the 20th century, the media have become the main integrators of our national culture. Older institutions like churches, social organizations, political parties and -- to a certain extent even the family -- have been replaced, at least in part, by the media. No other institution is poised to assume this role.   Even so, much of the media, both print and electronic, is suffering. One explanation for the recent decline in media participation is the demographics of the baby boom. Those people born at the peak of the baby boom -- 1957 -- will be 34 this year. They and their older and younger siblings are hitting their strides in their careers and at home. These people, living in dual-employment families and juggling many time-consuming obligations, simply have less time to devote to reading, watching television and other forms of entertainment.

headline: Consumers' Confidence Dips Again
abstract: Reflecting worry over rising unemployment and the Persian Gulf war, consumer confidence fell again in January, the Conference Board reported yesterday. Not since the early 1980's has the board's monthly survey turned up such pessimism.   Consumer confidence, as measured by the Conference Board and the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center, more or less tracks the ups and downs of the nation's economy by suggesting how willing Americans are to spend. January's low reading indicates that a spending spree is not yet on the horizon to lift the nation out of recession.

headline: Northwest Air in No Hurry to Spend
abstract: While strong airlines like American and United have been jumping to buy the precious international routes that weaker carriers have been forced to sell, Northwest has so far remained on the sidelines, picking up only small pieces.   Northwest, the nation's fourth-largest carrier, certainly appears to be in a position to buy. Moreover, its cash position was strengthened considerably by the decision announced Wednesday by Samuel K. Skinner, the Transportation Secretary, to allow foreign companies to own bigger portions of domestic carriers. As a result, the Dutch airline KLM will be able to keep its 49 percent ownership of Northwest, and Northwest will not have to use $250 million to redeem common shares held by KLM.

headline: Afterward, Make Africa a Priority
abstract: When the war in the Persian Gulf is over, the United States will turn to the other pressing international concerns that need its attention. But there is a growing fear among United Nations, African and other development officials that one vital concern -- the deepening, decade-long economic crisis in Africa -- is unlikely to feature prominently in the post-gulf agenda of the United States and the other major aid-giving powers. Such neglect would deal a severe blow to the profound but largely unreported political and economic reforms being undertaken on the continent -- reforms that are Africa's only hope for reversing what is nothing less than an economic and social nightmare for its peoples.   Even before Jan. 16, when the war in the Persian Gulf began, it was getting increasingly difficult to mobilize the kind of attention from which Africa benefited in the mid-1980's, when a special session of the United Nations put the region firmly at the top of international development concerns. The democratic revolutions of Eastern Europe and the need to financially support their market reforms rapidly pushed Africa down the list of Western priorities. The ending of the Cold War also stripped the continent of its strategic significance to the superpowers. And Africa's puny contribution to international trade made it seem less and less relevant to the economic growth of richer nations.

headline: Japanese Seem Ahead Again on Advanced Chips
abstract: Japanese semiconductor manufacturers appear once again to be ahead in the race to develop advanced computer memory chips, according to papers to be presented at a major technical conference here this week.    At the meeting, the International Solid States Circuits Conference, four Japanese companies will present papers showing working progress on dynamic random access memory chips, or D-RAM's, that can store 64 million bits of information. The four are Fujitsu, Mitsubishi Electric, Matsushita and Toshiba.

headline: IRAQ SAYS U.S. KILLED HUNDREDS OF CIVILIANS AT SHELTER, BUT ALLIES CALL IT MILITARY POST
abstract: Two bombs dropped by American Stealth fighter-bombers destroyed a concrete building in a residential neighborhood of Baghdad yesterday, killing hundreds of civilians, Iraqi officials said.    The Iraqi authorities said the structure had long been a civilian air raid shelter; American officials countered that they had evidence that the structure was a communications center for the command of military forces.

headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: The U.N.; Last-Minute Debating, Then Final Plea to Iraq
abstract: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, made a final personal appeal tonight to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to give up Kuwait and avoid armed conflict in the Persian Gulf.    The Secretary General made his appeal after the Security Council tried but failed to agree on a final message of its own to the Iraqi leader. France insisted that the Council promise to convene a Middle East peace conference to settle the Palestinian problem if Mr. Hussein withdrew, while the United States and Britain rejected any such "linkage" between the two issues.

headline: Old Troubles And New Vex Top Ugandan
abstract: When the President of Uganda, Yoweri K. Museveni, was chosen as chairman of the Organization of African Unity last July, people thought it could mark the entrance of a new-model African leader onto the world stage.    But this has been a rocky period for the 46-year-old Mr. Museveni, a popular national leader since his guerrilla army fought its way to power in this East African nation five years ago.

headline: 6 Iraqi Boats Destroyed
abstract: United States and British helicopters and fighter-bombers today destroyed at least six Iraqi missile-carrying patrol boats in a 12-hour battle in the northern Persian Gulf, British officers said.    British naval planners said they thought the Iraqi boats, some carrying Exocet anti-ship missiles, had been trying to take advantage of poor visibility to escape allied bombing of Iraqi ports.   Among the craft were at least two vessels that carry the Exocet missiles, the British officers said, adding that the six boats were either sunk or left burning and thatthe allies had suffered no casualties. Iraqi casualties were not known.   The officers said three British Lynx helicopters and United States F-18 and A-6 fighter-bombers attacked the six Iraqi boats repeatedly throughout the day. The Lynx pilots reported heavy antiaircraft fire from the boats.   "I believe we may have passed a watershed in the coastal phase of the maritime war," said Commodore Christopher Craig, commander of British naval forces in the gulf. "We have neutralized several of the Iraqi Navy's prime attack vessels."

headline: S.E.C., Firm In a Clash Over Stock
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission and Morgan Stanley & Company squared off yesterday for a legal battle. The commission charged that Morgan improperly sold certain restricted stock during the 1987 market crash, and the investment house replied that the commission's action could undermine the marketplace.   The S.E.C. charges also raised the hackles of one commissioner, Edward H. Fleischman, who contended that in bringing them, the commission was disregarding policy advice it provided in letters to other market participants.

headline: Censors Screen Pooled Reports
abstract: The American-led military command in Saudi Arabia has put into effect press restrictions under which journalists are assembled in small groups and given access to various military sources.   These pool reporters obtain their information while under military escort, and their accounts are subject to scrutiny by military censors before they are distributed. Some of the information appearing today on American military operations was obtained under such circumstances.

headline: Stocks Retreat Broadly As Dow Falls by 23.02
abstract: Stocks sagged broadly yesterday on the first trading session of the new year, despite a jump in bond prices, a big decline in crude oil prices and widespread feeling that the Fed will continue to cut interest rates.    Oil prices slumped $1.95 a barrel, to $26.49, normally enough of a reason for stocks to pick up, but the Dow Jones industrial average slid 23.02 points, or almost 1 percent, to 2,610.64.

headline: Eastern Europe's Historians, Now Free, Face New Burden
abstract: After a half-century of misusing history to provide a cloak of legitimacy to governments imposed by the Soviet Union, historians throughout Central and Eastern Europe are enjoying, most for the first time, the satisfaction of practicing their art in freedom.   Most do so with the enthusiasm of a person rising from a long, disabling illness, with a step that is not always steady and sure. Some say that not all scholars avoid the risk of once again making history serve a political goal. The objective pursued by some is to assert a highly charged nationalism, which was for the most part banned in the Communist era.  History Could Be Deadly    Historians here and in Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, allowing for some national differences, agree that the indispensable requirement for history, a critical spirit among historians and their public, was either destroyed or greatly diminished by the Orwellian ministries of truth that reigned from the end of World War II to the revolutions of 1989 or driven into illegality in which infractions could be punished by death.

headline: Executives Named At Times Group
abstract: The New York Times Company Magazine Group announced two senior publishing appointments yesterday.   Winthrop Stevens was named vice president and group publisher of trade magazines and special services in the Magazine Group's sports/leisure division. And Valerie B. Salembier succeeds Mr. Stevens as senior vice president and publisher of Family Circle magazine.

headline: Modest Prime-Time Hopes
abstract: Executives at the three broadcast networks and at Fox Broadcasting are all describing midseason prime- time programming strategies that are built around not-at-all-great expectations. Page C9.

headline: Market Place; Still More Growth In Biotechnology?
abstract: WITH most of the premier biotechnology stocks at or near 52-week highs, investors face a tricky decision: Is it time to take profits or is there more growth left in the group? There is no unanimity among Wall Street analysts.   While they have at least in part been borne aloft by a bull market, biotechnology stocks have outperformed the market in recent weeks. A string of major product approvals by the Food and Drug Administration has focused investor attention on these companies.

headline: Legislators Take Sides for Combat Or for Reliance on the Sanctions
abstract: Congress today began debating the prospect of war in the Persian Gulf, arguing whether an early attack on Iraq or continued reliance on economic sanctions was more likely to force Iraq out of Kuwait.   A strong sense of history permeated the day's proceedings. The proposal backed by President Bush and the one thought most likely to pass, the "Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Iraq Resolution" was described by a pivotal sponsor, Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democratic of Florida, as the "practical equivalent" of a declaration of war, a step the Congress has taken formally only five times.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Espionage; 2 or 3 Agents Are Believed Killed After Rare U.S.-Syrian Contacts
abstract: Two or three undercover agents believed to be working for Israel in a Syrian-based terrorist group were unmasked and killed last fall, not long after the United States gave the Damascus Government information about terrorist activities in the country, several Bush Administration officials say.   The link between the two events has not been proved. But officials said American experts believe that terrorists obtained the intelligence information given to Syrian leaders and used it to track down the agents within the terrorists' ranks.

headline: Groupe FCA Buys Bloom In Latest French-U.S. Deal
abstract: THE Bloom Agency, known for its ads for Scott Paper and Pentax cameras, was acquired yesterday by Groupe FCA, a French agency that creates advertising in Europe for clients like Nestle, L'Oreal and Bayer.    The combined agencies, to be called Bloom FCA, will have billings of about $600 million. Terms of the agreement, which includes the acquisition of Bloom Public Relations, were not disclosed.

headline: Complacency Over Chemical Attack Setting In
abstract: Western military officials said today that Iraq is likely to attack allied ground forces with chemical weapons if a land battle breaks out.   The assessment is not new, but it comes against a backdrop of what many diplomats and chemical warfare experts say is a budding public complacency here that the threat of an Iraqi chemical attack has passed.

headline: Big Note Offerings By Ford and G.M.
abstract: Auto makers accounted for a sizable amount of the total debt issued yesterday as Ford Capital B.V., an overseas unit of the Ford Motor Company, and the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the financing arm of General Motors, priced $800 million in securities for offering to the public.   Ford's financing of $500 million in noncallable seven-year notes, which are due to mature in 1998, was made through an underwriting group led Goldman, Sachs & Company. Underwriters gave the notes a 9 3/8 percent coupon and then priced them at 99.933 to yield 9.387 percent, or about 154 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.    Goldman said the Ford notes were rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.    The General Motors financing, consisting of $300 million in noncallable four-year notes, was priced through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company. The issue was given an 8 3/4 percent coupon and offered to the public at a price of 99.771 to yield 8.818 percent, or about 135 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.    These securities carry the same Moody's and Standard & Poor's ratings as the Ford issue.

headline: Inland Steel Posts a Loss
abstract: Inland Steel Industries, the operator of the nation's fourth-largest steel producer, yesterday reported a net loss of $57.1 million for the fourth quarter. The loss was a result of start-up expenses on a new joint venture with the Nippon Steel Corporation that were higher than expected, the company said.   In the fourth quarter of 1989, Inland earned $6.7 million, or 9 cents a share. Revenues for the latest quarter fell 4.9 percent, to $907 million, from $954 million in the fourth quarter of 1989.

headline: Bonwit Chief May Resign
abstract: Frank Doroff is expected to resign soon as chairman and chief executive of the revitalized three-store Bonwit Teller retail chain, according to executives close to the company.   The 43-year-old Mr. Doroff, formerly chairman and chief executive of Federated/Allied Merchandising Services, New York, joined Bonwit Teller last year after the company was sold to the Pyramid Companies, a Syracuse developer. Under Pyramid, Bonwit has operated stores in Syracuse, Buffalo and Boston.

headline: Real Estate; Marketing 555 Broadway Amid SoHo Office Slump
abstract: BUILT in 1889 as a department store, then used for light manufacturing, the 12-story building at 555 Broadway has been almost vacant for two years. Now a Japanese company is marketing it as office space, despite a commercial real estate slump.  The acquisition of the 220,000-square-foot building, between Prince and Spring streets, marks the initial foray into the United States real estate market by the Ise Group, the parent company of Ise America in Freehold N.J., which is one of the largest egg producers in the United States.

headline: Philip Morris Sells 3-Year, 7 5/8% Notes
abstract: The Philip Morris Companies sold debt in the credit markets through competitive bidding yesterday. The three-year notes were won by the First Boston Corporation.    Reoffered to the public at a price of 99.958, the 7 5/8 percent notes due Feb. 15, 1994, yielded 7.64 percent, or about 67 basis points more than Treasury securities with similar maturities. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.    Underwriters said the issue featured a non-call provision and was rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.

headline: New England Withdrawals
abstract: Officials at the Bank of New England estimated today that $800 million to $1 billion had been withdrawn from it and two affiliated banks on Friday and Saturday after the news that it expected losses of up to $450 million for the fourth quarter of last year.   The bank had said on Monday that $20 million had been withdrawn, but officials today said that only represented cash in hand had been taken out by depositors. The total amount of withdrawals also covered checks, wire transfers and other commercial transactions. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which said on Sunday that it was taking over the bank group, had estimated $1 billion in withdrawals on the two days.

headline: World Markets; A Direct Hit on the Pessimists
abstract: One thing the intensive air attacks on Iraq did last week was knock out the war pessimists. Money managers and analysts who had worried that a war would not go well, even at the beginning, were transformed by the success the United States and its allies had in the air. Even the Iraqi attack on Israel on the second day of fighting did not significantly undermine this confidence, as reflected in the rise in stock markets in Japan and the United States Friday and the relatively small declines in Europe.    "I stand agog at what has gone on in the markets," said David Roche, an international strategist, referring to the worldwide rallies in markets Thursday, just hours after the bombing of Iraq began.

headline: Brisk Trading Worldwide, but No Panic; Companies Set Gasoline Price Curbs
abstract: The news of military action drove oil prices wild last night, first up by 20 percent in a few minutes, and then down below their starting point, as it appeared that the American air strike met almost no resistance from the Iraqis.   Meanwhile, some large United States oil companies quickly announced that at least for now, they would not change retail gasoline prices at their company-owned service stations. They also said they would freeze the prices they charge independent distributors and urge them to hold the line, too.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Aritmos A.B., Malmos, Sweden, a sporting goods company, has acquired the remaining 23 percent of voting stock in the sporting goods company Puma A.G. for about 70 marks a share. Besides all the voting stock, Aritmos also owns 72 percent of Puma's capital stock. * Chiquita Brands International Inc., Cincinnati, a food company, said it was willing to pay up to $500 million to acquire about half of the fruit production capacity of PPI Del Monte, a unit of Polly Peck International P.L.C., which is in bankruptcy proceedings in Britain. But Polly Peck said PPI Del Monte was not for sale. * Elcor Corp., Dallas, an industrial products manufacturer, said its Chromium Corp. unit would close its leased plant in Chicago this year. * Kinder-Care Learning Centers Inc., Montgomery, Ala., which operates child-care centers, has cut about 10 percent of its corporate staff and a smaller percentage of its field staff. * Koor Industries, Tel Aviv, a communications, electronics and industrial products company, said it had filed an application with the District Court of Tel Aviv-Jaffa in Israel for approval to restructure its notes in the United States and Israel. * Merrill Lynch & Co., New York, said it would sell its Family Life Insurance Co. unit to Financial Industries, Austin, Tex., an insurance company. Terms were not disclosed. * Motorola Inc., Schaumburg, Ill., and Northern Telecom Ltd., Mississauga, Ontario, a unit of BCE Inc., will develop enhancements for their cellular telephone products based on new open system standards. * Nucor Corp., Charlotte, N.C., a steel products company, said it would build a hot-rolled sheet steel mill in Hickman, Ark. The cost would be almost $300 million. * Rocky Mountain Helicopters Inc., Provo, Utah, has acquired Avtech Systems Inc., also of Provo, a parts manufacturing company. No terms were disclosed. * United Industrial Corp., New York, said its AAI Corp. unit has received a multiyear contract worth more than $200 million from the National Weather Service and Federal Aviation Administration to provide an automated weather system at U.S. airports. * Universal Health Services Inc., King of Prussia, Pa., was the subject of an S.E.C. filing: Members of the Bass family of Fort Worth, including Lee M. Bass and Perry R. Bass, had cut their stake to 8.6 percent, or 919,332 common shares.

headline: Germany's New Custodian of Stasi Secrets Insists on Justice
abstract: From a drab and unmarked office in what was once East Berlin, an earnest clergyman named Hans Joachim Gauck is working to unravel the secrets of one of the world's largest and best-organized spy networks.    Mr. Gauck is the official custodian of millions of files collected over the last four decades by agents of the now-dissolved Stasi, East Germany's secret police. His quiet insistence that Germans face the truth about the Stasi has made him a hero to some, especially those who were victimized by the Communist rulers who governed East Germany until last year. But others, including some prominent politicians in Bonn, wish him no good.

headline: 3,000 at Chrysler Face White-Collar Job Loss
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said today in a company newspaper that it might have to eliminate 3,000, or about 11 percent, of the auto maker's 27,000 white-collar workers.   The company said the decision to undertake the reduction would depend on "business conditions," but it was not specific about what they might be. News of the possibility of further layoffs are likely to worsen morale in Chrysler's work force, which has already been hit hard by cost-cutting measures intended to keep the company solvent until key new car and truck models are brought to market.

headline: Savings Units' Earnings Hurs
abstract: Real estate problems hurt fourth-quarter earnings at two of the largest savings and loan companies.   H.F. Ahmanson & Company, parent of the largest savings and loan, Home Savings of America, said today that fourth-quarter net income was $475,000, or less than 1 cent a share, compared with earnings of $66.9 million, or 57 cents a share, in the same period a year before.   Earnings for the year were $191 million, or $1.64 a share, down 9.2 percent from $21.03 million, or $1.80 a share, in 1989.   Ahmanson stock rose 62.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange today, to $14.75.   CalFed Inc., the third-largest savings company and parent of the California Federal Bank, said it lost $130.5 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a profit of $23.6 million, or 88 cents a share, in 1989.   CalFed said it would add $200 million to its fourth-quarter reserves to cushion against losses on commercial real estate loans, mostly in the Southwest and on the East Coast.   For the year, CalFed lost $256.9 million, in contrast to net income of $82.4 million, or $3.12 a share, in 1989.   CalFed stock slipped 12.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange, to $3.75.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Strategy; Iraq's Kuwait Defense: 3-Tier Plan That Collapsed
abstract: Two days of American and allied ground assaults have thwarted Iraq's basic military strategy for holding onto Kuwait, military experts say.   To contest the attacks, the Iraqis have employed a three- tier defense, drawing on their experience during the eight-year war with Iran.

headline: S.& L. Figure Has Surgery
abstract: The former owner of the Vernon Savings Association, Don R. Dixon, who was convicted last month on fraud charges, was listed in fair condition today after open- heart surgery.   Mr. Dixon was recovering in the intensive care unit of Harris Methodist Hospital after the three-and-a-half-hour operation, in which doctors inserted a defibrillator to stabilize his irregular heart beat, a hospital spokeswoman said.   Mr. Dixon's lawyer, Deborah Goodall, said her client would probably remain in the hospital for another week. He had been freed from the Mansfield Law Enforcement Center on Monday by Federal District Court Judge A. Joe Fish.    Mr. Dixon, one of the most visible figures in the nationwide savings and loan industry debacle, will be sentenced on March 19. He was found guilty last month of 23 of 38 counts of fraud and misconduct relating to his ownership of Vernon, which failed in 1987 at a cost to taxpayers of $1.7 billion.   He faces a maximum sentence of 115 years in jail and a $5.7 million fine.   Before the operation, Mr. Dixon said appealing his conviction was the most crucial mission of his life.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Aicorp Inc., Waltham, Mass., a software company, named Frank Chisholm president and chief operating officer. * Amwest Insurance Group Inc., Woodland Hills, Calif., named John E. Savage president of Amwest Surety Insurance Co., its primary unit. He replaces Gary R. Peterson, who retired last year. Arthur F. Melton was also named senior vice president. * Chase Manhattan Bank, a unit of Chase Manhattan Corp., appointed Timothy McGinnis and Thompson M. Swayne executive vice presidents. * Data-Design Laboratories Inc., Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., a computer hardware manufacturer, named Theodore D. Zucconi vice president of technology and quality. * Dynagen Inc., Cambridge, Mass., a manufacturer of diagnostic health-care products, named Jack L. Barlow chairman and executive vice president. * Lands' End Inc., Dodgeville, Wis., named Jane M. McAndrew and Jack Sidebotham vice presidents.

headline: Senior Vietnamese Criticizes Hanoi's Leaders
abstract: A second senior and widely admired Vietnamese intellectual has criticized the leadership in Hanoi, calling for individual freedoms, younger leaders and changes in the system.    Nguyen Khac Vien, 78 years old and one of Vietnam's best-known historians, submitted a petition to a party meeting in January that described the current leadership as "totally impotent, plunging the country into disorder and preventing all development."

headline: Consumer Spending In Big Drop
abstract: Consumer spending, which slipped severely in the final quarter of last year, dropped an additional six-tenths of a percent in January, the Government said today. It was the steepest decline in consumer spending in more than four years.   Contributing to the cutback was a drop of five-tenths of 1 percent in personal incomes, the largest such decline in more than two years.

headline: Kuwait Bank's Credit Line
abstract: Credit Lyonnais said today that it had signed an agreement to give the Commercial Bank of Kuwait a $160 million line of credit.   "This credit line, which will be booked through Credit Lyonnais in London, will permit the bank to resume normal management of its treasury," Credit Lyonnais said in a statment.    An official at Credit Lyonnais said the purpose of the credit line was to avoid transaction delays, adding that virtually all of the Kuwaiti bank's accounts were frozen after Iraq invaded Kuwait last year.

headline: IN OTHER SECTIONS
abstract: CITY CELEBRATIONS New York City plans a ticker-tape parade, an ecumenical religious service and a fireworks display for returning veterans. Page B1.    NETWORK WOES Despite their satisfaction with the coverage of the war, the three broadcast networks face serious economic consequences from the war's costs, and one or more may be compelled to cut budgets and news staff. Business Day, page D1.    A NATIONAL OIL POLICY? The next few months are beginning to look like a very difficult time to form a national policy for becoming less dependent on imported oil. News analysis, page D1.

headline: Mastercard, in Turn, Names Head for U.S.
abstract: Mastercard International, not to be outdone by its rival Visa, which named a president for its American operations last month, did the same yesterday. Peter S.P. Dimsey will be the Mastercard president for the United States.    The credit-card organization took the action at its annual meeting yesterday in New York, at which a plan was approved to organize the card's United States membership as one of six regions within its global structure.

headline: Revlon Settles Logisticon Suit
abstract: Revlon Inc. said today that it had settled a lawsuit against a software supplier that had disabled some of the cosmetics company's computers, in a case that called attention to the vulnerability of computerized corporate operations.   The terms of the settlement, which was reached late in December, were not disclosed.

headline: Toys 'R' Us Japan Is Moving Ahead
abstract: The chamber of commerce approved Toys "R" Us Japan's plans to open a store in Niigata, a city on Japan's west coast, despite opposition from toy shop owners.   Toys "R" Us Japan, 80 percent owned by Toys "R" Us Inc. of Paramus, N.J., and 20 percent by the restaurant chain operator McDonald's Japan Ltd., has applied to open a store with a sales floor of about 6,000 square yards in Niigata. The company already received similar permission for a 3,960-square-yard store north of Tokyo.

headline: Business and the Law; Putting Lawyers Under Scrutiny
abstract: LAST summer, Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin of Washington sharply criticized the bar in a celebrated case of a collapsed savings and loan. Where were the lawyers, he asked, when the institution and scores like it first began to encounter serious financial problems?    The judge's opinion, written in the case involving the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association and its former head, Charles H. Keating Jr., laid a significant amount of blame for the overall savings and loan crisis on lawyers who wittingly or unwittingly helped savings associations skirt the rules when they engaged in risky investments.

headline: PHILIPPINES SEEKS HIGHER BASE RENT
abstract: The Philippines told the United States today that it wanted more money to allow the Americans to use military bases here after their lease expires in September.   Philippine negotiators made their proposal one day after the chief United States negotiator, Richard Armitage, offered what United States officials called a "reasonable" package for use of Clark Air Base, Subic Bay Naval Station and four smaller installations.

headline: An F.D.A. Approval for Amgen
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the use of the first of a new class of genetically engineered drugs that are expected to be of major benefit to people with cancer and could eventually open an era in the treatment of a wide variety of infections.   The drug, known as granulocyte colony stimulating factor, or G-CSF, was developed and will be sold by Amgen Inc., a biotechnology company in Thousand Oaks, Calif. Securities analysts expect G-CSF to become one of the largest-selling and most important drugs produced by the young biotechnology industry.

headline: Policies Vary on Pay for Reservists
