abstract: Since August, when the first troops were sent to the Middle East, only 35 employees of Borden Inc. have been called to duty. Not a hefty number, but one of the employees worked in a personnel department that had little excess staff.   "The personnel man's boss is doing his work," said James T. McCrory, Borden's vice president for public affairs. He noted that while Borden will pay to keep its reservists on full salary, less military pay, for six months, it will not pay to replace them.

headline: Publishers Are Looking to Libraries for Growth
abstract: About 25 executives from Bantam Doubleday Dell will each spend two days working in libraries this spring and summer. "Libraries are an important market for our books," said Jack Hoeft, the company's president and chief operating officer, "so we thought it's time to get to know them better."   Libraries are equally important to small publishers. "It's the life-support system for an important range of books," said Kent Carroll, the publisher of Carroll & Graf. "Selling 2,000 to 3,000 copies of a new mystery virtually underwrites the publication of that book. And we'd find it difficult to publish serious nonfiction without that market."

headline: I.B.M. Makes Changes In Work Station Line
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced faster versions of two of its work stations yesterday and dropped some prices. But the computer manufacturer continued to steer clear of the highly competitive low-priced end of the work station market.   While Sun Microsystems Inc. and the Digital Equipment Corporation are moving quickly to offer the power of work stations in more compact desktop packages, I.B.M. said it would continue to view work stations as machines to be used by scientists and engineers, distinct from desktop personal computers used in business.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: COMPANIES    Amoco said its net income surged by 68.6 percent. It was the first report in what analysts expect to be a series of large gains in fourth-quarter profits in the oil industry.  [ Page D1. ]   When the Go Corporation demonstrates its Penpoint software, it will mark the beginning of a battle to control what is expected to become the next big form of personal computing.  [ D1. ]   Raytheon, already basking in the Patriot's glow, announced record sales and earnings. And the Government asked the company to step up production of the anti-missile missiles.  [ D1. ]   Delta Air Lines agreed to buy airport gates and an international air route from Eastern for $42.9 million.  [ D1. ]   Reynolds Metals said earnings plunged 89 percent, the result of a $94 million charge and lower aluminum prices.  [ D2. ]   Shares of L.A. Gear tumbled 21.5 percent after the company said it expected to lose $4 million to $6 million in the quarter.  [ D4. ] THE ECONOMY    The luxury tax that Congress adopted may cost retailers and the I.R.S. more to collect than the revenues it brings in.  [ D1. ]   As reservists are called up, companies find their desire to maintain reservists' income and get work done without overloading the remaining staff may clash with cost-cutting programs.  [ D8. ]   New steps to accommodate the disabled would have to be taken by banks, theaters and offices under proposed U.S. rules.  [ A1. ]   The idea of converting trash to electricity, and making money at it, has not worked out as planned in Maine.  [ A19. ] INTERNATIONAL    A Polish agent jailed in the U.S. a decade ago for stealing military secrets now epitomizes Poland's new breed of Westward-looking entrepreneur.  [ D1. ]   Mongolia will sign its first trade agreement with the U.S. on Wednesday as part of efforts to broaden exchanges.  [ D2. ]   Airline travel to the Middle East has become limited and uncertain as most leading carriers have canceled flights.  [ D9. ]   Support for the war effort was expressed by the chief economic policy makers of the six main U.S. industrial partners.  [ D9. ]   Could foreign debt be the lever that moves poor countries to save rain forests? President Bush apparently thinks so.  [ C1. ]   Mexico's 50-year-old film industry is taking heartening steps toward new commercial possibilities.  [ C11. ] MARKETS    After collapsing last week, the price of oil rebounded slightly, with crude up $2.05, to $21.30 a barrel.  [ D9. ]   Stocks fell, though the shares of military contractors advanced sharply. The Dow dropped 17.57, to 2,629.21.  [ D12. ]   Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in thin trading in a session that would not have taken place but for the war.  [ D18. ]   The dollar drifted lower in quiet trading as attention turned from the Persian Gulf to the weak U.S. economy.  [ D19. ]   Prices of gold futures rallied along with oil amid perceptions that the war may last longer than many traders expected.  [ D19. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS    In the debate over paying for health care, all sides have been adding up the costs of adopting a Canadian-style system. Milt Freudenheim: Business and Health.  [ D2. ]   Technological developments in the next 10 years will revolutionize the advertising industry, a study predicts. Kim Foltz: Advertising.  [ D11. ]   Spreads are widening between yields on high- and lower-quality bonds. Floyd Norris: Market Place.  [ D12. ]

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Encyclopedia Britannica U.S.A., a unit of Encyclopedia Britannica Inc., Chicago, to Shain/Colavito/Pensabene Direct, New York, with a budget of $5 million. * Parade of Shoes, a division of J. Baker Inc., Hyde Park, Mass., to Rossin Greenberg Seronick, Boston, with a budget of $2.5 million. * Woman's Workout World, a chain of physical-fitness centers, Morton Grove, Ill., to Lou Beres & Associates, Chicago, with a budget of $1 million. * The Faultless Starch/Bon Ami Co., Kansas City, Mo., to GSD&M Advertising, Austin, Tex. Billings have not been determined. * Seventh Generation, makers of "environmentally responsible" products, to Beaumont-Bennett, New York, a unit of Grey Advertising, New York, for sales promotion. Billings have not been determined. * Foscavir, an anti-viral AIDS drug made by Astra Pharmaceutical, to William Douglass McAdams Inc., New York. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Patents; A New Way to Remove The Plaque in Arteries
abstract: Among medical researchers, it might be called Son of Roto-Rooter. An entrepreneur and professor of bioengineering at the University of Washington obtained a patent this week on one of the newest weapons in the war against clogged arteries: the Rotoblator.   Invented by David C. Auth, founder of Heart Technology Inc. in Seattle, the device consists of a tiny metal burr, coated with microscopic diamond chips, that rotates 180,000 times a second at the end of a catheter. As a doctor threads the catheter through an artery, the Rotoblator scrapes off plaque into particles small enough to be carried off by the bloodsteam.

headline: Marketing Campaigns Receive Top Honors
abstract: The 13th John Caples International Awards were presented in New York last night, recognizing the best direct-marketing campaigns of 1990.   First prizes in the business-to-business competition were awarded to: Kobs & Draft, for its work for Polaroid; Lowe Direct, for its work for Xerox; Grey Direct Ltd., London, for its work for Topdeq; Tomas Ohman, Sweden, a freelance copywriter, for his portfolio; Christiansen & Fritsch Inc., Seattle, for its self-promotion campaign; Wunderman Worldwide, Australia, for its work for The Australia Post, and Oglivy & Mather Direct, New York, for its work for Ryder.    First prizes in the consumer competition were presented to: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Direct Ltd., London, for its work for Pedigree Foods; Leo Burnett, Chicago, for its work for Schenley, a producer of alcoholic beverages; Paul Chesloff & Partners Advertising, Los Angeles, for its work for Thornton & Company, a linen manufacturer; BKV Inc., for its work for the Christian Children's Fund; Oglivy & Mather Direct, for its work for Ryder and Owens-Corning Fiberglas, and Bronner/ Slosberg, Boston, for its work for A.T.&T.

headline: Market Place; A Turning Point For Chip Makers
abstract: FOR Japan's electronics giants, it was supposed to be a sure thing. By early this year at the latest, their mainstay moneymaker -- the one-megabit memory chip, which holds more than a million bits of information -- should have been heading into retirement. It would be replaced by the four-megabit chip, four times as powerful and, more importantly to the sellers, immensely profitable as computer makers all over the world scrambled for scarce supply.   Instead, the four-megabit chip is still limping along. So are the shares of leading makers, like Toshiba and Hitachi, as investors try to determine just how much profits will be pared in the fiscal year starting April 1. Oddly enough, what may hurt the Japanese most is the expiration this summer of the semiconductor trade agreement with the United States, which was intended to curb the Japanese industry and, instead, brought it enormous profits.

headline: Avery Charge Of $85 Million
abstract: The Avery Dennison Corporation, an office and industrial products company formed three months ago through the merger of Avery International and Dennison Manufacturing, said today that it would take an $85 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings to cover the cost of job cutbacks and other changes.   The changes, which include eliminating 700 to 900 jobs in the next 18 months, will result in a loss for the quarter.

headline: SCE May Halt Merger Offer
abstract: SCEcorp, parent of the Southern California Edison Company, said a proposed decision by the California Public Utilities Commission might make it impossible to proceed with its $2.90 billion merger offer for the San Diego Gas and Electric Company.   The proposed merger of the two California companies would create the nation's largest investor-owned electrical utility.

headline: A Japanese Symbol of Excess
abstract: It was bad when the banks sent their people to monitor his debt-laden operations and worse when they slammed the brakes on his hectic pace of property acquisitions. But now the bankers say the three private jets must go.   No, this is not Donald J. Trump, Robert Campeau or some fallen savings and loan owner. Meet Harunori Takahashi, chairman and owner of the privately held EIE International Corporation, a big hotel and resort developer struggling under $6 billion in shaky debt.

headline: Accusers Balk at Winnie Mandela Trial
abstract: The Government's case against Winnie Mandela, the wife of the African National Congress leader, approached the brink of collapse today when two important witnesses refused to testify against her, saying they feared for their safety.   The two, Kenneth Kgase, 31 years old, and Barend Thabo Mono, 23, took the stand separately to say they were afraid to give evidence because of the disappearance of Gabriel Pelo Mekgwe, 22 years old. Mr. Mekgwe, who was the state's third principal witness, vanished on Sunday.

headline: A Win for Pirelli In Takeover Bid
abstract: Shareholders of Continental A.G., the German tire maker, voted 2 to 1 on Wednesday to scrap the company's main takeover defense, giving Pirelli S.p.A. a victory in its six-month bid to take over Continental.   The vote abolished restrictions that limit shareholders' voting share to 5 percent, regardless of the size of their stake. While the vote gave Pirelli considerable leverage, bankers said the Italian tire maker still does have the majority it needs to complete the takeover. Continental is the world's fourth-largest tire maker; Pirelli is No. 5.

headline: Nintendo Is Backed
abstract: Nintendo of America Inc. said a Federal judge had granted a preliminary injunction that bars the Atari Games Corporation and its Tengen Inc. subsidiary from selling or copying Nintendo's copyrighted computer programs for use in its video games. It said Atari had incorporated the programs into video games that were compatible with those of the Nintendo entertainment system. Atari Games officials could not be reached for comment. Nintendo of America is a unit of the Nintendo Company of Japan.

headline: Record Drop in Orders to Factories
abstract: Factory orders for manufactured goods in November took their steepest one-month plunge on record, the Commerce Department said today in yet another report reflecting a weakening industrial sector.   The department said orders for durable and nondurable goods fell 5.9 percent, to $235.4 billion, the worst decline since it began tracking orders in 1958. The past record was a 5.5 percent drop last January.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; K Mart Names President At Pay Less Drug Chain
abstract: Timothy McAlear, who climbed the corporate ladder at K Mart Corporation and was named president and chief executive of its Pay Less Drug Stores subsidiary on Thursday, says the most interesting and rewarding job he held was more than 20 years ago, when he became manager of a K Mart store in Richmond, Ind.   "When you are starting out in the retail business, nothing matches the sense of responsibility you get from your first store manager's job," he said.

headline: Federal Farm Credit Banks In $2.5 Billion Bond Offering
abstract: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering $2.5 billion in consolidated systemwide bonds, which are divided into four parts and are being sold through various securities dealers.   All of the consolidated bonds are priced at 100.

headline: British Trim Rates Again
abstract: Britain reduced interest rates today as the Government moved again to try to lift the economy out of recession amid signs that inflation was slowing.   The Bank of England, the nation's central bank, cut its money-market rates and commercial banks followed, lowering their base lending rates to 12.5 percent from 13 percent. It was the third interest rate cut since mid-February.

headline: Can OPEC Enforce the New Accord?
abstract: The day after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries struggled to agree to cut production by 5 percent, its 13 members are trying to project a united front. But given OPEC's poor record in enforcing its previous production agreements, many analysts predict that prices could slide because the new output levels could greatly exceed demand and because individual OPEC members, as in the past, might try to increase revenues by producing more than their allocated levels.    OPEC officials said cheating by members would be less than in the past because a more cooperative and realistic spirit pervaded the group since the gulf war. They also said that their monitoring of output had improved, and that with so many members producing near capacity, the chances of cheating were reduced.

headline: NCR Is Appealing Stock-Plan Ruling
abstract: The NCR Corporation appealed a Federal court ruling that invalidated the company's new employee stock ownership plan. The ruling will effectively bar NCR workers from voting the shares at a shareholders meeting on A.T.&T.'s takeover bid.   The appeal was filed in the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Cincinnati. No hearing was immediately scheduled. NCR's chairman, Charles E. Exley Jr., said in a statement that he believes NCR's board acted in the best interests of its shareholders and employees in adopting the plan. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company. has begun a hostile $90-a-share tender offer for NCR, based in Dayton. It has said it will raise the offer to $100 a share if the NCR board is removed and replaced with A.T.&T. candidates.

headline: Israeli Unanimity on Golan's Worth: More Than Peace With the Syrians
abstract: This tiny kibbutz in the southwestern corner of the Golan Heights was only restating its longstanding position early this month when Ilana Rosenthal, the executive secretary, told the Israeli press that "we believe no settlement should be an obstacle to peace."    "It wasn't anything new," Mrs. Rosenthal said. "We said the same thing 10 years ago," when Israelis were arguing over their withdrawal from the Sinai. But this time the remark fell with a loud thud that is still reverberating today because, from one end of Israel to the other, it is difficult to find one soul who supports the idea of giving up the Golan Heights, even in exchange for peace with Syria.

headline: Israel Prepares For U.S. Move
abstract: Israel lifted its state of emergency this morning and advised citizens to resume normal lives.    But while jubilant Israelis ripped the plastic sheeting off their windows and tossed their gas masks in the closet, the nation's leaders finished up work on the political bunkers they believe they will need as they prepare for next week's visit by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who wants to revive the Arab-Israeli peace process.

headline: Labor Chief in Brazil Amazon Is Killed and Another Is Hurt
abstract: A labor leader in Brazil's Amazon region was killed in his home and another union organizer in the region was shot three times in a separate attack, a church worker said today.   Sebastiao Ribeiro da Silva was killed by a hired gunman on Friday at his home in Tailandia, a remote town 1,860 miles northwest of Rio, the church worker said.

headline: A Moment of Rapture as a Saint Is Marched Home
abstract: Scores of priests in golden robes and thousands of believers accompanied the relics of one of Russia's most hallowed saints today on a journey back to the church from which he was hidden for more than 70 years.   Waves of elderly women in tight wool shawls pressed forward relentlessly and an old man prostrated himself in the snow as the procession of Russian Orthodox clerics, with Patriarch Aleksy II in their midst, bore the relics of St. Seraphim of Sarov in a reliquary of glistening brass from the Leningrad railroad station to the Cathedral of the Epiphany several miles away.

headline: Three Catholics Killed in Ulster
abstract: An illegal Protestant group said today that it was responsible for killing two Roman Catholic teen-agers and a 29-year-old man to death in Northern Ireland on Thursday night, and warned of more attacks.    The three victims -- Katrina Rennie, 16 years old; Eileen Duffy, 19, and Brian Frizell, 29 -- were slain in Craigavon by a hooded gunman who walked into a candy van serving customers from a Catholic housing development at about 8:30 P.M. The two young women were working behind the counter when the gunman shot them point-blank. He then shot Mr. Frizell outside the van, the police said, and was driven away by an accomplice.

headline: POLAND IS GRANTED LARGE CUT IN DEBT
abstract: Western governments have agreed to forgive about half the $33 billion that Poland owes them, the French Government announced today, with the creditor nations offering what they called "extraordinary terms" to help ease Poland's transition to a market economy.    Western officials said the debt-reduction package was the most generous treatment that the creditor nations, meeting in an informal group known as the Paris Club, had ever given a debtor nation. Many indigent African nations, for example, have been granted 33 percent debt relief, and they, along with developing nations in Asia and Latin America, are expected to demand treatment similar to Poland's.

headline: Reverberations From a Forgotten Recession
abstract: When the word "recession" is mentioned on Wall Street, it is the downturns of 1974-75 and 1981-82 that are recalled. But there was another recession sandwiched between those two, one that has been almost forgotten.   That was the recession of 1980, and it may soon seem to be a precursor of our current recession. Then, as now, weak economies suffered a quick blow from an unexpected event. In 1980, it was credit controls imposed by a Government fearing inflation. In 1990, it was rising oil prices and falling consumer confidence, brought on by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.   There are big differences between 1980 and now. Then, the problem was rampant inflation. Now it is the economy's excessive debt burden. But in both cases the sharp blow was short-lived. Oil prices are now down, just as credit controls were quickly lifted in 1980. In each case, the Federal Reserve responded by aggressively easing credit.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Soviet Union; Moscow Sends Revised Plan to Baghdad
abstract: The Soviet Union and Iraq's Foreign Minister sent proposals for several new Iraqi concessions by radio to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today in a race against the deadline declared by President Bush.    The new proposals were still short of conditions set by Mr. Bush when he demanded that Iraq begin pulling its troops out of Kuwait by Saturday noon, Eastern time.

headline: Some of Those Closed May Not Get Insurance
abstract: Federal regulators said today that many of the 35 credit unions and 10 banks and investment companies that were closed on Tuesday in Rhode Island were too weak to be eligible for Federal deposit insurance.   Roger W. Jepsen, chairman of the National Credit Union Administration, said the agency would probably provide insurance for 22 of the 33 credit unions that had applied. It was reported late today that seven of them will be insured and could reopen on Monday. The 33 hold $1.5 billion in assets that had been covered by the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation, the insolvent state program.

headline: Airlines Bailout Called Unlikely
abstract: Any attempt by the Federal Government to bail out the struggling airline industry is likely to do "more harm than good," the head of the Federal Aviation Administration told Congress today.   The F.A.A. Administrator, James B. Busey, told the House Public Works and Transportation Committee that such aid was unlikely to be offered.   Mr. Busey told the committee that "assistance to the weaker carriers would distort the normal workings of what today is a very competitive marketplace."    The industry suffered an unprecedented $2 billion loss last year, $1.7 billion of it in the fourth quarter, after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait sent jet fuel prices soaring. Those prices have since retreated.   In addition, a fear of terrorism caused by the war with Iraq caused a sharp decline in passengers.

headline: Made Homeless by Missiles, 1,000 Israelis Fight for Aid
abstract: Each time the smoke cleared after Iraqi missiles exploded in Haifa and Tel Aviv, Israelis rejoiced that most of the damage was limited to buildings and property. Now, with the distance of a few days, it has become clear that the rockets have brought long-term misery to well over 1,000 people.    In Tel Aviv alone, officials say, 910 people lost their homes because of the destruction wrought by five missiles. After a Scud slammed into a two-story apartment building in a Tel Aviv suburb on Tuesday, 260 others were forced to move into hotels.

headline: PERU CHALLENGED BY 2D INSURGENCY
abstract: At a time when the Government has begun to make inroads against Peru's largest and most violent guerrilla organization, the Shining Path, a newer insurgent group has begun an offensive, aimed primarily at American establishments like the United States Embassy, cultural centers and fast-food franchises.    Insurgency experts in the Government as well as private consultants warn that it will be very difficult for the Government of President Alberto Fujimori, already struggling with a cholera epidemic, to fight a guerrilla war on two fronts. They predict that the Government will continue to concentrate on its 11-year pursuit of the Shining Path, which is often characterized as a mystical and harsh revolutionary organization intent on removing the country's leadership by the most violent means.

headline: Chevron Sees Higher Profit
abstract: Sounding almost apologetic, the chairman of the Chevron Corporation said yesterday that because of the Persian Gulf crisis, his company's fourth-quarter profits would be sharply higher.   At a news conference in New York, Ken Derr, the chairman, said Chevron's fourth-quarter operating profits would be about $900 million, and after a write-off of a little more than $200 million related to the sale of a fertilizer subsidiary profits would be $700 million, or about $2 a share.   The company reported a loss in the fourth quarter last year of $883 million, because of write-offs; operating profit was $320 million, which Mr. Derr called "pretty awful."   For 1990 as a whole, operating profit will be $2.2 billion to $2.3 billion, he said, compared with $1.2 billion for 1989. The 1989 net was $251 million, after write-offs.   But Mr. Derr stressed that the crisis hurt the company in the previous quarter, and that profits were still modest compared with other industries'. And much of the profit will go into new investment, which will rise $800 million, to $5.1 billion, he said.   At the news conference, and in letters to employees, retirees and shareholders, Mr. Derr said opinion surveys commissioned by the company showed that most Americans think that the American oil companies have assets in the Middle East and that they are manipulating gasoline prices. But Chevron has no substantial assets there, he said, and an Energy Department study found no price gouging.   Mr. Derr said that since July the price of crude oil has risen far more than the price of gasoline, and that this had sharply cut profits in refining and marketing.

headline: The Soviets Ratify a Treaty On Uniting the 2 Germanys
abstract: The Soviet Parliament ratified a six-nation treaty today putting the legal seal on German unification and formally ending the Allied rights in Germany that stemmed from postwar occupation.    The treaty was signed in Moscow in September by the former East and West German states as well as the four Allied powers with special occupation rights in postwar Germany -- the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France. The Soviet Union was the last of the six to ratify the agreement.   The ratification marks a formal end to Allied rights in Germany, which was suspended with unification in October.

headline: So Far, U.S. Industry Finds It's Business as Usual: Entertainment; Higher Demand For Escapism
abstract: Paramount Pictures releases "Flight of the Intruder" today, two days after American planes began bombing Iraq. Will people flock to a Vietnam film about Navy jets, or stay home watching television news?   "The success of our air strikes can only help this movie," said Jeffrey Logsdon, an analyst with Seidler Amdec Securities. "Emotionally, it may be a way to vicariously get involved."

headline: IN OTHER SECTIONS
abstract: MOURNING IN NEWARK Private Robert Tally wanted to become a doctor but he lost his life to "friendly fire" in the Persian Gulf. Metropolitan News, page B4    A NEW ERA IN WEAPONS Precision-guided bombs and missiles have played what appears to be a decisive role in a war, a turning point in military history. Science Times, page C1.    ON THE AIRWAVES The opening of the ground offensive brought renewed attention from the television networks. Page C13. Included in the coverage is a documentary on Saddam Hussein. Television review, page C16.    BARGAINS IN OIL STOCKS? Even with war's volatility, some analysts say this is a good time to buy shares in oil companies. Business Day, page D10.

headline: A Fantasy Land of Toys Where No Child May Play
abstract: Toy makers and toy vendors have turned a section of this Renaissance city into a paradise for children, but no child is allowed to see it.   For one week each year, Nuremberg is host to the world's largest toy exposition. This is the week, and the sprawling convention center on the edge of town has been packed with a variety of playthings so vast and dazzling as to numb the adult imagination.

headline: Nikko International Reshuffles at the Top
abstract: Less than two years after a change in senior management, Nikko Securities International, the American arm of Japan's third-largest securities firm, has reshuffled, naming Tsuneo Iida chairman and chief executive.    Mr. Iida, who had been president of the American operation since 1989, succeeds Hideo Suzuki, who is returning to Japan to work at the parent company in a senior management position, the firm said in a statement yesterday.

headline: Don't Knock Corporate Philanthropy
abstract: To the Editor:   As an educator whose work has been the beneficiary of generous corporate grants, I was greatly struck by the articles on corporate philanthropy ("Philanthropy as a Business Tactic . . . With Some Attendant Risks," Dec. 30). I disagree with one point.   In the midst of the Saharan campaign, Winston Churchill defined opportunity "not as a seat but a springboard." To me a springboard is just what corporate philanthropy provides.    Mr. Macke suggests that Dayton Hudson Corporation's giving is not entirely altruistic. Perhpas, fearing charges of self-aggrandizement, he feels unable to stake such a claim. Still, charity, however it is manifest, does promote altruism. That the returns on such an investment accrue in part to corporate interests should not minimize our sense of the value of giving. The form of social investment constitutes a considerable springboard -- it yields opportunity and altruism at once.   In the early 1970's, Richard Titmuss, at the London School of Economics, conducted a global study of blood donation and concluded that "how an institution organizes itself has all to do with promoting altruism." In a recessionary economy, we need all the altruism we can get and Dayton Hudson has organized itself in a manner to promote it. Keep it up Mr. Macke. WILLIAM BAGLEY  Wallingford, Conn., Jan. 9

headline: Some of the Americans Feel Test of Mettle Was Too Easy
abstract: The war's swift end has left soldiers and marines relieved that there were few American casualties, skeptical of Saddam Hussein's intentions and disappointed that they never got to test their mettle in battle.    Despite Baghdad's announcement that Iraq would honor the United Nations resolutions and begin a cease-fire, American troops interviewed in Kuwait and Saudi Arabia question Iraqi motives.

headline: 4 Days After Vote, Salvador Still Awaits Result
abstract: As the slow official count began Wednesday for El Salvador's legislative and municipal elections, the head of the election board from one of the country's 14 departments asked that nobody bring guns to the session.    Smiles and a few giggles went around the table in the hotel bedroom temporarily turned into a conference room, but the remark seemed to go with the passions aroused in the aftermath of the voting on Sunday.

headline: Bank Warns About Rumors
abstract: A Rhode Island savings institution has taken out a newspaper advertisement threatening to prosecute those spreading rumors that it blames for a run on the institution.   In an ad in The Providence Journal-Bulletin on Tuesday, Old Stone Bank asked readers to give it the names of people who spread rumors about its financialcondition. Depositors began a run on the institution last week, withdrawing at least $10 million, Old Stone's president, Theodore Barnes, said.   Noting that state law prohibits spreading lies about a bank's financial status, the Old Stone said it would give the names to prosecutors.   Rumors have spread since Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun ordered 45 banks and credit unions closed on Jan. 1 after their private insurer collapsed. Most have reopened, but $1.3 billion in deposits remains frozen. Mr. Sundlun announced plans on Tuesday for repaying depositors whose money is tied up.   Old Stone, with $3.7 billion in assets, is insured by the Federal Government and was not among the institutions closed.

headline: AMERICAN REVIVAL IN MANUFACTURING SEEN IN U.S. REPORT
abstract: In the last recession, America's aging industrial heartland was widely considered to be incapable of saving itself. But a Government report issued yesterday suggests that the Rust Belt has staged a renaissance on the factory floor.   Thanks to a wrenching contraction in payrolls and plants, manufacturing productivity -- the measure of output per hours worked -- climbed at a record rate from 1979 to 1990. Industrial productivity growth, which trailed that of the United States' trading partners in the 1970's, rebounded to equal their pace in the 1980's.

headline: Wheat Planting Down
abstract: Farmers have planted slightly more than 51 million acres of winter wheat for harvest this year, down 10 percent from 1990, the Agriculture Department said Friday. A major reason for the reduction is the department's requirement that farmers take more land from wheat production this year in an effort to stem rising stockpiles and depressed market prices. Winter wheat accounts for about three-fourths of the total United States wheat output.

headline: KOREAS TO UNIFY TEAMS IN 2 SPORTS
abstract: Sports officials from North and South Korea agreed today to form the first unified Korean teams since their country was divided in 1945.    The agreement, if carried out, could have important ramifications for efforts to relax the cold-war confrontation in Northeast Asia.

headline: Ramsey Clark Plans Inquiry
abstract: Ramsey Clark, the former United States Attorney General, announced the formation today of an international commission of inquiry to gather evidence on charges that United States committed war crimes in the gulf war. Mr. Clark, a frequent critic of American foreign policy, said the commission's final report would be put before an international tribunal, whose membership he did not disclose.

headline: Sequent Shares Drop by 33.3%
abstract: Shares in Sequent Computer Systems Inc. plummeted today after the company said its earnings for the fourth quarter, which ended on Dec. 29, would be lower than in the corresponding period last year.    Sequent, which is based in Beaverton, Ore., had been the last important computer manufacturer with uninterrupted growth in earnings. Its shares closed today at $11.50 in over-the-counter trading, down $5.75 a share, or 33.3 percent.   While Sequent expects revenue for the quarter to be at least 50 percent higher than the $47.8 million it reported for the fourth quarter of 1989, net earnings are expected to be 10 cents to 20 cents a share, compared with 23 cents in the quarter last year.   The profit decline was caused by a combination of three things, Casey Powell, Sequent's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. These were a drop, from $16 million in the third quarter to below $10 million in the fourth, in the company's original- equipment manufacturing business, in which Sequent computers are resold by the Unisys Corporation; the softening of the economy, and the transition to a new product line.   Mr. Powell said he expected the first quarter of 1991 to be difficult also. "I think we're going to come out of this healthy," he said. "I don't think we're going to come out of it unscathed."

headline: Freeport-McMoran Convertible Notes
abstract: Freeport-McMoran Inc. yesterday priced $325 million in convertible subordinated notes due 2001 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.   The company's proceeds from the note sale are expected to total about $258 million, with the cash used to repay bank debt and for general corporate purposes.    The 6.55 percent notes were priced at 79.50 to yield 9.814 percent at maturity. They are convertible into the company's common stock at a price of $37.75 a share, representing a 17.968 percent conversion premium over Tuesday's closing price of $32.   Freeport-McMoran has the option to redeem part or all of the issue on or after Jan. 15, 1994. According to the underwriters, these notes have a below investment grade rating of Ba-3 from Moody's Investors Service and BB- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.    Yesterday the stock closed at $33.25 a share, up $1.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Two News Organizations To Promote War Coverage
abstract: WHILE most big advertisers are exceedingly reluctant to tie their advertising to the Persian Gulf war, some media companies are not being quite so shy.    National Public Radio, for instance, is using an advertising campaign to promote its war reports. And it is no surprise that the Cable News Network, with its extensive coverage, is doing the same.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Turmoil in Banking    The Federal Government took control of the troubled Bank of New England, assuring that it remain in business with its deposits intact until a buyer is found. The rescue is likely to cost taxpayers at least $2.3 billion.  [ Page A1. ]  In only a year, the Bank of New England was transformed from a regional banking powerhouse into a ward of the state, waiting for Federal regulators to choose how and when they will sell it.  [ D8. ]   The White House wants to create a "super regulator" of banks, savings associations and other financial services, in a sweeping overhaul of the complex regulatory system.  [ D1. ]   Rhode Island's Governor announced emergency plans for withdrawals by depositors of closed credit unions.  [ D9. ] The Economy    The Bush Administration has turned more truculent in its economic relations with Tokyo, reflecting both frustration over Japanese trading policies and unease over the wave of Japanese investments in the United States.  [ D1. ]   The White House is considering changes in the student loan program that would increase lending by the Government and curtail the role of banks, which lend more than $12 billion a year.  [ A1. ] Companies    USX and the United Steelworkers will reopen talks today that could determine whether the nation's largest steelmaker can hold on to the cheaper labor costs it has enjoyed for two years.  [ D1. ] The Media Business    Two television stations are starting nightly newscasts that will be broadcast on rival channels. The moves by WRC in Washington and WNEP in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., indicate how drastically television is changing at the local level as stations try to respond to shrinking profit margins and altered viewing habits.  [ D1. ]   Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver is reeling after two of its top executives left the ad agency. Advertising executives are wondering whether Levine, Huntley will be the latest middle-aged but still-revered agency to lose its way.  [ D6 ] .   Little, Brown plans to start publishing mass-market paperbacks, even though overall paperback sales are declining.  [ D6. ]   Magazines are feeling the effects of changing demographics. Slower population growth is bad news for mass-circulation magazines. At the same time, the aging of the baby boom bodes well for specialty publications. Deirdre Carmody: Magazines.  [ D6. ]   Coke and Pepsi will be going head-to-head for the first time at the Super Bowl. Each soft-drink maker is sponsoring a multimillion-dollar game that viewers can play by watching advertising just before or during the game. Kim Foltz: Advertising  [ D1. ]   The Newspaper Guild is bringing charges of illegal strikebreaking against at least 98 of its members at The Daily News.  [ B3. ] International    Hong Kong's leading bank is seeking ways to protect itself after the Chinese take control of the British colony in 1997. But the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation may be heading into a minefield as it becomes a fully international bank.  [ D1. ] Today's Columns    Corporations are expected to issue a considerable amount of new debt this week, analysts and investment bankers said, because they are afraid that interest rates will soar if the U.S. goes to war with Iraq later this month.  [ D5. ]   Investors in government bonds around the world did a lot better than stock buyers last year. There were big gains in Britain, Spain, Italy and Australia. Even in the two worst performing markets of the year, Japan and Germany, investors benefited from a strong fourth quarter. Market Place.  [ D4. ]

headline: Kremlin Says Its Extra Troops Have Left Lithuania
abstract: Kremlin officials said today that most troop reinforcements involved in the deadly attack on civilians in Lithuania earlier this month had been evacuated. But officials in the republic said there was no evidence yet of an easing in the Soviet crackdown that President Bush has said might be expected.   Two columns of Soviet military trucks left Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, and caused much interest and speculation. But since the city routinely sees frequent convoy movements because of the many Soviet military bases in the region, there was no firm indication that the Government of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was signaling a retreat from its recent hard-line position on the republic's independence campaign.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Aegon U.S.A. Inc., Baltimore, a subsidiary of Aegon N.V., a Dutch insurance group, said one of its subsidiaries had acquired Western Reserve Life Insurance Co., Idex Distributors Inc. and Idex Investor Services Inc., from Pioneer Western Corp., a unit of Enstar Group Inc., Montgomery, Ala. Terms were not disclosed. * Contel Corp., Atlanta, a telecommunications company, said its 90 percent-owned subsidiary, Contel Cellular Inc., would purchase a rural Kentucky cellular property from an unnamed seller for undisclosed terms.

headline: Earle Palmer Brown's Janklow/Bender Deal
abstract: After a yearlong search, Earle Palmer Brown, based in Bethesda, Md., has found an agency for its fledgling New York office to team up with. The New York office has billings of about $10 million.    Jeremy Brown, the agency's chief executive, said yesterday that Earle Palmer Brown would acquire Janklow/ Bender, a New York agency with billings of about $20 million. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Rig Count Off Sharply
abstract: The number of rigs exploring for oil and natural gas dropped by 40 last week, to a total of 908, Baker Hughes Inc. reported on Monday. The count is identical to that of the comparable week a year ago. The rig count traditionally falls through April.

headline: France to Continue Efforts
abstract: The chairman of the foreign affairs committee of the National Assembly said tonight that France reserved the right to pursue a diplomatic solution to the gulf crisis if Wednesday's talks between Secretary of State Baker and Foreign Minister Aziz failed.    The assembly member, Michel Vauzelle, a confidant of President Mitterrand, said little today about the meeting he held on Saturday with President Hussein. But he said that "the horizon doesn't stop growing darker" and that the chances of peace were "not completely closed off."

headline: British Detain 32 More Iraqis
abstract: The British Government has announced that it has taken 32 more Iraqis into custody with the intention of deporting them. The 32 were detained on Tuesday and today.  A Home Office spokesman said that since Iraq invaded Kuwait the Government had taken action against 160 Iraqis with no connection to the Iraqi Embassy here and 12 other nationals, either deporting them or preventing them from re-entering the country.

headline: Rally Isn't Curing Wall St. Blues
abstract: After months of gloom, investors returned to buying stocks with a passion in the first months of 1991, sending the Dow Jones industrial average climbing at a giddy rate -- a rise of more than 500 points since mid-January. Investors, who had pulled back from the market as losses spread in 1990, are suddenly making money again.    So why is the joy so restrained on Wall Street?

headline: Fleeing Violence, Peruvians Fall Into Poverty
abstract: The Santa Rosa communal kitchen in Monte Negro, a poor Lima neighborhood occupied by people who have fled violence in the Peruvian highlands, is a hub of activity every day. Some 30 women, dressed in traditional Peruvian colors and carrying their infants on their backs, feed themselves, their families and the community's orphans.    The menu is limited: rice, a few carrots, peas, soy soup and bread.

headline: CRACKDOWN TALK EASED BY BEIJING
abstract: In the clearest sign so far of the Government's changing position on the army crackdown in June 1989, China's chief spokesman has said he hopes people will forget the matter.    "I don't much want to mention it -- that June 4 disturbance -- and I hope people gradually forget it," said the chief spokesman, Yuan Mu, in an interview with Chinese television broadcast on Sunday night.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Chevys, a chain of Mexican restaurants based in San Francisco, to Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein, San Francisco, with a budget of $3.6 million. * Idaho Potato Commission to the San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam, with a budget of approximately $3 million. * Sointal, a casino operator based in Algarve, Portugal, to Ayer Portugal, a subsidiary of Ayer Worldwide. Billings are estimated at $1 million.

headline: New Concerns Over U.S. Science
abstract: IN November 1944, with the end of World War II in sight, President Franklin D. Roosevelt wrote to Vannevar Bush, the distinguished engineer who headed the Office of Scientific Research and Development, to ask his advice on four fundamental questions:    *What could be done, consistent with military security, to make known to the world, as soon as possible, the contributions made during the war effort to science and technology? "The diffusion of such knowledge," Roosevelt said, "should help us stimulate new enterprises, provide jobs for our returning servicemen and other workers, and make possible great strides for the improvement of the national well-being."

headline: Sicilian Mafia Leader Freed on Technicality
abstract: Michele Greco, the white-haired "godfather" of the Sicilian Mafia jailed in 1987 for life for having ordered 78 murders, was released from prison today on a legal technicality.   Shading his eyes from the sun outside Palermo's maximum security prison, Mr. Greco had just one word to say to a throng of television crews and photographers: "Extraordinary."

headline: Acquisition Of Lincoln's Branches Set
abstract: The story of the troubled Lincoln Savings and Loan Association moved one step closer to completion today when the Great Western Financial Corporation said it had agreed to acquire Lincoln's 28 branches from the Federal Government.    Great Western said it would pay $12.1 million for the branches, all in Southern California, and their $1 billion in deposits. The price was at the low end of what savings institutions have been paying to acquire branches and deposits. Great Western, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., is the nation's second-largest savings and loan company.

headline: In East Africa, U.S. Cuts Diplomatic Presence
abstract: Across East Africa, the United States has moved to ward off terrorist attacks as a result of the Persian Gulf war. After incidents of violence and threats by Muslims sympathetic to Iraq, Washington has closed its embassy in the Sudan, evacuated officials in Tanzania and increased precautions in Uganda and Kenya.   In the Sudan, the American Ambassador, James R. Cheek, and remaining staff members at the embassy in Khartoum, about 50 people, were evacuated from the building hours before the first strikes against Iraq. The embassy building is now closed. Two American diplomats remain in the Sudanese capital and are working out of the British Embassy, which is heavily guarded by British soldiers flown in to provide extra protection.

headline: Real Estate; Unfinished, But Leased, In Cincinnati
abstract: A BURST of corporate expansion, coupled with a periodic reshuffling of tenants, has enabled a Houston developer to find tenants for almost all the space in a large office building months before its completion.  Construction of the 520,000-square-foot Chemed Center is to be finished in March. The developer, Gerald D. Hines Interests, has leased 98 percent of the building, at 255 Fifth Street.

headline: Mr. Hussein, Please Surrender
abstract: From the way the world's markets reacted last week, one would have thought that victory in Iraq had already been won. The Dow Jones industrial average gained more points than it ever had in a week, amid general rejoicing over early success in the air war.   The buying, which sent the Dow up 145.29 points, or 5.8 percent, to 2,646.78, reflects hopes for a lovely bullish scenario. That calls for a victory in Iraq to send the price of oil spiraling down, providing extra cash for newly confident consumers to spend. And that spending, in turn, makes the American recession short and relatively painless.

headline: What Investors Should Not Ignore
abstract: To the Editor:   William C. Crawford's contention ("Advice Every Investor Should Ignore," Feb. 10) that "every investor in the stock and bond markets is taking into account the same bad news," is true enough regarding national and world events. But your readers should not construe this to mean that all the information about any given stock is built into the stock's price. This may be true about the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, but it is not likely true about second-tier stocks and certainly not true about most small company stocks.   A small company may tell its story in a number of cities and yet not be written about in the national press, evaluated in print by an analyst, or placed on the buy list of a national borkerage firm. And then one day one of those events occurs, and the stock's price begins rising. Nothing has changed except suddenly the company has a following. The buyers bidding up the price of the stock are doing so on the same information that was available on a more limited basis. ROBERT A. DRESSER  Los Angeles, Feb. 13  The author is national president of the Los Angeles-based Stockbrokers Society.

headline: Market Place; A Rearrangement Of Damon Stock
abstract: THE Damon Corporation, an operator of clinical laboratories and one of the last leveraged buyouts financed by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., has done better than it was expected to when it was taken over in 1989. Sales are up, and while heavy debts have forced it to report losses, those losses are a bit less than expected.   Now it plans to restructure in a complicated transaction -- involving a subsidiary taking over its corporate parent -- in a way that will make it far easier for insiders to take out cash. The plan announced yesterday, if completed, would also create a larger public company that could attract investors seeking a pure play in the lab business.

headline: Big Cut in U.S. Deposits Hastened Fall of Freedom Bank in Harlem
abstract: While public funds were being used to shore up the Bank of New England, the Treasury Department sharply cut back similar deposits at the Freedom National Bank, thus hastening the collapse of the small minority-owned Manhattan institution.   According to former officials of Freedom National and bank documents, the Treasury in March suddenly curtailed its longstanding practice of keeping at Freedom as much as $300 million of income-tax withholding payments in what are known as "tax and loan" accounts.

headline: 2 RAIL TERMINALS IN CENTRAL LONDON HIT BY I.R.A. BOMBS
abstract: For the second time in 11 days, the Irish Republican Army struck in central London today, setting off two bombs in railroad stations, killing one man and wounding 40.   One bomb, hidden in a trash can, sprayed glass and shrapnel across the concourse of Victoria Station at 7:40 A.M. when it was crowded with commuters on their way into the city from London's southern suburbs. Three hours earlier, a bomb exploded in Paddington Station, north of Hyde Park, damaging the building's roof but causing no casualties.

headline: Contract for Lockheed
abstract: The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, a division of the Lockheed Corporation, has been awarded a $757 million contract by the Defense Department for work on the Trident missile program, the Navy said on Thursday. The contract is for work and services to be performed at Sunnyvale, Calif., and at the Kings Bay, Ga., submarine base. The work is expected to be completed in 1994.

headline: India's Government Quits and Calls for New Elections
abstract: Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar's Government resigned today and recommended new general elections as India's political parties braced themselves for a second nationwide ballot in less than two years.   His decision to quit followed a boycott of Parliament by the Congress Party after its leader, former Prime Minister Rajiv Ganndhi accused the Government of "political espionage" because police had conducted surveillance of his home.

headline: Savings Bailout Gets Overseer
abstract: An experienced Pentagon investigator started work today as the top overseer of contractors for the Government's savings and loan industry bailout.   Howard W. Cox, who is 41 years old, will direct the contractor oversight and surveillance office of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which was created by Congress in August 1989 to handle the cleanup.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: Chemical Arms; Export Curbs on Allies: Baker's Hard Choice
abstract: As he prepares for a postwar visit to the Middle East, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d faces a sensitive decision on whether to include Israel and Egypt on a chemical arms watch list.    The proposed list is to include countries subject to special controls when they seek to acquire American products that could be used in developing chemical or biological arms.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; Air Assault Fails to Wipe Out All Mobile Missiles
abstract: Allied warplanes mounted a huge effort to destroy Iraq's mobile missile launchers on Friday and again this morning, but apparently failed to wipe them all out.   Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the American commander in the Persian Gulf, said Air Force planes had found and demolished three launchers loaded with missiles aimed at Saudi Arabia, had knocked out three empty launchers at the same site and were continuing to attack five other empty launchers.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   8.75-9   8.75-9   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   6.10   6.20   8.25        3-MO. headline: U.S. Seeks Ways to Delay Summit Parley in Moscow
abstract: The White House instructed the State Department today to explore a suitable way of postponing the February summit talks in Moscow, primarily because President Bush does not want to be in the Soviet Union if there is a war in the Persian Gulf, officials said.   Although he is eager to support President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Mr. Bush also is concerned about the possibility of a crackdown in the Soviet Union and does not want to become embroiled in Soviet domestic politics if the situation there worsens, the officials said.

headline: AFTER THE WAR: The West Bank; Palestinians Still Revere Hussein As Their Savior
abstract: As most of the world watched the Iraqi Army stumble in defeat, Palestinians continue to cling stubbornly to a different image of Saddam Hussein than the one being projected almost everywhere else.    According to West Bank popular opinion, the Iraqi President is even now shrouded in glory -- a powerful, clever Arab leader who defied the West until he chose to withdraw his army from Kuwait, intact and able to fight for them on another day.

headline: Compaq Said To Discuss Silicon Link
abstract: The Compaq Computer Corporation has approached Silicon Graphics Inc., a leading maker of computer work stations, to discuss a possible merger, sources close to the two companies said today. Such a merger would unite two of the fastest-growing companies in different sectors of desktop computing and give Compaq an instant entry in the hotly contested work station market.    A link with Silicon Graphics would also transform Compaq from a maker of high-quality clones of the International Business Machines Corporation's personal computers into a technology powerhouse. The combined company would present a formidable challenge to Sun Microsystems Inc., which has taken the lead in work stations from older companies like the Digital Equipment Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company. The market for work stations, which are basically desktop computers with about three times the power, has grown rapidly in the last few years.

headline: Lebanese President Warns P.L.O. to Halt Rocket Attacks on Israel
abstract: President Elias Hrawi warned Palestinian guerrillas this weekend that they would no longer be allowed to mount attacks on Israel from Lebanese territory.   "As of today we will not tolerate the use of Katyusha rockets to provoke an invasion of this country," Mr. Hrawi said in an address on Saturday to southern Lebanese villagers. He asserted that Palestinian gunmen were at the root of the violence that has plagued southern Lebanon.

headline: U.S. Issues Rise on Jobless Data
abstract: After a big rise in initial unemployment claims was reported, prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday and interest rates fell further.    At 515,000, initial unemployment claims in the week before Christmas were at their highest level in almost eight years.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                  Jan. 25   Jan. 18   Jan. 26        1991   1991   1990        Gasoline production, daily   6.7   6.5   7.0        Distillate production, daily   2.8   2.8   3.1        Gasoline stocks   220.9   217.7   226.8        Distillate stocks   115.4   119.0   116.5        Crude imports, daily   5.4   4.9   6.2        Product imports, daily   1.8   1.3   2.8        Crude stocks   324.4   321.3   343.4        Crude production, daily   7.4   7.4   7.5        Refinery utilization (%)   82.3   81.6   88.8       (Source: American Petroleum Institute)

headline: ALLIED UNITS SURGE THROUGH KUWAIT; TROOPS CONFRONT ELITE FORCE IN IRAQ; BUSH SPURNS HUSSEIN'S PULLOUT MOVE SURRENDER DEMAND
abstract: President Saddam Hussein today made the public commitment to withdraw from Kuwait that President Bush demanded. But Mr. Bush said the promise was inadequate, pressed for virtual surrender and ordered allied forces to continue attacking to break the Iraqi's "power and control in the Middle East."    Mr. Hussein said in a radio address today that his troops were withdrawing from Kuwait and would be gone by the end of the day. But he tried to portray the retreat as a victory. He also left unclear whether he was renouncing his claim on the country he invaded last Aug. 2, and he did not mention Mr. Bush's other conditions, including acceptance of all 12 United Nations resolutions on Kuwait.  'Remnants of Power'     "He is trying to save the remnants of power and control in the Middle East by every means possible and here, too, Saddam Hussein will fail," Mr. Bush said in a three-minute statement from the Rose Garden.  [ The text of Mr. Hussein's address and a transcript of Mr. Bush's response are on page A20. ]

headline: Developers Shrug Off Rate Cut
abstract: The latest steps to reduce interest rates -- the Federal Reserve's half-point cut in the discount rate on Friday and a similar cut in the prime rate used by banks -- are no more likely to provide relief to developers and investors in the beleaguered commercial real estate market than other interest rate cuts in the last six months, developers and financiers say.    These people say the risks of investing in the overbuilt real estate market still overshadow the lower rates. After the Fed cut the discount rate, the rate it charges on loans to commercial banks, most banks cut the prime lending rate to 9 percent from 9.5 percent.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Press; Process of News Reporting on Display
abstract: The conflicting Pentagon and Iraqi versions of the bombing of what may or may not have been a bomb shelter in Baghdad placed the messy process of news reporting on unusual display Wednesday as reporters struggled to separate propaganda from fact.   Editors at some of the country's major news organizations said yesterday that they were satisfied that they had been balanced in their presentation of the situation. Most reports allowed both sides to give their very different accounts of what had happened, and most news organizations pointed out that the Iraqis were not available to be questioned or challenged by independent reporting.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: U.S. Statements; Transcripts of Statements by Bush and Fitzwater on Unconditional Pullout
abstract: Following are transcripts of the statement made this morning by President Bush on the Persian Gulf, and a statement later by his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, as provided by News Transcripts Inc.:  BUSH'S STATEMENT     Good morning. The United States and its coalition allies are committed to enforcing the United Nations resolutions that call for Saddam Hussein to immediately and unconditionally leave Kuwait.

headline: Air France Cancels Some Cutbacks
abstract: Air France rescinded part of an emergency plan to reduce wages and working hours by 6 percent, citing a rebound in passenger traffic since the end of the gulf war. Air France said it would resume previously canceled spring and summer flight programs and add new flights to some destinations.   The cost cuts were adopted last month. Other cutbacks will remain in effect, the airline said, including a salary freeze, an early retirement program, non-renewal of long-term supply contracts and limited new hiring.

headline: Chief Executive Quits At Ailing Child World
abstract: Child World Inc., the struggling No. 2 toy chain, said yesterday that its president and chief executive, Peter J. Hayes, had resigned.    Mr. Hayes, 47, is taking a position at another company, which was not identified, and will be leaving shortly, Child World said.   Mr. Hayes said yesterday that his new company did not want the announcement of his appointment to be made yet, although he expected to be able to discuss it in about two weeks.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Poll; Americans Back Continued Air Strikes
abstract: While resigned that ground combat against Iraq will probably be necessary, the American public overwhelmingly prefers that bombing from the air continue for the next few weeks. That preference did not appear to change much as a result of the storm this week over the Iraqi civilians killed in a Baghdad building hit by allied bombs, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.   But there were strong indications in the poll that a bloody ground war would significantly reduce public support for the Persian Gulf conflict. While many Americans remain apprehensive about the eventual cost of the war, especially if a ground attack begins, at this time they are putting their reservations aside to rally around the flag, the troops and the Commander in Chief.

headline: Response to Chile Human Rights Report Is Violent
abstract: This country is being rocked by terrorist attacks after the release of a report detailing human rights abuses under the former military dictatorship.    In the last week, three police stations in Santiago have been bombed and six banks robbed by groups who say they are leftist extremists acting in reprisal for abuses by the former Government. On March 15, gunmen shot and killed Concepcion's chief investigator, Hector Sarmiento Hidalgo.

headline: Grey Awarded Dannon Yogurt
abstract: The Dannon Company, the yogurt manufacturer based in White Plains, has awarded its $10 million advertising account to Grey Advertising Inc., New York.   In a review that began early last month, Grey beat out TBWA Inc., Ogilvy & Mather and Wells, Rich, Greene, said Frank Palantoni, vice president of marketing at Dannon. The incumbent agency, Lord, Dentsu & Partners, formerly known as HDM Worldwide, was not included in the search.

headline: War's Cessation Buoys the Dollar
abstract: Last   Prior   Year       Week   Week   Ago              Japanese Yen   134.70   132.15   150.25       per Dollar       German Mark   1.5395   1.5060   1.7177       per Dollar       Canadian Dollar   1.1523   1.1523   1.1924       per U.S. Dollar       British Pound   1.8955   1.9440   1.6480       U.S. Dollar per British Pound       Gold   $366.50   $356.75   $403.25       Republic National Bank       Currency: Friday NY Close

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Alco Standard Corp., Wayne, Pa., a paper concern, said it would acquire the office products companies of Hillman Co. Pittsburgh, for an undisclosed amount of Alco common stock. * Ashton-Tate Corp., Torrance, Calif., agreed in principle to settle the stockholder class-action lawsuits filed against it and certain of its directors and officers between June and August 1989 and a derivative suit filed in January 1990.

headline: Bank of New York Prices Certificates
abstract: The Bank of New York priced $750 million in credit card certificates yesterday through a group of underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.   The certificates, which have an average life of 3.07 years, are being issued through a BNY Master Credit Card Trust with a 7.95 percent coupon at a price of 99 21/32, to yield 8.214 percent, or about 95 basis points more than three-year Treasury notes. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: Article 991191 -- No Title
abstract: A $400 million issue of zero-coupon subordinated notes due in 1988 being sold by J.P. Morgan & Company was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Inc.   The noncallable notes make no periodic interest payments but yield 8.40 percent if they are held until maturity. They were initially priced at $560.86 for each $1,000 of bonds and will be reoffered at various prices. At the initial pricing, the spread over Treasury securities with a similar maturity was 50 basis points. A bases point is one-hundredth of a percent age point.

headline: Baltic Assaults Lead Europeans To Hold Off Aid
abstract: In the strongest Western response to date, the European Parliament blocked a $1 billion European Community food-aid package for the Soviet Union today to protest the crackdown by Moscow against pro-independence groups in the Baltic republics.   The 12-nation community, which on Monday night suspended a high-level meeting with Soviet trade officials scheduled for later this week, also announced that it would slow execution of a $550 million technical assistance agreement with Moscow after the latest violence in Latvia.

headline: War Summary
abstract: U.S. REVIEWS ITS METHODS    American military officials in Riyadh and Washington said they were studying ways to avoid bombing civilians in the pursuit of military targets. The announcement came as the outcry continued over the deaths of Iraqi civilians in the bombing of what the Americans had identified as a major military command post in Baghdad. The Iraqis say the building was a civilian bomb shelter. Allied military officials said theywere considering dropping leaflets before air raids urging that civilians avoid target areas. As mourners marched through Baghdad, Iraqi officials said that 288 bodies had been recovered so far from the building, including the corpses of 91 children. Reporters touring the installation in Baghdad said they saw no signs of military of communications equipment. 1,300 IRAQI TANKS DESTROYED    American officials are reporting increased success in destroying of Iraq's main ground weapons in Kuwait. Officials said 1,300, or almost a third of the 4,280 tanks, Baghdad had prepared for deployment in the war, had been demolished. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES    Troops: The loss of two pilots in a plane crash brought the toll of American casualties to 62, including 14 killed, 12 wounded, 28 missing and 8 taken prisoner or war, the Pentagon said at its briefing yesterday.    Aircraft: United States official reported the crash of the EF-111A Raven electronic jamming plan in northern Saudi Arabia. An investigation is under way, but preliminary reports indicated that the incident will be classified as a combat loss because the plane appears to have been hit over Iraq or Kuwait. The U.S. Central Command in Riyadh said the crash brought to 27 the number of allied aircraft destroyed, 19 from the U.S. and 8 from other countries in the coalition. IRAQI FORCES    Troops: No precise new casualty figures for the military were reported. There are more than 1,100 prisoners of war in Saudi hands and 122 in American custody, the U.S. command said. It said 24 Iraqis surrendered in the last 24 hours.    Aircraft: The U.S. Central Command said Iraqi aircraft losses held steady at 40.Another 138 Iraqi planes are being held in Iran. No involvement in air combat was reported in the last 24 hours.

headline: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: Washington; Bush Appeals to Kremlin Leaders To Refrain From Force in Baltics
abstract: President Bush said today that he was increasingly concerned about violent repression of nationalist independence movements in the Baltic republics by the Soviet authorities.    "I would again appeal to the Soviet Union leaders to resist using force," Mr. Bush said at an impromptu meeting with reporters on his return from a weekend at Camp David to the White House. He was referring to reports of killings on Sunday in Riga, the Latvian capital, by elite troops from a Soviet Interior Ministry unit.

headline: People
abstract: * Valentine Zammit has been named chief financial officer of Bozell Inc., New York. * TBWA Advertising Inc. has named three executive vice presidents: Grant Castle, Patricia Cameron and Geoff Hayes.

headline: Many Print Ads Revive 'A Bare and Open Look'
abstract: Wide open spaces are returning to American print advertising and publication design.   In newspaper and magazine advertisements for Toyota cars, Royal Viking cruise ships and Aspen, Colo., the gaps between letters, words and lines are growing wider. The mixing of disparate typefaces, which reached a peak in Entertainment Weekly and Spy magazines, is declining. Borders are reappearing around photographs and text that once bled to the edge of advertisements. And the "clutter" and "typographic frenzy" that Print magazine criticized in regional ads and magazines last year are settling down into a plain, no-frills look.

headline: Yield Independence Claim or Face Worse Strife, Lithuanians Warned
abstract: After an overnight truce that raised fleeting hopes of compromise, the suppression of Lithuania's independence government continued today with the capture of the Parliament's last radio outlet and a threat of more bloodshed if the government did not quickly capitulate.    A spokesman for the National Salvation Committee, a front group created by the Communist Party and backed by Soviet troops, said that if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev did not disband the elected Lithuanian government and introduce direct Kremlin rule, the violence would continue and spread to other republics.

headline: Teaching Children to Manage Money
abstract: To the Editor:   "Teaching the Kids About Money," (Jan. 6) brought to light an important aspect of child-rearing and education.   Most child development specialists would agree that children should be encouraged to learn about money and to participate in financial decisions, even at a young age. Money management is akin to self discipline, which is, after all, one of our main parenting objectives.   In this connection, it is vital to realize that a child's judgment will not always be the same as yours. If they opt to buy something which you deem foolish, it is your responsibility to explain your point of view. After that, they should be permitted to make the purchase and live with the consequences. If you do otherwise, you interfere with your objective.   Likewise, if a child immediately spends an entire allowance or earnings and has nothing left for the rest of the week, you may choose to be benevolent the first time. On another occasion, you might even extend a loan which should be repaid. Thereafter, the child must learn the lesson the hard way.   Finally, it is easy for money to assume emotional overtones. Parents should avoid using money as a power base or as a substitute for love. LAWRENCE BALTER, Ph.D. New York, Jan. 6  The writer teaches applied psychology at New York University and is the psychology reporter for WABC-TV.

headline: Ethics: It's Mutual, Not Dual
abstract: To the Editor:   In his Forum article ("The Indivisibility of Ethics," March 3) Robert J. Myers argues in support of Peter Drucker's view that "There is only one ethics, one set of rules or morality, one code." He emphasizes that in business, no less than any place else, "the locus of responsibility remains with the individual." That view ignores the role of organizational cultures and their norms.   Executives, chief executives and boards of directors are responsible for the cultures of their organizations. If they fail to lead in making their cultures ethical, they are responsible for the unethical behavior of their organizations' members. Paradoxically, that does not make individuals any less responsible.    Mr. Myers apparently does not recognize that paradox. He quotes a Conference Board report saying , which says, "Unless ethical considerations are a part of every manager's thought process, both the corporation and individual executives will fail to exercise the level of responsibility which good business represents and law demands." He asserts that holding "both the corporation and individual executives" responsible opens up "a dual standard of ethics."   Focusing on both individual and organizational standards does not necessarily open up a dual standard. Ideally the standard of organizations and their members, as well as industries and societies, are mutually reinforcing, not dual.   Executives can encourage mutuality by involving people in creating organizational codes. Involvement increases the likelihood that people will in fact live by the code. And thinking about how that code applies to specific ethical dilemmas can increase people's ability to make ethical decisions.    In my opinion, Mr. Myers' concern about shifting attention away from individual responsibility is being dealt with by those executives whose focus is on encouraging integrity, both personal and organizational. That can contribute to creating ethical individuials and organizations. Granted that is an ideal, but it's worth striving for. WILLIAM GELLERMANN New York, N.Y., March 3

headline: LTV Names New Chief
abstract: The LTV Corporation, the Dallas-based steel and aerospace company that began 1991 in its fifth year of Chapter 11 bankruptcy, yesterday named David H. Hoag its president and chief executive.    Mr. Hoag, who is 51 years old, is the company's top steel executive. He succeeds Raymond A. Hay, 62, who has led the company for the last eight years and who remains its chairman.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; RAIDS SAID TO CUT POWER IN BAGHDAD
abstract: Sketchy reports from Western news agencies and television correspondents suggest that the Iraqi capital has lost its electricity and telephone service and is suffering a severe shortage of water.    A third day of bombardment and the wail of air raid sirens have reportedly sent thousands more civilians fleeing for the countryside and other Iraqi cities.
