headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Allies and Adversaries; Bush Gets Europe's Support While Jordan Is Optimistic
abstract: Leading European countries today gave full backing to Washington's ultimatum to President Saddam Hussein on an immediate withdrawal of his troops from Kuwait.   In a statement issued by the Western European Union, a regional group, the nine governments welcomed Soviet efforts to end the Persian Gulf war as "a step in the right direction," but they rejected Iraq's attempt to attach conditions to its offer to leave Kuwait.

headline: Many Competing Bills Chase the Energy Problem
abstract: Lawmakers have responded to the Bush Administration's national energy strategy with a flurry of competing proposals to raise gasoline taxes, improve automobile mileage, raise energy efficiency in businesses and homes, open sensitive regions to oil exploration, and spend hundreds of millions of dollars for research on conservation and renewable sources of energy.   At last count, the House Energy and Commerce Committee was reviewing 68 proposals for revamping Federal energy policy, and, in the Senate, four main bills and more than a dozen others have been introduced.

headline: Globex Debut Is Set
abstract: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade will begin their long-delayed Globex electronic trading system around the middle of this year, Merc officials said on Tuesday. Globex is envisioned as a worldwide computerized system for trading financial futures and options products of various international exchanges during the hours that their trading floors are closed. Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the third partner in the venture, is supplying the computer terminals and technology. The Merc first announced plans for Globex in September 1987 and hoped at that time to have it in operation by the spring of 1989.

headline: All the Fashion Rage in the Desert: The Coveted Olive Green Parka
abstract: The most chic article of war garb is definitely the parka. The nylon-lined, waterproof cross between a safari jacket and a poncho is the hottest item being distributed to soldiers here in the northeastern Saudi desert, and for those in the first "combat pools" of reporters who will follow them in case of war.   The much-coveted speckled, olive green parka belts at the waist, swoops down in the back with a slip that can be tied at knee length, and in the front, at mid-thigh level. The most sartorially splendid here predict that knock-offs at army-navy and Banana Republic stores across America can only be a month or two away.

headline: Bangladesh's Lack of Oil Is Felt in the Fields
abstract: The old man with the flowing white beard sat on the veranda of his thatched home and looked across scores of acres of parched, cracked earth. In normal times, he said, the fields would be filled with wheat and the air would be filled with the hum of irrigation pumps drawing water and flushing it across the land.   This year, because of an oil shortage that was heightened by the Persian Gulf war, diesel has been difficult to get and many diesel-fed irrigation pumps in this and neighboring villages, about 90 miles north of the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka, are silent. At Dhaka, there are long lines of vehicles at gasoline stations.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; U.S. TROOPS CLASH WITH IRAQI FORCES ON SAUDI FRONTIER
abstract: As the Iraqi Foreign Minister traveled to Moscow for talks aimed at avoiding a costly land war in the Persian Gulf, American troops fought a series of sharp skirmishes today with Iraqi forces on Saudi Arabia's northern borders.   The Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, arrived in Moscow for a meeting on Monday with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in which Moscow hopes to discern whether Iraq's conditional offer on Friday of a withdrawal from Kuwait represented an opening bid to end the war.  [ Page 7. ]

headline: British Free 6 Jailed in '74 I.R.A. Blasts
abstract: Six men from Northern Ireland jailed since November 1974 for the Irish Republican Army bombings of two Birmingham pubs were freed today by the Court of Appeal, after prosecutors admitted that their confessions and police evidence against them were discredited.   The defendants, known as the Birmingham Six, who had insisted on their innocence all along, walked out of the Old Bailey, or Central Criminal Court, this afternoon waving clenched fists, to cheers from supporters outside, some of whom had campaigned for years for their release.

headline: Syndication Gain Is Seen For Networks
abstract: In a setback for Hollywood studios and producers, the White House today signaled its support for proposals to end restrictions that prohibit television networks from syndicating the programs they broadcast.   In a letter responding to questions from a member of Congress, the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, clarified the Administration's position and strongly backed the idea that the 20-year-old rules should be repealed.

headline: Bond Prices Move Slightly Higher
abstract: The early success of the allied ground offensive into Kuwait and southern Iraq was almost completely ignored in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury issues moved marginally higher and interest rates fell slightly in light trading.    Indeed, market participants said that distributing the huge amount of securities sold over the last few weeks was a much bigger problem for dealers than sorting out the unfolding of the war.

headline: Economic Scene; No Accounting For Bad Banks
abstract: WHICH banks should be counted as the walking dead, doomed to follow the Bank of New England into Federal receivership? Regulators are not telling -- and could not, even if they were so inclined. For the accounting methods currently used by banks, argues Lawrence White, an economist at New York University's business school, offer only the haziest clues to their net worth.    Mr. White should know: As one of three members of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, he watched with chagrin as the savings and loan cowboys ran out of excuses in the late 1980's and left Uncle Sam to pay the bill. His book, "The S & L Scandal," to be published next month by Oxford University Press, reflects on what went wrong and what could be done to prevent a repeat performance.

headline: Magazine Revenues Up, But Ad Pages Decrease
abstract: Total magazine advertising revenues in December 1990 were up nearly 6 percent from December 1989, the Publishers Information Bureau reports. But the number of advertising pages was down nearly 2 percent.   For all of 1990, advertising revenues were up nearly 2 percent, while pages were down almost 4 percent.   A reason for the disparity between the rising revenues and the falling number of pages was that many magazines raised their ad rates last year.    Still, "the year was as disappointing for magazines as it was for advertising in general," said James Guthrie, executive vice president of Magazine Publishers of America. "In the 20 years, there have been six similiar soft periods of declines in ad pages."

headline: Lithuanian Premier Resigns Over Policy
abstract: The Prime Minister of Lithuania and her Cabinet resigned tonight in a dispute with the republic's Parliament over economic and political policy.    The abrupt move by Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene created a further sense of instability in the Baltic region a day after the Defense Ministry announced that it would deploy troops to Lithuania and to other restive republics in an effort to force compliance with the military draft.

headline: Health Funds Led the Way Last Year
abstract: The winning mutual funds in 1990 either put their money in health stocks or sent it abroad, to be invested in foreign bonds. The losers held a wide variety of investments, including "junk bonds" and shares in small gold-mining companies.    The best-performing fund, by the rating of Lipper Analytical Services, was the Fidelity Select Biotechnology Fund, a so-called sector fund that invests in only one industry. Biotechnology stocks were market leaders in the year, and the fund wound up 1990 with a gain of 44.38 percent.

headline: RJR Plans Stock Sale To Cut Debt
abstract: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, the consumer-products giant that emerged from history's largest leveraged buyout, said yesterday that it planned to sell 75 million shares, increasing the company's publicly held portion to as much as 22.8 percent, from 17.1 percent.    The company also said it planned to sell $750 million in a new issue of senior debt for the RJR Nabisco Capital Corporation, a unit that issues debt.

headline: Slim Chance Is Seen for Burmese Democracy
abstract: Nearly a year after the military Government in Myanmar, formerly Burma, was repudiated in free elections, the prospect of any transfer of power to elected civilian authorities has grown increasingly remote, Western diplomats say.    "It is quite clear that the military regime will not transfer power in the foreseeable future to any form of representative civilian government," said an analyst who lives in the Burmese capital and who spoke here today. The military has a deep distrust, he said, "for anyone remotely resembling a politician."

headline: Coke-Sony Promotion
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company and the Sony Corporation announced yesterday that they planned to give away 5.6 million miniature compact audio disks with 6-packs and 12-packs of Coca-Cola beverages.    Coke declined to say how large an advertising and promotion budget it had set for this year's promotion, scheduled to begin in May, but it is expected to total in the tens of millions of dollars.

headline: Continental Air
abstract: Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. is in talks with a Houston business group to help it raise capital from local investors, an airline spokesman said. The airline, which is operating under chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code, is trying to raise $550 million for expansion. The spokesman, who said the discussions were "exploratory and very preliminary," said Hollis L. Harris, Continental's chairman, had met with members of the Greater Houston Partnership, Houston's largest business group, to discuss local investment in the airline, which is based in Houston.

headline: Slight Profit at Turner
abstract: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. today reported a small profit for the fourth quarter of last year, as well as its first annual profit since 1985. For the quarter that ended on Dec. 31, TBS had earnings of $7.3 million, compared with a $110.9 million loss in the comparable 1989 period. Revenues totaled $356.5 million, up 21.7 percent from $292.8 million. For the year, Turner reported a profit of $4.6 million, compared with a loss of $70.7 million in 1989. Revenues rose 31 percent, to $1.39 billion from $1.06 billion.

headline: Hopes Rise for Spending Rebound as End of War Is Seen
abstract: WITH the end of the Middle East war in sight, once-pessimistic agency executives are almost giddy, anticipating a healthy surge in advertising spending.    "This gives us a big psychological boost," said Edward Meyer, the chairman and president of Grey Advertising.

headline: OPEC Output Rose in '90
abstract: Oil production by OPEC kept rising in December, and the group's output for 1990 was the highest in 10 years, despite the global boycott of oil from Iraq and Kuwait, according to a survey released today.    Led by Saudi Arabia and Iran, several OPEC members increased production significantly in recent months to offset the daily loss of about four million barrels of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude embargoed during the Persian Gulf crisis, the Middle East Economic Survey said.   The survey, published weekly in Cyprus by independent economic researchers, said Iraq's production for the year was down 27 percent from 1989. It fell from 1.75 million barrels a day before the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 to 450,000 barrels a day afterward, used only for local consumption, the survey said.   Crude output by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in December was estimated at 23.86 million barrels a day, up 230,000 barrels from November.

headline: Outcry Over Jews' Move to Germany
abstract: The recent migration of thousands of Soviet Jews to Germany has set off an impassioned response among many Jews, especially those who survived the horrors of the Nazi era.    On the one hand are those who say that, even after 50 years, the memory of the atrocities against Jews is too raw to rebuild the once-flourishing German Jewish population. On the other hand are those who say that the emigres, whatever their decision, should have the freedom to settle where they want.

headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Overview; IRAQIS FIRE MISSILES AT ISRAELI CITIES AFTER SECOND DAY OF ALLIED BOMBING; U.S. DISCOURAGES AN ISRAELI RESPONSE
abstract: After a day of allied successes in the war against Iraq, Baghdad struck back today with missile attacks on Israel and Saudi Arabia.    Preliminary reports indicated that seven Iraqi missiles hit Israel, and there were reports of injuries but no deaths. The missiles did not appear to be armed with chemical warheads.

headline: EUROPEANS CONFER ON EMIGRE LIMITS
abstract: Once they get the freedom to travel, 1.5 million to 2 million Soviet citizens are likely to leave home looking for work in the West, a Soviet official told representatives from the Council of Europe this week at a conference on policies on migrants and refugees.    That figure is far below some of the alarmist estimates offered recently as Western Europe contemplates the possibility of a tide of immigrants from a collapsing Soviet Union and its former satellites in Eastern Europe.
